HEADLINE: Who Needs a Will? Just About Everyone

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Mark C. Kruse, a 34-year-old vice president of Mercantile Mortgage Bankers in Rye, N.Y., and his 32-year-old wife, Lynn, had no wills. But with two children and a third on the way, they decided it was time to put their wishes in writing and are consulting an estate lawyer.
"I've got my insurance policies in place, my net worth is starting to grow and this is the next step," he said. "I'd feel more comfortable in case anything happens to me and it makes my wife more comfortable." 
 Like Mr. Kruse, millions of Americans do not have wills. In fact, estimates are that over 60 percent of American adults die without a will. Yet experts say that almost everyone -- rich or poor, young or old, working spouse or nonworking spouse -- should have an unambiguous will.
And with a slew of changes in the estate tax laws pending, more people are talking about wills these days. That's because both the Clinton Administration and Congress are considering ways to change the $600,000 amount exempt from Federal estate tax -- with some proposals to lower that amount and others to increase it.
"Dying intestate -- without a will -- is a fate worse than death," said Conrad Teitell, an estate lawyer in White Plains. "If you have property, you need a will if you want to distribute it according to your own wishes."
The role of a last will and testament is to transfer ownership of assets from a testator -- the person who writes the will -- to beneficiaries. Although each state has different laws governing various aspects of a will, the basic reason for spending the time and money to draw it up is the same everywhere: only with a will can you decide, sometimes within limits, who gets your assets.
While a formal will may frequently contain elements that are not found in any other -- "no will has a brother," estate lawyers say -- it can be as simple or as detailed as you want it to be. It should, however, indicate who is to get what legacies, state how remaining assets will be disposed of and establish the process for carrying out your instructions by naming an executor and a guardian for minor children. Of course, you should appoint someone who has already agreed to serve in those roles.
"If you die without a will, an administrator will be appointed by the court," said Ralph M. Engel, a partner in the New York law firm of Rosen & Reade. "You don't get to pick him. And generally that person will have to post a bond."
Frequently a trust, known as a testamentary trust, is included in a will. The commission schedule for trustees named in a will is set by law, ranging from 1.05 percent a year on the first $400,000 to three-tenths of 1 percent a year on amounts over $1 million.
Along with a general reluctance of people to write wills are a number of common misconceptions about them. For example, not everything owned by an individual can be bequeathed to someone else through a will.
"You may have assets in joint name or with designated beneficiaries that are not governed by a will," said John M. McFaul, a lawyer in Mineola, L.I. "That includes jointly owned bank accounts, life insurance policies and retirement plan accounts."
Another widely held misconception, according to Jerome M. Leitner, a professor at Brooklyn Law School, is that you can disinherit a spouse in a will. "But most states provide minimum shares of the estate for surviving spouses, usually one-third or one-half," he said.
Any amount that you leave to a spouse is exempt from Federal estate tax under the so-called marital deduction, but when the surviving spouse dies, estates become subject to this tax beginning at $600,000.
The estate tax rate currently starts at 37 percent and goes up to 50 percent, although the Clinton tax plan calls for increasing the top rate to 55 percent. Many states also impose their own death taxes on estates.
Furthermore, some people do not think about the age of the person named as executor in relation to their own age. "There's no point in an 80-year-old man being an executor for a 30-year-old person," said Maurice S. Spanbock, a partner of Carro, Spanbock, Kaster & Cuiffo, a New York law firm.
Mr. Kruse, the mortgage banker, was made aware of some of these misconceptions when he and his wife met with Mr. McFaul this week. For example, while each spouse named the other as executor, they both appointed his brother as alternative executor in their wills.
"I'm relieved that this is all set," Mr. Krause said. "And I'll be even more relieved on Thursday when we sign the wills."
Standard will forms and computer software for writing a will can be bought inexpensively in a store and completed without using a lawyer. Yet a lawyer's fee is often recouped in the form of advice dispensed or taxes later saved. Fees vary widely from less than $100 for a simple will prepared by a lawyer in a rural area to as much as $10,000 or more for a complex document in a big city.
Once a will has been written, it should be executed by the creator by signing the document in the presence of either two or three witnesses who have no interest in the will. In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, only two witnesses are required.
A will can be changed or revoked at any time. It ought to be reviewed, though, at least every three to five years, when you move to another state or whenever there are major changes in family or overall economic conditions. If appropriate -- and you are legally competent -- you can then write a new will or a codicil modifying your existing will.
It is not a good idea to keep a will in your safe deposit box because the box may be sealed at your death and require court approval to be opened. Leave it in your lawyer's custody and keep a copy at home.

GRAPHIC: Photos: John M. McFaul, left, an estate lawyer with his clients, Mark and Lynn Kruse, and their daughter, Katie. The Kruses are having wills prepared. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A 19th Century Balkan Solution

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis; Flora Lewis is Senior Columnist of The New York Times.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
None of the attempts to stop the outrage in the former Yugoslavia have even begun to answer the question, then what? There is no real incentive to end the fighting. Threats have been viewed as empty, while the demands to lift the arms embargo on Bosnia would guarantee escalation and probably the spread of war.
There are no defensive weapons in this war. They are all used to seize territory and wreak vengeance. If a truce were reached in Bosnia, massacres would almost surely begin in Kosovo, just as violence erupted in Bosnia as soon as Croatia achieved a tentative calm. 
 The menace of war spreading through the Balkans, perhaps further, continues to mount. The idea that it can somehow be contained while traditional enemies fight to exhaustion is an illusion and a cop-out.
All the proposals to separate combatants, from the Vance-Owen plan to drastic and inhumane suggestions for a huge exchange of populations, would only advance Balkanization, the region's historic handicap. The need is to induce de-Balkanization.
This requires a broad regional context. The one thing everybody in the area agrees upon is the desire to emerge from the backwardness, isolation and underdevelopment that have been their traditional lot and to move toward the European mainstream. Now they are attempting it as rivals, shoving to the head of the line.
All Balkan economies are being hurt by the war. None will attract investment and flourish until there is confidence in security and stability. This can only be achieved by a comprehensive approach, and the initiative must come from outside.
Therefore, it is urgent and propitious to call a grand 19th century style conference, like the 1878 Congress of Berlin, which headed off a Great Power war over the region, to establish a Balkan security regime. The convoking powers must be the U.S., Russia and Europe. Countries to be invited would include the states of former Yugoslavia, Albania, Greece, Turkey, Bulgaria, Romania and probably Hungary. They should be offered either one big security treaty guaranteeing borders and protection of minorities or a web of bilateral defense treaties, in either case to be guaranteed by the sponsoring powers.
Each of these countries has its own ambitions and fears. Disputes are so tightly interwoven that it is futile to try to separate them and deal with each one piecemeal, one step at a time, as current efforts seek to do. A regional system can offer peace and security for all as the reward for concessions and renouncing old aspirations.
There also needs to be an economic development plan, not necessarily detailed but credible as a long-term follow-through to be undertaken in several stages. It must focus on regional development of use to all, not country-by-country projects. This means primarily transportation, communications, energy, a base for tourism.
Past proposals for a Balkan confederation failed, foundering on shifting local alliances and conflicting interests of outside powers. Now, for the first time, the outside powers are not enemies and share a common interest: peace and security in the region.
Russian participation is essential. It would help support Boris Yeltsin's pro-Western policy and reform program and deprive his opponents of the Serbian pretext to mobilize ardent nationalists and nostalgic militarists.
This is not a proposal for a confederation: feelings run too high for that. As the European Community's experience has shown, cooperation doesn't diminish national responsibility and ethnic identity. It makes existing borders acceptable because they lose importance. Little steps have failed, and the prospects are for ever more murderous failures. It is time to think big and boldly -- and it is possible.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Primer on Health-Care Idea: 'Managed Competition' Plan

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
Just another proposal little more than a year ago, the "managed competition" strategy for revamping health care has since been endorsed by many health experts as an ingenious American-style answer to runaway costs.
More important, the approach, which seeks to prune waste with a combination of market forces and Government oversight, has been embraced by President Clinton as he develops proposals for national reform. 
 But now critics are emerging from left, right and center to question everything from the morality to the practicality of the approach. Defenders think they have solid answers. Still, the attacks presage a stormy reception for Mr. Clinton's plan, which is to be unveiled this spring.
 
2 Views of Concept
 If it works the way proponents say, the strategy could make Americans happier, healthier and richer.
"Everyone would have health insurance and you could move from place to place without worrying," said Dr. Paul M. Ellwood, a doctor and health economist who is a chief designer of managed competition. "There would be higher quality care and it would be cheaper."
But critics call this a pipe dream. Managed competition would rob patients of choice and doctors of autonomy, worsen inequality and fail to curb costs to boot, said Dr. Steffie Woolhandler, a leader of a group of 5,500 liberal doctors who want a Canadian-style system in which Government pays for all health care. "It's basically an effort to preserve a role for the private insurance companies," she charged.
 
Questions on Cost-Cutting
 Conservatives praise the emphasis on market forces, but lament the infringements on patient choice and the new regulatory bodies that the approach requires. They also question whether it can reduce costs.
"If they end up with an even bigger bureaucracy than today, then the very reasons why they proposed competition will be lost," said Robert E. Moffit, a health expert at the Heritage Foundation, a research organization in Washington. Dr. Moffit and other free-market advocates propose using tax credits or other measures to help individuals buy their own health insurance, without all the intermediaries and regulators called for in managed competition.
The debate is clouded by the daunting complexity of the issues and public unfamiliarity with important concepts -- not least the phrase "managed competition" itself, which the President's advisers now shun.
However the nation proceeds, transforming an overbuilt health system into a sleek machine will involve painful change. What some call waste, whether excess hospital beds, unnecessary operations or redundant insurance brokers, others consider their livelihood.
"We have an extremely wasteful and inefficient system that has been bathed in cost-increasing incentives for over 50 years," said Alain C. Enthoven, a Stanford University business professor and a main theorist of managed competition, in a recent talk. "We badly need a radically more efficient system. That will mean closing hospitals and putting surgeons out of work."
 
The Strategy Of Competition
 Under managed competition, most people in a region, including those now buying insurance on their own, those employed by smaller companies and the uninsured, would be clustered in large, state-organized purchasing groups, or "health alliances" as the President's advisers now call them. These pools, and large employers that made their own arrangements, would bargain with health plans for good prices on a standard set of benefits. Group members would then be offered a choice of several plans.
Tax incentives would encourage people to choose lower-priced plans, but they could pay extra for plans offering extra coverage or more freedom to choose nonplan doctors, for example.
For their part, doctors, hospitals and insurers would join together to offer such plans, most of them similar to health maintenance organizations in which all care, from vaccinations to cardiac surgery, is given for a preset annual fee. These plans would compete for patients, forcing them to continually search for ways to trim waste.
Government agencies would supervise the process, protecting the quality of care and helping the poor join in. Everyone would have access to at least the same basic insurance whether young or old, healthy or sick.
In essence, managed competition seeks to transform the way most Americans buy health insurance, making them more conscious of the price of their coverage, and to change the way care is delivered, making doctors more aware of the costs and benefits of medical decisions.
Even many experts who favor the approach are worried about how aspects may work in practice: Would price competition force plans to scrimp on care? Would the savings be as large as the nation needs?
Advisers to the President have said he will create his own blend of measures. He appears committed to the basic approach of managed competition but plans to add other means of controlling spending.
No one can predict exactly how interacting forces would play out. Proponents say they have built in monitoring and corrective measures to steer things in the right direction. Critics, mindful of how the health system has eluded controls so far, are skeptical.
 
Debate on Freedom To Choose Doctors
 Mindful of the sensitivity of the issue, the President's advisers are calling theirs a pro-choice plan. Many people, though, will unquestionably have less freedom to select their doctors if strong financial pressures are used to push them into health maintenance organizations, or H.M.O.'s. Some people may feel they have been torn from a trusted doctor.
But the issue is not simple. Some 41 million people already belong to H.M.O.'s. Tens of millions more have little choice anyway because they are uninsured, have Medicaid benefits that are scorned by many doctors or live in rural areas where they have few choices. The 35 million elderly people on Medicare may not be pressured to switch, at least in the near term.
There is a chicken-and-egg aspect. If most patients join prepaid plans, most doctors will have to join them too, so many people may be able to follow their current doctor, though problems may arise when family members want doctors from different plans.
In the strategy, people would be offered a choice of several health plans, including some that allow patients to go outside the approved roster at extra cost and, perhaps for an extra premium, an old-fashioned fee-for-service plan allowing use of any doctor. The point is not to curb choice, according to Dr. Enthoven, but to make individuals bear the economic consequences of their choices.
Within an H.M.O., patients are generally free to choose a primary doctor from among many. Dr. Arnold S. Relman, the former editor of The New England Journal of Medicine, who supports managed competition with reservations, said he felt the choice issue was overblown. What most people really want, he said, is the freedom to change doctors when they are not satisfied, something they could still do within limits.
"I think we have to disabuse the average American of the idea that you can't get good care unless you have a large menu of doctors out there, look at their qualifications and pick one," he said. "That's not what most people do anyway."
At a different level, some people fear restrictions on their ability to consult outside specialists when confronting serious diseases like cancer. The medical groups should be large enough to allow for second opinions, but patients may have to use their own money for treatment elsewhere. For desperate patients this may seem important -- but discouraging shopping around for hopeful diagnoses or marginal therapies is a key to cost control.
 
Will the Quality Of Care Be Hurt?
 Perhaps the most alarming charge is that medical groups, forced to cut prices in a fierce competition for patients, will shortchange patients -- pressuring doctors to avoid needed tests, for example, or to prescribe a cheaper drug when a more expensive one would help the patient more.
Proponents say they have built in safeguards so that the competition would turn on quality as much as price. They envisage fostering medical groups that would behave like the best of current H.M.O.'s around the country, which tend to leave doctors rather than insurance officials in charge of medical decisions and try to save in part by improving care.
The Government would require plans to collect new data on their medical performance and patient satisfaction. This information would help people compare quality as they shop for plans.
New research would also provide doctors with feedback on their own performance, promoting steady improvements. These measures, Dr. Ellwood said, would be a vast improvement over the present, where opinions about proper treatment vary wildly and neither patient nor doctor can easily judge the quality of care.
But critics question whether tools are available for accurately distinguishing good care from mediocre, and for, in effect, standardizing medical decisions. "If we don't have a serious attempt to develop measures of quality, we'll compete on price and drive care down," said Dr. Robert Brook of the Rand Corporation, a California research institute.
Some like Dr. Relman think nonprofit medical groups would be more likely to protect quality than the investor-owned groups they fear will prevail. But others, including Dr. Ellwood, say they find no evidence that this is necessarily so.
Dr. Ellwood also stresses that H.M.O.'s promoting prudent medicine can avoid the overuse of tests and surgery, which not only drives up costs but can do more harm than good. "Most consumers think more is better in medical care, but it isn't." he said. "You hear about Cadillac medical care. I think that's crazy. The best medical care in the U.S. right now is costing less."
 
Will the Savings Be Large Enough?

In fee-for-service medicine, with insurers simply paying what they are billed, doctors and hospitals have incentives to perform more rather than fewer services. But with preset budgets, providers instead have incentives to save -- hopefully, to concentrate resources where they can do the most good. In managed competition, conservative medical practice would also be encouraged by new national guidelines on uses of medical technology.
Dr. Ellwood said he believed that within four or five years, the strategy would bring health costs in line with the general inflation rate, ending the surge that has created the current crisis. Dr. Enthoven asserts that total health spending, now at 14 percent of the gross domestic product, might even be driven back to 9 percent or 10 percent of the economy.
But many experts, pointing to the march of technology, the inertia in medical habits and the limited success of managed care in holding down costs so far, fear the savings would not be as steep and fast as the country needs.
"They are asking the nation to take a high-stakes gamble," said Henry Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution who favors placing limits on spending in the system as a whole. Mr. Clinton apparently agrees, and his advisers are considering ways to impose caps on health spending.
Advocates of a Canadian-style system say managed competition and its continuing role for private insurance companies would only add to paperwork, wasting large sums that could be devoted to care. A Government takeover would save large administrative sums, they say, and could be combined with spending ceilings.
Dr. Enthoven has been reluctant to endorse budget caps and opposes price controls. He argues that arbitrary ceilings or price controls may fail to wring out the worst inefficiencies, something the market can best achieve. Given political realities, he argues, governmental controls are more apt to freeze existing arrangements in place.
From the other side, conservatives like Dr. Moffit charge that the Government boards and mandates called for in managed competition would lead to overregulation, stifling innovation and needed restructuring of the health economy, and would invite costly political meddling with the free market.
But defenders say the new institutions are needed to help individuals accurately compare health plans, avoid the costs of administering multitudes of conflicting plans and approaches, and promote quality and fairness.
 
Quest to Achieve Equality of Care
 Dr. Woolhandler predicted that affluent people would pay extra for plans offering better coverage and freedom to choose the best doctors, while others would be left in cut-rate H.M.O.'s. "You'll see a rigid class stratification in health care," she said.
Some critics also fear that as large companies make their own deals with medical groups, the regional purchasing pools through which others obtain coverage might become second-class.
Several measures in the strategy are aimed at preventing serious inequities, mainly by promoting a high level of care for those who accept the lower-cost plans. Proponents of managed competition say the basic benefits required of all plans should be generous, offering insurance that most people would find ample. Government monitoring should uncover substandard medicine, forcing plans to improve or lose patients. And approved plans would be required to accept all applicants without screening.
Already, Dr. Ellwood said as an example, a growing share of patients at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., are in prepaid plans like those called for in managed competition. Under the new system, these would presumably become available to anyone in the region. "If you can buy better care than that, go ahead," he said.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. and Washington Divided On Aid for the Developing World

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
As a meeting of the International Monetary Fund's main policy-making committee ended, the head of the fund remained in disagreement with the United States and Germany today over a proposal to increase aid for the third world and former Soviet-bloc nations.
Michel Camdessus, the fund's managing director, has proposed that the fund be allowed to use its special powers to create $50 billion in new money to help end a global economic slump. But he said opposition from several major countries prevented approval at this week's meeting, which brought together finance ministers and central bankers representing the fund's 176 member nations. 
 The money Mr. Camdessus has proposed would be in the form of credits, called special drawing rights, that the member nations would receive from the fund. The nations could then use these credits to purchase goods from other countries.
The Clinton Administration, which has been promoting its own economic stimulus package, found itself in the awkward position of opposing Mr. Camdessus's plan. American officials say the monetary fund already has all the money it needs -- at least for now -- to help the former Communist nations and the third world.
Mr. Camdessus argues that it is time to use the fund's extraordinary powers to create this money, often called "paper gold," because global growth is weak and many poor nations desperately need more currency reserves.
Helmut Schlesinger, the president of Germany's central bank, also opposes issuing this new money, saying it could spur inflation. Mr. Camdessus dismissed this worry because inflationary pressures are low in most of the world.
At the meeting, many of the finance ministers urged other countries to do more to spur global growth. Norman Lamont, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, said Germany should move faster to cut interest rates.
He said the most important contribution to growth "would come from an early and successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round," of talks aimed at liberalizing world trade rules sponsored by the 112-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Mr. Lamont suggested that the monetary fund consider selling some of its gold reserves to help finance increased lending to the world's poorest nations.
Officials from many developing nations countries voiced dismay with the slow rate of growth in the industrial world. "The bad news is that the prospects for economic growth remain anemic," said Manmohan Singh, India's Finance Minister. "There is clearly an urgent need to adopt a concerted global strategy to accelerate the pace of economic growth."

HEADLINE: Hillary Clinton's Bipartisan Pitch for Health Plan

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton tried today to signal a new bipartisan approach to health-care reform, conducting a remarkable private briefing of Senate Democrats and Republicans on the Administration's emerging plan. But the initial lines of partisan division were immediately apparent.
After the two-and-a-half-hour meeting with about about 52 Senators evenly divided between the parties, Republicans paid careful tribute to Mrs. Clinton's courtesy and her willingness to reach out as chairwoman of the Administration's task force on health care. But several Republicans said they had qualms about some of the basics favored by the Administration's health-care planners, including national limits on medical spending and a mandate that employers provide or arrange for health insurance for their employees. 
 "It's a program that has a lot of merit to it," said Senator John Chaffee of Rhode Island, a centrist Republican and one of his party's experts on health. "But there are some quite fundamental differences between that program and what the Republican senators would be for."
Senator Phil Gramm, a conservative Republican of Texas, asserted that the Administration was clearly moving toward wage and price controls in the health-care field. "I hope we can deal with it on a bipartisan basis, but my bottom line is, I want programs that have some chance of working," said Mr. Gramm, a former professor of economics. "We have experience with wage and price controls that go back 5,000 years, and never, ever, have they been used anywhere that has worked."
Still, Senator Jay Rockefeller, the West Virginia Democrat, told reporters after the briefing today that price controls should be "less of a sticking point, because one of the things that's being very seriously considered by the White House is that cost controls be done on a voluntary basis."
Doctors, hospitals and pharmaceutical companies would be given the opportunity to restrain their own costs, Mr. Rockefeller said, but there would be back-up legislation to impose regulations if the voluntary controls failed.
Participants in the meeting said later that many Republicans were concerned about the heavy regulatory role envisioned by the plan. Mrs. Clinton, accompanied by Ira C. Magaziner and Judith Feder, the two top staff advisers to the task force, sketched out the Administration's proposals for a system built around health insurance purchasing cooperatives. Under the plan, the cooperatives would pool the bargaining power of businesses and individuals to negotiate for health care. Mr. Gramm, signaling the political fight to come as the plan moves from policy debate to Congress, said after the meeting that a health insurance purchasing cooperative "was like a five-legged animal; it may work, but we don't see any of them in nature."
Participants said Mrs. Clinton indicated the task force was looking at a range of options on how to pay for the plan, which would be aimed at insuring that all Americans have access to a basic health package.
 
Opposition to Tax
 But Senator Rockefeller said Mrs. Clinton indicated that a value added tax, a kind of national sales tax that is favored by some Administration officials, was "substantially down the list." Others suggested she was even more negative on it. The idea was floated by several Administration officials earlier this month and prompted much criticism.
Also discussed at the session was the idea, now being reviewed by the Administration, to require employers to contribute a certain percentage of their payrolls to cover the cost of health benefits for their employees, participants said.
The session was also symbolic -- an attempt by the White House to create a public image of bipartisanship after watching its plan to stimulate the economy collapse in bitter partisan maneuvering in the Senate this month. Mrs. Clinton, after the session, briefly took questions with Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, on one side, and Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, on the other.
Mrs. Clinton declared, "health care is an issue that goes beyond politics." Mr. Dole said, "The American people want us to work together."
But the Republican leader outlined a view of the consultative process that was perhaps more expansive than the White House envisioned. "We've been working on a plan, the White House has been working on a plan," Mr. Dole said. "I don't believe anybody has the votes right now, whether its Democrats or Republicans." He added that any final health legislation "ought to be totally bipartisan, not trying to pick off three or four Republicans or whatever."
Mrs. Clinton said today that the health-care task force was on schedule "to coming forward in May, and we intend to do so." For all the talk of Congressional consultation, Mrs. Clinton has repeatedly reiterated her intent to stick to a May deadline for unveiling the plan, despite the pleas from top Democrats in the House to hold off a few weeks, so that it would not collide with an important vote on the President's economic package.

With her were Senator Bob Dole, left, the minority leaders, and Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Most Wanted Man: the County Judge

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EBENSBURG, Pa.

 BODY:
Judge Joseph F. O'Kicki, once the most feared man in this western Pennsylvania town, has become its most wanted fugitive, last seen having his Visa card repossessed by a bank in Ljubljana, the capital of Slovenia.
The judge fled to Slovenia last month from Ebensburg, where he had been a Judge on the Court of Common Pleas of Cambria County for 17 years before his conviction in 1989 on charges of demanding bribes and concessions from banks, lawyers and businesses, as well as sexually harassing his two secretaries. 
 The jury found that Judge O'Kicki had held a campaign fund-raiser to pay off personal debts, demanded what he called loans and commissions from lawyers who appeared in his court as well as payments from employees for promotions. He ordered court officers to chop his firewood, trim his lawns and chauffeur him around.
Two of his secretaries testified that several times the judge had called one or the other into his chambers when he was nude or wearing only yellow bikini underwear. When she refused his sexual advances, one secretary said, he began treating her badly.
 
Demands Put in Writing
 The prosecutor said the judge had become so arrogant that he even put illegal demands in writing. "I think the most bizarre thing he did was to write, on court stationery, to a bank demanding that his auto loan be forgiven or else he would deny them access to the court," said Lawrence N. Claus, the state's chief Deputy Attorney General. The bank reduced the interest rate on the loan and made other concessions.
Some people here celebrate the judge's downfall as poetic justice, while others poke fun at the jurist on the run. At his tavern near the courthouse, Bernie Tirabassi has a lively trade in "Where's the Judge" T-Shirts. Another bar, Dempsey's Irish Pub, offers "Slovenian Buffet" happy hours.
But experts on rural justice say this is neither a laughing matter nor an isolated case of a corrupt judge in the Allegheny Mountains. Of the nation's 55,000 county judges, there are probably hundreds of corrupt ones like Mr. O'Kicki and thousands of others who flagrantly abuse their power, said Maurice D. Geiger, a co-founder of the Rural Justice Center, a public interest group in Montpelier, Vt.
In many small counties he has studied, he said, few lawyers or residents dare complain to the authorities about a judge, appeal a judge's decisions or challenge his re-election. If they do, they risk alienating the judge who might one day rule on their divorces, custody cases or contract disputes.
 
Judicial Review Criticized
 "Judicial review mechanisms are a joke in most states, and that is why you get a guy like O'Kicki in a rural county court," Mr. Geiger said. In Ebensburg, where Judge O'Kicki solicited bribes from lawyers for many years, only one lawyer says he complained to the state Judicial Inquiry and Review Board. The board would not confirm or deny receiving a complaint, but it did not take any public action until after Judge O'Kicki's conviction, when it had the judge suspended.
Judge O'Kicki apparently fled the country to avoid a court hearing on March 8 to determine where he would serve his prison sentence of two to five years and how he would finish paying $249,000 in fines and restitution. The court had already seized $156,000 from him. Judge O'Kicki also faces a second criminal trial that deals with his private investments. The 16 charges range from forging documents to operating a beer distributorship illegally.
Judge O'Kicki was born in nearby Franklin to a very poor family of immigrants from Slovenia. His mother cleaned houses and his father was a stonemason. After his father died and his mother became too ill to work, Joseph became the family's sole wage earner, mining coal after school.
He won a full scholarship to the University of Pittsburgh and, after graduation, served two years in the Navy and enrolled in the University of Pittsburgh Law School. His first marriage, which produced seven daughters, ended in divorce in 1986. He married again and had two sons, and his second wife recently filed for divorce.
In his first foray into politics, in 1970, Mr. O'Kicki narrowly lost an election for the United States House of Representatives. The next year, he won his first 10-year term on the county court here, and in 1981 he was re-elected to a second term. Bar associations gave him high ratings, and he was repeatedly considered for vacancies on the Federal bench in Pennsylvania. Even after his conviction on corruption charges and his suspension from the bench with pay, he ran for re-election in 1991 and lost in a landslide. The judge has always maintained his innocence. "My trial is a classic example of abuse of police power and prosecutorial power," he said after his conviction. "I see conspiracies everywhere." He also said he might be killed in prison by some of the criminals he had sent there. "I have a general fear of going to jail," he said.
Many people here say that before his downfall, the judge treated Ebensburg as his realm, ruling it from the castle-like 111-year-old Cambria County Courthouse, the only architectural remnant of the era when Ebensburg was a resort for such wealthy families as the Vanderbilts and the Carnegies, and the place where Mary Todd Lincoln went to recuperate after her husband's assassination.
The style of the courthouse suited Judge O'Kicki. In June 1988, while a grand jury was investigating 76 charges against him, he had a lavish ceremony to commemorate his swearing in as presiding judge. He wore purple robes and when he entered the magnificent domed courtroom, about 10 trumpeters, standing among the pink marble pillars, played a fanfare.
"It was more like a coronation than a swearing in," said June Fether, a copy editor at the Mountaineer-Herald, a 140-year-old weekly newspaper. In the last month there have been several sightings of Judge O'Kicki in Slovenia, an island of calm amid the blood bath taking place elsewhere in the former Yugoloslavia. Slovenia might not be the place of choice for many fugitives, but Judge O'Kicki apparently went there because his Slovenian ancestry gave him the right to citizenship and a passport. What's more, his two small sons and his second wife, Sylvia Onusic, are in Slovenia.
Ms. Onusic, who recently filed for divorce and changed her last name from O'Kicki to Onusic, is studying the Slovenian health-care system on a Fulbright grant. But Pennsylvania authorities this month charged Ms. Onusic with perjury in connection with her name change as well as six counts of fraud and deception involving the deed to the house she shared with the judge. She did not return telephone calls placed to her in Slovenia.
 
No Treaty With Slovenia
 Authorities are trying to bring the judge home to prison, but the United States does not yet have an extradition treaty with the newly independent Slovenia.
On April 16, Mr. O'Kicki telephoned a television station in Johnstown, Pa., and said he would stay in exile until a higher court agreed to hear his case.
"I will remain in exile until such time as somebody that has the legal authority such as the Supreme Court with its plenary powers, the Senate Judiciary Committee, or some Federal court decides to hear the merits of my case," Mr. O'Kicki said during a taped interview with a local television station, WWCP.
His avenue of appeal seems unlikely, however, since the state Supreme Court has already rejected his earlier request for an appeal.
Mr. O'Kicki refused to say where he was calling from, but made the call after a request for an interview was faxed to his wife in Ljubljana.

Bernie Tirabassi, owner of Tirabassi's Central Tavern, wore a T-shirt that he sells there posing the question "Where's the Judge?" (Terry Clark for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Escalates War of Words on Japan Trade

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, accused the Japanese Government today of discriminating against American construction companies and supercomputer manufacturers. He threatened trade sanctions if negotiations did not produce changes.
The statements were the latest and clearest sign of the Clinton Administration's strategy to reduce the nation's huge trade deficit with Japan by challenging the status quo on specific trade disputes. 
 The Administration plans to seek negotiations with Japan on the construction issue, but Mr. Kantor would not describe the American strategy for such talks.
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, however, told reporters at a breakfast today that in dealing with Japan on many trade issues, "I think only pressure is going to produce results, and only things that are measurable and monitorable are going to produce results."
 Japanese officials have criticized the Clinton Administration's emphasis on setting specific trade targets, contending that this amounts to managed trade. But Mr. Kantor said today that clear gains are needed from trade negotiations to prevent the American people from losing their faith in the international free trade system.
Seiichiro Noboru, the top economics official at the Japanese Embassy here, was particularly critical of Mr. Kantor's decision todayto start the clock on a law that would allow the Administration to impose sanctions unilaterally in 60 days.
"It is highly regrettable that the United States Government made such a decision, because we are not in any way treating American construction companies in a discriminatory manner," Mr. Noboru said. "We will never accept negotiations under duress."
Mr. Noboru said that American construction companies won $330 million worth of Government contracts in Japan last year, while Japanese companies won $325 million worth of American public works contracts.
 
Different Construction Figures
 But figures from the Commerce Department told a different story. They showed that American companies won $189 million of the $700 billion Japanese market for public- and private-sector construction last year, while Japanese companies won $1.5 billion of the $425 billion American market.
The Commerce Department has no figures on the Japanese share of the American public works market because cities and states have not provided the necessary figures. The department has traditionally played a larger role in negotiations with Japan than in talks with other countries.
Mr. Kantor did not commit himself today to imposing trade sanctions on the 61st day if no results were obtained in construction negotiations. But he said that he would use the "trade tools" given to him by law, which would allow him to impose sanctions.
Today's move was especially striking because Mr. Kantor made it on his own initiative. The Bush Administration usually waited until a domestic industry had been lobbying for months before it began threatening sanctions.
 
A Surprise to Builders
 And Mr. Kantor's announcement today caught the American construction industry off guard. Its trade group, Associated Builders and Contractors, and the industry's largest companies all declined to comment.
Mr. Kantor also said today that the Federal Government would begin monitoring Japanese Government bidding procedures for supercomputers in the coming months. If the procedures are not satisfactory, then the United States will begin a formal legal action under an American trade law that allows the United States to impose unilateral trade sanctions if American concerns are not addressed, Mr. Kantor said.
Mr. Noboru said that Japan had complied with a three-year-old agreement on opening its Government market for supercomputers and said that the United States Government had not bought any Japanese supercomputers, while the Japanese Government bought several American supercomputers in recent years.
Mr. Kantor said American companies produced a much more competitive product. The United States holds 84 percent of the European market for supercomputers, where American and Japanese companies compete on a roughly equal footing, he said.
In a separate move, Mr. Kantor said that the Administration had also put Brazil, India and Thailand at the top of its list of countries with which it wants to negotiate agreements providing for greater protection of American copyrights, patents and trademarks.

HEADLINE: 20-Point Rally Fizzles, But Dow Ends Up 2.43

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The stock market rose modestly in fitful trading yesterday, as surging interest rates lured some money away from stocks.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up only 2.43 points, to 3,427.55. An early rally that had sent the Dow 20 points higher lost most of its momentum in the last two hours of trading. Still, other leading stock market indexes rose yesterday. 
 For the week, the Dow was up 13.78 points.
In the bond market yields rose and prices plunged in thin trading. Some traders were concerned about the uncertainty surrounding the size of the 30-year Treasury auction later this month, as well as the uncertain economic outlook. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.92 percent, from 6.88 percent.
 
Gold Stocks Mixed
 The gold stocks did not benefit from the interest-rate jitters, however, as they sometimes do. Gold fell in price for much of the day, losing as much as $4.40 in selling from Australia and the Middle East, but recovered from almost all of its losses. Gold for June delivery closed only 20 cents lower, at $357.20 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Gold stocks were mixed. Newmont Mining, which sold a large block of Newmont stock to the financier George Soros, was the exception, closing up 7/8, to 48 3/4. But Newmont was one of three gold mining companies -- the others were Echo Bay Mines and Homestake Mining -- whose stock assessments were lowered to "underperform" from "hold" by a Kidder Peabody mining analyst.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.98 point, to 243.46. Volume on the Big Board was again moderate at 247.5 million shares, compared with Thursday's 249.8 million shares. Winning stocks on the Big Board outnumbered losers by 1,210 to 670.
The Standard & Poor's 500 rose 1.30 point, to 440.19, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 2.97 points, to 661.42. The American Stock Exchange composite index rose 2.21 points, to 420.96
The Dow was lifted yesterday by Allied Signal, which rose 1 3/4, to 65 1/4. Allied, a diversified manufacturer for the automotive and aerospace industries, said earlier in the week that it expected earning to increase.
But the Dow tended to be dragged down by Texaco, Sears and General Electric, each of which dropped 1 point.
The S.& P. 500 was lifted by a wide variety of stocks, led by Johnson & Johnson, which reported stronger first-quarter earnings Thursday. It rose 1 1/4, to 43 5/8. The leading S.& P. 500 groups were diversified health-care companies, including Johnson & Johnson and Abbott Laboratories; insurance companies, like American International Group and Aetna; and household products, like Procter & Gamble and Clorox. But no particular group provided strong support for the S.& P. 500.
Once again, Telefonos de Mexico topped the most-active list on the Big Board at 4.46 million shares, compared with Thursday's 10.3 million-share volume. Its American depository receipts have been buffeted by poor first-quarter results and concerns over passage of the North American Free trade Agreement, but they had been lifted by a stock buyback program announced Thursday. Telmex closed down 1/8, to 47 7/8.
At a 3.1 million-share volume, Philip Morris was the second most active stock following the announcement Thursday that the company was willing to cut prices further for its Marlboro cigarettes, if necessary. Philip Morris closed down 1/4, to 47. The Limited Inc., the specialty retailer, was the third most active stock on the Big Board at 3.07 million shares on no discernible news. It closed down 3/4, to 22 1/8.
In Tokyo, stocks moved sharply higher yesterday. The Nikkei index of 225 issues surged 464.61 points, or 2.27 percent, to 20,919.18.

HEADLINE: March Consumer Spending And Factory Orders Fell

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
Consumer spending fell in March for the first time in seven months and orders to factories slumped, too, the Government said today. Personal income rose, but mostly because of huge farm-subsidy payments.
"We are basically just mired in a slow-growth economy," said Lawrence Chimerine, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill in Lexington, Mass. 
 Personal-consumption spending declined two-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.23 trillion, the Commerce Department said. Incomes rose six-tenths of 1 percent, to an annualized $5.26 trillion, but that increase was bolstered by the largest monthly farm subsidy payment in nearly six years.
The department said new orders to factories dropped 1.5 percent, the worst decline since August.
 
Fewer Takers for Big Items
 Orders for durable goods -- big-ticket items like cars and computers -- dropped 3.4 percent, the largest decline since December 1991. Orders for nondurable goods like food and clothing were up seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Much of the decline came in aircraft orders, but even excluding transportation, factory orders edged down one-tenth of 1 percent.
Today's reports underscored earlier statistics showing that economic growth has slowed drastically this year after reaching a five-year high during the last three months of 1992.
On Thursday, the Government reported that the gross domestic product -- the total value of goods and services produced in the United States -- grew at an unexpectedly slow annual rate of 1.8 percent in the first quarter, down sharply from 4.7 percent in the fourth quarter of 1992.
 
Economist Is Puzzled
 David Berson, an economist at the Federal National Mortgage Association, explained, "We couldn't keep up the pace of growth we saw in the fourth quarter, not with the relatively weak job and income growth we are getting."
The largest component of incomes --wages and salaries -- increased a scant one-tenth of 1 percent after falling two-tenths of a point a month earlier.
The Clinton Administration has used the gloomy numbers to argue for its economic-stimulus package. Republicans contend that the fear of new taxes is discouraging consumers and business.
Many economists focused on income growth. "When we say we can't figure out why people are so pessimistic, well this is why," said Evelina M. Tainer of Prime Economic Consulting in Chicago. "Wages and salaries just aren't growing."
Still, the rise in March overall income -- including such things as waiters' tips and managers' bonuses -- was the largest since a 1 percent advance in December. It followed increases of one-tenth of a percent in February and five-tenths of a percent in January.
Two conflicting special factors influenced the personal-income statistics: a $3.3 billion farm-subsidy payment, the largest since October 1987, and the cost of damage to uninsured housing caused by severe Eastern storms. Excluding special factors, incomes rose two-tenths of 1 percent in March and four-tenths of 1 percent in February.
 
More Paid Out to Jobless
 Government transfer payments, including unemployment benefits, rose in March. Interest income was down.
Real disposable income -- income adjusted for inflation after taxes -- rose five-tenths of 1 percent in March after a two-tenths of 1 percent decline the month before.
Consumer spending fell four-tenths of a point for durable goods and 1.1 percent for nondurable goods. It rose two-tenths of a percent for services.
The combination of rising income and falling spending produced a big increase in the American savings rate -- to 5.4 percent of income, the best in 10 months, from 4.5 percent in both January and February.

HEADLINE: Shanghai Journal;
For Lucky Students, It's All Work, Work, Work

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
After American high school teachers die and go to heaven, they may find themselves in one of China's best schools teaching shiny-eyed dynamos like Ellen Y. Zhu.
Classroom violence? That's what happens to frogs in biology class. 
 Student discipline? A problem, yes, particularly on Saturday evenings, when children are inclined to take a few hours off to watch television.
Teen-age sex? Not much happens.
"Romance is not banned, but the school does not encourage us to fall in love so early," Miss Zhu, 18, said with a primness to drive a stake through the hearts of her male classmates. "We should concentrate our energies on school work."
 
English in Second Grade
 Miss Zhu, by the way, was speaking in fluent English, without a single "you know" thrown in, the kind of language that would bring a fond gleam to the eye of an English teacher in an American high school. Here in Shanghai, students begin studying English in the second grade.
China's economic liberalization is well known in the West. But if China manages to shrug off centuries of poverty and emerge as a major international power, another factor will be the top-notch education that some lucky students are getting.
In the cities, elementary school children take tests to determine which school they get into. The best institutions have computer rooms, language labs and fine laboratories, all overrun with the kind of youngsters who do terrible things to grade curves.
Take Jessica J. Cao, who like Miss Zhu is a student at the Shanghai Foreign Languages School, where most students adopt English names as part of their effort to understand Western culture. The faculty includes three foreign English teachers, who stay for a year at a time, and this fall the school will send its second student to Harvard College in three years.
 
Classes, Classes, Classes
 Miss Cao wakes up at 6:15 each morning and reads from an English novel after breakfast. Classes begin at 8 and continue, with a lunch break, until 4:30. Then there is a two-hour break for dinner and homework, then classes from 6:30 to 9.
Miss Cao then has 30 minutes to prepare for bed in the student dormitory, where girls are housed up to 12 to a room, before lights go out at 9:30. To dispel any suggestion that she and her classmates are automatons, she emphasizes that the students do not go out with the lights.
"We talk among ourselves, about everything," Miss Cao said. "Sometimes we listen to a radio and dance in the darkness."
School lasts half a day on Saturday, and Miss Cao then goes home to spend the rest of the weekend with her family.
 
Even TV Is Good for Them
 "On Saturday night I make up for all the time in school and watch television," Miss Cao said. "There's always an English-language movie on, and I like to watch that."
Top students in major cities give up their Saturday afternoons and Sundays to attend "Olympic Schools" for special instruction in mathematics, physics, chemistry and other subjects.
Zhu Yanhong, a 17-year-old chemistry ace, is one of the compulsive overachievers. She lives at home but is now preparing for a science contest, which means that she leaves for school at 6:20 A.M. and returns 12 hours later -- just in time for an hour of homework. On top of the homework, Miss Zhu puts in a couple of hours of academic work that the teacher has not even assigned.
"My father and mother always tell me that I must study hard, so most of my time is occupied by my homework," Miss Zhu said, acknowledging that she does also sneak a bit of time to enjoy English pop music.
Miss Zhu is a student at the Shanghai No. 3 Girls School, one of the few single-sex high schools. The school is so competitive that only one-sixth of the applicants can be enrolled.
One reason many students are so driven may be that increasingly they are only children, "little emperors," the fruits of China's strict family-planning policies. Two parents and four grandparents push each child to perform well.
"They figure they're the center of their family," Luo Peiming, the Foreign Language School principal, said of the only children. "The parents bring them food and help them do everything. The parents act as maids to their kids. They even wash their children's hair."
Parents buy pianos for their little emperors, arrange English tutors, even try to bribe the best kindergartens to admit their children so they can get into a fine university a dozen years later.
 
Meanwhile, Out in the Villages
 While it is clear that China's high schools produce some first-rate graduates, the system also raises fundamental questions of fairness. Instead of trying to equalize educational opportunities, as one might expect a Communist Party to do, China is creating an ever larger chasm between the educational haves and have-nots.
Most schools are still shabby buildings in the villages, where peasant children sit jammed on rickety chairs and shriek out their lessons in unison. Public education is not free in China, even in elementary schools, and in rural areas many pupils -- particularly girls -- drop out in elementary school because their parents cannot afford the $10 or $20 annual tuition.
Nationally, only 13 percent of children even enter high school. In 1992 the drop-out rate in junior high schools actually rose, by 6 percent.
The state offers a subsidy of about $200 a year per pupil to the best high schools in Shanghai, but many village schools get nothing. While China is producing a crop of brilliant scientists at its best schools, it is also producing another generation of semi-illiterates from its rural schools.
Is this fair? The Shanghai students squirm a bit, but say it is.
"If we gave the same amount of money to the rural provinces, we could support a lot more students," conceded Shirley Q. C. Zhao, an 18-year-old at the girls school. "But their facilities and teachers aren't very good, so it's not much use to try and teach them so much. It's better to train us."

GRAPHIC: Photo: If China is to shed the centuries of poverty that have kept it from being a major power despite its population and size, many feel it requires a superior educational system. Zhu Yanhong, right, who attends the elite Shanghai No. 3 Girls School, ends a 12-hour school day with an hour of homework. (Nicholas D. Kristof/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Israel Boycott Violation Is Top Issue for Baxter

BYLINE: By RICHARD RINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 30

 BODY:
The main topic of today's annual meeting of Baxter International Inc. was not sales and profits but the fallout from the company's admission that it had violated a Federal law against cooperating with the Arab economic boycott of Israel.
The chairman and chief executive of the medical products supplier, Vernon R. Loucks Jr., has come under pressure to resign since the guilty plea earlier this month. Even student groups at Yale University, where Mr. Loucks is a trustee, have called for him to step down. But he received a strong vote of confidence from shareholders and a large customer today. Still, at least one big customer has threatened to cut off its orders. 
 Most shareholders cheered and applauded Mr. Loucks several times during the meeting here in the auditorium of the Art Institute of Chicago. The most demonstrative applause came after Mr. Loucks rejected one shareholder's demand that he resign over the boycott incident, which he acknowledged had "placed a mark on our company that we deeply regret."
 
Customer Reactions
 Another vote of support came from American Healthcare Systems Inc., Baxter's largest single customer. Monroe Trout, chairman and president of the hospital management company based in San Diego, told shareholders that American would continue doing business with Baxter.
"I am not going to run away from Baxter," said Mr. Trout, whose company bought $648 million in goods and services in 1992 from Baxter.
But another of Baxter's biggest customers, Premier Hospitals Alliance of Westchester, Ill., has threatened to cut off its annual purchases of $250 million. Premier, which operates 50 hospitals nationwide, of which about a third are sponsored by Jewish organizations, was to meet with Baxter's outside directors after the shareholders' meeting.
The outcome of the meeting with the Premier officials could not be determined. But Mr. Loucks told shareholders that the matter with Premier was "something we can work out."
Earlier this week, a Premier spokeswoman said the company would not demand that Mr. Loucks resign.
 
Sought Removal From List
 Mr. Loucks and Baxter have come under fire since the company pleaded guilty in early April to a single felony charge relating to the company's efforts in 1988 to be removed from the Arab blacklist of companies that do business in Israel.
While it is not illegal for companies to try to get off the blacklist, Baxter admitted overstepping the law by providing Syrian officials with information about a business it operated in Israel. G. Marshall Abbey, who led the initiative, resigned as Baxter's vice president and general counsel. Baxter and Mr. Abbey were fined $6.5 million, which the company paid.
Mr. Loucks tried to distance himself today from any illegal activities. He said he had relied on the efforts of Mr. Abbey and independent counsel to be removed from the blacklist.
"It was always my belief that we were acting within the law," Mr. Loucks said. He said he was unaware of any impropriety until a meeting later with Justice Department officials who investigated the case.
Mr. Loucks said Baxter had taken several steps to avoid a repetition of the situation. Those steps include a review by the board's public policy committee of Baxter's ethics initiatives and policies and the creation of a corporate responsibility office. That office will be responsible for, among other things, ethics training and reporting on ethics violations.
Several matters concerning Baxter's guilty plea remain unresolved. The Defense Department is reviewing whether it should continue to buy from Baxter. Also, the New York City Employees Retirement System, which owns about 947,000 Baxter shares, has asked Baxter for a report on the boycott incident.
The city agency also wants assurances that "appropriate actions" will be taken against any Baxter employee "responsible for the transaction" that led to the violation of the Federal statute.

HEADLINE: Reversing Field, Bond Prices Drop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Despite signs of slowing economic growth, prices of Treasury bonds fell sharply yesterday and yields jumped.
Many traders were surprised by a sharp reversal during the day in the movement of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bonds, which led the broader market decline. In the morning, the bond's price was up as much as 11/32 point, but it ended the day losing 19/32 of a point. Volume was light. 
 The 30-year bond yield rose to a three-week high of 6.92 percent, from 6.88 percent late Thursday.
A variety of factors have weighed on the market recently, including uncertainty about the size of the 30-year Treasury auction scheduled in May and the Clinton Adminstration's ability to cut the budget deficit.
But the size of the losses in Treasury securities left many perplexed. "I can take some guesses," said Alan Levenson, a money market economist with UBS Securities, "but from an economist's perspective, it's hard to come up with a good explanation."
If not for the recent bearish tone in the market, bonds might have been expected to rally on the negative economic news released yesterday. Weak economic growth is usually taken to mean scant prospects of inflation, and low interest rates. That, in turn, drives up bond prices, as the price of bonds and similar securities move inversely to their yields.
Traders also focused yesterday on recent data from the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago, which said that its April index of manufacturing activity fell to 54.3, from 60.7 in March.
 
Weak Economic Data
 In addition, the Government said that factory orders slumped 1.5 percent in March, the largest drop in seven months. Other economic statistics also pointed to negative performance. The data seemed to reduce the chance that the Federal Reserve system would raise interest rates.
But prices drifted down anyway, amid growing market nervousness. In the afternoon, as rumors of big sell orders circulated, the 30-year bond's decline accelerated.
Of particular concern are plans by the Treasury to announce details on Wednesday of its regular quarterly refunding, a series of auctions to be held in May, that will give definite signs of how much it will pare its issuance of longer-term securities.
With interest rates higher for longer-term debt, it is generally cheaper for the Government to offer shorter-term securities. Many traders hope that the Treasury will halve its annual issuance of 30-year bonds, now about $35 billion, and eliminate the seven-year bond issue.
Yesterday, shorter-term Treasuries were 1/32 point lower and intermediate maturities fell 1/8 point to 5/16 point, Telerate reported. The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, lost 2.74 to 1,295.14.
The discount rate on three-month Treasury bills was unchanged at 2.89 percent, while the rate on the six-month bills rose to 2.97 percent, from 2.96. The rate on one-year bills rose to 3.14 percent, from 3.13 percent.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, rose to 3 1/8 percent from 215/16 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds slipped 3/32 to 100 7/8 from late Thursday. The average yield to maturity edged up to 5.96 percent from 5.95 percent.

HEADLINE: Panel Named To Plan Help For Airlines

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
President Clinton and Congressional leaders have spurned both consumer groups and the leading airlines in naming the 15 members of a bipartisan commission charged with recommending measures to revitalize the ailing American airline industry.
The President asked the commission Thursday night to "take a step back" from the debate over why the industry lost $10 billion in the last three years, and "examine the context in which the aviation industry operates." 
 "To the extent the commission can help us understand how we got to where we are today, and provide a vision for a competitive future, it will have rendered an invaluable service," the President said.
 
 
Authorized by Congress
 The chairman of the commission, authorized by an act of Congress signed by the President on April 7, will be Gerald L. Baliles, a former Governor of Virginia. The President described Mr. Baliles as "an old friend" who "recognized that aviation is the lifeblood of commerce in a global economy, and made it an important part of his state's competitiveness strategy."
"That is what we must do now at a national level," the President said.
The commission members are drawn from airline unions and management, as well as from finance and academia. Members include Felix G. Rohaytn, a Manhattan investment banker who played a leading role in the rescue of New York City from its fiscal crisis of the 1970's.
Unrepresented, however, were any consumer groups or any of the nation's big airlines. The commission is required to make its recommendations within 90 days.
Noting the absence of consumer groups, David Stempler, counsel for the International Airline Passenger Association, said, "The Administration and the Congress have loaded the commission with people who are part of the problem and are not likely to be part of the solution."
Mr. Stempler said that the omission of consumer advocates showed that the Administration thought that the airlines "are run for the benefit of airline employees, airports, aviation manufacturers and financial institutions," rather than for travelers.
 
 
Proposals to Be Reviewed
 The commission is expected to study proposals including loan guarantees and tax relief for airline companies and the lifting of restrictions on foreign ownership of United States airlines. Other proposals include examining the bankruptcy laws that have kept several airlines aloft, to the chagrin of more successful rivals; enhancing overseas access for United States airlines, and reducing barriers to competition, including frequent-flier programs and computer reservation systems that favor the airlines that own them.
The White House and the leaders of the Senate and the House each named five members. In addition, there are 11 ex-officio members, including Laura D'Andrea Tyson, who heads the President's Council of Economic Advisers; five Senators, and five House members.
Following are the appointees to the commission:
 
 Appointed by the White House
Bette B. Anderson, president, Kelly, Anderson & Associates, a management consulting firm in Washington; Gerald L. Baliles, a partner in Hunton & Williams, a Richmond law firm; Sylvia A. de Leon, a partner in Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld, a Washington law firm; Herbert D. Kelleher, chief executive of Southwest Airlines, Dallas; Gina F. Thomas, managing attorney for international and regulatory affairs for Federal Express, Memphis.
 
 Appointed by the Senate leadership
Charles Barclay, president of the American Association of Airport Executives, Washington; Robert F. Daniell, chief executive of United Technologies, West Hartford, Conn.; Felix G. Rohaytn, managing partner at Lazard Freres, New York; Russell W. Meyer Jr., chairman and chief executive of Cessna Aircraft, Wichita, Kan.; Abraham D. Sofaer, partner in Hughes, Hubbard & Reed, a Washington law firm.
 
 Appointed by the House leadership
J. Randolph Babbitt, president of the Air Line Pilots Association, Oakton, Va; John Peterpaul, vice president of the International Association of Machinists; Sandra Painalto, first vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland; John E. Robson, Lister Crown Distinguished Faculty Fellow, Yale University; Daniel M. Kasper, director of transportation practice and an airlines analyst with Harbridge House, an international consulting firm in Boston.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Hopes of German Rate Cuts Raise Dollar Against Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Renewed hopes for significant reductions in German interest rates drove the dollar modestly higher against the German mark in erratic trading yesterday.
Gold ended slightly lower after surging more than $5 an ounce in the last two days in New York. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fell 20 cents an ounce to $356.50. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $355.80 an ounce, off 10 cents.
 
British Official's Remarks
 Traders largely focused on comments by Chancellor of the Exchequer Norman Lamont of Britain that the German central bank should step up its rate reductions. 
 But the dollar was mixed against other European currencies and posted only slight gains against the Japanese yen, in part because Mr. Lamont said that he was not bothered by the yen's recent rally.
Mr. Lamont also said the International Monetary Fund might consider selling modest amounts of its gold reserves, but the remarks were not specific enough to push gold futures prices off their highs for the day.
 
Bundesbank Cuts a Rate
 The dollar initially jumped in European trading after the Bundesbank, the German central bank, made an unexpectedly large cut of half a percentage point in its three-day bill rate. This led traders to speculate that the bank's policy-making council would make more significant rate cuts when it meets on Thursday.
Lower German interest rates would hurt the value of the mark by diverting money elsewhere. But the mark rebounded against the dollar after the Bundesbank issued a statement that the rate cut was not abnormal.
The dollar regained the lead in early afternoon New York trading when Mr. Lamont said in Washington that he favored more German interest cuts. He also said he expected European nations to cut rates further.
In Europe, the dollar rose to 1.5880 German marks from 1.5825 marks late Thursday. Later in New York, the dollar advanced to 1.5850 marks from 1.5790 marks Thursday.
Among other currencies, the British pound edged up to $1.5733 in late afternoon trading in New York, compared with $1.5725 on Thursday.
Also in New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 111.10 yen yesterday afternoon, up slightly from 110.95 yen on Thursday.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Posner Deal Expected to Revive DWG Units

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

 BODY:
Arby's Inc. and the Royal Crown Cola Company, two units of the DWG Corporation that had suffered under the management of the financier Victor Posner, should start showing signs of vigor under new ownership, industry analysts and investors say.
"The recognition now that they are adequately financed makes a big difference," said Michael A. Connor, a money manager of Fahnestock & Company, whose clients own 400,000 shares of DWG. 
 Last week, the Trian Group, a New York investment firm headed by Nelson Peltz and Peter May, both 50, bought a controlling stake in DWG for $72 million from Mr. Posner and his affiliates as part of a settlement of a long-running lawsuit. Shareholders contended that Mr. Posner had enriched himself and family members at the company's expense.
As part of the deal, DWG, based in Miami Beach, Fla., refinanced $405 million in debt and received $10 million through the sale of stock to Merrill Lynch & Company and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc.
As a result of lower interest costs because of the refinancing and other economies, Mr. Connor said he expected DWG to have a $50 million increase in earnings, to $2.50 a share, next year. "Some of these businesses were handicapped by a shortage of capital," he said. "These are all elements of the penalties that the Posner regime imposed on operations."
For the year ended April 30, 1992, DWG had a loss of $7.5 million on sales of $1.27 billion.
If shareholders approve, the parent company will be renamed Triarc, a combination of Trian, Arby's and Royal Crown.
On Tuesday, DWG appointed these managers for its four core companies:
*John C. Carson, 47, a former president of Cadbury Beverages, was named president and chief executive of Royal Crown Cola.
*Donald L. Pierce, 48, a former president of Pepsico Inc.'s Hot 'n Now hamburger chain, was appointed president and chief executive of Arby's.
*Ronald D. Paliughi, 49, a former senior vice president of AP Propane, was named president and chief executive of the National Propane Corporation.
*E. Douglas Kingsmore, formerly the executive vice president of DWG's textile company, the Graniteville Corporation, was named president and chief executive.
In an interview, Mr. Carson said, "I know the intention of the new company is to put more resources into the business," but he could not specify exact plans. He said Royal Crown's bottlers needed marketing and advertising support. R.C., known in the industry for introducing the first diet soda, has seen its market share slip to 2.1 percent last year from a peak of 5 percent in 1979, according to Beverage Digest.

HEADLINE: Robert H. Brimberg, Executive Of Securities Business, Dies at 64

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Robert H. Brimberg, a Wall Street executive who was known for the lunches he held so that major investors could meet each other and talk about their business, collapsed and died at a restaurant in Manhattan Thursday night. He was 64.
The cause was cardiac arrest, his family said. 
 He headed Brimberg & Company, a small securities business by Wall Street standards, but he was legendary for his lunches and his Christmas parties.
He was a big man and in "The Money Game," a 1967 best seller about Wall Street by Adam Smith, Mr. Brimberg was portrayed under the name of "Scarsdale Fats."
His personality and the stature of those attending his lunches were the main attractions for guests. His pointed questions and sometimes brusque manner cut through platitudes and kept the meetings lively and popular.
"The price of admission was that you had to have something to say," said H. Erich Heinemann, an economist. "He ran the only true salon, in the 17th-century French meaning, for the investment community."
Arther Lipper 3d, an investment banker and friend who was dining with Mr. Brimberg when he died in a Chinese restaurant in midtown, said that Mr. Brimberg "was the intellectual peer of those he dealt with, but because he did not feel the need to be intellectually competitive with them, he could get people to talk about what they were doing."
Mr. Brimberg graduated from Yale with a degree in English. He started his career on Wall Street after his father, a furrier, bought a small Wall Street firm because he thought the fur business was declining.
Soon afterward, Mr. Brimberg recognized that such institutions as pension funds, bank trust departments and mutual funds were emerging as the major forces in the stock market. Unable to offer research reports like larger firms, Mr. Brimberg began holding lunches in a spartan rented room on Broad Street.
His firm benefited from the lunches because major investors, out of gratitude for information gleaned through him, would use Brimberg & Company to handle some of their trades.
Mr. Brimberg is survived by his wife, Dorothy Anne, and three sons, Frederick of New York, Richard of Greenwich, Conn., and Christopher of North Miami, Fla., and one grandchild.
