HEADLINE: INVESTING;
When a Star Stumbles, Investors Are Bruised

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:
HOLLYWOOD publicists were only the first, long ago, to discover the economic power of celebrity. Mutual fund groups are trying to catch up.
"You can now join the client list of Fayez Sarofim," boomed a recent advertisement for the Dreyfus Appreciation Fund. In a movie poster layout, the credit list showed that the Ford Motor, Rice University and Oregon State pension funds have been Sarofim clients for decades. 
 Most of these clients have enjoyed returns far better than the Standard & Poor's 500 benchmark. But the smaller investors attracted to his Dreyfus mutual fund have watched their advantage disintegrate. Since Mr. Sarofim took over at the end of 1990, the fund bested the S.& P. 500 by 8 percentage points in 1991, then fell 3.3 points behind last year. So far this year, it has lagged the S.& P. by almost 8 percentage points.
The fund's recent retreat illustrates the risks of betting that a star money manager will continue to shine. The picks that made Mr. Sarofim a hero through the late 1980's -- the consumer and drug stocks -- have fallen into decline.
Mr. Sarofim is by no means the only money manager seized by the marketing wizards. By night, Rockefeller Center's Rainbow Room might feature Rosemary Clooney crooning or Tommy Tune dancing; by day, several weeks ago, it was Peter Lynch lunching, with the news media reveling. Mr. Lynch no longer manages a Fidelity fund, but still looms large in its advertisements.
Mr. Sarofim's case is special, however, because lately the performance that earned such renown has withered. Mr. Sarofim, understand, is the investment world's leading consumer of brand names. Through his firm, based in Houston, he is the largest institutional investor in such stocks as Philip Morris, Pepsico and Procter & Gamble, as well as in such drug issues as Pfizer and Merck.
Such companies led the market's advance into the early 1990's. Year after year, they raised their prices faster than inflation, no matter what the economy's state.
Their retreat started last year, as investors migrated to cyclical issues. Beginning in August, drug stocks cracked under Bill Clinton's repeated attacks on medical costs.
Then came Marlboro Friday, early last month, when Philip Morris cut the price of its leading brand to meet competition from private and discount labels. The stock collapsed, with the damage soon spreading to other name-brand companies.
Just last week, it was Tambrands' turn. The company's stock, a Sarofim favorite, fell $5.50, to $45.375, last week, on word that the Tampax brand, dominant for half a century, has been losing market share.
Dreyfus says that money continues to flow into the fund Mr. Sarofim manages. But with other institutions fleeing many of his favorite stocks, the small fry might be wondering whether to swim away from his fund.
Many financial advisers counsel patience in such cases. When managers with superior long-term records begin to waver, they say, it's worth giving them a year or two to straighten out. Wall Street fashions, as changeable as Seventh Avenue's, can penalize money managers whose long-range strategies remain sound.
Investors who kept their money in funds that buy small technology stocks had to endure several dry years to enjoy the run-up that began in late 1990. Sarofim clients who left him in the early 1980's as energy stocks, then his core holdings, staggered, missed out on their comeback.
Mr. Sarofim's conservative investment style -- buy and hold, and hold, and hold -- keeps turnover and expenses low. In 1990, the Dreyfus Appreciation Fund's portfolio turned over almost twice. In 1991, the first full year under his management, turnover was a mere 13 percent.
His stability compounds his gains. Mutual fund managers who regularly sell stocks to take their gains have to pay out taxable distributions.
But what if the downfall of consumer growth stocks is no investor whim, rather a long-term recognition that cigarettes, processed cheese and tampons aren't so glamorous? Investors sometimes do wring out vast industries. As smartly as banking stocks have rebounded, analysts doubt they will return to the premium price ratios, compared with their earnings, that they enjoyed decades ago.
Many analysts say that Marlboro and other brands have lost huge chunks of their value, as shoppers switch to generics or private labels at half the price. The President himself has vilified drug companies and vowed to control their prices.
Mr. Sarofim says that consumer- goods producers still have vast growth prospects abroad. Drug makers, he says, can aid the battle against medical costs because their medicines allow patients to avoid expensive hospital stays. "To go from the most admired to the most hated is a little incongruous," Mr. Sarofim said. "The markets have discounted most of the negative news."
His fund's investments in oil stocks and such industrial issues as General Electric and Ford have buffered his recent losses. But he agrees with some institutional clients that his style might be best for those who can spread their money among a host of managers.
Jay Fewel, who oversees stock investments for Oregon's pension fund, plans to retain Mr. Sarofim as one of 16 managers. "Much as a manager will diversify among securities, we diversify among fund managers," he said. "If our entire stable of managers had his focus, there would be some concern."
As there might now be among individual investors unwilling to follow 16 mutual funds.

HEADLINE: Blacks Accuse Jews In 'Show Boat' Revival

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, April 28

 BODY:
"Show Boat Hurts," reads one picketer's sign. Others say: "Stop This Racist Play" and "Terrible Use of Taxpayers' Money." A statement from the Coalition to Stop Show Boat declares that "the entire play, its plot and characterizations demean black life and culture."
A score of people, mainly blacks, are on the sidewalks around a nearly completed performing arts center in the Toronto suburb of North York. The center's three theaters, one with treelike pillars merging into a gold-domed ceiling and another modeled on Amsterdam's Concertgebouw, and a 5,000-square-foot art gallery make the arts complex one of the largest in North America and the first to be built in Canada since the 1960's. 
 The $51 million North York Center for the Performing Arts is not scheduled to open until October, but it is already mired in controversy over the choice for its inaugural production, a new $8 million staging of the 1927 musical "Show Boat."
The dispute has challenged assumptions about one of the classics of the American theater and stirred tensions between this city's blacks and Jews.
A leader of the protest, Stephanie Payne, a school trustee in North York, publicly condemned "Show Boat," both the musical and the novel on which it was based, as an example of "hate literature" directed against black people. She also said Jews were responsible for most of the works that denigrate blacks.
Arnold A. Auguste, the publisher of Toronto's black newspaper, Share, lamented the Jewishness of the show's creators and its current producers. He said that of all people, Jews "must know what it is like to be reviled, denigrated and to suffer abuse."
"I feel my people's pain just as surely as you feel yours," he said in one column addressed to Jews.
But in a letter to Mr. Auguste, Gerda Frieberg, chairwoman of the Canadian Jewish Congress, angrily asked how Jewishness was relevant.
"We find it abhorrent that in the process of upholding your community's interests as you see them, you also have seen fit to besmirch, malign and wound our community."
"Show Boat," with music and lyrics by Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, was written in 1927 from a book by Edna Ferber. The musical has often been revived and was made into films twice, in 1936 and in 1951. This year it was chosen for a commemorative stamp by the United States Postal Service for the esteemed place it occupies in the history of musical theater. The cast of the North York production is to include Elaine Stritch and Robert Morse. The director will be Hal Prince and the choreographer Susan Stroman. Garth H. Drabinsky, its producer, said he hoped to take it to Broadway next year.
 
What's in the Show
 The story about life on a Mississippi steamboat at the turn of the century provides a picture of the lowly status of blacks and describes some consequences of racial hatred. Mr. Hammerstein, a liberal of his day, has been described by Miles Kreuger, who wrote a history of the show, as highly sensitive to the racial issue.
The musical helped make the artistic reputation of Paul Robeson, one of its early stars, whose rendition of "Ol' Man River" is considered one of the great moments of American theater. The politically active Robeson became a highly visible critic of discrimination.
But some prominent blacks in Toronto contend that the show romanticizes a dehumanizing era in black history, reinforcing negative images and stereotypes that are used to undermine black people. And they are critical of its selection as the vehicle for the opening of a publicly supported arts center in a community where blacks are a significant and growing proportion of the population.
Some 350,000 blacks live in Canada, about half of them in Toronto, according to 1991 census figures. The Jewish population was nearly identical, numbering 370,000, and about half of them live in Toronto as well. The population of Canada is 27 million.
" 'Show Boat' is not a true reflection of black history," said Jeff Henry, a professor of drama at York University and the founder of black theaters in both Toronto and Montreal. His Fountainhead Theater here closed during the 1990 recession, but his Black Theater Workshop in Montreal is still active.
 
By Whites, for Whites
 " 'Show Boat,' " he said in an interview, was "created by white people for white people at a time when black writers like Langston Hughes of the Harlem Renaissance were trying to define black dreams, hopes and ambitions."
Among the faults he found with the musical was its portrayal of blacks as "civil and accommodating" when in fact during the 40-odd years covered by the story of "Show Boat," "there were all kinds of protests and uprisings."
Angela Lee, the general manager of the Canadian Artists' Network: Black Artists in Action, a Toronto-based advocacy group, said the musical propagated a stereotype that was damaging for young black people.
"The portrayal of blacks as shuffling, mumbling, dancing, singing caricatures enhances the picture of a people who are not only happy in their condition but obviously better off with somebody looking after them," she said, adding that "slavery, Reconstruction and the post-Reconstruction period in the Americas was not about singing, dancing and joyful celebration."
Not all prominent blacks have been critical of the show. "Why boycott it?" asked former Lieut. Gov. Lincoln Alexander of Ontario. "How can I judge something if I don't go and see it?"
The Rev. Eustace Meade of the First Baptist Church of Toronto said he would be among the first to watch the show. "I have my own dignity and 'Show Boat' or whatever cannot demean me."
 
A Benefit Suffers
 Yet the strength of the negative feelings here was expressed in the resignation of 19 of the 22 members of the United Way's Black and Caribbean Fund-Raising Committee to protest the charity's participation in a benefit performance of the musical in October.
The "skeptical atmosphere, opposing views and tense climate" related to United Way's involvement in "Show Boat" make it "impossible to proceed with the planned fund-raising activities for the charity with the black community," said Delores Lawrence, vice president of the Black Business and Professional Association and a former United Way chairwoman.
Mr. Drabinsky, the producer, said he was convinced that the protest would blow over and had no second thoughts about the choice. "We needed something to show off this space musically that had shades of major operatic demands," said Mr. Drabinsky, president of the Live Entertainment Corporation of Canada, which has a long- term exclusive management agreement covering the three York Center theaters.
"There was nothing on the horizon that was available to us, so we went back to the canon of musical art," he said.
While he respects the right to protest, Mr. Drabinsky said, "the reality is that six months from now what they will see on the stage will be a wonderful evening of theater presented with dignity, integrity and great sensitivity, and I believe that nothing on the stage will offend one person in the black community."

HEADLINE: Stronger Yen, Weaker U.S.

BYLINE: By R. Taggart Murphy; R. Taggart Murphy is writing a book about the financial relationship between America and Japan.

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
Senate testimony by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and Federal Reserve market intervention have ended a successful campaign to push up the value of the yen against the dollar. The Clintonites stuck close to a script written by the Nixon, Carter and Reagan Administrations, which all turned to dollar cheapening as a "remedy" for "politically intolerable" trade deficits with Japan.
The scenario: Make public comments about how desirable it would be for the yen to get stronger. Use bullying tactics to keep Japan on board and the market guessing. When the rate shoots past the desired level, intervene to signal approval. Thus, once unthinkable rates -- 265 yen to the dollar in 1973, 180 in 1978, 145 in 1985 and now 110 -- become the norm. 
 Doubtless the Administration congratulates itself on the 13 percent revaluation of the yen. It should recall what happened after earlier scripts ended: A major crisis followed each decline in the dollar. OPEC's quadrupling of oil prices in 1973 was partly a reaction to the dollar devaluation that year. After the Carter Administration "talked down the dollar," there was currency havoc and double-digit interest rates. Two years after the Plaza Accord of 1985 -- which was convened to lower the dollar and was so "successful" that U.S. currency lost almost half its value against the yen -- Japanese investors dumped dollar securities after realizing that cheapening the dollar had done nothing to reverse the U.S. trade deficit. Five days later came the 1987 market crash.
Using the yen-dollar rate to cure the trade deficit makes things worse. In the past, each time the yen got stronger, the trade surpluses retreated a bit and then came back stubbornly higher and more intractable.
Boosting the yen is supposed to make Japanese goods more expensive and lead Americans to favor cheaper domestic products while Japanese consumers rush to stock up on low-price American imports. But Japanese companies have demonstrated they will do almost anything to hang on to market share abroad, while in Japan it is the producers -- not the powerless consumers -- who matter.
How do Japan's producers react to a stronger yen? They rationalize production and squeeze costs. When this is insufficient to maintain competitiveness, they move production offshore, where the high yen makes investing cheaper. Our trade deficit with Japanese companies is half again as large as our deficit with Japan because of Japan's investments in its rapidly growing neighbors. When we push the dollar down, our trade deficit with Japan becomes a deficit with all Asia.
With a stronger yen the Japanese can build factories and buy companies in the U.S. more cheaply than Americans can invest in Japan. As Dennis Encarnation's book "Rivals Beyond Trade" shows, the explanation for the trade imbalance lies in the lopsided difference between Japanese direct investment in the U.S. and American direct investment in Japan.
A combination of inflated Japanese real estate prices and a quarter century of dollar-bashing by successive U.S. administrations has made it impossibly expensive for U.S. business to establish more than a toehold in Japan.
The latest ratcheting up the yen has brought yowls from Japanese exporters, but it is also quietly welcomed. It weeds out inefficient firms, provides an excuse for reneging on implicit lifetime employment contracts and, most importantly, together with the currently contrived Tokyo stock market rally, eliminates the danger of a wave of foreign acquisitions of strategic Japanese companies.
The Administration has yet to learn that trashing the dollar is no substitute for a coherent Japan policy and that Japanese bureaucratic skill at blocking meaningful foreign participation in its economy is the real cause of the trade and investment imbalances.

HEADLINE: 'Foreign Aid' for Los Angeles

BYLINE: By Eric Mann; Eric Mann is director of the Labor/ Community Strategy Center, a community advocacy group.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
It has been a year since the urban rebellion in Los Angeles and just two weeks since "the verdict." The headlines from Waco and Bosnia obscure an inescapable truth: our society has written off the inner cities and their escalating, increasingly racially defined poverty.
In Los Angeles, the unemployment rate for black and Latino men between the ages of 17 and 35 approaches 50 percent; for 20-year-old black women it is 70 percent. More than half a million Latino and Asian immigrants labor in a sweatshop economy for annual wages of less than $10,000. As a report issued last week by the Labor/Community Strategy Center makes clear, public health centers, 24-hour emergency room services, parks and libraries are urgently needed by inner-city residents. But these are not on the way; the Los Angeles city budget deficit is expected to be $500 million this year. 
 The rebellion in April 1992 was just that, a rebellion, not a riot. Those who urge inner-city residents to adopt more constructive approaches should concede the limits of our society's reform efforts. Among the failed options:
* Elect a black mayor. In 1973, a multiracial movement elected Tom Bradley, a moderate who promised jobs and justice. The Bradley legacy has been a revitalized downtown business district, the transformation of the mayor's office into an adjunct to the Chamber of Commerce and the polarization of wealth and poverty. At every major juncture the Bradley administration sided with privilege and against the poor.
* Allow the private sector to take over government functions. Days after the rebellion, Peter Ueberroth, the former Olympic wizard, was crowned by Mayor Bradley and Gov. Pete Wilson to lead a private sector consortium to bring jobs to the inner city. A year later, the consortium and its market strategies have generated an avalanche of corporate public relations pitches, pre-empted far more militant and community-based efforts and, after defining the employment needs of South Los Angeles at 95,000 jobs, delivered at most a few thousand.
* Elect a Democratic President. Bill Clinton made an unspoken deal with the black community and progressives of all races: Vote for me as if your life depended on it, let me court the Reagan Democrats and the suburban middle class and after the election I'll address your concerns. A few months into his term, Mr. Clinton has focused on deficit reduction instead of poverty reduction, advanced the bankrupt strategy of enterprise zones and backed down on his own "economic stimulus" package.
A real war on poverty would mean dramatic increases in Aid to Families with Dependent Children, funds for education and housing and direct transfers of income. It would include an $8-an-hour minimum wage and a prohibition of permanent replacements for strikers.
In the 1960's, the antipoverty movement momentarily captured the imagination and conscience of our society. It was subverted -- not, as revisionism has it, because you can't throw money at the problem, but because big city, usually Democratic, mayors suppressed the community action programs that were succeeding only too well at enlisting the poor.
There is a need for a national movement, multiracial and rooted in urban centers, to make the cities and social welfare programs the highest priority of the Federal budget. The proposals must be aggressive: the most radical taxation of corporate profits and individual wealth, immediate cessation of the savings-and-loan bailout and explicit rejection of deficit reduction as a Federal priority. One immediate intervention could set the tone for this strategy: deliver the $1.8 billion pledged to Boris Yeltsin to Los Angeles instead, as "foreign aid" to one of America's abandoned cities.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Hundred-Day Headache

BYLINE: By Lester Bernstein; Lester Bernstein was formerly the editor of Newsweek.

 BODY:
After an interminable drumroll, the Roosevelt curse fell on Bill Clinton this week as he marked his 100th day as President.
Prompted by Frankin D. Roosevelt's Hundred Days -- the duration of the special session of Congress he convened five days after taking office on March 4, 1933 -- generations of journalists have gauged new Presidents by their performance in the same time frame. This time around, in the way journalists have of getting ahead of themselves, the judgments poured in early -- and harshly enough for a defensive Mr. Clinton to launch his own spin campaign. 
 One hundred days is certainly a nice round number, though a wholly arbitrary one based on a situation of economic crisis unparalleled in American history. Among other things, Roosevelt took the U.S. off the gold standard, saved the banking system and won passage of 13 major pieces of legislation including bank deposit insurance, billions of dollars in relief, Wall Street reforms, creating the Civilian Conservation Corps and the Tennessee Valley Authority, refinancing of home mortgages, creation of the Civilian Conservation Corps and, of course, the return of real beer. In the process, he gave 10 major speeches, sent 15 messages to Congress and met the press twice a week.
Mr. Clinton, the first President who was not yet born before Roosevelt's lifetime, may be the first to have touted his own 100 days before they started and before they were over. Last week, at his second press conference in three months, he brought up the subject, to give perspective, he said, to his widely criticized failure to get his economic stimulus bill passed. He offered a list of achievements, headed by the successful budget resolution (which must still be spelled out in future legislation), with a heavy smattering of plans for reform that have yet to be turned into law. And by broadcast and brochure, he kept plugging his claims.
He might have done better to play it cool in the manner of his predecessor and hero, John F. Kennedy. When Kennedy was working on his Inaugural Address, he told his amanuensis, Theodore Sorensen, "I'm sick of reading how we're planning another 'Hundred Days' of miracles." And the speech indeed read: "All this will not be finished in the first 100 days. Nor will it be finished in the first 1,000 days . . . . But let us begin."
Despite Kennedy's prescient effort to disarm the curse, his news conference of May 5, 1961, produced a request for his own appraisal of his 100 days. His complete response was: "Well, I feel I can read what you gentlemen write about it, and I wouldn't attempt to contradict you." A classy reply (despite the touch of period sexism).
Even Lyndon B. Johnson, F.D.R.'s political protege, whose blizzard of laws enacted in his five years rivaled the master's, rejected the role of 100-day wonder. Knowing the ways of Congress better than anyone else, he sent each bill to the Capitol only when the timing seemed right. "It's like a bottle of Bourbon," he explained. "If you take a glass at a time, it's fine, But if you drink the whole bottle in one evening, you have troubles. I plan to take a sip at a time and enjoy myself."
Actually, Kennedy tried hard for a dazzling first 100 days, coupling his natural glamour with a blaze of dynamic activity. "He did everything but shinny up the Washington Monument," wrote James Reston. But Kennedy's 100 days also included the Bay of Pigs invasion.
President Clinton should be grateful that the shortfalls blemishing his own start do not include anything so catastrophic. And perhaps he, and we, can find comfort in the thought that Roosevelt's achievements in the 73d Congress were possible only because the nation stood at the abyss.

HEADLINE: Libraries' Funds Cut as Use Hits Record Highs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your editorial "Saving New York's Libraries" (April 13) delivered an important message: Libraries are indeed more important than potholes in the Information Age. Yet many of our nation's libraries -- school, public and college -- struggle to keep books on the shelves and their doors open due to government funding cutbacks.
Public libraries nationwide report record-high levels of use by job seekers, students, the elderly and others in need of information, education and entertainment at the same time their funds have been cut by legislators or eaten away by inflation. In Massachusetts, 20 libraries have had to close in the last six years. In Syracuse, N.Y., there is no more telephone reference service, no more bookmobile or books-by-mail programs for the elderly and physically impaired as a result of budget cuts. There are waiting lists for preschool story hour in Philadelphia. 
 In California, more than half the school libraries have closed, and students have even less access to library service as a result of public library closings due to the state's budget crisis. In Austin, Tex., school officials estimate it would cost $3.5 million to replace the outdated materials on school library shelves. The average age of library books in Louisiana schools is 25 years, according a recent study. The cuts continue despite recent findings that there is a direct correlation between good school libraries and student achievement.
In Washington, the President has proposed cutting all Federal funds for college libraries -- funds badly needed to purchase the technology that will support the national electronic information network that both he and the Vice President have endorsed. These funds, a pittance of the Federal budget, can make a significant difference to college libraries struggling to provide students and researchers with the latest advances in information technology.
The good news is that voters show their support for libraries at the polls. A recent Gallup Poll found that members of the public believe that funding for libraries should be more than double the current national average of $18 per capita, less than the cost of a hardcover book.
Starting during National Library Week (April 18-24), the American Library Association and Friends of Libraries USA began providing an opportunity for members of the public to show their support. We are inviting people of all ages to write and share how the library has made a difference in their lives. Letters and postcards can be delivered to local libraries or sent to the American Library Association, 50 East Huron Street, Chicago, Ill. 60611.
This "testimony" will be used to deliver the message to our nation's legislators: Americans value and want their libraries adequately funded.
 
MARILYN L. MILLER
President, American Library Assn.
Chicago, April 22, 1993

HEADLINE: Aftertaste of Scandal in the Schools

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
On the day after the latest scandal broke over a South Bronx school board long known more for patronage than pedagogy, Eugenia Irizarry took stock of her term on the board and pronounced it a failure.
After 10 years as an active parent in Community School District 12, including four on the board, the hardest years of her life, Ms. Irizarry, decided not to run in the board election next Tuesday -- and she says she has not found another candidate worthy of her vote. 
 "I tell parents I will not support any candidates who are running, not one single one," she said. "The web just gets bigger and bigger."
In a scathing report on the affairs of the district, investigators said Ms. Irizarry had been a bystander as rival factions on the school board secretly parceled out principal's jobs, mainly to educators who promised to bring in contributions or votes -- or in one case, investigators said, pay a bribe.
Yesterday Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez began the formal process of taking over the district, where he has intervened repeatedly because of financial improprieties or personnel problems. He summoned the board to a meeting next Thursday, and school officials said he was likely to appoint a team to run the school district.
And just four days shy of an election in which three of the implicated board members -- along with two non-members also accused of improper political activity -- are seeking election, Ms. Irizarry and other parents and teachers said the affair had left them more bitter than bewildered about the entire system of community-controlled schools. They are not so much outraged, they say, as unhappily resigned.
"The parents who go to all the meetings and know the wheeling and dealing that goes on were not angry," said Maria Falcon-Cintron, the president of the parents association at Public School 102 in the district. "They were relieved it all came out."
Ms. Irizarry said it was almost impossible to bring the board to focus on educational issues in the central Bronx district, which has some of the lowest scores on math and reading tests in the city.
"It was like trying to move the Berlin Wall," she said. "Their agenda is politics."
 
Scenes on a Videotape
 The investigation by Edward F. Stancik, the special investigator for the New York City schools, led Wednesday night to the arrest of one educator, Virginia Noville, on charges that she passed thousand of dollars in bribes to a member of the school board to secure an job as principal of Public School 214.
The school board member, Edward Cain, had agreed to cooperate with authorities, after they produced evidence that he and several colleagues had pocketed the proceeds of a fund-raiser for which principals across the district were expected to purchase and sell tickets.
On a videotape, Ms. Noville is shown counting money and passing cash to Mr. Cain in front of Katz's deli on the Lower East Side. She also calls him her "godfather" in the district. Mr. Stancik's report also accused Councilwoman Lucy Cruz, a former school board member, of doling out principal jobs to supporters, and requiring school administrators to install a chandelier, plant flowers at her house, and chauffeur her around.
In his report, Mr. Stancik recommended that four members of the current school board be removed from office and the board be stripped of all hiring power. The board members he named include three who are seeking re-election on Tuesday -- Veronica James, Pablo Ortiz and Randy Glenn. The fourth named, Raul Cruz, is not running.
 
Chancellor's Acts Criticized
 Mr. Ortiz, the president of the school board, said he would meet with the Chancellor and would accuse him of engaging in "character assasination." Mr. Ortiz said that he had done nothing wrong, and that both the Chancellor and Mr. Stancik were "vicious individuals."
Another board member, Carmen J. Tarveras, said that the board would meet with the Chancellor as requested. She said that the report was "unfair" and that many principals appointed in recent years are "working hard to help our kids do their best."
But the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, said that the latest report of corruption in the district was not at all surprising.
"It has been an open secret that people have been selling principalships, and shaking down book companies," he said. "I'm really outraged. Every time a new scandal hits, they act stunned, shocked. It is like Claude Raines at the runway in 'Casablanca.' "
Mr. Ferrer called for new legislation requiring that parents make up a majority of all school boards, and if that fails to improve the system, for the community boards to be appointed rather than elected.
In District 12, Ms. Irizarry and other parents and teachers seem even more pessimistic.
"The morale is very low," said one teacher at P.S. 214 who would not give his name. "It is very hard to get a job in another district when you come from District 12."
For Ms. Irizarry, the problem is the poverty and ignorance of parents in the district, who she says are sometimes manipulated by principals who tell them that if a favored candidate is defeated, the school will lose money and programs.
"If I felt I could have made a change I would have stayed on," she said. "But I wasn't getting anywhere. I was getting really stressed out from fighting. Now we have all these religious groups supporting candidates because of the Rainbow Curriculum. Where were they when I was screaming about quality?"

A chart on Saturday listing candidates in local school board races in Brooklyn omitted an endorsement for Chester P. Lustgarten, a candidate in District 15. He has been endorsed by the Council of Supervisors and Administrators, the union representing principals and other school administrators.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: May 2, 1993,

SECTION: Section 7; Page 22; Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1148 words

HEADLINE: Crime

BYLINE: By Marilyn Stasio

 BODY:
Nobody appreciates that wacky social institution known as the American family more than Sue Grafton. In "J" IS FOR JUDGMENT (Holt, $21.95), the 10th mystery in her witty alphabet series, the author uses a cleverly executed fraud as yet another illustration of the ingenious crimes and misdemeanors that people will commit in the cause of domestic tranquillity.
Kinsey Millhone has seen it all in this series. But the cheeky private investigator who operates out of southern California is still pretty impressed with crafty Wendell Jaffe, who may have faked his own suicide and run off to Mexico with a chippy when his fraudulent business empire collapsed. "I'm not trying to defend the man, but he's not all bad," Kinsey finds herself explaining to one of the two bratty sons Jaffe abandoned. The kid isn't any more convinced than Jaffe's financial partner, who went to prison for him, or Jaffe's brittle wife, who has to surrender the insurance money if Kinsey can prove that her husband is still alive. 
 Ms. Grafton writes a smart story and wraps it up with a wry twist; but she takes care to sweeten her tart characterizations with amused understanding and, in the case of Jaffe, even affection. That this smooth scoundrel would risk his ill-gotten freedom out of familial concern touches a soft spot with Kinsey, a confirmed "outsider, a loner," who has just discovered relatives of her own. Let's hope they're total rogues.
There's nothing subtle about the crude criminal psychology that John Camp applies to his mad-dog killers in the suspense novels that he writes under the pseudonym of John Sandford: "He'd never had a chance, not from when he was a child. They'd always picked on him, victimized him, tortured him." That just about covers his analysis in WINTER PREY (Putnam, $21.95) of the predator who has sexually corrupted several children and their parents in a rural Wisconsin town, and who then goes on a homicidal rampage to protect his identity from Lucas Davenport, the formidable protagonist in this series.
But if Mr. Sandford can't be bothered with fancy psychology, he knows all there is to know about detonating the gut-level shocks of a good thriller. There's no release from the bombardment of visceral stimulation that begins with the slaughter of an entire family by the Iceman, a stealthy killer who slips through deep woods and over frozen lakes on a snowmobile. By the time he is cornered, after a land-and-air manhunt during a raging blizzard, a good deal of blood has frozen into ice.
Davenport, a cool, cynical man of action, is entirely in his element in this harsh terrain -- so bitter that it turns animals against men, so brutal that it turns men into beasts.
"Everything that had happened was connected in a logical way." Thus does Mary Higgins Clark instruct those of us dopes and skeptics who either can't follow or won't swallow the contrivances that support the elaborate plot of her new suspense thriller, I'LL BE SEEING YOU (Simon & Schuster, $23). "The minute you understand the structure," she reassures us, "everything falls into place."
True enough. There isn't a structural hair out of place in this twisted yarn about Meghan Collins, a television reporter who catches the eye of a killer while she is on assignment at an "assisted reproduction facility" for a feature story about in vitro fertilization. It's not logic, though, but common sense that is strained when Ms. Clark gussies up her woman-in-peril formula with a convoluted subplot that awkwardly links Meghan's deceased father with the shady doings at the fertility clinic.
Despite the excess narrative weight it has to lug around, the story moves swiftly and plays cunningly on the universal fear of parental loss and abandonment. And by voicing our secret anxieties about designer genetics -- what if some dummy lab technician drops my "cryopreserved embryo"? what if some thief steals it? what if I have somebody else's baby? -- Ms. Clark raises such horrid possibilities that, like Meghan, we have no patience for some silly killer lurking in the shadows.
After lying low for these past five years, Gabe Wager, the rugged Latino cop in Rex Burns's police procedurals, is swamped with heavy work when he gets back into action in ENDANGERED SPECIES (Viking, $19). There's been a gang killing on the west side of Denver, where the Gallos and the Tapatios are feuding over drug turf. Two cops get shot at the Blue Moon Bar and Grill, where someone else was recently knifed to death. On top of that, Wager can't get rid of Stovepipe, an ex-con who wants him to cosign a mortgage loan.
Except for the occasional pit stop at the Satire Lounge for enchiladas and green chili, Wager is one of those driven cops who are all business, and the worst piece of business he's seen in a long time is the incinerated corpse found in the ruins of an arson fire. When dogged police work turns up evidence that the arsonists are "eco-warriors" with incendiary designs on an atomic weapons plant, Wager finds himself working with an F.B.I. partner in a thrilling race to stop this doomsday mission.
Although it would normally boggle the mind to imagine a city cop going from street fights to terrorist plots, nothing seems inconceivable these days. And with the unsettling facts he delivers about local nuclear installations like Rocky Flats, Mr. Burns finds plenty of scary cause for hauling his lawman out of mothballs.
Mario Balzic has got a right to sing the blues, but he's also got a job to do. Balzic, the soul and conscience of K. C. Constantine's BOTTOM LINER BLUES (Mysterious Press/Warner, $18.95) and nine earlier novels, is the police chief of Rocksburg, an economically depressed and spiritually depleted town in western Pennsylvania that is still reeling from the collapse of its coal mines and steel industries. "Most of the people where I live are just like me, too old to find another job, too young for Social Security, and we ran outta unemployment . . . years ago," rants Nick Myushkin, a barroom philosopher they call the Mad Russian. "I mean we're back in the barterin' and poachin' stage."
A man of simple beliefs and deep compassion, Balzic has always managed to throw out the lifeline that keeps his neighbors from going under. But the hopelessness gets to him this time when he answers a call from a disturbed woman with a wild, sad tale of domestic violence. He's moved by her pain but put off by her craziness, and he lets the town malcontents distract him with their own long-winded, if poignant, blues.
Mr. Constantine, who has a golden ear for dialogue, has not lost his Whitmanesque feeling for the voice of this forgotten region. ("I speak for a lotta people who don't know how to speak," Myushkin says.) Like his dispirited hero, however, the author seems to have given up on his job, which is not singing the blues but telling stories.

PUB-DATE: May 2, 1993,

SECTION: Section 6; Page 28; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: David Geffen, Still Hungry

BYLINE: By Bernard Weinraub; Bernard Weinraub covers Hollywood for The New York Times.

 BODY:
David Geffen glances out the window of his black Lincoln Town Car, moving fitfully down Fifth Avenue toward SoHo. He's on the phone with one of his closest friends, Sandy Gallin, who manages Michael Jackson and Dolly Parton. There are messages to call Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House chief of staff; Arthur Liman, the lawyer; Leo Castelli, the art dealer; Ed Lampert, one of Geffen's financial advisers, and Jeffrey Katzenberg, the chairman of Walt Disney Studios.
Abruptly, Geffen hangs up the phone and points to a luxury condominium building on Union Square. "That was Klein's, Klein's department store, remember?" he says. "My mother used to buy bargains there, things that were dirty. She'd say, 'Americans are so crazy, you're going to have to wash it anyway.' " He laughs. 
 His loyal driver, Phil Singer, joins in the laughter. "Mothers are always right," says Singer, who used to work as a part-time driver for Madonna. Singer's decision to quit Madonna caused the superstar to stop talking to Geffen.
"Life is too short," says Geffen, as the car threads past 14th Street. It is one of his favorite expressions. "All Phil wanted was a full-time job so he could get health insurance for his family and a bar mitzvah for his son. She didn't want to hire him full time. So I did. And what was so remarkable was how angry she became. These people think they have a kind of divine right of kings. And what gets me is I've been extraordinarily helpful to Madonna."
David Geffen has been extraordinarily helpful not only to Madonna but also to, among numerous others, Katzenberg, Lampert, Castelli, McLarty and McLarty's boss. Geffen, who is the richest man in Hollywood (and also one of the most complex), helped raise millions of dollars for President Clinton in the election, and has now set his sights on a mountain more formidable than Hollywood -- Washington, D.C.
 AT 50, WITH A $1 BILLION FORTUNE, Geffen is hardly seeking a Cabinet job; but he's looking for an apartment in Washington and probably wouldn't mind serving on a Presidential commission or two. Asked if he ever saw himself working for the Administration, Geffen says, a little surprisingly: "No one's asked me. If somebody felt there was a job I could actually do I would consider it -- not out of any ambition to be in Washington, but I do want to rise to the occasion of serving there if warranted."
Even more surprising is Geffen's friendship with McLarty, the reserved, buttoned-down Little Rock businessman whose childhood friendship with Clinton led to his appointment as chief of staff. Like a lot of people, McLarty says that he enjoys talking to the Brooklyn-born mogul on the phone.
"We established a relationship at the economic conference in Little Rock," McLarty says. "It's a very easy relationship. We call each other. David's very selective in his calls to me. He's not aggressive or inappropriately assertive."
McLarty adds: "When he calls, he wants to know how things are going, how he can be helpful, what are the problems. Mostly David and I talk about the economic and business side. He doesn't really ask for anything, and doesn't have an agenda per se. He strikes me as someone who has handled his immense success in a very exemplary manner."
The enormousness of Geffen's wealth, while calming his temper and cowing everyone in sight, has hardly quelled his demons. Like his idols, those 1930's movie moguls who were born poor, had scant formal education and were brilliant and ferocious men, Geffen has a hunger for success that seems bottomless.
On virtually every level, Geffen comparmentalizes his life. There is the Wall Street world of his friends Felix Rohatyn and Herbert Allen Jr. There is the art world of Larry Gagosian, his ambitious dealer, and Castelli, whose Old World elegance dazzles Geffen. There is the music world of Allen Grubman, his lawyer, and other New York buddies who gossip with him on Saturday mornings over bagels at Barney Greengrass on the Upper West Side. There is the gay world of Miami and Fire Island. There is the Malibu world of the movie stars and studio chiefs who come to him for guidance. And now there is the political world of Washington.
Politically, the 5-foot-7 1/2, 148-pound Geffen is carving out a a powerful role comparable to the one played for many years in Hollywood by Lew R. Wasserman, the 80-year-old chairman of MCA. Wasserman, whom Geffen greatly admires, served as an adviser to Democratic Presidents and wielded enormous clout beyond his base in the entertainment industry. He was a behind-the-scenes kingmaker whose Beverly Hills home served as a virtual station of the cross for national political candidates. Geffen is already considered the Clinton Administration's Lew Wassserman.
Beyond politics, Geffen has far outdistanced Wasserman -- and just about every other friend or mentor. With a stock portfolio estimated to be worth $800 million, he is clearly one of Wall Street's top players. In just a few years, he has also become a prolific art collector, focusing on postwar Abstract Expressionists, and his sudden appearance in a SoHo or Madison Avenue gallery on a Saturday morning, often with his friend S. I. Newhouse Jr. in tow, tends to resemble the unexpected arrival of two four-star generals in a basic-training barracks.
Even Geffen's personal life has taken on a monumental public dimension. His announcement that he was gay at an AIDS benefit last November (he had previously announced he was bisexual) suddenly turned him into a spokesman on gay issues, a result he never intended. The revelation of his homosexuality also seemed to liberate him personally, a result he did intend. "He just seems so relieved," says the designer Calvin Klein, one of Geffen's closest friends. "He felt he could be a role model. Gay men are not necessarily thought of as the shrewdest businessmen in the world. He felt he should do this publicly as well as for himself and he's really much happier."
But Ahmet Ertegun, a founder and co-chairman of Atlantic Records and a mentor of Geffen's, thinks Klein may be overstating the case. "I think David's probably as happy as he could be," Ertegun says carefully. Adds another friend, Terry Semel, the president of Warner Brothers: "Compared to the way he was 10 years ago, I would say that David now has the ability to enjoy life a little. He would say a lot. I'd say a little."
 MOST PEOPLE SEEM TO AGREE ON ONE thing about David Geffen: he is a man of contradictions. On the one hand, he appears totally unpretentious. The jeans and T-shirt that mark his sartorial style mirror a no-nonsense directness in his approach to friends. "He's voracious in his criticisms," says Jeff Katzenberg. "When he sees a movie of mine he doesn't like, he massacres me. But it comes from a place of total generosity."
Geffen can also be generous toward employees. Upon her retirement, he gave his longtime secretary 1 percent of the sale of his record company, which made her $5 million. Yet Geffen also has a take-no-enemies side. He has often been singled out for the Machiavellian role he played in the 1990 downfall of the temperamental Walter Yetnikoff, the former head of CBS Records. (Geffen calls the reports "Hollywood silliness.")
"David will do anything for you if you're his friend," says Howard Rosenman, a movie producer and, yes, a friend. "But if you're his enemy, well, you might as well kill yourself."
Although Geffen has a mind like a laser and writes nothing down as he makes call after call, deal after deal, he remains insecure about his lack of college education. As a result, he's flattered -- perhaps more than he should be -- by all the attentions lavished on him now.
If Geffen has had one conspicuous failure, it is a personal one: his inability to maintain a long-term relationship. Although Geffen is remarkably candid, he winces and struggles when talking about his current personal life. "I aspire to have a relationship with somebody," he says. "I haven't always been successful at it. But being gay is very different from being straight in the area of relationships. Of course, there are gay people who've had a long-term relationship for 50 years, but they're not the rule. And it's difficult to be in a relationship with someone as well known and wealthy as I am. There's a disparity that works in heterosexual relationships that doesn't work in homosexual relationships." His last serious relationship, he says, ended in 1989.
Paradoxically, Geffen's most intense and longest-term relationship was with a woman -- Cher. The two, lovers in the early 70's, maintain a close, if somewhat turbulent, friendship.
"We slept together and, believe me, I know the best and worst of David," Cher says. "It's impossible to get along with him -- his mind just moves so quickly. He's always brighter than everybody else. I kept saying to him, 'Sweetheart, you have a sweet side to you, a vulnerable side, but then you can be so mean and awful to people. Yeah, people are terrified of David -- his temper, his intelligence. He's not afraid of anybody."
Cher laughs. "We were like children when we met," she recalls. "I had been married at 16, and came out of the marriage at 27. I knew nothing. David had never had an affair with a woman. He literally took me in, fed me, gave me money, got me a lawyer. He was my best friend and he wanted to marry me and I just couldn't do it. But we were madly in love for about two years.
"He still calls me and says, 'Sweetheart, come over for dinner and we'll watch a movie.' So I go to his house in Malibu and we eat dinner and he tells me how uninformed and ridiculous my life is and asks me what stupid things I'm doing and do I have a boyfriend, and I say no. And then we watch a movie and he always wants to turn it off because he's bored by it, and I say no, and I make him watch it and that's how the evening goes."
ALTHOUGH Geffen frequently points out that he was a multimillionaire in the music business at 25, his enormous wealth was a result of ferocious ambition and intelligence -- as well as a little bit of luck.
In November 1990, Matsushita Electrical Industrial Company of Japan bought the entertainment conglomerate MCA for more than $6 billion. At the time Geffen owned 10 million shares of MCA stock -- a result of the sale of his company, Geffen Records, to MCA early that year. In a single stroke, Geffen realized more than $700 million from the Matsushita sale. His investments since then, coupled with his real-estate holdings, art collection and film-company profits have made him a billionaire.
While he wears jeans, sneakers and Gap T-shirts, shaves only when necessary and shows up at Christie's auctions on Park Avenue defiantly wearing a white painter's cap backward, Geffen lives an awful lot like a sultan.
For years, his main home has been an elegantly Spartan beach house behind an unadorned wall on Pacific Coast Highway in Malibu, with pale wood floors and a vast expanse of glass overlooking the Pacific. He also owns a seven-room apartment on Fifth Avenue in New York, designed by his favorite architects, Charles Gwathmey and Robert Siegel, and replete with dark green marble floors and striking paintings by David Hockney, Jasper Johns and Willem de Kooning on the gray-blue walls. An incongruous exercise bike that Geffen never uses rests like a piece of sculpture in the living room, but this will soon be discarded. He just bought the upstairs apartment and is turning part of it into a gym.
Compulsively neat, Geffen sits most days in New York at his custom-made oak desk beside a window overlooking Central Park, working the phones or reading letters, memos and faxes, then tearing them to shreds. Because of his ability to retain information, his desk is paper free.
Geffen also has a home in the mostly gay community Fire Island Pines, and is shopping for beach-front property in East Hampton. But his biggest real-estate prize to date is the fabled Jack Warner estate in Beverly Hills, for which he paid $47.5 million three years ago. It's an expansive 10-acre property on which he's spending millions more, gutting and renovating. His goal is to reopen the house in December for a huge Democratic fund-raising event, whose principal guest might be the current occupant of the White House.
Yet Geffen professes dismay at the house. "A staggeringly stupid thing to buy -- do you know an Arab sheik who wants it?" asks Geffen, now sitting in his $26 million Gulfstream 4 as the plane glides over the San Gabriel wilderness after takeoff from Burbank Airport for New York. The specially designed, lushly carpeted plane is equipped with a state-of-the-art satellite communications system, hundreds of movies and enough bagels and lox to feed the entire Catskills on a Sunday morning.
Characteristically, Geffen speaks of the mansion with the same cold detachment that has marked the decisions he has made for years about investments, talent, employees and friends. "I was always fascinated by this house," he says. "Once, the gates were open and I drove in just to see it, and in four seconds there were police cars and sirens and they threw me out." After Ann Warner, Jack Warner's widow, died, Geffen called Sandy Gallin and asked him to take a ride with him to the Warner place.
"Well, we walked in and they said they got an offer from a developer to subdivide the property, and all of a sudden I got protective about it," Geffen recalls. "So I bought it, with everything in it, instantly. I just bought it with all the furniture, all the scripts, all the Oscars, everything.
"I mean, this is the home of one of the men who created the town and the industry," he says. "I had worked for Warner Brothers most of my adult life, and I was totally enthralled by the world that this guy had created. So I bought the house. And I sold Warner Brothers all the scripts, the Oscars, the mementoes for $3 million, which they're going to use for a museum. I sold some of the rest of the stuff for $7 million. And I kept millions of dollars of furniture and silver. So I was really paying about $34 million for prime Beverly Hills property."
He smiles.
But, he is asked, are all these extravagant homes really necessary?
The smile vanishes. "You say extravagant -- well I'm a very wealthy man," he says. "I've earned all this money. I've worked for it. I didn't cheat anybody. I didn't issue junk bonds and put people out of work. I earned it. And I live relatively modestly given my level of success and wealth."
ONE OF DAVID Geffen's closest friends says that Hollywood is like the Balkans. "There are duchesses and dukes and a court of sychophants," the friend says. "And David is one of the emperors. There's Mike Ovitz and there's David. Two emperors.
"And you have to pay your respects to both of them," he goes on. "And David sort of sits there in the darkness. Very quiet. You don't know what he's doing except controlling and manipulating. Sort of like the original-cast album cover of 'My Fair Lady.' That's David. But he's tired now, he's tired of the con artists and the hustlers and all these betraying human beings here. And he wants more. He wants clout on a bigger stage. And he's doing it."
It's 11:15 A.M., and Geffen is, as usual, on the phone in his Fifth Avenue apartment. He's speaking to Bob Burkett -- a former political adviser to Ted Field, the department-store heir and movie producer -- whom he hired this year to run the David Geffen Foundation. Geffen finances the foundation with the $600,000-a-year salary he earns from MCA heading his own record company, as well as earnings from being a movie producer and theatrical investor. The private foundation gives away $5 million to $8 million each year to such causes as AIDS, homelessness, abortion rights and assistance to Ethiopian and Soviet Jews settling in Israel, as well as substantial donations to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art.
Geffen's new interest in politics was sparked, he says, by the Republican National Convention last August in Houston. "Really, it scared me," he says. "They didn't care about anybody but white, Christian, heterosexual males." Before the convention ended, Geffen was on the phone to an old friend, Mickey Kantor, the Los Angeles lawyer who headed the Clinton campaign and is now United States Trade Representative. Geffen became a major contributor and fund-raiser, helping to fill Democratic Party coffers with millions. Since the election, he has been invited to a number of conferences at the White House and has spoken at least a dozen times with President Clinton.
Geffen remains an unabashed Clinton fan, brushing aside any criticism that the President appears to be backing away from his commitment to end the ban on homosexuals in the miliary. "He intends to overturn the ban," Geffen says firmly. "He's going to do it."
The phone keeps ringing.
A friend, the investment banker Herbert Allen Jr., offers a potential investment. Geffen passes it up. Then he takes a call from Ed Rosenblatt, the president of Geffen Records in Los Angeles, about record sales and airplay for some of the company's major stars -- Guns 'n' Roses, Aerosmith, Nirvana. Although he's no longer interested in bankrolling Broadway shows, Geffen has earned substantial amounts of money as a producer of or major investor in (Continued on page 45)
hits like "Dreamgirls," "Cats," "Miss Saigon" and "M. Butterfly."
He talks with Felix Rohatyn, senior partner at Lazard Freres, about the Clinton Administration's budget proposals.
Another call comes in from an agent at Creative Artists Agency in Los Angeles about a deal to star Brad Pitt in the movie version of the Anne Rice novel "Interview With the Vampire." It's a project that Geffen has been consumed with producing for several years. (Despite such successes as "Beetlejuice" and "Risky Business," Geffen has not quite reached the level of success as a movie producer that he has in the music business. One notable flop with critics, the trashy "Last Boy Scout," is still an acute source of embarrassment to him.)
Another call, this time from Sandy Gallin. They are planning to see the Off-Broadway comedy "Jeffrey" by Paul Rudnick, about a gay man who decides to give up sex in the age of AIDS. Diane von Furstenberg and Fran Lebowitz are set to join them. Geffen's close circle of friends in show business include homosexuals and heterosexuals, but he speaks with rage at insinuations that there's a "gay mafia" in Hollywood.
"Let's just say that there are successful gay people who are aware of each other," he says. "And if you're in a minority group that comes with the territory. But if you talk about a gay mafia involved in some kind of nefarious activity, that's ridiculous."
Coincidentally, he tosses over several letters congratulating him on his decision to declare his sexuality last fall. "I wasn't looking to be gay," he says. "I was quite upset when I discovered that was part of my life. I wished it would go away. But you can't change who you are. And I tried to fight it in the beginning. And then I had a cancer scare in the mid-70's. And that turned out to be a mistake, and I thought, 'Life is too short.' "
A call comes in to Geffen from Larry Gagosian, a longtime friend who, like him, started in the mail room of the William Morris Agency. Gagosian, whose abrasive tactics have made him a controversial figure in the Madison Avenue art world, advises Geffen on his expanding collection of Jasper Johns, Jackson Pollock, Roy Lichtenstein, Willem de Kooning, Barnett Newman, Frank Stella and Andy Warhol.
"I've decided this is one of the few good things to do with my money," says Geffen. "In the end, you're just a renter anyway. You only own these things for as long as you live. After that, who knows? If I live until I'm 80, I'll have 30 more years of collecting. If the collection is big enough, I'll build a museum. And if not, I'll leave it to a museum."
In the meantime, Geffen has been reading and tearing up the faxes and notes on his desk. There are several sad, hand-scrawled letters from men with AIDS -- or families of AIDS-stricken patients -- asking for money. All the letters will be answered. Every now and then, when a letter deeply touches him, or comes from someone he once knew, he writes a check for as much as $10,000.
At about 11:30, Geffen makes an impromptu decision to have lunch with Kirk Varnedoe, director of the Museum of Modern Art department of painting and sculpture. Varnedoe may or may not have a lunch date, but he eagerly agrees to see Geffen, a member of the museum's acquisitions committee. They meet at Michael's on West 55th Street, where the talk ranges from the museum's expansion plans to the dangers and high costs of shipping paintings to exhibitions.
In the limousine afterward, on the way to Calvin Klein's offices in the garment center, Geffen says: "In the field of art, to be able to have lunch with Kirk Varnedoe is thrilling. I met him at Si and Victoria Newhouse's dinner one night. Barnett Newman's widow was there. That's the part of me that's a fan. Like when I was a kid and went to the Brooklyn Paramount. Well, my interest has expanded, and it's not just rock-and-roll."
HIS BACKGROUND -- AND his upward ascent -- resemble the rise of the mythic executives he idolizes -- Louis B. Mayer and Harry Warner.
He talks a great deal about his mother, a diminutive immigrant named Batya Geffen, who called her younger son "King David" and supported the family with a corset-and-brassiere business in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn. She died in 1988. Yet it was his father, Abraham, who probably had the greater impact.
"My father died in 1960," says Geffen. "He was an intellectual. . . . She made the money and he read a lot. He wasn't successful or ambitious. He spoke lots of languages. There were times that kids said to me, 'What does your father do?' and I had to make something up because I actually didn't know what he did."
At New Utrecht High School, where in his senior yearbook he predicted he would be a dentist, Geffen graduated in 1960 with a barely passing 66 average. He tried a semester at the University of Texas, and then Brooklyn College, but dropped out, hungering to earn a living in the entertainment business and to live in Los Angeles, which seemed, for him, as far away from Brooklyn as the moon.
He worked for a while as an usher at CBS and landed a job in the mail room of the William Morris Agency, a training ground for agents. Because the agency demanded college graduates, Geffen lied and said he had just completed U.C.L.A. Convinced that his employers would check, he arrived at dawn every morning to open the mail. When the letter from U.C.L.A. finally arrived, he steamed it open and inserted a forged note on university stationery that he had graduated. It was then that he began a close friendship with another agency employee, Barry Diller.
GEFFEN WAS TOLD BY older agents that the only path to success for a young man was the fledgling music business. He began hunting for talent and soon found the brooding singer and composer, Laura Nyro, who wrote a string of Top 10 hits for other artists. When her publishing company, half-owned by Geffen, was sold in 1969 to CBS, Geffen received $2 million in CBS stock. He was 25.
In 1970, the relentlessly aggressive agent-turned-manager started his own record company, which was called Asylum because, he says, "it was all craziness." Geffen's skill at tapping talent was extraordinary: Joni Mitchell, Jackson Browne, Linda Ronstadt, the Eagles. After running the company for five years, Geffen sold it to Warner Communications. In 1975, its chairman, Steven J. Ross, named Geffen vice chairman of Warner Brothers, the company's Hollywood studio. The job's corporate and bureaucratic restrictions left him stifled.
He quit in 1976, wealthy and unhappy. Later that year bladder cancer was diagnosed, and he dropped out of business altogether, spending a lot of time with the sybaritic crowd at Studio 54 as he waited to die. It was the age just before AIDS -- and Geffen partied, taught business courses at U.C.L.A. and Yale and started to buy art and real estate.
In late 1979, the cancer scare proved to be a false alarm. Geffen lined up backing for his own record label, Geffen Records, from Mo Ostin, then the chairman of Warner Brothers Records.
It is common lore in Hollywood that Geffen was constantly in search of father figures, and found one in Steve Ross. Actually, the man who proved to be his mentor was Ahmet Ertegun, head of Atlantic Records. "Ahmet took a fatherly interest in me," Geffen says. "Steve never took a fatherly interest. I was an asset of his."
IN HIS FEARS OF growing increasingly isolated, Geffen is haunted by the specter of Ross, the chairman of Time Warner who died of cancer last year. Geffen had broken furiously with Ross, his one-time boss in the late 1980's, after a sharp disagreement over the value of his music company. The breach never healed, even as Ross lay dying. And what Geffen realized was that despite Ross's public reputation for social as well as business acumen, he died a lonely man, his life clouded by a series of troubled marriages, a distant family and few real friends.
"He did not have an easy life, Steve," says Geffen, cryptically. "He didn't make it easy for other people but he sure didn't have an easy life."
Geffen is sitting in his Eames chair in his open, simple, Zen-like office atop the two-story building he used to own on Sunset Boulevard near Beverly Hills. (Geffen bought the building in 1985 for $5 million and sold it in 1991 for $13.5 million.) The office -- like all homes he owns -- is sparely furnished.
"We all die unhealed," Geffen says firmly. "We all acquire damage as infants and children and we work on removing those scars all of our lives. You won't heal everything, but what's important is the work.
"I'm a great believer in anything that makes you 1 percent better," he goes on. "So I try everything. Freudian. Jungian. Est. Life Spring. Course in Miracles. Twelve Steps. I have pain from time to time. I have joy from time to time."
Geffen is asked what more he could want, and to talk about his future. He takes a sip of herbal tea. "Do any of us really have a clue? We don't know what's going to happen tomorrow. Or what word will come up in a conversation that will change our lives. You can be in the shower and scrubbing under your arm and find a lump that wasn't there yesterday. I'm doing things here and now. Life is evolving. Every day life evolves."
"Evolving" is one of Geffen's favorite words, but his close friends say his life, while more serene than before, is hardly moving toward contentment.
"Washington? This is an entirely new sphere for David," says Barry Diller, the former Fox executive who is now chairman of the home-shopping network QVC. "Think if it in geopolitical terms and David putting it in balance with the other spheres of his life."
But what does David want?
"What does David say?" Diller replies with a slight taunt.
And Gallin, clearly nervous about speaking of his close friend and offending him, says Geffen's life is a complicated one. "Is he lonely? Well, he's too busy to be lonely." And then he pauses and says, "I guess you can be a little lonely and always be busy."
AS GEFFEN WALKS INTO Calvin Klein's showroom, the designer is frantically preparing for a new fashion show of men's jeans and clothing. Klein hugs Geffen. The two are old friends but, beyond that, it was Geffen who bailed out the designer last year by buying up about $62 million in junk-bond debt of Klein's company, enabling it to avoid a principal payment.
As if that weren't enough, it was Geffen's idea to hire Marky Mark, the rapper, for only $100,000 to promote Klein's jockey briefs. The ads, and the financial results, were sensational.
Geffen's inner circle has come to rely heavily on his good advice. Jeff Katzenberg well remembers the time Geffen bluntly told him that the musical scores for Disney's animated films were lackluster and implored him to hire the team of Alan Menken and Howard Ashman to compose Broadway-style scores. The results were "The Little Mermaid," "Beauty and the Beast" and "Aladdin," which will probably make more money for Disney than any films in the company's history.
In the showroom, Klein and his business partner, Barry Schwartz -- the two grew up together in the Bronx -- are eager for Geffen's approval. The three men survey the jeans and jackets and shoes on the male models in the frenetic showroom.
"Is that the cool thing now, to turn up jeans at the bottom?" asks Geffen.
"It's very cool, David," says Klein.
"I'm so uncool," says Geffen.
"Look at the suits, David," says Klein.
"How much?"
"Generally $1,400 to $2,000, but now we're doing a line, less expensive, for the Bloomingdale's customer, the Macy's customer. Not the expensive stuff like Barneys and Bergdorf's."
"I like it. How much are the jeans?"
"Forty to fifty bucks in the store. Retail."
"Terrific," says Geffen. "The pockets look great."
"It's the poor look," says Klein. "It's the 90's. You don't want to look rich."
Geffen, who's wearing finely pressed Calvin Klein jeans and Reeboks, nods.
ON THE FLIGHT BACK TO LOS ANGELES Geffen eats licorice jellybeans as he watches the first cut of "M. Butterfly," the film adaptation of the hit play he produced. The film, which stars Jeremy Irons, was directed by David Cronenberg and is not set to be released until the fall. But as soon as the movie ends, Geffen grabs the phone and tries to reach Terry Semel, the president of Warner Brothers, who is in Aspen.
When he finally connects, Geffen is exuberant. "Terry, I'm over the moon. I just saw 'M. Butterfly.' I mean . . . Academy Award. It's great. And I can't believe we made it for $17 million."
The other passenger on the plane is Edward Lampert, the 30-year-old president of E.S.L. Investments and a major investment adviser to Geffen. "I view us as being sort of in the stay-rich business rather than the get-rich business," says Lampert, who is catching a lift on the plane for a date with a woman in Los Angeles.
Geffen, as is his custom, is plying his passengers with potato knishes, delicatessen and fresh fruit -- and offering Lampert romantic advice. "Send her a bowl of tulips -- that helps," he says. Geffen calls his Los Angeles office to make sure that Lampert has a Mercedes waiting for him in Malibu.
At the Burbank Airport, a Lincoln Town Car is waiting for Geffen. Reaching home as darkness falls, Geffen bounds out of the car. His Pritikin cook, Edwin Saks, announces dinner: Cornish game hen, orzo with shiitake mushrooms, spaghetti squash, roasted bell pepper sauce and nonfat banana cream pie.
The whoosh of the Pacific's waves casts a stillness over the house. David Geffen picks up the phone to ask a friend if he wants to drop in for a movie.

(Photographs by Diego Goldberg/Sygma for The New York Times)(pg. 28-29); The former mail boy sorts the daily delivery in his Los Angeles office. A moguls' lunch with the agent Jeff Berg. Whatever his Washington ambitions, Geffen hasn't loosened his grip on Hollywood. Bruce Oppenheim, chiropractor to the stars, limbers up Geffen in his office. Dinner for one, with a view. Geffen in his $26 million plane. HEADLINE: ENDPAPER: PUBLIC STAGES;
Madcap Millionaires

BYLINE: By Frank Rich

 BODY:
THE GREEDY 1980'S stand in such disrepute that Michael Milken, desperate for a fresh, just-folks image, poses for photographs without his wig. "Barbarians at the Gate," the book about Wall Street buccaneering, turns up on television as a scabrous farce by Larry Gelbart, the author of "M*A*S*H." The big money, big hair and big scams of the Reagan-Bush decade now loom in memory as a decadent apocalypse to rival Weimar Germany and prerevolutionary czarist Russia. Yet once again America's love affair with madcap millionaires is heating up.
Times remain hard, after all, and the egalitarian buzzword of the new Clinton age, sacrifice, as yet offers more long-term hope than short-term help. In hard times, Americans traditionally turn to the fabulously rich and famous for escapist entertainment, and this economic drought has had no shortage of moneyed clowns. 
 Think of George Steinbrenner marking his baseball comeback by posing as Napoleon on the cover of Sports Illustrated. Or of Donald Trump choosing Broadway's fabled vaudeville shrine, the Palace, to announce Marla Maples's pregnancy. Or of Rupert Murdoch celebrating his re-entry into New York City's tabloid wars by having his limousine take him slumming about town to peek at the proletarian readers nostalgic for the salad days of Son of Sam.
Madcap millionaires have in fact rolled off the assembly line at The New York Post this year. First came grinning Steven Hoffenberg, who vowed to revive the paper by printing only good news, then found himself impaled by the bad news other papers reported about his financial empire. Next was Abe Hirschfeld, a crackpot whose fortnight as Post publisher passed instantly into local legend. It took the publisher of Screw, Al Goldstein, to sum up the emotions of a grateful city when praising Hirschfeld on Don Imus's morning radio show: "I like Abe because he makes me look very sane. He's the uncle who salivates, whose teeth are encrusted with food, who, at all public affairs, embarrasses you."
That's what we like about these millionaires: For all their money, they often look more ridiculous than we do. They are men of whom it can be said: If they're so rich, why aren't they smart? Their prototypes can be found in Hollywood screwball comedies of the Depression, in which the idle rich distracted the unemployed masses from their woes by sinking to a level of foolishness beyond the idle poor's means. In a typical Preston Sturges comedy, "The Palm Beach Story," the butt of the jokes is John D. Hackensacker 3d, played by Rudy Vallee. He spends a fortune to woo Claudette Colbert, who takes the money and runs back to her strapped inventor husband, Joel McCrea.
A half-century later, little has changed. In "Indecent Proposal," our own era's idea of a screwball comedy, it is Demi Moore who must decide between the madcap billionaire played by Robert Redford and her strapped middle-class husband, architect Woody Harrelson. Redford is in the madcap mold because he offers a million dollars (plus a new wardrobe) to sleep with Moore -- Vallee offered Colbert $99,000 (plus a new wardrobe) -- and because he has made his fortune without having any discernible profession. "He's not the better man," Harrelson protests to his wandering wife. "He's just got more money." That reassuring Hollywood moral never goes out of fashion.
IT'S WHEN THE RICH DO BEHAVE AS IF THEY think themselves better than anyone else that Americans bare their populist teeth and turn on them. We love the filthy rich as long as they act like rascals, not kings, and confine their overreaching to such certified playpens as show biz, gambling resorts and tabloid journalism. The love affair ends the moment they make a greedy or mean-spirited foray into the real world, whether to grab other people's money, treat commoners like dirt or flount 90210 morality in lower zip codes. Woody Allen and Mia Farrow were belovedly flaky as long as they kept their titillating unconventional off-screen relationship on screen. But once their private lives bled beyond the fairylands of "Hannah and Her Sisters" and Elaine's into a judge's chamber, they were seen as let-'em-eat-cake aristocrats, ripe for beheading.
In the televised "Barbarians at the Gate," the difference between a madcap millionaire and a despised millionaire is clearly drawn. The madcap model is vulgar, self-made, fun-loving F. Ross Johnson, played by down-home James Garner. By contrast, the leveraged-buyout czar Henry Kravis dines on rabbit in gilded royal surroundings and condescends to the help. Lest anyone doubt that Kravis's style of millionaire is un-American, he is played by a British actor (Jonathan Pryce).
For Bill Clinton, America's adoration of good ole madcap millionaires and rage at 80's money-grubbers presents a political mine field. While the President's domestic agenda is as democratic as F. D. R.'s, his millionaire-laden Administration, typified by Robert E. Rubin (1992 Wall Street salary: $26.5 million), is hardly madcap. Zoe Baird might have survived her trial in the court of public relations if she had played her big scene like Katharine Hepburn in "Bringing Up Baby" instead of Sigourney Weaver in "Working Girl."
But the billionaire Clinton must worry about most is one outside the White House: Ross Perot, whose last television address was broadcast the same weekend as "Barbarians at the Gate." The two Rosses seemed locked in an adorability contest. "I've never been a big fan of debt," said Garner's Ross Johnson on Saturday night, anticipating the other Ross's lecture on Sunday night.
Clinton has made a strategic decision to rip off Perot's madcap mask. So while Perot tries to sell himself as a populist billionaire who drives his own car, Clinton is determined to smoke out Perot the closet megalomaniac, more J. R. than James Garner, who takes his marbles and goes home when he can't get his way. When Perot refused to support the Administration's economic plan, the President began trying to expose the petulant Perot by needling him with insults.
And why not? Given the swelling ranks of Perot's unofficial third party, United We Stand America, the fate of the Clinton Administration may well ride on whether the Texan turns out to be the madcap hero of "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town" or just another mad barbarian at the gate.
