HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Smilin' Thru?

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
Congress is trying to pull a fast one on tax policy. No, this is not a diatribe about VAT -- for "value added tax," wrongly called the "VAT tax" by the Redundance Kids -- but a shot across the bow of Senator Dale Bumpers and Representative Robert T. Matsui, authors of a tax bill that would enshrine in law the informal spelling of through as thru.
Comes now (a fine legal archaism) Anne Heausler of the firm of Fulbright & Jaworski, L.L.P. (short for Limited Liability Partnership, which I assume combines the protection of a corporation with the camaraderie of a partnership) with a fax of a bill to amend the Internal Revenue Code. Our linguistically swinging legislators hope to provide capital gains savings for investors "who make high-risk, long-term, growth-oriented venture and seed capital investments in start-up and other small enterprises," a practice known on the Street as taking a flier on little cats and dogs. 
 Our solons want to create what they call a "pass-thru entity," which they define as "any partnership, any S corporation, any regulated investment company and any common trust fund." To drive home their enthusiasm for clipping the old-fashioned ough off through and substituting a zingy, with-it u, the would-be lawmakers add a section on a "look-thru in case of subsidiaries," which is defined incomprehensibly but I think is intended to mean "disregard," as in "That snooty White House legislative aide looked right thru me."
This practice is known as lite legislating, which occurs in Washington every nite. Simplified spelling is an enterprise that was undertaken with fervent dedication by no less a language maven than Noah Webster, and carried on with passion by George Bernard Shaw and later by Col. Robert McCormick, The Chicago Tribune's publisher, but never caught on, no matter how authoritatively or resolutely presented. Certainly usage tends to simplify spelling (alright, already), but native speakers hate to be told by philologists, advertising copywriters and other brisk neatness freaks how to fix the old lingo. We'll make it easier in our own time, the public seems to say -- just don't push us.
Merriam-Webster's Ninth New Collegiate Dictionary treats thru as an unstigmatized variant of through, but not even that publisher's anything-goes Dictionary of English Usage greenlites the spelling in noting, "Thru was on the first list of reformed spellings issued by the American Philological Association in 1876," adding, "As the organized interest in spelling reform waned, however, the use of thru in publications also shrank. . . . It remains a distant second choice in print."
The only place the hapless reform zips along at high speed is on the New York State Thruway, a thoroughfare that is not spelled throughway. The "reform" may make it into general speech one day; it's nice to see the old, unsimplified spelling hanging in there, tho.
Incidentally, many lawyers, even those who do not limit their liability, send faxes with a "confidentiality notice" boxed in funereal black. It goes: "The documents accompanying this telecopy transmission may contain confidential information belonging to the sender which [sic] is legally privileged. . . . If you are not the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any disclosure, copying, distribution or the taking of any action in reliance on the contents of this telecopied information is strictly prohibited."
Henceforth, when I get such foolish attempts at unsolicited solicitations from solicitors on the cover sheet of a fax, I will automatically blaze back with the fol lowing: "Your attempt to burden this machine, which is my personal property, with your unwanted and demonstrably unconfidential information is summarily rejected; my fax machine is programmed to spew out telecopies of whatever it receives, whenever it gets the urge, with happy abandon to all and sundry, and if you find such dissemination objectionable, you may cease and desist from further unsought importunings and stick your information printed on my paper in your ear."
Have I gotten thru?
 
LEFT IS NOT RIGHT
 "DOES IT BOTHER YOU as much as it does me," writes Ray Bradbury (whose new book is "Switch on This Night"), "to hear former Communist groups in Russia described as right-wingers or conservatives?"
Yeah, it does; where do those old-line radicals, loony lefties and die-hard pinkos get off trying to climb into my post-modern political lifeboat?
The problem is that the left-right spectrum no longer works. The bird metaphor began in 1707 in descriptions of the right and left wings of an army; in the French National Assembly, the radicals were seated at the President's cote gauche, or left side, with the conservative nobles on the right and the moderates in front. But confusion reigns today in the republics of the former Soviet Union, because the forces of change toward conservative market economies are described as being on the left, while the old radicals -- who long for a return to the discredited statist command economies -- are said to be on the right. What a halftime this has been!
Some newscasters, sensitive to the anger of American right-wingers at being lumped in with the apparatchiks of the Evil Empire they helped defeat, prefer a spectrum different from left-right. Sam Donaldson of ABC, for example, uses a variation of hard-soft, describing the former Communist leaders as hard-liners. However, this leaves only soft-liners to denote the reformers, and nobody likes to be called a softie. (This contrast began with the Hard Shells versus Soft Shells, also known as Barnburners, fighting over slavery policy at the 1848 Democratic convention in Baltimore.)
Metaphorically, where does that leave us? It's the reformers versus the hard-liners, which is no metaphor at all. Worse, the hard-liners want to change the current Yeltsin Government, not the usual goal of a hard line, while the reformers want to keep the executive in power, not the usual goal of reform.
Somebody is going to make a big reputation, maybe even a fortune, coming up with a new metaphor to describe the clash between returners to the old way and keepers of the new way. Lites and Heavies? Ups and Downs? Suggestions will be entertained.

The New York Times

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2999 words

HEADLINE: Waiting for Act 2 Around Times Square

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
THE three buildings certainly look impressive. There's 1585 Broadway, a silvery, 1.3 million-square-foot behemoth, towering over 47th and 48th Streets.
A couple of blocks south, between 45th and 46th Streets, there's 1540 Broadway, its green tint and striking prow highlighting its million square feet of bulk. 
 Then there's the small-by-comparison 750 Seventh Avenue, a stark black 580,000-square-footer perched between 49th and 50th Streets, once envisioned as Rockefeller Center's cousin to the west.
But an imposing presence does not a successful building make. And indeed, until recently all three seemed headed for disaster. Two were barely tenanted; one, 1540, stood totally empty. Lenders were snapping at their developers' heels and all three seemed to be sinking into a paralysis that neither their foreclosing lenders nor their besieged developers could ever pull out of.
Today, the buildings' fortunes are as disparate as their appearances.
Ian Bruce Eichner's project, 1540 Broadway, is out of the fiscal woods. Last year Bertelsmann Inc., the big German entertainment company, bought it as its headquarters for $119 million, and is all but moved in. Mr. Eichner and the lenders lost nearly $200 million on the building, but at least it is off their books. As for renting the retail space or any excess office space -- well, that's now Bertelsmann's problem, not theirs. And it's usually a lot easier to rent space in a thriving, occupied building, anyway.
David Solomon's 750 Seventh Avenue is looking to be the Little Building That Could. It has only one office tenant, Mendes & Mount, a law firm that took at a rock-bottom rent about 100,000 feet of "as is" space previously occupied by the now-disbanded law firm of Olwine, Connelly, Chase, O'Donnell & Wehyer.
But at least one company, Societe Generale, has expressed an interest in buying it -- albeit at a price that few expect the banks to accept. Caroline's Comedy Club has taken a chunk of the retail space and several office rental deals are said to be in the offing.
The one big loser seems to be 1585 Broadway, also a Solomon building. Thanks to ongoing disputes over the building's semi-finished condition, its sole occupant, the Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn law firm, did not begin paying rent for its 11 floors until last November, more than two years after it moved in..
And what had seemed a done deal only a year ago -- the sale of the building to Primerica Corporation, which would have used it to house its Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company stock brokerage unit -- fell apart when Sanford I. Weill, Primerica's chairman, arranged to buyShearson Lehman Brothers and made plans to shoehorn Smith Barney into vacant Shearson space.
Attempts to find another buyer, or even major renters, have been thwarted time and again by disagreements among the Bank of Montreal, Swiss Bank Corporation and the Toronto-Dominion Bank, the banks that control the building.
Why such different fates for properties that first seemed equally destined for greatness, and then equally destined to shoot down the tubes together?
All three were conceived in the mid-80's, when New York City's economy was vibrant, when Times Square redevelopment looked like it would really happen and when the city had relaxed its West Side zoning rules to allow developers to build the type of tall structures that offer gargantuan paybacks.
And all three had developers with glittering track records.
David and Jean Solomon, a husband-and-wife team, had made a fortune renovating Manhattan lofts in the mid-70's and later, building Tower 49, an office building on 49th Street east of Fifth Avenue that they later sold for multiples of its cost.
Ian Bruce Eichner, a lawyer turned residential real estate developer, had also done well with brownstones and condominiums and cut his commercial teeth on Cityspire, the office building on 56th Street between Sixth and Seventh.
But by the time the buildings were ready for occupancy, the New York economy had faltered, the Times Square redevelopment project was on hold and what had been a seller's market in commercial real estate had turned into one where renters and buyers dictated the terms.
The buildings sank into bankruptcy, making them even less attractive to the dwindling number of space-hunters left.
"Their lenders consistently overvalued the market and they just would never reach far enough to close deals," said Franklin Speyer, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate brokerage and management company.
Indeed, the answer to the divergent fates lies less in the buildings themselves or the economy that greeted them, than in the attitudes of the owners, the degree of risk-taking their banks would allow and, in a few cases, pure luck.
 
1585 Broadway
A Home-Run Deal Proves Elusive
 WITH bankruptcy goes bureaucracy, and with bureaucracy goes stretched-out negotiations. That, more than anything else, has kept 1585 Broadway relatively empty and unsold.
"If the banks had moved quicker, the sale would have been a done deal by the time Sandy Weill made his acquisition," said one broker.
This may or may not be true. After all, Mr. Weill might have persuaded Smith Barney to use its own stalling tactics while he was negotiating the Shearson acquisition.
Nonetheless, an inability to agree on anything seems to pervade the building to this day.
"This is a good building, with great large floorplates and a lot of usable space," said Richard S. Hayden, whose architectural firm, Swanke Hayden Connell, has analyzed the building for potential buyers and renters. "The deals are falling apart because of the negotiation problems."
Mr. Solomon declined to rehash painful memories, but those close to him say his frustration has been monumental.
"He had deals with tenants up and down the board, but the banks simply wouldn't give the go-ahead," said one associate.
Mr. Eichner, for one, offers him total sympathy.
"It's like the Vietnam peace talks over there, where they can spend six months arguing about the shape of the table," the rival developer said. "I don't think anyone short of Attila the Hun could deal with that bank group."
Officially, Mr. Solomon's investment group still holds title to the building. In March, though, the bankruptcy court approved a reorganization plan that will ease the transfer of ownership to the banks. No one expects that to break any impasses, though.
Apparently, the banks are still looking for a home run -- a buyer for the entire building, or at least a tenant large enough to take many floors as well as the building's base.
"I wanted to show a 100,000-foot tenant the top floors and the banks weren't even interested in showing the space," said Franklin Speyer, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield.
David T. Lawrence, senior vice president of Hines Interests Limited Partnership, which is now representing the building, concedes that anything less than a mega-user doesn't interest him much, at least for now.
"It's just not always good strategy to lease the best space first," he said. "You don't want to lose a user who will take 350,000 feet and the base because you rented someone else the top of the building."
Potential buyers are not exactly tripping over each other.
Jarchow Investment Group of Dallas and Kuwait International Investment Corporation bid on the building a few years ago, but their joint bid was not pursued because the banks were so sure the Smith Barney deal would go through.
Mr. Lawrence said the Jarchow deal was still on the table, but "there's been a lapse in communications, and negotiations are not currently active."
The problem again is probably price. A speculative investor would face enormous workletter costs to rent the space and would probably offer no more than $130 million or so for a building that cost nearly triple that to build. There's no reason to expect the banks will take that kind of bottom-line hit.
"Banks are always terrified of selling a building cheap and two weeks later having the buyer flip it at twice the price," said Alan J. Pomerantz, head of Weil, Gotshal & Manges's real estate department. "It's always, 'Let's just wait a few more weeks and see what we can get.' "
There's been some good news, though. Proskauer, which had sued the banks and Solomon Equities, has finally settled and begun paying its rent. And, although it seems far from a satisfied tenant, it has expressed no desire to move.
"We would certainly have expected them to have finished the elevators and the building's base long before this," said Herbert T. Weinstein, a Proskauer partner, "and it really would be nice to have other tenants in the building."
Mr. Lawrence admits to frustration, but not to depression. "The activity we see at 1540 and 750 encourages us," he said. "At least it shows that the West Side is an acceptable location."
 
750 Seventh Avenue
Hurry Up and Wait: A Study in Frustration
 IT can take a lot of patience to negotiate a deal at 750 Seventh. Just ask Mr. Speyer of Cushman & Wakefield, who put Caroline's Comedy Club in the building's retail space. He thought he had negotiated a pretty solid deal with David Solomon, only to discover that Citibank and the other banks controlling the bankrupt building thought otherwise.
"The bank's desire to protect their investment added eight months to the process," he said. "When you're dealing with a bank consortium, a negotiation process can turn into a cabinet meeting."
To be fair, that frustration is not unique to 750 Seventh Avenue, or even 1585 Broadway. David Solomon (no relation to the developer), an executive vice president of the Harper-Lawrence brokerage firm, remembers the horrors he went through trying to negotiate a renewal and expansion deal for Frederick Atkins, a major tenant at 1515 Broadway, when Equitable Real Estate, then its owner, filed for bankruptcy protection for the building in 1991.
"Can you believe it took two tortuous years to negotiate expansion space?" Mr. Solomon said. "We had to go through 10 drafts of a 150-page lease. Without the bankruptcy, it would have been three drafts and 75 pages."
Still, at 750 Seventh Avenue there seems to be something else at play -- a strong belief that holding out for high rents remains the best long-run way to go. After all, an empty building -- or one with high-rent tenants -- remains easier to sell than one that is locked into tenant-friendly leases.
"Citibank has been really bullish about pricing; they simply will not treat this as a distressed product," said Mary Ann Tighe, executive managing director of Edward S. Gordon.
In fact, some brokers insist that what they call the banks' voraciousness consistently scuttles deals.
"Sometimes it seems that as soon as they smell an interested prospect, they raise their asking price," said Mitchell S. Steir, a senior managing director at Julien J. Studley, the real estate brokerage. "I've had them come back to the table for second-round negotiations with suggested terms that had gotten worse, not better."
But unlike 1585 Broadway, 750 Seventh Avenue does not represent an impregnable wall to would-be tenants. The banks have hired Newmark Real Estate as leasing agent for the building.
Newmark, in turn, has arranged to prebuild some space for quick rental to small tenants and is aggressively marketing the larger blocks to brokers.
The Newmark people are playing host for breakfasts and guide for building tours for any tenant brokers they can corral. They are offering Newmark's own tenant reps cash for leads. A fancy marketing brochure stressing the building's technological aspects and its great river views is just coming off the press.
Slowly, deals are moving. Ernst & Young is said to be ready to rent 50,000 square feet for a regional office and several brokers say they are making nibbles at other space.
Many of the deals may still get skewered, though. The banks will not let Newmark hold anything approaching a fire sale. James D. Kuhn, Newmark's president, says he is holding out for rent from the mid-$30's for large blocks in the building's middle to the $40's for the top floors.
"We've turned away tenants who won't pay what we see as market value," he said. The reason, said another broker close to the bankers, is that the hope for a buyer still remains paramount.
"Like everyone else, their main hope is for Bertelsmann II," he said.
 
 
 
1540 Broadway
Turning a Renter Into a Landlord
 FROM the first, 1540 Broadway had things going for it that neither 750 Seventh Avenue nor 1585 Broadway had. For one, it was totally empty, which meant a new owner wouldn't have to worry about an angry Proskauer or an insolvent Olwine Connelly plopped in the building's middle.
And it offered an empty block of 850,000 feet plus 150,000 feet of retail space, enough to accommodate even a large owner/user's needs.
But it also had less tangible but equally important assets: a developer who was comfortable bringing his banks to the negotiating table early, a lead bank willing to rely on outside evaluations of the market and a tenant's representative team that could persuade a recalcitrant company that it really did want to buy a building.
Indeed, if anyone had told Bertelsmann management several years ago that they would soon own Manhattan property, they would have laughed. They were a music company, they were a publishing company -- but the one business they had little desire to get into was real estate.
"We wanted to spend our capital on media properties," said Christian Alpers, a Bertelsmann senior vice president.
What they did want to do was lower their occupancy costs. Their Bantam, Doubleday, Dell subsidiary was locked into a way-over-market lease -- rent in the high $40's in a market that was commanding maybe $32 -- for 250,000 feet at 666 Fifth Avenue, which didn't expire until the year 2000. The BMG Music Group had the mirror-image situation: It was paying less than $17 a foot for a similar amount of space at 1133 Avenue of the Americas, but that lease was expiring in 1994.
"We were hired to lower Bantam's costs and find a great deal for BMG, but we were told not to even consider an equity deal," recalled Jeffrey A. Lichtenberg, executive vice president of Peter R. Friedman, which represented Bertelsmann.
Mr. Lichtenberg and his crew looked at 1221 and 1251 Avenue of the Americas, 1585 Broadway -- and yes, 1540 Broadway -- but no one came up with a deal that Bertelsmann liked. The sticking point in almost every case: Bertelsmann wanted the new landlord to take over Bantam's lease and the landlords were having none of it.
According to Mr. Lichtenberg, Mr. Eichner and his lenders showed signs that they might bend on that score. But it became a moot point: the tenants and their brokers ran the numbers, and realized that, with a credit-worthy tenant like Bertelsmann renting a huge chunk of the building, the banks could probably sell it for as much as $140 million. As a vacant building they'd be lucky to get $100 million, if they found a buyer at all.
"Why should the banks get the vigorish?" Mr. Lichtenberg asked.
Why indeed. By mid-April 1991, Bertelsmann was thinking "buy."
Still, getting Mr. Eichner, Citibank, 16 Japanese banks, a brokerage team and a huge cost-conscious company to agree on price and terms was another matter. Mr. Lichtenberg recalls that they had arrived at a deal by fall of 1991 only to have Citibank back out at the last minute. (Citibank did not return repeated phone calls.)
"Internally at Citibank, groups were fighting each other and nobody had the authority to make a deal," he said.
Actually, Newmark's Jimmy Kuhn, then an independent consultant Citibank had hired to advise it of what the market values were and to drum up alternative buyers, says he recommended that Citibank turn down that deal.
It would have allowed Bertelsmann to buy the office portion of the building only and stuck Citibank with the lease for 666 Fifth.
"That was too much of a hit to ask the bank to take," Mr. Kuhn said.
Finally, Bertelsmann paid a lowball price, but it had to buy the entire building, including retail space, a theater and a garage. And it retained the lease for 666 Fifth Avenue.
"It was a good buy, but it was a great sell," Mr. Kuhn said. Mr. Alpers's take was: "We could finance this at rates that a real estate developer could only dream about."
Mr. Eichner gets much of the credit for the deal, too. He was the liaison between the brokers, the tenants and the banks. Many say it was his idea to put the building into a prepackaged bankruptcy, which saved enormously on transfer taxes. And, he helped the brokers persuade Bertelsmann that the banks would give them a fairly low price on the building if they backed off on the lease-takeover requirement for the 666 Fifth space.
"The question wasn't R for Rent or B for Buy, but C for Cheapest way to do it," Mr. Eichner said.
Today, Bertelsmann has moved into most of the building. It still has the Broadway retail space to let out, as well as about 150,000 feet of contiguous office space left over. Bertelsmann's deal with the city requires it to prebuild about a third of that space for use as "incubators," places that companies that do not currently have offices in the city can rent cheaply on a month-to-month basis while they look for larger quarters elsewhere.
Bertelsmann has also agreed to provide a commercial concierge who will help these newcomers, particularly foreigners, open bank accountants, establish busines contacts and otherwise get a foothold in the city.
And Mr. Lichtenberg says that deals for the remaining space are in advanced negotiations. In fact, he says, one full-floor deal is ready to close.
"We could negotiate that in a couple months," he said. "After all, with Bertelsmann as the owner, we only have to get an O.K. from one party."

HEADLINE: Bank Robbers Are Turning More Violent

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
BANK robbers in New Jersey are becoming more violent, more brazen and better organized, Federal law-enforcement officials say.
And despite increasingly sophisticated security measures, the number of robberies has been growing. In 1992, officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said, there were 121 bank robberies in the state, as compared with 109 in 1991 and 94 in 1990. 
 "We're seeing the re-emergence of bank robbery gangs," said James B. Lamb, a spokesman in the Newark office of the F.B.I. One such a gang is now being sought, he said, in connection with robberies this year in Paramus, Clark, Edison and River Edge.
"And we're seeing an increase in takeovers," Mr. Lamb said, explaining that in several recent robberies gangs have completely "taken over" the bank lobby and teller area by brandishing weapons and ordering everyone in the bank onto the floor while they empty the cash drawers.
 
The Old 'Standard' Bandit
 The latest bank robberies, Mr. Lamb said, are in contrast to the "standard event" of the past when a lone bandit made a quiet demand for money, usually without actually producing a weapon. That kind of bandit took whatever money the teller provided and left the bank before anyone but the teller knew what had happened.
Garey S. Chin, who is supervisor of the violent-crimes unit of the F.B.I.'s Newark office, said that he believed that bank robberies run in cycles and that a new one has begun as a number of convicted robbers have now completed their prison terms. "A lot of them are recidivists from 10 or 12 years ago," he said.
Mr. Chin also attributed the start of the current cycle to economic conditions, and Kurt E. Schaub, spokesman for the New Jersey Bankers Association in Princeton, agreed.
"In a down economy," Mr. Schaub said, "let's just say that people are looking for alternative ways to supplement their income."
Particularly troubling for law-enforcement officials, Mr. Chin said, is the phenomenon of gang-style holdups. He said that an organized gang appears to have been responsible for a string of 10 holdups committed between October and December 1992. The F.B.I., he said, has arrested six people in connection with those robberies.
He also described the recent robberies in Paramus, Edison, Clark and River Edge as being the work of an organized gang. A March 26 holdup in Paramus, for example, is typical of such a gang-style robbery, he said.
Capt. Claude Majcher of the Paramus Police Department said that on March 26 about 10 A.M. three men armed with handguns entered the Midland Avenue branch of the Chemical Bank New Jersey. One of the men ordered customers in the lobby to get down on the floor while his accomplices vaulted over the teller counter at opposite ends.
Once behind the counter, the robbers ordered the tellers to open their cash drawers. One teller, who happened to be standing in front of another teller's cash drawer, did not have a key for the drawer and was unable to comply with the robber's demand.
"Apparently he got impatient and fired off a round at the drawer," Captain Majcher said. A fragment of the bullet ricocheted off the cash drawer and struck the teller in the face, causing a minor injury, Captain Majcher said.
 
Another Shot Fired
 The robber then fired another shot at a second cash drawer. Neither shot opened either drawer. The other robber was busy emptying drawers at the other end of the counter.
After less than one minute, Captain Majcher said, the bandit who was on the lobby side of the teller counter said, "Let's get out of here," whereupon the three men left the bank and jumped into a waiting car. The gang took about $10,000.
Seconds later, the police arrived at the scene in response to a silent alarm that had been activated by a bank employee. They got a description of the getaway car and found it, empty, about a half-mile away in a parking lot on Route 17.
Apparently, Captain Majcher said, the robbers switched from the getaway car, which had been stolen, to another vehicle and then disappeared into traffic on Route 17.
"We found the stolen car within a minute of them leaving the bank," Captain Majcher said. "That's how close we were."
A similar strategy appears to have been used by a gang that held up a bank in River Edge last month. The bank, a branch of the Midlantic National Bank, had been robbed once before, in January 1992.
 
No 'Bandit Barriers' Used
 Another common denominator in the two robberies was that neither bank was outfitted with "bandit barriers" -- bulletproof Plexiglas panels installed on top of the teller counter to make it difficult for robbers to enter the teller area.
Lieut. Ronald Starace of the River Edge Police Department said the absence of such barriers made a bank vulnerable.
"To be robbed once was a freak," Lieutenant Starace said, referring to last year's robbery of the River Edge bank. "But twice and you've got to be considering that you have to start doing something."
Midlantic National Bank officials declined to comment on the River Edge robbery or on their intentions about the installation of bandit barriers at the branch. But a representative of the banking industry offered a possible explanation for the less-than-universal use of such barriers.
"They create an atmosphere that is not particularly conducive to saying, 'This is your friendly neighborhood bank,' " said James Silkensen, executive vice president of the New Jersey Savings League.
 
Other New Security Devices
 Bandit barriers are only one of the new security devices many banks have put in place.
"With CCTV, there's obviously hidden surveillance and recording features that weren't available years ago," said Tom Friesema, sales manager for Wells Fargo Alarm Services in Lyndhurst, referring to the new generation of miniature closed-circuit television monitors.
"They monitor all the entrances and exits, the vault entrances, the teller lines and the platform area where the bank officers sit," Mr. Friesema said. "Time lapse recorders can record up to 600 hours without changing a tape."
During hours when the bank is closed, he said, more sophisticated burglar alarms are now being used.
"We're using infrared technology now instead of microwave or ultrasonic protection like 10 or 15 years ago," he said. Infrared technology, which detects movement, is far more sensitive than the older technologies.
 
Silent Alarms Installed
 In addition, he said, there are silent alarms that are directly connected to police departments. Those alarms can be activated by any teller or automatically, when the last bill is taken out of the cash drawer.
But even when such alarms are available, and no matter how sophisticated security devices become, nearly every bank robbery boils down to a confrontation between an intimidating, potentially armed robber and an unarmed, frightened bank teller.
"People tell me it's like a nightmare," Lieutenant Starace said. "I've heard people say a 30-second robbery feels like an eternity."
In many cases, he said, the teller never activates the alarm until the robber has left the bank.
"There's always the risk that the police will respond too fast," Lieutenant Starace said. "We always want to catch the guys, but if you happen to be the person inside that bank, you'd like to know that the guy is out of there before we show up."
Lieutenant Starace said the policy of his department was to abstain from using sirens when responding to a bank robbery and to avoid pulling up directly in front of the bank.
"We don't want to create a hostage situation," he said.
 
Putting Safety First
 Bank officials say each bank has its own set of procedures for dealing with robberies. One rule that appears to be universal, however, is that the safety of customers and employees is paramount.
"The tellers are told, 'Don't resist, do what they tell you, and never jeopardize anyone's life,"' said an official for a bank in northern New Jersey who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The money's insured," he said. "We don't want to see anybody get hurt."
The official said that his bank held regular security meetings with employees to go over different robbery scenarios "to keep everyone abreast of what to do in the event something does happen."
If a bank is robbed, he said, "there are always ways that we try to pass something on to them that will be traceable." One example is the "bait pack," a stack of bills with sequential serial numbers that can be traced.
The official said one way to reduce the impact of a bank robbery was to insure that the tellers kept minimal amounts of cash in their drawers.
"They're restricted to certain totals," he said. "And once they reach that limit, they've got to reduce their cash and lock it up in the vault."
And would he open the vault if ordered to do so by a robber?
"You betcha," he said. "If somebody puts a gun to your head, you're going to do whatever he wants."
 
Limits on Access to Vault
 He added that in most banks no one person can gain entry to the main vault on his own, but requires the assistance of another employee.
"You just hope they believe you when you say you can't do something," he said.
The best way to deter a bank robbery, the official said, is through increased use of bandit barriers.
"They work," the official said. "Most of the robberies that have taken place have occurred where there aren't barriers."
But experts in bank security agree that nothing can completely deter a determined bank robber.
"Trying to prevent bank robberies is a little like being the Dutch boy with his finger in the dike," said Marcus Ford, executive vice president of Profit Protection Inc., a Miami company that specializes in bank security. "You plug this hole here, and another one pops up over there."
Law-enforcement officials offer a case in point.
 
The Case of the 'Jumper Bandit'
 "We call him the 'jumper bandit,' " Mr. Chin of the F.B.I. said, referring to an athletically built man who vaults not only over the teller counters, but also over bandit barriers.
"He's good for over 16 bank robberies in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York," Mr. Chin said.
The man, he said, working alone, enters a bank with a sawed-off rifle, orders the customers to lie on the floor and tells tellers to open their cash drawers. He then vaults over the counter and the bandit barrier, stuffs cash from the drawers into a gym bag, vaults back into the lobby and heads for the door.
"He's in and out very quickly," Mr. Chin said, adding that six of the robberies were committed in New Jersey and that all of them occurred between September 1991 and July 1992. The jumper bandit is still at large.
"We haven't heard from him lately," Mr. Chin said.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Forstmann Little's Next Coup?

BYLINE: By Susan Antilla

 BODY:
MAKING golf clubs and marketing ceramic villages are decidedly obscure slivers of the economy. But if you have not been thinking about them, maybe you should.
One person in the latter line of work picked up $25 million last year, and would put an extra $10 million in his pocket soon if all goes well with an initial public offering of Department 56. The company, which is based in Eden Prairie, Minn., sells sweet little illuminated villages that have found their way under Christmas trees and onto mantles. 
 In the golf club business, some smart investors who had put a little money into Aldila Inc. last year have the chance to nearly triple their investments by the Fourth of July.
Feeling pretty good about all those golf clubs and small villages are the principals of Forstmann Little & Company, the leveraged buyout firm run by Theodore Forstmann. Forstmann Little and its investors picked up San Diego-based Aldila last January for $83.1 million and have recently filed documents with the Securities and Exchange Commission to take 29 percent of the company public. If successful, the offering would bring them $27.6 million, wiping out most of the $31 million in bank debt that went into the deal.
Forstmann and his partners paid $3.99 a share for Aldila 16 months ago. They are hoping the investing public will pay $10 to $12 a share.
The case of Department 56 is even better: It had no bank debt. The filing to sell a chunk of the company comes only six months after the Forstmann investors bought it for $71 million in equity and $213 million in subordinated debt provided by the investors.
A cash cow, Department 56 was the brainstorm of Edward R. Bazinet, the chief executive, who would be $10 million richer if the deal goes as planned. Regulatory documents for the stock offering show that Mr. Bazinet picked up a $9 million bonus last year for his 1991 and 1992 contributions to the company's success. At about $4.5 million a year, that is a decent showing even by the standards of executives on Wall Street, who sock away million dollar bonuses the way some people invest in vacation clubs.
Mr. Bazinet also got a check for an extra $16 million in return for his willingness to waive an old compensation plan that allowed a group of key executives to share bonuses that amounted to 15 percent of the firm's pretax income each year.
Department 56 insiders would not comment until after the public offering. They no doubt were wary of the executive compensation cops, who often frown on such generous bonus arrangements in public companies.
Considering the fast and generous returns, it would be hard to find much wrong with the deal from the standpoint of the investors. But the swift turnaround from purchase to partial spinoff raises the question of whether the smart money knows something the rest of us do not.
Preston G. Athey, who runs the T. Rowe Price Small-Cap Value Fund, said he thinks the initial public offering market feels tired. "I received nine red herrings on Monday," he said, referring to the documents that companies file to start the process of going public. "To my mind, that's an example of a somewhat overheated market."
Mr. Athey and others said the two Forstmann deals will fly anyway, partly because of the quality of the companies they are competing against in the market for initial public offerings. Many high quality companies went public during the rush in 1992 to sell new shares, Mr. Athey said. Now, profitable companies like Aldila and Department 56 may stand out among an increasingly trashy array of offerings.
Coming to market at 17 to 24 times their earnings of last year, neither company would be asking an outrageous premium at a time when investors are clamoring for shares of companies that have no earnings at all.
Norman Fosback, a newsletter editor whose publications include a new issues letter, said he was impressed that Department 56 "seems to be humming right along," despite having gone through a leveraged buyout. The balance sheet health, he said, had much to do with the favorable terms of the debt that Department 56 got from the Forstmann investors, who will let the company operate for 11 years before demanding payment of amortization. Bank financing, which traditionally had been used in leveraged buyouts, would require the repayment of the principal in the first or second year after the deal was complete.
But Mr. Fosback said that both the Forstmann purchases have the potential risks of any deal in which the price far exceeds the tangible assets of the company being bought -- something that becomes worrisome if, for some reason, the luster of the Aldila or Department 56 brand names should fade. Brand-name deflation is no small issue in the markets today, with companies like Philip Morris and Procter & Gamble getting jolts from fickle consumers. The two Forstmann companies could be immune to such a fate, but there are no guarantees, Mr. Fosback said.
There is also the potentially troublesome matter of accounts receivable at Aldila, which hit $3.27 million at the end of the first quarter -- a huge number compared with a modest $171,000 for the comparable period a year ago. A spokesman for Forstmann Little would not comment on the receivables because of the regulatory quiet period.
Robert Natale, an expert on new issues at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said investors frequently make money buying and holding quality companies that go public at the right price. But there is always the question of what management knows that investors do not. Initial public offerings occur, by definition, when things are looking unusually good for a company, he said. "It can be a fair price when they go public," he said. "But they go public when underlying fundamentals are very good, and company executives know it won't last forever."

HEADLINE: At Work;
Making a Case for Family Programs

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
It is hard-shell gospel among advocates of "family friendly" or "family supportive" corporate policies that helping employees helps the bottom line. But gospel doesn't crunch as well as numbers, and the unsentimental, lynx-eyed financial types who prowl the balance sheets of corporate America in these lean times tend to be non-believers.
Researchers are beginning to accumulate the systematic, hard evidence that advocates need to make their case. According to two studies reported last week, companies that make it easier for employees to juggle their work and family responsibilities do reap gains in greater loyalty, increased job satisfaction and lower turnover. The benefits of the policies also seem to reverberate beyond the companies' human resources departments. 
 "Lavish claims for all the wonderful things work-family programs do always made us nervous because they used an untested hypothesis," said Ellen Galinsky, co-president of the Families and Work Institute, the New York research group that did one of the studies. "We knew lots of studies that showed the cost of not providing programs. Finally we have two studies that begin to address the benefits," she told an audience of human resources executives at the Conference Board's annual family and work conference last week in New York.
The studies were in essence evaluations of work-family programs at Johnson & Johnson, the consumer and pharmaceuticals giant based in New Brunswick, N.J., and Fel-Pro Inc., a medium-size maker of automotive sealing products based in Skokie, Ill.
J.& J. and Fel-Pro both offer an extensive menu of family programs, including on-site child care as well as dependent and elder care resources and flexible schedules.
The Families and Work Institute found that four years after the Johnson & Johnson "Balancing Work and Family" program began, 38 percent of the employees who responded to the survey said they "strongly agreed" that they felt more comfortable raising personal issues at work. That was up from 18 percent in 1990, when the baseline evaluation was done. And slightly more than half the employees said they strongly agreed that supervisors -- who are critical to the success of work-family programs -- were responsive to their personal and family needs, up from 36 percent in 1990.
One important consequence of the changes since 1990, said Chris Kjeldsen, a J.& J. vice president, is that employees no longer feel they have to lie to get permission to take time off if a child is sick or for some other family emergency. "It's bringing about a positive cultural change at J.& J.," he said.
Nearly three-quarters of the employees who responded to the survey said the family policies were "very important" in deciding whether to stay at the company.
At Fel-Pro, researchers from the University of Chicago found that employees who took advantage of work-family programs were more likely to participate in total quality management and other programs companies consider critical to their competitiveness. They were also more likely to be "good corporate citizens" who pitched in to help other employees, the researchers said.
Susan Lambert, the Fel-Pro study's principal investigator, said family policies are often seen primarily as a way to attract women to a company. "They have additional benefits," she said. "They can help lay the groundwork for other major cultural changes."
Neither study found evidence to support a fear common among managers that employees will exploit and abuse company programs. At J.& J., Mr. Kjeldsen said, there was no increase in absenteeism or tardiness or decrease in productivity even though, because of the economy, people were working longer and had more responsibility.
In both studies, the employees who used and liked family programs most were the highest performers, the least inclined to leave the company and the least likely to have disciplinary problems. Since the Johnson & Johnson program began, employees seem to take their job troubles home less. Given the difficult economic times and the pressure on employees, Ms. Galinsky said, "that is an astonishing finding."
 
 
 
HIGH ANXIETY
 One of the more intriguing findings of the Families and Work Institute's study of Johnson & Johnson: Women with their children experience fewer of the day-to-day distractions of parenthood and find it easier to concentrate on work than do men. Only 13 percent of women with children in onsite day care, versus 36 percent of men, report that parental responsibilities distract them from work or impinge on their productivity.
 "The men are feeling the pressure of being the one in charge," said Ellen Galinsky, the research project's director. "Women feel it less because they've always been in charge. The research is fairly consistent, that when men take on more work-family responsibilities, they seem to feel the stress more at this stage in our history."
 Dana Friedman, who is a co-president of the institute with Ms. Galinsky, said men get less support and more aggravation for doing what is regarded as natural for women. "They even get hassles from women, who will say, " Hi, Mr. Mom,' " Ms. Friedman said. For men, "it's more novel, and more difficult. There are probably more negative career sanctions." The study found no differences in absenteeism between men with child-care responsibilities and those without. "Any negative impact is very modest," it concludes.

PUB-DATE: May 2, 1993,

LENGTH: 1565 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/April 25-30

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY 

When, Exactly, Does It Become the Clinton Economy? Stay Tuned
 
One honeymoon may be just about over. So far, President Clinton has been able to point to grim economic statistics and say, "See what the Republicans did! Just let me fix it." But at some point it'll become the Clinton economy, and voters will hold his feet to the fire if things go sour. Last week's report of surprisingly slow first-quarter growth -- just a 1.8 percent annual pace -- may mark the beginning of the changeover. For while Mr. Clinton called the report further evidence that the nation badly needs a shot in the arm, Bob Dole, sniping happily from a treetop, quickly turned the report against the President. "The American people," he said, "are grading the President with their pocketbooks." One surprise was the biggest plunge in 20 years for the military -- without which the growth rate would have been 3.5 percent. The military machine is certainly shrinking, but no one expected that quick a drop.
 
To Head the S.E.C., a White Male
 
One thing Bill Clinton did not do much in his first 100 days was hire people. Tugging at one elbow, women and minorities; at the other, familiar white males. And often Mr. Clinton jogged a lot of laps before deciding. Arthur Levitt Jr., former head of the American Stock Exchange, had wide backing to head the Securities and Exchange Commission. But also in the running was Consuela Washington, a black woman who is an aide to Representative John D. Dingell. Mr. Clinton went for the white male this time -- a white male who had also helped raise millions for his campaign. The S.E.C. has had its share of conflict in recent years, and Mr. Levitt was described by one colleague as "a master of consensus."
 
Half-Speed Ahead on Fast Trains
 
The Administration announced a $1.3 billion plan to develop high-speed train service in various areas nationwide, but again the question arose: Is the campaign glass half full or half empty? The plan, which includes $300 million for work on a train that floats on magnetic cushions, is the first Federal support for high-speed projects outside the Northeast corridor. And Transportation Secretary Federico Pena saw an improvement over the Reagan-Bush era, when there was "no commitment, no leadership." But Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine of New York said, "I'm disappointed the Clinton Administration is not following through" with the broader commitment promised during the campaign.
 
Take a Letter, Mom
 
Chelsea Clinton, 13, went to school on Wednesday. She told her father she knew what he did for a living. Kathleen Wood, 9, didn't know, so she tagged along. She learned that "short duration mortgage factors were attractive." Her response: "Boring." On Take Our Daughters to Work Day, organized by the Ms. Foundation for 9- to 15-year-old girls, up to a million girls nationwide skipped school to taste the joys, and drudgery, of life in the 9-to-5 lane. In the Chicago trading pits, it was joyful indeed, as the girls did some awesome trading of pizza futures. And how much work did Mom and Dad get done? Don't ask.
 
Saving the Trees, Part 2
 
When President Clinton backed down from including in his budget proposal a plan to curtail logging on public land, he drew fire from environmentalists -- and vowed to find another way. Maybe that way has been found. Last week the Forest Service proposed changes that would end logging in more than a third of national forests, affecting more than 60 million acres in 23 states. The difference: This proposal can go into effect in spite of Congressional opposition, which is what derailed the earlier attempt.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Flying in Formation in Europe
 
Bigger is better -- or simpler is better. You now need an air traffic controller to sort out the deals and cross-ownerships: Swissair and Delta own 5 percent of each other, KLM owns 20 percent of Northwest, SAS has ties to Continental . . . the list goes on. So, after discussing closer ties, Swissair, SAS, KLM and Austrian Airlines decided to go all the way and merge into a single European giant. The economies of scale are irresistible. "Small national carriers are an anachronism," one analyst said. "Critical mass" is the key. The deal is far from done, though: Routes must be cut or combined, government approvals are needed.
 
Disney Loses a Bit in Translation
 
Euro Disney. The name seems like an oxymoron. How could something so quintessentially American possibly be exported? Not too smoothly, as it turns out. The park near Paris has had problems since it opened, and last week it predicted a big yearly loss and said it badly needed cash. Attendance isn't bad, but visitors aren't spending as freely as Euro Disney would like. One problem: The French miss their mealtime glass of wine.
 
The Queen Needs the Cash
 
British royalty owes its astonishing survival to being one of a kind, floating regally above the muck. Well, it's losing altitude. Already humbled by some divorce messiness, it has now joined those lesser nobles who must, to pay the bills, let the untitled masses scuff their carpets and ogle their treasures. Last week Queen Elizabeth, to raise cash to repair Windsor Castle, said that for $12.50, summer tourists could get a glimpse of the innards of Buckingham Palace. If that doesn't raise the $50 million or so needed, of course, there's always a home equity loan.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
G.M., Profitable and Defiant
 
General Motors may be pulling itself out of its slide, and it certainly doesn't want a massive truck recall to slow it down. Last week it reported a quarterly profit of more than $500 million, compared with a huge loss a year earlier, saying it had made real progress in a vital area -- cutting costs. A day later, the company held its ground in a battle with Washington, refusing to recall 4.7 million pickup trucks whose fuel tanks, the Government says, pose an unacceptable fire hazard. It has come down to a battle of numbers, like the speed of impact in Government tests. And now, if the Government doesn't flinch either, it may all have to be sorted out in the harsh glare of public hearings.
 
Continental: Seven Lives to Go
 
The airline heavyweights can't blame Continental anymore. As their troubles grew, American, United and Delta were quick to say that their bankrupt rivals tilted the landing field, that they had an unfair advantage in being able to reduce debt and break contracts to buy or lease planes. But last week Continental emerged from bankruptcy -- the first airline ever to do so twice -- and it's ready to play with the big kids. And it is ready: It's got $600 million tucked away for a choppy day, and it has fewer unionized workers than its rivals, giving it a big edge. To lure customers, it plans to sell itself as a carrier with something it certainly didn't have a decade ago -- good service.
 
Mr. Gerstner, Meet Your Bosses
 
One wonders if Louis Gerstner knew what he was in for. After less than a month on the job, the new head of I.B.M. was thrown to some angry sharks -- an annual shareholder meeting in Tampa, heavy with retirees. These folks had built up nice, safe, true-blue-chip nest eggs in I.B.M. stock before heading for the sunshine, and were not at all happy at the way those nest eggs had cracked. One typical comment: "I.B.M. no longer provides for your old age, but it certainly hastens its arrival." One shareholder even included the newcomer among those responsible for her woes, noting that the stock had fallen even further after Mr. Gerstner took over. For his part, Mr. Gerstner acknowledged their pain and vowed: "I mean to do something about it."
 
1-800-GET-AT&T
 
A new battle has been joined in the Great Telephone War. A.T.&T. dominates "800" numbers, controlling 75 percent of this $7 billion market. Why is this so, with MCI and others making such dents elsewhere? For one thing, you had to change numbers to switch carriers, and no business that had spent big money teaching the public its number wanted to start over. Under new F.C.C. rules, you can take your number with you. In addition, customers have 90 days to break A.T.&T. contracts without penalty. This is a huge business for A.T.&T., accounting for fully 40 percent of the 150 million calls it carries daily. But it is not expected to lose much of it to rivals just yet.
 
It Wasn't Time to Slash and Burn
 
It's becoming a familiar tale: A huge company in trouble. An old-style boss. A slash-and-burn newcomer charging in to save the day. Conflict. Well, score one for the old guard. At Kodak last week, Christopher J. Steffen, the chief financial officer intent on bolstering earnings and trimming costs, quit suddenly, saying, "The company and I disagree on the approach to solving its problems." Kay R. Whitmore, chairman and chief executive, insisted the company still had a turnaround plan, saying of Mr. Steffen, "He was part of the plan, but he was not the plan." Trouble is, Wall Street liked Mr. Steffen. Kodak stock had shot up when he joined, and it slid right back down when he left, losing $1.5 billion in value in a day. Not that Kodak plans to scrap all efforts to slim down. It rushed to assure shareholders that it would sell at least one sizable asset by September.

LENGTH: 2739 words

HEADLINE: Honda's Ugly Little Secret

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

 BODY:
TOM ROULETTE opened a Honda dealership in Painesville, Ohio, in 1978, offering what were becoming the hottest cars in America. But more than one Honda Motor Company executive told him, he recalls, that to get all the cars he wanted to sell he would have to "play the game."
During the next eight years, Mr. Roulette concedes, he played the game faithfully, showering Honda executives with gifts -- a car, jewelry, a stereo system, barbecue grills and thousands of dollars in cash. On some Christmases he received a list specifying what executives expected from Santa. One year, he recalls, he sent his wife to buy a watch costing more than $2,000 for the wife of a Honda executive. 
 "These guys were so cocky, they'd come in, put their feet up on my desk and tell me what I had to give them," he said.
In return, Honda increased his supply of cars. With the models selling quickly, often at prices well above their suggested retail price, Mr. Roulette grew prosperous enough to afford a second Honda dealership. "Those were great days," he recalled. "But you couldn't get cars unless you paid."
Later, Mr. Roulette and Honda grew apart -- he sued over a franchise that the company awarded to someone else -- and in his bitterness over what he thinks was extortion he agreed to disclose in interviews details about what went on before. "This has to come out," he said.
Mr. Roulette's story is not unusual. In interviews with The New York Times and in testimony in recent lawsuits, dozens of former Honda dealers and employees suggest that the company's system for distributing cars and awarding franchises has been riddled with corruption since the 1970's. Many dealers now say that to secure more cars and franchises from the company, they offered executives money, gifts or stakes in dealerships; other dealers say they were forced to pay up.
Accusations of bribery and extortion grew out of at least four lawsuits around the country filed by Honda dealers against other Honda dealers or the company itself. Testimony from one of those cases, in Concord, N.H., has been referred to the Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and both are investigating for possible violations of mail- and wire-fraud laws.
 
Senior Executives Accused
 Three senior executives in Honda's United States operations, who have since left the company, have been accused in court testimony of accepting cash or a secret stake in a dealership. Six of the 10 executives who supervise Honda's regional zones in the United States have resigned in the past year. One of the six has been accused by a former Honda dealer in Virginia of secretly accepting a stake in a new dealership. A Honda spokesman, citing confidentiality in dealings with employees, declined to say why any of the executives left.
Rooting out corrupt and possibly illegal practices among its dealers and sales executives has become a paramount concern for Honda's United States management, which is based in Los Angeles. Richard Colliver, recruited from Mazda two months ago to be Honda's senior vice president of sales, said the bribery accusations are credible and "bring shame to the entire company."
After internal investigations, Mr. Colliver said, Honda has dismissed "a few" employees for violating company policy against conflicts of interest and specifically acceptance of expensive gifts. He declined to elaborate.
To be sure, Honda dealers who played it straight lost cars to those who cheated. But this is more than an intramural squabble. The scandal could be viewed as an illustration of an unintended side effect of trade protectionism. Japan's agreement to restrain car exports, resulting from pressure by Detroit's Big Three and the United Auto Workers union, was the most important factor in limiting the supply of Hondas in the United States. With demand for Hondas exceeding the supply, some dealers raised prices sharply, and began striking deals with Honda executives to secure all the cars they wanted.
Any illicit payments were financed by the people who bought the cars. Paying off executives, in effect, became part of a dealer's overhead.
Honda also suffered: "The people who really lose are the shareholders," said Lawrence J. White, professor of economics at the Stern School of Business at New York University and former chief economist in the Justice Department's antitrust division. "Instead of Honda getting the higher wholesale price for its cars or reaping the customer goodwill for not charging a higher price, the executives and the dealers are getting what becomes in effect the higher wholesale price."
 
Unusual? No
 Such scandal is not unknown to other car makers. When models have been hot, dealers eager to get cars that will sell at a big profit have done favors for the manufacturers. "This situation has happened many times," said J. David Power, founder of J. D. Power & Associates, a marketing research firm based in Agoura Hills, Calif. For young, underpaid auto executives, "it is a very big temptation, especially when the dealers are making so much." In the early 1970's, the Toyota Motor Corporation's United States network faced a scandal similar to Honda's.
Nor is the phenomenon limited to the auto industry. While generally suppliers ply retailers with favors to persuade them to buy more, the opposite situation can occur during shortages -- whether the item is oil, steel or tickets to a show.
The scandal at Honda is in one sense a consequence of the company's very success. Honda began building cars in 1967, and when it began exporting them to the United States in 1970 it had to beg prospective dealers to sell them. But all that changed when the energy crisis in the mid-1970's put a premium on light, fuel-efficient cars from Japan.
In the 1980's, Hondas gained a reputation for reliability and stylishness. Demand became so great that buyers frequently offered to pay more than the sticker price, would wait weeks for their Honda to arrive and were willing to forgo their favorite color and choices of options.
Some dealers began to raise prices above Honda's suggested retail price, frankly disclosing "additional dealer profit" as the reason; other times they added "options" that didn't cost them much, like pinstriping and undercoating, and then charged hundreds of dollars for them. "The best deal I can remember was a $12,000 Honda Prelude that I sold for $5,000 above list price," Mr. Roulette said. "My gross profit was at least $7,000."
 
Fabulous Riches
 The most successful Honda dealers opened additional showrooms and earned millions annually. "We were coming back from Florida on the Learjet one night and I asked myself, 'What's wrong with this picture?' " said a former employee of a chain of Honda dealerships, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "I sell cars for a living. I wasn't supposed to be living like a rock star."
Honda, according to a custom developed by the Big Three, allocated cars according to how quickly dealers sold what they had. But some dealers couldn't get enough cars under that system, so they looked to Honda executives for help.
"If there was a guy who could get you a few more cars you might buy him clothes and send him a gold Rolex to curry favor," said an East Coast dealer who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "Don't forget, this guy was making $50,000 a year and dealers were making $2 million or $3 million at every store."
But Hondas aren't nearly as easy to sell these days. A strong yen and strengthening competition from the Big Three have hurt the company. Honda's sales are down 20 percent from last year. The Accord, in recent years the nation's best-selling car, was passed last year by the Ford Taurus. Doing favors for Honda executives has been rendered unnecessary.
As the market has weakened, lawsuits have been filed by a growing number of disgruntled Honda dealers who claim they were hurt by favoritism toward other dealers. It is in these suits that the bribery and extortion accusations have surfaced.
Some Honda executives have been accused of accepting secret free equity stakes in new dealerships in return for permission to open them. Edward W. Mixon, a former Honda dealer in Woodbridge, Va., testified in a suit against a former partner that he promised Dennis Josleyn, the Honda zone manager in Gaithersburg, Md., 10 percent of a new dealership in Warrenton, Va., worth $90,000 by Mr. Mixon's estimate, "because he had been helpful to me in the past." The dealership was never opened.
Mr. Josleyn, who resigned from Honda a year ago, declined, through his attorney, to respond to a reporter's questions. However, he has denied in a deposition that he was promised a stake.
In another suit, William and Mary Jo Shepherd, Honda dealers in Concord, Calif., contend that a former Honda executive vice president, Cliff Schmillen, was given a 10 percent interest in a competing dealership in nearby Walnut Creek "illegally and illicitly, in order that the mix, color and style allocations to Walnut Creek Honda be increased." Asked in an interview whether he held a stake in the dealership, Mr. Schmillen, who left the company in 1990, replied, "I don't think it's proper of me to comment on that right now."
 
The Alleged Payoffs
 Then there are the accusations of payoffs. Take the case of Richard M. Nault, a former Acura dealer in Concord, N.H. In a suit against Honda, Mr. Nault said he didn't receive enough cars because Honda favored a competing Acura dealer in nearby Nashua, Thomas Bohlander. In a pretrial hearing, Mr. Bohlander acknowledged that in November 1986 he presented David L. Pedersen, a Honda assistant zone manager, a 1987 Acura Integra as a gift; he said he also paid $17,197 in tuition to Gannon College, where Mr. Pedersen's son was a student. Mr. Bohlander testified that the gifts were for friendship, not for allocation of cars.
Another witness in Mr. Nault's case, Damien C. Budnick, testified that in mid-1990 he delivered $100,000 in cash from a Honda dealer in Cocoa Beach, Fla., to Mr. Pedersen, then an assistant zone manager in Georgia. Mr. Budnick, a former district sales manager, said funneling cash to executives was common. Executives called it "passing the football."
Mr. Pedersen resigned from Honda last June. Asked whether accusations that he accepted gifts and money from dealers were true, he said "Consider the source," and did not elaborate.
Mr. Budnick also testified that dealers had funneled money to two Honda senior vice presidents who supervised the zone managers: James Cardiges, who resigned in 1992 and was Mr. Colliver's predecessor, and Jack Billmyer, who preceded Mr. Cardiges. Attempts to find Mr. Cardiges were unsuccessful and his attorney did not return a half-dozen phone calls; several messages left on the answering machine of Mr. Billmyer were not answered. Neither Mr. Cardiges nor Mr. Billmyer has testified on the accusations; but Mr. Billmyer, who took early retirement in 1988, has been quoted in the trade press as denying that he accepted payments under the table.
On Feb. 22, Steven J. McAuliffe, the Federal District Court judge presiding over Mr. Nault's lawsuit in Concord, ordered the testimony and evidence related to accusations of bribery referred to the Justice Department for investigation. Peter Papps, the United States Attorney in Concord, confirmed an investigation but would not say which executives or dealers he was looking at, or what if any charges might be filed.
Last week, the F.B.I. also said it was investigating the matter. Bribery and extortion, if proven in this case, would be a violation of Federal mail- and wire-fraud statutes. Moreover, the Internal Revenue Service might decide, as is customary, to investigate whether taxes were paid on gifts and cash payments.
If investigators look into the case of Mr. Roulette, the former Honda dealer in Ohio, they will learn that he thinks he had no choice but to bribe executives.
From the outset, Mr. Roulette said, he told Honda executives: "What does it take to get more cars? I'll do what it takes." He said one executive told him his father wanted a new Pontiac Bonneville. Mr. Roulette said he bought one for $12,000, and the executive paid him $7,000 for it. Mr. Roulette also said he paid for a watch costing more than $2,000 for the executive's wife. "After that, I became one of the guys," he said.
 
'I Had to Do It'
 Mr. Roulette, who now lives in California and owns a Chevrolet dealership in San Jose, said he isn't worried that he might have broken laws. "I'm sorry -- I had to do it," he said. "I've got a wife and kid to support."
As for his latest dealership, Chevrolets have been slow sellers, so dealers would find little reason to make questionable payments to General Motors executives to get more cars. Still, Mr. Roulette said, "they send a letter saying don't even send us candy for Christmas."
 
 
 
FOUR WHO DECIDED TO GO TO COURT

The accusations of payoffs at the Honda Motor Company stem largely from four unrelated cases involving the auto maker and Honda dealers.
Richard M. Nault, an Acura dealer in Manchester, N.H., sued Honda in state court in 1989 -- the suit was later transferred to Federal court -- accusing the company of damaging him by placing another Acura dealership too close to him and then by canceling his franchise when he moved to a different building to save money. The judge in the case referred the testimony to the United States Attorney in Concord. The suit is scheduled for trial next month.
Edward W. Mixon, a former Honda dealer in Woodbridge, Va., sued Richard C. D. Hunt III and his wife, Peggy T. Hunt, who with Mr. Mixon had agreed to open a Honda dealership in Warrenton, Va., in 1990. Mr. Mixon had Honda's permission to open the franchise; the couple had agreed to erect the building. But when the Hunts couldn't get financing, the deal fell through. Mr. Mixon sued in 1991 for breach of contract. The lawsuit was settled earlier this month, but the terms were not made public.
William and Mary Jo Shepherd, Honda dealers in Concord, Calif., sued the company in 1991, alleging breach of contract. Mr. Shepherd said he lost money when forced to sell his dealership after Honda failed to allocate enough cars to him. The Shepherd case is in litigation in United States District Court in San Francisco.
In 1988, Tom Roulette sued Honda in California, accusing the company of breaking a contract under which he was to have been awarded an Acura luxury-car franchise in San Jose. The suit went to trial last summer, and a jury awarded Mr. Roulette $5.5 million in general damages and $1.5 million in punitive damages. Honda appealed in November and the case is awaiting a hearing by the 6th Appellate District Court in San Jose. Fueled by his anger against Honda, Mr. Roulette decided to make public his accusations of bribery against former Honda executives.
 
ONE FOR HONDA'S DEFENSE

DAVID CONANT, part owner of Norm Reeves Honda Superstore in Cerritos, Calif., remembers the good old days a decade ago when Civics and Accords regularly sold for as much as $500 above the suggested retail price.
And he remembers that some dealers always seemed to get more cars than others. However, Honda managers were willing to show him computer printouts and explain how cars were allocated, he said.
Of accusations that some dealers have bribed Honda employees with gifts and cash to receive more cars and franchises, Mr. Conant, chairman of the Honda Dealers Council, said: "I don't really know whether these things are true or not. But it makes me angry and it makes me sick. With an image as golden as Honda's, we don't want to see anything happen that could hurt that image."
Last year Mr. Conant's dealership sold about 6,000 new Hondas, making it the largest Honda dealership in the nation. "We got this big by setting standards that aren't just auto-industry standards but standards of business excellence over all," he said. "That's the message the customers and employees get: you can get that way playing by the rules."
Periodically, he said, "certain models will be hot, and scarce." He said his dealership probably gets fewer cars than it is entitled to because it's so big and Honda doesn't want to appear to be favoring it. "Right now, for example, the Civic coupe is hot," he said. "I could use more."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
When the Risks of Wall Street Affect Us All

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
The days of guaranteed returns have ended. And that will have major effects on millions of Americans and also on the financial system.
It was not too many years ago that the average American had no real reason to be concerned with the financial markets. Much of his or her money was in the bank, or perhaps in Treasury bills, providing a guaranteed yield with no principal risk. The pension awaited at retirement was a fixed amount each month. If the pension fund investments did not make enough money, that was a problem for the employer, not the employee. 
 But that has been changing gradually for several years. The flow of money out of banks, and into stock and bond mutual funds, has become a flood. Some funds are riskier than others, but all involve some principal risk. Similarly, the trend is for companies to drop defined-benefit pension plans in favor of defined-contribution plans, in which the employee controls how the money is invested, usually by choosing among mutual funds, and wins or loses as those investments rise or fall.
So far, none of this has created a significant problem. Those who took risks with their financial assets have been rewarded. "In the past few years we have seen the pleasant side of volatility, with just occassional interruptions to remind us that markets do not move in straight lines," the economist Henry Kaufman said last week in a speech to the Chapman University Economic Forum in Irvine, Calif.
Now, there is a campaign to persuade employees that those who do not take risks are foolish. Long-term, we are told, stocks outperform everything else. So long-term investment plans should emphasize equity investments. It is too bad that lesson was not taught in the mid-1970's or the early 1980's, when stocks were cheap by historic standards, rather than now, when they are expensive.
Nonetheless, there will come a time when volatility works the other way, when a bear market arrives in some or all financial assets. Mr. Kaufman suggested that could depress the underlying economy, as consumers cut back on spending out of concern that their wealth is evaporating. His forecast was that markets could fall rapidly as individuals panic and bail out, particularly if short-term interest rates have risen, providing a reasonable alternative investment.
That is not likely to happen soon, if only because the lesson many individuals have learned from the 1987 crash is that declining markets provide buying opportunities. But if prices were to fall, and kept falling, Mr. Kaufman asked whether investors might lose confidence in the stock market and demand the Government use "open market operations" to support share prices, as it now intervenes in the Treasury bill market to affect interest rates.
Such an idea seems farfetched, but something similar happened in Japan this year. And it serves as a reminder of just how much the world is changing, as more and more financial risk is passed on to individual Americans.
