HEADLINE: OUT THERE: MINNEAPOLIS;
Survivors Get to Dance

BYLINE: By Neal Karlen

 BODY:
THE notorious Nick Beavers, clean and sober at last, was fidgeting at a rear table in his new Minnesota nightclub, nursing what would be diagnosed back home on Broadway as a serious case of flop sweats. Here in downtown Minneapolis, however, locals would simply say that the owner of the newly opened Rogue bar and restaurant was having a cow.
Nick Beavers . . . nervous? It didn't seem possible. Back in the decadent 1980's, when he helped run such hard-partying Manhattan night spots as the Surf Club and the Zulu Lounge, Mr. Beavers was famous for his air of preppy bad-boy nonchalance. But now, on the most important opening night of his life, the 28-year-old self-exiled child of Fifth Avenue was skittishly swilling Diet Cokes and chain-smoking Marlboros. 
 "I'm not afraid anymore to show that I'm scared," Mr. Beavers said as he pushed back his chair and walked the length of his 12,000-square-foot club to inspect the dance floor. What he found were a couple of not-quite-glamorous Midwestern couples swaying to the music. "Who are these people?" Mr. Beavers asked.
"Minnesotans," he was told.
"Hmm," he said, tapping his foot and checking his watch. It was 9 P.M. "It's O.K.," he mumbled, "it's still early."
Mr. Beavers retreated to his office in the club, which is situated in the bowels of Minneapolis's historic Lumber Exchange Building. "In my clubs in New York," he said, "I never used the office for anything but, how shall I say, entertainment. Here, finally, I've learned how to pay attention."
Indeed. Scattered in piles about Mr. Beavers's desk were papers bearing floor plans, economic projections and proper-looking prospectuses for would-be investors. He pulled out a manila envelope. "Here," he said, "are the old days."
Lying there like lox were news clips dating from Ronald Reagan's second term, culled from night-life columns in The New York Post, Interview, The New York Daily News and Town & Country. Most of the old stories included pictures of the dashing, club-owning Beavers brothers: Toby, Angus and Nick, the youngest. Some articles pointed out that the brothers are blueblood descendants of two fine old New York families, the Beekmans and Devereauxs. Another one mentioned how he was the first student to be thrown out twice from the St. Mark's prep school.
"In the 80's, I was going out every night, trying to be entertained by people I hardly knew," he said. "If I numbed my senses, everybody seemed fascinating. Booze gave me the illusion that my life was great."
By 1988, Mr. Beavers had burned out. After a few stops at Minnesota's famed Hazelden clinic, the cure took. Wary of New York, of his old friends and habits, he took a minimum-wage job scooping frozen yogurt at a Minneapolis shopping mall. "I know it sounds funny," he said, "but that job was the first time I ever really felt good about myself."
While at Hazelden, Mr. Beavers had run into Terry Prem, 29, an old friend from his New York days, who had come to Minnesota to kick a heroin habit. There, they came up with the plot to bring a New York-style night spot to Minneapolis. "We wanted to do what Eric Goode did at Area," he said.
For most of last year, the two plotted and built their club, at a cost of $450,000. Thirty artists, most of them local, painted pictures for the walls and built 125 pieces of furniture, as well as two bars covered with mosaics. The music would be deep house, the look very New York -- an effect heightened when Dante, the former doorman at the Manhattan club Tatou and a fellow Hazelden graduate, was hired to work out front.
"At the door," Mr. Beavers said, "we decided to take the Nell's philosophy of being much more democratic than the typical New York club. There's a deep-seated populist morality here in Minnesota that we knew we'd have to honor if we were to survive."
The proprietor locked his office door and headed back into the quickly filling club. By 11, the place was wall-to-wall with SoHo-Melrose Avenue looks, though the accompanying accents sounded like they came from Lake Wobegon. It's the Minneapolis Style, a hybrid hipness wherein scene fiends with pierced noses can be as polite as Archie comic-book characters.
By 11:30 on opening night, Rogue was filled to its 1,000-person capacity with the kind of people Nick Beavers wanted in his nightclub. Wasn't he tempted by all the alcohol? "At first I was, but you get acclimated," he said.
Besides, Rogue has a fully stocked juice and cappuccino bar meant to serve the legions of recovering addicts from both coasts who have decided to stay in Minnesota. Here, away from their old habits, they huddle with their newly sober friends in a community of expatriates that includes some of the most style-conscious types in the country.
That community came out in force for Nick Beavers's opening night. Gripping designer juice bottles, they hugged each other in the V.I.P. room and discussed how Minneapolis had become a happy Elba for the hip and dry. "I've been drunk in every club in Paris, Los Angeles, Rome and New York," said Jasper, 28, a now-sober studio musician who would not identify himself further, after he embraced Mr. Beavers. "And this is as cool as anything I've seen."
Someday, Mr. Beavers said, he'll go back to New York. He thinks and dreams about home, but for now, he's happy where he is. And he said he felt no guilt that for many, the lasting legacy of places like his old Surf Club was personal destruction.
"The drugs were everywhere, and everybody was touched," he said. "The key word of the 80's was extreme -- and I lived it. I'm glad I did it, but I'm grateful that I'm alive and still have my brains and health."
The dance floor was bopping. "Anyway," he said happily, "now I've got my club."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Minneapolis has become a happy Elba for the hip and dry. Nick Beavers and Terry Prem, above right, two Hazelden clinic graduates, have opened the Rogue bar, above. (Photographs by Steve Woit for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Pontiac's More Insurable Pony Car

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
OVER the past 40 years, I have owned a lot of automobiles. Somehow, though, there have been surprising gaps in that history.
There has been no Corvette, for example, and I would love to have a Corvette. I have never owned a Mustang, Ford's original pony car. Nor have I sallied forth to fly home in a Camaro or Firebird. 
 Those last two, F-bodies in General Motors nomenclature, were G.M.'s followup to the Mustang. The sporty Chevys and Pontiacs came out in 1967, three years after Ford scored its coup, and they have worn well, selling millions of copies with just four redesigns.
Pontiac alone has put more than two million Firebirds on America's streets, but there is a good reason why some of us have been left looking. As practical vehicles, after all, the cars are ridiculous.
They are hard to get into and to get out of. They have almost no room inside, and the back seat is useful only for small children or for torturing in-laws. Their fuel economy has been better left unspoken, and a commute in a Firebird of the past could nicely be compared to a tooth-jarring trip in a very fast stagecoach.
They have big engines and rear-wheel drive and they don't go in the snow. They are, in truth, fairly silly. But they sure are wonderful toys.
The fourth generation, new for '93 and the first redesign since 1982, is the best since the original. Power has been increased. The bodies have more solidity. Aerodynamics have improved, and the three models -- basic Firebird, Formula and Trans Am -- are exercises in sleek styling.
They will appeal to their usual audience, however, and therein lies a further problem. Except for the basic model, whose market is said to be mostly female, the Formula and Trans Am hot rods attract young single males, and soaring insurance costs have made the cars prohibitive for many would-be buyers.
As a result, Pontiac has fortified the new vehicles' structure and added safety items, along with streamlining service procedures and reducing the price to replace the parts.
Antilock brakes are now standard, and there are air bags for the driver and front passenger. Bumpers protect against 5-mile-per-hour impacts, double the Federal standard, and more integrity has been built into the doors.
Most body parts are plastic, hung on a stiff steel inner cage, and the outer panels resist dents, dings and corrosion. Those body parts that are in fact steel, like the rear quarter panels and hood, are galvanized on both sides.
"We've made the car more theft-resistant and less costly to repair," said John Middlebrook, Pontiac's general manager, "and that should take a bite out of the premiums that owners have traditionally paid."
Chuck Hurley, a vice president of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, an information group supported by the major insurers, agrees -- to a point. And he notes that the insurance companies will probably reduce rates, based on the air bags alone.
"Some will and some won't," he said. "Certainly, most major companies do offer discounts for cars equipped with the bags, and the discount ranges from 20 to 60 percent. There are some companies, too, that have offered discounts on cars with antilock brakes. But what I think is important is that the manufacturer is placing a high priority on reducing the premium burden on the customer."
Still, the hatchbacks are naturally popular with people who like to go fast, and with thieves, and that makes them high-risk vehicles.
To counter theft, Pontiac has added the security of a delayed electrical relay that disables the unlocking functions of the doors and rear hatch 30 seconds after a Firebird has been locked from the outside. That eliminates the possibility that the car's power locks will be activated by illegal means.
In addition, there are locking nuts for the jazzy aluminum wheels, and the doors have mechanisms that are all but impossible to open with "slim jims," thin steel shafts that are a thief's favorite tool.
The test cars, a white Firebird coupe, a metallic green Formula and a flame-red Trans Am, shared those basics, but there were big differences, too.
The base car, with a sticker that started at $13,995 and had a bottom line of $17,086, was equipped with a new 3.4-liter V6 that sent its 160-horsepower to the road through a four-speed automatic transmission and tires that were slightly smaller than those of its more robust companions.
The $21,230 Formula was essentially the cleaner basic body with all the same innards of the more outrageous $22,706 Trans Am. Both the hotter cars were driven by Pontiac's new 5.7-liter V8, and the Formula had a new six-speed stick while the Trans Am had the optional automatic.
And while the V6 puts out 20 horses more than the engine in last year's base coupe, the V8 is up by 35. That means a rating of 275 horsepower, quite enough to burn the rear wheels to the ground if you are young and macho or own stock in Goodyear.
But no matter the model, the Firebird is fun, with dash and good looks. This year's body is far more solid and there are fewer creaks and groans than in the past. On the highway, there is even a decent ride, and the cars will appeal more than ever to the singles and couples that have always been Firebird's meat.
As for me, I think I'll continue to give G.M.'s pony car a pass. Maybe an occasional turn at the wheel is enough. Maybe I'm just getting old.

HEADLINE: Declare Victory, Hand Off, Slip Out, Cross Fingers

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

 BODY:
WHEN former President Bush deployed American troops to assure the delivery of relief supplies in Somalia as his Presidency reached its end, he spoke much of moral imperatives and of taking a stand. In those days, he meant to signal Washington's unwillingness to remain idle while a handful of marauding warlords kept food from 2 million people who risked starving to death.
It was language reminiscent of Desert Storm, in which Mr. Bush vowed that United States forces would teach Saddam Hussein a thing or two about stealing the territory of a neighboring country. But last year, Iran quietly took over four islands belonging to the United Arab Emirates and deported their people, with hardly a protest from the United States. The lessons of Desert Storm appeared to have struck deeper in Washington than in the gulf. 
 Now, with the bulk of American troops home from Somalia and the Clinton Administration reluctantly weighing whether to intervene in Bosnia, it seems a fair time to tally up the lessons Washington may glean from its odyssey in the Horn of Africa. Yesterday, the United Nations began financing most of the foreign presence in Somalia, where up to 5,000 American troops will remain in an international contingent of 28,000.
"Much to everyone's dismay, Somalia may be characteristic of the kinds of situations that we face in the future," said Mary E. Morris, a policy analyst at the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif., who is studying the Somalia intervention for United States Army planners. "There aren't clear political goals stated up front."
From a distance, Somalia seemed an easy place to do some good. Mustering a mandate for intervention was not difficult for an outgoing President, for Somalia presented few of the pitfalls that surrounded other horrors beckoning for an American response.
The savannahs and flat deserts of southern Somalia made the region seem almost like an open palm, with none of the mountainous hiding places of the former Yugoslavia. The long coastline made access to major cities simple, and the weather, hot and dry, made military movements relatively easy.
The desertscape was matched by a relatively clear political field. Somalia's lack of a government meant an absence of credible organized opposition, either political or military -- a circumstance not echoed in nearby Sudan, where people were also starving because of a civil war. And it allowed the international community to virtually sidestep the issue of sovereignty.
Nor was the fighting among factions complicated by the musty historic and religious hatreds that could trigger ethnic cleansing in the Balkans, the specter of which looms elsewhere over the former East bloc.
Now, as an important chapter in America's intervention in Somalia ends, it can be called a success, in modest ways. Sacks of rice made it inland from the ports unassaulted. People stopped dying by the hundreds each day from famine. Gravediggers, once the busiest men in town, began looking for new jobs.
And the United States managed a relatively clean, quick intervention with a hand-over to United Nations forces, now armed with authority to enforce the terms of the Somali peace agreement. United Nations troops will have an unprecedented mandate to disarm the fighting clans, rather than living uneasily in the traditional passive role of peacekeeper or observer.
But what may have seemed a blessing before intervention proved a problem later. The lack of a central government or military meant there was no authority to shore up, making a total withdrawal of United States forces and expertise untenable for the moment. Americans will remain behind in important leadership posts and 20 to 30 will stay on to help negotiate the peace.
"We're not sure the United Nations can provide the structure that will allow Somalia to create its own political framework," said Ms. Morris. "Once we get out of there, six months down the line, are things going to be really better than they were before we went in?"
So simple from afar, Somalia demonstrates how intractable the problems that demand the rescue by foreign armies can be, and how impenetrable and unpredictable are the barriers of culture.
Once American troops answered scattered attacks by destroying a heavy weapons compound of Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, the threat became largely a matter of sniper fire and children throwing rocks. The power of the warlords waned, but organized gangs sprang up to present new dangers to relief workers.
And United States forces, which had been deployed to feed starving children, instead found themselves carrying bats and sticks to beat off youngsters who made a sport of stealing their sunglasses and field rations. In the worst instances, marines and soldiers ended up killing youngsters under dubious circumstances.
 
Corruption Prevailed Anyway
 Over 100 Somalis are thought to have been killed by foreign forces on a humanitarian mission, making some grumble that it seemed more like an occupation. Eight American soldiers and nine from other countries died.
Despite American success in getting the relief supplies to the hungry, the essential breakdown of Somali society meant that the thievery and violence weeded out in one place simply cropped up elsewhere. Corruption ran so deep that many village elders who received the relief supplies diverted them from their own people for sale in the markets. Relief agencies were no longer paying extortionate off-loading fees; instead, they paid extortion in the form of protection fees to "employees" who did little work, and who subsequently robbed many of them when they tried to fire them.
Somalia also demonstrated how difficult limiting American presence can be, even in a multinational context. While President Bush ruled out brokering a political solution to Somalia's anarchy when he announced the deployment, it was not long before United States troops and diplomats found themselves doing more than simply securing the delivery of food relief -- patrolling the streets at night, disarming some of the factions and shepherding a political reconciliation among the 15 rival factions.
Somalia may, ultimately, prove to be such an anomaly that it may have little to reveal for other engagements, like Bosnia. There, both the goals of an American-led intervention and the level of commitment appear more difficult to determine beforehand.
"The acutest suffering in Somalia has been alleviated. The Bosnian case will be much more uncertain in that respect," said Helmut Sonnenfeldt, a guest scholar at the Brookings Institution in Washington. "In many ways, horrible as it was, Somalia will prove to have been a lot simpler and less bloody than the former Yugoslavia."

HEADLINE: GETTING IN, GETTING OUT;
Any War in Bosnia Would Carry a Domestic Price

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS the Clinton Administration drew up its tougher policy on Bosnia last week, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said any decision to intervene militarily in the Balkans had to meet four criteria: the goals must be clear and understandable to the American people; the chances for success must be high; the American public must support the effort; and an "exit strategy" for getting out quickly must exist from the start. That is a very sensible list of criteria. The problem is that the only operation they could fit is another American invasion of Grenada. World War II would not have qualified, let alone Bosnia.
Mr. Christopher cannot be faulted for trying to bring some analytical clarity to President Clinton's first major foreign policy decision: to commit American military power to help resolve the Bosnia crisis. But Mr. Christopher is like a navigator advising his captain to follow the stars in the middle of a hurricane; it's great advice, but in the middle of a storm, you can't see Orion. And in the middle of a Balkan civil war, no checklist, no amount of advance planning, can eliminate the risks when a great power becomes embroiled in the politics of small tribes. 
 Mr. Christopher's effort, though, reflects the struggle going on now in President Clinton's head as he weighs what to do in Bosnia. Mr. Clinton is not just weighing military options -- sanctions versus bombing, lifting the arms embargo on Bosnia versus sending in ground troops. He is weighing his Presidency. He is weighing Bosnia versus his health care initiative, Bosnia versus his budget, Bosnia versus his national service plans.
These are the real tradeoffs Mr. Clinton may have to make if he intervenes in the Balkans, for it is hard to focus like a laser on the economy from inside the windowless White House situation room. And the reason Mr. Clinton has agonized over his Bosnia policy so long, the reason Mr. Christopher has come up with his star chart for a Balkan black hole, is that they are trying to figure out how to limit those tradeoffs. They are looking for that perfectly calibrated policy that will be just enough to tilt the balance of power in Bosnia toward a settlement, just enough to convince historians that when genocide stalked Europe for the second time this century they didn't avert their eyes -- but not so much as to suck them into a quagmire. Clinton aides say only by such a nuanced strategy can they hope to have Bosnia and the budget, Sarajevo and national service.
That is the underlying logic of the policy course decided at the White House yesterday. While the details were not spelled out, Mr. Christopher said the President had decided in principle to commit a limited amount of American military power to try to end the fighting in the Balkans. He said he was being sent to Europe to persuade the allies to go along with this strategy of using limited force, economic sanctions and diplomatic pressure to compel the Serbs to accept a peace agreement.
This is dangerous stuff. Why? Because as a student of the Presidency Mr. Clinton surely knows that the minute the United States takes military action in Bosnia, as the world's only superpower, it will assume responsibility for the outcome there. It will become "our war," no matter how many allies join in, just as happened in both the Persian Gulf war and in Korea. And Mr. Clinton will become a war President, with all that that entails in terms of demands on his time and the need to come out a winner. In effect, Mr. Clinton is going to make himself responsible for resolving the ultimate tribal feud.
Which leads to the second thing Mr. Clinton undoubtedly realizes -- that an open-ended American involvement in the Balkans could hamper his domestic agenda with the very same ferocity that Vietnam hobbled Lyndon Johnson's Great Society. "Like Bosnia, Vietnam was a war that Johnson was wary of getting involved in at the time," said the historian Ronald Steel. "But the pundits said, 'How can we just stand by and let this happen?' And columnists like Joe Alsop questioned Johnson's manhood. And so he acted. In Vietnam we acted as the leader of the free world. In Bosnia we are told we must act as leader of the whole world."
But Johnson was also trying to transform the country with his Great Society programs, Mr. Steel said, "and then the war chewed up greater and greater resources, and then he refused to raise taxes to pay for the war because it was unpopular, so he had to reach into the domestic programs to pay for it, and deficit financing, and that led to inflation, and then the opposition to his Vietnam program from liberals was married to the conservatives in Congress who hated his domestic programs and so he was totally paralyzed. In the end, the same pundits who drove him into the war abandoned him."
Clinton aides say this analogy is very much on the President's mind. But there is also a third thing weighing on him -- that a young President cannot afford to look indecisive and unprincipled in the face of ethnic cleansing and rape -- for that too can corrode a President's effectiveness at home and abroad.
"There is a price for Clinton not acting consistent with his principles, and having acted, there is an equally weighty price for the inevitable unanticipated consequences of being consistent with his principles," said Yaron Ezrahi, a Princeton-based political theorist.
The necessity for the President to act on Bosnia now could not come at a worse time for him, right at the end of his first 100 days, when he has been widely criticized for having lost some of his single-minded focus on the nation's economy, the main reason he got elected.
What he could use now is an easy victory abroad that would quickly yield political capital at home -- capital that he could use to re-energize his domestic agenda, and leadership stature. The gulf war victory was like a booster rocket for Mr. Bush; the only problem was that he had no domestic agenda to harness it to and so it simply flamed out.
Theoretically, a successful assertion of Clinton leadership in the Balkans could help the President win approval of his health care plan at home. The problem for Mr. Clinton is that Bosnia, by its very nature, is not a military situation that will yield easy political capital, because in such an ethnic war the definition of success is much more elusive.
The American people could easily understand the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. It was one nation seizing another. America came in and pushed Iraq back across the border. But Bosnia is made up of a thousand mini-border wars, between people who share the same sidewalks, the same hillsides, the same villages. What constitutes success there? Is success when everyone is returned to his or her ancestral home? Is success simply punishing the Serbs? Is success the establishment of a Jeffersonian democracy in Bosnia? When everybody has a definition of success, nobody has a definition, and that makes translating victory there into political momentum at home extremely difficult.
What Mr. Christopher was trying to do in laying down his four fixed guidelines was to chart a pathway for Mr. Clinton to be both principled and prudent. It was a commendable effort, but there is no such thing as Euclidian diplomacy for a civil war. There are no parallel lines in the Balkans; the laws of geometry do not apply. The only rules there are no rules at all and, if history is any guide, the only direction that you can be certain events there will go is in a circle.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
In Peru, a 'Second Coup' Reveals the Upper Hand

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
THE episode is being called Peru's "second coup" army tanks rolling into the streets of Lima a week and a half ago in a furious reaction to attempts by the Peruvian Congress to investigate human rights abuses by the military.
It was the most graphic illustration to date of the precarious power equation that has existed in Peru since what is widely known as the first coup under President Alberto K. Fujimori: On April 5, 1992, with the military's support, he suspended constitutional rule to seize near-dictatorial authority, asserting that he needed greater powers to combat a debilitating guerrilla insurgency, rampant corruption and drug trafficking. 
 The army's latest show of force underlined, if there were any doubt, that the President's survival ultimately depends on the backing of generals. To be sure, he is still a popular leader, with 64 percent of public support -- because of his tough action rather than in spite of it. He has made major advances in dismantling the feared Shining Path guerrilla group by capturing its leader, Abimael Guzman Reynoso, and many of its leaders. And he has promoted a free-market economic policy that has investors once again looking at Peru.
But in abolishing constitutional rule last year he became a captive of the military in times of crisis. And thus Peru serves as a reminder that two defining characteristics of the struggling democracies of Latin America are the ever-present threat of military meddling and the enduring appeal of the coup to the region's generals.
Venezuela has suffered two coup attempts since the beginning of 1992. In Chile, the three-year-old civilian Government has struggled so far in vain to nudge Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former dictator, out of his position as Commander in Chief of the army. In Uruguay, Bolivia and Paraguay, secretive groups of current and former military officers periodically warn civilian governments not to delve into past abuses.
Across Latin America, unlike in the United States, the prevailing sentiment is that the military is above the reach of the people. It is an elite society within a larger society, tightly closed to the outside world, highly regimented and far more stable than political parties and governments that come and go.
Latin militaries in the end have a messianic self-image, seeing themselves as the nation's ultimate strength and resource, not just as its protector against foreign invasion.
"In Latin America, it is similar to the Prussian military thinking, that the disappearance of the armed forces means the disappearance of the nation, and that the armed forces are the foundations of nations," said Enrique Obando, a political analyst with the Peruvian Center for International Studies. "In the United States, the military is subject to the Constitution. Here, they say that in theory, but in practice they are above the Constitution."
 
Open Defiance
 At the core of the Peruvian military's current discontent is its conviction that outside interference -- in the form of human-rights scrutiny, for example -- is undermining what it sees as its vital and overriding mission of rooting out subversion.
In the latest confrontation, the army openly defied the authority of the new Congress that Mr. Fujimori created in elections last November.
When called before the legislature, the Army Commander, Gen. Nicolas de Bari Hermoza, refused to answer questions about the disappearance of nine students and a professor last year at La Cantuta University, just outside Lima. And he accused a group of lawmakers of aiding guerrilla organizations.
"I am not going to tolerate this," he said, summing up the military's frustration.
For the next two days, on April 21 and 22, tanks appeared in parts of Lima. General Hermoza is now being called "the other president."
Mr. Fujimori seemed to be taken by surprise. Instead of displaying his usual confident, in-control demeanor, he became the cautious mediator in a national address. Many Peruvians argue that he should have promptly dismissed the officers responsible for the show of force. Others say that would have provoked his immediate overthrow.
Most agree that Mr. Fujimori is between the sword and the wall, pressured by the United States to eliminate human-rights abuses as a condition of much-needed financial aid, but facing an army that believes that such abuses are inevitable and unavoidable in its internal war against subversives.
Officers say privately that cases in which innocent victims were subject to abuse should be investigated (a commitment belied recently by an Americas Watch report concluding that rapes by counterinsurgency troops are common and officially tolerated). The officers also say it is unacceptable to question the killing of the Cantuta students, who even Western diplomats acknowledge were most likely members of the Shining Path.
"No official is going to let his career or the career of a fellow officer be ruined because they killed a terrorist," said Mr. Obando. "They consider that by killing terrorists they are completing their mission."
Another development angering the military was the release to the press of anonymous reports on the killing of Shining Path members, in which the identities of senior officials involved were revealed.
"All the families started coming to command headquarters with wives and children asking for security, fearing the Shining Path would start knocking them off," said a member of congress. The guerrillas are known to take revenge on military officers and their families.
Analysts say the army is not about to rise up and force Mr. Fujimori out of office. That would be hard, because of his high level of public support and the prospect of retaliation by both the United States and Latin American countries.
Many say that for perhaps the first time since he suspended the Constitution, President Fujimori now understands the limits on his power and will thus have to walk a tightrope over the next few weeks. To move the economy ahead, he will have to mollify the Clinton Administration on human rights. But analysts expect a policy response designed to just squeak by and not lead to the sacrifice of many senior army officers.
For in the end, he cannot afford to abandon his ultimate source of strength.

HEADLINE: Conversations/Angela Oh;
Giving Voice to the Hurt And Betrayal of Korean-Americans

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
ONE year after the rioting that devastated the Korean community here, Angela Oh, a prominent Korean-American lawyer, has decided to learn to read and write the language of her parents.
She can speak Korean, said Miss Oh, a busy, no-nonsense professional who, as president of the Korean American Bar Association of Southern California, has emerged as a spokesman for her community. Learning to read it would also allow her to read the documents of her clients. It took her a while to confess: "Really, it's on a personal level. I want to read novels. You know that? That's my goal. Yes, I want to read novels and I want to read the poetry of the people." 
 The riots that erupted on April 29, 1992, were a watershed for Korean-Americans, bringing them up short in their headlong pursuit of economic success and forcing many of them, including Miss Oh, to rethink their place astride two cultures.
More than 2,000 Korean businesses were damaged or destroyed, totaling more than $350 million in damage, and only one in four have reopened a year later. The failure of the police to protect them and of the government to help them rebuild has bred deep resentment as well as a realization that Korean-Americans must work harder to be included in the political and social process of the country.
"Already in the first days after the riots last April, many of us were saying: This is our rite of passage into American society. This is our people's tragedy," said Miss Oh, 37, in an interview in her downtown law office. "It is what internment was to the Japanese.
"It's a little scary because I don't see where this one is going to end," she added. "There is a lot of animosity toward Koreans out there right now," from the public and even from some government agencies.
The place of Koreans in American society is lonely and precarious, she said, and has served as a convenient buffer between the racism of the white majority and the anger of the black minority. Just as Korean-owned businesses, which suffered nearly half the looting and vandalism in last year's violence, became an outlet for the rage of many rioters, Korean-Americans here now view themselves as "human shields" in a complicated racial hierarchy, she said.
"We stand between the African-Americans, who are really at the bottom rung, and the white community, which is at the top rung because they are at the top of the power structure," Miss Oh said. "That's why I hate the term 'model minority.' It really makes me blanch. It translates into being a human shield."
 
Hard-Working Drones?
 Instead of confronting the profound socioeconomic problems blacks face, Miss Oh said, whites merely point to the industrious Koreans and say, "How come blacks aren't more like you guys? Why don't they help each other more? Why don't they work as hard as you do?"
In the midst of the city's ethnic and racial frictions, Korean-Americans are also glibly caricatured, and dismissed, as hard-working drones by those in power and resented by poor blacks. "We are perceived as being, as a people, greedy, selfish, insulated and unwilling to become a part of America," Miss Oh said. "That is how we are seen. It is very untrue in terms of the heart of the people."
A low point came this week in a two-hour televised town meeting that brought together representatives of many racial and ethnic groups. A Korean spokesman challenged Labor Secretary Ron Brown to find $20 million to help reopen hundreds of burned-out Korean-owned liquor stores.
The questioner drew derisive laughter when Mr. Brown responded that if the Federal Government had $20 million to spare, it certainly would not spend it to open liquor stores.
"That was a horrible moment," Miss Oh recalled. "But the problem is that there is a moral obligation that Los Angeles needs to make to the Koreans. These people lost everything. They had investments ranging from $180,000 to half a million dollars. Those losses for the most part could not be insured because they couldn't find carriers, or the carriers were bogus. How do you tell these people that lost half a million dollars that there is nothing you can do about it?"
One widely accepted lesson of the riot and its aftermath is that Korean-Americans must become more involved in politics and American society. "They need to begin to participate in other aspects of American life, other than the material," Miss Oh said. "Materialism was a very, very prominent characteristic in our community. People understand now that those things they have gathered can be taken away so easily."
Most political participation had been confined to making campaign contributions, she said. "That's not political power, as we saw," she said. "They learned that very painfully." When the crisis came, they lacked the clout to win a fair share in recovery efforts. While Koreatown has mostly rebuilt, most of the businesses located in the South Central neighborhood have not.
 
She's Not Meek
 When Miss Oh's parents immigrated to Los Angeles as college students in the 1950's, there were only a few Koreans in this country. As her mother, a schoolteacher, and father, a laboratory technician, raised their five children -- a lawyer, a doctor, a pharmacist, a dentist and an architect -- the Korean population of the country swelled to nearly 700,000. The huge increase, particularly over the past decade, included mostly the small merchants whose influx to Los Angeles has created the largest Korean enclave outside Korea.
After receiving her law degree from the University of California at Davis in 1986, Miss Oh became active in civil rights and human rights causes. Since the riots, her criminal defense practice has included a larger number of Korean-Americans, and her awareness of their special needs has grown acute.
She is now defending a married couple charged with arson in the fire that burned their store a year ago. Unable to speak English or comprehend the American legal system, Miss Oh said, they are at the mercy of forces they do not understand.
Over the past year, she has increasingly taken it upon herself to give voice to the needs of her community. Influenced by the feminist movement, she says, she has broken with a cultural tradition of meek and dutiful womanhood to become an advocate, active in political campaigns, government commissions and women's rights groups.
Along with its needs, the potential cultural contributions of the Korean-American community have been overlooked, Miss Oh said, including areas such as literature and the arts. "Along with the politics and the economics and all that," she said, "I really think that the creativity that is needed at this point in the history of this country is going to come from other sources, from the guts of the people."
Like many in her community, Miss Oh says she remains suspended between the two cultures, unsure of her identity or her role. "I see myself as a Korean-American -- not Korean, not American, but something quite different and undefined," she said. "But definitely I have in my gut a sense that I am valuable to this country."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Mightier Yen Makes Japan Very Edgy

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
RARELY has an issue as abstract as exchange rate policy gripped a country as it has Japan over the past few weeks.
When the yen soared to a postwar high against the dollar in response to Clinton's remark two weeks ago that a stronger yen would help reduce Japan's trade surplus, Government officials here were enraged, arguing that this policy would weaken their economy. But when Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen indicated on Tuesday that the yen's swift appreciation may have been excessive, the exchange rate settled down and the Japanese breathed a collective sigh. 
 It is doubtful, however, that the obsession here with currency movements is over, and American consumers may soon learn that the issue is likely to affect their wallets. The price of Japanese goods in the United States is likely to rise substantially, economists say, affecting everything from the price of a new Mazda to American computers with Japanese components. In the past, American manufacturers took such opportunities to raise their own prices, giving a fillip to inflation.
Which is the point of the policy. The Clinton Administration encouraged the stronger yen as one means of taming Japan's enormous trade surplus. A mightier yen makes Japanese goods more expensive for Americans, and American products cheaper for Japanese.
That means improvements in America's industrial competitiveness will be paid for partly by Americans. Japanese exporters will also be squeezed, which was one reason their Government criticized the American policy. A deeper reason was the Clinton Administration's failure to consult the Japanese before the President endorsed the yen's rise.
That may be the harshest lesson from the yen's 10 percent rise in value since the beginning of this year, to a current rate of about 111.50 to the dollar. Japan is the only member of the Group of Seven industrial nations with a trade surplus, which is likely to hit an unprecedented $160 billion this year. The United States and the other countries seem to think that such a scenario would place a heavy burden on the Japanese to promptly reduce this imbalance, or the solutions will be imposed on them.
The Japanese Government has responded by charging that the manipulation of currency rates is being done for political ends, but economists say the yen is likely to rise even more, possibly to 100 to the dollar, as a natural reaction to Japan's surplus.
"President Clinton is not being unfair, as the Government is saying," said Kazuaki Harada, president of the Sanwa Research Institute. "It is quite reasonable that the yen should appreciate. It is likely to get worse."

HEADLINE: American Voices: On a Role in Bosnia/A special report.;
In American Voices, a Sense of Concern Over Bosnia Role

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 28

 BODY:
When Nancy Brier talks about the shooting and killing in Bosnia, there is anger in her voice. And frustration. And confusion.
Only one thing seems clear to her. 
 "It should be stopped, but we shouldn't try to stop it on our own, not with American boys," she says. "Terrible as it is, it's basically Europe's problem because it's in Europe's backyard. Maybe we can help out a bit through the United Nations. But no more than that."
 
Wary of Involvement
 The comments of Ms. Brier, a marketing representative here for the Sprint telephone company, echoed many of those from about 100 conversations struck up during a weeklong, 1,200-mile trip half-way across the waist of the country, from Virginia's Atlantic Coast to the wheat fields of Kansas. If President Clinton commits the United States to a major military role in the Balkans, he will probably have a difficult time winning approval from people like Ms. Brier.
"Let Italy or Austria or some other neighboring country take the lead in this one," Ms. Brier said. "It's not our guilt trip."
There is much confusion among Americans about what the fighting in Bosnia is all about. There is suspicion that there are not many white hats in the feuding and that neither diplomats nor reporters have made this clear.
 
'Everybody Is a Bad Guy'
 "Who's the real enemy beyond the killing?" asked Abel Garcia, a financial management executive in Overland Park, Kan. "Who would we be fighting? I've been reading and watching for months, and I still don't know. Maybe everybody is a bad guy in this one."
There is resentment that other nations, particularly those neighboring the Balkans, are looking to the United States, thousands of miles away, for a solution.
"Asking America to clean up that mess over there is like asking Sweden and France to stop a fight over here between Illinois and Missouri," said Georgia Dunaway, a hotel receptionist in Okawville, Ill., a farm village just east of St. Louis. "It's absurd. Why are we forever being dragged into these things? Why are we forever sending our sons?"
There is worry, some of it tinged with cynicism, that the President may be making more of the American role in the crisis than is warranted, turning it into a test of his political manhood or allowing others to turn it into such a test.
"The danger is that he'll feel at some point, or that he'll be made to feel, that this is the time and place where he has to prove he's a strong leader," said Jan Buerge, owner of the World's Window gift shop in Kansas City. "He's already in trouble in the polls. Better watch out."
 
The Specter of Vietnam
 There is abiding fear that the Balkans are another Vietnam, a deep-seated angst that tends to outweigh concern that another Holocaust is in the making there.
"I know about the Holocaust and I certainly don't denigrate it as a concern," said Ernest Pepples, senior vice president and general counsel for the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation in Louisville, Ky. "But I also know about Vietnam and what a hopeless quagmire it turned out to be for us."
Above all, when it comes to Bosnia, Americans have questions.
"The question I want answered is, 'Why are there so many questions?' " said Arthur Parks, a public relations executive from Kansas City. "It seems to me that when you have a situation in which there are so few answers, you'd better slow down and give things some extra thought. If we go in, we'd all better agree on why, what's at stake, what our goals are, how we're going to achieve them and how we're going to get out. None of these questions has been answered yet."
Polls within the last 10 days have come up with contradictory results about what role Americans think the United States should play in Bosnia, depending on how the questions are asked. But every survey has uncovered deep concern about greater United States involvement.
The random conversations, in seven states and a score of cities, towns and villages, produced detailed explanations for this concern, some reasoned, some emotional, some visceral. Some were given only under persistent questioning, as if the subject was being explored thoroughly and openly only for the first time.
 
'You Just Grit Your Teeth'
 Only a handful of people called for immediate United States military action against Serbian gunners or for the strengthening of the anti-Serb forces. They argued that "ethnic cleansing" had created a moral crisis that only American leadership and armed might could end.
"Since others won't stop it, we have to step out front and do it," said Austin St. Clair of Huntington, W.Va., clutching her 2-year-old daughter, Virginia. "They're killing children over there in cold blood. This isn't something you argue about. You just grit your teeth and do it because doing something is the right and moral thing to do."
A few people said the United States should play no role at all in the crisis.
"All of this talk of genocide and another Holocaust -- that's overstatement," said Jabr Dumit, a St. Louis camera shop owner. "I know something about ethnic tension. I'm Lebanese. Both sides are 'cleansing' over there. That goes with the territory. Let 'em wear themselves out."
But while a few people wanted immediate American military involvement in the crisis or no involvement at all, most tended to take the approach proposed by Ms. Brier. In the absence of more action by European nations to end the crisis, they were willing for the United States to take part in an intensified peacekeeping effort by the United Nations, but only if the force was not made up mainly of American units. And even then their enthusiasm was muted.
"You have to wonder when something like this is in Europe's backyard and Europe doesn't bother to put an end to it," said Dr. York Silliman, a pathologist from St. Joseph, Mo. "Still, I'd go along with a mixed, balanced U.N. force if all efforts at negotiating fail. But I worry. These people have been fighting each other for so long they can't remember why they're fighting. And now we're going to break it up?"
Tom Mayberry, a hotel bellhop from Floyds Knobs, Ind., worried that if the United States becomes involved in military action in the Balkans, even as a bit player with a United Nations force, the involvement will drag on longer than most people expect.
"We should help stop the killing," he said. "It's got to be stopped. But what then? There's no way this is going to be a short-term affair. This strikes me as an open-ended commitment when it comes to peacekeeping."
As Kendall Kiely, a Louisville insurance executive, sees the situation, it is basically a leadership challenge for President Clinton, a challenge that could fatally flaw his Presidency if mishandled. He wants Mr. Clinton to put more pressure on the Europeans to take action on their own.
"He's trying to lead us when what he really needs to do is lead the Europeans, get them more involved," Mr. Kiely said. "They won't do anything more until he forces them to do something, even though it's basically their problem. They'll just sucker us in if they can. He's got to tell them to move on something this serious or our relations with Europe are going to sour. The Serbs will come around if they become convinced that he's serious and the Europeans are serious."
 
Crossroads for U.N.
 For Sue Orwick, a secretary in Louisville, the only acceptable way for the United States to play a military role in Bosnia would be as part of a United Nations force. In fact, she sees the Balkans crisis as a crossroads for the United Nations, coming as it has after the demise of Communism in Europe.
"This is as good a place as we're going to find to make U.N. peacekeeping a real force in this world," she said. "The balance of power has changed and there's now more opportunity than ever for nations to pull together, to share roles without trying to dominate each other. The U.S. can be just another of the players. You can't find a better test than Bosnia. We're talking about keeping a whole nation from being wiped out -- another Holocaust, the moral dilemma of this decade."
Is Bosnia another Holocaust in the making?
"That's overstating things," said Judge Ellis Gregory Jr. of the St. Louis County Circuit Court in Clayton, Mo. "True, there is terrible killing going on over there. But this is mostly a continuation of ethnic hatreds that have been boiling over for literally centuries and are likely to continue boiling over. The killing must be stopped. But let's not overstate the case."
To Rabbi Joshua Taub of Prairie Village, Kan., little is accomplished by trying to compare what is happening now in Bosnia and what happened during the Nazi occupation of Europe during World War II. The only real issue, in his view, is that people are dying.
"Call it what you will," he said. "But we must all speak out. It must be stopped. I would like to see the U.S. go in as part of a U.N. force. We don't rule the world. We can't act independently. But having said all that, I'm not very optimistic over the long haul. Holocaust? We had one. The world condemned it. And the killing goes on. Speak out."
Ralph Maledy, a retired florist from Columbia, Mo., argues that what is happening in Bosnia today bears little resemblance to what happened in Europe half a century ago during World War II. He is a veteran of that war.
"I was with Patton's Third Army," he said. "We liberated some of the concentration camps. This isn't on the same scale. That doesn't excuse what is happening today. The killing ought to be stopped. But facts are facts."
Should the United States stop the killing?
"Only as part of a larger force," Mr. Maledy replied. "If the European nations don't get in, we certainly shouldn't. This is no threat to us, not militarily, not economically, not strategically, not any way. I deplore it. But ultimately I can't see it as a threat to anybody but the people already fighting each other."
For Oscar Johnson, who owns a photo supply store in Clayton, Bosnia is more than a killing ground. It is a bitter reminder that man's inhumanity to man does not always move world leaders.
"If what's been going on in South Africa for all these years doesn't qualify for intervention, than what does?" asked Mr. Johnson, who is black. "I say stop the killing in Bosnia. And stop it in South Africa. And stop it in Central America. Stop it everywhere, not just where there are white faces."
Marc Boysworth, a 19-year-old freshman at James Madison University in Harrisonburg, Va., called Bosnia "another Vietnam we don't understand." He would not object to minor American participation in United Nations intervention in the Balkans, but thinks that is not practical because the United States has historically been the leading force in military peacekeeping groups.
He also has another reason for opposing American involvement in Bosnia.
"It's my generation that will have to do the fighting," he said. "I don't want to go to war with a commanding general who ducked the draft and now wants to prove he's a tough guy."
Finally, there is Linda Ballard.
A librarian from University City, Mo., she has made a concerted effort in recent months to understand the Balkans and reach a decision about what the United States should do, but says she just cannot see an easy answer.
"Every morning I pick up the paper and I begin to read," she said. "And then I see the word 'Bosnia.' I just despair."

HEADLINE: Gangs Go Public in New Fight for Respect

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 1

 BODY:
Jimel Barnes, a legendary gang member who made his name two decades ago by punching one of the founders of the Crips gang, was picking at his hors d'oeuvres the other day in the ballroom of the Westin Hotel here.
"Crips and Bloods aren't going to go away," he said, referring to the rival street gangs that have turned South-Central Los Angeles into a battleground. "But now they've got to stand for positive things." 
 All around him, scores of tough young men wearing gang colors sipped soft drinks and exchanged calling cards at a remarkable convention that was part business meeting and part motivational seminar here in the gang capital of America.
 
Evidence of a Truce
 "The main idea is to show the world that there is a truce, to build mutual relationships with corporate America and with city officials to help us resolve the economic problems of the city," said Malik Spellman, a spokesman for Hands Across Watts, former gang members who organized the meeting.
As they age into their 20's and 30's, some gang leaders around the country have begun what they call "trucing." Tiring of the continuing killings, concerned for their own children and tempted by the celebrity of national attention, some of the leaders are leaving the streets for the talk shows to call for peace. But the poverty and anger that spawned the violence are working against them, and there are no easy solutions.
This weekend in Kansas City, Mo., in another gathering, dozens of gang members converged from several cities for a "summit" organized by Mayor Emanuel Cleaver, and their gathering included similar exhortations to end gang violence, a peace march and shopping at Country Club Plaza, an upscale mall.
The gathering attracted the Rev. Benjamin S. Chavis Jr., the newly chosen executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, who said, "What we're trying to achieve, in part, is to say clearly to this nation, to this city, to our communities, 'The killing must stop.' "
 
Taking to the Talk Shows
 For the past year, since the Los Angeles rioting after the first verdict in the police-beating case gave impetus to a shaky truce among some black gangs here, many gang members have been going public. Stripping their blue or red bandannas from their faces, they have become regulars on television talk shows and have added their angry voices to the anguished self-examination of this violent and racially divided city.
A new class of professional former gang members has emerged, with violent crimes and prison records as their credentials. Their agenda of jobs and inner-city renewal is backed by a veiled threat of further violence. If you want peace in the cities, they warn, you must pay for it.
Government officials listen politely.
"Keep up the good work," said Yvonne Brathwaite Burke, a Los Angeles County Supervisor who attended the meeting at the Westin Hotel. "We are so proud of you. We are going to do everything we can."
But with jobs and resources continuing to disappear, there remains little tangible that Ms. Burke or anyone else can offer.
 
Publicity vs. Violence
 For some of the new gang stars, it seems that public exposure is replacing violence as a way to satisfy a hunger for identity and purpose. Some experts on gangs, like James J. Galipeau, a Los Angeles County probation officer, say that for some of these people notoriety may be an end in itself.
"They're spending too much time being celebrities," Mr. Galipeau said. "You heard the younger kids talking about how the projects are blowing up. It's these guys' job to stay in the streets."
The new stars are men like Tony Bogard, a former member of the PJ Watts Crips who heads Hands Across Watts and who crystallized the prevailing rhetoric at the conference on Thursday when he said: "We've got to build up self-esteem. We need black people that are empowered. Each one teach one. We've got to start some kind of dialogue. We need to be a better race of black people."
Another star is Charles Rachal, an inactive member of the 5 Duce Broadway Crips who was invited to President Clinton's inauguration in January "We're not asking for nothing," Mr. Rachal said. He said being in a gang was "about respect, and all we're asking for now is respect."
Then there is Stanley Williams, revered as a co-founder of the Crips, who spoke on videotape from San Quentin prison to the hushed and darkened Westin ballroom, calling on the younger men to "reverse this madness of minority versus minority violence."
Others introduced to applause in the ballroom included the mothers of well-known gang members who are now imprisoned. One of these women was Georgiana Williams, the mother of Damian Williams, who is awaiting trial in the beating of a white truck driver at the beginning of last year's riots.
 
Getting Down to Business
 For some participants, the Westin conference offered an opportunity to establish contacts. "We can do lunch sometime," a gang leader known as Diamond told a new acquaintance as he stood outside the ballroom. "Just make the first call and we can get away from all this."
But not everybody at the meeting was buying the message of peace. Keith Peddler, a member of the Piru Nation gang who said he was now "totally into the positive," balked at calls for disarmament.
"I'm tired of black Uncle Toms telling us to lay down our guns when the police are out there killing us," he said, to enthusiastic applause. "I'm not dumb. Check this out: If you are going to go out and fight a war for the white man, you better damn sure stand up and fight for yourself."
And a 29-year-old member of the Grape Street Watts Crips who calls himself Hi-T said in an interview that he doubted the usefulness of public meetings like this one.
"We're not ready for this type of gathering," he said. "What I'm saying is that we need to take a better look at ourselves and decide what we want before we start asking people to do stuff for us or for our community."
With private financing, Hi-T has managed since the riots to open a sporting goods store in the riot-ravaged South-Central neighborhood. The store employs 12 people, and he was cheered as a hero when he took the stage at the ballroom. But he said later that few Los Angeles gang members were prepared to put in the time and work to make a business succeed.
"A lot of guys are still playing the hard-core role, you know, 'I kill you,' " Hi-T said. "We all know we can kill. I can kill, too. We have pumped babies and women. But we don't have to be talking about that any more."
He added: "I feel like this. If I had a million dollars, I'm not going to give it to gang members. You haven't proven to me that you are worth an investment."
But Hi-T joined the virtually unanimous sense both here and at the Kansas City gathering that the time had come for gang members to stop killing one another, if some alternative occupation or means of self-expression could be found.
As more gang members from the violent and heavily armed generations of the Crips and Bloods enter the age of family and fatherhood, the views of these older men have begun to be felt on inner-city streets. The wild and thoughtless killings typified by drive-by shootings have met with a new tinge of revulsion.
"People are just getting older and wiser," said Damon Hall, who at the age of 23 has been a Philadelphia gang member for a decade. "Last year I went to 12 funerals. I'm not going any more. It's time to make a change for the next generation."
 
A Limited Truce
 Truce movements have had some effect in Boston, Chicago, Minneapolis and Philadelphia as well as in Los Angeles.
But the much-publicized truce here that followed the riots seems to have taken hold only in the Watts neighborhood and in the adjacent city of Compton. In addition, there is no truce among the city's prolific and violent Hispanic gangs.
Gang killings in Los Angeles set a record last year, topping 800 for the first time, and they show no signs of abating.
This week's meetings here and in Kansas City were intended to find ways to reduce this violence, but it is generally accepted both among gang members and law-enforcement experts that only deep-running social and economic changes can have a lasting effect.
With inner-city families and school systems breaking down, with public funds for recreational programs all but gone, with entry-level jobs disappearing and with drugs still plaguing the nation, few people hold out immediate hope for the young men of the cities who are are black and poor.
"Selling dope isn't going to take you anywhere," said Gabriel Warren, a 22-year-old gang member in Kansas City.
And he is looking for something else, applying recently for more than 20 jobs, though without success.
"I've got a son to take care of," Mr. Warren said.

HEADLINE: New Balkan Talks Open At a Resort Near Athens

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VOULIAGMENI, Greece, May 1

 BODY:
A new round of peace talks on the Balkans began today at this resort south of Athens amid hopes that the Bosnian Serbs would agree to an international plan to end the yearlong civil war in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Arriving at Athens airport today, Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader, said peace could come "within two weeks" if minor modifications were made to the plan. On Friday, Dr. Karadzic said he hoped to bring back a modified version of the original peace plan put forward by the United Nations and European Community that the Bosnian Serb assembly would accept when it meets in Pale, Bosnia, on Wednesday. Both the Croatian leadership in Bosnia and the Muslim-led Bosnian Government have already accepted the plan. 
 "I don't think the Vance-Owen plan will be signed in Athens but we can make a big advance so that the Serb Parliament can accept it May 5," the Serb leader said, referring to the two authors of the peace plan, Cyrus R. Vance, the United Nations mediator, and Lord Owen, the European Community negotiator.
 
Address by Lord Owen
 In an address to the opening session of the peace conference tonight, Lord Owen said: "The comprehensive peace plan that has eluded us so long is now within our grasp. We hope you all will have the courage to seize it."
After explaining a number of technical amendments to the plan, Lord Owen said he hoped that "with these clarifications it will now be possible for the Bosnian Serb delegation to agree to sign."
Only last week the same Bosnian Serb assembly decisively rejected the Vance-Owen plan, which divides Bosnia and Herzegovina along ethnic lines into 10 largely autonomous provinces with a weak central government in Sarajevo, the republic's capital. The Bosnian Serb council voted against the plan despite the recommendations by both Dr. Karadzic and Slobodan Milosevic, the President of Serbia, that they accept it.
The shift in Bosnian Serb sentiment since that vote is described by diplomats here as a result of continuing pressure from the Serbian leadership in Belgrade together with the realization that President Clinton is now seriously considering force.
Nevertheless there is real concern that Bosnia's Muslims, who agreed to the Vance-Owen plan reluctantly this year, might withdraw their assent if they feel the mediators are offering the Serbs new concessions.
 
Withdrawals Uncertain
 And even if all goes as the mediators hope, with the Bosnian Serbs signing the peace plan next week and a cease-fire coming into effect, it remains unclear whether the Bosnian nationalist forces on the ground will withdraw from large areas they have captured as the plan requires. Under the plan, the Bosnian Serbs, who now hold about 70 percent of the region's territory, would control only about 45 percent.
If the Serbs do finally accept a version of the Vance-Owen plan, the United Nations will ask the Security Council to send a new and more aggressive peacekeeping force to Bosnia numbering 60,000 to 75,000 soldiers and estimated to cost more than $1 billion a year.
The two-day round of peace talks, which is taking place in a luxury hotel at this seaside resort 12 miles south of Athens, has brought together the leaders of all the factions involved in the Balkans crisis.
Among those attending in addition to Dr. Karadzic and the two mediators are Dobrica Cosic, the President of federal Yugoslavia, which consists of Serbia and Montenegro; Momir Bulatovic, the Montenegrin leader; Alija Izetbegovic, the President of the Muslim-led Bosnian Government in Sarajevo; Franjo Tudjman, the Croatian President, and Mr. Milosevic.
 
U.S. Envoy's Instructions
 Thorvald Stoltenberg, the former Norwegian Foreign Minister who is taking over Mr. Vance's mediating role next week, is also here, along with Vitaly I. Churkin, a Deputy Foreign Minister of Russia, and Reginald Bartholomew, President Clinton's special envoy. Mr. Bartholomew's instructions, State Department officials said today, is to "make clear, particularly to the Bosnian Serbs that words alone will not deter the United States and the international community from pursuing further options."
There are signs that the Serbs are losing some advantages. In addition to mounting economic hardships, which include rampant inflation and sharply reduced industrial production, diplomats here say the growing possibility of direct Western military action raises the likelihood that Serbs could also start to lose the advantage they hold over their rivals on the ground.
The outcome of the recent Russian referendum may also have affected Serbian thinking as well as the warning from President Boris N. Yeltsin, who handily won a vote of confidence from Russian voters, that he expects the Serbs to sign the Vance-Owen plan. Many Serbs had expected Mr. Yeltsin to lose and believed a government more sympathetic to the Serbian position would come to power in Moscow.
To obtain the self-styled Serb parliament's backing for their plan, the international mediators are likely to offer Dr. Karadzic additional concessions at this weekend's talks so that he can say that he has won a better deal.
At Athens Airport today, Dr. Karadzic said that 70 to 80 percent of the plan was acceptable to him but added that he still wanted to insure physical links among three Serb-controlled provinces as well as guarantees for Serbs living in areas controlled by Croats or Muslims.

Shelling Kills 5 in Sarajevo

SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, May 1 (AP) -- Mortars slammed into the center of the Bosnian capital today, killing at least 5 people and wounding 20. The Bosnian radio reported Serbian shelling in other Muslim-held towns.
United Nations officials said Canadian peacekeepers in the eastern Bosnian enclave of Srebrenica retreated under fire when they ventured out of town to try to repair the water supply. A United Nations convoy, meanwhile, tried to reach another eastern Bosnian town, Gorazde, where heavy fighting was reported.
Gorazde has held out for months against surrounding Serb forces, but no relief convoys have managed to get through in two months.
Most of the casualties in Sarajevo occurred when a shell exploded in front of the Roman Catholic cathedral. The hospital said many of the wounds were serious. A Canadian commander, Barry Frewer, a spokesman for the United Nations peacekeeping forces, said about 145 shells landed in Sarajevo from mid-afternoon Friday to early today.

HEADLINE: Too Much of a Good Thing on Long Island Sound;
Resurgence of Lobsters Lowers Prices, Brings More Fishers and Spawns Tensions

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HUNTINGTON BAY, L.I., April 29

 BODY:
Running with the morning tide, Arthur Fodera cleared the entrance to Huntington Harbor, powered up the diesel engine in his 35-foot fishing boat and headed across the bay toward Long Island Sound to check the catch in his 700 lobster pots.
With fresh bait fish in buckets at the stern and sea gulls trailing in a cloudless blue sky above his wake, Captain Fodera flipped on his radar, depth finder and the Loran tracking system that helps him find the thousands of dollars worth of lobster fishing gear he leaves on the bottom of the Sound. 
 "There are no pots of gold in this business," said Captain Fodera, the morning sun warming his ruddy face against a chill breeze from the northeast. "It's a lot of work, but it's a good living."
Captain Fodera is one of a growing number of people sharing in a rebirth of the centuries-old lobster business on Long Island Sound. Aided by conservation efforts and a decline in its natural predators, like sand sharks, the lobster has returned to the Sound in great numbers in recent years.
 
Signs of a Turf War
 That, plus the growing demand from seafood markets and restaurants in the New York area, as well as from new markets, including Japan and, most recently, Europe, has brought with it a doubling in the number of licensed commercial lobster fishers over the last several years.
But as a promising new season begins, Captain Fodera and the 20 other lobsterman based in Huntington and neighboring Northport fear success may spoil their business. A large supply is holding prices down, squeezing already narrow profit margins, and the rush to drop more traps has recently led to gunfire at sea and the wounding of one lobsterman.
In the most recent incident, a week ago, a Glen Cove lobsterman was shot and seriously wounded by three masked gunmen as he pulled his traps from the Sound off Lattington Beach. The Nassau County police warned that it could signal the start of a lobster turf war.
"That was a crazy thing to do," Captain Fodera said. "But the Sound isn't getting any bigger and some guys are feeling the pressure. Some days it's like a parking lot out here."
 
A Fourth-Place Catch
 New York State issued 1,171 commercial lobster fishing licenses to state residents last year, up from 371 in 1981. More than 300 lobster fishers worked full time at the job for most of last year, including a stalwart 100 or more, like Mr. Fodera, who fished year round, weather permitting, state fishery officials said.
The latest data show that in 1991, a record 2.9 million pounds of lobster was pulled from the waters around Long Island, most of it from the western half of the Sound, up from 1.8 million pounds in 1989. For statistical reasons, the state divides the waters around the Sound into five areas. The second heaviest yield is from the Sound's eastern zone.
The 1991 catch was less than 10 percent of the national catch, but Long Island moved into fourth place behind Maine, Massachusetts and Rhode Island.
The New York catch produced $8.9 million, making it the state's second most valuable marine product, after hard clams.
Captain Fodera, 32, who takes to sea with his dog, Bo, a sturdy Akita, is an independent man of few words and is somewhat secretive about his business. He shied away from questions about his total catch and yearly income -- both private matters among most lobster fishers.
He said he was now receiving around $4.50 a pound, "maybe a little more" than this time last year, and down from a high of $6.50 a pound this winter. Because the Long Island winters are milder than those of New England, the fishers here can take advantage of the season's higher prices for longer.
In the summer, when the supply increases, not only from the Sound but also from New England and Nova Scotia, the wholesale price drops to around $2.50 a pound. "And things can get tight," he said.
 
Thousands in Equipment
 Since his 700 lobster pots cost him $35 each, he has more than $24,000 invested in his traps alone. His floats, lines and other gear spread around the Sound cost another $10,000, and his boat and its equipment adds another $100,000. Then there's diesel fuel and bait.
Because of the size of his investment, he asked that the colors and design that mark his buoy floats remain known only to himself, his mate, neighboring lobster fishers and state registry officials. Poachers and some competitors have been known to cut or snag lines, and use illegal, unmarked buoys, like floating plastic bottles, to avoid state regulation.
"I don't want to lose any of my gear to poachers," he said, securing a pot line to a hydraulic lift that pulled seven plastic-coated wire traps up from the deep. Some were empty, some had lobsters that were too small to keep, and two had four lobsters whose carapace, which runs from the eyes over the main shell, measured three and a quarter inches, the Federal and state minimum.
After their claws were banded shut, the lobsters were tossed into a "wet well" with fresh pumped sea water, where they were kept until they were unloaded at dockside in Huntington Harbor.
"I started when I was 10 years old, digging clams on the beach with my brother," he said. "He's still a clammer, but five years ago I had a chance to buy this boat and go into lobstering." The boat, "Danny's Song," is named for Captain Fodera's 2-year-old son, Daniel.
 
More FishersLobsterman Than Space
 Captain Fodera credits lobster-fishing rules adopted in 1978, including a requirement that all females bearing eggs be returned to the sea, with helping to replenish the lobster stock in Long Island Sound.
He said he would now welcome a limit on the number of licenses the state grants for lobster fishing, as well as a limit on the catch. Both requirements are under consideration by Federal and state officials. Some lobster fishers now operate three or more boats, placing increased pressure on those with only one boat, leading, they say, to turf disputes.
"These disputes all come down to just one issue, too many people and not enough space," said James F. King, 50, president of the Long Island Sound Lobstermen's Association, who runs his boat out of Mattituck .
He said there had been a number of other ugly incidents in recent months on the Sound, including a shooting off Norwalk, Conn., in early March in which one lobsterman shot at another, also in a quarrel over turf.
"But that was a shot across the bow and no one got hurt, not a blast amid ship like the last one," Mr. King said.
 
'A Unique Animal'
 Mr. King said he had been "chasing lobsters around for 30 years" and that the Sound "is the busiest it's ever been."
As for the lobsters he's been chasing, he said: "I have yet to figure them out. But I've come to respect them as a unique animal."
He said tests had shown that lobster traps themselves attract lobsters to an area. "The young can slip into the pots, steal the bait and slip out escape hatches," he said. "They find it a rich hunting ground. In their own way, they've adapted."
He said the lobster's natural enemies -- sand sharks, dog fish, black fish and other bottom-feeding fish -- have been overfished in recent years and are fewer in number.
Commercial lobster fishers who are New York State residents can buy a state license for $50 a year. Out-of-state commercial fishers -- only 38 in 1991 -- pay $150, said Philip Briggs, a marine biologist and statistician with the State Department of Environmental structure. Connecticut charges the same fees.
Mr. Briggs said the number of lobsters in the Sound began to return to fished-out areas in the early 80's, after conservation efforts and new fishing rules. He said there were no restrictions on setting traps, except they are banned from the narrow shipping lanes where they might be a hazard to navigation.
 
Gunshots on the Waves
 Mr. Briggs said the industry has "a few bad guys, but mostly good guys."
"They have a great respect for one another, and news travels fast when one of them gets hurt," he said.
The victim in the April 24 shooting was Able Miguel, 43, who operates a 47-foot fishing boat out of Glen Cove. He was shot four times in the chest, groin and buttocks with at least one 9- millimeter handgun. Despite his wounds, he managed to use his boat radio to call for help. His attackers were tracked down by police helicopter and marine units and arrested on a beach nearby.
A grand jury heard testimony on Wednesday against the three suspects. Loreto Rufa, 38, unemployed and from the Bronx; Louis Filardi, 29, a potato chip salesman from Yonkers, and John Reina, 41, a carpenter from Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., appeared at separate hearings on Wednesday and were released on $100,000 bail each. None of them are licensed commercial lobstermen; all three were charged with attempted murder.
Mr. Miguel, a native of Portugal and a lobsterman on Long Island Sound for 20 years, was in satisfactory condition today at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset. He told the police he believed the attack was the result of a dispute with another lobsterman who operates three boats out of City Island.
Mr. Miguel told the police that he sold the man a boat about a month ago. Since then, he told the police, the City Island man has accused Mr. Miguel of cutting some of his lobster trap lines and threatened reprisals. Mr. Miguel told the police he believed it was all part of a ruse to bully him off his favorite fishing grounds.
The police said they had questioned the City Island man, whom they declined to identify, and that the investigation was continuing.
