HEADLINE: Nations Join On Economy

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
For the last few years, the economic game plan of the major industrial nations has seemed to be every man for himself, an unhappy formula that helped push the world economy into its stubborn slump. In recent weeks, however, the major countries have sharply changed tack.
Embracing stimulus plans, cutting interest rates and budget deficits, the countries have been taking steps that benefit other nations as well as themselves. Indeed, if there was a theme at this week's meeting of the Group of Seven's finance ministers, it was that economic cooperation has come back from the dead. 
 The meeting, in Washington, seemed to be more of a lovefest than a slugfest, and the ministers came out talking nonstop about synergy: how Germany's interest rate cuts, Japan's stimulus package and Washington's plan to cut its budget deficit would feed upon each other and build the foundation for a long-lasting economy recovery.
It is far from clear how much these steps may help in pulling the world out of its slump, but this meeting -- and the one three weeks ago in Tokyo offering Russia $28 billion in aid -- were the first in years in which the leading industrial nations worked hand in hand.
 
 
Turnabout From '92
 All this is a sea change from last year's Group of Seven meetings, when Germany ignored its neighbors and kept its interest rates high. Japan did not do nearly as much as other countries wanted to stimulate its economy. By all accounts, those meetings sounded like families squabbling over who should do unpleasant chores first. The Germans and Japanese would rebuff American pleas to promote growth until the Americans cut their budget deficit, while the United States insisted that the others needed to do more first.
The way some economists see it, the Group of Seven -- the United States, Germany, Japan, Britain, France, Italy and Canada -- bogged down in recession, saw the folly of their ways and began listening to the pleas of economic partners.
It would be wrong, however, to say all these countries have acted selflessly. Certainly, Germany's independent central bank did not cut interest rates solely because France and the United States pushed it to; the Bundesbank, too, no doubt wants to reverse Germany's deep recession. But, many economists say, the pleas for the Bundesbank to cooperate -- to boost growth in Europe, for instance -- led it to cut rates deeper and sooner.
 
 
Larger Package From Japan
 Entreaties to cooperate were also not needed for Japan to put together this year's stimulus package. Economists and government officials, however, agree that the package would have been considerably smaller than $116 billion if Japan had not yielded to outside pressure to cooperate.
"The stimulus package is bigger as a result of foreign pressure," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics.
Tokyo's stimulus package could turn Japan's economy around by the end of next year, economists say. Germany's rate cuts should eventually give a powerful boost to Europe's economy. As for the efforts by the United States, Britain and France to chop their budget deficits, these should help hold down inflation and interest rates, preventing their recoveries from petering out soon.
 
 
Clinton Plan to Cut Deficit
 Clinton Administration officials suggested that the single move that opened the door to the recent flood of cooperation more than any other was the President's plan to cut the Federal budget deficit. Mr. Clinton's moves gave Washington the credibility to press other industrial nations to cooperate.
"Fortunately, we were able to bring to the table something that the Group of Seven countries had been admonishing us about for some time, and that was getting our own house in order," Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said. "So we have been in a position to help restore some leadership."
The contrast with last spring's Group of Seven meeting is stark: then, American officials suggested that Bonn cut its inflation-causing budget deficit to give Germany's central bank some leeway to cut its interest rates. The Germans reacted with outrage, asking how Washington, with its $300 billion deficit, could ask another country to cut its deficit.
 
 
A New Willingness
 The attitude last year was, after you Alphonse, after you Gaston, with no one wanting to take the first cooperative step. Now many nations seem willing to go the extra mile when other countries press them.
In the view of several Group of Seven officials, Japan might have offered Russia nothing this year -- instead of the $1.8 billion it promised -- if the Group of Seven had not forged a highly visible, everyone-pitch-in effort to help Russia. The pressure to cooperate helped persuade Tokyo to promise aid despite its anger at Moscow for seizing four northern islands at the end of World War II.
Despite the new wave of cooperation, Group of Seven tensions have not suddenly vanished like Cinderella's coach. The biggest remaining source of friction is Japan's trade surplus of more than $100 billion with the rest of the world. If the cooperation breaks down, it could well be over trade imbalances and trade barriers.

HEADLINE: Israeli Concessions Said to Revive Peace Talks

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
A series of Israeli concessions has stirred optimism among Palestinian delegates after the first week of resuscitated Middle East peace talks.
Among the concessions, which the Israelis prefer to call confidence-building measures, were decisions to allow a leading Palestinian from East Jerusalem to join the Palestinian delegation and to let a group of Palestinians banned from the occupied territories come home. 
 Together they cleared the way for the parties to put aside important but somewhat peripheral issues and move on to the crucial question of the status of the occupied West Bank and Gaza.
"I'm not saying we are there yet," said Hanan Ashrawi, the spokeswoman for the Palestinian delegation. "I'm saying, finally the peace process is showing indications that it can move ahead, it can produce, it can be a vehicle for change."
Ms. Ashrawi said she believed the Israeli gestures could move the talks to a "qualitatively different phase. Some doors are being opened and we are doing our best to help and respond positively."
The Israelis are negotiating simultaneously with the Palestinians, Syria, Jordan and Lebanon. In a sense, their concessions this week have allowed the Palestinian talks to catch up with the other three. In the other negotiations, the parties are discussing the primary issues, without the distractions caused by the deportations and other issues that have stalled the Palestinian talks.
But while the Israelis and Palestinians may have cleared away much of the chaff that has prevented progress, they are just now getting to the essence of the most difficult issues. So far in the quid pro quo that is a part of negotiations, the concessions have come from Israel. Next week, Israeli and American officials say, it is time for a significant gesture by the Palestinians.
"We hope next week they will seriously engage on the issue of interim self-government arrangements and how they can plan on structures of self-government," said a senior State Department official who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The quo really is the substantive engagement we hope will happen."
The talks between the Israelis and the Palestinians are aimed at producing an agreement on self-rule for the Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza for a five-year interim period. No later than the third year, the two sides would begin talks on the final status of the occupied territories.
"What we want to do is to send a message things are happening," Israel's chief negotiator, Elyakim Rubinstein, said on Friday, referring to the 1.7 million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza.
On Wednesday, the Israelis agreed to allow the return of 30 Palestinian exiles who were deported from the territories between 1967 and 1987. The first 15, all members of Palestinian factions loyal to Yasir Arafat and the Palestine Liberation Organization, came home to a heroes' welcome in Jericho on Friday.
The Israelis no doubt hope that the Palestinian people will note the contrast between the triumphant homecoming of the 15 deportees and the forlorn impotence of 396 exiled supporters of Hamas, the militant Islamic fundamentalist group, languishing in southern Lebanon.
The Israelis have also offered to allow 5,000 Palestinian expatriates with families in the occupied territories to remain permanently at the end of their traditional summer visits. And Ms. Ashrawi said Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin's Government was considering giving housing permits to Palestinians whose homes were slated for demolition for economic or security reasons.
Driving the Israeli-Palestinian talks is a fear that further delay will strengthen Hamas, which opposes negotiations with Israel. The growing influence of Hamas is causing the Israelis to move to buck up Palestinian leadership in the territories. In a break with the past, the Rabin Government does not care if that leadership is tied to the P.L.O., so long as it is not linked to Hamas. "What we are saying is that we want to speak to whoever lives in the territories, regardless of who he supports or what he's a member of," said a senior Israeli official on Friday.

HEADLINE: As U.N. Prepares for Somalia Command, Rebuilding Is Most Urgent Task

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOGADISHU, Somalia, May 1

 BODY:
Late into the night, the open-air cinema in central Mogadishu blares Bruce Lee movies and American rap and rock tunes, the towering screen dancing shadows off the walls of buildings. During the day, in the overwhelming heat and humidity, the streets drone with the sounds of generators that supply electricity to one-room shops offering T-shirts, imitation Reeboks and even photocopying services.
Commercial ships dock at the port; one last month was laden with a shipment of thousands of plastic toy guns. There are still no telephones, but on certain blocks, standpipes provide running water. There is even a fledgling police force. 
 All this is not to say that petty theft, occasional looting, gunfights and random shootings are not frequent in Mogadishu, the nation's capital, where there is still no government or banking system. Yet five months after American troops landed to insure the delivery of food and medicine to a starving population, life is taking on a semblance of normality.
In a city where thousands of American troops were once based, it has become rare to see a desert camouflage uniform on the streets or the once-ubiquitous military utility vehicles called humvees. In a brief ceremony next week, the United States military command will officially hand over control of the relief operations in Somalia to the United Nations.
Aside from the handshakes and the raising of a new flag over the command headquarters, it will be little more than a symbolic goodbye. Except for about 4,000 troops who will stay behind in Somalia, the Americans have already departed and have been replaced by soldiers from about 20 countries. The overall American presence reached a high of nearly 26,000. The remaining American troops force will include a quick-reaction force of 1,300 and about 2,700 logistical personnel.
 
New Ground for the U.N.
 Yet in other ways it is far from a token handover. As the political and military commands change hands, shifting much more responsibility onto the shoulders of the United Nations, the mission here in Somalia is expected to expand to encompass the entire country and even move beyond relief assistance into reconstruction. Its success will be a test case for future United Nations missions elsewhere.
Among relief workers, Somalis and United Nations officials there is a feeling of uncertainty, and concern that if this operation does not succeed, then Somalia has no other options.
"There is a good basis to start working from," said a Western official in Mogadishu. "But it has got to continue. There can't be a pause or a dip. There is no time to lose. To make that transition, the U.N. has to move forward on a cease-fire and disarmament. They have to get the banking system and the police back together. What worries me is that they don't have a coherent plan."
There is also concern that the Somali factions whose warring pushed the country into anarchy and prompted the American intervention will try to test the resolve of the new United Nations force in the next several weeks. But United Nations military commanders insist the groundwork for a transition has been well established and that any disruption will be dealt with firmly.
"It's a bit like Belfast," said Geoff Loane, relief coordinator for the International Committee of the Red Cross, referring to the capital of Northern Ireland, where British Army troops have confronted the I.R.A. for the past 24 years. "It's almost an antiterrorist presence, a show of force with the ability to pull the trigger if necessary."
 
U.S. Mission Accomplished
 The American mission, narrowly defined as providing a secure environment for the delivery of relief supplies as well as disarming the warring factions, has been accomplished, said Gen. Robert Johnston, the Marine commander in charge of the American-led task force in Somalia.
About 22,000 members of a United Nations force that is expected to reach 28,000 is already on the ground. Two of the major players in the United Nations operation in Somalia are high-ranking American military officers. Adm. Jonathan Howe, retired, is the United Nations special envoy and Maj. Gen. Thomas M. Montgomery of the Army is deputy commander of the military branch of the United Nations force and has tactical control of the quick-reaction force.
Both General Montgomery and the United Nations commanding officer, Lieut. Gen. Cevik Bir of Turkey, say their first priority will be consolidating control over the territory already under United Nations control and that disarmament of the warring factions will be pursued.
Only then, and after the political branch of the United Nations operation has paved the way, will they move into the northern part of Somalia. "Our mission is a unique mission," General Bir said. "It is the first time in the history of the U.N." But although the military side has a blueprint for its operations, the political side is more tentative. One of its biggest handicaps will be money.
While the military side of the United Nations operation will cost about $1.5 billion for one year, donor nations have promised so far only about $150 million for relief aid, of which only an estimated $14 million has been delivered.
 
Warlords' Competing Claims
 Since the reconciliation conference in March, at which the warring Somali factions agreed to form an interim governmental council, little progress has been made toward that end except for some international campaigning by a couple of the Somali warlords. Mohamed Farah Aidid, the warlord who controlled most of Mogadishu, has been traveling in search of international support and recognition, Western officials say. A rival, Mohammed Ali Mahdi, a hotel-owner and self-proclaimed President, is in Italy for health reasons but made a radio broadcast recently reaffirming his claim to be President of Somalia.
Last month, American troops gradually pulled out of three towns they once controlled, handing over Bardera to the Botswanans and Merca and Mogadishu to the Pakistanis, all part of the United Nations force.
The force on the ground is now an international patchwork. The countries with the largest contingents are Pakistan, with about 4,760; the United States, with 4,000; Italy, with 2,558; Morocco, with 1,295, and France, with 1,100. And while the military presence in Mogadishu was once overwhelmingly American, it has become more mixed than ever. The Egyptians guard one end of the airport, the Pakistanis the other. The Turks and Australians share guard duty at the United States Embassy compound. The Nigerians patrol in miniature white armored cars with bold "U.N." letters painted on the sides. The Zimbabweans drive huge boxlike trucks with slits on the sides and no markings, and the Pakistanis have camouflage Ford pickups with "Pakistan" scrawled with chalk on the doors. Communication among the soldiers is limited to pidgin English.
 
Starvation No Longer the Issue
 The Somalia that the United Nations force inherits is no longer a country ravaged by war and famine: food is reaching every town. But there are still isolated pockets of malnutrition, relief officials say, and looting of food on the roads between towns is still common. The relief agencies' convoys still move with military escorts, and there are still firefights and occasional grenade attacks on compounds in places like the southern port city of Kismayu.
But as emergency aid moves into the rehabilitation phase, there is also a change of emphasis in relief work and the feeling that the situation is no longer crucial enough to warrant putting lives at risk.
Care International pulled out of Bardera in March because of threats and demands for pay raises from its Somali truckers. The Red Cross, the relief agency that has been in Somalia the longest, is paring down its branches because it says there is no longer need for extensive emergency intervention. It has closed down operations in Bardera and Baidoa, and by June will have closed down its 1,000 feeding kitchens.
"My own view is that we've changed the goal posts," said Mr. Loane, the Red Cross coordinator. "The levels of danger we were ready to accept in 1992 were much higher. Everyone has modified their expectations of security. And now the risk to expatriates is felt to be higher than in 1992 even though it was much more dangerous then."
 
A Need for Jobs
 Perhaps the biggest challenge will be the rebuilding of the country's infrastructure and the creation of jobs. Unemployment is pervasive. Every day in Mogadishu, hundreds of men stake out relief and U.N. agencies in the often-futile hope of finding work.
The first step has been the creation of a police force of 4,600 men, 3,000 of whom are based in Mogadishu; 20 percent of them are armed. The United Nations has invested $4.8 million in the first six months of this project and hopes to more than double the number, to about 10,000 police, by next year. The goal is to eclipse the power of the warlords.
There are now two magistrates in Mogadishu and three in Baidoa, and a prison in the capital with 43 inmates. The present judiciary system is based on a 1962 law drawn from the Italian penal code. But the structure is still fragile, Somalis and Westerners agree.
Last month, the police became the first civil servants in Somalia to be paid in more than two years. But their salaries bring to the forefront another problem. Their pay, about $90 a month, is many times higher than similar salaries in other developing countries, and United Nations officials worry they may be creating a civil administrative structure that the Somalia Government will not be able to support once the United Nations leaves.
For the moment, justice appears to be swift. The day after being arrested in Baidoa a few weeks ago, a well-known looter and murderer was sentenced to 20 years in prison. But when his lawyer and the prosecutor both appealed the next day -- one for clemency and the other for a tougher sentence -- the magistrate condemned the man to death. He was executed within the hour.

HEADLINE: Political Scandals in Japan Find a Role for Mah-Jongg

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 1

 BODY:
Japan's running political scandals have tainted the governing party and brought down a onetime kingmaker on an array of charges of financial misdeeds. Now the affair has implicated one of the nation's dearest institutions: mah-jongg.
Developed in China, mah-jongg is an ancient, four-handed game played a bit like gin rummy, but using ivory or plastic tiles. Young men generally learn it at school, developing a lifelong passion for the gambling and bonhomie essential to the game. It is a rite of passage not just into adulthood but into the back rooms of the political world. 
 As described by several Government officials, games of mah-jongg can involve little more than an evening of entertainment for a group of men; women rarely play here. But, like poker in the United States, the game can also provide a test of bravado and a forum where important deals are cut.
 
Cheating the Tax Collector
 Mah-jongg is also notorious as a means the powerful employ in a little-seen, yet robust national industry here -- tax evasion. Until he was dethroned by the scandals of last year, Shin Kanemaru was Japan's most powerful politician. He had a personal mah-jongg parlor near his office, and he played high-stakes games there late into the smoke-filled evenings with other top politicians.
Now those games have created a sensation, angering those who would rather keep prying eyes away from the strategically important game.
"This industry has largely been a supporter of the L.D.P., but I have lost any desire to support them any more," said Hiroshi Aoki, head of an association of mah-jongg parlor owners, referring to the governing Liberal Democratic Party's leadership. "This is a total disaster for us, what those Diet members have done. Mr. Kanemaru was not playing mah-jongg, he was just using the game to exchange money."
 
Limits of Civic Virtue
 Odd as this deep concern with mah-jongg may seem, it underscores what many financial experts, businessmen and Government officials admit is a serious and surprisingly common, if rarely acknowledged, problem in Japan. This may be a country where even on the most deserted street pedestrians refuse to cross against a red light, but taxes and financial dealings appear to be another matter.
In the fiscal year that ended last June, the Government caught corporations evading the equivalent of $5.5 billion in taxes and individuals evading $2.5 billion more. Experts concede that that is probably a fraction of the amount actually dodged every year. In addition, corporations are permitted simply to declare some of their expenditures as "unaccounted for." It is widely believed that much of this money finds its way into the hands of politicians. This sum came to more than $500 million in the last fiscal year.
"Tax avoidance practices are rampant here, even with some new rules they imposed," said Yukio Tomioka, a professor at Chuo University and a former Government tax official. "It is highly regrettable, but using mah-jongg as a game to make secret payments is a very old method in Japan. In business and politics this is widely practiced. It is deep in the culture."
 
Money Leaves Few Footprints
 Gaping loopholes in the laws and the fact that this is largely a cash economy make tax evasion, and money laundering, simpler in Japan than nearly any other industrial country. This remains true despite a recent tightening of various rules, experts say.
Mah-jongg has its own special niche in this well-oiled system. Gambling on mah-jongg is frequently used to pass along large illicit payments, with the players skillfully winning or losing large sums as the occasion demands. A senior corporate executive said some hosts would even hire professionals to insure that by the end of the evening the appropriate sums had crossed the table. It is illegal to gamble on mah-jongg, but the law is rarely enforced.
Mr. Kanemaru's reported links to mah-jongg were so explosive that just about every member of the Cabinet has been grilled by reporters on whether they played with him. (Although Mr. Kanemaru is out of jail on bail, he is under indictment on tax evasion charges.) Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa felt compelled to insist that he had not played in 20 years.
 
Living High on Illicit Cash
 Adding to the public's outrage at the idea of politicians trifling away millions of dollars of illicit contributions over a mah-jongg table is the fact that Mr. Kanemaru appears to have diverted huge amounts of political contributions for his personal use.
Mr. Kanemaru was said to have obtained millions of dollars in illicit payments every year from construction companies that he helped by shepherding Government work their way.
Mr. Kanemaru was arrested earlier this year on tax evasion charges after he was found with tens of millions of dollars of special long-term bank debentures, or bonds, secreted in his offices, and more than 220 pounds of gold.
Mr. Kanemaru was the most prolific money-raiser in the governing party, and his immense influence rested in part on his ability to dole out cash to other politicians, Liberal Democrats and opposition members. The cash was a bond that smoothed the way for legislation and patronage.
That is where his personal mah-jongg parlor is said to have come into play. Asked once how this money was transferred, one of Japan's most senior politicians, replied, "Oh, Kanemaru loses to them in mah-jongg or poker or something like that."

High-stakes mah-jongg games have attracted many of the country's top politicians. (Kaku Kurita for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Israel Builds Ties to Ex-Soviet Muslim Lands

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, May 1

 BODY:
While it remains in a technical state of war with most of its Islamic neighbors, Israel has moved resolutely beyond its region to establish diplomatic and trade relations with the largely Muslim republics of the former Soviet Union.
The Jewish state's ties to the Islamic world have always been thin at best, aside from a few conspicuous exceptions like Egypt and Turkey, but it has met little resistance in the Central Asian republics since the breakup of
the Soviet empire two years ago. 
 To the contrary, Israeli diplomats and business executives say they are being avidly courted, in large part because they have the know-how to help those emerging states transform outdated farming techniques and communications systems. Israelis tell of projects that have multiplied tomato yields six-fold in Kazakhstan and increased cotton output by 30 percent in Uzbekistan while reducing water consumption by two-thirds.
Endless Middle East conflicts seem distant to Muslims in those countries, and minor compared with their own troubles, the Israelis say. And although Iran has sought to expand its influence, Israelis report that it has not been aggressively anti-Israel in its approach.
"These countries are aiming to establish relations with the West, and know that economic progress depends on following the secular Turkish model and not that of Iran," a senior official here said. "Israel, too, is a model on which they would like to pattern themselves."
The Israelis recognize that the secularly oriented governments they are embracing could be replaced one day by more assertively Islamic ones. But they call it a risk worth taking, both for the potential trade benefits and the political mileage inherent in dealing on a friendly basis with Muslims.
In the last two years, Israel has established official relations with five of six largely Muslim republics: Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Azerbaijan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan; only Turkmenistan has held back. Leaders of Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan have visited Israel, as have a string of lower-ranking delegations from the other countries, including trade missions and officials looking for training in irrigation techniques and livestock husbandry and food storage.
 
United States Participates
 "They realize that we have a relative advantage in these fields of agriculture and irrigation," said Ehud Gol, director of the Foreign Ministry's Division for International Cooperation. He added that many aid programs were run jointly with the United States, the Americans usually putting up the money and the Israelis the expertise.
Perhaps inevitably, Israeli interest in the Asian republics also has a Jewish dimension.
Officials estimate that 200,000 Jews live in the region, most in deeply rooted communities that have experienced little virulent anti-Semitism. But there is concern here that Jews could get caught up in a backlash of anti-Russian nationalism. As a result, Israeli officials want to keep the exits clear, and they have set up regular flights to and from important regional capitals like Baku, in Azerbaijan, and Tashkent, in Uzbekistan.
But for now, those flights are used mainly by Israeli executives, who have developed a lucrative trade in irrigation piping, plastics, pesticides, telecommunications and some consumer products. Leading the pack are the heads of two large Israeli business groups, Shoul Eisenberg and Yosef Maiman, whose rivalry is particularly intense in Kazakhstan -- a huge, oil-rich trading lodestone, even if now it pays mostly by barter and not cash.
Compared with Western European nations, tiny Israel is in a junior league, Mr. Maiman acknowledged, but he said that it holds its own. "These countries are rather pragmatic," he said. "I think they feel they can get a lot of support from Israel, and they're going after it."
On that score, Mr. Eisenberg agreed. "We very seldom talk politics," he said. "Business is business."

HEADLINE: State Health Bill Interests Clinton

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, May 1

 BODY:
On Wednesday, a few days after this state passed a universal health-care bill similiar to the plan favored by the Clinton Administration, the President called Gov. Mike Lowry of Washington to the White House for advice on how he won approval for the plan.
All the elements that are shaping the President's health-care plan, to be released later this month, were in place here: an army of lobbyists that warned of dire consequences, radio talk-show hosts who orchestrated a flood of negative phone calls and a minority party that refused to budge. 
 Last Friday, after the lobbyists had been locked out of the State Legislature in Olympia, the Clinton model won, carrying a handful of Republican votes in the solidly Democratic Legislature.
When the Governor signs the bill, probably within 10 days, Washington will have one of the most aggressive health-care experiments in the nation, a program that would extend medical benefits to all 5.1 million residents of the state and try to control costs through a cap on insurance premiums.
The plan would require all employers to pay at least half the cost of health insurance premiums for their employees. By promoting a managed competition system, in which people and businesses would buy health care from a network of doctors and hospitals, the bill is closer than the reform efforts of any other state to the plan mentioned most frequently by the Clinton Administration.
 
A Leap Into the Unknown
 "This is monumental, historic legislation that the Clinton Administration can go to school on," Governor Lowry said in an interview. But the state plan would also be a leap into the unknown, a move that many business leaders said could have disastrous economic consequences.
In talks with Governor Lowry, President Clinton and his wife, Hillary, who heads the national task force on health care, were particularly interested in the political strategy used in the state, the Governor said. But some of the lessons learned in this Washington may have already been lost on the other Washington.
While the Clinton task force had antagonized the medical establishment early on, Washington began by enlisting the support of the leading doctor group in the state, which became a crucial ally. In addition, the task force has been criticized for keeping many of its meetings private. In this state, the promoters of health care reform went out of their way to involve the public.
"We tried to avoid the traditional Democratic approach that would have doomed this thing from the start," said State Senator Phil Talmadge, who steered the bill through the Legislature. "We weren't going to create some huge new government bureaucracy, so we took that away from the critics. Also, we had some pretty good data that showed that the state would save a significant amount of money in the long haul by adopting health reform now."
 
A Debate Over Savings
 With the cost of health care rising 15 percent a year in the state, Washington was faced with a situation of endless tax increases to balance its budget. The new plan was sold as a way to prevent future tax hikes. But critics said Washington may have committed itself to a new multibillion-dollar burden.
"It's not going to bring down costs," Dr. Michael Schlitt, a Seattle neurosurgeon, said of managed competition. "By having a centralized entity making your medical decision, it's only going to raise costs."
Washington is one of six states that have passed universal health-care bills. Florida recently signed a similar bill into law, after legislators fought off an intense lobbying effort. In Washington, most of the major lobbies, from business to labor to unions representing state workers, opposed the reform.
"I think the interest groups underestimated the incredibly strong desire for change and reform coming from the people," Mr. Talmage said.
Critics conceded that, because the opponents lacked a clear alternative, they were outmaneuvered. "I don't think anybody likes the status quo," said Rick Rubin, a health policy expert who worked with business groups to oppose the plan. "The business community is very interested in health-care reform that controls costs. But they are suspicious of this approach. You can't name an industry where price controls have been effective."
 
Some Benefits for Business
 While the plan would place most of the burden on the backs of businesses, it does have some benefits: the cap on insurance premiums, financial assistance for struggling companies, and the ability to buy insurance through a purchasing cooperative.
Without an overhaul of the system, the supporters of the bill said, per capita spending on health care would rise to $7,000 by the end of the decade from $2,737 today. The Boeing Company, the biggest employer in the state, would spend nearly $19,000 a year in health costs on each employee if the present trends continued for seven years, according to state projections.
The plan would phase in over six years the rules that would require employers to offer health insurance. Even self-employed people would be required to buy health care.
It also would set up four purchasing cooperatives, which would pool the resources of thousands of people to buy services from certified health plans. By forcing doctors and specialists to join these plans, costs would be held down, the promoters of the bill said.

HEADLINE: 60 Are Chosen for National Academy of Sciences

 BODY:
The National Academy of Sciences, a private organization established by Congress in 1863 to advise the Federal Government, has elected 60 new members. The election brings the number of active members to 1,683.
The academy also named 15 nonvoting foreign associates, bringing their total to 298. 
 Election to the academy is considered one of the highest honors that can be accorded an American scientist or engineer. The academy said election recognized "distinguished and continuing achievements in original research."

HEADLINE: Nannygate for the Poor;
The Underground Economy in Day Care for Children

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
For years, Gladys Cordero was pointed out by strangers as "the lady in the green house." She cared for as many as 16 children at once in her modest home on Staten Island -- illegally. Neighbors knew her. Cabdrivers directed customers to her. Even the public elementary school across the street sent parents her way.
A loyal clientele trailed the 60-year-old woman three years ago, when she moved to a new neighborhood 40 blocks away. Mrs. Cordero charges $20 a day for babies in diapers and $15 for older children. But the real currency is trust, she said, in a widespread commerce that has served struggling, low-income parents for decades in New York City. 
 Officials say there is no way of knowing how many people like Mrs. Cordero provide illegal day care. She cares for three preschoolers and an 11-month-old grandson in her home in South Beach, S.I. But with more women working and more mothers providing the sole support for their family, child-care advocates suggest there could be at least 25,000 day-care providers operating without licenses or official oversight in the city's working poor neighborhoods.
One city official called the largely invisible world of these day care operations the "poor person's nannygate" -- the flip side of the highly publicized troubles of Zoe Baird and Kimba Wood, President Clinton's first two choices for Attorney General. Both were forced to withdraw their names after questions were raised about their hiring of illegal aliens as nannies.
 
Nowhere Else to Turn
 Nationwide, there are from 550,000 to 1.1 million unlicensed family day-care homes, according to a 1991 study commissioned by the Federal Government. The study also showed that households with incomes under $15,000 spend an average of 23 percent on child care, while families with incomes over $40,000 spend an average of 6 percent.
In New York City, day care subsidized by the city serves only 13 percent of the parents who are eligible. A vast majority are left to find day care on their own. Many low-income parents, who typically can afford to pay only $50 to $75 a week, ultimately turn to neighbors or relatives or even strangers whose names are posted on telephone poles or community bulletin boards.
City officials fear that such arrangements might expose children to unnecessary hazards. Providers might be caring for a dangerously high number of children, not meeting fire and safety codes or, in rare cases, might have a history of abuse or neglect.
In February, two children died in a house fire in Queens at an unregistered day-care operation run by an 82-year-old woman. But officials stressed that the Queens fire was unusual, the first such fire since two children entrusted to an illegal day-care provider in Brooklyn died seven years ago.
 
'Not Day-Care Cops'
 For every child under the age of 3 in regulated care in New York City, 15 children of that age are entrusted to illegal providers, estimates Child Care Inc., the largest nonprofit resource and day-care referral agency in the city.
"People are desperate for care, and they want to believe their baby sitters are adequate to the job because it's hard to face the possibility that it might not be true," said Caroline Zinsser, an expert on informal and unregulated day care in New York. "Unlicensed care is not necessarily bad, but when you get into dealing with strangers, a license is a help in assuring quality."
State law requires certification for any person who cares for more than two children not related to the provider. The day-care providers must pass physical exams, be checked for child abuse and neglect and subject their places of business to random inspections. The requirements become more stringent the more children a provider cares for.
The city's Department of Health is reponsible for the inspections and enforcement. But city officials, as well as child-care advocates, concede there is not an aggressive effort to root out illegal operations because of inadequate staffing and recent budget cuts.
"We're in the business of facilitating day care," said Steven Matthews, a spokesman for the city's Department of Health. "We're not day-care cops. If we become aware of a center, we will move to bring it into compliance."
 
'The Best I Could Do'
 Among the reasons that many providers do not comply with regulations are a desire to avoid taxes, a disdain for government intrusion and a fear that they may lose welfare benefits because of the income. Some are intimidated by the red tape, while others, like Mrs. Cordero, simply see no need for it. "I never thought of it," she said. "The time flies."
Yolanda Cutler, a single mother in Jamaica, Queens, saw the merits of having a licensed provider. But when she could not find one for less than $100 a week for her 3-year-old daughter, she took a chance on a stranger whose phone number was tacked to a supermarket bulletin board for $75 a week.
The provider cares for four young children as well as five of her own in a tiny apartment in Queens. In the last six months, Ms. Cutler said she has been unhappy that her daughter, Mischalett, is allowed to watch television all day. She is unnerved by the cats that race about the provider's home, the litter box by the front door and the perilously steep stairway.
But the 21-year-old Ms. Cutler, who studies social work at York College by day and rings a cash register at a Burger King at night, says her options are limited. She earns $6,000 a year and lives with her mother.
"It's not up to my standards, but right now it's the best thing I could do," Ms. Cutler said.
 
On the Waiting List
 Vivian Jones, a single mother, feels the same way. Every day, her two children, still in diapers, are dropped off at the apartment of an illegal day-care provider, known as "Auntie" by neighbors along Amsterdam Avenue in Washington Heights.
Ms. Jones, a secretary who makes less than $20,000 a year, worries about the arrangement. But she said she received little help from the government when she sought day care.
In January, Ms. Jones applied for day care that would have cost her only $35 a week with the Agency for Child Development, the city agency that administers subsidized day care. But the 25-year-old mother said she was told that there was nothing available on the West Side of Manhattan for children the age of hers, 10-month-old Shafonda and 22-month-old Rondell. Ms. Jones's name was added to a waiting list.
Ms. Jones said she could not afford to wait. She recently found an illegal day-care provider through a network of relatives and friends. She pays $100 a week for her children to spend 10 hours a day with the provider.
"She's a known person," Ms. Jones said. "She has raised a lot of children in the neighborhood for over 12 years."
 
'It Doesn't Even Stink'
 The day-care provider, like many others, declined to be interviewed. Ms. Jones said her children's provider, who cares for three babies and two school-age children, chooses not to become regulated because, she says, "It's too much hassle."
On her first visit, she was heartened that the provider was open and friendly. There was a smoke detector. The provider's fifth-floor apartment in a tenement building was spacious, clean and free of graffiti. "It doesn't even stink when you go in," Ms. Jones said.
Ms. Jones, who considered quitting her job to care for her children, would have been given a higher priority for subsidized care if she had been on welfare, an abuse and neglect victim or a teen-age parent, said city officials and child-care advocates. But she describes herself as an independent woman and is loath to join the welfare rolls.
"I'm focusing on working instead of depending on the system," she said in frustration. "It's hard for somebody who's motivated to work to find proper care for their children."
Ms. Jones said she would have preferred to have her children in regulated day care, but she made her decision out of necessity.
"I can't take my kids to work and I don't want to quit my job," she said. "You have to use what you can use and keep going. You are always going to worry because you don't really know what people are going to do behind closed doors. You ask God to bless the children and protect them and watch over them."
 
Licensing Process Changed
 Last year, the state changed its licensing process to encourage illegal day-care providers to comply with regulations. Providers no longer must be inspected by officials before getting a license; they must simply fill out a long application form to become automatically certified.
But advocates say the daunting, English-only form and a fear of an Internal Revenue Service crackdown has only discouraged potential providers and driven even more underground.
City officials concede there have been problems. But Mr. Matthews, of the health department, said the application forms have been shortened. If the process were simplified more, he said, "you would run the risk of 'What value is the regulation?' "
"The whole idea," he said, "is to have certain requirements and standards."
The penalty for operating without registering can run as high as $500 a day and the closing of the illegal sites. Since the February fire in Queens, city officials said they received a flurry of calls from parents inquiring whether their day care was legal. But in the last eight months, no fines have been levied for operating without proper registration, said James McCormack, a deputy director at the city's Department of Health.
Patricia Lee, who provides day care for three children on Coney Island, said the fire in the home in Queens had only a fleeting impact on the parents who live in the high-rise projects in her neighborhood.
"That was something tragic," she said. "But when people are looking for a baby sitter, they don't mention the Queens apartment. They're not that meticulous about apartments or smoke alarms. They want to know if they feel comfortable knowing you won't hurt their children. We don't have too much choice out here."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vivian Jones and Oscar McDonald use an unlicensed day-care provider, known along Amsterdam Avenue in Washington Heights as "Auntie," to take care of their children, Rondell, left, and Shafonda. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Where's Judge Landis When You Need Him?

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
Because the baseball owners are dragging their spikes, I've decided to begin my own search for a new commissioner. Not that a new commissioner will necessarily solve all of the national pastime's problems, but the grass roots do need hope. Who really believes that baseball is in economic pain and that either the owners or the players are potential victims? Isn't the crisis about the public's attitude? Will baseball survive as a "national pastime," a game that reveals the soul of a country, or as just another circus?
I began my search with Richard Ravitch, real estate developer, former New York mayoral candidate and currently major league baseball's chief labor executive, and Jim Bouton, the former Yankee 20-game winner, sports newscaster and author of the best book on baseball ever, "Ball Four". 
 Ravitch and I met for lunch at Il Menestrello, a pricey Italian restaurant in midtown Manhattan where he is apparently well known. I asked him whether he was prepared to take the commissioner's job if offered. He said he was not a candidate. We got down to business.
Ravitch is proposing a two-step program to bring the game into the 21st century as a rival to basketball, football and Japan. Step one would be an owners' common market in which revenue would be shared. Step two would be a limit on players' salaries, a cap for each club. The effect, he says, would be a settling of the current disorder in baseball with owners threatening to move or go under and players hopping from team to team, further cranking the national insecurity. There would be an equality of talent, which would lead to more exciting games and pennant races, he maintained, and an end to the hostility between player and owner.
Ravitch favors expansion to more American cities as well as exporting the game overseas, and an industry-wide effort to promote individual players on a national basis. He would explore earlier starting times to engage kids, and more rather than fewer games. He would like to know why there are not more black and Hispanic fans.
Ravitch has a bemused and superior attitude; as a longtime fan (he said he saw Jackie Robinson's first game at Ebbets Field) and a liberal public policy activist, he has the background to charm or alienate players, owners and journalists equally, which is a plus. He smokes and was chairman of the Bowery Savings Bank when Joe DiMaggio was its pitchman, which could be used against him.
Jim Bouton and I met for lunch at Bogota, an inexpensive Italian restaurant in downtown Teaneck, N.J., where he is apparently well known. He said he was prepared to take the commissioner's job if it is offered. "It would be fun," he said, "and would give baseball some credibility." We got down to business.
Bouton's three-point plan involves radical changes by ownership. He said: "First of all, owners would have to stop trashing the players. In what other business does management tell customers that the product is not worth the money it costs? And secondly, all owners would have to agree to stay put, there could be no movement of clubs, no threatening to leave."
His third point mandates long-term contracts to create player and fan loyalty. He suggests that with intelligent scouting, an owner could offer several youngsters a season a guaranteed million dollars over 10 years. There would be bonuses, some of them multimillion dollar bonuses, for making the major league roster, for winning a batting title, for a certain earned-run average, etc. Even if only a few kids pan out, the team would be better off than under the present system of club-hopping free agents.
"Most important," said Bouton, "the owners have to start selling the game as an exciting entertainment filled with interesting personalities. Right now, they're selling the game as if it's about winning, which it can't be. If every team won its fair share of World Series championships, that would only be about four per century. Fans have been falsely led to believe that they deserve more victories than that.
"Baseball should be about the pleasure of the process, not just the end result."
As commissioner, Bouton would try to defuse the various hostilities in the game, particularly owners versus players and players versus sportswriters.
"I'd hold an orientation for new players on how to deal with the press," said Bouton. "I'd say, 'This is the only business where you get free advertising every single day. So be nice to the free advertising guys. Talk to them, it doesn't even have to make sense what you say. Just never spit on them. And once in a while, give one an old glove. You'll own the writer for life.' "
Bouton, who at 54 can stand on his head, is an inspiring motivational speaker, and is married to a psychologist, which is a plus. He still pitches, mostly knuckleballs, in a competitive hardball league and is writing, with Eliot Asinof, what looks so far to be a smart and funny inside baseball novel, which could be used against him.
The search has only just begun. I am taking all suggestions seriously.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard Ravitch, currently major league baseball's chief labor executive, proposed baseball enter a two-step program to save itself. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mr. McCall for State Comptroller

 BODY:
The New York Legislature elects a new State Comptroller this week to succeed the Republican, Edward Regan, who has resigned after 13 years. A Democrat will win because a majority of the legislators are Democrats, and the outcome will almost certainly hang on the endorsement of the Assembly's powerful Speaker, Saul Weprin.
On the merits, the vote should go to Carl McCall, president of New York City's Board of Education. He has performed sensibly and responsibly in that difficult role, and that performance argues for the challenge of higher office.
Gov. Mario Cuomo's backing for Mr. McCall raises the issue of independence. A Democratic comptroller must be just as independent from Democratic governors and legislators as Mr. Regan was in auditing state accounts and investing pension funds. Again, Mr. McCall's experience as a banker and elected official recommends him as someone who can watch the money while avoiding needless political bickering and personal conflicts. 
 Both Mr. McCall and his chief opponent, Carol Bellamy, wisely advocate an investment committee to share in decisions. Both also agree that there is room to invest in ways that aid economic development or support worthy social objectives.
It can be argued that Ms. Bellamy's career has given her strong credentials for Comptroller. She has been an investment banker since leaving office as president of New York's City Council in 1985, and we trust she would perform ably as Comptroller.
But Ms. Bellamy cast a shadow over her candidacy for the same office in 1990 by accepting $38,000 from Carl Icahn, the aggressive investor who had locked horns with Mr. Regan. She concedes it was a mistake because it created the impression of dependence on a rich contributor. It still remains a troubling blemish on her record.
The new Comptroller's term will expire next year. If Mr. McCall were to win re-election then, he would be the first black candidate elected statewide. The prospect of a more diverse Democratic ticket is another reason to choose him now.
On balance, the nod goes to Mr. McCall as an interim choice in a job that voters will need to give close attention in 1994.

HEADLINE: 'This Incredible Gift You Give'

 BODY:
"I remember the first time I stuck my toes in the bottom of a pond. I said, 'What is under there?' I was used to concrete pools. I heard little country bugs instead of being rocked to sleep by city noises. Most of all, I experienced another side of life. This is an incredible gift you give."
That's how John Wright, a native New Yorker who now works with homeless youths in the Times Square area, recalls his two weeks as a Fresh Air Fund child years ago. Mr. Wright is not alone in his memories. Since 1877, more than 1.6 million inner-city youngsters have enjoyed summer vacations in the country provided by the Fresh Air Fund. 
 The program opens its annual fund drive today. This year, the fund hopes to provide vacations for more than 10,000 children. About 7,200 will stay with volunteer host families from Virginia to Maine. Another 2,500 will hike and fish and learn to swim in Fresh Air Fund camps in Fishkill, N.Y.
Some youngsters will see for the first time that milk comes from cows, not cartons, that there are green stretches where the air is clean and the nights calm. Yet this "incredible gift" is not cost-free. The recession has taken a toll among other summer camps; the fund survives thanks to the energy of its volunteers and the willingness of donors to help kids break free of the city in summer.
A child's two-week vacation with a family costs $297, which covers transportation, insurance and administrative costs. Sending a needy child to camp costs $816. Last year the fund received 48,576 gifts totaling $3,632,324. The goal this year is to raise $3,698,000 by September.
"My mother wanted me to see the world," said Vanessa, 7, after her Fresh Air experience last year. Those who wish to open the world for other inner-city kids may address tax-deductible contributions -- as well as inquiries about becoming a host family -- to: The Fresh Air Fund, 1040 Avenue of the Americas, New York, N.Y. 10018.

HEADLINE: Free Trade's Huge Costs

BYLINE: By Edmund G. Brown Jr.; Edmund G. Brown Jr., Governor of California from 1975 to 1983, was a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination last year.

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Unfortunately, White House budget director Leon Panetta's pronouncement that the North American Free Trade Agreement is dead is untrue. The powerful free-trade ideologues and business interests which helped President Bush design and draft the agreement in virtual secrecy are very much in the driver's seat.
Washington insiders, including President Clinton, talk as if free trade is a magic bullet that automatically raises wages and generates jobs. Yet, since 1973, American trade with other countries has doubled while the average weekly paycheck has fallen by 18 percent, adjusted for inflation. The economy got bigger -- our national income per capita grew 28 percent -- but the benefits were channeled to those with the highest incomes. 
 Under the banner of free trade, American employers continue the hemorrhaging of U.S. jobs to (supposedly) efficient foreign production sites. For example, Smith Corona, the last American typewriter company, is discharging 875 of 1,300 employees and moving production to Mexico. The reason given is typical: equally skilled Mexican workers will do the same work for a lot less pay.
This shows the painful reality behind President Clinton's boast that the pact will create high paying jobs. The truth is, it will only create a race to the bottom in wage levels and environmental standards. This is inevitable if we rashly link ourselves to Mexico, where wages are one-tenth our own, environmental laws are unenforced, unions are captive to the state and the political system is rife with corruption and electoral fraud.
One would think that such a radical trade alliance with Mexico would inspire foreboding and widespread debate. Instead, Congress allowed the pact to be negotiated in secret and written in language so abstruse that debate about its provisions falls prey to arcane economic assumptions. Non-economists who refuse to think in terms of the econometric models marshaled in the pact's defense are chastised as neanderthals and narrow special-interests out to protect obsolete jobs at the expense of progress.
Compounding all this is the grossly undemocratic fast-track process for Congressional consideration of the pact. It perverts constitutional procedure by abrogating Congress's power to amend -- only a yes or no vote is allowed -- and it also imposes strict time limits on debate. As a consequence, the active participation of those who represent labor, environmental, consumer and human rights concerns is drastically limited.
Politically connected industries, however, are spared the rigors of unconstrained free trade: they are given special treatment. The trade agreement includes a "yarn forward clause" that protects American textile manufacturers by favoring yarn spun in North America, where U.S. companies are the low-cost producer. This exception to free-trade doctrine, one of several dozen in the pact, shows that trade restrictions are widely used, with the only question being: Whose financial interests are to be protected and for what reason?
The short answer is that global companies and their shareholders are protected because of their enormous political power. Those on both sides of the border without powerful lobbyists or financial clout are left to fend for themselves. The pact lifts protection on Mexican corn and other foods. As a result, economists at the University of California at Los Angeles estimate that 800,000 Mexican farming families will be driven off their communal lands because of low-cost U.S. competition. Approximately 700,000 additional illegal immigrants will then cross into the U.S. in search of work. The outcome will be suffering and depressed wages on both sides of the border as the number of desperate workers rapidly increases.
Another danger of the pact was exposed in legal challenges brought under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, on which the pact is based. Both trade agreements allow unelected officials to resolve conflicts by declaring national and local environmental and safety standards to be "non-tariff barriers" to trade and thus subject to financial penalties.
In August 1991, a three-person secret GATT dispute panel in Geneva ruled that the U.S. Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 was an illegal trade barrier because it restricts the importing of tuna caught with nets that kill dolphins. The case was brought by Mexico. And in March 1992, a GATT panel ruled, after a complaint by Canada, that tax breaks in many U.S. states for small breweries were inconsistent with the global agreement and are subject to international sanctions.
In these decisions, the panel was saying that GATT overrode our Federal and state laws. Under this kind of reasoning, neither Congress nor our states could put in place environmental regulations like mandatory refillable bottles or restrictions on the export of raw logs.
Instead of democratic decisions made at the state and local level, under GATT and the North American trade pact we would all be subjected to a supergovernment of unelected trade bureaucrats.
These experts would bring to their jobs the narrow frame of reference of economic utility and not the dynamics and diversity of democratic participation. The side agreements that President Clinton is negotiating on labor and the environment change nothing: they are mere fig leaves to mollify critics.
Instead of going along on the fast track, Congress should reject Nafta as undemocratic and inconsistent with our growing understanding that political and economic power has become too centralized. What is needed instead is a trading relationship among Canada, Mexico and the U.S. that emphasizes social justice, enriching local communities and respect for the environment. This will only be possible only after the reigning fallacies behind free trade are thoroughly debated and refuted.

HEADLINE: Republicans Too Have Campaign Reform Plan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A more apt title for your April 25 editorial "Bob Dole Versus Political Reform" would have been "The New York Times Versus the Truth."
Nowhere in the editorial do you mention that Senate Republicans have introduced their own comprehensive campaign finance reform proposal -- one that bans political action committees, restricts both party and nonparty "soft money," prohibits the practice of bundling campaign contributions and improves political competition by allowing the political parties to give early "seed money" to viable challengers. Our proposal accomplishes all of these reform goals without asking the taxpayers to contribute a single dime. 
 You are dead wrong when you suggest that Americans are willing to support public financing of Congressional campaigns. Just look at the Presidential tax check-off system, where the participation rate has fallen to an all-time low of 17.7 percent. Quite simply, the American people want to cut Federal spending, not increase spending with an entitlement program for politicians.
Will President Clinton be making a big mistake if he insists on public financing? You bet. Unfortunately, the President has chosen not to consult with Congressional Republicans as the Administration puts the finishing touches on its own campaign finance proposal, a legislative strategy of exclusion that no doubt helped sink the so-called stimulus package.
Republicans have always been willing to sit down and negotiate a package of reform proposals on which there is broad agreement. Recognizing the need for bipartisanship, I recently told the Senate Rules Committee: "If Congress is to restore its credibility with the American people, then passing comprehensive campaign finance reform must be a top priority this year. And to ensure that the credibility of reform is in no way diminished, its crafting must be done on a bipartisan basis. The American people don't want a political document. They want a document they can trust -- one that enjoys broad bipartisan, and nonpartisan, support."
Perhaps you were referring to this statement when you denounced my "rhetoric" as amounting to "shilling for a corrupt status quo."
I would have welcomed the opportunity to clarify my position if you had bothered to contact my office before printing the editorial, which regrettably resorted to personal attacks among its barrage of falsehoods and guesswork. Apparently, when there is an honest disagreement, you would prefer name-calling to civility.
Finally, it appears The Times does not always practice what it preaches. A young aide in my office recently ran for Congress from New York's Seventh Congressional District, covering portions of both Queens and the Bronx. Although the race occurred right in your own backyard, you did not give his candidacy a single word of coverage, nor did you allow him to come before the editorial board for a candidate interview. The editorial board gave him the stiff-arm treatment, claiming that his candidacy was "not viable," even though he received 44 percent of the vote on Election Day, a higher percentage than Bill Clinton received nationwide.
You know as well as anyone that free press coverage is the lifeblood of underfinanced challengers and invaluable to leveling the political playing field. Now, when I read your editorials pontificating about the need to make politics more competitive, one word immediately comes to mind: hypocrisy. Thank you for giving me this opportunity to set the record straight.
 
BOB DOLE
Republican Leader, U.S. Senate
Washington, April 26, 1993

HEADLINE: On Sunday For Giuliani, A Liberal Use Of Party Label

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

 BODY:
CANDIDATES for mayor of New York City met yesterday with state Liberal Party leaders at the Hotel Inter-Continental in mid-Manhattan, vying for the party endorsement in the fall election. Though results will not be known for a few weeks, the favorite appears to be a Republican, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former Federal prosecutor who was endorsed by the Liberals in the 1989 race and is the least liberal of the major candidates.
 Awarding him the Liberal endorsement would invite ridicule if it happened anywhere else. But New Yorkers are quite sophisticated and do not expect politics to make sense. 
Pity the poor out-of-town liberals. They get confused. In the early 1980's, as the Associate Attorney General in the Reagan Justice Department, Mr. Giuliani fought fiercely to keep Haitians locked in immigration camps, while people from other countries were released into the community. Ira Kurzban, a Miami liberal who is counsel for the Haitian Refugee Center, battled Mr. Giuliani, eventually winning the Haitians' freedom. "Rudolph Giuliani liberal?" says Mr. Kurzban. "About as liberal as Pat Buchanan."
 Richard D. Emery, a former New York Civil Liberties Union lawyer, fought Mr. Giuliani over defendants' rights in criminal cases. During the Reagan years, Mr. Giuliani spearheaded a national shift toward expanded prosecutorial powers. "I'm not an enemy of Rudy's anymore," says Mr. Emery, who now admires some of his policies. "But liberal? I wouldn't call him liberal. He sort of believes in the very opposite."
 Indeed, Mr. Giuliani is working to win the Conservative Party endorsement, too. "I don't understand how one person can be both," says Mike Long, Conservative Party leader.
 As United States Attorney, when Mr. Giuliani was criticized as being a publicity seeker -- having Wall Street executives arrested and handcuffed in their offices -- he often responded by bashing liberals. "If I don't tip in favor of law enforcement, who will?" he once said. "The civil libertarians won't. The defense lawyers won't. The liberal editorial writers won't."
 "I don't think even Rudy would say he's liberal," Mr. Emery says.
 Asked whether Mr. Giuliani considers himself liberal, Richard Bryers, his spokesman, says: "I don't think he'd pin himself down that way. He talks about no party having a franchise on good ideas."
 It's easy to understand why Mr. Giuliani wants the Liberals. In liberal New York City it can only help a Republican on the ballot.
 But why would Liberals want a conservative? Cynics suggest that the party that once supported John V. Lindsay and Mario M. Cuomo for mayor is now most interested in backing a winner who can deliver jobs and political influence beyond its size (26,500 city voters). During Mr. Giuliani's 1989 race, the Liberal Party leader, Raymond B. Harding, was a prominent though unpaid Giuliani adviser; Mr. Harding's son was on the Giuliani campaign payroll. Says Mr. Emery, "The Liberal Party doesn't stand for liberalism, it stands for opportunism."
 The Liberal Party leader isn't bothered by Mr. Giuliani's views. Mr. Giuliani supports the death penalty; the party is against it. ("Tell me what that has to do with being mayor," says Mr. Harding.) Mr. Giuliani opposed an all-civilian police review board. ("That issue's all over with," said Mr. Harding.) Mr. Giuliani endorsed Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Conservative Party candidate, for Senate over Robert Abrams, whom the Liberal Party endorsed. ("Understandable," said Mr. Harding. "They're both Republicans.") The Liberals supported President Clinton's jobs bill; Mr. Giuliani opposed it.
 Mr. Harding says the Liberals will endorse whoever can best provide clean government and stimulate the economy. Ideology doesn't matter for a mayor, he says: "People don't care if their garbage is picked up liberally or conservatively."
 "Put aside ideological differences," Mr. Giuliani's spokesman says. He wants be a fusion candidate, reaching out to all. On the one hand Mr. Guiliani pledges to cut city taxes; on the other he wants city teachers paid as much as suburban teachers and drug treatment on demand. Where will the money come from? By cutting administrative waste and salaries, Mr. Giuliani says, he can pay for teacher raises.
 United Federation of Teachers leaders support many of Mr. Giuliani's ideas, but say cutting administration won't make up the 23 percent difference between city and suburban salaries. "If you don't raise taxes," says a union spokeswoman, Susan Amlung, "you'd have to shift spending priorities." If the teachers get more pie, someone goes home with a sliver, and that is when ideology matters.
 So it is worth keeping in mind this new fact of life of city politics: A Republican-Liberal is not always a liberal Republican.

HEADLINE: Trouble Is Her Middle Name

BYLINE: By Peter S. Prescott; Peter S. Prescott, a 1993 fellow of the National Endowment for the Humanities, is writing a biography of Alfred A. Knopf.

 BODY:

SWIMMING IN THE VOLCANO
By Bob Shacochis.
519 pp. New York:
Charles Scribner's Sons.
$22. 
 WHAT'S a short-story writer like Bob Shacochis ("Easy in the Islands," "The Next New World") to do when he attempts his first novel? Should he write from his strength -- his ability to tell a story deftly, using no more words than necessary? Or should he flex his biceps, snap off all restraints and write long? The temptation for the expert in brevity must be strong: if you're going to write a novel, why not try for the big view, take time, as Mr. Shacochis suggests, to smell "the thick cloying stink of jasmine and gardenias" and build an entire world while you're at it?
In "Swimming in the Volcano," his wall-size portrait of a Caribbean island something like Grenada, Mr. Shacochis tries both approaches. He begins with a fine symbolical short story, pauses, resumes with a funny short story, then about a third of the way along stops completely to write a dour novella involving entirely new characters. Meanwhile, scores of island people, from conspiring politicians to barbers on the beach, sprawl across the pages like oleander and hibiscus. Lacking a compelling narrative, or even compelling characters, the novel shouldn't work at all, but to a large degree it does -- at least for a reader blessed with time and tolerance. I'll explain why in a moment, but first a word about the plot.
The island is St. Catherine, newly independent from Britain; the year, 1977. The Prime Minister, a saintly man, is besieged by rebellious elements within his Government who think him morally naive. There have been disturbances in the north; here and there, soldiers stop cars. These tremors have little effect on the American expatriates who might have continued securely on the island had not an American woman, whose true moral naivete is equivalent to a detonator's blast, arrived to visit her former lover and set all at risk.
Mitchell Wilson, the ex-lover, is a young economist who came to St. Catherine to work for its Minister of Agriculture. He had an idea that he might discover "the secret to accomplishing something good and just on this earth, like rescuing a child-nation that had fallen, and was floundering, in a pigpen of greed." He never will; his Minister leads the conspiracy and, besides, in tumultuous times Americans look like C.I.A. provocateurs and are treated accordingly. Mitchell doesn't want to see Johnnie, as the young woman from his past is called. She's been away five years, been married to a drug dealer who's been indicted for murder. Now Johnnie squeezes past Customs with a stash of cocaine in her diaphragm case. She wants Mitchell and, as Mitchell dithers over what to do about her, the police pick up her trail.
In the novella that Mr. Shacochis has laid into his narrative, we learn the life history of the damaged young man who will become the sociopathic police officer assigned to Johnnie's case. For more than 60 pages the main story is suspended as this subplot develops -- a digression like those in Hugo's novel "Les Miserables." An impatient reader may scratch and curse, but in fact Mr. Shacochis is pursuing his real design. Neither the plot nor the characters are his principal concern; what he's interested in is the life of the island itself.
The author has lived in the Caribbean and has written about it in his short stories. He knows everything there is to know about islands like St. Catherine, and in the way of an encyclopedist he means to tell us everything. Quite literally, he takes us from the depths of the waters by its coral reefs to the clouds squatting at the top of its volcano. In a prefatory note reminiscent of Mark Twain's in "Huckleberry Finn," Mr. Shacochis claims to have invented a "trilevel" West Indian dialect. When he gives us an afternoon rain squall and tells us how the air feels just afterward, even a tourist will recognize that he's got that rain, that air, just right. An English interloper -- Graham Greene, say, or Somerset Maugham -- would have left the local politics offstage, but Mr. Shacochis convinces us, seemingly without effort, that the fears and ambitions of his Government men are specific to this place and to this time.
One of the characters in the novel, a hotelkeeper, appeared earlier as the protagonist in the author's wry short story "Easy in the Islands." But the way the man is played in that story is markedly different from the way he's played here -- and the difference suggests the development in Mr. Shacochis's perspective. In the story, the hotelkeeper is part of an Evelyn Waugh comedy, a sympathetic outsider baffled by an incompetent and laughable island bureaucracy. In the novel, the ho-ho element has vanished. Early on, the Prime Minister sets the tone for the book: "We are not clowns, our country is not a comedy."
Nor is this impressive and overlong novel a comedy, a novel in which the writer of short stories never quite lets go. Each of its many scenes is expertly wrought, and the sum of the parts is greater than the whole.
