HEADLINE: Is It 60's Politics Or Gang Warfare?

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
A YEAR ago last month, 50 Latin Kings armed with guns, bats and knives stormed a housing project in Meriden intent on bringing a renegade faction into line. Three defiant members of the organization were injured in the attack, which sent bystanders fleeing. The incident drew more attention to the Latin Kings, an organization of Hispanic and Italian men and women founded four years ago within the state's prison system. Over the last two years authorities have linked the band to scores of assaults and at least six homicides. As reports of the group's activities surfaced in the news media, Beatrice Codianni of New Haven, a longtime supporter of grass roots politics, took note. What she read and heard, she said, mirrored the days when she worked with the Black Panthers in the late 1960's and witnessed the Federal Bureau of Investigation discredit the organization by circulating distorted information to the public.
The same pattern was occurring with the Latin Kings, which was a relatively young organization in Connecticut having what Ms. Codianni called positive goals. Though she recognized that the group had a violent element, she said she had also seen how it had changed the lives of people like her 21-year-old son Andrew, by steering him away from drugs and giving him a strict moral code to live by. In May of last year Ms. Codianni began corresponding with Pedro Millan, one of the founders of the Latin Kings who is currently awaiting trial in a state prison on conspiracy charges stemming from the Meriden shootout. She suggested to him that the Latin Kings begin a public campaign to change their image, and that they begin by offering AIDS education along with literacy and high school classes to its members. Ms. Codianni soon after joined the organization and now serves on the board of directors, making her one of the Latin Kings highest ranking members. 
 Since then she has organized high school classes leading to a General Equivalency Diploma in New Haven and workshops to teach members how to settle disputes nonviolently. She plans to expand those efforts throughout the state. Late in March a state task force made up of Federal, state and local law enforcement officials raided Ms. Codianni's apartment in New Haven. Apart from membership lists and letters that she had received from Latin Kings' members serving prison terms, Ms. Codianni said law enforcers had confiscated her 15-year-old son's baseball card collection, smashed her videotape recorder and broke small ceramic figures. Ms. Codianni has not been charged with violating any laws.
"This is like being part of the witch hunt," she said the night of the police raid. "I know that there's been violence in this organization but we're trying to move away from that."
But law enforcement officials around the state tell a different story. They said that recent crimes linked to the group indicated that its tactics were just as brutal as ever. Authorities suspect that the shooting deaths of three young men in East Rock Park in New Haven last October were ordered by Latin Kings. And evidence shows that members have traveled to different cities in Connecticut and Springfield, Mass., to take part in "beat downs," shootings or stabbings. The organization continues to be fueled primarily through drug trafficking, the authorities said.
 
State Monitoring Gangs
 Lieut. Dan Stebbins, who directs a state office in charge of monitoring gang activities, said that in the past couple of months Latin Kings have sought to harm at least four police officers assigned to curtail gang activity. He added that recent seizures of weapons from the homes of Latin Kings in New Haven and Bridgeport have included Uzis and AK-47's.
"These are not the tools to promote a good image," he said, adding that the organization "is growing at a faster rate than we can respond to it."
The Latin Kings began as a fraternal organization in Chicago in the 1940's. It surfaced in Connecticut in 1989 after two inmates at the Somers Correctional Institution, Nelson Millet and Mr. Millan, started a state chapter. Authorities estimate that membership may be anywhere from 2,000 to 8,000.
 
Philosopher Among Officers
 At least six chapters of the Latin Kings have surfaced in the state's larger cities. Each holds regular meetings and elects officers including a president, vice president, philosopher and regional commander.
To join the organization people must be of Hispanic or Italian descent. Bylaws and philosophy are contained in a thick charter written by Mr. Millet and Mr. Millan. Members are prohibited from using drugs, committing thefts, assaulting other members and discussing the organization with nonmembers.
Ms. Codianni, who refers to the organization as "the family," said that its purpose, to advance the struggle of Latin people, had been shrouded in myth largely perpetrated by the news media and the police. Although members include lawyers, accountants and other professionals, most Latin Kings and Queens, she said, come from bleak backgrounds and are struggling to overcome economic and educational disadvantages.
Whenever a drug-related shooting occurs in Connecticut, she said, the Latin Kings are often the first suspects, though there may be no evidence to make such claims. Contrary to police reports, which say that members are beaten if they try to leave the organization, she said, "We've had several brothers turn in their colors with no harm done."
The group's image has also been mired by people with violent intentions who falsely claim to be Latin Kings or Queens, she said. But when she has called reporters to dispel the myths and to tell them how the organization has changed direction, she said, they have ignored her.
"The media doesn't want to hear about anything positive," she said. "They just want me to tell them where all the dead bodies are."
Ms. Codianni, who is 45 years old, grew up in East Haven. Throughout most of her life she has participated in politics. During the 1960's and early 1970's she worked in a health clinic run by the Black Panther Party and participated in the draft resistance movement and the women's movement. Ms. Codianni, who received three years' probation for a drug conviction in 1986, said she had no other police record. Those who have known Ms. Codianni for several years and are not affiliated with the Latin Kings described her as a nonviolent person with strong political convictions, who does not smoke, drink alcohol or use drugs.
Ms. Codianni said she was supported by welfare and did not receive a salary from the organization. For the last five years she has worked as a volunteer for AIDS Project New Haven and for Free Forever Prison, an advocacy group for Connecticut inmates.
As a feminist, she said, the Latin Kings and Queens appealed to her. "I like the idea that there were a lot of strong independent women in the organization," she said. "There are women chapter presidents and regional commanders. You're appointed for your qualities."
 
Political Awakenings in Prison
 She described Nelson Millet, the president who is serving a 45-year Federal prison term in California for robbery, as "thoughtful and articulate and concerned about moving forward." She said Mr. Millet and Mr. Millan had both undergone a political awakening in prison similar to that of Malcolm X. She said she communicated with Mr. Millet by phone several times a week. Mr. Millet declined to be interviewed for this article.
In response to the organization's involvement in drug trafficking, Ms. Codianni said she could not comment, adding, "I know that the only thing drugs will bring us is jail or death."
Members of the Latin Kings in other cities around the state often seek her advice and counsel. Heriberto Cruz, the treasurer of the Hartford chapter of the Latin Kings, said that they were following Ms. Codianni's lead by trying to encourage younger members to stay in school and off the streets.
On April 24, the state's gang task force raided an apartment where Mr. Cruz was staying and seized a loaded 9-millimeter semiautomatic handgun, five bags of marijuana and documents. At the time of the siege, Sgt. Christopher Lyons, a member of the task force, said that the documents were evidence that the Latin Kings were a dangerous criminal organization and that some of the records described the band's war with Los Solidos, a prominent gang in Hartford.
 
Cleaning a Street Together
 Mr. Cruz said in a recent telephone interview that he bought the gun on the street for protection. He added that the misunderstanding between his organization on Los Solidos had been resolved. Last Sunday, the day following the police raid, Ms. Codianni and Mr. Cruz and other Latin Kings said they met members from Los Solidos on Park Street in Hartford, where both groups spent the day together cleaning the street.
"The media and the police are always saying we're into buying and selling weapons, which is a bunch of crock," Mr. Cruz said. "If we're such a big criminal organization, how come no one has a car or any money?"
At Junta for Progressive Action, a social service agency for Hispanic people in New Haven, about 20 Latin Kings and Queens from the Fair Haven area recently attended a G.E.D. class on the parts of speech. The participants ranged in age from 16 to 35, and many wore black and yellow beads and greeted one another with a special gesture and the phrase "amor de rey," love from the king.
 
Opening Doors
 The director of the agency, Frank Taylor, said that when Ms. Codianni first approached him about holding the classes, he welcomed the idea, yet people in the community thought he was crazy for opening his doors to the Latin Kings. "But I say, let's show those who think we are crazy what we can do to help these people in need," he said. "Because if we don't, we have only ourselves to blame."
Abie Quinones, a guidance counselor for the city's adult education programs and coordinator of the G.E.D. classes for the Latin Kings, pointed to the 40 percent high school dropout rate for Hispanic people in New Haven. "These are people who are screaming 'We need your help,' " she said. "They are not in the situation because they are bad people but because they have been given few opportunities."
Most of the people attending the session had served one or more prison terms. Many had grown up in poor households headed by their mothers. Few had known their fathers. Selling drugs was one of the few ways they knew of to earn money, some of them said. One 32-year-old man said he had recently filled out 25 applications for work in fast-food restaurants and has not heard back from any of them. Others told similar stories. They said they joined "the family" because it gave structure to their lives and moral grounding. But being a Latin King also subjected them to job discrimination and made them an easy target for police.
"I'll tell you right now that the biggest gang in town are the police," said Frankie Soto, 19 years old. He said the police often harassed him verbally and sometimes physically for walking down the street. The young man stood on crutches because he said he had been shot in the foot by someone who "hated the Latin Kings." He added, "There are a lot of people out there who'd like to kill us."
Mr. Soto said he was going to try to sit down with the man who shot him, to settle the matter peacefully. "We don't want violence," he said. "We want jobs and education and a nice home with a family."
Junito Fret, 16 years old, wore a cast on his arm because he said he had been shot in a drive-by shooting. Raised in public housing projects in Stamford and New Haven, he said his father had disappeared before he was born, which made him angry. When he was 11 he said he had grown tired of watching his mother struggle to provide for him and his four sisters and began dealing drugs. He was later arrested and sent to the Long Lane reformatory in Middletown. At 14, he was shot outside of Roberto Clemente Middle School. Since then he has been shot three more times, he said.
 
Famous for Being Alive
 "They call me Mr. Lucky because I've been shot at 15 times," he said. "I'm famous because I'm still alive."
He called Mr. Millet and Mr. Millan his heroes and said he faithfully read the Latin Kings' charter. "I was on my way to becoming a gangster," he said. "But the family gave me a lot of rules to help me live my life by."
Still, he said, he often thought about committing suicide. "There are times when I cried to my mom, 'Please, get us out of New Haven.' That's my dream, to get out of this violent hell."
Nicholas Pastore, the New Haven Police Chief, called the emergence of organizations like the Latin Kings symptomatic of the crisis that is eroding urban America. He said in a recent interview that he welcomed any efforts of the organization to turn its image around. Chief Pastore recently had a meeting with Ms. Codianni and others from her organization at a community policing substation in Fair Haven, to discuss their concerns and any future initiatives. He added that changing the public's fear of the organization would not be easy.
"It's great that they want to rechannel their energies because there's a lot of leadership qualities in the group," he said. "But society has been intimidated by the Latin Kings for too long. They have to recognize that their reputation is tarnished and there's a lack of credibility."

HEADLINE: The Business That a Brake Tester Built

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
ON the ground or in the air, Bernard Milano is preoccupied with safety and high technology. As a corporate pilot for Primerica and most recently Dun & Bradstreet, Mr. Milano has flown around the world half a dozen times as captain of Gulfstream and Falcon jets. And because of his flexible schedule as a corporate pilot, in which he flies only 8 to 11 days a month, he has had time to develop a business of his own, Ardsley Mobil Automotive Service Center, which he says is the only high-technology service station of its kind in Westchester.
"What gives us that distinction is a brake-testing machine I had installed after I bought the station seven years ago," Mr. Milano said. "It is an extremely sophisticated and expensive piece of equipment, which cost us $35,000, but technically it is the state of the art," he said. "This level of equipment isn't for the average service station, but we wanted to attract demanding customers. We excel in Jaguar repairs, and I thought it would be a great marketing tool. There are only four machines of its kind in all of New York State, Connecticut, New Jersey and Pennsylvania."
For the mechanically ungifted, Mr. Milano described the brake tester as "a computerized machine that literally gives customers an 'EKG' profile of their cars." The process is the same, he said. "When the car goes up on the rack, the brake tester makes a diagnosis in as little as a minute. But in that time the car is weighed. The wheel alignment on all four wheels is checked; the brake-system performance is analyzed, and then all the information is cranked out in a computerized report."
 
Satisfaction and Profitability
 The printouts, he said, which are given to the customer, enable them to monitor their car's performance.
"There are a lot of things that can go wrong with a car," he said. "If a customer is driving to Florida, for instance, and has car trouble, the print-out contains valuable information that will be useful to a strange mechanic."
The brake tester, he said, is paying its way in customer satisfaction and profitability. "It yields so much important information that even car dealers and other service stations bring in their cars to us for a testing."
Customers having work done on their cars are not charged extra for an inspection on the brake tester, Mr. Milano said, but someone wanting only a checkup would be charged $40 plus tax. The hourly labor rate varies from $65 to $75 depending on how "exotic" the car is.
Mr. Milano, who is 35, said he has been working at the station in one guise or another more than half his life. "When I was in school I had a part-time job there," he said. "The station is a landmark in Ardsley. There has been a service station on the same corner since 1926. It was previously known as the F.H.L. Service station when it was owned by Floyd Lichtenberg, when I was a kid. Many years later I bought it from Mr. Lichtenberg."
 
A Changing Industry
 But, he said, the station he worked in as a teen-ager bears little resemblance to the one today. "Those 'Gasoline Alley' days are gone," Mr. Milano added. "I remember when I was in high school, everybody with even a slight mechanical bent used to tinker with their cars. But today, you can't monkey with a car. It's even impossible to change carburetors because high-tech computer microprocessors control their function."
A few years after he bought the station, Mr. Milano said, he realized the best way to keep business growing was to upgrade the service. "The industry was changing," he said. "It was becoming so specialized that technicians were needed to service cars instead of mechanics. It was expand or die. We decided to expand."
Using their own money, Mr. Milano and his wife, Isabel, who is his partner and takes care of the bookkeeping and business end of the business, invested about $750,000 to remodel the 5,000-square-foot building with five king-size bays.
"At the station we only do mechanical work," Mr. Milano said. "We're set up like a dealership in that every car we work on gets dealer parts, and every car we service is tested on the brake machine for free."
 
Jaguars a Specialty
 Customers come from all over the county and include many Jaguar owners. "Jaguars once had a bad rap for always being in the shop," Mr. Milano said. "But they have been vastly improved. We service both the brand-new models and the classics. We even find original parts for the classics, but like any other high-powered car, they both need periodic checkups. The way I started servicing Jaguars is that some of the executives I fly for brought their Jaguars in, and through word of mouth other Jaguar owners followed."
In addition to the equipment that he has installed, Mr. Milano employs 21 technicians. "They receive ongoing training weekly at an automotive facility," he said. "They also have a library of service manuals, electronic technical service bulletins and access to a technical hot-line service."
He continued: "We're not talking about mechanics, but highly skilled, highly educated individuals who are looking not for jobs but careers here. They earn $35,000 at the beginning and can work up to $70,000 with full benefits included."
 
Fascination With Jet Engines
 The connection between his own two careers, he said, is his mechanical ability. "It was the mechanical aspects of flying more than the romantic idea that attracted me," he said. After graduating from St. John's University in Queens, with a bachelor's degree in administration, Mr. Milano continued his studies at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University in Daytona Beach, Fla. "Embry-Riddle is known as the Harvard of the aeronautics industry," he said. "I went there because I was fascinated with jet engines."
Two years later, Mr. Milano graduated with an associate degree and received a license as a commercial pilot and flight instructor.
"My first job was with a Cessna dealer teaching classes of 10 students how to fly," he said.
 
Victims of the Recession
 The planes he flies for corporate clients have all been based in hangars at Westchester County Airport.
"What isn't common knowledge is that the Westchester Airport is the largest corporate jetport in the world," he said. "And when it comes to the travel activities of executives, corporations prefer to keep a low profile."
Recently, he said, more than one corporate jet had become a victim of the recession. "When corporations have to cut back, the $30 million jet may be one of the first things to go," he said. "A lot of corporations are using commercial airlines today, which is another reason I am very glad to have a business. We expect to do $1.5 million to $2 million in sales this year, which is up 20 percent from last year's figures."

HEADLINE: New Momentum for Electronic Patient Records

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Mass.

 BODY:
Dr. Barry G. Zallen, a pediatrician at the Harvard Community Health Plan center here, turns to the Apple Macintosh on his desk, steers the cursor to a patient's name and clicks, and a 5-year-old girl's record appears. Dr. Zallen, who has no computer background, instantly gets a detailed account of the girl's chronic cough, the medication he prescribed, her medical history and a list of her previous visits.
Through a central computer, Dr. Zallen's colleagues also have access to these records, so they all share up-to-date data on each of the center's 7,300 patients. Cumbersome, often illegible paper records stuffed into file folders have been banished. 
 The computer does not stop there. It also The system also walks the doctor through the diagnosis of a variety of illnesses by setting out a list of symptoms. It enables Dr. Zallen to send prescriptions to the center's pharmacy and order diagnostic tests. It tracks every prescription and test result and alerts him if a patient doesn't fill a prescription or have a test. It reminds him of allergies or other conditions. All this goes into a data base that could later provide valuable information for researchers.
"This is the future," Dr. Zallen says.
That future has been a long time coming. The health care industry has been very slow to enter the information age, but it could be ready to make the leap. A number of big medical centers, like the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota, are investing in systems like Harvard's (see box). With costs soaring and reform in the air, the time is certainly ripe: It is estimated that $40 billion to $80 billion could be saved annually if such computerized record systems come into wide use.
Interest has heated up in the past year, under rising pressure to cut costs and improve quality. President Clinton's calls for competition among medical providers have increased the sense of urgency for hospitals, practices and clinics to become more efficient. Many realize that despite the initial costs, computerized records are not a technical luxury but an economic necessity.
"Only 1 or 2 percent of health care facilities have started toward this," said Everett Hines, an analyst with Coopers & Lybrand. Those that do not do it "will be taken over by more aggressive competitors or disappear."
Justifying the costs is a tough order. "If you go to a local hospital and ask what they'll save, they can't show you the numbers," said Dr. Paul Carpenter, who is in charge of setting up the Mayo Clinic system. "There are so many intangibles."
But the savings would be enormous. The systems could feed information into nationwide data bases, which could then be studied to determine which treatments work. This invaluable evidence would enable doctors to eliminate unnecessary exams and surgery. The systems could also eliminate the need for repeating tests when results are lost.
True, many hospitals have computer systems, mostly for accounting. But it is a long way from this to a nationwide data base.
One obstacle is the catch-up costs. The industry is paying the price for ignoring information technology's potential for three decades. While most industries spend up to 6 percent of revenues on data systems, health care devotes barely 1 percent.
IN addition, there are privacy concerns. Patients worry about confidentiality if there is such wide access to intimate details, and many local regulations inhibit the use of electronic records. But proponents say computerized records actually offer far more security, with passwords and encryption technology, than paper records, which are easily misplaced or removed.
Physicians tend to err on the side of caution. If information is missing from a record, a test will be reordered or a patient will stay longer in the hospital. Dr. Zallen said the Harvard system, the most sophisticated now in use, has changed the way he practices medicine, cutting out time-consuming searches through erratic paper records, sharply lowering the risk of error in both diagnoses and prescribing drugs and providing immediate, up-to-date information for other clinicians.
Even as the center in this Boston suburb demonstrates the wonders of such systems, it is also a testament to the difficulty of installing them on a wide scale. The center, for example, is simply a test site for Harvard Community Health Plan, one of the nation's largest HMO's. Only 12 doctors and nurses in Burlington now have access to the system, even after two years of operation.
The test system was installed, at a cost of several million dollars, as the center was being built. Donna DeAngelis, director of the project, estimated that it would be at least five years before an organization-wide system could be up and running for the more than 1,000 physicians and 550,000 patients at the 14 Harvard centers.
IN years past, physician resistance to computers has been high. But today, physicians under 40 (Dr. Zallen is 39) have used computers in school and are ready.
Still, the concept of having records accessible to the estimated 550,000 physicians and 7,000 hospitals nationwide remains a distant goal. Most observers predict that it will be the end of the decade before the infrastructure is in place to make it feasible.
"In the year 2000 we can have the kind of computer-based record most of us thought we could have in 1980," said Dr. William Stead, a researcher at Vanderbilt University who is working to install such a system.
And Dr. Clement J. McDonald, a researcher in computerized records who is on the staff of the Regenstrief Institute for Health Care at the University of Indiana, adds: "It's very hard. The analogy is not a heart transplant, it's a brain transplant."
First, hospitals, H.M.O.'s, and group practices must push ahead to install computer-based systems internally before there is any hope of creating the networks and standards needed for a nationwide system.
Proponents of computerized patient records seek more than just the conversion of paper records. They say these systems can and should change the way clinicians work. Charles Singer, a health care technology consultant in Wakefield, Mass., said health care providers must embrace the changes that are sweeping corporations. The computerized record should be the basis for a re-engineering of health care in the search for greater productivity, he said.
Roberta Clarke, a Boston University management professor who specializes in health care, said each effort to track data, such as seeing whether people having prostate surgery end up getting better or worse, has a start-up and management cost. "You end up reinventing the wheel for each of these studies," Ms. Clarke said.
The concept of computerized records is already more than 20 years old and continues to foster debate. Even the discussion about what constitutes a computer-based record and what to call it still rages.
"A lot of places say they have it already," said Dr. Paul Tang, a physician on the faculty at Stanford University Medical Center and an engineer at Hewlett-Packard. "And even though some institutions are more computerized than others, no one has the whole thing."
In January 1992, the Computer-based Patient Record Institute was created to spearhead a national effort to build an electronic data system. By bringing together hospitals, computer makers, software companies and health care professionals, the institute intends to set a clear definition of what constitutes the computer-based patient record and how to make it a reality.
Along with the functions in the Harvard system, the institute's definition includes a requirement for both inpatient and outpatient records as well as image-processing capability, for storing X-rays, CAT scans and MRI scans electronically.
"There hasn't been an economic incentive to create a perceived need for these systems," said Dr. G. Octo Barnett, director of the computer science lab at Massachusetts General Hospital. "Physicians have felt medical records are abysmal and gotten worse for 50 years, but the economic crisis will bring the change."
 There is also room for optimism. Rather than wait for a national referendum, many hospitals, HMO's and clinics have pushed ahead with computer-based record systems despite the costs. In addition, several ambitious initiatives are under way in medical centers at schools like Vanderbilt, Duke and the University of Wisconsin.
The wait for a nationwide system may be longer than proponents want. "It's up to the Federal Government when it happens," said Dr. Carpenter, citing the need for an information highway to be in place before other technologies can be applied. "If all the legal issues were handled state by state, it would take the next half century to implement."
 
 
COMPUTERIZING FOR SURVIVAL
 At the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., Dr. Paul Carpenter is overseeing an ambitious three-year, $100 million plan to create a system similar to the one at Harvard Community Health.
The plan calls for a computerized patient record system covering the entire Mayo network, which includes facilities in Rochester, Jacksonville, Fla., and Scottsdale, Ariz.
The installation of such a system, serving 500,000 patients a year, will be daunting. But Dr. Carpenter is ambitious and says it will work if it is done correctly. "The driving concept is to have the right information at the right time and the right place," he said.
The Crozer-Keystone Health System in Delaware County, Pa., a tightly affiliated group of four hospitals and assorted clinics,recently signed an $80 million, 10-year contract with Shared Medical Systems of Malvern, Pa., to install an enterprise-wide data system. Shared Medical is a $400 million supplier of health care data services.
The goal is to create a single electronic patient record accessible to all 4,000 clinicians at every Crozer-Keystone facility.
John C. McMeekin, president and chief executive of Crozer-Keystone, said it was difficult to sell his directors on such a large capital expenditure but they finally understood that the need outweighed the expense.
He said he turned to Coopers & Lybrand and Perot Systems to get a cost-benefit analysis. "They told us we didn't have much of a choice," Mr. McMeekin said. "If we were to survive, we had to make the commitment."
Mr. McMeekin said such a system can be installed only as fast as the clinicians will allow, citing physician resistance as the "Achilles heel of this vision."

HEADLINE: Fitness That Blooms in the Spring

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
AT Tiger Schulmann's Karate and Fitness Center in Yonkers, the focus is on the total body -- the mind as well as the muscles. "No machines, no racquetball courts, no swimming here," said Toni L. Caserta, program director. "Just self-discipline and self-defense."
In Scarsdale, at East Coast Fitness Center, yet another approach is taken. The free weights, Nautilus circuit, Stairmasters and tanning beds serve a mostly male clientele, average age 18 to 24. There, pumping iron is the order of the day, the manager, Michael Lewandowski said. 
 In Dobbs Ferry, at the Rivertown Center for Yoga and Health, fitness "is a matter of looking at the body from the inside out," said the co-director, Brahmani Holly Liebman. Along the road to a smaller waistline, she said, "People can find inner peace, too."
 
Many Exercise Options
 And in White Plains, at Club Fit, it is a combination of approaches -- aerobics, free weights, Nautilus machines, yoga, stress-reduction seminars and nutrition, among them -- that promises both a better body and a sense of well-being to a mostly "working professional crowd," said Debra Gersten, the fitness and exercise director.
Whatever kind of exercise one does -- and there are many options to choose from in Westchester -- May is the month to focus on getting in shape. Westchester is kicking off National Physical Fitness Month today at 2 P.M. with its second annual Great Westchester Walk-In at the Kensico Dam Plaza in Valhalla. Sponsored in part by the county's Department of Health and the Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation, it is a free event to promote walking as an ongoing fitness activity for people of all ages.
Also this afternoon, the Yonkers Pulse Healthy Heart Program Walk-In, sponsored by the health departments of the city, county and state along with other organizations, will be held at 2 P.M. at Redmond Field on Cook Avenue.
And Bicycle Sundays, sponsored by the county's Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation, resume at 10 o'clock this morning along a seven-mile stretch of the Bronx River Parkway that is closed to vehicular traffic. The county closes the parkway every Sunday from May through October except on May 30, Sept. 5 and Oct. 10.
Also, May 19 is National Employee's Health and Fitness Day, and the physical-fitness industry has named May as its Commit to Get Fit Month.
 
Goals for the Year 2000
 The Federal Department of Health and Human Services has set physical fitness goals for the year 2000, which include increasing to 85 percent the number of Americans over 6 years old who participate regularly -- five or more times a week -- in a fitness activity.
In New York State, polls show that three-fourths of all residents do not exercise regularly, said Christopher Maylahn, an epidemiologist with the State Health Department.
And nationally, it is estimated that only 42.2 million Americans, or about 17 percent of the population, work out regularly -- 16.7 million of them in health clubs, according to the Boston-based Association of Quality Clubs, a trade organization representing 2,000 health clubs.
But as the Federal Government attempts to get more Americans to exercise, there are indications that the fitness revolution of the 1980's may be tapering off in this decade, a trend that has health experts and the fitness industry worried, said Harvey Lauer, president of American Sports Data, a Hartsdale marketing firm that serves the sports and leisure industry.
"We will never go back to the sedentary life styles of the 1950's," Mr. Lauer said, "but there have been some declines in recent years."
Despite fitness fads and fashions -- like in-line roller skates, step aerobics, specialized foot gear and home gyms -- Mr. Lauer's organization reported that "80 percent of all sneakers are never sweated in."
In part, the recent decline in participation in fitness programs can be attributed to the recession, which caused some people to put off spending $300 to more than $900 a year for club memberships, said Steven M. Goodfriend, a research manager for the Association of Quality Clubs.
 
Offsetting the Aging Process
 To bolster their memberships, fitness-club managers said they have begun pitching their services to a broader market -- targeting men and women in their 40's and 50's, the elderly and children -- and stressing the long-term benefits of working out.
"We're emphasizing cardiovascular fitness more than weight lifting now," said Sarah Collins, manager of Court Sports II Health and Fitness in Yonkers. "People are more interested in a lifetime of health and fitness than just putting on muscle in the short run."
At Club Fit, Jocelyn M. Leigh, a personal trainer, works with women older than 30, who "need to build up muscle density, not only for the esthetics but to protect their bones," she said. "Staying fit offsets the aging process."
Said Felix Corona, owner of Flex Fitness in North Tarrytown and the 1991 Natural Mr. U.S.A. ("natural" meaning that no steroids were used to build muscle bulk): "The emphasis clearly is shifting. We're realizing fitness is not just about huge muscles, but about cardiovascular health and proper nutrition."
 
Walk for Life Campaign
 Walking, health experts say, competes with aerobic classes, weight lifting and Nautilus circuits as a way of staying fit for life, and it is less expensive. "It's free, it's fun, and most everyone can do it," said Joan E. Sullivan, assistant director of the County Health Department's Bureau of Disease Control.
The county is sponsoring its Walk-In as part of the New York Walk for Life Campaign, Ms. Sullivan said, because County Health Department statistics show that during 1989 the state had the highest rate in the country of deaths from heart disease -- 275.3 per 100,000 residents. Westchester had an even higher rate -- 280.8 per 100,000 people. In Yonkers during 1989, where the State Department of Health sponsors the Pulse Healthy Heart program, the rate was higher still -- 404.6 per 100,000.
The State Health Department, which has targeted high cholesterol, cigarette smoking, high blood pressure, a sedentary life style and overweight as the major risk factors in heart disease, promotes walk-ins and sponsors seven Pulse Healthy Heart programs besides the one in Yonkers, Mr. Maylahn said.
Dr. Jean Rosenbaum, director of the American Fitness Association, a research organization in Durango, Colo., recommends walking three times a week at a brisk pace to combat heart disease. "The only cost for walking," he said, "is a decent pair of shoes."
 
Medical Consultations Suggested
 Dr. Rosenbaum, who also recommends weight lifting, even for older people, said: "The debilitation of old age is not necessary. Instead of withering on the vine, exercise."
But doctors in the county had some warnings about how and where people should exercise.
"Unless you are a proven college athlete, check with a doctor before you set out on an exercise program," said Dr. Michael V. Herman, chief of cardiology at the New York Medical College and the County Medical Center in Valhalla. "I'm a great enthusiast of appropriate physical fitness, but within a person's abilities to perform it.
"Most of us," he added, "are overfed and under-exercized and should proceed with caution."
Dr. Herman recommended consulting a doctor before starting an exercise program, and stopping an activity immediately if any of the following symptoms are noted: chest pain, lightheadedness, shortness of breath, undue fatigue or unusual joint or muscle pain.
 
A Need for Supervision
 Dr. Murray Low, director of the Westchester Cardiac Rehabilitation Center in Scarsdale, said he was pleased with all the attention given to fitness. "Finally, the Clinton Administration has the focus on preventive care, rather than acute care, with all its higher costs."
But he recommended stress testing before proceeding with an exercise program and checking to make sure that fitness instructors and personal trainers are properly certified, preferably by the American College of Sports Medicine.
"There is a lot of misinformation out there," Dr. Low said. "And exercisers have to be supervised properly. If someone has high blood pressure, it may be dangerous to lift weights. And if someone is overweight, he or she shouldn't start with jogging."
"But most of all," he said, "people can't undo in one day what took 30 years to happen. There's no magic bullet for getting fit."

HEADLINE: The State's Drug Companies Face New Political Environment

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
WHILE the rest of the Connecticut economy languishes, pharmaceutical research is growing across the state. Boehringer Ingelheim in Ridgefield, Miles Laboratories in West Haven, and Pfizer in Groton are all opening or building major laboratory expansions, and smaller operations are following suit.
A spokesman for the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, David Emerick, said an estimated 12,000 people in Connecticut worked in drug research and development, which placed Connecticut ninth in the country. 
 "It's the industry nobody knows," Mr. Emerick said. "It's an invisible industry. The public sees a pill coming out of a bottle and has no idea what it took to get it to that point."
Now, as President Clinton and other national political figures attack the spiraling cost of pharmaceutical products, there is increasing concern about the impact on Connecticut, and drug companies in the state are considering how they can counter the criticism.
 
Future Is Uncertain
 "We obviously are very concerned, just as all the companies are, about the impact those kinds of comments could have," said David W. Nurnberger, a spokesman for Boehringer Ingelheim, a German company in the middle of doubling the size of its United States headquarters in Ridgefield, to 500,000 square feet.
A spokesman for Miles Laboratories, Donald Hyman, said that company had just completed the second phase of its research center expansion in September. The company more than doubled its scientific staff, to 230 biochemists, chemists and biologists. With plans for a third phase already on the boards, Miles expects its scientific staff to total 600 people by 1998, for research into diabetes, dementia, bone and auto-immune diseases, and other chronic conditions.
"That's assuming we have the kind of business environment that allows us to sell our new products and develop new products," Mr. Hyman said. "The business environment right now is, shall we say, a little uncertain. It's a difficult time for us, and we're watching things closely in Washington. We're trying to catch up, from a lobbying point of view."
Some industry analysts believe the debate over drug costs will continue for a while, but there is little danger that the drug industry will suffer serious harm.
"I don't think health care reform will be as draconian as people expect," said an analyst with Stein, Rowe, Furnham Inc., Art McQueen. "I think there are going to be negotiations between the Government and industry, and the compromise will be something both sides can live with."
Still, over the last couple of months, the President and some prominent members of Congress have attacked drug company profits, and said controls on the price of pharmaceuticals was one way to control health care spending, a proposal that has executives in some of the pharmaceutical companies on edge.
"We support the President's idea of managed care, and extending Medicare coverage to prescription drugs, but we oppose the idea of price controls," Mr. Hyman said. "How will you produce the next generation of breakthrough drugs if you have price controls? There will be no incentives."
"Smallpox, polio, diphtheria -- these are all laughed at today because of the drugs private industry has developed," Mr. Hyman said. But we have new scourges to deal with. All of this research is expensive, and we have to pay for it."
Not all drug development companies are worried about the President's criticisms. The owner of one small company said price controls could work to his company's benefit.
Edward B. Michaels, president of E. B. Michaels Research Associates Inc. in Bridgeport, said big companies had huge advertising budgets, and could easily crowd out smaller competitors.
 
Millions for Marketing
 "New products are very difficult to bring onto the market," Mr. Michaels said. "You need to spend millions of dollars to make people aware of a new product -- money that could be better spent on research and development."
President Clinton's plan to control the prices of drugs could force the big drug companies to rethink how much money they spend on advertising and marketing, which could improve the competitive climate for companies like his, he said.
The big drug companies, though, are also often the only ones that can afford the billions of dollars it takes to develop new drugs, and for the tests it takes to get them through the regulatory process.
Mr. Emerick, the manufacturers' association spokesman, said research and development spending in the drug industry would cost an estimated $12.6 billion this year, 13.5 percent over 1992.
Drug makers point out that hundreds of compounds are developed for every one that makes money. Without financial incentives to bring out new and better drugs, drug research and development might be deemed too much of a risk, said the president and chief executive officer of Pfizer, Allan Steere.
 
Future of High Technology
 Pfizer increased its research staff to 4,000 people from 1,700 in the early 1980's, with the bulk of the growth at its research center in Groton.
The state has also staked its financial future in part on pharmaceuticals. Two years ago, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. ran on a platform that stressed the future of high technology industry in Connecticut, industry that could bring high-paying, white-collar jobs to the state. He used the pharmaceutical company as an example of the type of industry Connecticut should try to attract.
That strategy has not changed, despite the national call for health care cost control, said a spokesman for the state Department of Economic Development, Joseph Cohen.
New health policies "could actually produce increased business for the pharmaceutical companies in Connecticut," Mr. Cohen said. As the Federal Government expands Medicaid and Medicare to include pharmaceutical coverage, to make sure everyone has access to medications and immunizations, the companies could benefit, he said.
 
'Very Bright Future'
 "We're not changing our direction at all," Mr. Cohen said. "We think the pharmaceutical industry has a very bright future in Connecticut."
Mr. Hyman said he believed there were three reasons for the recent attacks on drug company profits. First, he said, drug costs are more visible: people generally pay for prescriptions and other drugs out of pocket, while many other health care costs are billed directly to insurers. The Bureau of Labor Statistics estimates that drug costs account for 7 cents of every dollar spent on health care in the United States; in Japan, it is 30 cents.
Another factor, he said, is that drug companies are easy to attack from a political perspective. "Most Congressmen don't have a pharmaceutical company in their district," Mr. Hyman said, "but they all have hospitals and doctors."
The third factor in the attack is that drug companies have not done enough from a public relations standpoint, telling people what pharmaceutical companies have done to keep health care costs down.
"We've done a poor job of telling our story," Mr. Hyman said. "We've done a good job talking to doctors and scientists and other health care providers, but we haven't spent a lot of time talking to the patients."
Mr. Steere said, for instance, that most people are not aware that of the 100 most prescribed pharmaceuticals today, 95 were developed by private industry, compared with three by government or university laboratories and two by individuals. The average American works 40 minutes to pay for the same pharmaceuticals that cost people in Germany, France and other industrialized countries a full hour's wage, he said.
And drugs are one of the few areas where the United States has maintained an edge through innovation, which helps with the international balance of trade, Mr. Steere said.
 
'A Peanut' in Total Costs
 "So, we were all caught off guard by the vehemence of the attack on the industry, particularly because we're a peanut in terms of total health care costs, and because we could be such an integral part of controlling costs," Mr. Steere said.
Pharmaceutical companies contend that drugs can help prevent, or shorten, hospital stays, which is where most of the country's health care dollars are spent. Medications are being developed every day that prevent disease, which is far less costly than treating someone who is sick.
"We're part of the solution, not part of the problem," said Brian M. McGlynn, a spokesman for Pfizer.
Mr. Steere, who is president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, said the industry has begun lobbying members of Congress to make sure nothing damaging to the drug industry is passed. "Little by little, we're making ourselves heard," he said.
Drug company officials are stressing what they say are the facts showing that pharmaceuticals are a good buy. A study by the University of Mississippi Research Institute of Pharmaceutical Sciences, for instance, found that the growth in the list prices of pharmaceutical drugs has actually slowed in recent years, from 11.6 percent a year in 1989 to 6.4 percent in 1992.
"Should this trend continue, it is likely that prescription drug prices will decline in real terms, relative to price levels in the economy as a whole," the study concluded.
Pfizer recently promised voluntary price controls: There will be no price increases on many of the company's major products -- like procardia XL for heart patients and Feldene for arthritis sufferers -- and no individual price increase will exceed 4.5 percent, the company said in a Jan. 25 news release.
Pfizer and the other pharmaceutical companies that are doing business worldwide say they will try to make sure their voice is heard in the national debate.
"We've dealt with every form of government regulation and health care system," Mr. Steere said. "No one knows, with certainty, what direction the President's health care policy will take. But we can live with any rational national health care scheme."
Still, there is considerable concern about how the debate will finally end. "If our industry is subjected to restrictive government price controls, virtually the entire pharmaceutical industry would become a public utility," Mr. Hyman said. "With all due respect to power and water companies, is that the model of innovation and risk-taking the nation needs to guarantee the next generation of breakthrough drugs?"

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS VIEW;
Timeless Purity From the Soul Of Bluegrass

BYLINE: By BILLY ALTMAN; Billy Altman has written about pop music for Entertainment Weekly and Rolling Stone.

 BODY:
Of all the threads that together form the fabric of country music, none have held more proudly to their origins than bluegrass. Several generations have passed since the groundbreaking 1940's recordings by such pioneers as Bill Monroe and the Blue Grass Boys, Lester Flatt and Earl Scruggs, and Carter and Ralph Stanley and the Clinch Mountain Boys. Such recordings set in motion the revolution that gave Southeastern hillbilly string band music a bold new shape and, ultimately, a trademark name.
Nearly half a century later, the genre's parameters remain virtually unchanged. Whether made in 1947 or 1993, good bluegrass has the same pristine sound: of acoustic stringed instruments played with precision -- often at blinding speeds -- and high-harmonied voices singing plaintive tales of home and hearth. 
 That bluegrass has retained its essential purity despite changes in the rest of country music is due to several factors. For one thing, the music's limited success in the marketplace has discouraged outsiders from infringing upon it. (Flatt and Scruggs's 1962 theme from "The Beverly Hillbillies" television show and Eric Weissberg's "Dueling Banjos" from the 1972 film "Deliverance" are the most famous of the genre's few pop hits.) For another, bluegrass has maintained a working relationship with Nashville -- the Grand Ole Opry includes bluegrass performers on all its shows -- as well as with the folk audience, which regards bluegrass as a link to an otherwise vanishing American music heritage.
Finally, bluegrass has produced a number of artists -- Jim and Jesse McReynolds, Mac Wiseman and Jimmy Martin, to name a few -- whose lifelong dedication to the genre has helped keep it vibrant. Chief among these artists, of course, is the ubiquitous Mr. Monroe, now past 80 and still a godlike presence on the Opry stage and bluegrass festival circuit. But if the mandolin-playing Mr. Monroe is the father of bluegrass, then the 66-year-old banjo player and singer Ralph Stanley, who has been performing mountain music since 1946, must surely be its soul. His recent two-CD set, "Saturday Night and Sunday Morning" (Freeland Records 9001), is recommended to anyone interested in bluegrass or the authentic sounds of traditional country music.
In both his playing and singing, Mr. Stanley has been fiercely loyal to the hill country music he and his brother Carter grew up hearing in southwestern Virginia. Since his brother's death in 1966, he has been a teacher and living legend to the many sidemen who have gone through "bluegrass boot camp" under his direction. Mr. Stanley has some 145 recordings to his credit, but his new album may well be the crowning glory in a career that has spanned the entire history of the genre he helped create.
The 30-song collection, split evenly between secular and sacred material (hence the title), is filled with new versions of Stanley brothers classics, including "Rank Stranger," "All the Good Times Are Past and Gone" and "Vision of Mother." These are songs whose stark, natural imagery and simple messages of the value -- and the price -- of honor, love and faith really do sound as old as the hills that inspired them. On all of them, Mr. Stanley displays flawless, economical banjo playing -- a fascinating blend of the old-fashioned, two-finger "clawhammer" style with the more modern three-finger technique perfected by Mr. Scruggs. Mr. Stanley's vocals are taut and soaring; even when young, he came across like an old-timer; his lonesome tenor now seems otherworldly.
What sets this work apart, though, is the exceptional effort put forth by an all-star lineup of guest vocalists who queue up to pay homage to, and partake of, Mr. Stanley's timeless music. For some, it is a reunion: Ricky Skaggs, who began his career as a teen-ager with the Clinch Mountain Boys, is heard on two bittersweet ballads, "All I Ever Loved Was You" and "Sea of Regret." The strong, clear voice of Charlie Waller, founder of the Country Gentlemen, anchors the gothic "Banks of the Ohio" (about a man who drowns his lover because she won't marry him) and "The Fields Have Turned Brown," in which a wandering son learns by letter that his broken-hearted parents have been dead for years.
Mr. Monroe joins Mr. Stanley for graceful renditions of two Monroe standards, "Letter From My Darling" and "I'll Meet You in Church Sunday Morning," and Mr. Martin, a onetime Blue Grass Boy, provides a gritty lead on "All the Good Times Have Passed and Gone."
For Vince Gill, Dwight Yoakam and Patty Loveless, the recording is a chance to reveal sides of their musical personalities usually precluded by their star status. Mr. Gill and Ms. Loveless ring in with lilting harmony vocals on several tracks. Mr. Yoakam's reverential singing on "Down Where the River Bends" and on his atmospheric composition "Miner's Prayer" is a revelation for an artist often viewed as an outsider by the country establishment. And for country veterans like George Jones ("Wonderful World Outside"), Tom T. Hall ("The Water Lilly") and Emmylou Harris ("I Never Will Marry"), who give strong performances regardless of the surroundings, it's one very good day at the office.
Even amid the accumulated talent, Ralph Stanley manages to dominate the album. He sings lead on only a third of the tracks, and his banjo solos always tend to be part of the whole rather than calling attention to themselves. And yet, it is his idiosyncratic harmonies and perfectly placed instrumental runs that elevate each of these performances to a higher esthetic ground. Hearing Mr. Stanley sing "Heaven's Bright Shore" with one of bluegrass's brightest young stars, the 21-year-old Alison Krauss, a listener senses the torch not being passed but shared, and those stubborn bluegrass roots growing deeper into the ground.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 16, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption on May 2 about bluegrass performers at the 1964 Newport Folk Festival misidentified the musician at the left. He was George Shuffler.

HEADLINE: FORAGING;
Mild-Mannered Quilters Pursue Quarry

BYLINE: By Cara Greenberg

 BODY:
NEW YORK is a mecca for quilt makers from overseas and from the heartland, and that includes Connecticut. The Phabric Phantoms shopping tour last Monday, led by Marilyn Henrion and Diane Rode Schneck, included Hiroko Matsuda from Kagoshima, Japan; Leslie Granbeck from Minneapolis and five women from Connecticut towns where most fabrics are tiny flower prints.
"We don't do calicoes," said Paula Nadelstern of the Bronx, speaking for those who consider their quilt-making an art. The group assaulted seven fabric shops in Manhattan, seeking nontraditional materials. Stops included Handloom Batik on Mulberry Street, which sells Indonesian and Indian imports, and Paron Fabrics on West 57th Street, where, for $4.50 a yard, they bought French cottons. 
 At B & J Fabrics on West 40th Street, crushed silk and metallic organza ($20 a yard), novelty cottons with fish and cowboy prints ($8 a yard), subtly woven Japanese ikat cloth ($15 a yard) and vibrant African kente cloth ($15 a yard) made one want to re-enroll in home-economics class.
The women bought a yard here, half a yard there. At Paron Fabrics, Jennifer O'Brien, the president of the Nutmeg Quilters Guild in Ridgefield, Conn., marveled over the prices. "Nine dollars a yard for Liberty of London!" she said. "It's $24 to $28 where I live."
Margo Bacon of Brookfield, Conn., said she joined the tour because "I wanted to find all these places." Florence Suerig of Greenwich, Conn., added: "New York is so vast. This way, you go into seven or eight places that are for sure good places."
Mrs. Henrion and Ms. Schneck run Phabric Phantoms tours on demand, varying itineraries with the interests of each group. The daylong tours cost $35 a person. The two women choose stores on the basis of fabric quality, price and integrity.
"We know which ones you can trust on fiber content," said Mrs. Henrion, whose quilts have an M. C. Escher-like complexity. She and Ms. Schneck publish New York Unraveled!, a quarterly newsletter for quilting enthusiasts. Mrs. Henrion and Ms. Nadelstern invented Quilt-O-Rama, a board game.
Today's quilting subculture includes artists whose work incorporates materials like newspaper headlines, gum wrappers, ugly ties, dryer lint and Christmas lights. "If you can sew it down, you can put it in a quilt," Ms. Schneck said.
In front of B & J Fabrics, Mrs. Henrion gave a short, to-the-point orientation. "They're very nice here, very helpful," she said. "They'll cut halves. The prices marked on the bolts are one or two dollars more than the price you will pay -- ask."
Every woman on the tour confessed to being a fabric junky. "I've got six or seven unfinished projects and enough fabric to last three lifetimes," Ms. Granbeck said.
Kirsten Bell of Newtown, Conn., said quilting was great "because you can justify constantly buying fabric."
"I have 40 feet of shelves stacked with fabrics, and I keep buying more," she said.
Several members of the Phabric Phantoms tour agreed that there was a common thread running through the worldwide community of quilt makers. Indeed, Ms. O'Brien and Ms. Matsuda became pen pals because of their interest in quilting, and Ms. Matsuda was visiting her friend for the first time.
"It's a carry-over from the days of the quilting bee," Ms. Schneck said of the quilting network. Yet, quilt making remains an individualized form of expression. Ms. Nadelstern said: "Each of us is going to go home and create something totally unique with what we've bought. Golfers and bird watchers don't have that."
Phabric Phantoms shopping tours are run on demand, usually twice a month; (212) 982-8949 or (212) 249-5094. More information about the tours will be available at the Manhattan Quilters Guild booth at the Great American Quilt Festival, May 12 to 16 at Pier 92, the Hudson River and West 52d Street.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: TOP BOSNIAN SERB, FACING U.S. ACTION, SIGNS A PEACE PLAN;
VOTE SET ON ACCORD

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VOULIAGMENI, Greece, May 2

 BODY:
Bowing to pressure from his sponsor in Belgrade and the threat of American air strikes, the leader of Bosnia's warring Serbs signed an international peace plan today intended to end the devastating year-old civil war in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The endorsement by the leader, Radovan Karadzic, came after months of on-again, off-again talks in which he seemed intent primarily on buying time so his forces could seize more territory. 
 Today he said his agreement to the plan, which has already been signed by rival Muslim and Croatian factions, hinged on the approval of his self-styled parliament of Serbian nationalists, which is to meet on Wednesday at its headquarters in Pale. The assembly unanimously rejected the plan six days ago, but this time Dr. Karadzic appeared confident that he could bring his forces into line.
 
Prodding From Milosevic
 Diplomats said Dr. Karadzic capitulated under prodding from President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, who has provided the arms, supplies and ideological support for the Serbs' campaign of "ethnic cleansing" in Muslim and Croatian areas of Bosnia. Retaliatory sanctions imposed last year and tightened last week by the United Nations on the rump Yugoslav federation of Serbia and Montenegro are destroying its economy.
If the Bosnian Serbs accept the plan on Wednesday, the signing today would theoretically lead to a cease-fire throughout Bosnia and the deployment of at least 50,000 troops for the biggest, most ambitious, expensive and dangerous peacekeeping operation the United Nations has ever undertaken.
In a departure from usual policy, the heavily armed peacekeepers would have orders to use military force as necessary to compel dissident commanders to comply with the plan's provisions.
 
Need for Quick Commitments
 But it was unclear if, or when, major nations would be willing to commit the 50,000 to 60,000 troops needed to enforce the plan, which calls for a cease-fire, disarmament and the creation of 10 semi-autonomous provinces dominated by the major ethnic groups under a weak central government.
With only 7,000 United Nations troops stationed in Bosnia now, diplomats said that lining up an adequate number to enforce the plan could take weeks. They emphasized that the Western allies should commit troops quickly to the peace effort if they wanted it to remain alive.
The signing ceremony, which came after two days of talks among Serbian, Muslim and Croatian leaders at this luxury beach resort near Athens, brought immediate pleas from mediators for the Clinton Administration to drop its threats to use military force against the Serbs now that the Serbs seem ready to stop fighting.
"I don't doubt it has helped concentrate minds," said Lord Owen, who with former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance drafted the peace plan. "But now the time is to talk of peace, not war.
"I certainly hope there will be U.S. peacekeepers in blue helmets as well as troops from Russia," he added.
Lord Owen said that if countries that already have troops serving in the United Nations force in Bosnia -- including Britain, France and Canada -- agreed to commit those soldiers to the new force, "we will be making a good and fast beginning."
President Clinton called Dr. Karadzic's decision a "positive step," but said the United States would continue to press for tougher allied action if the Serbs failed to act in good faith.
 
Threat of U.S. Action
 Skeptical of promises from Bosnian Serbs, the Clinton Administration decided in principle on Saturday to commit American air power to help end the fighting but delayed a final decision. So far it has had little success in persuading European allies to join an operation involving force.
Britain and France have resisted direct military intervention by American forces, arguing that it might provoke the Serbs to attack troops in the United Nations force. Military strikes would also force them to suspend the crucial convoys that are feeding more than 2.3 million people in Bosnia, they argue.
Under the peace plan, the estimated 50,000 troops, probably including a substantial number of Americans, would be sent to Bosnia to oversee the withdrawal of Serbian forces from much of the territory they have conquered. Critics say the partition would nonetheless reward the Serbs, who made up less than a third of Bosnia's population before the war began in April 1992.
Lord Owen said that since the United Nations lacked the expertise to organize and command a force of tens of thousands with a complex mandate providing for serious military action, the Security Council was likely "to ask NATO to play a role in the planning and command and control procedures."
While diplomats attending the talks consider the threat of American intervention redundant if the Serbs keep the agreement they made today, the tightening trade blockade that contributed to their reversal is likely to be relaxed only gradually, if the Security Council finds concrete evidence that all sides are carrying out their promises.
After praising Dr. Karadzic's "courageous" decision to sign the plan, Lord Owen called for it to be put into action as soon as possible so that peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina could "spread out" and defuse the armed standoff between Serbs and Croats in the Krajina district of neighboring Croatia as well as the tensions between Serbs and ethnic Albanians in Serbia's southern province of Kosovo.
 
Serbian Attacks Continue

But even as Dr. Karadzic signed the plan, Serbian offensives continued in northern, eastern and western Bosnia. Heavy shelling, infantry attacks and many casualties were reported in Gorazde, one of three Muslim towns in the east that has not yet fallen to the Serbs.
United Nations officials said the Serbs besieging Gorazde nonetheless allowed an aid convoy through to the town for the first time in a month, Reuters reported.
Although some Bosnian Serbs in Pale said they disagreed with Dr. Karadzic's decision, Lord Owen said they had little choice but to endorse the peace plan. There is "formidable pressure on them from Belgrade," he said, "because the war machine is being fueled from across the border."
Last week, after the Bosnian Serbs unanimously rejected the Vance-Owen plan, President Milosevic of Serbia sent them an angry letter saying they had no right to subject Yugoslavia's 10 million inhabitants to new and harsher economic restrictions.
The United Nations Security Council had voted to impose the stricter penalties only if the Bosnian Serbs refused to sign the settlement. The Council set a deadline of April 26, the day after a referendum in Russia, to insure that Russia would not use its veto power to block the new sanctions.
Russia is a traditional ally of the Serbs, and President Boris N. Yeltsin feared he might lose a vote of confidence if his Government supported draconian sanctions against the Yugoslav Government. Mr. Yeltsin's victory last Sunday, followed by his warning that the Serbs must sign the peace plan, ended any hopes on their part that he might be replaced by someone more sympathetic to their cause.
Another factor in the Serbs' calculations today was the recent hardening in the Clinton Administration's decision to press for military intervention and the re-arming of beleaguered Muslim forces, officials said.
 
No Boundary Changes
 The agreement Dr. Karadzic signed today is identical to the one he rejected just over a week ago and contains no changes in the boundaries of the 10 new provinces that will be carved out of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
When rejecting this map in the past, however, Dr. Karadzic has complained that the Serbs were being asked to reduce their share of the country from more than 70 percent at present to around 43 percent, ceding most of its industries and richest mines to other ethnic groups.
In particular, Dr. Karadzic has sought to carve out new corridors connecting the three Serbian-controlled provinces created under the plan and giving them direct access both to Serbia and to the Serbian-dominated Krajina area of Croatia.
Such demands aroused fears among Muslims that the Serbs are still hoping to create an independent state in Bosnia and Herzegovina that would eventually unite with Serbia.
In the end, Dr. Karadzic settled for a compromise proposed by mediators guaranteeing Serbs freedom of movement between their provinces along demilitarized roads under the control of the United Nations forces who will ban unauthorized military convoys. Dr. Karadzic was also assured that the Serbs will have a veto over the nationality of the peacekeeping forces put in control of these roads.
 
 
 
THE TERMS FOR PEACE
HALTING THE TROOPS

 
1. Once it has lined up adequate peacekeeping forces, the U.N. Security Council calls for cease-fire within 72 hours
 
2.All sides report status and location of forces.
 
3. United Nations starts moving in peacekeeping force.
 
4. All heavy weapons withdrawn out of range of Sarajevo within five days.
 
5. All other heavy weapons withdrawn out of range of opponents within 15 days.
 
6. All heavy weapons placed in designated areas under United Nations supervision.
 
7. All armed forces pulled back simultaneously and eventually regrouped in a province controlled by respective ethnic factions.
 
8.Work starts on restoring power, water and communications.
 
9. United Nations takes control of borders and starts opening roads allowing free movement.
 
POLITICAL ARRANGEMENTS
 
(pending the drafting of a new constitution and preparations made for free elections)
 
1. Nine-member central government (three Serbs, three Muslims, three Croats) nominated by the ethnic factions). All decisions unanimous. Mediators arbitrate disputes.
 
2. Ten provincial governments each composed of governor, vice governor and 10 members. Nominated by ethnic parties according to share of population. Supervised return of refugees, election preparations, police.
 
3. Human rights protection. All forced transfers of property voided.
Mediators appoint four ombudsmen to investigate complaints.
All citizens may request international monitoring where human rights violations are suspected.

HEADLINE: HEALTH-CARE COSTS MAY BE INCREASED $100 BILLION A YEAR

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
Government financial experts have told the White House that President Clinton's health-care plan may require $100 billion to $150 billion a year in new public and private spending by Government, business and consumers, depending on the scope of benefits guaranteed to all Americans.
Several Administration officials contend that those numbers are too high and are urging the financial experts to reduce their estimates. So far, they have refused to do so. 
 The estimates, coming at a time when Congress is anxious about new taxes needed to pay for a reorganization of the health-care system, are in confidential work papers from the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform.
 
Beginning to Circulate
 Financial experts have been working on cost analyses for months, but only recently, as the Administration's thinking has crystallized, have estimates of overall costs begun to circulate inside the Government. They have not been made public before.
The financial experts, from the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, estimated the cost of three possible packages of benefits. The least generous would cost $99.5 billion a year, while the most generous would cost $150.6 billion, they said.
Not all that money would come from the Government, but the Administration has not decided how the cost might be divided among government, businesses and households. Nor has Mr. Clinton decided which type of package to propose when he unveils his plan this month, though White House officials have said it will be comprehensive.
 
Cost and Coverage Vary
 The three possible benefits packages would cover hospital and doctors' services and some prescription drug costs, but they vary widely in how much of the cost would be covered by insurance and how much consumers would have to pay.
The manager of the task force, Ira C. Magaziner, estimated in early February that the health program might require $30 billion to $90 billion a year in new spending by the Federal Government alone. The nation as a whole is expected to spend more than $900 billion on health care this year.
White House officials say the new estimates are subject to change because final decisions on the details of the President's plan have not been made. Moreover, they argue, people should not be alarmed by the estimates because total spending on health care in the United States is already increasing by $100 billion a year. They say Mr. Clinton's plan will eventually slow the increase.
Most of the new money -- $69.5 billion to $82.2 billion, not all of it from the Government -- will be needed to provide coverage for people who do not have any health insurance, the actuaries said.
The Health Care Financing Administration runs Medicare and Medicaid, the programs for 67 million people who are elderly or poor. The agency's chief actuary, Roland E. King, and his staff have decades of experience estimating health costs and population trends. On Capitol Hill, they are respected for independence, integrity and accuracy. But some economists at other agencies still favor lower estimates.
Hillary Rodham Clinton, the head of the task force, said in an interview last week that it was "very difficult" to get Government agencies to agree on cost estimates or even on procedures for estimating. To some extent, the disagreements involve technical issues. But they could have a big political effect on members of Congress, who will be asked to help finance Mr. Clinton's plan with new taxes.
 
Clash Between Agencies
 Work papers from the task force show disagreements between two agencies in particular. The Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, a unit of the United States Public Health Service, offered lower estimates for "insuring the uninsured": $42.6 billion to $49.3 billion a year from all sources, or roughly 60 percent of the cost computed by financial experts from the Health Care Financing Administration.
The lower estimates assume that uninsured people are generally healthy, like insured workers. The higher estimates assume that substantial numbers of the uninsured will be heavy users of health care, like Medicaid recipients.
Mr. Clinton has said for more than a year that he wants to require employers to provide or arrange health insurance coverage for their workers. He has said his plan will provide "the security of guaranteed access to comprehensive health care" for all Americans.
White House officials say it will reduce administrative costs, curb inflation in the health-care industry and save money in the long run. But significant savings are not expected for five or 10 years, and Mr. Clinton wants to take immediate action to provide coverage for the 37 million people who lack health insurance.
 
'A Conceptual Exercise'
 Kenneth E. Thorpe, the Federal official in charge of cost estimates for the task force, said the work papers were prepared as part of "a conceptual exercise" to help Mr. Clinton understand the cost of various options proposed by his health-policy advisers.
Work papers from the task force show these costs for other elements of the President's plan but do not specify how these costs would be divided:
*Better coverage for families with meager health insurance could cost $12.5 billion to $38.3 billion a year, depending on the scope of benefits. In many families, the head of the household has coverage from an employer, but his or her dependents have no insurance.
*Coverage of prescription drugs for Medicare beneficiaries would cost $8 billion to $10.3 billion a year.
*Coverage of long-term care, in the form contemplated by the White House, might cost $7.7 billion to $15 billion a year.
*Upgrading care for poor people, homeless people, migrant farm workers and others who are "medically underserved" would cost $1.8 billion to $4.8 billion a year.
Mr. Clinton has already asked Congress for a tax increase of more than $270 billion over five years. That money is to reduce the Federal budget deficit, not to pay for his health-care plan, which will require large amounts of revenue beyond those already requested.
 
Looking Beyond Politics
 In a speech last week, Mr. Magaziner seemed to minimize the political difficulty of getting Congress to raise taxes.
"Often," he said, "our friends in the media focus their whole attention on health-care reform as if what specific piece of money might have to be raised next year to help us insure the uninsured is the most important thing in health care.
"We know better. We know that what is really going to matter to the American people five years from now, 10 years from now, is not what amount of money was raised initially to get over the hump of getting the uninsured insured. What's really going to matter is what happens when I go to my doctor. What happens when I get ill? How does my insurance coverage look? Does it really protect me or not?"
Businesses, households and Government are listed in the documents as the main sources of money for Mr. Clinton's plan. If the Federal Government pays less, businesses and households pay more.
 
The Cost toof Employers
 Thus, under one set of assumptions used by the White House, American businesses would pay $168 billion a year in health insurance premiums for employees under current law. Many small businesses do not now provide health coverage, but if the Government required all employers to provide a low-cost set of health benefits, spending by employers would rise by $59 billion, to a total of $227 billion a year, the work papers say.
If the Government required employers to provide a generous set of health benefits to their workers, the employers' cost might rise by $87 billion, to $255 billion a year, the documents say.
At the heart of Mr. Clinton's plan is a proposal to guarantee a uniform set of health benefits for all Americans. All three packages would help pay for hospital and doctors' services, X-rays and laboratory tests, prescription drugs and some mental health services. Dental care would be covered under two of the three plans.
The austere plan, as conceived by the Administration, would provide more extensive coverage than 20 percent of private health insurance plans now in force. The generous plan would provide more protection than 90 percent of the existing private plans. The medium-cost proposal would provide more coverage than half the plans now in effect. Under Mr. Clinton's proposal, private health insurance would continue, but the Government would regulate the industry to guarantee that all Americans had access to a minimum set of benefits.
In public comments over the last three months, Administration officials have often discussed their desire to guarantee comprehensive health benefits. But they have generally refused to discuss the cost or the tax increases needed to finance it, and they have emphasized potential savings rather than new costs for employers or employees.
When asked for an estimate of cost, Robert O. Boorstin, a spokesman for the task force, said, "I'm not going to talk about that one."
Mr. Magaziner said: "There will be significant savings in what we propose. The difficulty is that those savings mostly begin to come in a five- to 10-year time frame. If you want to move quickly to expand coverage, you've got to spend money before that. So there is a timing issue here."

Final decisions have not been made. (Source: White House, Task Force on National Health Care Reform.)(pg. B8)
