HEADLINE: Balking at Clinton in Party Bedrock

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, May 2

 BODY:
They call their Congressman Jerry in the blue-collar Polish neighborhoods of South Milwaukee, where the Democratic Party still holds a place of importance in people's lives, along with close families, tidy lawns and attending church.
But as Representative Gerald D. Kleczka prepares to vote in the House Ways and Means Committee this month on the tax proposals in President Clinton's economic package, the message the Democratic lawmaker is hearing from his constituents goes against the grain of Administration policies. The predominant theme in his mail and town meetings, his staff members say, is that spending should be cut before taxes are increased. 
 At a town meeting on Saturday attended by 40 constituents in West Allis, an industrial suburb just west of Milwaukee, Mr. Kleczka was forced to parry a barrage of attacks on Government waste and Congressional privileges, as well as Mr. Clinton's plan to allow homosexuals in the military and his easing of restrictions on abortion.
 
Clamor Forces Critical Look
 Andrew Wolf, a 73-year-old retired welder, said: "You people in Congress don't want to listen. You're spending millions of dollars over a study to find out why truck drivers get tired."
Mr. Kleczka says he wants to support Mr. Clinton as much as possible, but the clamor from home is forcing him to take a critical look at some important elements of the President's legislative program. He has already declared his opposition to the free trade agreement with Mexico, and he promises to oppose Mr. Clinton's requests to finance the space station and superconducting supercollider.
The Ways and Means Committee begins drafting Mr. Clinton's tax plan this week, and Mr. Kleczka says he will support the President's requests for new taxes on fuel and higher-income recipients of Social Security.
But he says he will oppose the Administration's proposal for an investment tax credit for business. And he says he is undecided on Administration requests to keep taxes on capital gains lower than proposed rate increase on wealthier individuals.
As a junior member of the tax-writing panel, Mr. Kleczka would not normally be considered a force. But with the committee's chairman, Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, distracted by a Federal investigation of his finances, Mr. Kleczka and the 14 other new committee members have acquired great potential influence.
 
'Cut More Before We Spend'
 "We're going to try to see that President Clinton does well," Mr. Kleczka said. "But that doesn't mean I'm in lock step."
Mr. Kleczka's meeting on Saturday was punctuated by impassioned speeches and other dramatic demonstrations of strong political views. Some people distributed literature criticizing Government spending, with an outline of Mr. Kleczka's voting record on things like his support for the "giveaway" of money for foreign aid and his support for the "unconstitutional" financing of legal services for the poor.
"We need to cut more before we spend more," said Rudolf Pfister, a 59-year-old telephone installer. Expressing the prevailing mood against Washington, he added: "There are the lobbyists who wine you and dine you to sway your vote. Who do you think we are -- you think we are smoking marijuana down here?"
The drumbeat of middle-class anger and criticism was so fierce that one middle-aged man rose to tell those at the meeting, "Maybe you all should run for Congress."
"No," responded Mr. Kleczka, as he lifted up his pen to show he was taking notes. "I'm writing fast."
 
Pledges to Use Sharp Knife
 The 49-year-old Representative explained that his work on the Ways and Means Committee was separate from the process by which Congress approves spending. He pledged to take out a sharp knife when spending bills came to the House floor later this year.
The mood in West Allis, a community hit hard by high real estate taxes and factory closings, reflects some of the troubles Mr. Clinton faces as he attempts to marshal the public behind his policies. It is also the kind of district of tradition-minded conservative Democrats that will be a battleground should Mr. Clinton seek re-election.
Mr. Clinton only narrowly defeated President George Bush in West Allis in November. Many people did not like Mr. Clinton's pro-choice views on abortion.
Mr. Kleczka has managed to remain popular here, because of his strong constituent services and his down-home style. His popularity has allowed him to resist the opinions of many of his constituents who oppose the national Democratic Party's social agenda.
Judy Clark, a 47-year-old housewife, urged Mr. Kleczka to oppose Mr. Clinton's plan to allow homosexuals in the military. "Homosexuality is not a civil rights issue," she said. "It comes down to values and morals and beliefs."
But Mr. Kleczka responded: "I don't think any group in the society should be faced with discrimination. As far as gays in the military, I support the President's action."
The Congressman urged greater tolerance, and to break the tension, he pointed to an elderly woman and asked if she could be certain the woman sitting beside her was not a lesbian. "I can, because she's my sister," the woman snapped back.
Everyone, including Mr. Kleczka, had a good laugh.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Making Welfare Work By an Emphasis on Jobs

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
MORE people now receive welfare than attend public school in New York City.
Graduation rates for both groups are alarmingly low. The ranks of welfare recipients are swollen by the school system's failures. But few candidates in tomorrow's school board elections, while sermonizing about ancillary issues in a stampede to claim the moral high ground, draw a parallel between one group and the other. And some defenders of the poor argue that further education may not always be as good an antidote to welfare as work. 
 Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, in the preface to a forthcoming report by the New York State Business Council's Public Policy Institute, warns that tolerating a range of behavior from pre-teen pregnancy to bureaucratic hobbling of his Family Support Act amounts to "collective madness."
So too, critics insist, is merely preaching abstinence while withholding sex education and condoms from youngsters.
Mr. Moynihan's outrage forms the preamble to a largely non-ideological analysis of New York's efforts so far to transform eligible welfare recipients into productive workers. The critical study, by David Shaffer of the Public Policy Institute, the Business Council's research arm, is to be released later this month.
It suggests that while the recession has impeded the goals of Mr. Moynihan's Family Support Act, the state has been slow to expand its most successful programs and to embrace the evidence of what works: a wide range of job preparation and search programs and education and training as vital elements of job preparation rather than as a goal to be pursued to the exclusion of employment.
Under Mr. Schaffer's vision, the elderly, disabled, children and others unable to work would still receive regular grants. Others would join an employment security system that would provide a training stipend while preparing people for work, pay for a public works job, and offer parental leave benefits for single parents with young children -- modeled, in part, on New York's Working Toward Independence Program and on America Works, a private company that gets paid by local government only when it produces results.
A recent study by the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation found measurable progress in California's jobs program, which requires schooling for welfare recipients without a high school diploma or the equivalent or are not proficient in English and cannot find a job within a few weeks.
"Making welfare-without-work somewhat less attractive and less common is one necessary way of attacking the problem," Mr. Schaffer writes (adding, though, that when a punitive approach has been tried "workfare has indeed been a disaster"). "But it is also important to try to make work, even in entry-level jobs, more attractive."
He figures that a mother of two on welfare in New York City receives a $2,856 basic grant, $636 in home energy payments, a $3,432 housing allowance, $2,784 in food stamps for a total of $9,708 annually, or 80 percent of the poverty level. If the mother had a minimum-wage job, she would make $8,829 in salary, $2,880 in food stamps, $3,360 in public assistance, a $1,200 earned-income credit and would pay $4,200 ($175 a month per child) for day care, $2,500 ($50 a week) in work-related expenses and $678 in Social Security taxes for net income of $8,891. Working for $8.50 an hour -- twice the minimum wage -- would disqualify the mother for public assistance and for Medicaid after one year, which would reduce her net income to under $9,000.
Mr. Schaffer rejects calls from conservatives to lower benefits and from liberals to raise the minimum wage. Rather, he suggests a state earned-income tax credit or letting working welfare recipients keep more of their wages before the basic grant is reduced.
The caveats: training, education and public works employment can be costly; many welfare recipients are ineligible for jobs because of age or dysfunction. Still, some programs seem to work. Tried together, they may tip the ratio between the number of New Yorkers in school and on welfare and improve graduation rates among both groups.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

A NEW ATTITUDE ON SMALL BUSINESS
After decades of counting on big business and local government to create jobs, New York City must now look mainly to small companies to rebuild its decimated jobs base and thus must make it easier for them to operate, political leaders, economists and urban planners say. This represents a new attitude toward small businesses, which for years have lacked the clout to pressure City Hall for the financial incentives granted to large corporations that threatened to leave the city. A1.
 
SEX SHOPS TEST NEIGHBORHOOD TOLERANCE
New York City has long held a reputation as one of America's most permissive cities, especially on issues that touch on First Amendment protections of free speech and expression. But the striking proliferation of sex video stores, topless bars and nude dance clubs in neighborhoods where they have rarely ventured before -- from Chelsea to Marine Park in Brooklyn, from the Upper East Side of Manhattan to Forest Hills in Queens -- is now straining that tolerance. B3.
 

POLICE PONDER ACTION ON ILLEGAL DRIVERS
The New York City Police Department said that it is considering new procedures to crack down on unlicensed drivers in the wake of three car accidents in the last three weeks that killed three pedestrians in Brooklyn, all children, and injured several others. Yesterday, a 90-year-old woman was killed in Brooklyn by a car driven by a man who the police said was intoxicated. Unlike in the other recent fatalities, the driver charged in the crash did not have any license suspensions, the police said. B3.
 
TAKING THE SCHOOL BATTLE TO THE VOTER
The battle for control of New York City's 32 school boards moved to churches, streets and parks, as opponents made a final push in a heated election that some combatants hope will chart the ideological future of education in the city. Congregants at St. Patrick's Cathedral picked up voter guides produced by Pat Robertson's conservative Christian Coalition. In Central Park, volunteers for the Gay Men's Health Crisis passed out another voter guide. And the Rev. Al Sharpton took to the pulpit of the Mount Ollie Baptist Church in Ocean Hill-Brownsville to denounce what he called meddling in local issues by right-wing religious groups. B5.
 
BIAS SUSPECTED IN ATTACK IN BROOKLYN
A 16-year-old youth told the police that he was attacked with fists and walkie-talkies and that eight of his friends were roughed up on a Brooklyn street by 20 to 30 men in Hasidic garb who said his "kind" was not wanted in their neighborhood. The police said they were investigating it as a possible bias incident. B2.
 
REGION
 
LOBBYING FORMS TRIAL BACKDROP
The trial of Armand D'Amato, who is charged with 24 counts of mail fraud in connection with filing false paper work for $120,500 he received from Sperry Corporation and its successor, Unisys, opens a window on the world of lobbying. B6.
 
ODDS ON CASINO BILL HARD TO FIGURE
For all the public-relations thundering about jobs and the endlessly repeated television and radio advertisements by Mirage Resorts of Las Vegas, the final outcome of Connecticut's casino gambling debate remains a crapshoot, and people like Gary D. Le Beau are the reason. For the last nine months Mr. Le Beau, a Democratic State Representative from East Hartford, supported the casino plan. But with the first floor votes only a few weeks away, he has turned, scared by the power and money of the gambling promoters who he now thinks could end up running the state if they get approval to build the casinos they want in Bridgeport and Hartford. B6.
 
THE FLEAS THAT SAVED MAIN STREET
Something happens in Chester, N.J., on weekends. No one is sure when it started, exactly. But every Saturday morning, throngs of tourists pour into this pastoral Morris County borough as if the carnival were in town, hanging out all day and staying for dinner. And even more show up on Sunday, when Main Street might as well be Disney World. Most residents say that what started the phenomenon was the flea market. B6.

HEADLINE: Black Muslims Enter Islamic Mainstream

SERIES: Muslims in America -- Second of four articles.

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
Every Friday afternoon, hundreds of black men, women and children stop work or school for a couple of hours and hurry to a 15,000-square-foot building on the edge of town.
They represent the rainbow of black America: suburban and urban; professional and poor; deep brown and light tan. They pull up in faded station wagons and gleaming Mercedes Benzes. Inside, the men sit in the front; the women in the back. Many used to be Baptists, African Methodist or Roman Catholic. 
 Now they are Muslim.
They gathered here, at least 600 strong, on a recent afternoon at their mosque, the Atlanta Masjid al-Islam. It was time for the prayer known as juma, as it is every Friday around the Islamic world, including dozens of neighborhoods in the United States.
After the service, they rushed back to their offices or classrooms, back to the bustle of mainstream America in which so many black American Muslims place themselves, in sharp contrast to the old days of the "Black Muslims" and the racial separatism of the once-dominant Nation of Islam.
"We make a conscious effort to be open and involved in all aspects of American society," said Plemon Tauheed El-Amin, an imam, or leader, in Atlanta who was educated at Harvard University.
Like many other black American Muslims, Mr. El-Amin was once a member of the Nation of Islam but later embraced a more conventional Islam, which rejects the Nation's racial theories. "We don't make distinctions based on color or race," he said. "No longer are we an isolated community, happy to keep to ourselves."
No one knows exactly how many black American Muslims there are but estimates range from 500,000 to 1.5 million. They are police officers in Newark, soldiers in Germany, college professors in Chicago and the Mayor of Kountze, Tex., where there are only two Muslim families and where 70 percent of the 2,700 residents are white.
They have opened hundreds of mosques, from sparkling modern buildings to weather-beaten houses. They run dozens of schools that teach Islamic culture along with advanced algebra and American history.
And even though they are only a small fraction of the 30 million blacks in the United States, their influence among non-Muslims is real and visible. The Muslim greeting, "as-salaam alaikum," or peace be with you, echoes through some inner-city neighborhoods almost as frequently as "Good morning." For Muslims the skull cap called a kufi is a symbol of humility; for non-Muslims it increasingly conveys style. Muslim chaplains are on the staffs of many prisons, where conversions are common. And more and more, tenants in troubled housing projects call on Muslims to patrol their streets and face down drug dealers.
The 2,000 members of the Atlanta masjid, or mosque, one of the largest and most active black American Muslim communities, can loosely be called orthodox Sunni Muslims, as are the majority of the world's Muslims. But by no means are black American Muslims monolithic in Atlanta or elsewhere. In this city alone, there are at least three distinct communities.
 
17 or 18 Variations
 As many as 17 or 18 significant subgroups of black American Muslims are scattered across the country, mostly in or around inner cities, with as many leaders. The majority are generally aligned with mainstream Islam, but some are theological splinter groups, like the Moorish Science Temple, the Five Percenters and at least three versions of the Nation of Islam, said Aminah McCloud, herself a Muslim and a professor of Islamic Studies at DePaul University in Chicago.
Most of the three million to four million Muslims in this country are immigrants. Black Americans account for most of the country's native-born Muslims. In the past, ties between immigrant groups and black American ones were minimal, but some on both sides are now working to build links.
Some converts say they are Muslim first and black second. Others say the opposite. Some love America, others shun it.
The reasons black Americans have turned to Islam are varied. For some it is a cultural statement, a recognition of spiritual ties to Africa, where Islam spread from Arabia centuries ago.
The emphasis on discipline and conservative values may attract people who live among too much crime and social disorder. And in the face of white racism, some are also drawn to Islam by its reputation for assertiveness. "Young black people see Islam as more of a fighting religion, whereas Christianity is seen as a kind of passive, turn-the-other-cheek religion," said Conrad Worrill, who heads the Inner City Studies program of Northeastern Illinois University.
Generally, black American Muslims, like most Muslims around the world, oppose abortion. And in keeping with Islamic principles they frown on premarital sex, short skirts and spoiled children. They forbid gambling, eating pork and drinking alcohol.
Like the Roman Catholic Church, Islam does not typically allow women to ascend to the highest level of the religion: the imam or prayer leader. Besides being separated from the men when they pray in the mosques, women often wrap their hair in scarves to protect their modesty.
 
'The Change'
Move to Join The Mainstream
 The members of the Atlanta masjid are part of a large group of black American Muslims in the United States that have joined mainstream Islam. Although they have their own local imams like Mr. El-Amin and 51-year-old Ibrahim Pasha, a Muslim since the age of 4, nationally they follow the spiritual guidance of Warith Deen Mohammed, the son of Elijah Muhammad, who led the Nation of Islam for 40 years until his death in 1975.
In a remarkable and traumatic transition, since his father's death, Mr. Mohammed has guided most of his father's followers away from racial separatism and firmly into the embrace of moderate Sunni Islam. This continuing effort is known among black Americans as "the change."
Mr. Mohammed is believed to have 100,000 to 250,000 followers. By contrast, the biggest Nation of Islam group, led by Louis Farrakhan, which for the most part is carrying on the teaching of Elijah Muhammad, has about 20,000 followers.
But even after all these years, Mr. Mohammed still thinks he must spend considerable time reminding his followers of the change. "Too many people are holding on to the old ways," he said in an interview.
Every Tuesday, he flies to Chicago from his home in Little Rock, Ark., to tape his weekly television show about the Muslim world and to give lessons on Islamic vocabulary and culture because "so many of us have recently converted to Islam and are not aware of Muslim expressions."
In a recent taping, as he smiled into the camera like an experienced late-night talk show host, he said he wanted his audience to remember the change and to understand that Islam "is a religion for all people."
In many ways Mr. Mohammed has become part of the religious establishment. Last year, he became the first imam ever to give the invocation before the United States Senate. In the 1980's, he voted Republican in Presidential elections because of his own anti-welfare beliefs, and last year he backed President George Bush over Bill Clinton.
Mr. Mohammed's followers "always listen to him, but they don't always follow his politics," said Lawrence H. Mamiya, a professor of religion at Vassar College.
During the war in the Persian Gulf, Mr. Mohammed was a strong supporter of Saudi Arabia and the United States, not a universally popular position among Muslims. "The imam's stance is always pro-America," said Nevorn K. Askari, a 37-year-old pediatrician and a member of the Atlanta masjid. "I don't feel that way."
But Mr. Mohammed's relationship with the Saudis was strong long before the first bomb dropped in the gulf. The Saudis have donated most of the $8.5 million to build a mosque for Mr. Mohammed's followers in South-Central Los Angeles and are committed to building at least five others across the country.
Mr. Mohammed says he supports the Palestinian struggle for "a home and a right to self-determination" but he does not condone "terrorism or attacks on innocent people on behalf of that cause," said the imam's special assistant, Abdul Malik Mohammed. But so far that support has been no more than verbal, and Mr. Mohammed's publications do not display the obsessively anti-Jewish attitudes of the Nation of Islam.
The relationship between black American Muslims and immigrant Muslims has been improving, but there are still ethnic and cultural differences, the assistant said. "Immigrant Muslims were seeing African-Americans the way the media portrayed African-Americans, as lazy and criminal. And the African-American Muslims were seeing the immigrants as the media portrayed third world people, as lazy and criminal," he said.
Imam Mohammed's efforts to pull his followers into the Islamic mainstream have indeed broken some barriers between the groups, but there is still not much cooperation on political or social issues.
 
The Roots
An Antidote To Indignities
 The roots of Islam run deeply through the soul of black America, stretching back to at least the early years of the century and perhaps much farther. Islam had spread to West Africa by the 12th century, and historians believe that some slaves brought to the Americas were Muslim. The slaves were quickly converted to Christianity.
The first significant group of black Americans identifying with Islam in this century was the Moorish Science Temple founded in Newark in 1913. Several other groups followed, but it was Elijah Muhammad 20 years later who introduced Islam, at least a highly unorthodox version of it, to black Americans on a large scale.
His was a fiery blend of Islam, the Bible, black nationalism, racial chauvinism, military-style discipline and bootstrap economics, which his son said was probably the message dearest to his father's heart.
According to the Nation of Islam, whites were created by a mad scientist as a curse on the superior black race. The white man was the devil and the Nation wanted to be separate. It was the white man who flooded black neighborhoods with liquor and drugs and poverty. And it was the Christian church that told blacks to be patient and forgiving.
During its glory years of the 1950's and 1960's, the Nation of Islam dismayed many, scared some and saved others from a life of crime and drugs, including its most famous convert, Malcolm X, who left the Nation and moved toward mainstream Islam before his murder in 1965. For many members, the Nation was more than a religion. Setting up blacks as racially superior, it was an antidote to pervasive white racism.
Safiyyah Shahid, the daughter of a Baptist preacher in Atlanta and now the principal of the Atlanta masjid's elementary and high school, joined the Nation of Islam in 1968 for reasons that continue to resonate among many black people today, though she later made the change.
"I joined the Nation because I thought the Christian church represented more of a barrier to African-American progress," she said. "There was too much talk of waiting for the by and by, too many pictures of a white Jesus. I liked what the Nation was saying about do-for-self, that the black man had a lot of dignity, that we had been written out of the history books."
 
The Groups
Large Branches And Offshoots
 At least three groups claim to be the Nation of Islam today: a small band in Detroit; another with headquarters in Atlanta, and the biggest and best-known, with temples in most large cities, led by Mr. Farrakhan from Chicago.
His is one of the fastest growing of all the movements, Professor Mamiya said, adding, "When he talks out about racism in American society, he strikes a responsive cord, especially among the young."
Mr. Farrakhan, who declined requests for an interview, began his Nation of Islam in 1978 after disagreeing with Mr. Mohammed's plans to move toward mainstream Islam. For a few years, Mr. Farrakhan had about 1,000 members. Today, he has more than 20,000.
Whether Mr. Farrakhan and his Nation of Islam are true Muslims is the source of much debate within the American Muslim community. In traditional Islam there is no talk of separation of people based on race. Mr. Farrakhan has also made comments about Jews that are widely regarded as anti-Semitic, and his group publishes literature regarded as anti-Semitic. Recently, Mr. Farrakhan has been toning down the Nation's racial message, Professor Mamiya said.
Even more unsettling to many Muslims, however, is the Nation's belief that Allah appeared in Detroit in 1930 in the person of W. Fard Muhammad, the founder of the Nation of Islam, who passed his message and work on to Elijah Muhammad before he disappeared in 1934. Orthodox Islam says that there is only one God and that the Prophet Muhammad was his last messenger.
Still, many black Muslims are reluctant to criticize Mr. Farrakhan or other splinter groups too harshly. Mr. Mohammed, eager to avoid bad feelings, said of the Nation: "I have to accept it as a Muslim community. We see it as one in transition, moving much slower than we did."
The two men do not often see each other and they have very different styles. Mr. Farrakhan travels with bodyguards and keeps a tight grip on his Nation. He lives in Elijah Muhammad's Chicago mansion, known on the streets as "the Palace."
Mr. Mohammed usually travels alone, carrying his own bag. He does not have or want, he says, any direct control over his followers. "I'm not against leadership," he said. "I'm against dictators."
The two men did meet recently in Harlem at the funeral of a highly respected black American imam, Yusuf Shah, who bridged both worlds. As dozens watched, Imam Mohammed and Minister Farrakhan embraced.
"Although there are smaller groups, there are actually two African-American Muslim leaders: Farrakhan and myself," Mr. Mohammed said in an interview before the funeral. "He's the leader of those who hold on to the old ideas. I'm the leader of the change."
But Islam in America is sprouting many leaders and variations in tradition.
In a rough pocket of Atlanta called the West End, Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin, known in the 1960's as H. Rap Brown, the fiery civil rights leader and Black Panther, is the spiritual leader for hundreds of families here and in 30 other cities, including Chicago, New York and Detroit.
Dozens of his followers have bought houses near the group's mosque, a one-story building overlooking a basketball court where Imam Al-Amin and his followers play ball and talk religion with neighbors.
"We make them believers right here," Imam Al-Amin said as some men shot baskets. "We play the best ball around."
Imam Al-Amin interprets the Koran strictly, and rejects much of Western civilization. "When you take a sense of the creator out of anything, like prayer in school, you produce serial killers, rapists, abortionists, the dregs of mankind," he said.
The imam and his followers strive to distinguish themselves as Muslims and to maintain their spiritual distance from the larger society, which they see as being almost hopelessly corrupt. The men wear beards, robe-length shirts and kufi caps. The women wear long dresses and scarves.
At night, they patrol their neighborhood, chasing drug dealers and other criminals. They make and sell incense from one of their of small stores, whose windows are filled with sports trophies the members have won.
"The Prophet didn't pray all day and he didn't play all day," Imam Al-Amin said. "He had a balance. That's something else we're striving for."
 
Beliefs
Model Community Is Being Built
 A few miles away, the solemn call to prayer washes over the parking lot of the Atlanta masjid. Depending on the wind, the sound can travel a quarter of a mile or more. It is broadcast over loudspeakers five times a day, beginning at daybreak.
"We've had a few complaints about it, especially in the morning," Mr. El-Amin said in an interview in his office at the mosque.
Like Muslims everywhere, the members of the Atlanta masjid try to pray at the five prescribed times a day, either at the mosque or wherever they happen to be.
"We're trying to build a model community," the imam said. "It's hard to do in America with a liquor store on every corner. We're not forcing our religion on people. We're just trying to show them there's another way."
To spread the word, they send teams onto college campuses, into the malls and through the public-housing project across the street. Monthly, a group from the mosque has "a dialogue, not a debate," with a group of Christians from a nearby church.
The mosque also operates a 300-student school, through 12th grade, open to non-Muslims, and the students do their part to show "that Muslims aren't a bunch of terrorists," said the imam's 17-year-old daughter, Fatima, who has been accepted by Harvard University and Smith College, from where her mother, Sandra, graduated.
Most of the students' parents are blue-collar workers, but others own their own businesses. The group also owns the small shopping center where its mosque is and leases space to Muslims and non-Muslims, including a Korean family that sells beer and pork, which are forbidden to Muslims.
When the faithful arrive at the mosque, everybody takes off their shoes and sits on the floor, which is covered by a green carpet. The men and boys go to the front of the large room, the women and girls to the back.
Mr. El-Amin said the men and women were separated for modesty's sake. The imam said there were obvious differences between the sexes that must be maintained. "We don't want to destroy the natural identities, especially the role of the woman as mother," he said. "We're turning away from the natural roles of men and women, and we're producing monsters."
Mr. Mohammed, the national leader, said he was trying to encourage his followers around the country to advance women in the church. "It's a problem we'll have to deal with," he said. "The Catholic Church has the same problem."
In this respect, perhaps, Louis Farrakhan's Nation of Islam may be ahead of other Muslim groups. His branch has at least five female ministers, Dr. Mamiya said.
Dr. Askari, the Atlanta pediatrician, and Mrs. Shahid, the principal, said they did not feel discriminated against as Muslim women. Instead, they said, they felt protected and respected by the brothers.
At 16, Jamillah Karim, a senior at the W. Deen Mohammed High School a few blocks from the Atlanta masjid, said she sometimes thought her male classmates had it easier than the girls, not at school, but in life.
The girls stand out more after school because they wear long blue skirts and white scarves as part of their uniforms. The boys wear blue pants and white shirts. They can blend in at the mall or on the corner.
"You think you'd be more attractive to the opposite sex if you dressed more like everybody else," she said. "Watching music videos you wonder how'd you look in those clothes. You always think you're missing out.
"I like being a Muslim. But sometimes it's hard. New friends assume we don't watch TV, go to parties, the movies, nothing fun. It's almost like they don't look at us as normal teen-agers. Then when they get to know us, they're surprised. We're normal people. The only difference is, we're Muslims."
Next: An immigrant Muslim community comes of age.
 
 
 
NAMES BIND CONVERTS TO THE FAITH
 In keeping with Islamic tradition, most American converts take Muslim names as a sign of their faith, often changing their names legally. The names, usually Arabic, bind the living to great figures or concepts from the Islamic past, providing inspiration for daily life.
Common is Muhammed or Mohammed, for the Prophet himself. Other historical names are Ali, for a nephew of Muhammed who played a crucial role in the faith's early history, Hasan and Hussein for grandsons of Muhammed, Khadijah and Zainab for wives of Muhammed and Fatimah for a daughter.
Ali was also a great Islamic general. Hence the name Muhammed Ali -- selected for the boxer by Elijah Muhammad, late leader of the Nation of Islam -- evokes a powerful combination.
Many names include the Arabic word for one of the 99 attributes of Allah, the creator, in the Koran. One attribute is rahman, meaning "gracious" or "beneficent." No one could have the trait as fully as Allah does, so the word Abdul, meaning "servant of," is added, and Abdul Rahman means "servant of the most gracious."
Karim, meaning "generous," is another of the 99 attributes, and Jabbar means "the compeller" or "mighty one." Hence the basketball star's name means "generous servant of the compeller."
Most often, people pick their own names. "You look for good qualities you will try to represent in your life," said Dr. Abd'allah Adesanya, assistant imam of a mosque in Brooklyn. Dr. Adesanya combined Arabic and African influences in choosing his name. His first name is Arabic for "servant of Allah," while his surname is from the Yoruba language of West Africa and means "the crown repays suffering."

HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal;
They Eat Whales, Don't They? A Fight Resumes

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 29

 BODY:
As he surveyed his restaurant one recent pre-holiday evening, Kiyoo Tanahashi was proud that almost all the wooden chairs and tatami mats were occupied by office workers or college students partaking of the house specialties -- whale steak, whale bacon, fried whale, smoked whale, raw whale and whale soup containing slivers of whale tongue.
But Mr. Tanahashi, who dishes out the equivalent of two whales a year, turns sour when he thinks of the ban on commercial whaling that is making restaurants like his Kujiraya, which means whale store, an endangered species. "I am rather angry that outside countries would tell us what food we should or should not eat," he said. 
 The freedom to eat what one chooses has become a rallying cry among whaling supporters on the eve of a crucial meeting of the International Whaling Commission, the 39-nation group that regulates whaling.
The annual meeting, which will be held in Kyoto from May 10 to May 14, comes when the moratorium on commercial whaling that has been in effect since 1986 shows signs of cracking.
Iceland has withdrawn from the commission, though it has not started whaling, and Norway announced last year that it would resume whaling, although it will remain a member of the commission. Now Japan, with the meeting on its home turf, will push -- against long odds -- to have the ban lifted.
 
The Opposing Arguments
 Japan and Norway argue that the moratorium, initially put in place to revive stocks that had been depleted by decades of excessive whaling, is no longer needed for certain types of whales. The whaling commission's scientific committee has estimated that there are 760,000 minkes, a relatively small whale, in the Southern Hemisphere. Japan says that catching 2,000 a year would have no effect on the population.
Those opposed to whaling say that whales in general are still in such a precarious state that even the minke whales should continue to be protected.
But now the issue is becoming whether whales, which many people consider majestic creatures with high intelligence, should be hunted at all, even if their numbers permit.
Some countries, including Australia and New Zealand, already have said whaling should never resume and the United States is also strongly in the antiwhaling camp. France has proposed that the entire Antarctic region south of 40 degrees latitude be made into a whale sanctuary. The idea, supported by the United States, will be a major item on the agenda in Kyoto.
"If we were using whale meat to offset the hunger of the third world it might be permitted," said Dr. Michael F. Tillman, acting assistant administrator for fisheries at the United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the leader of the American delegation to the Kyoto conference. "But that's not what's happening. It's going to the most expensive restaurants in the largest cities in the world."
Japanese officials argue that the idea of a whale sanctuary represents the imposition of one nation's morals on another and is, in a sense, a form of Japan-bashing. Why, they ask, should Western nations be allowed to kill cows and pigs and Japan not allowed to kill whales.
"We should not make a new religion of whale-ism," said Kazuo Shima, Japan's commissioner on the whaling body and deputy director general of the Government's Fisheries Agency. "We believe science and we believe scientists. We should not permit religious arguments in this field."
Japanese officials say they want to take a stand to insure that other species, like dolphins and different types of trees, also do not come under protection for what they say are irrational reasons.
Last year, the International Whaling Commission approved a computerized formula for calculating the permissible yearly catches for some types of whales. But it said it would not allow any whaling to resume until it approves other necessary measures, like monitoring and inspecting whaling ships.
At this year's meeting, Japan and Norway will push for approval of such plans, thereby clearing the way for whaling to begin. But it is considered unlikely that the commission will complete the work this year, especially since countries opposed to whaling will delay the process as much as possible.
"The longer this thing drags out the more people in Japan will forget about eating whale meat," said an official of an American environmental group.
Norway has said it will resume whaling this summer, even if the commission does not allow it.
Japan, however, is not expected to take such a bold move or to withdraw from the whaling commission. Despite its tough words now, it is unlikely the nation would risk the enmity of the United States and many European nations for the sake of a whaling industry that, in terms of Japan's overall economy, is insignificant.
The nation has been trying to years to reverse a poor environmental image that stems from its history of industrial pollution and its reluctance to cease trading in whales and other endangered species like tortoises. Even though it has stopped commercial whaling, Japan continues to catch about 300 whales a year for research purposes, with the meat ending up at restaurants and food stores.
Japan now has only four boats with 28 crew members active in catching a few types of small whales that are not protected, according to the Fisheries Agency.
"The industry's gone," said Kunio Yonezawa, an adviser to the Japanese Government on the whaling issue. "We are fighting for a cause, not for economic interests. We have to insure the principle of rational use of ocean resources."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Uneasy Days for the Bond Market

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
This week could be bumpy for the bond market.
The beginning of every month brings the Labor Department employment report and the traumas that come with waiting for its release on Friday. But coming just after last week's report on the economy's weak performance in the first quarter, the jobs report could be more jolting than usual. It will be scrutinized to see if the slow trend in economic growth is continuing or was just weather related. 
 Possibly even more disturbing -- though of much less importance in an economic sense -- will be the Treasury's announcement on Wednesday of its plans for the quarterly auction this month and the related release of a report on how the Treasury can reduce its borrowing costs. That report is expected to be released Wednesday or earlier.
Speculation about what the report will say about the future of the 30-year bond auction has added to the market's recent volatility. The market seemed to signal this concern Friday as the price of the 30-year bond dropped 19/32 and the yield jumped to 6.92 percent, its highest level in a month.
Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J., said uncertainty about the Treasury's plans had put a lid on trading recently. "There is a reluctance to take any more risk than necessary now," Mr. McCarthy said.
The concern centers on the size of the 30-year bond auction. The Treasury has already cut the quarterly sale from $12 billion in November 1991 to $9.25 billion this February, a reduction of 23 percent. But the Clinton Administration's deficit-reduction plan is assuming $16 billion in savings over five years from cutting the costs of Government borrowing. One obvious path to savings is to shift borrowing from higher-interest-rate, long-term borrowing to shorter-term, lower-interest-rate maturities.
Many analysts and traders are philosophically opposed to any major changes in the Treasury's borrowing mix because they prefer predictability, which means fewer surprises that can provoke losses. Still, the prospect of a smaller auction of 30-year bonds had helped send prices higher because it would mean less supply to meet the same demand.
 
Smaller Cut Is Expected
 As the announcement approaches, market opinion seems to have changed about the size of the possible cut in the 30-year auction. Earlier expectations were for a big cut -- including a move from four to two auctions a year. Now, a less significant shift is anticipated -- an opinion that seems to fit with the promises of Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen that there would be no radical change. But he has never defined what radical means.
Mr. McCarthy is looking for a cut in the 30-year bond auction of $750 million, to $8.5 billion; a $250 million cut in the 10-year auction, to $10.5 billion, and an increase of $500 million in the three-year auction, to $16 billion.
After the selloff in the market on Friday, it did not appear that such a small change would weaken the price of the 30-year bond any further. In fact, the most significant outcome of the Treasury announcement would be the removal of the uncertainty. Of course, a bigger reduction would now be a surprise and would be expected to push bond prices higher.
As for the employment report, forecasters expect the data to show that the economy is growing faster than the 1.8 percent annual pace of the first quarter but no faster than the 3 percent annual pace in many predictions. The consensus estimate for the increase in nonfarm payroll jobs is around 175,000, which is a little higher than the average monthly increase for the first quarter of 153,000.
With such a report, the outlook for the market would be neutral. Assuming no surprises from the Treasury on the 30-year bond, there is nothing right now to drive market yields on the bond out of a trading range that runs from a low of 6.72 percent to a high of around 7 percent.
April retail sales, which are to be released on May 13, might have that potential. If they show a strong rebound from the 1 percent decline in March, there will be more proof that the consumer, who stayed at home in the first quarter, is coming back. That could worry those who are hoping that slow growth would pull yields lower.
On the other hand, the April inflation reports which come on May 12 and May 13 could lay the groundwork for higher prices and lower yields if the data are in line with the surprisingly small jumps for March.
The current market forecast is summed up by Glenn Murphy, chief investment officer at Travelers Asset Management International in Hartford, who said, "The bull market is over, but the bear market is not around the corner."

HEADLINE: Mandated Insurance Faces Fight

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
Small businesses are making an emotional 11th-hour appeal to head off the Clinton Administration's plans to require all companies to pay for health insurance for their workers -- a mandate that critics say could bankrupt thousands of companies and cause large-scale layoffs.
Small business is squaring off not only against President Clinton, who needs employers to help finance the huge cost of extending coverage to uninsured Americans, but also large companies, which already provide health coverage and say small companies are not doing their share. 
 The resistance of small businesses could be the political Achilles' heel of the President's health plan. If small business blocks the requirement, the President will have a devilish time groping for other ways to pay for his ambitious health-care changes.
 
 
Fever Pitch
 With the Clinton Administration expected to produce its health-care proposal in May, to be followed by months of Congressional debate, lobbying on the issue has reached a fever pitch.
The debate has pitted an array of small-business organizations, like the National Federation of Independent Business, the National Restaurant Association and the National Retail Federation -- all of whom say many of their members cannot afford to provide health benefits -- against the United States Chamber of Commerce and many of the nation's industrial giants.
Representatives of small business are gearing up for a strong attack once the Administration introduces its plan, but they are already pressing their views among members of Congress and to Hillary Rodham Clinton's health-care task force.
 
 
'Unbelievably Expensive'
 "There's a huge division here," Stephen Elmont, chairman of the National Restaurant Association, said. "For large companies, this is a non-issue, because they are already providing insurance, but for small business, it's a huge issue -- not because we don't want to do it, but because it's unbelievably expensive."
During the Presidential election campaign, Mr. Clinton said he intended to require employer contributions to health insurance, and he has given no sign of relenting, though subsidies may be proposed to soften the impact.
The Urban Institute estimates that it would cost American companies at least $30 billion more a year if the Government required them to cover employees working 18 hours or more a week. Otherwise, the Government may have to pick up the tab.
Documents from the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform say the Administration's plan could cost Government, businesses and households up to an additional $150 billion a year. The nation's businesses now pay $168 billion in health-care premiums a year; requiring all employers to pay for a low-cost set of health benefits -- including the upgrading of benefits in some cases to meet the Federal standard -- would cost them $59 billion more.
Of the 37 million Americans who now lack health insurance, 28.5 million are workers and their families.
To cushion the impact on small businesses, the President's health-care advisers are considering placing a ceiling on a business's health-care payments of 7 or 9 percent of its payroll. Under such a ceiling, small businesses would pay only a part of the insurance for minimum-wage employees, with the Federal Government paying the rest.
 
Government Subsidies
 Some small businesses can live with such a ceiling, but are pressing for it to be as low as possible. But many businesses oppose any requirement to provide coverage, arguing that workers can buy their own insurance, perhaps with the help of tax breaks or Government subsidies.
How, they ask, can a small retailer or restaurant owner who relies on minimum-wage workers afford thousands -- perhaps tens of thousands -- of dollars in health-care insurance each year?
In the view of large businesses, many small companies are trying to shirk their responsibilities. It is unfair, big business executives argue, that many small companies do not provide coverage because the rest of society ends up paying the medical bills for their workers -- with big businesses picking up much of the tab.
The Big Three auto makers and other large manufacturers are particularly galled that many small businesses routinely hire the spouses of workers at large manufacturing companies without providing health coverage, knowing the manufacturers will foot their health insurance bills by providing family coverage.
"As a nation in a global economy, we can no longer continue having our manufacturers carrying the health-insurance costs not only of their own workers, but of the workers' spouses who are employed elsewhere," said Walter Maher, director of Federal relations for the Chrysler Corporation.
He cited one estimate that all of this cost-shifting had socked American manufacturers with $11.5 billion a year in extra health-care costs. This represents a fourth of their health-care bills.
Mandated coverage would fall disproportionately on businesses with fewer than 50 employees, because so many of them do not provide coverage. About 10.5 million of their 40.2 million workers lack health insurance, according to the Employee Benefits Research Institute. By contrast, among businesses with more than 500 employees, only 5 million of the 54 million workers lack coverage.
Although big business appears to be carrying the day so far, small business is optimistic that it can persuade its friends in Congress to block any mandate requiring employer-paid health insurance. Some Republicans, especially conservatives in the House, are expected to pounce if the Administration proposes such a mandate.
"I think this will have a lot of trouble on the Hill," Mr. Elmont of the restaurant association, said. "Workers' compensation costs are already out of control. We pay through the teeth in payroll taxes. The Administration has just added a parental- leave requirement, and they're talking about raising the minimum wage. To say we're going to pull out the stops over health insurance is an understatement."
 
 
Scary Prospect
 For some small businesses, the prospect of mandated health coverage is downright scary. Typically, it costs small business $1,800 a year to cover an unmarried employee and $4,000 to $5,000 for a worker with dependents.
Jack Faris, president of the National Federation of Independent Business, gave the example of a business owner earning $35,000 with five employees who earn $15,000 each. "If the small-business owner has to pay $3,000 a year in health insurance for each one, that's $15,000," he said. "This lowers his earnings to $20,000, and it could mean he has to lay off workers or go out of business."
Worried that such a mandate would disproportionately hurt small business, some Administration officials are considering another financing option: a payroll tax on all employers.
Supporters of mandatory health coverage insist that requiring companies to provide insurance for all employees could ultimately lower health insurance costs. They argue that only when every employer provides coverage will the Administration be able to fully set up its managed competition plan to squeeze down health costs.
Under the Administration's plan, individuals and small businesses would pool their resources and buy health insurance coverage through cooperatives. These powerful cooperatives would be able to bargain for much lower rates than small businesses now receive.
"If small business got off its knee-jerk opposition to a mandate and analyzed these proposals, they'd say it is extremely fair to small business," said Henry E. Simmons, president of the National Leadership Coalition for Health Care Reform, which represents large corporations. "It would control their costs and enable them to do something most of them are already doing -- providing health coverage -- without having their health costs double every six years."
By some estimates, about 75 percent of businesses with fewer than 100 employees provide coverage; far more than 90 percent of those with more than 100 workers provide insurance.
Among the states, only Hawaii requires employers to provide health-care coverage, a mandate that took effect in 1974. Jack Lewin, the state's health director, says the system has helped to hold down health costs without imposing huge burdens on small business. Oregon is now phasing in such a requirement.
But illustrating the political difficulties of such mandates, a Massachusetts plan to require employer coverage in 1992 was delayed by the heated opposition of small business.
Supporters of mandated coverage acknowledge that it could impose a formidable burden on companies with many minimum-wage employees, who earn $4.25 an hour, or $8,500 a year for a full-time worker. Employers could be expected to scream if they were required to pay for $4,000 in health insurance for an employee earning $8,500 a year.
To soften the blow, the Administration is looking at setting ceilings on the payments by small businesses. With a ceiling of 7 percent of an employee's pay, an employer would pay about $600 for a minimum-wage worker.
Small businesses also fear that they would be required to provide coverage for part-time workers. The Administration is considering requiring employers to make partial health-care payments for part-time workers -- an employer might thus pay for half a policy for an employee working a 20-hour week.
If small businesses are not required to pay for any coverage for part-time workers, as small business lobbyists are demanding, that would be a substantial incentive for them to hire two part-time workers rather than one full-time worker.

HEADLINE: New York City Looks to Small Businesses for Jobs

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
After decades of counting on big business and local government to create jobs, New York City must now look mainly to small companies to rebuild its decimated jobs base and thus must make it easier for them to operate, political leaders, economists and urban planners say.
This represents a new attitude toward small businesses, which for years have lacked the clout to pressure City Hall for the tax concessions and financial incentives granted to large corporations, like CBS, Chase Manhattan, Morgan Stanley and Prudential Securities, that threatened to leave the city. 
 Indeed, there is finally widespread acknowledgment that the complaints that many small-business owners have voiced about high taxes, infuriating fines, confusing regulations and byzantine bureaucracy may have merit and that the city government is more of a hindrance than a help to small businesses in New York City.
 
A Political Consensus
 This consensus includes not only Mayor David N. Dinkins and his prospective challengers in this year's mayoral race but also City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman and Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker who is chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.
"New York has to reinvent its economy and that means making it easier for small and dynamic businesses to flourish here," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. "Right now we don't understand our advantages, and we certainly don't have policies that take advantage of our advantages."
Given the city's fiscal woes, making life easier for small businesses -- all businesses, for that matter -- involves radically reducing the cost of government so taxes and fines can be cut. It means vastly improving the efficiency of city services, which may require letting private companies take over some functions.
"They're all very, very difficult," Mr. Rohatyn said. "I have no great illusions that all are going to happen or some are going to happen."
Such changes would require big sacrifices from powerful interest groups that have shown time and again an unwillingness to make them.
These include unions like one representing sanitation workers who work short shifts for a full day's wage. They include state legislators who refuse to have the state pay for the city's 25 percent share of its Medicaid and welfare costs, penalizing the city for a high concentration of poor people. They include owners of one-, two- and three-family residences who scream when anyone mentions how unfair it is that commercial property-tax rates are more than six times theirs.
 
Much to Offer, Despite Everything
 Whatever the obstacles, New York still has enormous advantages to business: a diverse population, a huge, talented pool of labor, access to the companies and institutions that make it an international business and cultural center, 134 universities and colleges, and many leading research hospitals.
The result is a vast market with thousands of sizable niches, from printing financial documents for Wall Street to making music videos to supplying food to Indian restaurants. But given the high costs a business faces, from those imposed by the government to rents, utility charges and crime, only the truly fittest entrepreneurs can survive, let alone flourish. "The reality is New York City is not a good place for most small businesses," said William A. Sahlman, a Harvard Business School expert on financing entrepreneurs.
The figures bear this out.
While the number of small businesses, those with fewer than 100 employees, increased by 24 percent nationally in the 1980's, the city's grew by just 4 percent. Not coincidentally, the number of private-sector jobs in the city grew only 9 percent, or less than half the rate for the country as a whole.
The city has generally relied on local government and large companies for jobs. Companies with 500 or more workers employ nearly one out of every three people in its private sector. Nationally, their share is less than one in four.
But jobs at large corporations in New York City have vanished at an alarming rate. Of the 228,800 private-sector jobs lost between 1988 and 1991, 93,000, or 40.7 percent, were at large companies.
By comparison, employment at companies with fewer than 100 employees fell by only 58,660 in the three years, and their share of private-sector jobs edged up to 47.1 percent.
Signs are not promising for a rebound at large companies. The number of corporate headquarters in the city plunged in the last decade, continuing a long decline. Companies in financial, business and professional services -- the sector that fueled the 1980's economic boom -- had been mauled by the end of the mergers and acquisitions binge and the recession.
 
Ideas to Help Small Enterprises
 Ideas are not scarce on how to create a more hospitable environment for small business. They range from the modest but possible to the grandiose.
The former includes providing low-cost incubation space for fledgling biotechnology companies, which might enable the city to profit more from discoveries at its research hospitals. Another is Ms. Holtzman's proposal to use city pension funds to obtain federally guaranteed loans to entice light manufacturers to an underused duty-free zone at Kennedy International Airport, where they could import parts and export assembled products.
More sweeping is the Dinkins proposal to ease rigid laws governing where businesses like supermarkets and large discount stores and industrial concerns like warehouses, electronics assemblers and garment makers can locate. Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, argues that large-scale retailing and light manufacturing would provide tens of thousands of badly needed lower-skilled jobs. By attracting lots of shoppers, large retail stores could also help neighboring small businesses.
 
Bruising Experience In the Permit Maze
 Virtually all entrepreneurs clamor for one-stop shopping for permits. Consider what Abraham Mammen, owner of two Indian restaurants in Jackson Heights, Queens, went through when he bought his second restaurant.
Six months after he bought the restaurant, a Fire Department inspector told him the kitchen exhaust system did not comply with city regulations and fined him $350. Mr. Mammen was shocked. The system had been operating for 10 years and seemed to have all the needed permits.
Mr. Mammen hired an architect to design an exhaust and fire-extinguishing system and to submit the plan to the City Buildings Department. He then hired another specialist to submit a plan to the Fire Department.
Both departments approved the plans. Then the Health Department told him the kitchen layout was wrong. "The Buildings Department doesn't care what the Health Department says and the Health Department doesn't care what the Fire Department says," he said.
In response to such complaints, the Dinkins administration is preparing guides to regulations for specific industries. The next goal is one location to obtain all the needed permits. "We have to make it easier for a person with entrepreneurial drive," said Wallace L. Ford 2d, Commissioner of the Department of Business Services.
While this problem seems within grasp, the same cannot be said of another one: the heavy burden of taxes and fines.
"It's going to be very difficult for any administration in the near future to make substantial cuts in taxes and fines because of the city's budget crisis," said Stanley Schair, partner of a small Manhattan law firm and chairman of the Small Business Committee of the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry.
Indeed, the fiscal problems explain the survival of taxes that everyone agrees are especially harmful to small businesses. These taxes -- the unincorporated business tax, the personal income tax surcharge, the commercial rent tax, the city corporate income tax, and state and city hotel-room taxes that hurt tourism -- generated $2.77 billion in the last fiscal year. Fines brought in $405 million more.
 
Fledgling Company Threatened by Taxes
 But to make ends meet now, the city may be damaging its future by driving out the likes of the Cadus Pharmaceutical Corporation, a biotechnology company in an old printing shop in lower Manhattan. The 13-month-old company, which now has 5,000 square feet of space, needs 18,000 more. Its president, Jeremy M. Levin, wants to stay in New York but is not sure he can.
"Every dollar I spend on taxes is one less spent building our technologies, which will provide the company with a long-term basis for survival," he said.
Cutting taxes and fines would require substantially cutting municipal costs. Even the city's latest fiscal crisis was not severe enough to persuade city unions to improve productivity or the state to assume the city's share of Medicaid and welfare.
Nor is there reason to believe that other proposals -- like transferring to the state or selling city-owned hospitals, prisons and airports, and replacing city employees with private companies in functions like trash collection and school cleaning -- would be any easier to achieve.
"It is one thing to put your finger on what are the best policies when you're not in power," said Matthew P. Drennan, an economist and urban planner at Cornell University. "It is quite another to enact such policies as mayor."
Mr. Rohatyn, who is backing Mr. Dinkins's re-election bid, believes such actions are inevitable. "I just don't believe the status quo is viable because what I see coming down the road in the next two, three or four years," he said, referring to the city's anticipated budget deficits.
New York's government employment of 236,918 is one of the highest relative to its population: more than 32 per 1,000 residents. These figures exclude more than 100,000 employees of agencies like the Health and Hospitals Corporation, the Housing Authority and the Transit Authority.
But Mayor Dinkins is not threatening to make deep job cuts, possibly because the city's employees, many of them minorities, are constituents.
Nor is the Mayor, who raised annual taxes by more than $2 billion to cope with the city's fiscal problems, promising deep tax cuts soon. Indeed, he wants to extend the personal-income-tax surcharge that raised the top rate to 4.46 percent from 3.4 percent. It is to expire in December.
"The main point I am going to be making is taxes, taxes, taxes," said City Council President Andrew J. Stein and a Democrat like Mr. Dinkins.
Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former United States Attorney seeking the Republican nomination, added, "There's no question that the policies and programs have aggressively driven jobs out of New York City by failing to get control of government spending and then having to subsidize government by confiscating increasing amounts of money from the private sector."
 
Debating the Value Of Tax Cuts
 The most extreme proponent of tax cuts is Stephen Kagann, an economist and adviser to Mr. Stein. He calculates that if the city cut taxes by $4 billion over four years, 600,000 private-sector jobs would be created in six years and the city would break even in four years. In the interim, he contends, the city would only have to trim spending by 3 or 4 percent.
But Mr. Sullivan, the former banker Mr. Dinkins recruited last spring as architect of economic strategy, scoffs at this proposal as supply-side absurdity.
Mr. Stein said he also would not take that gamble. Like the other mayoral challengers, he says taxes should be cut in tandem with spending.
Mr. Dinkins has committed himself to freezing property and corporate-income taxes and water and sewer fees. He would have the city exempt 28,000 small businesses from the tax on commercial rents. The administration has also taken steps, and promised many more, to reduce the number of fines on small businesses for minor violations.
But the administration's position is that it cannot cut taxes until the state assumes the city share of Medicaid and welfare and the local economy rebounds. "It would be very helpful for the city and state to gradually reduce the tax burden, but the city will have to participate fully, or even more than fully, in the national recovery to have a chance," Mr. Sullivan said.
Instead, Mr. Dinkins has vowed to streamline the city's web of regulations and make it much easier for businesses to navigate the bureaucracy when seeking service, bidding for contracts or obtaining permits.
His administration has also created some small-business loan programs and set a goal of awarding 23 percent of city contracts to businesses owned by minorities or women. And it has begun to do something about a major problem for small retailers: street vendors.
These steps have heartened some small-business owners, who see Mr. Dinkins as the first mayor in decades who wants to help them.
But many think the Mayor is too timid to take decisive action. "The Mayor has shown good intentions and gestures, but we still need vigorous, courageous leadership," said Sung Soo Kim, co-chairman of the Small Business Congress, a group formed to press City Hall for relief.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "BURDENS: New York Taxes Small Businesses Love to Hate"
 
Personal Income Tax Surcharge
 
Top rate of 4.46 percent on individual income over $65,000 and joint incomes over $108,000.
 
REVENUE: $405 million in the 1992 fiscal year, which ended on June 30.
 
CRITICISM: Only New York and Washington have a progressive personal income tax. New York's top rate is the highest in the nation. A 1992 study by the Comptroller's Office found that most businesses go where there is no city and no state income tax.
 
City Corporate Income Tax
 
8.85 percent tax on income before deducting compensation to owners and officers.
 
REVENUE: :$1.17 billion in year that ended June 30.
 
CRITICISM: New York is one of few cities to tax corporate incomes. Business owners say it amounts to double taxation of incomes of owners and officers. Corporations in the city also have to pay 11.88 percent state corporate income tax, for state and local income taxes of more than 20 percent.
 
Commercial Rent Tax
 
6 percent on annual rents above $11,000 in Manhattan below 96th Street and on rents above $15,700 elsewhere.
 
REVENUE: $708 million in fiscal '92.
 
CRITICISM: Unique to New York City and raises the already high cost of renting space. Double taxation because rents typically include property taxes.
 
Unincorporated Business Tax
 
4 perent tax on the income of owners or partners.
 
REVENUE: $366 million in fiscal '92.
 
CRITICISM: Results in double taxation of the income of small-business owners who must also pay the city's personal income tax. meaning they have to pay a city tax of as much as 8.86 percent on their incomes.
 
State and City Hotel Taxes
 
4 percent state sales tax, 4.25 percent city sales tax; $2 city occupancy tax; 6 percent city hotel tax; 5 percent state tax on rooms $100 or more.
 
 
REVENUE: $114 million alone from city hotel and occupancy tax on fiscal '92.
 
CRITISICM: New York has the highest tax on hotel rooms in the world. The city Comptroller's Office estimates that these taxes cost the city $1.1 billion in lost convention business in 1988-92.

HEADLINE: CHESTER JOURNAL;
The Fleas That Saved Main Street

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES

DATELINE: CHESTER, N.J.

 BODY:
SOMETHING happens here on weekends. No one is sure when it started, exactly. But every Saturday morning, throngs of tourists -- from kissy couples to large, extended family groups -- pour into this pastoral Morris County borough as if the carnival were in town, hanging out all day and staying for dinner. And even more show up on Sunday, when Main Street might as well be Disney World.
Downtown Chester, all four blocks of it, is day-tripper heaven. Tourists trek in throughout the year from all over New Jersey, New York and Connecticut to browse the antique stores and boutiques, experience a meal in the town's landmark inns, marvel at one- and two-story colonial buildings and take in the apple orchards and horse farms along the way. 
 Now that May is here, even more will be coming. It is flea market season here, when 10,000 people cram into the 1.6-square-mile borough (population 1,214) every Sunday for the Chester Lions Club Flea Market.
In fact, the flea market is what most residents, whether in credit or blame, point to for starting the tourist phenomenon in the first place.
"When we started, downtown was mostly boarded up," said John Lefand, a past president of the Lions Club. That started to change, he remembers, when the Lions Club fund-raising market, now 22 years old, started getting word-of-mouth publicity on the regional flea market circuit. Crowds came and specialty stores followed.
But if the flea market quickened downtown's pulse, Main Street returned the favor. The Lions Club market, which was once like a big garage sale, now boasts 250 vendors, selling everything from socks to furniture, on a 12-acre lot not far from the main drag. The Lions Club made more than $90,000 last year by renting space to merchants, and donated it to local and regional charities.
"Our season runs through October 31 and it's a hit every weekend," said Mr. Lefand. "There's a spillover from the market to downtown and downtown to the market."
In a sense, the resurrection of downtown Chester is a familiar story. Similar tales could be told in Woodstock, N.Y., or Frenchtown and Lambertville, N.J., along the Delaware River, or any number of small towns across the country, where the answer to solving the riddle of the shopping mall ("How do you keep residents from abandoning downtown?") was to turn stores into shoppes.
The transformation has made Chester, an old iron-ore mining village that became an affluent rural commuterville, so popular it makes the state tourist guides.
But charm and popularity has a price. The weekend crowds mean that Main Street, which is also Route 24, never gets a traffic break. In fact, on weekends, traffic is worse. Cars that jam the skinny road hem and haw, sizing up the shops from the driver's seat. Parking requires the reflexes of a fighter pilot. And the traffic backups entering and leaving the flea market, off Route 206, can extend for miles.
"For what I do, it's the kind of town you want to be in," said Brian Rizzolo, who opened Aunt Petty Pat's Parlour Antiques and Such 11 years ago, when Main Street's metamorphosis was in progress. But, he added, "I can understand why some people would rather come during the week. I can't say that my most fun time is to walk through large crowds."
And while Chester's stable of stores carry a definite cachet, there is that ever-looming danger, common to all villages with artsy boutiques, that the kitsch will ride in like fleas on a hound.
For residents of the borough, weekends are a time to duck for cover. While a few stores cater to local residents, Taylor's Ice Cream Parlor, Chester Hardware and the bookstores notable among them, Main Street belongs to the tourists. And then, only the hale and hearty.
"I came early this time," said Clara Rosenberg of Morristown, who was visiting Chester on this first flea market day of the year. "But I can already see the cars coming. Yikes."
