HEADLINE: Big Aircraft Leaser Races the Clock for Financing

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, May 2

 BODY:
The GPA Group P.L.C., the aircraft-leasing company that is the largest purchaser of commercial jets, is scrambling to avert a financial crisis that could leave the company crippled and even jeopardize its survival.
Faced with a severe cash squeeze caused by its rapid expansion just as the airline business went into a steep slump, the company is hurrying to complete a deal with its lenders, suppliers and bondholders before it has to make $200 million in debt payments in the next two months. At the same time it is discussing selling a big stake to one or more outside investors, including the General Electric Company of the United States. 
 The negotiations are being watched intently not just by the banks and investors to whom GPA owes $5.5 billion, but also by aircraft manufacturers, which can ill afford the collapse of a leading customer.
 
 
Buying and Leasing
 GPA was built into a huge force in the aviation business over the last two decades by Tony Ryan, its chairman. The company buys planes from manufacturers and then leases them to airlines, which often find it less expensive to lease aircraft than to buy them. GPA sells the planes and the leases in a package to investors, using the proceeds to buy more planes.
But last year, the company's fortunes went into a downward spiral. Airlines, battered by a worldwide recession, needed fewer new planes. And the privately held company's plan to raise $800 million through an initial public stock offering collapsed, leaving it unable to finance its planned aircraft purchases and imperiling its ability to repay its debts.
For now, the company, which is based in Shannon, Ireland, has arranged to cancel or defer much of the $12 billion in aircraft orders it had placed with the Boeing Company of Seattle and the Airbus Industrie consortium of Europe, although it is still locked in a dispute with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's aircraft unit in Long Beach, Calif.
 
Working With Lenders
 GPA also seems close to agreement with all but a handful of its 138 bank lenders, led by Citibank. Under the proposed deal, people involved in the negotiations said, the banks would defer $1 billion in principal repayments on GPA's $3.3 billion in bank loans until the end of next year and would give back to the company $100 million in principal payments made in recent months, in return for higher interest rates. There also appears to be pressure from some banks for management changes at GPA.
But the company has so far been unsuccessful in its plan to raise $200 million from investors, and without new equity it is unclear whether the banks will agree to the deal.
Before they agree to take a chance on financing a turnaround, potential equity investors, and perhaps the banks as well, appear to be pushing GPA to demand that holders of $2 billion of unsecured high-risk junk bonds pay part of the price for the company's problems.
Last week, GPA hired the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation to advise it on rearranging the bond debt. People involved in the negotiations said GPA was not, as rumored, preparing to ask the bondholders to swap the debt for equity in the company, at least not yet.
 
A Fluid Situation
 Instead, they said, the company appears to be interested in concessions like deferred payment on the bonds. But they added that the situation was changing almost daily and that the banks and potential new equity investors could still force a debt-for-equity swap over the company's objections.
Some analysts said that such a swap, which given the company's weak condition would amount to an admission that the bondholders are unlikely to get their money back, is the only way for GPA to dig itself out of its financial hole.
"Without equitizing a significant portion of the unsecured debt, I believe the company's ability to raise new equity is nil," said Jack Hersch, an analyst at M. J. Whitman in New York, which trades in distressed bank loans and debt securities.
GPA has been trying to raise equity primarily from its existing shareholders, which include banks, other financial institutions and airlines around the world. Its banks had previously made new equity a condition of their debt-rescheduling agreement, but last week GPA said it expected to sign the bank deal before raising new equity.
Although many shareholders have proved reluctant to invest more money in the company, GPA said it was "encouraged by indications received in recent days from some of our major shareholders of their willingness to participate in the capital raising for more than their pro rata share." People involved in the negotiations said that the Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corporation, one of several Japanese institutions with stakes in GPA, was among those that had agreed to increase their stake.
GPA has also been looking for new investors and has had discussions with a number of airlines and investment groups, industry executives said. But much of GPA's attention, they said, has been on discussions with General Electric, based in Fairfield, Conn., which is one of the two leading aircraft-engine manufacturers (the other is the Pratt & Whitney division of United Technologies). G.E. owned as much as 22 percent of GPA during the 1970's and at one point sought unsuccessfully to acquire the entire company before selling its stake for a large profit.
G.E. subsequently bought a smaller aircraft-leasing business and is considering taking a big stake in GPA, perhaps a majority holding, people involved in the negotiations said. But they cautioned that General Electric remained wary of any deal that would increase its debt level and lower its debt ratings.

HEADLINE: Joan S. Rader, 58, G.O.P. Party Officer And School Trustee

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Joan Sperry Rader, who was active for two decades in the Republican Party in Connecticut, died on Friday at her home in Greenwich, Conn. She was 58.
The cause was lung cancer, said her husband, William Donald Rader. 
 Mrs. Rader, who had lived in Greenwich since 1965, was a real-estate broker and longtime school trustee. She was elected in 1989 to a two-year term as the vice chairwoman of the Republican State Central Committee of Connecticut, becoming its highest-ranking female officer. She was re-elected to a second, successive term and held the office at the time of her death.
Her many volunteer activities over the years included serving as a trustee of the Eagle Hill School in Greenwich, a private day and boarding school for learning-disabled children and teen-agers.
 
A Brooklyn Native
 Since 1981 she had been a real-estate broker with Douglas, Elliman Pickering Associates in Greenwich.
Mrs. Rader was born in Brooklyn, the daughter of Edward G. Sperry, who was for some years president of the Sperry Products Company, which manufactured railroad and subway track-testing equipment and other products in Connecticut and on Long Island, and the former Mary Elizabeth Garvin, who was a company director.
She grew up in Oyster Bay, L.I., and graduated in 1956 from Vassar College, where she majored in economics. In 1958 she married Mr. Rader.
Besides her husband, Mrs. Rader is survived by three daughters, Judith Anne, of Boston, Jennifer Caroline, of Springfield, Ohio, and Elizabeth Rader Edwards of Riverside, Conn.; two sisters, Judith Sperry Beavers of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Joy Sperry Emery of Ballston Lake, N.Y., and a granddaughter.

HEADLINE: Office Costs Are Faulted

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
International financial institutions must avoid wasteful spending on their offices, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said on Saturday.
His comments were made after the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development was widely criticized for spending $80 million on renovations of its offices, which included new furniture and decorative touches in Carrara marble. 
 It is critical that "the international financial institutions exercise prudence in their administrative costs, including salaries, travel, benefits and facilities," Mr. Bentsen told the World Bank and International Monetary Fund Development Committee.
The international financial institutions lend to middle-income and poor nations, with the goal of lifting the standards of living in those countries.
It is important that "taxpayer money is spent wisely, not wastefully, to insure adequate public support," Mr. Bentsen said. He encountered strong criticism of the bank's spending when he asked Congress to approve money needed to meet the United States' share of new financing for the international institutions.

HEADLINE: U.S. Presses Argentina On Patents

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, May 2

 BODY:
Despite Argentina's deep changes in opening markets to foreign competition, selling state companies and stabilizing the economy, the Clinton Administration has notified the Government of Carlos Saul Menem that it has not yet done enough.
The Office of the United States Trade Representative is considering taking the first steps that could eventually lead to trade sanctions against Argentina, if the Government fails to pass a law that protects the patents of American pharmaceutical companies here. 
 Argentine officials are worried about the potential action, saying that any hint of sanctions could send a damaging signal to financial markets and outside investors at a time when the country needs continued investment from abroad for further growth.
 
Making a List
 The American trade officials must decide which countries to single out as those that fail to protect the intellectual property rights of American companies. And Argentina is high on the list of candidates.
"United States companies have suffered significantly in Argentina as a result of lack of patent protection and the United States Congress has made it very clear that we have an obligation to do what is necessary to protect the interests of American companies abroad," said a senior official of the trade office. "I know Ambassador Kantor feels strongly about this," he said, referring to Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative.
The United States pharmaceutical industry contends that it loses up to $200 million a year in Argentina because of pirating of its patents.
The process now under consideration at the trade office with regard to Argentina has become known as the Special 301 review program of the 1988 Omnibus Trade Act. The law requires that by the end of each April the trade office must publish a list of the countries that it regards as the most abusive in permitting the pirating of patents, trademarks and other intellectual property rights.
 
The Ultimate Weapon
 When a country is put on the list, the trade office has a month in which to decide whether to begin a formal investigation. After the investigation is completed, trade sanctions can be placed against the country, the ultimate trade weapon of the executive branch.
American officials say that the other Latin American country with heavy patent stealing by pharmaceutical companies is Brazil. The Brazilian Congress is also debating passage of a patent law, but American trade officials say they have not seen the legislation and they doubt it will provide adequate protection.
Officials of the Clinton Administration say the issue goes beyond the loss of American pharmaceutical profits. They say they may want to use the case of Argentina as an example to other Latin American countries about the cost to a developing country, in terms of lost exports and investor confidence, if it does not respect intellectual property rights.
"United States firms are losing billions every year from a lack of patent protection and this Administration is intent on changing that," the trade official said. "Moreover for countries like Argentina, strict patent laws that stop pirating should actually stimulate intervention and investment there, something those countries say they are interested in."
Ira Shapiro, the general counsel of the United States trade office, testified before Congress that Argentina along with Brazil, India, South Korea, Thailand and Taiwan were countries that have made little progress in recent years in passing strong patent controls.
 
Change Is Opposed
 For its part, the Menem Government has been frustrated in getting passage of the patent law, now hung up in Congress. The law faces a powerful Argentine pharmaceutical industry with sales of more than $2 billion that has exerted broad influence on Congress.
Government officials fear that even the hint of possible trade sanctions could cause foreign investors to think twice about investing in Argentina and look elsewhere in Latin America, like Chile.
Multinational drug companies here say the Argentine companies copying their drugs actually charge more for the final product than the multinational manufacturers -- as much as 30 percent, some say. And that represents enormous profits because no research and development costs are involved.
"The original product needs 10 to 12 years of research and hundreds of millions of dollars in costs, and here the imitations only require large sums of money for marketing," said Rafael Alonso, the director of patents for the Argentine Chamber for Specialized Medicines, representing the multinational companies.
Mr. Alonso and others say quality control among Argentine companies is lax, which poses a potential health risk to the public.
 
Charges Are Denied
 Representatives from the national laboratories reject such charges, saying their prices are 8 percent to 9 percent lower.
They say the multinationals were aware the laws were different when they entered the Argentine market. An 1864 law protects the manufacturing process, but not the final product.
"We are not pirates, nor copiers, as we are accused," said Anibal Caprile, president of Cilfa, the group of 17 Argentine companies lobbying against the new law. "We use a different process than the original and arrive at the same final product, and that is permitted by our laws."
Indeed, the debate over pirating American drugs has been an intense issue here for two years. Ambassador Terrence Todman of the United States has taken a highly public stand on getting patent protection legislation passed. President Menem has promised several times to meet a deadline for Congress to pass the law but has repeatedly failed.
 
Stalled in the Legislature
 The bill, which American officials say is a model patent law, is hung up in eight congressional committees. The snag has led Argentine and American officials to doubt that anything will be done. They also warn that if Congress adjourns without passing the bill, under congressional rules it must reintroduce the bill and begin the legislative proceedings anew, a process that could take another two years.
In the past, drugs patented and tested by American companies have been produced and placed on the shelves of Argentine pharmacies by pirating companies here even before the American manufacturer got approval to sell the drug in the United States, American Embassy officials say. Moreover, the pirating by Argentine companies has gotten so sophisticated that one biotechnology company, Bio Sidus, is marketing the cancer drug, interferon B.

HEADLINE: Canada Races to Ratify 3-Nation Trade Pact

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, May 2

 BODY:
The North American Free Trade Agreement may face opposition in the United States Congress, but Canada is rushing to ratify the monumental pact that would bind 360 million people into a single market.
Having already cleared most of the major legislative hurdles, the Nafta Implementation Act is headed toward a final vote in the House of Commons in mid-May, despite opposition charges that the Government is ramming the bill through and polls showing strong opposition. 
 "As for general participation by the Canadian public, it will be zero," lamented Dave Barrett, trade spokesman for the socialist-oriented New Democratic Party, which contends that an existing five-year-old trade pact between Canada and the United States has caused the loss of thousands of Canadian jobs. The new pact, broadened to include Mexico, would replace the old one.
While polls show that more than half of Canadians remain opposed to the latest agreement, ratification is proceeding without major protests or demonstrations. Five years ago, the opposition to the pact with the United States was so rambunctious that an election had to be fought over the issue.
That experience led many to think that the Government this time would face an almost impossible task of winning approval of the more far-reaching North American accord.
But opinion analysts say that the pact evokes more resignation and fatigue than anger -- in contrast to American attitudes over Mexico's looser anti-pollution enforcement and low wages, which have raised fears of an undermining of American environmental and labor standards.
"Because Mexico is a long way from Canada, worry about eroding standards is just not so prevalent here," Angus Reid, a pollster, said. Canada's trade with Mexico is less than 2 percent of its trade with the United States.
Mr. Reid's polls suggest that opposition to the three-nation agreement, while still robust, especially in labor union circles, is diminishing. In March of last year he found 64 percent of Canadians opposed. By November, when he conducted his latest survey on the accord, naysayers had dropped to 53 percent.
Five years ago the Canadian-American pact stirred relatively little public interest in the United States. Then it was Canadians who fretted about deterioration of their standards from a closer union with the United States.
 
 
'Less Adamant'
 According to Donald J. S. Brean, professor of international economics at the University of Toronto: "It's now accepted that the pro-trade side has won. People remain opposed, but they are less adamant about it."
For the agreement to take effect, negotiations on environmental and labor side accords must still be wrapped up, and the United States Congress and the Mexican Congress still have to ratify it. President Clinton voiced confidence at his news conference on April 23 that the side deals would soon be completed. Negotiators next meet in either Toronto or Ottawa in mid-May.

HEADLINE: Review/Jazz;
Bobby Watson Leads His Own Big-Band Revival

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS

 BODY:
A year and a half ago, Bobby Watson pulled together some big-band arrangements he had been working on, took them to Columbia University's jazz orchestra and led the orchestra in a surprisingly successful concert. Mr. Watson, known as a saxophonist and composer, had big-band aspirations, not a fruitful thing to have, given jazz's generally enfeebled economic situation. The concert, often brilliant, looked as if it was set to go down in legend, a one-time event making Mr. Watson one of those rare jazz composers lucky enough to hear their music played by a large ensemble, if only for one night. With big bands seemingly relegated to the dustbin of history, the music was destined for the security of Mr. Watson's desk drawer.
But the current jazz renaissance has had all sorts of salutary effects, not the least of which is a flowering, albeit small, of interest in big-band music among both audiences and musicians. Lincoln Center and Carnegie Hall both have jazz orchestras; Jimmy Heath and Slide Hampton have started large ensembles recently, and Wynton Marsalis moves closer to fronting a big band every year. Illinois Jacquet's orchestra was one of the highlights of the 1980's, and the American Jazz Orchestra, David Murray's big band and Clifford Jordan's orchestra have all offered exceptional music. Along comes Mr. Watson, who has just released his first album on Columbia Records, "Tailor Made," which happens to be a big-band album. 
 Mr. Watson brought roughly the same band heard on the album into the Village Vanguard for three nights, and on Friday night, for its first show, it played surprisingly fluid music. Over the last 15 years, Mr. Watson has been producing some of jazz's most optimistic compositions, first with Art Blakey and then with a series of his own groups. His pieces resonate with a type of blues sunniness, in which small bits of bitterness make his optimism seem realistic. Small-group arrangements and compositions don't always make an easy transition to large ensembles, but on Friday night, Mr. Watson's pieces metamorphosed into big orchestrations, with the main themes underlined and surrounded with all sorts of asides, punctuations and embellishments.
There was a real ingenuity to the material. The band dropped away occasionally, leaving Mr. Watson and several saxophonists to perform unaccompanied, or he would let the band drift into honking discord, or set up soloists improvising against one another. At times the band drifted into light Latin jazz, which kept it from swinging as hard as it should and accentuated a prettiness that seemed more like Hollywood than New York. But for the most part, Mr. Watson's music maintained his own elemental harmonic personality. And Mr. Watson, his improvisations voluminous and flaunting a ripe and fleshy tone, kept the show tense and exciting.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bobby Watson playing with his big band on Friday night at the Village Vanguard. (Jack Vartoogian)

HEADLINE: The Administration's Trade War

 BODY:
The President calls for raising the tariff on Japanese minivans tenfold; his Treasury Department puts the proposal on indefinite hold. The President promises to hold up the free trade agreement with Mexico until he negotiates stringent conditions on the environment and labor; his chief trade negotiator, Mickey Kantor, goes before Congress to propose tame conditions. The President vows to push the Uruguay Round of international trade talks to conclusion; U.S. negotiators stymie negotiations.
The Clinton Administration is engaged in a trade war -- with itself. 
 One side -- led by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, his chief trade economist, Lawrence Summers, and the White House adviser, Robert Rubin -- fights to preserve the U.S.'s traditional commitment to rules that every country, including the U.S., pledges to follow. Should the U.S. break the rules by, for example, shutting out imports that threaten domestic producers, the Treasury officials fear that other countries will follow suit until trade shrivels and every country suffers.
On the other side are Mr. Kantor and Laura Tyson, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers -- backed by Democrats representing industries threatened by foreign imports. They call for a more muscular approach, whereby the U.S. wields its huge market clout to bully partners into granting trade concessions. Ms. Tyson, the more circumspect, calls for "cautious activism" to counter foreign threats to high-tech industries.
But in the hands of politicians like Mr. Kantor, cautious activism easily slides into rank protectionism. Minivans aren't high tech and U.S. manufacturers, accounting for over 90 percent of the market, aren't threatened by foreign competition. All the proposed tariff hike would accomplish is to jack up prices to consumers by thousands of dollars. Apparently Mr. Kantor prefers to reward Chrysler rather than the middle-class families his boss has sworn to defend.
Ms. Tyson and Mr. Kantor are backing other aggressive trade policies. They advocate managed trade, whereby Washington would set numerical targets for, say, exports of auto parts to Japan and retaliate if Japan misses the mark; they also back laws that would allow the U.S. to retaliate against trade practices it unilaterally decides are unfair -- even if such retaliation violates existing trade agreements.
Aggressive retaliation against foreigners who bend the rules isn't new; it's been the policy and practice of every recent Administration. Last week Mr. Kantor broke no rules by threatening to retaliate against Japanese restrictions on U.S. companies bidding for government contracts.
But for the U.S. to bully partners by violating international trade rules is new -- and dangerous. It invites destructive trade wars and taxes consumers in the process. The only people likely to cheer Mr. Kantor are the special interests he would serve and fund raisers at the Democratic National Committee.

HEADLINE: A Breakthrough on Bosnia?

 BODY:
President Clinton's escalation of pressure on the Serbs to make peace in Bosnia appears to be yielding encouraging results. In the most hopeful sign in months, the recalcitrant leader of the Bosnian Serbs, Radovan Karadzic, has signed the international peace plan designed to end fighting in the Balkans.
If the Serbs really mean to halt their genocidal onslaught, this is indeed a diplomatic triumph. Under the peace plan approved yesterday in Greece, the Bosnian Serbs would be forced to yield roughly a third of the territory they have seized and would be denied the corridors they seek to link Serb-held territory in Bosnia and Croatia with Serbia proper. 
 Although the plan, named after its crafters, Lord Owen of Britain and Cyrus Vance of the United States, was initially denounced as a sellout that would reward Serbian aggression, in the chaos that is now Bosnia it is beginning to look like the best available life raft.
But the danger remains that Serbian agreement to the plan may be nothing more than a cynical sham to defuse the rising pressures for allied military intervention. That makes it especially important for the Clinton Administration to keep up the diplomatic pressure, as Secretary of State Warren Christopher is now doing by continuing his rounds of European capitals to forge a firm and unified approach.
President Clinton has it just right when he insists that the Serbs must show by deeds, not just by words, that they accept peace. The Serbs must stop their artillery shelling of helpless cities . . . stop ethnic cleansing of Muslims from areas the Serbs have seized . . . stop the flow of arms from Serbia to Bosnia . . . and allow humanitarian relief to reach sick and starving victims.
A large hurdle lies just ahead. The self-styled parliament of the Bosnian Serbs, dominated by hard-liners, is scheduled to vote on the plan on Wednesday. The hard-liners must be left in no doubt whatsoever that if they persist in slaughtering lightly armed opponents and unarmed civilians, the allies will ratchet up the diplomatic and economic pressure and consider again the need for military intervention.
That warning to the hard-liners could be amplified if Secretary Christopher's understandings with European leaders this week are given wide publicity -- to let the Serbs see they will face a determined and unified coalition.
Several factors probably combined to spur Dr. Karadzic to sign the peace document yesterday. His backers in Serbia proper came under increasing pressure as the existing embargo on trade was greatly tightened and Serbian assets were seized abroad. That may have led Slobodan Milosevic, the President of Serbia, to urge a cooling off.
President Boris Yeltsin, fresh from a resounding referendum triumph, made it clear that Russia would not ride to the Serbs' rescue, increasing the pressure. And President Clinton let it be known Saturday that he was ready to commit American air power, lift the arms embargo that blocks shipments of guns to the Bosnian Muslims, and possibly help create "safe havens" for the Muslims to protect them from Serbian attack.
The Administration has many tasks remaining. Its goals need to be clearly defined before it commits troops or aircraft, either through military strikes or participation in an international peacekeeping force. And it will need to generate support from Congress and the public for any military commitments. But the hopeful developments this past weekend suggest that the Administration and its allies may finally be on the right path.

HEADLINE: Crucial Support Virtually Assures McCall's Election as Comptroller

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 3

 BODY:
Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, the Legislature's most powerful Democrat, endorsed H. Carl McCall for State Comptroller today, virtually assuring that Mr. McCall will become the first black to hold statewide elective office in New York.
If he is elected by the State Legislature on Wednesday, as is expected, Mr. McCall plans to resign as president of the New York City Board of Education by the end of the week, said his spokesman, Steven Alschuler. 
 Mr. McCall's departure comes as the board also is seeking a new schools chancellor to succeed Joseph A. Fernandez. Mayor David N. Dinkins will appoint a new member to replace Mr. McCall on the seven-member board, but the board, on which the majority has been aligned against Mr. Dinkins and Mr. McCall, will then elect a new president. Other board members, appointed by the borough presidents, said Mr. Dinkins would have a very hard time winning the board presidency for his new appointee. [Page B8.]
Mr. Weprin, who has been under heavy political pressure for weeks about his decision, said today that he selected Mr. McCall, a vice president for state and government relations at Citibank, because of his management skills and because the election of a black comptroller "offers a historic opportunity for New York State."
 
'A Real Responsibility'
 The 57-year-old Mr. McCall, who also has served as state commissioner of human rights, a state senator from Manhattan and part of the United States mission to the United Nations with the rank of ambassador, said he was relieved and honored by Mr. Weprin's decision.
In an interview, he said his selection served as recognition of the contributions made by black Americans since the Revolutionary War. "That recognition has come late, but it has come," he said. "And we have a real responsibility, once put in a position like this for the first time, to be a credit to all of the people who made it possible."
Mr. Weprin said he took into account the preference of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who supported Mr. McCall, and of his Democratic colleagues, who he said were split almost evenly between Mr. McCall and his main opponent, Carol Bellamy, a former City Council president. "My judgment was that Carl McCall by a very narrow margin -- because Carol was very qualified -- would make a better comptroller," Mr. Weprin said at a news conference.
But Bellamy supporters said the Speaker's decision ultimately reflected politics within the Capitol. It was more expedient, they speculated, for him to alienate the Democratic women in the Legislature who supported Ms. Bellamy than to anger the black legislators who backed Mr. McCall.
And they accused him of giving too much weight to Mr. Cuomo's wishes. Ms. Bellamy had made a campaign issue of the relative independence of the two candidates from Mr. Cuomo.
Though disappointed, Bellamy supporters in the Legislature said they would follow Mr. Weprin's lead and help elect Mr. McCall on Wednesday. "There will be no rebellion, but there will be repercussions, I imagine, and a lot of bad feelings," said Assemblywoman Catherine T. Nolan, who like Mr. Weprin is a Queens Democrat. "Is there ever going to be a chance for women to move up or is it always going to be someone else's turn?"
 
A Dramatic Climax
 Mr. Weprin's decision provided a dramatic climax to what had become one of the most peculiar campaigns in New York political history.
It was a race where the electorate consisted not of the state's 9 million voters but of its 211 legislators, and really only the 127 who form the Democratic majority.
The campaign began in February, when Edward V. Regan, a Republican who had been Comptroller since 1979, said he would resign on April 30 to take a job with an economic "think tank." The State Constitution provides for the Legislature, sitting as a whole, to fill the position when a vacancy occurs in the middle of a term.
Because Democrats hold a solid majority, a united Democratic front was assured of electing one of its partisans. But with the Democrats divided between Mr. McCall and Ms. Bellamy, it fell to Mr. Weprin, the leader of 101 of the 127 Democrats, to make a final awkward choice.
The comptroller job, which pays $110,000 a year, is coveted for both professional and political reasons. The comptroller is the sole trustee of the state's $56 billion pension fund, the auditor of state agencies and local governments, and the chief critic of state budgeting and borrowing practices. The position also is one of only six elected statewide offices, including two United States Senate seats, making it a potential springboard to higher office.
With Mr. McCall's election, it will be the first time in at least half a century that all four of Albany's statewide elected officials -- the governor, lieutenant governor, attorney general and comptroller -- will be Democrats, said John A. Marino, the state Democratic chairman.
 
Vote Is Scheduled
 Mr. Weprin and Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine, a Democrat who technically serves as the president of the Republican-majority State Senate, scheduled a vote by the Legislature on the interim comptroller for Wednesday at 10:30 A.M.
John E. McArdle, a spokesman for the Senate Republicans, said Senate leaders were still deciding whether to participate in the vote. If they did not, the Republican leaders could either boycott the session but allow Mr. McCall's election to take place or offer a legal challenge to the process.
Ms. Bellamy, who narrowly lost the 1990 general election against Mr. Regan, declined to comment on her previous pledge to challenge Mr. McCall in a 1994 Democratic primary if she did not win the interim appointment.
If elected on Wednesday, Mr. McCall will serve the unexpired portion of Mr. Regan's term and then will run for a full four-year term in 1994. As an incumbent, he would begin with a significant advantage in name recognition and financial support.
But Mr. McCall lost a statewide Democratic primary for lieutenant governor in 1982 to a white candidate. And he would face the challenge of running as a black candidate in a state where no member of a minority group has ever won a statewide general election and where black voters last November comprised only 10 percent of the state total.
This year's race featured a number of conflicting undercurrents, as groups yearning for power struggled for political advantage.
Black legislators and other supporters of Mr. McCall made clear that they considered the election an opportunity for the state's Democratic Party to repay the black community for decades of loyal support. Women felt their time had come after consecutive unsuccessful statewide campaigns by Bella S. Abzug, Elizabeth Holtzman, Ms. Bellamy and Geraldine A. Ferraro.
And in the final hours of the campaign, a number of Puerto Rican lawmakers in the Legislature broke with the state's black legislators, who traditionally have been political allies. After a weekend of negotiations, they threw their support to Ms. Bellamy, at least partly because they perceived that she was more committed to supporting Hispanic candidates in coming citywide elections and to providing state business to Hispanic-owned banks and brokerage houses.
Even though the gambit by the Puerto Rican legislators failed to help Ms. Bellamy, it reinforced the growing sense that there are two distinct minorities in New York politics and that they can no longer be relied on to work in tandem.

HEADLINE: Financing of $31.4 Billion Budget Presented by Dinkins Is Criticized

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins presented a $31.4 billion budget plan yesterday that drew criticism from independent fiscal experts for putting off tough decisions in an election year.
Mr. Dinkins proposed a modest series of cuts, including eliminating the Police Cadet Corps, ending 300 community college classes and slowing reductions in the commercial rent tax. But the core of the plan was his proposal to close a half-billion-dollar budget gap by relying on state and Federal aid that has yet to materialize. 
 The Mayor has been struggling since January to close a $2.1 billion gap between the city's revenues and expenses in the $31.4 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1. Mr. Dinkins's task became harder in April, when the State Legislature rejected his request for about $660 million in aid, leaving the city with more than a $500 million gap.
The spending plan released yesterday, which represents an $800,000 increase over the current budget, is the fourth Mr. Dinkins has proposed and comes a few months before he faces re-election. It reflects a fiscal situation less dire than what he encountered in his first two budgets, which he put together as the recession took hold. But the Mayor is under more strain than last year, largely because of a major labor settlement, which will cost the city about $400 million, and a drop in property tax revenue of at least $400 million as well.
 
Modest Spending Cuts
 To close the gap without cutting services, Mr. Dinkins said he would rely on a combination of modest spending cuts, a series of one-time revenue strategies, an unusual borrowing scheme, a greater-than-expected surplus from this year's budget and $530 million in state and Federal help, which has yet to materialize.
If the Federal and state aid fails to arrive, Mr. Dinkins threatened to carry out nearly $176 million in additional budget reductions, cutting such politically popular expenditures as city-financed day care, dental work for children, drop-in centers for the homeless and summer school.
The Mayor's plan drew criticism from independent fiscal experts, who said it depended too heavily on one-time revenues like bond refinancings and borrowing against future property tax receipts, which seem intended to tide the city over until after election day. His main rivals in the election -- Rudolph W. Giuliani and City Council President Andrew J. Stein -- said Mr. Dinkins was failing to provide leadership in making tough decisions to get the city's finances in order.
But Mr. Dinkins said his reliance on help from his fellow Democrats, particularly President Clinton and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, did not mean he was avoiding difficult decisions. Beyond election-year politics, he said, there was a basic question of fairness: that based on the state and Federal taxes the city pays, it is shortchanged in terms of state and Federal aid.
"The suggestion that we ought to just fold our tent and not fight is just not in me," Mr. Dinkins said. "We go to the contingencies if we have to, but I'm going to fight like hell in the meantime."
Already in the budget are an additional $128 million in cuts to city agencies that come on top of the $623 million in reductions the Mayor proposed in January.
The new measures include cutting more than 50 positions in the Transportation Department to save $7 million and erasing the Public Service Corps for a saving of $1.4 million. The measures also include a cut of $4.3 million from the maintenance budget for parks and playgrounds.
 
Scaled Back Initiatives
 The Mayor has also scaled back or slowed the pace of some of the popular initiatives that he announced with great fanfare in January. He has proposed delaying by three months the opening of 15 new "beacon" schools that provide social services to save about $2 million. He has also trimmed a proposed exemption from the city's commercial rent tax for 28,000 small businesses. He proposed $30 million worth of exemptions in January and put off granting two-thirds of that yesterday.
The proposed budget would increase the size of the city work force slightly, to 213,968 employees, from the 212,488 in the current year, city officials said. That increase is a result of the hiring of about 1,000 police officers ahead of schedule next spring, and the hiring of 500 environmental protection workers required under Federal clean-water guidelines, officials said.
The Speaker of the Council, Peter F. Vallone, described the Mayor's budget as "politically realistic" and "not totally Alice in Wonderland." He said that he would help Mr. Dinkins lobby for the state and Federal aid but added that there would be tough negotiating over what cuts to make should the aid not come through.
The fiscal experts faulted the Mayor for failing to permanently shrink the size and cost of the government to bring expenditures in line with taxes.
"Its a budget that says we're pulling out all the stops to get through this year," said Charles Brescher of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private budget monitoring group.
 
Call for Structural Changes
 Mr. Brescher said that whoever wins the election in the fall will face huge billion-dollar gaps in future years because Mr. Dinkins has failed to make fundamental changes in the work force. "If you cash in all your one-shots now," he said, "you're postponing the day when you have to make these structural changes."
Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the State Municipal Assistance Corporation, questioned the wisdom of depending on Albany and Washington for more aid to avoid hard decisions.
"Between the actions the city expects the state and the Federal Government to take, there is a considerable amount of money not in place," he said. "The longer you wait to deal with the problem, the more drastic the action that will need to be taken."
The Mayor's political opponents were quick yesterday to try to exploit what they saw as political opportunities in the budget.
"This is one that the Mayor can't escape responsibility for, though I know he will try desperately," Mr. Giuliani, the probable Republican candidate, said. "This deficit is largely due to his failure to manage the city."
Mr. Giuliani said much of the budget gap stemmed from the Mayor's failure to stick to his negotiating position with municipal unions, that he would only grant pay raises financed through increased productivity. Mr. Dinkins ultimately agreed to modest wage hikes that will still cost the city $428 million next year. "The Mayor added 400 million in raises and got nothing back in productivity except promises," he added.
Mr. Stein, who is challenging Mr. Dinkins for the Democratic nomination, echoed the same criticism. "He hasn't changed the fundamental culture of the way the work force functions in New York," he said.
Jeffrey L. Sommer, the deputy director of the State Financial Control Board, said Mr. Dinkins's budget contains more than $675 million in one-time revenues that will not help the city balance its budgets in the future.
Those measures include borrowing $215 million from a bank by using unpaid property taxes as collateral, refinancing of city bonds and stretching out bond payments to save about $214 million, and selling the Off Track Betting Corporation for $55 million.
 
'High Risks'
 "We still see high risks in fiscal year 1994 and the city has not addressed the multibillion dollar problems in fiscal years '95 through '97," he said.
The city benefited from higher income tax revenues than it had projected in January, even though property tax revenues dropped by nearly $400 million, city officials said. Overall taxes will bring in about $114 million more than expected in the current fiscal year and will produce about $90 million more during the next year, officials said.
Mr. Dinkins put in his budget $6.3 million in capital funds and a grant for the New-York Historical Society that, along with an equal amount of state assistance, will breath new life into the organization, which was nearly out of business.
The Mayor's plea for more aid from the state met with carefully hedged support from the Governor and legislative leaders.
Governor Cuomo did not promise to provide the relief from state mandates Mr. Dinkins has asked for, but he did point out that he had already proposed mandate-relief measures that would save much of the $280 million Mr. Dinkins is seeking, including proposals that would have the state gradually assume Medicaid costs.
"I've told the Mayor that all these mandate relief items are worth pursuing," Mr. Cuomo said. "It would be hard to get all the way to $280 million, but it's certainly worth pursuing."
Charles E. Schumer, a Democratic Congressman from Brooklyn, said Mr. Dinkins would face an uphill battle in Washington, where the prevailing wisdom in Congress is that the Federal budget should be cut, not expanded.
"The tone in Washington is unfortunately for more cuts out of the President's budget," he said. "It's going to be tough, but we'll do our best."

HEADLINE: Insurers Are Limiting Sales in Risky Areas

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
A rising number of insurance companies are stopping or limiting the sale of property insurance in coastal areas and other regions prone to natural disasters, actions that are likely to push up prices and force many consumers to turn to Government-sponsored plans for coverage.
The cuts are in response to the worst year of property losses ever for the industry, which continues to face unusually severe losses this year. 
 The American Insurance Services Group, an industry trade organization, announced yesterday that losses in the first quarter of this year, which included coverage of the bombing of the World Trade Center and the blizzard on the East Coast, topped $2.8 billion, up from $810 million for the period a year earlier. Losses for last year, which included Hurricanes Andrew and Iniki and the riots in Los Angeles, totaled $23 billion, up from $4.7 billion the year before.
 
Review of Risks
 As a result, the industry is undergoing a thorough re-examination of its risks in future disasters, particularly on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, where building has been heavy the last two decades.
Insurance commissioners in Florida, Hawaii, Louisiana, New Jersey, New York and Texas said that dozens of carriers had decided to stop selling or renewing policies for homes and other property. In Florida, companies are seeking increases in premiums amounting to 40 percent or more.
State Farm, the nation's top home and private property insurer, has also put a limit on policy sales in California, where earthquake and fire risks are high. Some agents also report a reduction in coverage in hail-prone areas of the Farm Belt.
Regulators say the biggest impact will be felt in Florida and Hawaii, where premiums are likely to rise sharply and the availability of private insurance will shrink. Those consumers who are unable to find private insurance will be forced to buy coverage from state-sponsored pools, which often cost far more than the private market, or from Government-sponsored "FAIR (fair access to insurance requirements) plans," which provide basic coverage.
In other states, like New Jersey and Louisiana, insurance commissioners say further cutbacks by insurers could hinder economic activities in shore areas and harm housing industries just starting to recover from a recession. Even with stop-gap government programs, new home buyers and developers might be discouraged by high prices or difficulties in finding coverage.
New Jersey's Insurance Commissioner, Samuel F. Fortunato, recently accused Cigna and the Ohio Casualty Group of Insurance Companies of illegally restricting sales near the New Jersey coast and said he had met with many other companies to discourage them from abandoning coastal areas.
"In my view, a good deal of this is a knee-jerk reaction," Mr. Fortunato said. "We will not tolerate any company turning its back on the Jersey shore."
New York's Insurance Commissioner, Salvatore Curiale, said yesterday that he had been informed by Allstate, Travelers and Geico that they planned to limit coverage on Long Island, which the industry considers particularly vulnerable to hurricanes.
Although Mr. Curiale said he believed other companies would take their place in most areas, homeowners in coastal areas will find much higher premiums or insurance available only from FAIR plans, which provide limited government-sponsored coverage for high-risk areas.
"Long Island is going to be the next place to experience some market- availability problems," said John Snyder, a vice president with A. M. Best, an insurance rating service in Oldwick, N.J. "Along the coast you will have problems locating coverage."
By far, the biggest impact has been in Florida. Allstate Insurance, the second-largest carrier in the state, announced last month that it would refuse to renew policies for 25 percent of its customers, or 300,000 property owners in the state, and that it planned to request rate increases of 40 percent or more. But Allstate is not alone.
Jill Chamberlin, a spokeswoman for the Florida insurance department, said that 36 companies, including State Farm, Prudential and Travelers, have announced that they will either stop writing homeowners and other property coverage in the state or severely restrict it.
She said that in the last 23 years, the insurance industry took in $10.8 billion in premiums in the state, while in several hours of Hurricane Andrew it lost $16 billion.
As a result, Ms. Chamberlin said that some analysts had estimated as many as 500,000 customers would be unable to find insurance from private carriers and would be forced to buy coverage from a newly established Joint Underwriting Association. The association will offer at least minimum coverage but at a cost 25 percent higher than the already rising standard market.
One problem for the association, Ms. Chamberlin added, is that the association has no funds of its own other than premiums paid in. If another big hurricane or large disaster should strike, the remaining insurers would have to pay claims, a process that many companies could not afford.
"We are looking at the urgent need for responsible companies to get their risk exposure under control," said Tom Gallagher, Florida's Insurance Commissioner. "But we won't let it become a license to take advantage of the citizens."
In Hawaii, where Hurricane Iniki caused more than $1.5 billion of damage, the insurance department estimates that more than 70,000 of the 218,000 homeowners policies in the state will not be renewed. Companies like State Farm and Transamericaearlier this year put restrictions on available coverage.
Sharp cutbacks in the availability of property insurance is also being felt in southern and central Louisiana, where Allstate, State Farm, and other companies with more than 50 percent of the market are curtailing sales, said James H. Brown, the state's Insurance Commissioner.
Mr. Brown said he expected that as many as 50,000 homeowners may have difficulty finding coverage in the private market and those forced into the state's Joint Underwriting Association will be hit with 15 to 20 percent increases in premiums.
State Farm has also announced that it will limit the sale of new policies in Texas, where the company has a 32 percent share of the market, and in California, where many insurers believe they are overexposed to risks after the 1989 earthquake and the Oakland fire of 1991.
Mr. Snyder of A. M. Best said he expected some restrictions of coverage in Kansas, where losses to hail were severe in recent years.
In a news conference yesterday, Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, and Robert Hunter, the president of the National Insurance Consumers Organization, said the industry is using last year's losses as an excuse to raise prices unfairly. With assets of more than $160 billion, they said, the industry is in a position to sell more than $10 billion more property insurance across the nation.
But spokesmen for the industry and a number of industry analysts disagreed, saying the industry's failure was overselling in the past and not paying enough attention to future risks.

 Over the last several years, the property-casualty insurance industry's overall profitability wasbelow that of most other American industries, though insurershave benefited from big gains in their investment portfolios as stocks and bonds rose sharply in the 1980's and early 1990's.
But, industry analysts say, when investment gains are excluded, the industry fared poorly on its basic insurance business.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Worried by U.S. Criticism Of Curbs on Construction Bidding

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 3

 BODY:
For months, the Government of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa has been trying to end the stream of embarrassing revelations about millions of dollars in illegal donations to prominent politicians, mostly in return for multibillion-dollar construction contracts.
Now, just as the scandals were beginning to die down, the Government is threatened with a new and unwelcome set of investigations, this time from the Clinton Administration. 
 Last Friday, in the latest challenge to Japan on trade, the United States threatened to impose sanctions against Tokyo if negotiations did not increase American access to the construction market within 60 days.
The Administration action revived one of the most contentious issues in the countries' trade relations: Washington's accusation that bid-rigging and political connections keep Japan's huge public-works contracts out of the hands of American companies.
 
Another U.S. Complaint
 The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said Friday that despite a 1988 agreement to let American companies bid on some projects, the market has remained fundamentally closed. His statement was one of the angriest challenges to Japan since the new Administration took office.
In Tokyo, however, Japanese officials seem less concerned about the American demands than with the prospect that they will direct new attention to the bribery scandals.
Japanese commentators concede that the bribery revelations of the last few months clearly gave Washington the ammunition it needed.
And for the first time, many commentators are drawing a strong link between the corruption at home and the foreign complaints that Japanese markets often exclude outsiders.
Government officials denounced Washington's threat of unilateral action. The Foreign Ministry spokesman, Masamichi Hanabusa, said, "The Japanese construction market is institutionally nondiscriminatory and open."
Prime Minister Miyazawa said the threats did not reflect the 1988 agreement because the Clinton Administration "was apparently not informed by the previous Administration of the contents so far agreed upon in negotiations between the two countries."
But even critics of Mr. Kantor made no effort to argue that public-works projects are allocated on merit.
"To our regret, there are various areas in which Japan must improve," Yomiuri Shimbun, a major daily with strong ties to the ruling party, said in an editorial on Sunday. "The current system is a hotbed of bid-rigging and cozy relations among politicians, bureaucrats and members of the construction industry," the paper said, adding, "The system is a strong barrier to foreign companies."
Since the 1988 agreement, United States companies have won a few contracts.
But in supporting Mr. Kantor's action last week, the United States Commerce Department maintained that progress has been poor, saying American companies had won only $189 million of the $700 billion Japanese market for public- and private-sector construction last year, while Japanese companies had won $1.5 billion of the $425 billion United States market.
 
The Files of a Power Broker
 In response, Japanese officials say American companies would have won more contracts if more of them had opened offices in Japan. Americans say, however, that with so little business available to them, it makes no sense to invest in expensive office space in Japan.
Ever since the arrest two months ago of Shin Kanemaru, 78, once the power broker of the Liberal Democratic Party, newspapers have been full of disclosures of how one major Government project or another was awarded under suspicious circumstances.
Construction concerns are believed to have been the biggest source of the $50 million in financial certificates, cash and gold bars found in Mr. Kanemaru's offices. He has since been released from jail and is awaiting trial on tax-evasion charges.
Japanese officials are loath to concede any link between the bid-rigging disclosed in Mr. Kanemaru's case and others, and Washington's contention that the system is rigged.
In fact, as many lesser players in the industry are quick to note, the system is rigged against all outsiders.
Prime Minister Miyazawa has so far said almost nothing about the scandals, and instead has promised reforms that would make it far more difficult for companies to influence politics.
But little progress has been made so far, and the reform proposal, critics say, is full of loopholes. For example, companies would still be allowed to classify millions of dollars of expenses as "unexplained costs."
Though companies must pay a stiff tax on such amounts (legitimate expenses are generally exempt from taxes), the category permits them to funnel kickbacks to politicians with little fear they will be traced.

HEADLINE: The Hotel Industry Is Roiled By Frequent-Guest Awards

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
A donnybrook between the giant Marriott Corporation and Hilton Hotels is riling the hotel industry. And as the invective has intensified, the Hyatt Hotels Corporation has cautiously sided with Hilton while Holiday Inn has come down equally gingerly on the side of Marriott.
"But mostly it's been kind of fun just sitting back watching our competitive brethren go at one another," Ken Pierce, a vice president of Holiday Inn, said. 
 Outwardly the fighting is over the value of a new Marriott awards program for guests, allowing frequent-flier miles on six airlines even without flying on them. But industry officials say the bad blood, or at least the willingness to spill it in public, is symptomatic of the struggle for dominance in the hard-hit hospitality industry, which is trying to attract business customers with perks for frequent travelers.
The traveler is the key to the value of the perks the different chains offer. With its bonus frequent-flier miles Marriott offers more miles -- generally the preferred perk -- than most competitors right now; alternatively, guests can choose hotel points redeemable in hotel stays, merchandise or travel once enough points are accumulated. In contrast, Hilton offers mileage on the top three airlines -- American, United and Delta -- plus points. The Hilton program is especially generous for couples.
After a building binge in the 1980's, the hotel industry has lost billions of dollars in recent years from overcapacity and a weak economy, both of which have depressed room rates. Now, foreseeing improved industry fortunes by 1994, the major chains are waging a bare-knuckled battle for customer loyalty.
"The whole point of these marketing programs is to boost a hotel company's name, particularly among business travelers, and boost demand," Margo Vignola, the lodging analyst at Salomon Brothers, said. "While there's a budding recovery under way in the industry, the full-service hotels, which cater to business travel, remain soft."
Ms. Vignola does not foresee an industrywide escalation of the incentive programs as long as the economy improves. "But if the recovery falls flat, you'll probably see them raise the stakes," she said.
Incentive programs, giving customers frequent-flier miles or free rooms, cost hotel companies $8 to $10 a guest. During good economic times, hoteliers say those programs pay for themselves by generating new business. But during economic slowdowns, the programs often wind up trying to take business from competitors. It is the fear of that happening, analysts say, that has helped intensify the current feud.
"I don't remember these kinds of public feuds in the past," said Mark Lomanno, research manager for Smith Travel Research in Gallatin, Tenn., which compiles statistics for the American Hotel and Motel Association. While hoteliers may trade private potshots, and chains often denigrate competitors in advertisements that are only slightly veiled, others agreed that they cannot remember any such squabble involving so many industry leaders.
What ignited the fight was Marriott's announcement in mid-April that beginning last Saturday guests at its 250 hotels worldwide could earn frequent-flier mileage on any of six participating airlines. Because travelers need not fly to receive the miles, and because there is no limit on the mileage that may be earned, Marriott called the program "precedent setting."
 
 
'Same Old Stuff'
 On the very day of Marriott's announcement Hilton blasted the program as "the same old stuff in a new package," and it has kept up its barrage of public criticism.
"The Marriott program is nothing more than a guise," said Michael Ribero, senior vice president of marketing for Hilton, in an interview. "We think the consumer is being deceived."
Marc Yanofsky, Hyatt's senior vice president of marketing, said in a similar vein, "It's clear that Marriott is scrambling eggs, hoping the consumer thinks the smaller omelet looks more appetizing."
Marriott has responded in kind.
"If you've spent as much time flat on the mat as Hilton and Hyatt," said Ralph Giannola, Marriott's vice president of marketing, "you'll say anything not to take another beating."
Joe Brancatelli, executive director of Frequent Flyer magazine, tends to agree with Mr. Giannola. "By Hilton and Hyatt going ballistic," he said, "this indicates to me they have been caught flat-footed."
 
 
Bondholders' Lawsuit
 Marriott, which faces a bondholders' lawsuit to prevent it from restructuring into two companies, is generally regarded as the industry pacesetter in combined size and innovation. It has some 750 properties worldwide, but its mileage program applies only to its 250 full-service hotels and resorts in the industry category known as upscale -- just below luxury and ahead of basic, economy and budget.
Hilton has 240 hotels and resorts worldwide, Hyatt has 165, almost two-thirds of them in the United States, Canada and the Caribbean. Holiday Inn, whose growing top-of-the-line properties compete in the luxury market with the three other chains, has 1,700 properties worldwide.
While all four chains enjoy occupancy rates above the industry average of 62.8 percent for upscale hotels, according to analysts, all are suffering from room rates that averaged only $66.60 for the upscale hotel sector last year -- well below what is required to service their debt, much less turn a profit.
Marriott's Honored Guest Awards is also the industry's biggest "frequent stay" program, with more than five million members. Holiday Inn's Priority Club program has three million members, while the Hilton HHonors program claims three million and Hyatt's Gold Passport more than two million.
At one time, Marriott offered both points and frequent-flier miles on participating airlines -- a benefit the industry terms "double dipping." But almost two years ago it required guests to choose between them.
Under the Marriott Miles program that went into effect Saturday, guests receive -- in addition to 500 frequent-flier miles for each stay -- an additional 2,500 bonus miles after every fifth stay.
Marriott did away with double-dipping, Mr. Giannola said, because its research showed that it was not necessary to offer both to attract frequent business travelers. And the difference between Marriott's program and those of Hilton and Hyatt is, he said: "Their philosophy is you can have a little bit of points and a little bit of mileage. We're saying you can have a lot of points or a lot of miles."
The participating airlines are American, British Airways, Continental, Northwest, T.W.A. and USAir. Continental's frequent-fliers earn 1,000 miles for each Marriott stay and 5,000 bonus miles after five stays, while T.W.A. frequent-fliers earn 1,000 miles for every stay at a Marriott outside the United States and 2,500 bonus miles.
Mr. Brancatelli of Frequent Flyer said that 73 percent of the magazine's readers prefer miles to frequent-stay programs, and that by trumpeting its miles program, Marriott is tacitly acknowledging as much. "This is a perception game," he said. The fact is that right now the two most important stay programs in the industry are Marriott's Honored Guest and Marriott Miles."
But that is not the way the competitors tell it.
 
 
'Credibility Problems'
 "What Marriott has done is cut its program benefits by precluding members from double-dipping," Mr. Ribero of Hilton said. "It's a cost-saving initiative that's being packaged to minimize consumer backlash."
He added: "The whole frequent- travel marketplace sometimes suffers from credibility problems with the fine print, and Marriott is adding to this problem. When consumers realize what they've been taken in by, it's going to give the entire industry a black eye."
What has most ruffled the feathers of other hotel chains is Marriott's claim that its program is unique.
ITT Sheraton, for example, has proclaimed in newspaper ads that it has been offering frequent travelers a choice of points or mileage for years at each of its more than 300 properties in North America.
Inter-Continental Hotels -- with only 10 hotels in North America but 98 more around the world -- offers frequent-flier mileage on American, United and six foreign carriers.
"Not only is it not necessary to have flown on any carrier to claim mileage," said Charles Brownfield, an Inter-Continental vice president, "we offer 500 miles for each night, not 500 miles a stay."
Hyatt offers frequent-guest points for every dollar spent, and 500 miles on United, USAir, Delta, Northwest or Alaska Air. But to qualify for miles, except on United, it is necessary to have flown one of the participating carriers.
Hilton also offers double-dipping. "If we matched the Marriott program," Mr. Ribero said, "we'd actually be taking away some of the benefits we offer our guests."
Those benefits include points for each dollar spent, as well as 500 miles on American, America West, United, Air Canada or USAir, or 1,000 miles on Delta. Only USAir and Delta require that guests fly on their airlines to be awarded the miles.
Hilton and Hyatt claim that Marriott is actually trying to reduce the cost of its awards program, which they portray as troubled.
"They have a huge liability because their program is very big, unwieldy and costly," Mr. Ribero said. "So they have had to do some kind of cost containment, and they're making it look like it's a tremendous benefit."
Hyatt's Mr. Yanofsky said, "If you borrow from the future to pay for the present," alluding to the widespread perception that Marriott's frequent-guest program was overly generous in years past, "the future ultimately arrives."
Mr. Giannola of Marriott scoffs at assertions that its awards program is in trouble. "If we were, we wouldn't be looking to expand its scope this way," he said, "because buying airline miles is not the inexpensive route to the frequent traveler's heart. But we can do it cost effectively."

HEADLINE: Islam in New York: Growing Presence of Diverse Peoples United by Faith

 BODY:
To get an idea of who New York City's Muslims are, stand outside the Islamic Center of New York, the city's most prominent mosque, on Third Avenue at 96th Street in Manhattan.
On a recent religious holiday, through its doors came Pakistanis in flowing pastel gowns, black Americans wearing kente-cloth hats, an Albanian couple trying to quiet their crying daughter, West Africans in high head wraps, Bahrainis in business suits, Egyptian cab drivers, Yemeni restaurateurs, a young Bosnian who stood up in mid-service and gave an emotional appeal for his countrymen. 
 The city has about 70 mosques, nearly twice as many as a decade ago, said Dawud Assad, associate director of the Muslim World League in New York City and president of the city's Council of Mosques. He said it was difficult to say how many Muslims there were in the city, but he estimated 800,000, up from about 680,000 a decade ago.
The Muslim population has also become more diverse by race and nationality as more and more immigrants have arrived seeking political or economic refuge.
"New York has the most cosmopolitan Islamic community in America," said Marc Ferris, who did research on Islam in New York for a coming book on Muslim communities in the United States. "To say a mosque is Pakistani or Guyanese just means they started it. Once it is open, everyone just comes on by."
 
Schools for the Faithful
 Roughly half of the city's Muslims are recent immigrants, and about half of them are South Asian, Mr. Assad said. Arabs make up the second-largest group.
New York Muslims have founded about 10 schools, most teaching through the eighth grade but some continuing through high school. The schools are scattered throughout the city, with a concentration in Jamaica, Queens, where many Asian and black American Muslims live.
Financed with donations and tuition, the schools combine standard school subjects with study of the Koran, Islamic history, Arabic and other religious topics. Lessons are scheduled around the daily prayers.
On religious holidays and on Fridays, the Muslim holy day, a mosque is usually packed with worshipers of various nationalities who may live or work in the neighborhood and go to the mosque because it is most convenient. But most other times the mosque reflects a particular Islamic ethnic group, serving as a place where congregants can speak their common native language, give money and gifts to those headed back to the homeland, exchange job information and gossip about local politics.
The mosques range from lavish Ottoman-style buildings to basements of car-service garages. In downtown Brooklyn, the Islamic Mission of America is the cornerstone of the Arab district on Atlantic Avenue, where Arab restaurants, bakeries and cafes give the area the feel of downtown Cairo. Founded in 1939 by a Moroccan immigrant, the mosque is among the oldest and most prominent in New York.
 
A Surge From Europe
 Perhaps 20 percent of recent Muslim immigrants to New York are from Eastern European countries like Albania, the former Soviet Union and the former Yugoslavia.
Albanian Muslims, who have tended to settle in Flatbush in Brooklyn, account for one of the biggest surges. Many live near the Albanian American Islamic Center for New York and New Jersey, where Imam Isa Hoxha oversees Friday prayers -- in both Arabic and Albanian -- for about 300 people each week.
By some estimates, at least 100,000 Asian Muslims live in the area, most from Bangladesh, India and Pakistan but many also from Malaysia, the Philippines and Sri Lanka. They live mostly in Queens, especially Flushing, where the Muslim Center of New York has expanded from a single apartment in 1975 to a large building now under construction.
Pakistani immigrants are by far the most active group in spreading the word of Islam and building Islamic institutions in the New York area, Mr. Ferris said. In 1983, they built the Islamic Center of Corona in Queens, the city's first mosque to be built as such. Before then, mosques were mainly established in abandoned buildings, storefronts and basements, where many still are.
Pakistanis are also behind a most American way of transmitting the holy word: bumper stickers that read "I <heart> al-Islam." They are not shy about ferreting out and calling up lapsed Muslims on Fridays to nudge them to prayers.
"Every since the 50's, the Pakistanis have done the most to promote Islam in New York," Mr. Ferris said. "The reason they work so well here is because they often speak English and keep a high profile. Some go door to door just like Jehovah's Witnesses."
 
Bound by Need
 In 1913, long before Elijah Muhammad and Malcolm X popularized the Nation of Islam, Noble Drew Ali started the Moorish Science Temple in Newark. Today there is a large concentration of black American Muslims in the New York area, many of them in Harlem, Crown Heights and Bedford-Stuyvesant.
A few scattered storefront mosques attract fundamentalists, who draw inspiration from the visions of outspoken imams like Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, who for years has called for the overthrow of the Egyptian Government.
The area's Muslim community is often bound more by necessity than by love. Muslims are a minority, and suspicion and hostility often surround them.
"Even Shiites and Sunnis go to the same mosques in New York," Mr. Ferris said, referring to the two major Islamic sects, which often feud. "Some say religion is the most tenuous of threads, but Muslims really stick together."

HEADLINE: WEST OFFERS PLAN TO CLEAN UP EAST

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUCERNE, Switzerland, April 30

 BODY:
After more than three years of hand wringing over the environmental disasters left by Communism, the rich nations of the West have adopted a common strategy to help clean up in Central and Eastern Europe.
A plan adopted on Friday by nearly 50 environment ministers from virtually all of Europe, the United States, Canada and Japan identifies the most urgent targets and lists projects deemed most manageable in the former East bloc, including western Russia. 
 The plan, called the Environmental Action Program, says air pollution is the most serious health hazard in the region, where lead, sulfur and soot have already affected the population. Second, it calls for improving and protecting drinking water, which is often laced with heavy metals or toxic chemicals. A third priority, it says, is to stop damaging nature in ways that may be irreversible.
 
What the Plan Leaves Out
 Experts involved in drawing up the accord said it was also noteworthy for what it left out, like projects on the wish lists of Eastern governments and Western environmentalists that could cost billions to carry out. Cleaning up rivers and toxic dumps, removing hazardous waste or decontaminating former military sites, the plan says, have no priority, given the limited money available in the West.
The program, prepared by the World Bank and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development after discussion with all the governments involved, is likely to be used as a blueprint for environmental action in the East in the coming years. Experts say that while the program is not binding on any country, it will influence how Western donors lend and spend their money.
"It's a game plan and it says: It will be a lot easier to get money from us if you do the following," an American expert said.
While the program is the firmest commitment yet from the West that it will help clean up, diplomats said it also includes the bluntest message to date that the West does not intend to pay for redressing most of the environmental havoc caused under Communism.
Resources for the environment "will be severely constrained over the next 5 to 10 years" while costs will be very high, the plan says.
 
$30 Million Is Pledged
 An author of the plan said: "You'll see projects to clean air and drinking water. But there won't be a lot of talk about digging up waste; it will just have to stay there."
The idea is that the program will not have its own funds but will have the ability to generate loans and grants, some of which are held up in Western banks or government aid budgets because of what has been described as a shortage of data or skilled staff in the East. At the three-day conference here, Western governments pledged a total of $30 million, including $10 million from the United States, to pay for technical preparation needed to get loans and projects under way.
"We think the plan is very good," said Carol M. Browner, Administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency. "It gives us concrete proposals and practical solutions."
It also places much of the onus on governments in the East. They would be required to take steps that also make economic sense, like reducing waste of energy and water, improving maintenance and monitoring new waste, the plan says, stressing that small investments in conservation can have major environmental benefits.
The main emphasis of the plan is to think small. Inexpensive solutions like new filters, storage tanks and switching from coal to gas, it says, "can be more appropriate than massive programs, most of which will have a relatively low benefit-to-cost ratio."
 
A Message to Industry
 A World Bank official said: "This is as much a message to Western industry, which has been pressuring to sell their new and expensive clean-up technology in the East. They have to understand that they cannot just come and duplicate those mega-sales in the East."
Among the targets indentified as the most urgent in the program are Czech and Polish lignite-fired power plants, where the reduction of sulfur emissions to Western European standards would cost a fortune, said Kurt Lietzmann of the German Environment Ministry. But he said the plants' toxic sulfur dioxide could be cut by almost one-third by adjusting temperatures, repairing pipelines and installing filters, instead of building huge desulfuring plants.
At the three-day conference here, environment ministers from Russia, Slovakia and other nations said that environmental issues, for all their gravity, had moved far down on domestic agendas because of the immediate problems of jobs, food and financing.
While delegates from East and West said they welcomed the new program, disenchantment on both sides was much in evidence in the corridors. Western experts complained that work in the East was uncommonly difficult because of the constant turnover of ministerial staff and the shortage of basic skills that prevent the monitoring of current Western-financed projects, let alone the start of new ones.
Delegates from the former Communist countries complained that the West had been long on promises and short on providing money.
