HEADLINE: Market Place;
Companies that work for other companies are getting popular

BYLINE: By Robert Hurtado

 BODY:
WALL STREET is taking a shine to companies that take care of business for other companies.
Known as outsourcers, these specialty companies perform specific services or manufacturing tasks under long-term contracts with corporations, which once handled the tasks themselves. The use of these companies for everything from medical care to computer software gained momentum during the recession and now is a permanent part of the landscape, since the idea is to increase the operating efficiencies of large corporations. 
 "As Corporate America continues to downsize, its reliance on specialty outsourcers should continued to grow," said Alison Bisno, director of research for Stephens Inc., a brokerage firm based in Little Rock, Ark. "Why add to overhead costs when you can farm out the job and save on the expense of machinery, benefits for employees and production capacity?"
Professional investors suggest looking for companies that dominate a market niche. "Lock your sights onto those outsourcers with a strong market position in a growing industry and chances are good you have picked a winner," Ms. Bisno said.
Hospitals are a major business for these companies. Coastal Healthcare Group Inc. of Durham, N.C., has contracts with hospitals to supply physicians for emergency treatment in obstetrics, anesthesia, gynecology and pediatric services.
Earlier this year, Coastal bolstered its position as the largest publicly traded "pure play" in physician outsourcing by acquiring the Medicus Medical Group in Oakland, Calif.
John Runningen, an analyst with Robinson-Humphrey in Atlanta, estimates that Coastal will earn $1.05 a share in 1993, up from 85 cents last year. Its stock closed yesterday at $19.375, up 37.5 cents, in Nasdaq trading.
Mounting political pressure on health-care companies to control costs is expected to benefit companies like the Healthcare Services Group, the country's largest provider of housekeeping and laundry services for nursing homes and retirement centers.
The Huntington Valley, Pa., company recently reported 1992 earnings of 61 cents a share in contrast to a loss in 1991. Keith Mullins, a special-situations analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, expects a gain to 85 cents a share in 1993 and to $1.05 in 1994. The shares closed yesterday at $10.25, up 25 cents, on Nasdaq.
Among the beneficiaries of the trend to contracting for services in manufacturing are the RCL Acquisition Corporation of New York, which recently agreed to merge with the HRM Holdings Corporation, the parent company of Hauppauge Record Manufacturing Ltd. on Long Island. HRM is the country's largest duplicator of audio and videocassette tapes and has major music companies like Elektra, RCA and Polygram as its clients. The company is also planning to enter the market for compact disk duplication.
Pro forma financial results for RCL, including HRM, for fiscal 1992 ended last July 31 show earnings of 29 cents a share. Thomas Heysek, an analyst with RAS Securities, estimates the company will earn 60 cents a share in 1993. RCL shares closed yesterday on Nasdaq at 523/32 , up 5/32 .
Large software developers like the Microsoft Corporation and the Aldus Corporation rely on the Prism Group of Woodenville, Wash., to fulfill production orders for computer software disks. Prism is able to mass-produce the disks, print the packaging material and ship directly to a software publisher's customers. Prism is expected to grow quickly and emerge as a leader in the disk-duplication industry, some analysts say. They expect it to earn 80 cents to $1 a share by 1995, up from 5 cents in 1992. Prism shares closed at $3.625, off 12.5 cents, yesterday on Nasdaq.

HEADLINE: April Purchasing Data Show Weaker Economy

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
A dearth of new orders seems to have brought the nation's manufacturing growth to a standstill in April, dashing hopes for a quick rebound from last quarter's slower economic growth.
The closely watched purchasing managers' index, which provides a first look at the economy's performance in the previous month, fell to 49.7, its lowest level since September, from 53.4 in March. 
 The purchasing managers' survey of 300 executives, released yesterday, suggests that the economy kept slowing weeks after blizzards and floods in March, and that manufacturing may even have contracted a bit in April. Technically speaking, a reading below 50 indicates that manufacturing is shrinking and a reading below 45 suggests that the entire economy is doing so.
"The economy has been on a slowing track since February," said Robert J. Bretz of Pitney Bowes Inc., the chairman of the National Association of Purchasing Management's business survey committee. "And the weather can be used to explain only part of it."
Manufacturers also cut employment last month, according to the survey.
"We feel we're in a period of stagnation," said F. Kenneth Iverson, chief executive of the Nucor Corporation, a steel producer based in Charlotte, N.C.
Clinton Administration officials used this new evidence of weakness to promote its plans to stimulate the economy. "This can only raise the likelihood that the Administration will produce a new stimulus package and that the American people will support it," said a high-level Administration economist, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because his appointment has not yet been confirmed.
But some executives -- including several who said they had voted for President Clinton -- said the real trouble with the economy was a growing lack of faith among business people in the Administration's economic policy, as well as sheer uncertainty over how the policy would evolve.
"The reason you have a slow recovery is a lack of business confidence," said George Hatsopoulos, chief executive of the Thermo Electron Corporation, a Waltham, Mass., maker of pollution-control equipment. "Business is very worried about another hit of government spending."
Mitchell S. Fromstein, chief executive of Manpower Inc., the country's largest temporary-help concern, agreed, saying there was "a crisis of confidence."
"There's a very uneasy sense that business is going to be expected to pay the cost of the Clinton Administration's new agenda," he said.
Virtually every important indicator of manufacturing activity covered by the purchasing managers' survey was down. More companies reported production declines. The growth of new orders stalled and factories' order backlogs -- a harbinger of production to come -- stopped expanding as they had in previous months. Manufacturing employment continued to shrink.
These are all signs that the huge inventory growth in stores in the last quarter, a result of consumer anxiety and bad weather, was rippling through to industry.
"It's very clear evidence that the manufacturing sector didn't catch on to theslowdown early enough and was continuing to produce as if the strong upturn were going to continue through the first quarter," said Kermit Baker, chief economist at Cahners Economics. "It will take a couple of months for the economy to catch up with their production levels."
 
Rebound in Export Orders
 One high note in the otherwise downbeat report: Export orders, which took a nose dive in March, bounced back strongly. More than three-fourths of the companies in the survey say they sell their products overseas.
But other signals that usually indicate a pickup in manufacturing activity -- firmer factory prices and longer delivery times -- actually reflected a temporary shortage of steel.
"The increase in steel orders is really due to some increase in car sales and production," Mr. Iverson said. "The other is the anticipation of higher tariffs." The Clinton Administration recently raised tariffs on imported steel.
Economists and executives say that the April report on manufacturing probably suggests a lull, not the beginning of a downward spiral. This stop-go pattern has already been repeated several times since the economic recovery began nearly two years ago.
 
Echoes of September
 In September, for example, the purchasing managers' index also fell below 50 percent as factories pulled back for a couple of months, waiting for customers to use up inventories before they began to reorder again. Once that happened, activity picked up again.
"The manufacturing sector, as it has tended to over the course of this recovery, got out ahead of the rest of the economy," Mr. Baker of Cahners said. "Every time there's some glint of hope, they start cranking up production, then they see that demand isn't as strong as they thought and that's the triple, quadruple dip."
But a Federal Reserve governor, Lawrence Lindsey, warned about making too much of a single month's numbers. "I'd rather wait for a trend to develop," he said.
"You get little bunches of pluses and minuses," he added. "We had terrible weather. Lots of reasons to be suspicious about March and April data. I expect a little bunch of positives to come soon."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Slippage in Building
 WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- The East Coast blizzard slowed construction spending in March, the Government reported today.
Spending for residential, nonresidential and government building slipped eight-tenths of a percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $442.7 billion, the Commerce Department said. This was the first drop since spending fell 1.4 percent in August.
Despite the harsh winter, spending in March was 5 percent above that of a year earlier. And the Commerce Department said spending in both January and February, also slowed by winter storms, was better than first thought.
The agency revised the January figure to an increase of three-tenths of a percent, rather than the 1.3 percent drop originally estimated, and said spending in February rose 1.2 percent, rather than the one-tenth of a percent it reported last month.

HEADLINE: College's Ties to Church Group Challenged

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 3

 BODY:
Opponents of the University of Bridgeport's affiliation with a group sponsored by the Unification Church filed suit today, challenging the agreement.
The suit contends that the agreement with the Unification Church group, the Professors World Peace Academy, violates the private university's charter and state laws governing nonprofit institutions. 
 It also contends that the State Board of Governors of Higher Education, in renewing the accreditation of the financially troubled university, exceeded its authority by accepting the academy's role. The academy, financed by the Unification Church, pledged $50 million in aid in return for the right to select up to 60 percent of the university's trustees.
"As a result, a cult now controls a university in the largest city in Connecticut," said Michael A. Stratton, a lawyer representing the plaintiffs. "It is not only illegal and against public policy, it is just plain wrong."
The chairman of the university's trustees, Colin Gunn, responded that the complaint "represents nothing more than a rehash of matters that have already been considered at length by the Board of Governors of Higher Education."
The suit, he said, is "merely another attempt to hamper and harass the university."
The university's administration and trustees have been the focus of protests by professors, employees and former students ever since they began considering an affiliation with the Professors World Peace Academy as a way of resolving a financial crisis at the university.

HEADLINE: Late Rally Produces Solid Gains for Stocks

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The stock market snapped to attention on a broad front yesterday, after a morning session muffled by a weak April report from the nation's purchasing managers, data that are thought to be a harbinger of the economy.
Money swerved from the bond market to stocks in the late afternoon, when bonds became more expensive on buying attributed in part to the expectation that the economy would remain sluggish and restrain interest rates. In generally light trading, all major stock indexes closed up solidly. 
 Yesterday's trading was something of a reverse image of Friday's trading, when bond prices plunged in thin trading, luring some money from stocks and causing a 20-point rally in the Dow to fizzle.
 
Final Surge
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 18.91 points yesterday, to 3446.46, with all of the gain coming in the last hour of trading. The New York Stock Exchange composite index was up 1.08 point, to 244.54, but trading volume was relatively low at 225 million shares, compared with 247.5 million shares on Friday. Gaining stocks on the Big Board outnumbered losers by 1,099 to 805.
The Standard & Poor's 500 was up 2.27 points, to 442.46, and the Nasdaq composite index, made up mainly of stocks with a smaller capitalization, was up 5.29 points, to 666.71. The American Stock Exchange composite index closed up 1.25 point, to 422.21.
The Dow Jones transportation average was up 14.70 points, to 1,607.54, though still far below its April 16 peak of 1,683.08. It rose mainly on the strength of Delta Air Lines; AMR, parent of American Airlines, and UAL, parent of United Air Lines, on no discernible news.
The Dow Jones industrials were lifted mainly by six stocks: Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, McDonald's, General Motors, Goodyear Tire, Merck and Kodak. These stocks accounted for nearly all of the rise. Higher first-quarter earnings contributed to most of 3M's rise; General Motors voted yesterday to maintain its quarterly dividend, but McDonald's rose on no discernible news.
 
Disappointing News
 The National Association of Purchasing Management reported a decline in its index of manufacturing activity to 49.7 percent in April; most analysts had expected an increase to 54 percent. The group surveys officials buying supplies for large companies. Construction spending for March, which declined eight-tenths of a percent, in line with expectations, added to the gloom.
The gold stocks, which received intense investor interest last week, were mostly down, paralleling a drop in spot gold futures prices. Gold set for June delivery fell $1.90, to $354.40 an ounce. Newmont Mining, which sold a large block of its stock to the financier George Soros, closed down 1 5/8, to 47 1/8. An exception: Freeport-McMoran rose 1/8, to 20.
Investors are looking for winning stocks with new urgency. Traders who had bought $1,000 of Dow industrial stocks at the beginning of April and held them would have lost almost $4 by the end of the month. Investors buying the same amount of S.& P. 500 stocks would have lost more than $22 in the period.
One indicator of that interest is the way investors in Nasdaq trading snapped up the initial public offering of Fidelity New York, which converted to a stock savings bank from a mutual savings bank. It was the second most heavily traded stock of the day, at 4.2 million shares. It closed at 13 1/2, up from the initial price of 11 1/2.
The most active stock on the New York Stock Exchange was Wal-Mart Stores, closing down 1/2, to 26 1/4, on no discernible news. Yesterday 4.56 million Wal-Mart shares traded hands, nearly twice the Friday volume of 2.57 million shares.

HEADLINE: Julio Gallo, 83, Wine Industrialist, Dies

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Julio Gallo, who helped to build the immense E.& J. Gallo Winery and in the process helped change Americans' drinking tastes, was killed Sunday afternoon when a vehicle he was driving veered off a dirt road on a family ranch near Tracy, Calif., about 80 miles east of San Francisco. He was 83.
Mr. Gallo, the longtime president of the company, which is one of the world's largest winemakers, was driving the vehicle, The Modesto Bee, a California newspaper, reported yesterday. He was flown by helicopter to Memorial Medical Center in Modesto, where he was declared dead on arrival. According to the Stanislaus County coroner, he died of a cervical spine fracture and partial dislocation caused by blunt-force trauma.
 
Family Injured
 Mr. Gallo's wife, Aileen, and two granddaughters were in the vehicle, a Jeep Wrangler, which plunged 35 feet down an embankment and into a shallow pond, an officer of the Tracy rural fire department said. 
 Mrs. Gallo, who is 80, and Gina Gallo, 26, were injured in the accident and were taken to Eden Hospital in Castro Valley, where Mrs. Gallo was treated for a fractured sternum and rib and Gina Gallo for fractured ribs. Both were reported to be in satisfactory condition and were released yesterday. The other granddaughter, Amie Gallo, 22, was not hospitalized.
Mr. Gallo and his brother Ernest -- his elder by one year and the chairman of the privately held winery, based in Modesto -- each amassed a personal fortune estimated in the hundreds of millions of dollars. Fortune magazine reported late last year that the two men owned the entire winery business and that their combined wealth was $1.3 billion.
Jon Fredrikson, a wine industry economist based in San Francisco, said yesterday that the $1.3 billion estimate was plausible. But some wine industry executives in central California estimated, after Mr. Gallo's death, that he and his brother each had assets of only about $300 million.
The Gallo business has annual revenue of about $1 billion. It sells an estimated 150 million gallons of wine a year and claims roughly 26 percent of the United States wine market. It markets 16 brands of wine, of which 7 are among the 20 top sellers in the country.
From his desk at the company's headquarters, the amiable Julio Gallo oversaw the buying of the grapes and the making of the wine, remaining active and touring vineyards regularly until his death.
His brother created the company in its mammoth form, oversaw sales and was the driving force. According to wine industry analysts, Julio Gallo was partly responsible for the company's growth and its role in increasing wine consumption by Americans after World War II.
In 1983, the wine critic for The New York Times, Frank J. Prial, said, "The Gallos' influence has been enormous -- and far more positive and benevolent than most people think."
But the company has had its troubles. It signed a consent decree in 1976 with the Federal Trade Commission to stop pressuring its wholesalers; the order was rescinded in 1983.
The winery was also boycotted for five years in the 1970's by the United Farm Workers in a dispute over worker representation.
In 1986, the Gallo winery sued Ernest and Julio Gallo's younger brother, Joseph, who had earlier managed vineyards for his brothers. The suit involved accusations of trademark infringement related to Joseph's opening of a cheese factory near his home in Livingston, Calif., using the family name. Legal documents and depositions in the case gave the public a rare look inside the business.
Eventually, the winery prevailed in its litigation with Joseph, who was barred by a court from using the family name in business.
Documents from the litigation and other data were the basis for a recent book, "Blood and Wine: the Unauthorized Story of the Gallo Wine Empire" (Simon & Schuster), which chronicled the family's rise and Joseph's counter-contention that Julio and Ernest had cheated him of one-third ownership in the business.
The author, Ellen Hawkes, recounted how the brothers' father, Joseph Gallo Sr., also known as Giuseppe, was a pubkeeper who entered grape-growing when Prohibition began, and went on to become a large-scale provider of wine grapes to the eastern United States, where home winemakers were legally permitted to make 200 gallons of wine a year during Prohibition.
Ms. Hawkes contended that Joseph Gallo Sr. shot his wife, Susie, to death and then turned the weapon on himself. The deaths were ruled a murder-suicide by the police, but the author reported that the motive was never known.
She argued that it was the elder Mr. Gallo who founded the Gallo Wine Company, in 1909, and that Ernest and Julio simply continued the business. The company's official history, however, said the two sons founded the company outright. It said the two were untutored in winemaking when their parents died and had to learn the art from a booklet they found in a library.
 
A Matter of Pride

The company grew primarily because of the popularity of Gallo's inexpensive wines. The company's success was a matter of fervent pride for both Julio and Ernest Gallo. Fred T. Franzia, a nephew of Ernest who became the president of the Bronco Wine Company, a small rival, once said: "They want to go out being known as the greatest winemakers, as well as the greatest wine marketers."
The bespectacled Julio Gallo was in charge of orchestrating the wines' tastes and controlling production costs. He and his staff got the grapes largely from California growers who had signed long-term contracts with the company.
Under his guidance, the wine business was a technology innovator. It pioneered the use of stainless-steel winemaking vats and computers for wine blending.
Although most of the Gallo wine output is unpretentious, a Gallo vice president, Charles Crawford, once said that when Mr. Gallo began making a premium-quality Chardonnay -- which was introduced in 1981 -- he was so discriminating that half the crushed grapes were rejected.
Mr. Gallo was largely responsible for the company's longtime refusal to turn out vintage wines -- those made from grapes grown in a single winemaking year, or vintage.
But the Gallo brothers eventually broadened their range of products and began producing, and energetically marketing, varietal and vintage wines, which have greater appeal to sophisticated wine drinkers. In the 1970's the company built a 200-yard-long subterranean complex for aging the varietals. It was furnished with more than 600 oak wine-aging casks, each with a capacity of 4,000 gallons.
While overseeing such wide-scale operations, Mr. Gallo did not stint on research, and the company prides itself on employing platoons of chemists and viniculturists. Aggressive product research has enabled the company over the years to introduce successful and relatively inexpensive products like Thunderbird, Ripple, Spanada and Boone's Farm for the mass market
In so doing, the company incurred widespread criticism for appealing to minority groups with some wines that were generally perceived as cheap and meant for drinkers who were interested in the alcohol's effect, not in the wine's savor. Thunderbird, Ripple and other inexpensive wines with relatively high alcohol content are often referred to in the wine industry as street wines.
In recent years, the Gallo business has broadened its market by promoting its midpriced wines and its Bartles & Jaymes wine coolers.
Another problem for the company has been that growth in the consumption of wine in the United States has slowed, except in the premium wine category. People are drinking less wine, but drinking wine of higher quality, industry analysts report.
The Gallo brothers, seeing sales of some of their traditional wine categories dwindle, began making a major effort to shift their production into premium wine categories.
With that goal in mind, Julio Gallo was highly active in his last years in the company's vast program to develop new vineyards, mostly in premium grape-growing regions in Sonoma County in northern California.
Mr. Gallo was born March 21, 1910, in Oakland, Calif., grew up outside Modesto and was graduated in 1929 from Modesto High School. In his early years, he labored in a vineyard near Modesto that belonged to his father, an immigrant from the Piedmont region, in north and northwestern Italy, which also has a wine industry.
In addition to his wife and the two granddaughters, Julio Gallo is survived by a son, Robert J. of Modesto; a daughter, Susan Coleman, and numerous other grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Broadly Lower And British Pound Retreats

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Despite an early spurt, the dollar ended broadly lower yesterday on a report that the American manufacturing economy shrank in April for the first time in seven months.
The report was the latest in a string of negative economic data and cast a shadow on a day already marked by thin trading. Markets in Tokyo and London were closed for holidays. 
 But the British pound retreated amid speculation that Britain's recovery may not be as strong as indicated by recent figures.
The dollar was up more than a pfennig against the German mark in the morning, but reversed course when the National Association of Purchasing Management released its monthly survey showing that the manufacturing economy contracted in April.
The April weakness further demonstrated that March's widely reported gloom could not be brushed aside as just the product of winter storms.
"I got the feeling the market is rethinking this whole recovery scenario," said Robert Ortiz, vice president in corporate sales at Continental Bank in Chicago.
The bearish dollar sentiment is building ahead of Friday, when the Government is to release employment figures for April, the month's most closely watched economic data.
But the dollar rose nearly 1 pence against the British pound. Lisa Pazer, an analyst with MMS International, traced the movement to a report in The Sunday Observer that the British Government had manipulated recent unemployment data to paint an overly rosy economic picture.
Traders said the report was "the fundamental backdrop to what happened in the pound today," the MMS analyst said.
The pound was quoted at $1.5620 in European trading, down from $1.5700 late Friday in London. In New York, the pound settled at $1.5650, down from $1.5733 late Friday.
The dollar slipped against the yen in New York trading, closing at 110.78 yen, down from 111.10 late Friday.
Financial markets were closed in Britain for a spring bank holiday. Markets are also closed until Thursday in Japan for a series of holidays.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Surge in Silver Is Halted; Weak Industrial Data Cited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver futures prices fell from a 21-month high yesterday after an industrial survey signaled weakness in the manufacturing economy. Gold and platinum prices also fell.
In other commodities markets, grains and soybeans ended mixed; hog futures surged, and oil futures rose. 
 Silver for May delivery dropped 9.9 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, to $4.29 an ounce. The contract traded as high as $4.45 during the session, 6.1 cents above Friday's settlement and the highest price for spot deliveries since July 1991.
June gold fell $1.90, to $354.40 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange. July platinum dropped $3.30 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, to $386.60 an ounce.
Investment funds sold silver after seven straight days of gains that had increased its price by 54 cents -- about 14 percent. The selling was prompted in part, said analysts, by the report by the National Association of Purchasing Management, saying that the manufacturing economy contracted in April for the first time in seven months.
The report "injected some caution in the trade," said Stephen Platt, metals analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds in Chicago. He said the market was due for a correction after the recent gains. Silver has industrial uses and is regarded by some as an indicator of industrial activity.
Analysts did not pronounce dead a longer rally in silver that had lifted its price by nearly 27 percent -- from a low on Feb. 22 of $3.51 an ounce -- but neither did they express confidence that it would soon resume.
"We've never really trusted the rally in silver," said George Milling-Stanley, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York. "There's nothing on the fundamental front to justify it."
In other commodities markets, the prices of grain and soybean futures ended mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade in advance of a corn-crop report after the close that said there would be planting delays because of bad weather.
Hog and pork-belly futures rose sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on reports of surprisingly light sales of hogs to meatpackers.
Light crude oil for June delivery rose 4 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange, to $20.57 a barrel.

HEADLINE: Savings Bond Rate Falls

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
United States savings bonds will earn interest at a rate of 4.78 percent for the next six months, the lowest since the Government began selling variable-rate bonds in 1982, the Treasury Department said today. The new rate, in effect through Oct. 30, is down from 5.04 percent the last six months. Rates are adjusted every May 1 and Nov. 1 to reflect changes in market-based rates.

HEADLINE: City Lights and Space Ads May Blind Stargazers

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
AS the glare of artificial light spreads ever more pervasively across the planet's night skies, astronomers are having nightmares.
America's great observatories now face the possibility that huge commercial billboards may soon be rocketed into orbit, while cities fearful of crime are flooding the night sky with ever brighter lights. Added to this plague of light pollution, astronomical observatories also face increasing interference from such mundane sources as radio-operated garage-door openers, 
 For much of the 20th century, astronomers have waged a losing campaign to keep night skies as dark as possible. Light pollution is a particular problem for the largest telescopes, which seek out the most distant and faintest galaxies at the edge of the universe. But now, great observatories that were once safely distant from the scattered glow of city lights are seriously threatened. Many scientists believe that the day will come when terrestrial astronomy becomes unproductive, and optical and radio telescopes will have to move to the far side of the Moon.
Two of the latest developments astronomers see as threats are indirect results of America's recession. The economic malaise has blighted downtown shopping districts, with the result that cities are scrambling to make them more appealing, in part by adding bright lights. The economy has also reduced Federal financing of several branches of science, leading some Government scientists to work with promoters on such projects as commercial advertising in space.
A major uproar followed the announcement last month that Space Marketing Inc. of Roswell, Ga., in cooperation with Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California and the University of Colorado, planned to launch a one-mile-wide display satellite into orbit around Earth. The spacecraft, made of thin plastic film, would reflect sunlight to Earth from aluminized letters or symbols. Orbiting at an altitude of about 180 miles, the sign would be just legible to the naked eye.
A description by its developers says that from the ground the satellite will appear to be somewhere between the size of the full moon and the size of a half moon, depending on variations in atmospheric effects. But highly reflective parts of the spacecraft that catch the Sun at an optimum angle may make it seem much brighter than the Moon. The "orbiting billboard," as detractors call it, would carry instruments made by Livermore to study Earth's atmosphere, and would entail no direct expense to the Government. Instead, the project would be supported by commercial sponsors, who would gain the right to use the spacecraft's symbol in their advertising.
The announcement prompted an angry letter to astronomers throughout the world from Dr. Derek McNally, a British astronomer who is chairman of an environmental committee of the United Nations International Council of Scientific Unions.
"The ultimate disaster for astronomical science is now clearly identified: commercial advertising from space," he wrote. "Such a misuse of space involving the launch of solar reflectors carrying advertising material, to appear as bright as the Moon (as a minimum), orbiting with 90-minute periods, will virtually wipe out deep-sky astronomy."
Mike Lawson, president of Space Marketing, denied in an interview that the proposed spacecraft would hurt astronomy. "The purpose of our 'Environmental Space Platform' is to help scientists who could not otherwise afford to do so to put environmental sensors into orbit," he said. "The project will be supported by commercial sponsors identified with environmental causes, who can display our symbol in advertising, just as sponsors of the Olympics do."
The mile-wide spacecraft, shaped like an ordinary billboard, would be visible over any given spot on Earth for only about 10 minutes at a time, and would not be visible at all during the middle of the night when it would be out of reach of the Sun's rays, its designers say.
When it is launched in 1996, it will cause astronomical observatories no more problems than do airplanes flying across the lines of sight of the big telescopes, Mr. Lawson said. Moreover, the "Environmental Space Platform," consisting almost entirely of thin Mylar plastic film, would re-enter the atmosphere and burn up within 20 days of launching.
These assurances have not mollified opponents.
 
'Trojan Horse' in Sky
 The Center for the Study of Commercialism, a public interest group in Washington, is organizing a coalition of scientists and laymen to oppose the project. "We see this orbiting billboard as a Trojan horse," said Karen Brown, a spokeswoman for the organization. "A would-be space advertiser needs only a permit from the Department of Transportation to launch his satellite. The Space Marketing satellite may be the first of many."
Dr. Preston Carter of Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, who is working with Space Marketing on the project, explained that the billboard satellite could be packed into a very small container for launching by a Delta rocket or even a smaller Conestoga rocket, or by a fairly small European, Russian, Chinese or Japanese rocket. In space, gas would be used to inflate thin Mylar tubes forming the rigid structure of the sign, and this structure would support a huge sheet of Mylar that would face Earth.
With the end of the cold war, Lawrence Livermore, a Federal nuclear weapons laboratory, has been ordered to apply as much of its scientific expertise and equipment as possible to benefit the economy. Support of commercial projects in space appears to fall within this new mandate.
But even without space advertising, astronomers are fighting against lengthening odds to stem the flood of light and radio pollution that spoils many types of measurement.
One of the latest threats to astronomy has arisen in the city of San Diego, where urban blight and crime have squeezed many businesses out of downtown neighborhoods. Many residents and merchants attribute the flight of businesses to the city's street lights, which, since their installation in 1984, have bathed the city in the bright, pure yellow light produced by low-pressure sodium vapor.
Viewed through a prism, this light is concentrated in two rather narrow lines of the spectrum, lines that can be filtered out by astronomical observatories. Yellow low-pressure sodium street lighting is important to observers using the mighty 200-inch telescope at Mount Palomar about 40 miles away. (The size of astronomical telescopes is expressed in inches or meters as the diameter of their light-collecting mirrors.)
 
San Diego Lighting Plan
 But last month a committee of the San Diego City Council voted to replace some of the low-pressure sodium lights with high-pressure sodium lights that emit a peach-colored light. This light is smeared across most of the visible spectrum, and astronomers cannot filter it out.
In the next several weeks, after a vote by the City Council, the city government is expected to order the change. A spokesman for Mayor Susan Golding, who spoke on condition that his name be withheld, said he knew of no scientific studies proving that lighting had any direct effect on crime.
"But a lot of people in San Diego object to these yellow lights -- bug lights, they call them -- partly because they wash out all color, and partly because the lights are perceived as invitations to crime," he said.
Dr. Robert J. Brucato, assistant director of the Palomar Observatory, which is administered by the California Institute of Technology, said: "This is a very unfortunate development. It's hard to say at this point just how damaging high-pressure sodium lighting will be for us, but it's bound to hurt observations of very faint objects -- the distant galaxies and quasars that are the main thrust of astrophysical science these days.
"Caltech is not asking San Diego to tolerate a high crime rate, but we don't know of any evidence that yellow light promotes crime any more than white light."
An investigation in 1980 by the National Institute of Law Enforcement and Criminal Justice concluded that "while there is no statistically significant evidence that street lighting impacts the level of crime, there is a strong indication that increased lighting -- perhaps lighting uniformity -- decreases the fear of crime."
 
Losing Battle in New York
 The lights seem not to be widely used outside of California, although statistics are not readily available. In New York City, for instance, where high-pressure sodium is the standard, astronomers at Columbia University, which has quite a large telescope, "gave up the fight many years ago," said Dr. Joseph Patterson, a professor of astronomy.
Light pollution has increasingly forced major observatories to move their resources away from the continental United States to darker places, including the mountains of northern Chile. "In California, light pollution from Santa Cruz and other communities was one of the reasons we decided to move much of our support to observatories on Mauna Kea mountain on the island of Hawaii," said Dr. Stan E. Woosley of the Lick Observatory.
Although light pollution is degrading astronomy in California, some other states seem to be holding the line. Dr. David Crawford of the Kitt Peak National Observatory in Arizona said the city governments of Tucson and other nearby communities had been highly cooperative in reducing sky glow by using low-pressure sodium lighting and placing shields over outdoor lights. Hawaii also maintains strict rules limiting outdoor lighting to protect the large observatories on Mauna Kea.
Light pollution does not necessarily block all forms of optical astronomy, and a great old telescope exposed to the lights of Pasadena, Calif., may have gained a new lease on life.
In 1917 when it was commissioned, the 100-inch telescope on Mount Wilson near Pasadena (affectionately known as "the 100-inch") began a career of breathtaking observations that reshaped understanding of the universe. In the 1930's Edwin Hubble and his colleagues used the 100-inch in their historic discovery that the universe is expanding. But by 1985, the lights of Pasadena had washed out the sky to such an extent that the Carnegie Institution of Washington decided to close down the 100-inch.
In 1989, however, astronomers and other admirers of the 100-inch created the Mount Wilson Institute and began soliciting donations to put the great telescope back to work. Dr. Robert Jastrow, head of the institute, said he hoped that this goal would be realized in July.
"Light from incandescent lamps in communities near Mount Wilson will continue to prevent deep-space observation by the 100-inch," he said, "but we can still do important work on objects within our own galaxy -- hunting for planetary systems, for example."
 
Problem of Radio Interference
 Stray visible light is merely one of the plagues of astronomy. Another is a thickening global smog of radio interference.
As astronomers increasingly focus on objects at enormous distances from Earth, they must concentrate on the part of the electromagnetic spectrum consisting of radio waves. Because the universe is expanding, light reaching Earth from distant objects undergoes a Doppler shift analogous to the drop in the pitch of a train whistle as it recedes from a listener. The recession of distant objects from Earth shifts visible light to lower frequencies in the radio range, and radiotelescopes are therefore increasingly important to astronomy.
But radio interference has sharply increased in recent decades. Powerful commercial broadcasting stations sometimes cooperate closely with radiotelescopes to avoid washing out signals from distant space, but a more serious problem, according to Dr. A. Richard Thompson of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory at Charlottesville, Va., is the radio haze created by small appliances.
"A lot of things laymen take for granted give us a lot of trouble," he said. "Things like welding machines, automobile computers and ignition systems, fluorescent lights, electric motors, and so on. And then there are things like radio-operated garage door openers.
"Paradoxically," Dr. Thompson said, "large sources of radio pollution are easier for us to identify and compensate for than are weak radio sources. The weak signals get mixed into the radio background, and are very hard to separate from the extremely weak signals from space we're looking for."
What of the future?
"We worry about a lot of things we see coming -- mobile phone systems that will go directly through a galaxy of 77 communication satellites, for example.
"I guess it's possible that eventually we'll be chased away to the Moon, if we want to continue doing astronomy," Dr. Thompson said.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Time For Apologies

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Something important is missing in all the talk about how only American muscle and guts are bringing peace in Bosnia -- an apology to Cyrus Vance and Lord David Owen.
The apology is a matter of decency. It is also a matter of understanding what happened, to help protect the peace in case it actually comes about. 
 Apology is due to these two honorable men from all the columnists, editorial writers, politicians and academics who vilified them while they fought for a political basis for peace.
I have been in rooms where journalists treated them as prisoners in the dock. In print, they were accused of being Chamberlains, of creating a new Munich, of selling out freedom and human rights, by outlining a political settlement.
Americans, private and journalistic, sent hate mail and spread dinner-table nastiness. I got all that myself just for supporting the Vance-Owen plan that is now accepted by Europe, the U.S., Belgrade and all Bosnians but a small group of Serbian hard-liners.
Mr. Vance said little in counterattack; that is his way. But Lord Owen has a fine tongue in him, which let it be known he has only one cheek to give to his country.
The Clinton Administration did not denounce them. But during the campaign and after inauguration, it wasted months by refusing to support the Vance-Owen plan.
Washington implied it could do better. But, like the journalistic and political packs, it came up with nothing else. That meant the U.S. could exert no decisive pressure on the combatants because it had nothing to offer.
When the Clinton Administration decided there was more to the Presidency than hey baby -- hey baby, it's all about money -- it began doing well. It accepted Vance-Owen, acknowledging it was the difference between peace, with all the Balkan complications, and the continuation of a particularly horrible civil war.
Washington also supported increased sanctions against Serbia itself. And Mr. Clinton's team resisted the American Bombing Association. Every day it was after them to start plastering Bosnian Serbs right away, yesterday, and get on smartly with bombing Belgrade.
That would have made the Balkan war an American war. That could still happen.
But resisting bombing for so long paid off for the U.S. Last week Belgrade backed far off from its Bosnian Serbian clients.
Maybe advance bombing talk helped. But Belgrade acted before Mr. Clinton made up his mind. Tough U.N. sanctions were biting deep into Serbia's economy, far deeper than into Iraq's before Desert Storm. Serbia is intimately tied into European markets, and did not have the advantage of Jordanian sanction-breaking so useful to Saddam Hussein.
Now the mighty U.S. and a small bunch of Bosnian Serbian hard-liners have each other by the throat.
Mr. Clinton has just about committed himself to bombing if the Bosnian hard-liners turn down Vance-Owen. Neither he nor the American public want that. And if the hard-liners in the Bosnian Serbian "parliament" do refuse -- or double-cross the U.N. later -- they will be bringing American power into the war, which their own sponsors in Belgrade are desperately trying to avoid.
I have been against the U.S. entering the war by bombing. But like people everywhere I hope the Bosnian hard-liners listen to the world and do not bring bombing down on their countrymen.
The critics of Vance-Owen choose to forget that the plan is not simply the only settlement on the table. It also includes the essential condition for any peace: a military schedule for disengagement and partial disarmament by all parties.
The U.S. still does not have what it needs most -- clear-cut understanding about how deep in the U.S. will get, and when if ever it will get out. But without the disengagement part of Vance-Owen, U.S. troops sent to join a U.N. force in Bosnia would be not keeping a peace but fighting a war from the day they landed -- something Mr. Clinton said he would not do.
Since it is not likely that Mr. Vance, his outstanding deputy Herbert Okun or Lord Owen will get their apology from their vilifiers, here's one to a member of the trio from a supporter.
In one column I referred to Lord Owen as a rather crabby Englishman. He corrected me: Welshman, he said, Welshman.

HEADLINE: Water-Rate Freeze Maintains a Balance

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Marjorie Shea and Peg Kocher wrote (letter, April 20) to express their concern that my program for affordable water and sewer rates -- a two-year rate freeze followed by at least a two-year inflation-limited cap on rate growth -- would produce cutbacks in resources for watershed protection and other critical environmental programs. This is a misplaced anxiety.
Our rate freeze is based on a plan developed by the Department of Environmental Protection that establishes long-term balance between revenues and key service needs. That plan reprioritizes the use of D.E.P. resources to increase investment in long-term, cost-saving programs: watershed protection, water conservation, preventive infrastructure maintenance and customer service. 
 This includes funding for over 350 watershed-protection personnel upstate, $47 million in capital funds for land acquisition, over $60 million in capital funds to upgrade our sewage-treatment plants upstate, and another $120 million in capital funds for additional watershed-protection investments over the coming decade.
My administration fully understands that spending money to prevent watershed pollution, instead of spending far greater sums later on filtration to clean it up, is the best way to protect both the public health and the pocketbook of our people.
These policies require a long-term vision and an ability to make long-term resource commitments. The rate freeze will not threaten that.
 
DAVID N. DINKINS
Mayor
New York, April 21, 1993

HEADLINE: A Test for Clinton in Race for Aspin's Seat Today

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JANESVILLE, Wis., May 3

 BODY:
Bill Clinton is not on the ballot, but he is definitely in the campaign here to fill Les Aspin's seat in the United States House. The Republican candidate is running against the President, and his Democratic opponent is running away from him in Tuesday's special election.
The rolling dairy lands and lakeside industrial towns in the southeast corner of the state is a swing district, Republican in some Presidential elections, Democratic in others. 
 But this time around, local polls indicate that the race in the First District between Mark Neumann, a Republican home developer, and his Democratic opponent, State Representative Peter Barca, is too close to call.
The contest may finally come down to a tug-of-war between organized labor, which generally backs Mr. Barca, and a coalition of people opposed to gun control and abortion, backing Mr. Neumann, over who can get out the larger vote.
Mr. Neumann has attracted President Gerald R. Ford, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas and former Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp to campaign for him and back up his contention that the election is a referendum on President Clinton's first 100 days.
At a fund-raising event in Janesville on Saturday night, Mr. Dole, the Senate minority leader, said the vote would be "a preliminary indication of how the President is doing."
 
Is Clinton Really a Factor?
 Voter turnout could be as low as 25 percent because it is a special election. And many voters and local political analysts scoff at the notion that the race is a vote about Mr. Clinton, saying that such an idea only has importance in Washington. Nevertheless, the tenor of the campaign suggests that support for Mr. Clinton's message and economic program may be eroding in the nation's midsection.
At a rally in downtown Janesville in a pouring rain today, Mr. Neumann told supporters that the election results would reverberate around the country. "The news stories on national television Wednesday can either be the people of Wisconsin have sent a vote of confidence for President Clinton, or the news story can be, we do not want the tax increases," he said.
In radio debates and campaign speeches, both candidates have railed against the free-trade agreement with Mexico, which Mr. Clinton has generally endorsed, and they have competed over plans for cutting spending.
Mr. Neumann has strongly opposed Mr. Clinton's economic package, and Mr. Barca has suggested that he might also vote against it if it includes the proposed energy tax, which he says would hurt manufacturing in Wisconsin.
Mr. Barca pointedly noted in an interview Saturday that he did not invite any national Democrats to campaign for him. "If I supported the President on everything, lock, stock and barrel, then there would be a referendum," he said.
In another interview with editors of The Wisconsin State Journal last Tuesday, he was quoted as saying, "I don't think Clinton's plan is that hot, frankly."
 
Lining Up Constituencies
 Mr. Barca, the third-ranking Democrat in the state Assembly, bases his election hopes on his reputation as a longtime friend of the auto workers and members of the government employees union in Racine, Kenosha, Beloit and Janesville.
Mr. Neumann is counting on the farm vote, and hopes rainy weather will persuade the farmers to take time off from plowing their soybean and corn fields to vote. He has campaigned by jogging across the winding side roads of the district, a stunt that has gained him favorable publicity in the farm-town press.
A victory for Mr. Neumann, who lost in a challenge to Mr. Aspin last November but gained valuable name-recognition in the process, would raise the Republican membership in the House to 177 members against 257 Democrats and one independent.
In another special election on Tuesday, a Republican is expected to win easily in Ohio, where Representative Bill Gradison retired before his term ended.
Mr. Aspin represented the Wisconsin district for 22 years before his appointment as Defense Secretary, but the district voted heavily in favor of President Ronald Reagan in 1980 and 1984, for the Democrat Michael S. Dukakis in 1988 and for Mr. Clinton last fall. Ross Perot won nearly 25 percent of last November's votes.
Most voters do not seem to link the election directly to their feelings about the President.
After shaking hands with Mr. Barca at a bingo get-together at the Racine Y.M.C.A. on Saturday evening, Rick Bernal, a 33-year-old foundry worker, said: "I don't believe Clinton is living up to his words, particularly on taxes. But I'm going to vote for Barca because he's with the union."
Odile Kirby, 75, a hostess at a fast-food restaurant, agreed, saying: "Why should this be a referendum? Clinton does his thing and we in Wisconsin do our thing."

HEADLINE: Middle-Class but Not Feeling Equal, Blacks Reflect on Los Angeles Strife

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Every so often, Dr. Delaney Smith will pull out a year-old videotape and relive the Los Angeles riots on his wide-screen television, watching the flames rise against the night sky and feeling the rage of his people all over again as the liquor stores and gas stations burn only blocks from his home.
"It has never left me," Dr. Smith, an internist who specializes in emergency medicine, said recently. "It brings me back to my roots. I don't ever want to forget." 
 For middle-class blacks who are living evidence of the nation's civil rights gains, the beating of Rodney King and the recent second trial of four white police officers in the case have been agonizing reminders of how much more has to change before they are truly accepted as equals.
Interviews with more than 70 well-to-do blacks in Los Angeles and around the country suggest that blacks did not find the convictions of two of the four officers a catharsis or a cause for celebration. Rather, they saw those verdicts as a grudging half step toward justice, a bittersweet culmination of a very bleak year.
 
'The Deepest Sadness'
 "When I heard the verdicts, I couldn't stop crying," said Dr. Donna Franklin, a Chicago writer and consultant. "It was crying of the deepest sadness. One piece of it was release. The other was, 'Will our children ever know the absence of racism?' "
She and others interviewed said they had lowered their expectations about race relations over the last year. They told of efforts to stand up to indignities and said they were rethinking their spending habits, putting money and economic clout behind other blacks and black-owned businesses.
Despite the whoops and cheers from a black church near the South-Central district that bore the brunt of the riots, there was no jubilation along predominantly black Crenshaw Boulevard or in the black middle-class sections of Leimert Park or Inglewood, all in or near the South-Central area.
"Justice was blind in one eye," said Dr. Richard Williams, a Los Angeles cardiologist. "Here was a black man who was severely beaten, and they only convict 50 percent of the people charged with beating him."
Those interviewed in Los Angeles said they had spent the last year trying to focus the anger they felt toward the officers who beat Mr. King, toward a Simi Valley jury that had acquitted them of state criminal charges, toward what they see as unequal treatment for blacks in everyday dealings in a white-dominated society.
The people who embraced integration in their climb into the middle class are now talking with bitterness and resignation about separation and solidarity. Last year's despair, they said, has turned to defiance.
"We have had to look in the mirror of our society," said Steven Lott, an architect here. "What I see is very ugly."
 
Citing Toll of Verdict
 He and others say they were angered that the officers' guilt in the beating took two trials, millions of dollars in legal fees, riots, millions more in lost property and dozens of lives to prove.
"Look at what it took to get this verdict," said Doris Davis, a Los Angeles teacher, a quaver in her voice.
While others talk of healing, those interviewed talked of doing for themselves and supporting one another in the way they said the Jews and Asians had done.
Many have turned inward in the last year, transferring money to black-owned institutions from white-owned banks, seeking out black businesses to repair their automobiles or buy wall-to-wall carpeting. They have been creating consortiums and cooperatives to serve the inner city and generally viewing the country as a more hostile place than they did before the Simi Valley jury verdict.
"We carry around a rage in us," said Walter Allen, a professor of sociology at the University of California at Los Angeles, who has written on racial issues. "We carry the weight of the race and the weight of racism. The Rodney King case has radicalized black folks that used to be mild-mannered. It has brought people face to face with the country's racial caste system."
Some are showing solidarity by putting their money where their concerns are. Since the riots, some black businesses are reporting banner years, with black customers seeking out the companies to show their support.
"I will drive on fumes to get to a black gas station," said Zna Portlock, a lawyer who, while recently looking for a new doctor, went down a list of physicians and called their offices to see which ones were black.
Gerald Hutchinson, owner of an auto-body shop in the Crenshaw District, said the beating case had done more for business than the few advertisements he used to buy. "It's a shame to have this happen for people to be more aware," he said, "but it's paying off."
The three black-owned financial institutions in Los Angeles posted gains in deposits despite the recession, which slowed growth at some other banks. At Founders National Bank in South-Central, deposits rose to $75 million from $60 million. The accounts held by black churches tripled to 50 after the riots, said Carlton Jenkins, the bank's managing director.
Deposits at the black-owned Broadway Federal Savings and Loan rose to $3 million from $2 million, while those at Family Savings Bank rose to $113 million from $109 million.
Mr. Lott, the architect, said he had transferred his firm's account to Founders after nine years at a white-owned bank, which he said had made the company jump hurdles for routine services like providing a line of credit despite the firm's good credit rating.
 
Making Banking Inconvenient
 Allysunn Walker, executive director of a youth program here, recently closed her account at Security Pacific Bank and opened a checking account, savings account and certificate of deposit at a black institution, Family Savings Bank.
The location of the bank, in the heart of the South-Central district, was not especially convenient, the rates were no better and, in fact, the switch meant she had to rearrange her schedule to do her banking in the daytime, when she feels safer in the neighborhood. But the place is black-owned, they know her by name and she likes the idea that the money will go for loans to blacks.
"My money is a little money, but it's mine," she said. "I feel like I'm indirectly helping my people."
Others are showing a new and tentative sense of oneness in other ways. Barbara Blackman, a librarian, stood in line at a Pasadena beauty-supply shop with her teen-age daughter Cherika and a half-dozen blacks recently and grew uncomfortable as she watched an Asian clerk scold a black man trying to make a return.
"The clerk was yelling and screaming at him," Mrs. Blackman said. "It was very disrespectful. He had only made the purchase an hour before. Suddenly someone in line said: 'We don't have to take this. We can take our money somewhere else.' "
The whole line of customers set their shampoo and rollers on the counter and walked out. "It was a matter of supporting this man," Mrs. Blackman said. "I said, 'Cherika, let's go.' Society needs to realize that we do have a certain amount of dignity and pride."
This has not been an ordinary year, as Mrs. Davis, the school teacher here, found when she was collecting some forms from her fellow teachers. She said she had asked a white teacher for hers. When the teacher did not have it ready to turn in, she appeared nervous and agitated and said, "What are you going to do if I don't get mine in -- burn down my house?"
She said racial fears reached an absurd point one day when her 23-year-old nephew visited her school in his baggy pants and dreadlocks. When he waved to her from down the hall, two white co-workers ducked.
"No matter how far we thought we had gotten, we haven't gotten anywhere," she said, the pain of years of rejection in her voice. "We've tried to become part of this country. Trying to impress white people is like trying to impress your daddy. No matter what you do, they still see color first. I say, forget them."
Blacks and the rest of Los Angeles are tensely awaiting the next legal developments in the case -- the sentencing of the police officers and the trial of four blacks in the beating of Reginald Denny, a white truck driver, on the first day of rioting.
Some blacks are already angry at what they see as a double standard, where the black defendants face higher bail than the white officers and more serious charges -- attempted murder -- for what they see as a nearly identical beating. They say they are troubled by the implication that crimes against whites are considered more serious than those against blacks.
"When they do something to a white man, all of a sudden it matters," Professor Allen said. "If they do something to a black person, it's fine."
At the core of all this is the sense that no matter how much shampoo or gasoline they buy from black businesses, there is little they can do about economic and racial inequities that create privileged white suburbs and desperate minority ghettos.
"It wasn't us that needed to change," said Wesley Snipes, the actor who lives just west of Los Angeles. "The change has to come from white America."
Indeed, there is deep frustration that the riots got so much more attention than the unemployment, poverty, crime, isolation and racism that many believe set the scene for the turmoil.
"What matters is what led to the rebellion in the first place, and none of that has been addressed," said Dr. Medria Williams, a black clinical psychologist who counsels teachers and students in the South-Central district. "The country has learned nothing from this, and that is the tragedy."

LENGTH: 1154 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON SEES NEED TO FOCUS HIS GOALS AND SHARPEN STAFF

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
Smarting from losses in early battles with Congress and from criticism of his first 100 days, President Clinton conceded today that his White House was "out of focus" and that his staff needed to be better organized.
Mr. Clinton, overburdened by his own crowded agenda, admitted his dissatisfaction in remarks to reporters in which he outlined a new effort to focus his Administration. 
 "One of the things that you risk when you try to get a lot of things going in a hurry -- and we tried to get a lot of things going in a hurry because four years passes in a hurry -- is that you wind up having people work very, very hard but maybe getting a little out of focus," he said. "And I think we can bring it -- tighten the focus a little, and I think that's what we ought to do."
 
2d Deputy Is Likely
 To help in that effort, he said, he will probably appoint a second deputy to assist his longtime friend, Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the chief of staff. The Administration mentioned no names in connection with the new appointment.
Administration officials say Mr. McLarty has been stretched thin trying to oversee both the White House's internal operations and Mr. Clinton's relations with Congress.
Mr. Clinton's unusual mea culpa was delivered in the Oval Office on a day in which his Secretary of State traveled abroad seeking support for the Administration's desire to lift the arms embargo against Bosnian Muslims and its plan to use air strikes against Bosnian Serbs.
At home, in the face of a looming Congressional defeat, Mr. Clinton had to retreat from his program on childhood vaccinations. But the White House also tossed another program into the political mix on Capitol Hill today: an $8 billion, five-year project to revitalize the nation's cities. [Page B9.]
 
Lack of Staff Coordination
 Mr. Clinton and members of his senior White House staff have admitted in recent weeks that their approach to government has often been scattershot. The President's $19.5 billion plan to stimulate the economy foundered under the weight of a Republican filibuster in the Senate because of political and communications problems. Efforts to sell Mr. Clinton's emerging health-care plan, hampered by secrecy and presented so far mainly as a package of new taxes, also appeared to be in trouble.
Mr. Clinton suggested today that one problem was a lack of coordination within his staff. "We think that there needs to be a little tighter coordination here to make sure that we've got our priorities straight, and that those priorities are communicated all the way down through the staff, and a little better focus," he said.
Mr. McLarty has maintained an unusually low profile for a senior White House aide, spending much of his time running the White House staff and smoothing relations with Congress. He is assisted by Mark D. Gearan, the only deputy chief of staff, who was appointed after Harold I. Ickes, a longtime New York politician, was dropped from consideration.
Unlike previous Administrations, when chiefs of staff like John H. Sununu and Donald T. Regan were attacked by their own aides in tough political times, the Clinton White House showed no signs of internal sniping at Mr. McLarty's performance.
 
'Not a Big Shake-Uup'
 Mr. Clinton went out of his way to say that he felt his staff had generally done a good job "on balance."
"As nearly as I can tell, we put more major initiatives out there in 100 days than any of my recent predecessors," he said, "and we're working on some very major problems."
During the Presidential campaign, power shifts became commonplace in the Clinton campaign as the fortunes of various consultants and advisers rose and fell. But Mr. Clinton seldom dismissed anyone, even if the person fell out of favor.
"There's not a big shake-up coming," one official said today. "But there will always be changes.
"It is as much a decision to look forward as to look back. We've had a lot of balls in the air in the last 100 days, and it doesn't get easier. It gets harder when you have health care and reconciliation coming up."
 
Critique of a Friend
 Mr. Clinton appears to hold special affection for and loyalty to Mr. McLarty, a childhood friend and former energy company executive who had little Washington experience before his appointment. But by acknowledging that his friend needed more help, Mr. Clinton seemed to be admitting what Democrats outside the White House have only speculated about: Mr. McLarty might lack the political acumen expected of a President's chief of staff.
White House officials said the coming changes should not be considered a wholesale revamping of West Wing responsibility. Instead, they said, the result could be that White House officials will begin grouping into clusters to meet on issues with an eye toward covering the political, policy and legislative bases.
A White House official who spoke on the condition of anonymity said senior aides had been meeting for weeks to "kind of just figure out how we can get to the top of our game in the longer term."
But in the current atmosphere, even an offhand comment was enough to drive the President off course. On Monday, Mr. Clinton was forced to apologize to Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, for a mocking joke delivered at the White House correspondents' dinner on Saturday night. The President accused Mr. Dole -- falsely as it turned out -- of trying to gain $23 million in Government pork-barrel spending for his home state of Kansas.
 
Mrs. Clinton Reappears
 The White House has responded recently to at least some of the criticism. Hillary Rodham Clinton, who had come under fire for closing her health-care task force meetings and who had stayed mostly out of reporters' reach since the inauguration, has begun granting interviews again. This week she appeared on the cover of three national magazines.
And after weeks of preoccupation with Washington politics, Mr. Clinton has also begun looking outward again. David Wilhelm, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has been charged with reporting to the President on what voters are saying around the country.
"What I think we need to do, frankly, is to get the focus back on to the things that I have been working on from the beginning," Mr. Clinton said. "Passing the major economic programs; giving -- making sure that Congress will adopt the spending cuts, but reaffirming that I have no interest in raising taxes until spending is cut -- no tax increases without the spending cuts; getting the budget program through so that we can keep interest rates down.
"After all, I just got here. I've never operated here before, and there are some things that are very different about the way Washington works -- some good, and some not so good.
"But I think that we're on the right track, and I just want to focus now on the work before us, which is passing this budget."

HEADLINE: Delay Sought in Law Meant to Trim Welfare Rolls

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration asked Congress today to postpone the effective date of a law passed under President Ronald Reagan that would require states to find jobs or job training for tens of thousands of married welfare recipients or face a loss of Federal welfare funds.
The request to the House Ways and Means Committee came as the committee began public discussion of the tax and spending bill that is the core of President Clinton's deficit-reduction plan. 
 The expectation of Administration officials, lawmakers and lobbyists is that the committee will approve most of the basic elements of the Clinton plan next week, and that the House of Representatives will follow suit by the end of this month. But the plan faces strong opposition in the Senate, and the outlook there is uncertain.
The welfare proposal involves a 1988 law that was supposed to go into effect this October. It requires the states to find jobs or training for at least one parent in 40 percent of the two-parent families receiving checks under Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the basic Federal welfare program. The percentage is supposed to rise each year until it reaches 70 percent in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, 1996.
 
An Unrealistic Goal?
 Wendell E. Primus, a deputy assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, asked that the requirement be postponed for two years. He told the committee that most states would be unable to meet the goal because their welfare rolls had mushroomed during the recession and the necessary training programs had not been created.
About 300,000 two-parent families nationwide, representing 1.2 million people, are on welfare and would be affected by the change in the law. That is a small proportion of the total welfare population of about 13 million, mostly families with a single mother.
The rules on single-parent families would not be changed. Under the law, the states must place 11 percent of these parents who are eligible in jobs or training in this fiscal year, and the percentage is to rise to 15 percent in the next fiscal year. Parents with children under age 3 are exempt in most states; some states exempt only parents with children younger than 1 year.
Last year, the Federal Government made $1 billion available to the states under this program, and the states were supposed to match this with their own funds. But only $600 million was used because the states did not come up with the matching funds to get the rest.
 
Campaign Promise Recalled
 Mr. Primus said the Administration would address the question of work requirements when it submits its welfare program to Congress later in the year. In his campaign last year, Mr. Clinton promised to end the current welfare system and replace it with one that would eventually withdraw welfare benefits from parents who refused to work or enter education or training programs.
Administration supporters said the request to delay the work requirement in the law did not reflect a retreat from the campaign principles but rather was a recognition that compliance with the law was impossible.
In the discussion of the main parts of the legislation, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the committee, said he was "firmly committed to help President Clinton achieve his basic plan."
The central elements of the plan would raise the income tax rates and Medicare taxes of the wealthy, increase the corporate tax rate, impose a new tax on fuel, require upper- and middle-income retirees to pay taxes on a larger portion of their Social Security benefits, cut Medicare and Medicaid spending and eliminate or restrict many tax deductions, including those for business meals and club dues.
 
How Lawmakers Feel
 The lawmakers seem likely to reject Mr. Clinton's proposal for an investment-tax credit for business. The proposal, meant as an economic stimulus, is believed by many economists to be a waste of money and has generated little support in business circles.
Instead of a variety of cuts in the Medicare program recommended by the President, the committee seems likely to approve a two-year freeze in payments for services by doctors, hospitals and laboratories.
Representative Fortney (Pete) Stark, a California Democrat who heads the health subcommittee, said he did not necessarily expect the freeze to become law but meant it as a "placeholder" until the Administration's overall health plan was announced.
One section of the bill would raise to $1,750 a year the earnings threshold above which Social Security taxes must paid for household employees like maids and nannies. The threshold is now $50 a quarter, a figure that has not been changed since 1950 and a level so low that it is widely ignored.
 
Juggling the Numbers
 Republicans on the Ways and Means Committee made it clear today that they would fight almost every aspect of the Clinton plan. One after another called it the biggest tax increase ever proposed, a claim that is true or false depending on how various calculations are made. Democrats retorted that it was actually the biggest deficit reduction every proposed, an assertion that also can be both proved and disproved.
The Democrats' 24-to-14 committee majority means they can ignore the Republican opposition and still approve the bill handily. The full House will consider the legislation under rules that strictly limit amendments, meaning that whatever the committee approves will probably be passed and sent to the Senate.
The measure, meant to reduce the deficit by nearly $500 billion over the next five years, would raise taxes by a net of about $260 billion during that period. The remaining deficit reduction would come from spending cuts.

Representative Sam M. Gibbons sat at left. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)
