HEADLINE: Clinton Proposes Assistance To Troubled Neighborhoods

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration announced today that its plan for improving the nation's most distressed neighborhoods would combine minor new spending, moderate tax breaks for businesses and a major new emphasis on the coordination of existing programs.
The program would assist 110 neighborhoods, chosen through a competitive process. But the top 10, to be called "empowerment zones," would receive most of the advantages. Six would be urban, three rural and one on an Indian reservation. 
 In a conference call today to leaders from five communities, President Clinton said the plan, which would spend $8.1 billion over five years, would bring "new economic growth, opportunity and hope in areas long denied their piece of the American dream."
Of that money, $4.1 billion would be tax credits to businesses for each worker they hire from the distressed neighborhoods. Another $1 billion would be new spending, and $3 billion would come from existing programs by earmarking them for the selected areas.
 
Variation of Idea
 The anti-poverty initiative is a variation on the idea of "enterprise zones," which was enthusiastically endorsed by previous Republican Administrations but never became law. Jack F. Kemp, President George Bush's Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, argued that cuts in capital gains taxes could attract businesses into distressed neighborhoods.
The Clinton plan even borrows a favorite word of some conservative anti-poverty planners: empowerment.
But Clinton Administration officials place less stress on the tax breaks, which they say are insufficient to attract businesses that fear assaults on their buildings or employees.
Instead, they are calling for a more coordinated approach that would integrate economic planning with a social services strategy intended to stabilize neighborhoods. "Not a dime will go out without a coordinated strategy developed at the grass-roots level," Mr. Clinton said in the conference call, whose participants included Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York.
 
Waivers on U.S. Policies
 Under the Clinton plan, communities would submit outlines of their business and social services strategies. They would be encouraged to seek waivers from Federal agencies to use existing, highly regulated programs in new and creative ways. Most Federal programs are now bound by complex regulations that make experiments difficult if not impossible.
Programs that provide money for nutrition, education and day care, for instance, might be combined to create a comprehensive center for children.
"The mayors told us, 'What would really help more than another little program here and there is if you would take away some of the strings that restrict us,' " said Gene Sperling, a White House deputy assistant for economic policy, who helped form the plan.
The Federal selection panel would be led by the Cabinet secretaries from the relevant domestic agencies, including the departments of Housing and Urban Development, Health and Human Services, Agriculture and Labor. In selecting the neighborhoods, they would be agreeing to provide the waivers.
Richard Cowden, executive director of the American Association of Enterprise Zones, endorsed the plan. "I think states and localities will find this is much more flexible," than previous proposals, he said. The association represents governments that run the 700 enterprise zones created under local and state laws.
Mr. Clinton's proposal comes after a campaign in which he said little about the country's most blighted neighborhoods, focusing instead on a broader appeal to the middle class. As President, he has stressed some portions of his strategy to help the working poor, calling for additional tax credits to supplement their wages, for instance, and a system of national health insurance to cover all Americans.
But he has not taken action on his campaign promises to overhaul the welfare system, and today's plan is the first to address the poorest Americans.
 
Earlier Plans Watered Down
 In the past, proposals for enterprise zones have been watered down in Congress, with many lawmakers trying to gain one for their own district, thus diluting the advantage to any one area.
The Clinton plan tries to deal with that problem by creating 100 "enterprise communities," that would receive priority for certain Federal programs, including community policing and community development banks.
But the more expensive incentives are to be concentrated on the 10 neighborhoods with the most promising plans. "We don't want to dilute the money so much that we don't learn anything," from the process of local experimentation, Mr. Sperling said.
The Clinton proposal also offers a different kind of tax break from the earlier plan, which would have spent about $5 billion over five years. That plan, pushed by the Bush Administration, mainly offered cuts in the capital gains taxes paid by employers who move to distressed areas. The Clinton plan attaches its tax breaks, up to $5,000 for each employee they hire from a designated zone, to hiring policies.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sales of New Cars and Trucks Surged Last Month

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 4

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and trucks rose 10.1 percent in late April, as automotive demand rose for the third consecutive month, to the highest level in almost 30 months.
For all of April, figures released today by the auto makers showed an 11 percent increase. 
 The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales for the April 21-30 period was 6.9 million, up from 6.1 million during the comparable period last year and up from 6.6 million in mid-April. But according to the broader measure of demand for all vehicles, the seasonally adjusted annual rate was 14.1 million cars and trucks in April, compared with 13.6 million in March and 12.9 million in February.
In large measure, the steady increase in automotive demand has been accompanied by the recovery of ground lost by the Big Three to Japanese producers. In April, the American auto makers accounted for 73.9 percent of total vehicle sales, compared with 70.8 percent of sales in April 1992.
 
 
'Strengthened Our Optimism'
 Even the General Motors Corporation, which has had the weakest recovery of the the Big Three, posted strong increases for the month. J. Michael Losh, vice president and group executive for sales in North America, said an 11 percent sales increase at his company in late April had "strengthened our optimism."
Economists, financial analysts, dealers and auto executives concurred that demand had reached its first sustained recovery since the fall of 1990, when the recession and the Persian Gulf war combined to depress automotive buying. Indeed, the poor results helped precipitate a financial debacle at G.M. that swept its chairman and several top executives out of office.
David Healy, automotive analyst for S. G. Warburg & Company in New York said good weather, consumer optimism and pricing incentives played a role in the recovery.
"Showroom traffic has increased," said Leo Mayas, sales manager for Robbins Chevrolet-Nissan-Oldsmobile in Houston. "It seems like people are more confident."
 
 
'Positive Momentum'
 Robert L. Rewey, vice president of marketing and sales operations for the Ford Motor Company, said, "Importantly, the automotive market appears to be accelerating its positive momentum."
But Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, cautioned that "with economic indicators pointing toward slow growth, it will be hard to top April's sales pace."
Stronger sales of light trucks, which include sport-utilities vehicles and mini-vans, have sustained the recovery, as more and more buyers are switching from cars. April marked a record month in light-truck sales for all of the Big Three.
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks in late April totaled 440,027; sales of domestically built cars in the period rose 8.9 percent, to 256,855, while sales of domestically built light trucks rose 11.8 percent, to 183,172.
For the month, total automotive sales, including domestics and imports, totaled 1,252,968, an increase of 11 percent from April, 1992. Sales of cars rose 7.4 percent, to 773,485; sales of light trucks rose 17.5 percent, to 479,483.
 
 
G.M.'s Aggressive Pricing
 G.M. has been able to gain ground by pricing its vehicles aggressively, through a combination of discounts, rebates and price increases that are more moderate than competitors. The Cadillac de Ville, for example, carries up to a $2,000 rebate in some parts of the country, which helped increase its sales 23.1 percent for the month. A restyled de Ville is being offered this fall.
G.M.'s cars sales for April rose 6.3 percent, to 280,937; G.M.'s light-truck sales rose 19 percent, to 163,154. Ford's car sales rose 12.5 percent, to 164,669; Ford's light-truck sales rose 15.2 percent, to 145,200. The Chrysler Corporation's car sales rose 38.2 percent, to 76,248; Chrysler's light-truck sales rose 21.8 percent, to 115,809.
The Toyota Motor Corporation's car sales rose 5.8 percent, to 65,585, partly on the strength of its Lexus luxury division; Toyota's light-truck sales rose 15.3 percent, to 22,791.
The Honda Motor Company's car sales fell 4.3 percent, to 60,015. The Nissan Motor Corporation's car sales rose 23.6 percent, to 41,879, while light-truck sales rose 11.5 percent, to 16,463.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
'Drive American' Ban
 WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Foreign auto makers have been barred from the "Drive American Quality" event on May 25 and May 26, at which members of Congress, their staffs and Clinton Administration officials will get a chance to drive their choice of 120 cars made by General Motors, Chrysler and Ford.
An official of the United Auto Workers, which is co-sponsoring the event with the United States auto makers, confirmed today that cars with foreign nameplates will not be allowed -- even if they are made in the United States.

HEADLINE: European Gypsies Issue Call For Human Rights at Meeting

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SNAGOV, Romania, May 2

 BODY:
At a time of ethnic warfare in the Balkans and of growing ethnic tensions elsewhere in Europe, the continent's most widely dispersed minority, the Gypsies, have begun to seek international recognition and protection.
For the majority of Europe's estimated eight million Gypsies, who live at a bare subsistence level, the highest priorities are enough food for the day and shelter from the elements. 
 But after recent attacks on Gypsies in Germany, Slovakia, the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary, Romania and Croatia, a handful of Gypsy leaders are starting self-help initiatives and joint appeals for international aid.
Assaults have left 26 Gypsies dead in the former Czechoslovakia, 6 dead in Romania and hundreds of Gypsy dwellings burned to the ground in the last three years. The assaults, combined with widespread poverty, have prompted tens of thousands of Gypsies to flee northward to wealthier countries, all of which would like them to go away.
 
Romania Co-Sponsors Meeting
 The atmosphere of heightened hostility and the dire economic plight of most Gypsies formed the background of a four-day conference here in a former royal villa overlooking Lake Snagov.
The conference was co-sponsored by the Romanian Government and the Project on Ethnic Relations, a Princeton, N.J. group that is financed by the Carnegie Foundation. It was organized in large part by Gypsy leaders from 14 countries and it drew government representatives from 11 countries.
According to the organizers from Princeton, Alan Kassof and Livia Plaks, the role of Romania as a co-sponsor represented the first time that a European government gave official recognition to the Gypsy community.
The diversity of Gypsies spread across more than a score of countries became immediately evident. Although their language, called Romany, originated in India a thousand years ago, it is spoken in widely varying dialects. As a result, many of the Gypsies here had to communicate through interpreters or in French or English.
 
Who Is King of Gypsies?
 There were other differences. At one stage supporters of Iulian, who has proclaimed himself Emperor of all Gypsies, got into a heated argument with supporters of Ion, who calls himself the King of the Gypsies.
But the dominant figure of the conference was Nicolae Gheorghe, a 47-year-old sociologist from Bucharest. Mr. Gheorghe drafted the agenda for the conference, which included "human rights in full equality," projects to link widely dispersed Gypsy communities, job training, creation of a Gypsy information center and "documentation of violence against Gypsies."
Asked to characterize the results of the Snagov meeting, Mr. Gheorghe said: "It is a beginning. We are trying to establish our identity."
At the conclusion, the delegates approved a statement they called the Snagov Declaration, urging European governments and international organizations to pay more attention to issues that concern Gypsies.
The problems Gypsies face became evident during a trip by delegates to Mihai Kogalniceanu, a town of 10,000 on the Black Sea where 16 Gypsy families were burned out of their homes in 1991 after an ethnic clash.
Working with Mr. Gheorghe, nearly all of the burned dwellings have since been replaced by the local authorities.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The growth in trading in natural gas futures may be here to stay

BYLINE: By Thomas C. Hayes

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
SO many traders have swarmed into the natural gas futures pit in the last few months that the New York Mercantile Exchange is about to move them into a remodeled, expanded trading area.
The exchange is acting none too soon. More contracts were traded for natural gas on April 27 than for any other futures contract that day for a physical commodity on the New York exchange, even more than crude oil. It was the first time that natural gas had led the pack in trading volume since the exchange introduced gas futures contracts in April 1990. 
 The large swing in prices this year for the spot-month contract is the biggest reason for the trading surge. "The futures are a more reliable and more financially secure means of transacting business" when prices are unpredictable, said Philip K. Verleger, an energy commodities specialist and visiting fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
The May contract reached a high of $2.758 per million British thermal units when it expired on April 23, compared with the low settlement price this year on Jan. 19 at $1.551 for the February contract. The June contract gained 2.8 cents yesterday, at $2.317. A year ago, the spot-month contract price was less than $1.60.
Gas marketers and futures traders are unsure whether trading in natural gas contracts can permanently overtake crude oil, the world's most widely traded nonfinancial futures commodity.
Special factors have been driving natural gas prices in the last few months -- like March snowstorms in the East and new accounting rules that prompted pipeline companies to reduce gas inventories in their transportation systems.
Yet natural gas is a vast industry in the United States, and many specialists say this year's trading surge is no aberration. The industry's share of the nation's total energy market is 25 percent and growing. Its price pattern has also been more volatile than the price trend for crude oil, which has been unusually calm for two years. Crude supplies 40 percent of the nation's energy.
Mr. Verleger said that gas buyers, producers and Wall Street firms that specialize in gas contracts were behind much of the trading surge, not speculators. Big users of natural gas like steel and auto plants and local utilities use the fixed-price contracts to limit and spread their risks that prices will zoom to financially ruinous levels. For their part, many producers are willing to pledge deliveries at prices more than 60 percent above the depressed levels a year ago.
AIG Trading, Louis Dreyfus Energy, Morgan Stanley and Paribas Futures Inc. are among the most active Wall Street firms in gas-futures trading. The Enron Corporation, the big natural gas company, is another major participant.
Contracts on the New York exchange can be bought for delivery on dates as distant as 18 months. Options, swaps and other variations written on those monthly contracts are designed for gas deliveries at a fixed price for 10 years or more.
The current price sequence for monthly gas futures contracts indicates that spot prices will fall to $2.244 this summer. The peak price for the next 12 months is on the December contract, at $2.64. The price average for those 12 months is $2.327 but it can shift rapidly, said Brian Manolis of Paribas Futures. It was below $2 in March.
But some analysts say the spot price cannot stay above $2.50 for long because, at that price, hundreds of large gas users switch to cheaper low-sulfur fuel oil. That should lower demand.
"To date, we have not seen prices sticking over $2.50 for any substantial period of time," said Jeffrey K. Skilling, chief executive of Enron's gas marketing group in Houston.

HEADLINE: Campus Journal;
Law Students Get Close To Human Rights Cases

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
The Lowenstein International Human Rights Clinic at Yale Law School is so little known that its phone number is not listed in the law school directory.
But the clinic's work is public. Operating out of a small office at the law school are 10 to 17 law students, sometimes exhilarated, sometimes depressed, often bleary with fatigue. The students are part of the team that filed suit in Federal District Court in Brooklyn in March 1992, challenging the United States' policy of detaining Haitian refugees at the Guantanamo Bay naval base in Cuba. 
 Last May the team expanded the case to challenge President George Bush's policy of forcibly returning all Haitians to Haiti, without determining whether they were political or economic refugees.
The students have spent the last year working 40 to 100 hours a week on behalf of the refugees, reading 50,000 documents, flying to Guantanamo and missing classes.
"I don't think any of us realized what we were getting into," said Veronique Sanchez, a 27-year-old student from Chantilly, Va.
In the next week or two, the students expect a decision on the Guantanamo issue from Judge Sterling Johnson Jr. of Federal District Court. The interdiction part of the case has been argued in the Supreme Court, and a decision is expected in June.
The students' odyssey had its genesis in a law school course taught by Professor Harold Koh and an adjunct, Michael R. Ratner, in which students represent victims of human rights abuses in Federal courts. Some recent graduates persuaded the professors to file suit on behalf of the Haitians, and to develop the case, the two men wanted firsthand accounts from Haitian refugees who had just been released from Guantanamo and were being detained in Miami.
Guido Calabresi, the dean of the law school, agreed to send 12 students to Miami to interview the refugees in March 1992, during spring break.
"There were cultural differences," said Laura Ho, a 23-year-old student from Tacoma, Wash. "I'd ask a refugee, 'Why did you flee?' and he would say, 'I had problems.' "
The students had to elicit specific information. Where had the refugees been on the night of Sept. 29, 1991, when President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was ousted by the military? Who in their families was killed? What organizations did they belong to? Were they starving? Were they working?
Each night the students wrote up the interviews, filled out forms and, at the end of the week, returned to Yale.
In a lawsuit, both sides are entitled to see the other side's relevant documents.
"The Government gave us 50,000 documents in one month, memos from the Immigration and Naturalization Service to the military on Guantanamo," said Steve Roos, 27, a student from Seattle. "Each student would read at least a thousand."
Students slept one or two hours a night for weeks at a time, poring over the documents and finally winnowing them to 500.
By December, six of the students who were taking a class in property law realized they had missed two-thirds of the classes, which were held from 10 to 11 A.M., four days a week. "A crisis always broke out between 9 and 10," Mr. Roos said. To avoid failing, one person went to one class, took notes and made copies for the others. Another person went to the next class. The six managed to pass.
A few weeks ago the students had a breakthrough. Judge Johnson, who was appointed to the Federal bench by Mr. Bush in 1991, ordered the Government to provide adequate medical care to 50 of the sickest refugees.
When the Haitians arrived in New York last month, Ms. Ho, Mr. Roos and another student, Michael Wishnie, 27, of Newton, Mass., were at the airport to meet them. "There was incredible joy on their faces -- and ours," Mr. Roos said.
And Professor Koh's response? Mr. Roos replied, "He said to us, 'Isn't this why you went to law school?' "

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: In Yen Windfall, U.S. Companies Prefer Profits

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 30

 BODY:
For all their complaints about how hard it is to do business in Japan, American manufacturers of cars, computers and chips are not trying to increase sales by cutting prices here after the big 10 percent surge in the Japanese yen against the dollar.
That could mean that the yen's appreciation, while making Japanese goods more costly in America, will not be as effective as Washington hopes in building up American imports to Japan and shrinking the United States trade deficit with Japan. 
 At a time when the United States Government is trying to take a tougher stance to increase sales of American goods in Japan, the pricing policies could leave American companies vulnerable to charges that they are not doing enough to help themselves but instead are milking profits from Japan by preferring high prices over high market share.
"Unfortunately at present we don't have any examples of the lowering of prices by U.S. companies," said Sadanobu Taguchi, deputy director of the price policy division at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. "This is a chance for U.S. companies to get a large share in the Japanese market if they change their prices."
Americans say there are valid business reasons for not lowering their prices. They say that distributing goods in Japan is costly. Some who manufacture in Japan say the currency difference is irrelevant and others say that merely cutting prices is no guarantee that sales will improve.
"I think Washington economists should be criticized for not understanding how American products sell here," said John Stern, the representative in Japan of the American Electronics Association. "I think Washington should stop assuming that exchange rates are a panacea for a trade deficit."
But some Japanese executives see the profit motive as the main reason for the failure to cut prices. "Our past experience shows that almost all foreign companies, more or less, want to take in the extra profit from the high yen for themselves," said Takeshi Yoda, deputy head of international business at Meidi-ya, a supermarket chain.
Most economists say that weakening the dollar versus the yen will lead to a decline in the United States trade deficit with Japan over time. That is what happened in the few years after the 1985 Plaza Accord, which sharply raised the value of the yen. However, Japan's industry seemed to adjust to the higher yen eventually and Japan's trade surplus with the world, which exceeded $130 billion last year, is now higher than it was before the Plaza agreement.
But in the short run, the higher yen is likely to lead to an increase in Japan's trade surplus, at least when it is measured in dollars. That is because it takes time for buyers to switch from expensive Japanese products to cheaper foreign ones. In the meantime, the stronger yen means that sales of Japanese products abroad account for more in dollar terms.
In theory, as the yen rises against the dollar, an American company that had been selling a personal computer here for 250,000 yen, or about $2,000, could now charge 225,000 yen and still get $2,000. If the price in yen is kept the same, however, the American company will record greater profits in dollar terms.
To be sure, accusations that companies try to milk profits from the strengthening yen are also leveled at Japanese companies. The electric utilities here are taking heat from consumers and industry for their refusal to lower their rates, despite presumably paying less for imported fuel.
 
Price Survey Under Way
 The Economic Planning Agency is conducting a price survey to see if the benefits from the higher yen are being passed on to Japanese consumers in the form of lower prices.
There has been a flurry of activity in supermarkets and department stores, which are cutting prices on foreign meat, wine, clothing and the like. These sales are advertised as aiming to pass on to consumers the benefits of the stronger yen. But privately supermarket executives say that the yen's rise is merely an excuse to have a sale for competitive purposes.
American companies offer several reasons for not having adjusted prices. One is simply that the yen's rise, from about 124 to the dollar in early February to under 111 now, is simply too recent and might be temporary.
"I don't think we have discussed it yet," said Kei-ichi Murai, spokesman for Eastman Kodak's Japanese subsidiary, which sells film here. "We are not sure if this trend is going to last forever."
The short time period since the yen's rise started, however, has not stopped Japanese companies like Sony, Honda and Mazda from announcing price increases for the products they sell in the United States.
Some Japanese distributors of American-made products have already stocked up with goods. Yanase & Company, the exclusive importer and dealer of General Motors automobiles in Japan, said it already paid for 90 percent of its inventory for the 1993 model year at a time when the yen was weaker. That leaves little leeway for lowering prices until the next model year, which begins in the fall, said Shoji Sugimoto, a director. In any case, he said, having automobile prices fluctuate monthly or quarterly with currency rates would make customers "uncomfortable."
Others say that strategic marketing factors and supply and demand, not just currency rates, play a role in determining prices. Walden C. Rhines, a vice president of Texas Instruments, said that "right now demand is very strong around the world" for semiconductors so there is no need to cut prices.
Cray Research, the American supercomputer manufacturer that has been vocal in complaining about lack of access to Japan's market, also has no plans to change prices because of the yen. "Our product is already price competitive," said Tak Kato, manager of strategic marketing of Cray Research Japan, who said the company recently introduced a new product line.
 
Japan-Incurred Costs
 Other companies, like I.B.M. and Procter & Gamble, say that they do much of their manufacturing here, so their costs are mainly yen-denominated and do not change when the yen appreciates. Even companies that import products say that much of the price in Japan reflects rent and salaries and other costs incurred in Japan.
"The local cost of doing business here is very high and it doesn't go down at all," said the head of Japanese operations for an American cosmetics company.
Another reason often cited for not lowering prices is that Japanese consumers care more about quality than about price.
"Just trying to sell a product here that's cheaper is no way to gain market share," said Mr. Stern of the American Electronics Association. In Japan, he said, "discounting your product somehow implies there's something wrong with it."
Moreover, Japanese companies are prone to match lower prices to hold onto their market share. "If you're a $50 million American company and your biggest competitor is a $42 billion Japanese company, you'd be crazy to try to get in a price war," he said.
Mr. Stern also said that American electronic products that were successful here were often imitated by the Japanese manufacturers after a couple of years. "People want to make profits off the product while it's still unique," he said
 
Discount Stores Popular
 Japanese executives say the notion that Japanese consumers avoid inexpensive products is outmoded. Discount stores have become popular in the recent economic slump, and some American personal computer companies have broken into the Japanese market by offering lower prices.
The trade ministry, which has done a pricing survey for the last few years, has found that in some cases, foreign products sell at far higher prices in Japan than they do in other nations. The foreign companies argue that this is because of Japan's bloated distribution system and not because of their own pricing policies.
This year, in an apparent attempt to embarrass such companies, the ministry said it would consider printing specific brand names in its survey. That sent some American and European businessmen into a panic, and they and their governments protested. The Japanese eventually dropped the idea.

HEADLINE: Dow Dips Slightly on Economic Concerns

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The stock market floundered yesterday, thrown off an already uncertain course by more bad news on the economy.
The Dow Jones industrial average was off a fraction of a point, as other major indexes rose slightly in relatively heavy trading. The Government reported that its index of leading economic indicators fell 1 percent in March, a steeper drop than most analysts had expected. 
 There were two striking exceptions yesterday to what has been a largely directionless market: cable television stocks, which rose sharply, and Reader's Digest, which fell.
 
Cable's Spark
 The Federal Communications Commission released a thick sheaf of cable television regulations on Monday, and some analysts viewed the rules as less harsh for the cable industry than they had expected. Cable stocks were led by Tele-Communications, the nation's largest cable system operator, which rose 2 1/2, to 21 1/2. It was the most active stock on any exchange, with nearly 13.7 million shares changing hands.
Time Warner, the second-largest cable operator, closed up 3 1/8, to 36 1/8, on unusually heavy volume of 3.3 million shares. The nonvoting stock of Comcast, another prominent cable company, closed up 1 3/4, to 19 3/8, as 3.04 million shares were traded. The company's voting shares were also active, gaining 2 1/8, to 20 5/8. Cablevision Systems closed up 3 5/8, to 33 1/4.
Reader's Digest hit a new low during the session, at 40, but recovered slightly to close at 40 1/2, down 6. The publisher of magazines and books announced lower than expected earnings, primarily because of lagging sales in its books and home-entertainment division. For investors, the real shock was the company's announcement that it would take up to two years to fix its problems in the American book market.
 
Stability in Gold
 The gold stocks closed unchanged to slightly mixed. An exception was Newmont Mining, which has sold a large stake to the financier George Soros. It closed up 1 1/4, to 48 3/8. Gold contracts for June delivery closed up 40 cents, to $355.70 an ounce.
The Dow Jones industrial average finished down 0.27, to 3,446.19, after trading in a narrow range for most of the session. The previous day it staged a late 19-point rally after a generally listless session.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index closed up 0.69, to 245.23, and gaining stocks outnumbered losing stocks by 1,267 to 702. Volume of 268.3 million shares was 19.2 percent higher than Monday's volume of 225 million shares.
The Standard & Poor's 500 closed up 1.59, to 444.05, and the Nasdaq composite index, made up of smaller-capitalization and high-technology stocks, was up 11.45, to 678.16. The American Stock Exchange composite index closed up 2.55, to 424.76.
The Dow rose as much as 15 points in early trading, seemingly shrugging off the gloomy report on leading economic indicators. But by noon, the Dow fell into a narrow trading range that straddled both positive and negative territory.
Intel was the second-most-active stock on any exchange, with trading volume of 4.3 million shares. It closed up 4 3/8, to 101 3/8, possibly on an analyst's speculation that Intel was negotiating to acquire an I.B.M. plant to increase its ability to make microprocessors. Intel has had trouble meeting demand for its 486 microprocessor, the heart of many personal computers.

HEADLINE: Regulator Says Connecticut's Largest Power Company Harassed Worker

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Northeast Utilities, Connecticut's largest power company, persecuted one of its engineers because he called a safety problem at a nuclear reactor to the company's attention, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday.
Moreover, it said, Northeast delayed reporting the problem even though it could have affected the safety of other reactors around the country. 
 The Federal commission said the violation of its rules was even worse because top officials of Northeast, including the company's chairman, were "aware of it, but failed to act in an effective manner to correct the situation."
It proposed a $100,000 fine and characterized the violation as being in the second most severe category; nationally, only three or four such violations are issued each year, and Northeast has not been cited that way since 1984.
 
Retaliatory Actions
 "We take whistle-blowers seriously, and we expect our licensees to take them seriously also," said Joseph Fouchard, the chief spokesman for the commission. The commission found, among other things, that managers at the utility, in retaliation, improperly sought to give the engineer, Paul M. Blanch, bad performance evaluations and initiated an audit of overtime and expense reports in the department he supervised.
The company said it was working on a detailed rebuttal and would file it within the 30 days allowed under the commission's rules.
Mr. Blanch, 51, who filed a complaint four years ago, said, "I feel very vindicated." But he added: "They agreed with me, but in the meantime I am unemployed. The action against Northeast and to protect me should have occurred within three months; why does it take four years?" He had quit his job at Northeast in February, after 20 years.
His next goal, Mr. Blanch said, is to get a job in which he could improve the quality of regulation of the nuclear industry. He is suing the company that makes the transmitters, Rosemount, of Eden Prairie, Minn., a subsidiary of Emerson Electric Corporation, contending that the company "influenced Northeast to supress my uncovery of the defect."
 
Further Study Pledged
 The chairman of the Connecticut Department of Public Utility Control, Clifton A. Leonhardt, said he found the Federal report "very troubling."
"It suggests a violation of a basic compact that's involved in the operation of four nuclear plants within the borders of Connecticut," he said. His agency will study the report, he said, and decide whether it will take action beyond what the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has done.
At Northeast, a spokesman, Anthony Castagno, said: "Our position is that no employees or supervisors or managers did anything that violated regulations at all. We don't believe there was any harassment or intimidation."
Mr. Castagno said that the commission had investigated the company in 1990, after other workers complained of harassment, and that it had found the majority of employees felt comfortable raising safety concerns. Since then, he said, Northeast had established a phone number for employees to make anonymous calls, installed suggestion boxes and established a "peer program" under which employees could relay their concerns to workers at their level to be passed on to managers.
 
Helped Develop Solution
 But in its report yesterday, the commission said that "various workers" at Northeast said they would not raise safety issues with management, because of the way Mr. Blanch had been treated.
Mr. Blanch discovered in the late 1980's that an electronic transmitter in use in one of Northeast's reactors -- as well as plants around the country -- tended to fail without giving any indication that it had done so. The result of the failure was to leave control-room instruments indicating a reassuring, but false, water level. Northeast adopted a solution that Mr. Blanch helped develop, a computer program that watches for a telltale lack of activity.
When other utilities that use the equipment formed a joint research group on the issue, the commission said, Northeast and the manufacturer of the equipment blocked Mr. Blanch from becoming chairman of the joint group.
The commission also faulted the company yesterday for failing to report promptly that in 1986 and 1987 5 of the 12 transmitters of the type Mr. Blanch had identified had failed. The failure file a prompt report is serious, the commission said, because the problem "could involve the safety of other nuclear-power plants." But the commission did not propose a fine.

HEADLINE: Economic Indicators Fall 1%, Casting Doubt on Recovery

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The Government said yesterday that its main economic forecasting gauge plunged 1 percent in March, the biggest drop since the middle of the 1990-91 recession. It was the latest report to raise questions about the strength and durability of the economic expansion.
President Clinton used the portent of possible future weakness that was suggested by the index of leading indicators to urge Congress to adopt his budget plan without delay. The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, labeled the report "a wake-up call for the White House to drop its tax-and-spend campaign." 
 But economists inside and outside the Government took a less alarmist view. A top Administration economist who insisted on anonymity because he had not yet been confirmed said that the decline was a "cause for concern" rather than a harbinger of another recession.
David A. Wyss, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, said, "The economy is very slow but not nearly in as much trouble as that number suggests."
Some economists said they expected the indicators to turn up next month. "As the spring weather sets in, activity should rebound enough to offset most if not all of the drop in March leading indicators," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence.
Indeed, other reports yesterday suggested that consumer spending revived in April. Sales at major retail chains rose 2 percent from March, according to the latest Johnson Redbook survey, and car and truck sales surged. [Page D5.]
And several of the 11 leading indicators -- including jobless claims and consumer expectations -- have turned positive since March, suggesting that the index may not keep declining.
Still, the March drop in the leading index, which seeks to predict economic activity six months ahead, was not only large, but pervasive: nine of its components fell. The biggest negative factors were a large drop in building permits, a rise in initial jobless claims, a shortening of the factory workweek and a worsening of consumer expectations about future economic conditions. The only two bright spots were minuscule increases in the prices of stocks and industrial materials.
Economists fretted that many of the components -- from money supply to new orders for consumer goods -- appear to have peaked several months ago, another indication that the economy might have gotten stuck on a plateau after December.
And several executives confirmed that the expansion, while continuing, was quite sluggish.
"Loan demand is soft," said John B. McCoy Jr., chief executive of the Banc One Corporation, the nation's eighth-largest bank. "We're seeing some loan growth out west in Colorado and Arizona and a little in Texas, but other areas have slowed down."
 
 
'It's Not Broad Based'
 Brian D. McLaughlin, chief executive of Hurco Industries, a midsize machine tool company in Indianapolis, said that while his business had been picking up in the last three months, orders were coming primarily from the Midwest and from a just couple of industries. "It's not broad based," he said.
Private and Government economists, however, warned that too much should not be read into a one-month decline in the leading indicators. "It would be premature," said Larry Moran, an economist at the Bureau of Economic Analysis, which compiles the leading indicators.
The forecasting index has occasionally predicted recessions that never arrived: for example, in 1987 after the stock market crash and in the early years of the long, strong Reagan recovery.
To reach the conclusion that the expansion is in serious trouble, Mr. Moran said: "You need to have a big decline. One percent is big. You need widespread decline. Nine of 11 is widespread. But we also need several months. We only have one month."
 
 
Index Above Pre-Recession Peak
 In the case of March, the decline followed a fairly rapid rise in the six previous months. And the leading index remains well above its pre-recession peak.
And some of the decline in March indicators -- namely those related to construction and possibly the factory workweek -- may have reflected the effect of blizzards and floods for the month. Most economists, including the Administration economist, say that several components have since turned up.
In addition, initial jobless claims have improved, dropping from 376,000 to 367,000 in April. And consumer expectations have edged higher, according to the Conference Board. The purchasing managers' survey on Monday, while negative, showed that orders for key consumer goods -- clothing and cars -- were up in April. And that survey also showed that delivery times, one component of the leading index, lengthened in April, another plus.
 
 
Drop in Money Supply
 There have been some declines in April, too. Stock prices edged down in the month and so did prices for materials. There was also a drop in the M-2 money supply (currency, checking accounts and some time deposits).
"It's tough to make a buck, margins are still brutal," said Michel D. Hobbs, a Connecticut home builder, "but activity seems to have picked up in the last few weeks."
Mr. McLaughlin of Hurco said that business had picked up "primarily because a lot of smaller shops are adding overtime and buying new equipment. They are signs that we haven't seen in a long time."

HEADLINE: Timetable Outlined for Trade Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
The nation's top trade official said today that the Administration hoped to complete a tentative agreement on reducing tariffs and eliminating quotas by early July. The ambitious goal reflects a quietly growing enthusiasm among Administration officials for a global trade pact but could complicate efforts to push the North American Free Trade Agreement through Congress.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said he hoped to strike the deal on access to foreign markets before President Clinton goes to Tokyo in early July for a meeting of the heads of state from the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations. Such a compromise would clear away the biggest remaining obstacle to the completion of the global free-trade talks to broaden the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. 
 Mr. Kantor's comment represented the first time a Clinton Administration official had set a clear timetable for industrialized nations to complete a global trade pact this year.
 
'Some Positive News'
 The Bush Administration negotiated a compromise last November with the European Community on farm subsidies, the other issue that has bedeviled the current round of world trade talks, which began in Uruguay nearly seven years ago.
"What we're attempting to do is work on market access in the Uruguay Round and have a preliminary agreement on market access, especially in the industrial products area and services area, prior to the G-7 meeting in Tokyo," Mr. Kantor said, "so that at the G-7 meeting we can have some positive news from those meetings about the Uruguay Round, which will then, we hope, give a great impetus to the round itself."
In a subsequent telephone interview, Mr. Kantor said he envisioned a deal among Canada, Japan, the European Community and the United States. The trade ministers from all four trading partners are scheduled to meet at the end of next week in Toronto, and Mr. Kantor said he planned to pursue this goal there.
Such a preliminary deal would still need approval from the rest of the 112 nations in the GATT talks. But Jules Katz, who oversaw the North American Free Trade Agreement and GATT negotiations for the Bush Administration, said that poor countries were eager to join a deal by industrialized nations. A preliminary deal would not set tariffs for every category of product but would leave many tariff cuts unresolved as bargaining chips for talks with poor countries.
 
Willing and Able Leadership
 Asked why he thought such a goal might be feasible now after so many years of failure, Mr. Kantor initially joked, "Maybe naivete." He then contended that President Clinton was showing strong leadership on the issue, and that American trading partners were very willing to negotiate.
The completion of national elections five weeks ago in France, where the free-trade talks are very unpopular and became a campaign issue, also helped, Mr. Kantor said.
Other Washington trade experts point out that a shift in the community's leadership in early January resulted in new leaders who are more willing and political able to strike a deal. The experts also said that the odds of a successful GATT deal seem to be improving now because the Clinton Administration appears to be seeking a less ambitious pact than did Bush Administration.
For example, Mr. Kantor has called for only a few restrictions on the ability of American companies to seek protection from foreign goods that are subsidized or sold below cost, a practice known as dumping. The Bush Administration had sought extensive GATT restrictions on these dumping and antisubsidy cases.
Another Democratic Administration, President Carter's, concluded the last round of GATT negotiations in 1979 by pursuing a modest agreement after the Nixon and Ford Administrations had failed to negotiate a broader pact.
 
A Spate of Talks
 Mr. Kantor spoke today at a conference at the State Department organized by the Council of the Americas, a trade group of nearly 300 multinational companies that do business in Latin America. He also pointed out that the United States and the European Community planned more frequent minister-level meetings on the world trade talks in the coming weeks than at any time in the last seven years.
Two weeks ago, Mr. Kantor met with Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's vice president for external economic affairs to discuss trade issues. He is scheduled to meet Sir Leon again here on Thursday, in Toronto at the end of next week and in Paris at the beginning of June. Both sides have refused to reveal any details of their discussions.
President Clinton said almost nothing about GATT in the Presidential campaign. So he did not come to office with the same commitment that he had made, in a campaign speech on Oct. 4, to put the North American Free Trade Agreement in place.
Mr. Kantor said very little about the GATT in his first weeks in office but now mentions it routinely as the backdrop for various bilateral trade negotiations with the European Community and Japan.
Sir Leon and Mr. Kantor have indicated in recent weeks that they sought progress before the Tokyo meeting. But Mr. Kantor's comment today was the first indication that an actual deal might be struck by then.
 
Effect on North American Accord
 GATT negotiations on tariffs are likely to create political difficulties for the North American Free Trade Agreement, which would eliminate trade barriers among Canada, Mexico and the United States. Some industries that would benefit from the North American pact, like textiles, would be hurt by the tariff concessions now planned for GATT.
Mr. Kantor, however, said the two pacts could be handled at the same time because both would produce American jobs.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Retreat of Dollar Continues Amid Jitters Over Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar weakened further against other major currencies yesterday amid jitters about the United States economy. Trading volume was light ahead of April employment data due out Friday.
Market participants are hoping that the payroll numbers, the first major figures not influenced by March's severe winter storms, will give a more accurate picture of where the economy is headed. 
 The British pound, meanwhile, gained only marginally against the dollar as traders continued to take profits following sterling's recent rally.
The dollar began declining in London in a delayed reaction to Monday's weaker-than-expected report on United States manufacturing from the National Association of Purchasing Managers. The London markets were closed on Monday for a national holiday.
But more sour economic news from Germany kept the dollar from falling further against the mark. Six leading economic institutes predicted in an annual report that Germany's economy will shrink 2 percent this year. The group added that stingy interest rate cuts by the German central bank, the Bundesbank, are prolonging the country's recession.
That raised some speculation that the Bundesbank's central council, which meets tomorrow, will step up interest-rate reductions to help stimulate Germany's economy. That would tend to help the dollar by making mark-denominated investments less attractive.
"I think the reason the dollar's breakdown was not sustained is because people stepped back and said, 'Why should we push the dollar any lower if the Germany economy is still weak?' " said Geoffrey Dennis, a currency strategist at James Capel & Company.
The dollar weakened against the Japanese yen but failed to break below the psychologically important 110-yen level, in part because of fears of further central bank intervention following last week's action by the Federal Reserve.
Financial markets in Japan were closed yesterday for a national holiday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 110.25 yen. By 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar fell to 110.25 yen from late Monday's 110.78 yen.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Electronics Replacing Coaches' Clipboards

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
A sports quiz:
Three teams -- the New York Knicks, the Chicago Bulls and the Los Angeles Lakers -- got off to the best start in the professional basketball playoffs that began last week, each winning its first two games. What else do these teams have in common?
Sheer coincidence, probably, but they are known as three of the most ardent users of computers in the National Basketball Association. In the last two years, pro basketball has become a test bed for mobile computing, and the Knicks, Bulls and Lakers have enthusiastically embraced the technology. 
 Using big sports arenas as their factory floors, and games won as the key gauge of market prowess, pro basketball teams are now employing computers much as other businesses do, especially companies with managers and workers who are constantly on the move.
 
Coming Up With Predictions
 Armed with notebook computers, fax modems and specialized software, the teams compile scouting reports, analyze statistics and create models to predict what players and teams might do in specific game situations. In a matter of minutes and a few keystrokes, the machines permit coaches to do work that used to take hours of laborious sorting through statistic sheets and play diagrams.
To motivate players, some teams, like the Knicks, compile specialized performance rankings, not only shooting percentages but also "teamwork" measures like the number of times a player dives for a loose ball or helps a teammate on defense. The player rankings are posted on the locker room wall. If a player sees his performance slipping in some category, the message to improve is clear.
Among mobile computing customers, "basketball teams are as good a prototype as any," said Richard Shaffer of Technologic Partners, a computer consultant in New York. "They don't have offices. They travel a lot. And, hey, it's a business."
Besides basketball coaches, the market may include an estimated 40 million mobile workers -- from traveling salesmen to interstate truck drivers -- although analysts disagree on precisely how to define the mobile computing business and the size of the potential market.
Today's primary mobile "platform," the notebook computer, accounted for about 13 percent of worldwide personal computer sales last year, according to Dataquest Inc., a market research firm. Within a few years, that share will rise to 25 percent or so, a Dataquest analyst, Janet Cole, predicted, adding that some analysts say notebooks will outsell desktop machines by the late 1990's.
The real payoff for mobile computing is several years down the road, when wireless communications, intelligent software and miniaturized machines are expected to come together in a futuristic world of easy-to-use hand-held "personal digital assistants." In theory, these machines will respond to written or spoken commands, communicate with other people's hand-held computers, and retrieve and display everything from movies to scientific documents.
 
Competing Suppliers
 Hundreds of companies are developing equipment and services for this personal digital future. The big players in computers and telecommunications -- A.T.& T., I.B.M., Motorola, Apple Computer, Hewlett-Packard, Microsoft and others -- are all in the chase. Yet there are smaller companies, like the Go Corporation, a pen-based software maker, and start-ups, like General Magic, which is working on operating software for hand-held wireless computers.
But that is the future, and getting there will involve developing new markets for mobile computing with more modest technological steps forward. So companies are working to spread the use of computers well beyond offices to police officers on the beat, ambulance drivers, traveling sales representatives and other mobile workers.
"The desk personal computer revolution never touched these people, but mobile computing will," said Bruce Claflin, general manager of mobile computing for the I.B.M. Personal Computer Company.
The International Business Machines Corporation sponsors the computing program in the N.B.A. and considers it both a test market and a promotional venue for showcasing its computers. The company, long a laggard in mobile computing, finally has something to show off.
In the past, Mr. Claflin conceded, I.B.M.'s mobile offerings were "marginally competitive and overpriced." But last fall, with the introduction of its new laptops, especially its high-end color machine, the Thinkpad 700C, I.B.M. became a serious competitor in the field.
 
Special Software for Sports
 The 27 N.B.A. teams are equipped with conventional Thinkpad notebooks. Recently, several teams have been experimenting with a pen-based model, the Thinkpad 700T, loaded with specialized basketball software developed by Information and Display Systems Inc. of Jacksonville, Fla. The pen-based system allows coaches and scouts to diagram plays and store them, up to 99 plays for each of the 27 teams.
Robert Salmi is a 33-year-old assistant coach of the Knicks and one of pro basketball's self-taught computer aces. A 6-foot-7-inch former college basketball player, Mr. Salmi knew little about computers before Pat Riley, the Knicks head coach, came to him early in the 1991-92 season and told him what he wanted.
Mr. Riley has a well-deserved reputation for being as demanding a task master with his coaching staff as he is with his players. He wanted to have the team's computers massage the statistics on scoring, rebounds and assists that were churned out daily by the league. But Mr. Riley also wanted a data base of in-house figures that reflect effort and behavior, like diving for loose balls. "Pat Riley wants to know everything," Mr. Salmi said.
Like most computer neophytes, Mr. Salmi struggled at first. Frequently, he sought the help of the computer experts at Paramount Communications Inc., which owns Madison Square Garden and the Knicks. "I went to them so often, they hated me," he recalled. "They'd run when they saw me coming."
Today, Mr. Salmi is comfortable with computers, speaking knowledgeably about data base programs or pen-based machines. But mostly, he views the computers as a tool that saves time and that can pinpoint problems and opportunities.
For example, Mr. Riley might ask his assistant for additional statistics on their initial playoff opponents, the Indiana Pacers, whom the Knicks beat twice last week.
The coach, Mr. Salmi says, might want to know the Pacers won-lost record in games when they were out-rebounded, or when their guard Reggie Miller took more than 15 shots and made more than 50 percent in a game, or when their forward Rick Smits scored more than 20 points. Or in games when all three happened.
"Two years ago, that would have meant three or four hours of going through files and stat sheets," Mr. Salmi said. "Today, I can snap that out in five minutes."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Platinum Plummets in Price; Silver Off and Gold Is Firmer

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Platinum futures prices were pounded yesterday by signs of sluggish economic growth and perceptions that the metal had become overvalued in its recent run to a 23-month high.
Silver futures also fell, extending Monday's loss, while gold prices firmed slightly. 
 On other commodity markets, lumber futures tumbled; grains and soybeans were mostly lower; oil futures retreated, and most livestock and meat futures fell.
Platinum for July delivery sank $9.30 on the New York Mercantile Exchange to $377.30 a troy ounce. The move followed a $3.30 drop on Monday.
 
Silver off by 2.4 Cents
 On the Commodity Exchange in New York, June gold rose 40 cents, to $355.70 a troy ounce, and May silver fell 2.4 cents, to $4.266 a troy ounce, after a plunge of 9.9 cents on Monday.
Platinum and silver have industrial uses that make them sensitive to economic signals. Yesterday's Government report of a 1 percent drop in the index of leading indicators, the sharpest decline since November 1990, worried investors, said Bette Raptopoulos, metals analyst with Prudential Securities Inc. in New York.
"If we get a recession and people stop buying cars, platinum could be selling for less than gold," said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc. in New York. Platinum is used in the catalytic converters of all cars sold in the United States.
Mr. Savaiko said platinum and silver had become too costly relative to gold, and their declines represented attempts by traders to realign the price relationships.
Lumber futures crashed to a three-month low on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as abundant supplies continued to find few buyers in a construction market weakened by foul weather.
Light sweet crude oil for June delivery fell 18 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange to $20.39 a barrel. June heating oil fell 0.30 cent, to 55.58 cents a gallon. June unleaded gasoline fell 0.22 cent, to 61.59 cents a gallon and June natural gas rose 2.8 cents, to $2.317 for 1,000 cubic feet.
In livestock trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle for June delivery fell 0.25 cent, to 76.97 cents a pound. May feeder cattle fell 0.02 cent, to 86.20 cents a pound. June live hogs slipped 0.05 cent, to 52.55 cents a pound, and May frozen pork bellies sank 1.28 cents, to 42.82 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: Failures Fall 10.2% in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The number of United States business failures fell by 10.2 percent for the first quarter, reflecting a stronger economy in the first three months of 1993 than in the period a year earlier, the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation said yesterday.
Dun & Bradstreet reported 23,180 failures, compared with 25,824 for the first quarter of 1992. The decline was accompanied by a substantial drop in dollar liabilities associated with bankruptcies, which fell 42.7 percent, to $12.9 billion, from $22.5 billion in the first quarter of 1992. 
 Joseph W. Duncan, vice president and chief economist for Dun & Bradstreet, said that with the exception of a few states -- particularly Florida, Michigan, New Jersey and Connecticut -- failures were down across the nation, indicating a broad economic recovery.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Budget Pleases Many Arts Institutions

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
While holding out the possibility of cutbacks in a number of city services, the budget announced on Monday by Mayor David N. Dinkins brought cheer to the Department of Cultural Affairs and many arts institutions.
The Mayor's proposed $31.4 billion budget, which is subject to City Council approval, adds $3.6 million to the Cultural Affairs expense budget (increasing it to $85.3 million for fiscal year 1994), and provides $6.3 million to match a grant from the State Legislature to rescue the financially troubled New-York Historical Society. 
 In addition, $7.5 million is earmarked for new capital projects like new roofing for the Brooklyn Museum.
 
'Ecstatic' About the Increases
 Luis R. Cancel, Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, said: "The Mayor has obviously taken to heart how the cultural community helps New York's economy. I'm ecstatic."
Asked about the concern he expressed on Monday that bailing out the historical society with $6.3 million might create "the appearance of rewarding an organization for mismanagement," Mr. Cancel said, "This money will flow through the Department of Cultural Affairs, and you may rest assured that we will have vigorous oversight on how it is spent."
While spokesmen for the historical society said they were thrilled by the budget, others complained that Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Cancel had "politicized the process."
For example, $2.2 million is scheduled for increased support for some members of the Cultural Institutions Group, an umbrella organization for arts institutions that occupy city-owned real estate. But only 13 of the group's 31 members -- ranging from the Brooklyn Academy of Music to P.S. 1 in Queens -- received increases, and one such increase went to Lincoln Center, which is not a member. Those that did not receive an increase include the Staten Island Children's Museum and the Jamaica Arts Center in Queens.
 
Every Group for Itself
 "It used to be that the C.I.G. would be funded together as a unit," said Gregory Long, chairman of the group and president of the New York Botanical Garden. "But now they've politicized the process. The 18 groups that got no increase don't want to work together in the future. They're going to be forced to fight for themselves and lobby against each other."
Mr. Cancel said that he rejected the charge of "politicizing the budget process," that he had been motivated by a desire to "allocate the available money in a way that would have the greatest impact."
The Culture Voucher Program, a new initiative conceived by Mr. Cancel, will receive $500,000 to start a pilot program under which 12,500 seventh-grade school children will be given "passports" worth about $40 to cultural events of their choice.

HEADLINE: Benefits of Federal Spending on Infrastructure

 BODY:
To the Editor:
During the debate on President Clinton's job stimulus package, I sometimes wondered if the Republicans ever gave a thought to the young lives that their filibuster may have impacted. I am a 69-year-old woman whose whole life has benefited from Federal spending during the Great Depression, even though that spending was not directed specifically toward me or my family. I can remember the strikes, the bread lines and the many hungry people who came to our door asking for food. I can also remember the jokes about the Works Progress Administration. 
 But the W.P.A. was not a joking matter in my life. My beautiful, well-designed high school in Freeport, Ill., was a W.P.A. project. In 1991 I went back to my 50th high school reunion. I found my old school building still one of the finest I have ever seen. And as a retired teacher and parent who has lived in many parts of our country, I have seen many school buildings. Not only did my class of 1941 have a beautiful school with comfortable classrooms, gym, library and band room; we had beautiful, original art hanging in the halls. And who did these paintings? Why, artists paid by the Illinois W.P.A. Arts Project.
At the 1991 reunion my old buddies and I recollected the first live symphony concerts we had ever heard, brought to us each year by the Illinois W.P.A. Symphony Orchestra under the baton of Izler Solomon. Then there was the first professional theater most of us had ever seen, the plays presented by the Chicago W.P.A. Theater. Out-of-school activities for us as teen-agers were picnics at the nearby White Pines State Park, built by the boys in the Civilian Conservation Corps, a park that has been and is enjoyed by thousands of visitors each year.
I can't speak for the contractors and workers who built my wonderful school and beautiful park, nor for the painters, musicians and actors who otherwise would have been jobless during that difficult time, but I can speak as an individual who had all kinds of wonderful experiences opened to her, and whose youth and whole life was tremendously enriched by the expenditure of public funds.
And to think that those funds have benefited and are still benefiting countless others. Would that our senators today had the breadth of understanding displayed by those of the New Deal period. They too could enrich the lives of generations to come.
 
MILDRED P. KATZ
Cambridge, N.Y., April 27, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 582 words

HEADLINE: Benefits of Federal Spending on Infrastructure;
Dole's Role Distorted

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your April 23 editorial on "Mr. Dole's Selfish Strut" grossly misconstrues the Kansas Senator's leader
ship of the successful Republican filibuster against President Clinton's economic stimulus package. You paint a distorted picture of the Senator in three respects -- his position, his record and his motives. 
 Regarding Bob Dole's position on the stimulus package, you describe his disregard for "the poorest, weakest and most undefended Americans, who might have profited by [the Administration's] job programs and by a stronger economy." In blasting the Senator's distaste for "creating jobs," you seem to endorse a theory that died along with European and Soviet Communism -- that governments should create jobs directly.
Mr. Dole argues not that unemployed Americans should be ignored, but that new jobs can be better provided by the private sector. Government's proper role is to foster a favorable business climate. This is the only effective recipe for sustained economic growth.
Mr. Clinton's spending plan, which basically amounts to providing cheap summer work for teen-agers, hardly delivers the "good jobs" he promised in his campaign. It's like putting a Band-Aid on the forehead of a headache sufferer: it fundamentally misunderstands the nature of the problem, but nonetheless creates the illusion of positive action.
You also distort Mr. Dole's record, insisting that he was instrumental in expanding the Federal deficit during the Reagan-Bush years. On the contrary, Senator Dole was a consistent and sober voice of spending control while other members of Congress (both Republican and Democrat) sought to party indefinitely on borrowed money.
Indeed, Mr. Dole often cites as his greatest achievement his forcing the 1985 austerity budget through the Senate by a vote of 50 to 49. This draconian package froze Social Security COLA's and axed 25 domestic programs. Unfortunately, neither the House nor the Reagan Administration was able to stomach the deep cuts; and a fatter budget was passed instead.
Finally, you question Mr. Dole's motives by calling him "selfish." This name-calling is utterly without basis. If he were only interested in his own electoral success, he wouldn't threaten to derail the Clinton gravy train. He would simply guide a portion of "stimulus" spending back to the voters of Kansas and reap the benefits.
Instead he made it his mission to fight the elements of Mr. Clinton's economic plan on which the President misled the voters. In his campaign, Mr. Clinton promised to cut two dollars in spending for every new dollar in taxes. Yet in his budget proposal, the ratio runs 4 to 1 in the opposite direction.
This stimulus package was entirely unnecessary. Real G.D.P. increased at an annual rate of 4.7 percent in the last quarter of 1992 (an especially impressive upturn, given that shallow recessions like the one of 1991-92 usually see very gradual recoveries); the economy was clearly rebounding vigorously without any injections of Federal spending.
So why did President Clinton deliberately break a campaign promise to include the stimulus package in his budget? The answer is obvious: so he could falsely claim credit for bringing about the recovery, thereby improving his chances for re-election in 1996. Now that is selfish behavior.
 
KRIS W. KOBACH
New Haven, April 25, 1993
The writer is a Teaching Fellow in Political Science at Yale University and is a student at Yale Law School.

HEADLINE: Eritrea, an Inspiration for Other Peoples

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In your editorial of April 28, "Eritrea's Harder Test Is Peace," you presented a challenge for Eritrea to establish a "generous peace with Ethiopia." This is truly an important test for Eritrea. However, it is an equally important challenge for Ethiopia to make peace with Eritrea. 
 With the establishment of a democratic Government in Ethiopia, the process of healing and genuine cooperation is under way. Ethiopia has agreed to respect the outcome of the referendum. Both nations are exploring ways to cooperate economically. Eritrea has agreed to guarantee Ethiopia access to the sea.
In fact, the real test of the new government in Eritrea is to develop a comprehensive strategy to rebuild the shattered infrastructure, and eliminate dependence on food aid. Water supply, agricultural productivity, communications, factories and so on were destroyed in the bitter 30-year war. Becoming self-reliant is a daunting task.
It is important not to forget that Eritrea was a pawn in cold-war strategic rivalry. This places a moral responsibility on the United States to actively become involved in reconstruction. By providing food aid, loans and technical assistance before a Somalia-like crisis develops, the United States will incur a lower and politically more acceptable cost.
Your editorial raises a concern about the trepidation of other African nations over redrawing post-colonial borders. In fact, the new Eritrea borders are the very ones drawn by the colonial powers. Rulers and tyrants in other African nations may be alarmed over this development; however, oppressed citizens in other nations are inspired by the hard-won self-determination of the Eritrean people.
With appropriate economic aid, Eritrea, in an irony of history, will become a crucial element for stability in the volatile Horn of Africa.
 
YOHANNES WOLDEMARIAM
Baltimore, April 29, 1993
