HEADLINE: Cancer-Causing Gene Found, With a Clue to How It Works

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
In findings expected to alter the direction of cancer research, scientists have discovered the existence and are near to pinpointing the location of a gene that causes several major cancers, and they have discovered a new way that aberrant genes cause the disease.
The gene, carried by 1 in 200 people, leads to colon cancer and a variety of other cancers, including uterine and ovarian. 
 Although the gene itself has not yet been isolated, the discovery is expected to lead within a few years to the development of a test to show whether a person carries the gene.
 
Odds Are Discouraging
 About 65 percent of people who carry the gene will develop colon cancer, a co-author of the new report, Dr. Albert de la Chapelle of the University of Helsinki, said in a telephone interview, adding that they constitute at least 13 percent of all colon cancer patients.
Ninety to 100 percent of those who carry the gene will get cancer, Dr. de la Chapelle said. Those who do not develop colon cancer will probably develop cancers of the uterus or ovary, or cancers of the stomach, small intestine, gall bladder, urethra, pancreas or kidney. Among those who do not get colon cancer, uterine cancer predominates. About half the women with the gene who do not get colon cancer get uterine cancer.
 
'Genuine Double Whammy'
 People who know they have the gene can have regular tests to detect cancer at an early stage, when in most cases it is more likely to be cured. And if they are at risk and find out that they do not carry the gene, they will be spared a lifetime of expensive, uncomfortable tests and worry.
All previously discovered cancer genes act by removing normal brakes on cell division, thus allowing cells to proliferate wildly. The new gene, in contrast, allows hundreds of thousands of mutations to accumulate in other genes.
 
'Genuine Double Whammy'
 The gene was found to lie in a small area of chromosome 2, one of the 23 pairs of chromosomes that contain the hereditary information in humans.
As for the other finding, the scientists said that the discovery of a new way for a gene to cause cancer would alter the direction of cancer research.
"This is a genuine double whammy," said Dr. Francis Collins, director of the National Center for Human Genome Research at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md.
 
'Phenomenally Exciting'
 Dr. Bernard Levine, chairman of the department of gastrointestinal oncology and digestive diseases at the University of Texas M. D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, said: "It's phenomenally exciting. It implies a new mechanism of cancer, a new class of genes."
Dr. Henry T. Lynch, a colon cancer specialist at Creighton University in Omaha, said, "In my opinion, it's the most important finding on this disorder in 30 years."
According to the American Cancer Society, colon cancer will be diagnosed in 152,000 Americans this year, and 57,000 will die. It is the third-leading cancer in men, after prostate and lung cancer, and the second-leading cancer in women, after lung cancer.
The latest discoveries are reported in three papers that will appear on Friday in the journal Science.
 
Many Mutations
 Two of the papers, by Dr. Bert Vogelstein of the Johns Hopkins University Oncology Center in Baltimore and Dr. de la Chapelle and their colleagues, report on the location of the gene and the observation that it induces hundreds of thousands of mutations in other genes.
The third paper, by Dr. Stephen N. Thibodeau and his colleagues at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., reports on finding the hallmark of the new cancer gene, the hundreds of thousands of mutations, in tumor cells of colon cancer patients who did not have a family history of the disease, raising the possibility that the gene is even more common than previously estimated.
Although millions of people might want to know whether they carry the gene, there are no facilities in place for mass testing. In addition, the test so far is only applicable to people from large families with a history of colon cancer where genes that are carried along with the cancer gene can be followed through the generations. This is an expedient that allows scientists to track the gene without actually isolating it. Researchers estimate that it might take two years before a genetic test is ready for everyone at risk of colon cancer.
"We don't have testing facilities set up," Dr. Collins said. "We don't have primary care organized in a way where we can do genetic counseling. These are going to be complicated issues. We have to move very quickly to develop tools to help primary-care practitioners. I don't think we can wait until something is marketed."
Dr. Levine agreed, saying: "This is one situation where we're way behind the science already. We don't have enough genetic counselors, we don't know all the ethical, economic and family-planning implications. Clearly, we don't have the expertise yet to provide people with the right sort of advice."
About two years ago, scientists discovered a different colon cancer gene, one that elicited a peculiar, and uncommon, form of the cancer. The gene causes a rare inherited syndrome, called familial adenomatous polyposis, in which people develop hundreds of thousands of tiny polyps on the wall of the colon. Some of the polyps develop into cancer.
The newly located gene is on a different chromosome, has no association with the rare inherited disorder and accounts for the exceedingly common, hereditary form of colon cancer.
Scientists caution that the new research, like any other new scientific claim, needs to be replicated by others before it can be considered absolutely certain. For example, the claim to have discovered the first colon cancer gene was followed five months later by an announcement by the same researchers, including Dr. Vogelstein, that the real gene they were looking for was actually immediately adjacent to the one they originally identified.
Until now, people looking for cancer genes consistently found tumor suppressors, genes that when mutated lead to wild and uncontrolled cell division. The familial adenomatous polyposis gene is a tumor suppressor, for example.
Dr. Vogelstein said he was astonished when he and his colleagues noticed that the new colon cancer gene was quite different. Instead of making cells divide, it caused cascades of mutations in other genes. Small, repeated segments of genes were expanding and contracting all over the genome. "This just totally blew our minds," he said.
He speculated that the colon cancer gene might lead to mistakes in copying DNA, the genetic material in the nucleus of all human cells, before a cell divides. If mistakes are not corrected, or if mistakes are actually induced, mutations could quickly accumulate, leading to cancer.
"The thing to remember is the time factor," Dr. de la Chapelle said. "We are talking about a cell or a cell clone that accumulates mutations over a long period of time. That explains why you don't get tumors when you are 2 or 12 but when you are 40."
The accumulation of hundreds of thousands of mutations was what struck Dr. Thibodeau and his colleagues as they studied cancer cells from people with colon cancer. Most of the 87 patients they studied had no family history of cancer, Dr. Thibodeau said. But in 15 tumors, or 17 percent of the group, "we observed these unique genetic alterations," he said.
Dr. de la Chapelle said the surprisingly high percentage of patients with the excessive mutations might indicate that the hereditary colon cancer gene is more common than investigators had suspected or it could be they are new mutations, the first emergence of the colon cancer gene in a family.
 
Traditional Beginning
 Dr. Vogelstein, who has studied the genetics of colon cancer for years, said that he and Dr. de la Chapelle had begun their search in the traditional way, by looking for families in which colon cancer shows up in generation after generation. Members of those families presumably carry a gene that causes the cancer. The researchers studied two large families, one in North America and one in New Zealand, that had many members in three generations who had developed colon cancer or other cancers associated with the gene.
"The major challenge in genetics is to determine the role of heredity in common diseases," Dr. Vogelstein said. "The problem with colon cancer is that it really is so common that even when you see what looks like a familial pattern, it is very difficult to tell whether it really is genetic. When something occurs in 6 percent of the population, you're going to see clusters in families just by chance."
But, Dr. Vogelstein added, "now that we have the linkage, we know beyond a shadow of a doubt that there is a genetic cause" for these cancers.

HEADLINE: LEVY ON PAYROLLS IS GAINING SUPPORT

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
Clinton Administration officials said today that they were seriously considering asking employers to pay a percentage of their payrolls in premiums to help finance health care for all Americans. To raise more money, employees would also have to pay a portion of their earnings.
Employers would pay the premium to a regional health insurance purchasing group, which would buy coverage for hundreds of thousands or millions of people. The "payroll premium" would apply to all companies that take part in the purchasing pool, including many small businesses that do not now provide health benefits to their workers. 
 Most of the nation's biggest companies serve as their own health insurers, and the Administration would probably let them continue to do so. But it hopes to lure them into the new purchasing pools.
 
Capping the Premium
 The Administration has been searching for ways to pay for its plan to revamp the nation's medical system. White House officials have assured business executives that the premium would not exceed 7 percent of payroll. If that is the case, the money would cover only part of the cost. Businesses in the program would pay the premium instead of whatever they now spend on health benefits for workers and retirees.
The Administration has discussed many other sources of revenue, including a national sales tax and higher cigarette taxes. While the cigarette tax increase is likely, the sales tax idea has apparently been discarded as politically unacceptable.
Last week Administration officials mentioned the payroll premium as one among many options. Today they said there was a strong possibility that it would be included in President Clinton's proposal this spring.
Mr. Clinton has not decided on a specific payroll premium rate. But in recent meetings with business executives, Administration officials have suggested that companies would pay a flat premium of 7 percent of payroll.
The nation's total payroll is $3.6 trillion this year. If all employers take part in the purchasing pools, a 7 percent premium or tax would raise more than $250 billion a year. The employee contributions could raise an additional sum of $40 billion to $60 billion.
John F. Sheils, a vice president of Lewin-VHI, a consulting concern that specializes in medical economics, estimated that public and private employers now spend $200 billion a year for employee health benefits, while workers pay $55 billion.
The payroll premium would thus raise some additional money for health care. Equally important, it would spread costs differently, reducing expenses for some companies that now have very high costs for employee health benefits. It would impose new costs on companies that now spend little or nothing for such benefits.
 
Seeking Support of C.E.O.'s
 Ellen L. Goldstein, director of health policy at the Association of Private Pension and Welfare Plans, a trade group composed mainly of Fortune 500 companies, said the proposal for a payroll premium had a dual purpose. "It is designed as much to get 20 C.E.O.'s on stage supporting the President's plan as it is to finance the program," she said.
Indeed, the payroll premium could garner support for the President's plan from some chief executives. Companies with older workers in manufacturing industries often pay more than 7 percent of payroll in health benefits.
For instance, Robert L. Ozment, director of insurance at the Ford Motor Company, said his company spent $1.35 billion, or 19 percent of payroll, on health benefits for workers, retirees and dependents last year. That is more than the $1.1 billion that Ford spent on steel, he said in an interview.
Small businesses generally oppose any requirements for them to provide or pay for health insurance. Some big businesses like the idea of paying premiums to an insurance purchasing group; others dislike it.
Business executives say a payroll tax or premium would increase the cost of hiring workers and would make it more difficult to create jobs, as Mr. Clinton wants to do. White House officials reject such concerns. Under the President's proposal, they say, employers would have at least two years to adapt to any new requirements.
 
Is It a Tax?
 Kristin Bass, manager of human resources policy at the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, had another complaint: the payroll premium, she said, "is really a payroll tax."
Vice President Al Gore said the premium was not a tax because it would not be paid to the Government. But a White House official acknowledged that this was a "metaphysical distinction," with little practical significance for employers.
White House officials have expressed confidence that the President's plan will hold down medical costs, and they have assured business executives that the premiums would not rise above 7 percent of payroll. But executives distrust such assurances.
Mr. Sheils, the health policy analyst at Lewin-VHI, said, "Health costs will almost certainly continue to grow faster than income and wages." To cover such costs, he said, the tax rate will need to rise above 7 percent.
 
Recalling California Plan
 The proposal for payroll premiums resembles a health-care plan proposed last year in California by the State Insurance Commissioner, John Garamendi, and one of his deputies, Walter A. Zelman, who is now working for Hillary Rodham Clinton, the head of the President's task force.
Mr. Garamendi and Mr. Zelman proposed "a single unified health-care system" for California and said it would be financed this way: "Each employer would pay a premium based on payroll. The overall average premium would be 6.75 percent of payroll, which would include the current cost of health care under workers' compensation."
In addition, they said: "Each employee would pay a premium based on wages and salaries. The overall average premium would be 1 percent of wages and salaries, with low-income workers paying less."
Under Mr. Clinton's plan, the 7 percent premium would cover the cost of a comprehensive package of health benefits defined by the Government. Workers could negotiate with employers for additional benefits. But employers could probably not take tax deductions for the cost of such extra coverage, and the benefits might be treated as taxable income for employees.
Mr. Clinton rejected suggestions today that he was spreading himself too thin and should delay sending his health-care proposal to Congress.
At a ceremony in the Rose Garden of the White House, Mr. Clinton told a group of nurses, "The lobbyists are lining up, strategizing about how they're going to pick this health-care proposal to death." But he said he would not bow to their pressure.
"I ask you to commit today not to let the special interests tell us that we can't deal with health care, not to let the special interests spook and scare the members of Congress away from doing what is our manifest duty to the people of this country," said Mr. Clinton.

HEADLINE: PANEL IN CONGRESS SEEKS A NEW IMAGE

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
Prompted by voter criticism of pork barrel spending, a Congressional panel widely viewed as a prime offender today adopted economic criteria for judging future projects.
"This represents a change in our thinking, a change in our way of doing business," said Representative Bob Carr, the Michigan Democrat who heads the panel, the Appropriations subcommittee on transportation. The subcommittee oversees more than $30 billion in Federal money for highways, airports, railroads and mass transit. 
 The panel's economic criteria would weigh the cost of a proposed project against the value of improved safety, air quality, congestion, travel time and other economic benefits. The guidelines, approved unanimously, are the first such criteria to be adopted by a House panel, and Mr. Carr said he hoped his subcommittee's example would inspire others.
In adopting the guidelines, Mr. Carr said the panel was moving away from decisions based on favoritism and political clout to determining "what will give us the greatest rate of return." He conceded, however, that these criteria would not totally replace arm-twisting and deal making.
"This is not a magic solution, not an effort to reduce everything to a number and put decision making on automatic pilot," Mr. Carr said. "But now we'll have some data."
He said several projects approved earlier by the committee, including a skyway in Jacksonville, Fla., would have not passed muster under the new criteria.
Representative Frank R. Wolf of Virginia, the ranking Republican on the committee, said the new guidelines should please taxpayers because the committee's spending decisions in the past had often been influenced by "who you know or who you hired."
Although the "cost-benefit analysis" became a staple in the executive branch in the mid-1970's, Mr. Carr said Government agencies that propose projects to his panel had a spotty record. The Federal Highway Administration does a good job weighing costs against benefits, he said. But he added that the mass transit agency falls short of the mark and the aviation agencies are "a mixed story."
Mr. Carr suggested that the committee's guidelines would even be a boon to members trying to resist the appeals of constituents seeking projects. With the new guidelines, he said, these lawmakers can blame the subcommittee for the failure of projects to be approved.
The economic criteria were developed during three months of consultations with the General Accounting Office, academic experts, Wall Street investors and management consultants.

HEADLINE: Squaring Off on Taxes;
Clinton Proposals Are Drawing Fire From Supporters of 1986 Reform Law

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
As Congress takes up the President's tax plan in earnest this week, the Clinton proposals are coming under fire from many supporters of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, who say parts of the plan will sabotage that much-praised law.
Admirers of those reforms say President Clinton's proposals will violate the spirit of '86 by creating new loopholes and rewarding tax shenanigans. They say the plan could encourage creative lawyers and accountants to play the type of tax-avoiding games the 1986 law sought to stamp out. 
 Mr. Clinton's proposals have come under heavy fire from people as diverse as Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat who was the intellectual father of the 1986 tax overhaul, and Martin S. Feldstein, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under Ronald Reagan.
 Compared with the tortured tax legislation that usually emerges from Congress, the 1986 tax act is considered a thing of rare beauty: simple, pure and virtually free of loopholes. The 1986 law broadened the tax base, taxed all forms of income at the same rate and lowered the top personal and corporate tax rates. It aimed to encourage companies and rich Americans to make financial decisions on their own merits, rather than to cut their taxes.
The opposition has already torpedoed the chances of an investment tax credit, which supporters of the 1986 law view as a loophole.
Another provision that many see as contrary to the spirit of '86 -- a large jump in the top personal income tax rate -- has survived partly because Democratic backers of the 1986 law say this increase is essential for cutting the budget deficit.
"The overall direction of the Administration's package is inconsistent with the spirit of the 1986 act because it increases rates, both individual and corporate, and it contains provisions that narrow the tax base," said Ronald Pearlman, Assistant Treasury Secretary for Tax Policy in the Reagan Administration.
Fans of the 1986 legislation fault several aspects of the Clinton plan in particular:
*A capital gains tax break for people who invest in businesses worth less than $50 million and hold those investments for five years. "It's the building block for new tax shelters," Senator Bradley said.
*The increase in the top personal income tax rate far above the capital gains rate, a move that could push the rich to hunt for tax shelters.
*Tax breaks to businesses that locate in enterprise zones. Supporters of such zones say these incentives are needed to help depressed urban and rural areas, but many backers of the 1986 law say the plan would distort business decisions.
*Restoring the investment tax credit. Critics say this would favor capital-intensive industries and unduly influence business decisions by, for example, swaying companies to spend more on machinery instead of job training. The 1986 law repealed an investment tax credit largely for these reasons.
 
'The Opposite Direction'
 Mr. Bradley called parts of the President's proposals a "rejection of the principle of tax reform." Mr. Feldstein said: "They're a complete reversal from 1986. That legislation sought to bring down rates, reduce the incentive for people to play games and cut out the search for loopholes. Now we're going in the opposite direction."
Administration officials deny that they are savaging the 1986 law, arguing that their proposals promote two objectives of the 1986 act -- fairness and economic growth. They say their plan also pursues another goal largely ignored by the 1986 act: deficit reduction.
They add that the proposals broaden the tax base by, for example, reducing deductions on business meals and eliminating deductions for country club membership. As for the President's plan to increase the top tax rate, they acknowledge it collides with the 1986 philosophy of lowering rates but say it is needed to raise revenues to cut the deficit.
"I don't think on the whole you can say the President's plan is inconsistent with 1986," said Samuel Sessions, Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary for Tax Policy. "We broadened the base and we increased the rates. Why did we do that? Because this is a deficit reduction measure."
 
Aims to Achieve Fairness
 Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said raising the top tax rates promotes fairness. "The President campaigned on a promise to restore some of the progressivity to the tax system," she said. "That may be different from what was decided in 1986, but that's what he was elected to do."
For supporters of the 1986 law, the proposed investment tax credit would be a new loophole, though Administration officials say it would spur investment and growth. Nonetheless, many business executives say they would rather forgo the credit than pay the higher corporate taxes in the President's program.
"We have virtually no support for the investment tax credit," said Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. "It will ignite all sorts of gaming."
Senator Bradley faulted the President's plan for trying to collect $30 billion by raising the corporate income tax to 36 percent from 34 percent and then giving most of that money right back to companies through the investment tax credit.
"On the corporate side, this is a direct rejection of the principle of tax reform, which is to cut rates and eliminate loopholes which were used by the rich to avoid taxes," he said. "The investment tax credit serves no economic purpose other than to reward certain narrow interest groups."
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said he believed an investment tax credit and capital gains tax break for small businesses would "encourage our businesses to make investments that will create jobs, improve productivity and put us in a better competitive position."
 
Possible Revenue Losses
 According to Mr. Feldstein, director of the National Bureau of Economic Research, the worst thing about the President's plan is it would create a large gap between the top income tax rate of 39.6 percent and the 28 percent rate for capital gains.
The 1986 law lowered the top tax rate to 28 percent from 50 percent, but the President wants to raise it to 36 percent from 31 percent for families earning $180,000 or more. (The 1990 budget accord raised the top rate to 31 percent.) For families earning $250,000 or more, the proposed surtax would raise the top rate to 39.6 percent.
This, Mr. Feldstein says, will encourage lots of maneuvering, whereby the rich rush to tax-exempt bonds or transform their ordinary income into capital gains income -- for example, by putting more of their money into sophisticated financial instruments.
Mr. Feldstein says that if the rich can maneuver to cut their taxable incomes by 10 percent, some two-thirds of the $27 billion in annual revenues the President plans to get from higher rates would disappear. Mr. Feldstein exaggerates such changes in behavior, Administration officials argue, adding that their projections already account for revenue losses from such behavior.
In its tax bill, the Administration has proposed several ways to block complex ploys that turn ordinary income into capital gains. The problem is that ingenious accountants will immediately begin seeking ways around them.
Supporters of the 1986 philosophy say the President should broaden the tax base further, noting that this might allow him to raise tax rates less. One frequent recommendation is to allow homeowners to deduct interest payments on only the first $250,000 of a mortgage, down from $1 million today.
But, says Eugene Steurle, a Reagan Administration economist and a fellow at the Urban Institute: "If you're serious about cutting the deficit, you can't have all base-broadening. At some point, you have to start raising rates."

HEADLINE: Two Committees Pass Legislation On Strike Hiring

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
Senate and House Democrats gave committee approvals today to legislation that would prohibit employers from hiring permanent replacements for strikers. The measure is organized labor's biggest demand from this Congress.
Although the Clinton Administration has strongly endorsed the bill, the prospects for enactment are uncertain because Senate Republicans are expected to lead a filibuster against it. Last year, supporters of the measure fell three votes short of the 60 needed to shut off debate. 
 "The Republicans will fight us tooth and nail," said Bob McGlotten, head of the legislative department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. He said organized labor was not assuming that those who voted for the bill last year would do so again. "We're canvassing each and every Senator," he said.
President Clinton's commitment to the bill may be measured by how two other Arkansas Democrats, Senators Dale Bumpers and David Pryor, vote this year. Both were among the five Democrats who voted with Republicans to keep the filibuster going last year, and supporters of the measure hope the two men can be persuaded to switch. Five Republicans voted to shut off debate last year.
 
House Approval Expected
 The House is expected to approve the measure relatively easily. Last year the House voted 247 to 182 for the bill. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, said the bill would be considered within a month. Senate scheduling will depend on how the votes look.
Today, the House Education and Labor Committee voted 28 to 15 to send the bill to the full House, and the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee voted 10 to 7 to send it to the full Senate.
In neither committee did any Democrats vote against the measure nor any Republicans vote for it.
Supporters of the bill contended that employers were using permanent replacements more and more in recent years, weakening the fundamental right to strike. Representative Major R. Owens, Democrat of Brooklyn, said, "If you can be replaced, you don't have the right to strike."
Opponents argued that the bill would invite strikes by favoring unions. Without the fear of losing their jobs to permanent replacements, said Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, a Kansas Republican, "there is little incentive for labor to make demands that are reasonable and reflect market realities."
The bill was first known as the Striker Replacement Bill. Then its supporters, seeking a more politically attractive title, renamed it the Workplace Fairness Bill. The House committee burnished the measure's image once again today, naming it the Cesar Chavez Workplace Fairness Bill to commemorate the farm workers union leader who died last month.
In 1938 the Supreme Court ruled that employers could hire permanent replacements when strikes dealt with wages or benefits or other economic matters. Permanent replacements can keep their jobs when a strike ends and strikers need not be re-employed.
In strikes involving claims of unfair labor practices, like a refusal to bargain in good faith, strikers must be reinstated when the dispute ends.
Temporary replacements, who must give way to returning strikers, have been widely used for many years by companies seeking to stay open despite a strike. But the use of permanent replacements has increased markedly in the last decade.
 
'Law of the Jungle'
 Advocates of the bill, like Representative William D. Ford of Michigan, chairman of the House committee, said the recent increased use of permanent replacements in disputes involving the International Paper Company and Caterpillar Inc. had "resulted in a near return to the law of the jungle."
Representative Marge Roukema, Republican of New Jersey, disagreed and maintained that replacement workers were hired in only 17 percent of recent strikes. In only 4 percent of strikes, she said, were strikers not reinstated. This showed that the present system was effective, she said, because "both sides in a labor dispute should have something to lose."
"The risks are intended to encourage settlements of labor disputes," she said.
Senator Kassebaum contended that the bill would weaken American companies' ability to compete with foreign businesses. But Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the committee chairman, said most leading industrial nations barred permanent replacements for strikers.
Senator Harris Wofford, Democrat of Pennsylvania, maintained that while he had been his state's secretary of labor, he had repeatedly seen communities torn apart when permanent replacements were hired.
House Republicans have labeled the measure the Strike Maker Bill, saying that it would give labor too much power and that it would be bad for the economy.
Representative Bill Goodling, the senior Republican on the House committee, today noted an event of 175 years ago. "This is Karl Marx's birthday," he said. "He couldn't ask for a better birthday present."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative William D. Ford, right, presided over the Education and Labor Committee yesterday as Democratic members endorsed legislation barring the hiring of permanent replacements for strikers. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Maturities Shortened

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Treasury Department surprised the bond market yesterday by making a big change in its debt management policy, shifting its emphasis to shorter-term borrowing.
The Treasury announced that it would increase the sale of two- and three-year notes and shorter-term Treasury bills, so it can reduce its borrowing through issues with maturities of five years and over by 45 percent. In the process, the Treasury eliminated the seven-year note, a favorite tool in the corporate and mortgage markets. 
 It also said it would cut its issuance of 30-year bonds by 40 percent, to about $22 billion a year. Auctions of 30-year bonds will be reduced to two times a year, from four, starting in August.
Immediately after the Treasury's announcement, Treasury prices and yields gyrated. But by the end of the day, they were little changed, reflecting a wait-and-see attitude.
The decision seemed to be driven by two factors: The Treasury wanted to lower intermediate- and long-term interest rates, and it hoped to achieve $16 billion in savings over five years by shifting borrowings from higher-interest rate long-term securities to lower-interest rate short-term securities. President Clinton promised the savings in his budget.
"We have considered this issue very carefully and believe the restructuring of our debt mix, over the long run, is in the best interests of American taxpayers," Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said in a statement. "This action to shorten the maturity of Treasury borrowing will produce real savings on interest costs over time. It is a carefully crafted and moderate move."
But the view from the bond market was different. While the 30-year bond had rallied this year in part because of expectations that the size of the auction would be reduced, many economists and analysts still opposed the move because they like the predictability and consistency of more frequent auctions. They also argued that it was a bad idea to bet that short-term interest rates would remain low.
"The real issue of whether this is a good idea or not is not whether short rates stay low for a few years but whether they stay low for 30 years," said William Dudley, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, which had predicted most of the Treasury's decision.
And Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, said, "I think it will cost the taxpayer money over time." .
In addition, traders said the elimination of the seven-year note could affect the functioning of the mortgage, corporate and swaps markets, where Treasury securities are used to hedge against the risk of losses on bonds and derivative products. "We lost a hedging vehicle and that is not good," said Vin Pica, a managing director at Prudential Securities.
Some traders also wondered about how to interpret the Treasury Secretary's moves in the future. He had promised for weeks that there would be no "radical" change in the borrowing mix. But traders and analysts saw yesterday's move as just that. "I would call this much more toward the radical end of the spectrum and more radical than they had been leading the market to believe," said John Costas, managing director of government trading and sales at the First Boston Corporation.
 
Changed Auction Schedule
 The last seven-year note was issued in April, and the first time it will be missed will be in July, when the next auction is scheduled. The 30-year bond auction next week will total $8.25 billion, down $1 billion from February. The shift to a twice-a-year rotation will occur in August, with the next auction in February.
The Treasury immediately increased the size of next week's three-year note auction to $16 billion, from $15.5 billion in February. But it did not cut the size of the 10-year note auction, leaving it at February's $10.75 billion level.
That apparently reflected a decision that getting rid of the less liquid seven-year note would have a bigger impact on intermediate-term interest rates than cutting each issue some. Intermediate-term interest rates, many economists argue, are more important than the 30-year bond yield because so much economic activity, including home mortgages, are based on interest rates in the 7-to-10-year range.
The Treasury also said that because of a severe shortage of both the 10-year note and the 30-year bond, it would auction more of the 6.25 percent 10-year note and the 7.125 percent 30-year bond next week rather than selling a new issue.
Some analysts argue that reducing 30-year bond auctions can bring down interest rates by reducing supply while demand remains the same. This would push prices higher and bring down yields. But it is debatable how much rates would fall. Mr. Dudley of Goldman, Sachs argued that economic fundamentals would be far more important and suggested that this could shave no more than 5 or 10 basis points off yields.
 
Savings Could Be Lost
 As far as the savings the Treasury is seeking, a rise in short-term interest rates could wipe out the savings and even increase the cost to taxpayers because the turnover of borrowing will be so much faster and will expose the Treasury to moves in short-term rates. Many corporations now are moving to longer-term borrowing to lock in the lowest long-term rates in almost two decades.
In describing the strategy yesterday, Deborah Danker, the Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary for Federal Finance, would not estimate the savings. But the plan announced is similar to one proposed by the Senate Budget Committee, which has estimated savings of $16 billion if short-term interest rates do not change.
She said that the Treasury was exposed to a rise in short-term rates but that "there will be no flip-flopping." She emphasized that the strategy has a much longer-term focus, which is aimed at cutting the risk premium the Treasury pays when it borrows longer-term securities.
"The strategy is based over time, a long time, on the idea that the yield curve is on average upward sloping because of the risk premium for longer-term securities," she said.
In trading, the price of the 30-year bond was up only 4/32 , to 10411/32 , to yield 6.78 percent, down from 6.79 percent. In part, this was because the switch to two 30-year auctions was delayed until August. The price of the to-be-eliminated seven-year note was up only 2/32 to yield 5.47 percent, down from 5.48 percent. Traders said the drastic cut in supply was outweighed by the fact that the seven-year note was now an orphan.

HEADLINE: Clinton Again Delays Announcing His Campaign-Finance Plan

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
Still struggling to win Congressional support for President Clinton's campaign-finance package, the White House today put off announcing the measure, at the request of House Democrats who wanted more time to negotiate over the proposal.
The postponement, from Thursday to at least Friday, is the latest of several delays in the timetable that Administration officials had set for producing a political package. Mr. Clinton had pledged to move quickly after taking office to unveil legislation that would curb the soaring costs of running for office and the dominance of special interests in campaigns. 
 But he has found that moving beyond the promises of last year's campaign and getting Democrats to agree on a bill is far more difficult than he predicted. While the substance of his proposal is much simpler than, say, overhauling the health-care system, no legislation is more politically charged than a plan to change the way people get elected.
White House officials largely blame House Democrats for the difficulty. Many House members from their own party, the White House says, have been far more resistant than anticipated to changing the system that helped them win election in the first place.
 
Details and Loopholes
 After weeks of negotiations with House and Senate Democrats and officials of the Democratic National Committee, the White House has drafted the outline of a bill that would limit spending by candidates, reduce the influence of political action committees and make it easier for challengers to finance their campaigns.
But when it comes to campaign finance legislation, what is important is the details -- or, to view it another way, the loopholes -- and House Democrats were still haggling this evening among themselves over specifics in the plan. Mr. Clinton sought to speed up a resolution by dispatching his chief of staff, Thomas F. McLarty 3d, to Capitol Hill last week, but the session only seemed to widen the rifts.
"I think the delays in part reflect the tremendous amount of resistance to a strong reform package," said Gene Karpinski, executive director of the U.S. Public Interest Research Group, which favors the changes. "The fact that these reforms might now be real has just heightened the opposition."
 
Pulled in Two2 Directions
 On one side are House Democrats who resent Mr. Clinton's efforts to tamper with the system that got them elected. Democrats in the Senate, who face re-election only every six years, have not been as nervous.
On the other side, lobbying groups and some in Congress are advocating change. They accuse Mr. Clinton of not going far enough and of being pressed into watering down his original proposal.
To accommodate the House members, the President weeks ago backed off from his campaign pledge to reduce to $1,000 from $5,000 the maximum amount a political action committee can donate to a candidate. He has made other concessions as well, like backing off a proposal to funnel public money to the national political parties.
In its latest form, the bill would offer incentives, like vouchers for television time, if House candidates capped their spending at $600,000 and Senate candidates adhered to a limit ranging from $950,000 to $5.5 million, depending on the state's population. The plan would also restrict large, unregulated contributions to political parties from corporations, unions and wealthy donors. And it would eliminate the tax deduction for lobbying expenses.
Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the Speaker, sought today to play down the differences between House Democrats and the White House. "I think we're coming to a very large consensus on what should be in the bill," he said. "It may not be 100 percent, but it's very substantial, and there may be some areas in which we agree to disagree. But I think in the overwhelming landscape of these issues that there is a very, very strong agreement."
Mr. Foley cautioned, however, that "there's still a very difficult problem over organizations like Emily's List," a political action committee for female candidates.
 
Support for 'Bundling'
 Emily's List contends that its efforts would be greatly damaged by a provision in the draft proposal to eliminate "bundling," the process by which organizations group individual donations to demonstrate their power.
Ellen R. Malcolm, the president of Emily's List, said: "Virtually all the top elected women are saying this is a terrible mistake. Women don't raise money from the same large donor networks that men do."
Representative Mike Synar, an Oklahoma Democrat who is one of the most outspoken advocates of a strong bill, called on Mr. Clinton to not give in to House members who do not truly want change. "If the President is bold, we will have no choice but to be bold," he said. "We need to be shamed by the President and the Senate to do a better job."
Even if the House Democrats throw their support to the proposal, Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, has already said he will lead a filibuster on whatever legislation emerges.
Complicating the already touchy discussions is that Mr. Clinton is trying to win support in Congress for his other proposals, including his economic plan and his health-care package.
And then there is the wild card of Ross Perot, whose pet issue is political reform.
"Perot is the proverbial 600-pound gorilla on this," said Mr. Synar, who is pushing for a bill that is more far reaching than the drafts that have circulated from the White House. "It's the only thing that he really has going for him. I'm confident if we do a good job on this, Ross Perot is history."
In a study of the 1992 general elections that was released today, two organizations lobbying for changes, Public Citizen and the U.S. Public Interest Research Group, sought to demonstrate why the legislation was necessary.
Among other things, the study found that in 265 of the 287 races where House incumbents faced challengers, the incumbent outspent the challenger by at least $100,000. It also found that in 211 of 287 races, incumbents raised at least $150,000 more from political action committees than their challengers raised.
 
No Cheers for Change
 "The key issue that we've been fussing about for a long time is that Congressional races are not competitive," said Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen. She said the President's proposal "will have a substantial impact on that by putting a limit on expenditures."
The reluctance among Democratic lawmakers to pass a campaign finance bill was demonstrated Tuesday night when the President addressed the Democratic Congressional Campaign Dinner, a fund-raising event here.
The lawmakers and the lobbyists who bought tickets cheered when Mr. Clinton talked about reforming education, creating jobs and improving health care. But there was hardly a peep when he declared, "We ought to pass a campaign finance reform bill."

HEADLINE: Manufacturers and Farmers Oppose Clinton Energy Tax

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
Manufacturers and farmers organizations declared war on President Clinton's proposed energy tax today, while at the same time opponents in the Congress said it would hurt industry and agriculture.
On the day the House Ways and Means Committee took up the energy tax, the National Association of Manufacturers and the American Farm Bureau announced that they had formed a coalition of more than 900 companies and associations that would fight the tax. 
 The coalition asserted that the tax would make American industry less able to compete in the world market and seriously harm rural America.
Jerry Jasinowski, president of the manufacturers group, said everyone would lose under the proposed tax "because it directly hurts the American economy at so many important points."
"This particular tax is a jobs killer," he said.
 
Unease in Both Camps
 The coalition's concerns were voiced just a few hours later by members of the Ways and Means Committee, the House's chief tax-writing committee, as Republicans said the energy tax would weaken American industry and farm-state Democrats voiced uneasiness with it.
"You're raising the price of every manufactured product," said Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the committee's ranking Republican.
Representative Peter Hoagland, Democrat of Nebraska, said farmers would have problems passing on the increased costs stemming from the tax because they operate in a fiercely competitive global market.
The Administration's energy tax is based on the heat content of fuels as measured in B.T.U.'s, or British thermal units. The proposed tax, expected to raise more than $20 billion a year, would be levied on coal, gasoline, natural gas and other forms or energy.
 
What Would Replace It?
 Sander Levin, a Michigan Democrat who was one of the committee's most vocal defenders of the tax, said the tax was an important part of the President's proposal. He laid down a challenge to the tax's opponents, saying, "It's important to ask, 'If it were removed, what would be in its place?' "
Even with a few Democratic defections, the proposal is expected to survive the Ways and Means Committee, where Democrats outnumber Republicans, 24 to 14. But it will face a tougher time in the Senate Finance Committee, the Senate's principal tax-writing committee, because the Democrats have 11 members to the Republicans' 9. In addition, some Democrats on the panel come from states dominated by agriculture and the energy industry.
The new coalition is called the Affordable Energy Alliance and includes the American Petroleum Institute, the American Dairy Products Institute and the National Federation of Independent Business, a grouping of 600,000 small businesses. Notably absent from the coalition was the United States Chamber of Commerce.
Many energy producers oppose the tax because it would raise energy prices and probably eat into energy consumption, and industry profits.
Responding to the formation of the coalition, a Treasury official said: "There are a lot of business concerned about the effect that the deficit has on our nation's economic prospects, who are supporting the President's plan, B.T.U. tax and all. They are concerned about the consequences of a continued failure to rein in the deficit."
In a news conference, Mr. Jasinowski said the new coalition hoped to block the tax in the House, but he predicted that the opponents would have a better chance killing it in the Senate. He said the coalition would focus on contacting lawmakers in states with large energy industries, including Louisiana, Wyoming, North Dakota, Texas and West Virginia.
How successful Washington-based industry groups are in blocking the tax could hinge largely on whether they succeed in getting thousands of businesses and farmers around the country to fight the tax.
The coalition said the new tax would significantly slow economic growth and cost the nation more than 600,000 jobs by 1998 -- an assertion Administration officials said was vastly exaggerated.
 
Squeeze on Farmers?
 According to the coalition, the energy tax and raising the cost of using inland waterways would squeeze farmers, costing an Illinois farmer with 500 acres of grain $670 a year.
To increase the tax's chances, the Administration has changed it several times since it was unveiled on Feb. 17. Petroleum products are supposed to be taxed at a higher B.T.U. rate than other fuels with the aim of reducing oil imports. But bowing to pressures from senators in New England, the Administration decided not to place the special levy on home-heating oil because so many New England homes are heated by oil.
For coal, the tax was originally to be levied at the mine mouth, but this was changed after mining companies complained that they were not equipped to measure the B.T.U. content of their coal. The Administration now proposes that the tax on coal be collected at the utility or industrial-end user.

HEADLINE: In Cattle-Raising West, a County Wants to Help U.S. Manage Federal Lands

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RESERVE, N.M., May 5

 BODY:
In the last four years Catron County here in southwestern New Mexico has been a thorn in the side of environmentalists and Federal agencies. The county has been filing lawsuits against the Federal Government and passing its own land-use ordinances in a struggle to gain more authority over how Federal forest and grazing lands within its boundaries are managed.
Now the county, home to 2,600 people and a $21 million cattle industry, wants Washington to let it help manage Federal lands under a contract with the Government. And while many environmental groups are suspicious of the county's motives, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt may have no choice but to give the plan a hearing. 
 Catron County has become a center of the movement among ranchers, loggers, property owners and cities to make environmental protection less costly. Its latest proposal is being considered by several Government agencies, and it has been endorsed by Western Senators of both parties.
 
May Be Focus of Hearing
 The plan could become a focus of debate on Thursday when ranchers and environmental groups meet in Albuquerque at the fourth of five public hearings that Mr. Babbitt will hold on the Administration's plan to raise fees for grazing cattle on Federal land.
President Clinton's proposal to increase grazing fees by 56 percent has met with a groundswell of opposition in Western states, where roughly 258 million acres of public land owned by the Forest Service and the Interior Department's Bureau of Land Management, are open to grazing by sheep and cattle. The aim of the Administration's plan is to end the Government's subsidy of cattle ranching in the West and ease damage to the environment.
Under the Catron County proposal, the county would contract with the Federal Government to help maintain grazing lands that extend across a region of mountains, meadows and desert larger than Connecticut. The county argues that the plan would allow it to improve the condition of Federal lands without raising the grazing fees for ranchers.
 
Government Reviewing Plan
 Aspects of the plan were described to top Administration officials last month by Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, at a White House meeting. Mr. Bingaman said in an interview that it is also being reviewed by the Interior and Agriculture Departments.
"These rural counties have very serious problems of sustaining their economic life, and we need innovative solutions to help," said Senator Bingaman. "I think this is one idea that has some merit and is worth exploring."
But environmentalists in New Mexico and around the country say that allowing Western counties, which are influenced by ranchers and loggers, such control in the management of public forests and grazing lands would weaken ecological safeguards.
"It's a terrible idea," said Sam Hitt, director of Forest Guardians, a regional environmental group based in Santa Fe. "It would set a bad precedent. I don't think counties have the expertise, and they are biased toward livestock at the expense of wildlife, water quality and endangered species."
In the past, environmentalists said they viewed the county's legal and political work with more skepticism than alarm. But the newest proposal poses a more substantial threat because of the interest it has generated in Washington, they said.
 
Seeking a New Agency
 Catron County leaders said that hiring the county to care for the range would save money for the Federal Government while demonstrating that counties could protect the environment without choking the economic life out of rural communities.
The proposal would establish a new local agency to provide range management services under contract to the Forest Service. The agency would hire experts to see that the Federal lands would not be overgrazed, that there would be cover and food for wildlife and that erosion would be controlled. Under the plan, the number of Federal employees now doing similar work would be reduced. The county contends this is where the Federal Government would save money.
"What we are after is a creative approach," said Dick Manning, a 56-year-old cattleman who runs 145 head on his Devil's Park ranch in a tight canyon along the San Francisco River 20 miles south of here. "There's a lot of environmental concerns that we share with the conservation groups.
"But we have got to solve the problems without destroying our economy, our customs and our culture. Our life styles are different, but our goals and desires about the land are not."
Mr. Manning, a central figure in the county's struggle for more authority over Federal land use, said the battle is not necessarily between ranchers and environmentalists. He sees it as county residents fighting to regain civil and economic rights that are being eroded by Government regulations.
"This country here is beautiful because people here took care of it," he said while saddling a quarter horse. "The endangered species are here because we did not ruin this ground. The pure streams are here. The forests are here. But we are accused of destroying this land and the Government is the one that is going to come in and protect it with rules and regulations. We just realized that if we don't stand up and fight it was all over."
If the plan is approved, it would be the first time a county had been contracted to help manage public range lands, Government officials said. James Perry, the assistant general counsel for natural resources at the Department of Agriculture, said that such a contract would not require amending Federal laws and could be done through administrative actions.
Since 1906, when the Government began to charge ranchers a monthly fee for every cow and calf fed on public land, every proposed increase has raised some level of opposition among ranchers in the West. But President Clinton's proposal earlier this year to raise the monthly fee for a cow and calf to $2.90 by the end of the decade, 56 percent more than the current $1.86 fee, caused a political storm.
The White House said it was time to end subsidies that were costing the Government tens of millions of dollars a year. Raising the grazing fees would also put cattle ranchers on the same competitive footing as those producing beef on private land, where the costs of leasing land is higher.
But a vast majority of the more than 30,000 ranchers who graze cattle on public land argue that a 56 percent increase would drive thousands of them out of business. They said the result would be to push families off the land, opening counties like Catron to more extensive development by resorts, condominiums and shopping centers, bringing with them higher water pollution and air pollution.
 
Population Damage Cited
 "When you replace a family ranch with five people with a subdivision of 3,000 people, that is significantly more damage to the environment," said Howard Hutchinson, a resident of Glenwood, 40 miles southwest of here, who helped prepare the Catron County proposal. "All the ramifications to the environment from removing cattle from the public lands have not been closely examined."
Such arguments about the human and environmental costs of the Administration's plan have largely been dismissed by environmental groups, particularly those on the East Coast. In the Southwest, some environmental leaders are more sympathetic to the concerns of rural communities.
Lynda Taylor, a staff member of the Southwest Research and Information Center, an environmental research group in in Albuquerque, said: "Environmentalists are locked into their perspective, and they have not looked very carefully at the legitimate concerns of a community whose life is based on natural resources. This is a new issue for environmentalists and for the West. We don't want to supplant one environmental problem with another."
 
Ranching in Gila Forest
 Here in Catron County, almost all the cattle are born and reared in the Gila National Forest, which covers 70 percent of the land. Thus ranchers are subject not just to Government grazing fees but to Federal policies controlling the number of cattle on the land and how the animals are managed.
Earlier this year, the county commissioned an economic analysis from Western New Mexico University about the effect of a 40 percent increase in grazing fees. The study predicted that if the fee was raised to $2.52 a month, the number of cattle would decline to 26,400 from 42,000. Such a sharp drop, the report warned, would reduce the number of ranches to 99 from 165, cut the number of jobs in the industry to 198 from 500 and reduce wages to less than $600,000 a year from nearly $1 million.
The study predicted that most of those who lost their jobs would take their families and leave Catron County, causing the population to drop to less than 2,000 people.
"We're like the Apaches fighting the Government to keep them from taking everything from us," said Harvey Hart, a cowboy and saddle maker. "People are struggling out here to stay alive."
The grim prospects of an increase in the grazing fee led to the county's land-management proposal.
"We can have cattle and a healthy range, and we want to prove it," said Victor Jenkins, a former Forest Service range specialist who helped draw up the plan. But Forest Service staff members here have their doubts.
"They might be in fat city for one or two years." said Gary McCaleb, a Forest Service employee. "But after that the regulations, the lawsuits, and the sheer weight of paperwork will put them exactly where we're at today -- paralyzed."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Medphone blames a messenger for its stock-price troubles.

BYLINE: By Kurt Eichenwald

 BODY:
THE Medphone Corporation had two options in explaining why its stock collapsed:
a) Because the Paramus, N.J., company was hemorrhaging cash, losing sales and hanging in such precarious financial condition that its own auditors doubted its survival. 
 Or, b) Because a small investor from Long Island said mean things about Medphone on a computer bulletin board.
Faced with that choice, the maker of electronic cardiac treatment systems blamed the guy with the computer. Setting a legal precedent and raising the corporate blame game to new heights, Medphone sued the investor, Peter DeNigris, for making a series of critical comments about the company on Prodigy's Money Talk bulletin board system.
Medphone said Mr. DeNigris's comments, including allegations that the company could fail and that big stock sellers were in the wings, caused shares to plummet, falling from $1.75 a share in April 1992 to 25 cents yesterday on the American Stock Exchange's Emerging Company Marketplace. On Tuesday, the company said that the Amex would delist its stock next week and that its shares would begin trading over the counter.
Mr. DeNigris sounds pretty powerful. Particularly since, according to his lawyer, Thomas F. Chansky, he did not own a computer until June -- long after Medphone shares began to collapse. Documents from Prodigy show Mr. DeNigris, a resident of Babylon, L.I., did not make his first Medphone comment until July, when the stock had already dropped to 56.25 cents a share. And the plunge could be traced to the summer of 1991, when Medphone's share price fell from $4.25 to $1.31.
No matter to Medphone. "That market decline is not objectively related to the company's performance," the company said in its complaint, filed in September. Rather, it said, Mr. DeNigris's "disparaging statements about Medphone are causing the otherwise inexplicable decline."
Well, not to wave a red flag in front of a suing bull, but if Medphone executives think shareholders had little reason to sell, they haven't been reading their own S.E.C. filings. Even a modest perusal would give any investor the willies.
Start with the company's 10-K for the fiscal year 1992, ended June 30. Sales of its medical products fell more than 50 percent from the previous year. Gross profits fell more, down to slightly more than $62,000. Meanwhile, net losses climbed, to $2.3 million from $1.6 million. The company attributed this performance to the economy.
Still don't see a reason for the "inexplicable" stock drop? Then look at the report of Deloitte & Touche, Medphone's independent auditor. "The company's recurring losses and negative cash flow from operations raise substantial doubt about its ability to continue as a going concern," the auditors wrote in their 1992 report.
Things don't get much better in more recent filings. In the first two quarters of this fiscal year, sales grew only slightly over last year's anemic performance for the first six months, from $54,017 to $57,175. But the cost of sales also climbed, meaning gross profits fell yet again.
And Medphone has been burning through cash -- much of it raised in a 1991 secondary stock offering. During the first six months of this fiscal year, cash plummeted from $729,725 to just $27,439. There seems to be little chance of more money from the capital markets. And in its lawsuit, the company says the stock drop "effectively prevented Medphone from obtaining capital necessary for the continuation and expansion of its business," a problem for which it blames Mr. DeNigris. Inventory climbed, even as the company cut advertising and marketing efforts.
Don't think that means other expenses are being cut: Consulting and professional fees almost doubled, to more than $100,000. The reason? Pursuing Mr. DeNigris in court costs money, and apparently Medphone executives think they have nothing better to spend it on.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Group of 7 Nations: Suddenly Pals, But Can They Coordinate?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
DID the finance ministers of the industrial powers really have nothing to squabble about at their meeting in Washington last week -- or did someone spike the punch bowl with LSD? Not to worry: The psychotropic drug of choice, at least in the northwest quadrant of the capital city, remains power.
One reason sweetness and light prevailed, Shafiqul Islam of the Council on Foreign Relations suggests only half-jokingly, is that all seven ministers had been embarrassed by their governments' barroom rhetoric on trade issues. Perhaps more important, there is strong agreement on two paramount issues: the need to stimulate global economic growth and the collective interest in keeping a pro-Western government at the helm of the Russian Federation. It is possible, then, that it will be back to sniping-as-usual -- perhaps even by the economic summit meeting in July. 
 But this mini-era of good feeling does raise an intriguing question. For the last two decades, economists have been fretting over the consequences of failing to coordinate national economic policies in a world of increasingly open markets for goods, capital and labor. Has something changed to make coordination a less impossible dream?
If the industrial powers are looking for an object lesson in the doleful consequences of going it alone, they have only to look at the last few years.
Bonn's unyielding reliance on sky-high interest rates to punish trade union wage hawks and to cope with the costs of German reunification upset Europe's best-laid plans for speedy monetary unification. Toyko's dawdling on fiscal stimulus tipped Japan into recession and gave American auto makers and other protectionists a juicy bilateral trade deficit to point fingers at. Washington's dithering over aid to the former Soviet Union weakened the political hand of radical reformers and helped bring the repository of half the world's nuclear weapons to the edge of anarchy. Economic summitry had come to resemble propaganda exercises, with elected officials mugging for the folks back home.
But this latest meeting of finance ministers seemed to have been orchestrated by Miss Manners: "The Japanese stimulus package was a little bigger thanks to G-7 pressure," says Fred Bergsten of the Institute for International Economics, "and certainly the Germans are feeling the heat on interest rates." For its part, the Clinton Administration is taking aim at the budget deficit, which the rest of the Group of Seven have been complaining about since the mid-1980's.
Is there a way to encourage more of this good thing? It was once fashionable to argue that the Group of Seven needed a permanent staff to scold governments into virtuous behavior. No longer. Robert Solomon of the Brookings Institution expects the International Monetary Fund is the closest thing to the hoped-for nanny the Group of Seven is ever likely to get, and dismisses the idea that hired hands can make much difference when national interests are at odds.
Richard Cooper, a Harvard economist and senior diplomat in the Carter Administration, offers a cautiously optimistic perspective. In the early 1980's, he notes, lower interest rates were needed to dig the third world out of the debt crisis, a goal achievable through a coordinated tightening of fiscal policies and loosening of monetary policies.
But the switch was out of the question in large part because the Reagan Administration did not agree with the underlying analysis -- namely that monster American budget deficits were jacking up interest rates. Today, by contrast, there are no comparable analytic conflicts among the economic powers, and thus there is at least the hope of agreeing on which means would serve which ends.
Robert Putnam, a historian of economic summitry at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, adds another reason to accent the positive. "The only times significant work has been done at economic summits," he concludes, "is when it was a White House priority." And unlike its predecessor, he argues, the Clinton Administration seems to take the process seriously.
But Mr. Putnam is not yet uncorking the Dom Perignon. Another likely precondition to revitalizing the Group of Seven, he notes, is strong leaders -- leaders who can make good on their pledges at the expense of powerful domestic interests. And among the seven, probably only Bill Clinton qualifies. Indeed, it is hard to remember a time when so many of these heads of state had so little claim to the affection or even respect of the electorate.
For example, could Kiichi Miyazawa, whose party has been devastated by scandal, take on Japanese rice growers? Could Francois Mitterrand, a lame-duck President, challenge the French grain lobby? Is Helmut Kohl in any position to tell eastern Germans that the good life is still a decade away?
The head says no, but some hearts say maybe. "The G-7 is back," enthuses Robert Hormats of Goldman Sachs International, who very much wants it to be true. "The pace and extent of cooperation is self-reinforcing," Mr. Bergsten adds, and is "more than the sum of the parts."

HEADLINE: Embattled Japanese Doctor Retains W.H.O. Post

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

 BODY:
A Japanese doctor, Hiroshi Nakajima, was re-elected yesterday as head of the World Health Organization, a United Nations agency, despite an extraordinary last-minute effort by the United States and European countries to block his re-election.
Dr. Nakajima won a second five-year term in a 93-to-58 vote at the annual meeting of the World Health Assembly in Geneva. 
 The United States and other major donor countries of the health organization contended that Dr. Nakajima, 65, was a poor administrator and communicator and had lost the support of the organization's 4,600-member staff.
But Japan campaigned vigorously to prevent Dr. Nakajima's ouster, and has denied accusations from Western countries that it had used bribery and threats of economic sanctions.
Dr. Nakajima's victory left a cloud of uncertainty over the future of the organization because his re-election was opposed by all the major donor countries. The United States has repeatedly said that the organization is essential to world health. But United States representatives at the World Health Assembly said that they were deeply concerned about problems that could develop between the Clinton Administration and Congress over support for the organization because loss of confidence in Dr. Nakajima's leadership was so widespread. The United States pays 25 percent of the organization's budget.
Walter Broadnax, Under Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, who led the U.S. delegation, said the Clinton Administration and the governments of "many other nations cannot justify going to our legislatures and people to request funds for W.H.O. unless we can assure those people that corrective steps are being taken in relation to both the fact and the appearance of any misconduct."
"Only managerial and leadership changes can prevent further erosion" in the organization's effectiveness, Mr. Broadnax told The Associated Press.
Dr. Nakajima passed a key hurdle last January when the organization's executive board voted 18 to 13 to recommend his re-election. Such recommendations have always led to unanimous approval at the World Health Assembly.
But before the election, a lengthy, acrimonious two-day debate erupted over the selection of Dr. Nakajima. It focused on auditors' reports on the awarding of contracts to members of the executive board prior to its January vote recommending Dr. Nakajima. Executive Board Chairman Jean-Francois Girard of France ordered the audit after reports that Japan was using threats and vote-buying to win Dr. Nakajima's re-election.
Mr. Girard said that 23 of the 31 board members were awarded contracts. Approximately 60 such contracts were awarded in the final half of 1992. The largest -- for $150,000 -- went to a former health minister in the Philippines for a study of his country's health system. Mr. Girard called the contracts legal but said that they presented "a problem of ethics."
"The question is not whether these contracts were technically within the rules," Mr. Broadnax said. But he added that the health organization "must meet the highest standards of accountability."
During the Assembly debate, Canada urged a ban on W.H.O. contracts with board members and recently retired staff members.

HEADLINE: Budapest Tries to Sell Hungarians on Capitalism

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, May 5

 BODY:
All over the Hungarian capital, a little boy in the red fez, the trademark of an Austrian grocery chain, beckons buyers. In addition, a German clothing chain's outlets and American candy shops compete for space along the Great Ring Road in Budapest with fast food franchises like Pizza Hut, Kentucky Fried Chicken and Dunkin' Donuts.
But the market economy that has brought variety to store shelves in the Hungarian capital has also brought the prospect of new monopolies. 
 Foreign retail companies are not only envied for the resources they can devote to modernizing their retail operations and advertising campaigns. They are also accused of passing up Hungarian goods in favor of imports, and contributing to the collapse of domestic industries already hit hard by the demise of the Comecon market.
Hungarians are trying to fight back against what many see as a potential foreign economic takeover. Opposition parties have called for privatization to be brought under direct supervision of parliament to insure that foreign companies do not buy Hungarian companies just to take over their markets.
The Christian Democratic People's Party, a member of the three-party governing coalition, has called for privatization in the food-processing sector to be halted. And the populist wing of the dominant Hungarian Democratic Forum is pushing for privatization to be slowed.
After a German retail group backed out of talks with the State Property Agency to buy Hungary's Centrum department store chain, a group of Hungarian businessmen made a bid for a majority share in the company.
"Retail chains with a 100-year tradition of selling Hungarian goods are dangerous to sell to foreigners whose interest is in selling through their own international networks," said Peter Vadasz, the president of Microsystem, Ltd. and the leader of the 10 businessmen who tried to gain a controlling share of Centrum.
Two years ago, foreigners acquired 70 percent of privatized property in Hungary. While that figure has decreased by now to about 50 or 60 percent, Hungarians still feel largely shut out of privatization.
Late last year, the Government decided to encourage Hungarian participation in privatization by floating shares of two prominent state-owned companies, the Danubius Hotels and Pick Salami, on the Budapest stock exchange. Now, after hesitating over the bid by the 10 businessmen, the State Property Agency has decided to float Centrum shares on the exchange.
In an attempt to coax Hungarians to part with some of their savings, the Government has also decided to offer installment payment opportunities for small investors to purchase shares in some state companies that will be listed on the Budapest Stock Exchange.
According to Eva Voszka, a specialist in privatization at the Financial Research Institute in Budapest, savings in Hungary amount to about $10.5 billion, or approximately half the value of state-owned assets.
"Savings in Hungary have grown very rapidly in the last three years, to everyone's surprise," Ms. Voszka said. "The problem is that people don't want to invest in state assets, because the profitability is very low."
Of 1,500 state enterprises, 15 percent are profitable, one-third are just surviving, and half are showing losses. Up to now, in spite of the governing party's hope of privatizing half of state property in three years, only about 17 percent of state property has been transferred to private hands.
To attract more domestic investors, the Government is considering easing terms for credit. It is also dividing large companies into smaller units that would be potentially more affordable to Hungarians.
"The splitting up of enterprises is a new slogan of the Government, and the other side of the program to create a strong middle class," Ms. Voszka said.
But critics say that by succumbing to political pressure to distribute state assets cheaply to citizens, the Hungarian Government is ducking the main economic aim of privatization.
"We've already learned that you can't just create a working class," Mr. Vadasz added. "Well, the same goes for creating a middle class."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Against Mark And Gold Is Off in New York

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against the German mark amid disappointment that the Bundesbank did not ease German interest rates further. But signs of a sluggish economic recovery limited the dollar's gains.
The dollar also firmed slightly against the Japanese yen, but it slumped against a resurgent Swiss franc. 
 Gold prices fell 20 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, where gold for current delivery settled at $354.60 an ounce. Late in the day, the Republic National Bank quoted spot gold at $353.75 an ounce, down 55 cents.
The German central bank allowed money market rates to slip to 7.71 percent from 7.75 percent in its weekly open market operation yesterday. The modest easing suggested to foreign exchange dealers that the bank would not immediately cut official rates. The mark drifted against most European currencies and the yen.
"There is a belief that rates are close to bottoming out everywhere in Europe except Germany, so the mark is falling across the board," a bank dealer in New York said.
The Swiss franc finished in Europe at its strongest close against the mark since mid-December. Dealers said previous speculation that the Swiss National Bank might cut interest rates was dashed by expectations of growing inflation.
The lira held up well despite a downgrading of Italy's foreign currency debt to A1 from Aa3 by Moody's Investor Service Inc.
The dollar rose to 1.5791 German marks in late New York trading, from 1.5755 marks on Tuesday.
The dollar showed little immediate reaction to the news that the Treasury was reducing its offerings of 30-year bonds, emphasizing instead those issues with shorter maturities.
Tokyo markets were closed until today for national holidays. In New York, the dollar was quoted late yesterday at 110.55 Japanese yen, up from 110.25 yen on Tuesday.
The British pound was at $1.5663 in New York, up slightly from $1.5660 on Tuesday.
