HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Prices of Lumber in Plunge As House Completions Fall

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Lumber prices plunged yesterday to their lowest level in three months after a Government report that housing completions had declined.
The Commerce Department said housing completions fell 11.4 percent in March to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.096 million. While much of the decline was tied to severe weather conditions, traders said building activity was not expected to improve fast enough to absorb built-up supplies. 
 "The weather has been a problem, but the industry also overestimated demand," said Curt Cunningham, president of Pacific Futures Trading in Seattle. "Housing starts have been down for the last three months, building permits were down sharply, and new construction spending was down. It looks like the economy is less robust than the industry had planned."
Lumber for July delivery settled at $311 for 1,000 board feet, down $10, the most it is permitted to fall on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
Lumber has soared about $200 since November 1992 on increasing logging restrictions in the Northwest and a predicted upturn in housing demand.
 
Inventories Gained in March
 Since March 15, July lumber has fallen $137.80, or 44.3 percent, from its peak at $448.80, when mills and lumberyards began cutting prices to reduce inventories. Inventories swelled in March, as adverse weather conditions hampered deliveries to construction sites.
Mills were quoting spruce two-by-fours at an average of about $260 for 1,000 board feet yesterday, down $50 from last week.
On other commodity markets, cotton futures rose and pork belly futures rebounded while other livestock futures slipped. Oil futures were higher.
Crude oil for June delivery rose 7 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange, ending the day at $20.46 a barrel. June heating oil was 0.15 cent higher at 55.73 cents a gallon. June unleaded gasoline was 0.12 cent higher at 61.71 cents a gallon and June natural gas was 9.3 cents lower at $2.224 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Despite G.O.P. Boycott, Democratic Legislators Elect McCall as Comptroller

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 5

 BODY:
Democratic members of the Legislature elected H. Carl McCall as New York's State Comptroller today, but the Republican lawmakers who boycotted the process filed a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of the vote.
Mr. McCall, the first black to hold a statewide elective office in New York, took the oath of office immediately after the vote. Although the Republican lawsuit puts his election in the hands of a judge, Republican officials said they were less interested in unseating Mr. McCall than in changing the procedure for filling future vacancies and for managing the comptroller's office. 
 The court challenge, which will be heard on Tuesday in State Supreme Court in Albany, focuses on technical issues of legal language and parliamentary procedure. But it signifies a major constitutional rift within New York's divided Legislature.
And it generated a volley of speeches, news conferences and news releases today in which legislative leaders used unusually harsh language to attack and counterattack.
 
'Attempting Blackmail'
 "While accusing us of backroom deals, they were attempting blackmail," Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat, said of his Republican colleagues.
The Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Republican from Oyster Bay, L.I., said in a Senate debate Tuesday night that the Democratic vote was "unconstitutional," "clearly illegal," "uncalled for," "unreasonable" and "a shabby way to deal with the majority in this house."
What's more, Mr. Marino issued a statement that gave Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine's first name as Stanley, a name that Mr. Lundine does not like to be called.
Several Democratic legislators accused the Republicans of seeking to thwart the election of a black.
"While the so-called lower house has heard the booming cry of justice born from our opportunity to select H. Carl McCall, the masters of the upper house have become deaf on this occasion," said Senator Alton R. Waldon Jr., a Queens Democrat who is black.
In response, Mr. Marino said, "The issue's not Carl McCall and it has nothing to do with race."
Mr. McCall, who is 57, said today that he would begin working immediately and that he had resigned as president of the New York City Board of Education and as a vice president of Citibank. After telling The New York Post on Tuesday that "running for governor is the next logical step," he deflected questions about his political future, saying he would concentrate on the job at hand.
He called the lawsuit "an act of irresponsibility" and said he worried that it would create nervousness in the financial markets about New York State notes and bonds. But he said he would try not to let the court battle distract him.
 
'A Terrible Distraction'
 "It wouldn't be just a personal distraction," Mr. McCall said. "It would be a terrible distraction for the people of the state of New York to think that this office is in some way seige at this important time."
Mr. McCall's election made New York the 13th state to have a black holding a statewide elective office, said David A. Bositis, a senior research associate with the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a Washington organization that specializes in minority affairs.
It also marked the first time since 1942, when Herbert H. Lehman was Governor, that all four of the statewide elected officials in state government have been Democrats. That bit of history made Mr. McCall's election particularly hard to swallow for the state's Republican leaders.
Since 1979, the comptroller's office was occupied by a Republican, Edward V. Regan, who announced in February that he would resign on April 30 to become the president of an economics institute. The State Constitution requires the Legislature to fill vacancies in the offices of comptroller and attorney general when they occur in the middle of a term.
New York's Assembly has a Democratic majority while the Senate is controlled by Republicans. But 127 of the 211 legislators are Democrats, enabling the Democrats to elect Mr. McCall today. The vote was 121 for Mr. McCall with 2 abstentions.
The Republican sections of the semicircular Assembly chamber remained empty during the vote, looking like missing pieces of a pie.
Mr. Marino charged in the lawsuit that the vote was illegal because the Senate had not voted to convene a joint session with the Assembly. But state law speaks only of a "joint ballot," not a joint session. And the Democrats maintained that Mr. Weprin and Mr. Lundine, who holds the ceremonial title of president of the Senate, could call a joint ballot without the Senate's agreement.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Republicans boycotted yesterday's vote during which H. Carl McCall was elected as New York State Comptroller. The Republicans left their seats in the chamber vacant and filed a lawsuit seeking to change the procedure for filling future vacancies and for managing the Comptroller's office. (Mike Groll for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Clinton's Refocusing

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
When President Clinton confessed on Tuesday that the White House needed "tighter coordination" because it had lost clarity of purpose, he said he planned to fix things by reorganizing his staff. It may take more than that.
The President is part of the problem, in the view of many senior staff members, because of his own native ebullience, the type of experience he brought to the job and the kinds of people he chose to surround himself with. He needs to learn to discipline himself, the associates say, as well as strengthening the structure built to serve him. 
 "A wise man told me when we started that the governors of small states tended to think Washington was an overgrown state capital," said a Clinton confidant. "He told me that the President would find the lessons he learned in Little Rock of real but quite limited use here, and he was absolutely right.
"You can't do it all at once. The media are harder. The Republicans are stronger. The bureaucracy is bigger and tougher. We have to change."
 
Mondale Advice Unheeded
 Mr. Clinton populated his White House staff and the domestic departments and agencies largely with men and women of limited Washington experience, many of them very young. Observing this, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale urged Mr. Clinton to take on at least one or two ranking staff members who had worked in the White House, but his advice was not heeded. As a result, learning the ropes has taken more time than it might have.
By contrast, the President, conscious of his own lack of experience in the area, chose experienced hands for the major foreign-policy and national-security roles, and many in Washington think Mr. Clinton has done a better job in foreign affairs than on most domestic matters, contrary to the general expectation.
The linchpin of most White House operations since Dwight D. Eisenhower's has been the chief of staff. Often, like Donald T. Regan and John H. Sununu in the Reagan and Bush administrations respectively, they have been sacrificed to propitiate the gods of politics at moments of stress for their Presidents.
By all accounts, the role of Mr. Clinton's chief of staff, Thomas F. McLarty 3d, is rather less all-embracing than those of his most recent predecessors, and the President did not directly blame him for his troubles. Indeed, he promised to get him some help. That is expected to arrive later this week in the form of Roy Neel, a 47-year-old Washington veteran who has served for many years as an aide to Vice President Al Gore.
Mr. Neel will join Mark Gearan as a second deputy to Mr. McLarty.
 
Overworked but Competent
 White House officials sprang to the defense of Mr. McLarty and Mr. Gearan, describing them as overworked but highly competent. Still, a staff shake-up is hardly a vote of confidence in the leader of that staff, and one top aide made the faintly damning comment, "I think Mack can still make a success of this job if the reorganization is done properly."
In an effort to focus the President's message more sharply, George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, has been asked to step back from his involvement with the daily briefings and give more attention to overall media and political strategy. But it is not yet clear how the change would work, who would take over the briefings or, indeed, whether Mr. Stephanopoulos will agree to any change.
The cascade of policy proposals in recent weeks, which the President's strategists fear might make it harder to push through his economic program and health-care plan in the form he wishes, results partly from inexperience, several top officials concede.
In addition, Mr. Clinton has found it hard to concentrate on domestic objectives when foreign crises like those in Russia and Bosnia keep crowding in on the Oval Office. An aide said today that the President "is terribly frustrated with the time that stuff costs him, though he knows how critical it is to him and to the country."
 
In Love With Details
 But the problems also result from what another old friend terms Mr. Clinton's "impatience to get things done and his utter absorption in -- no, his love affair with -- all the details and the subtleties of domestic policy."
Mr. Clinton is proposing major new programs at a rate approaching that of Franklin D. Roosevelt and Lyndon B. Johnson at the beginning of their Presidencies. But he has smaller majorities on Capitol Hill and more tenuous support in the country than they did, and they were helped by the sense of national trauma caused by the Depression and the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
Because of the effort to do so many things at once, a number of Mr. Clinton's proposals have had to be sharply modified, even before they reached the floor of the Senate or the House of Representatives. That was true of the immunization program and the plan to drop the ban on homosexuals in the armed forces, among other measures.
Even more significantly, the country has been bombarded with news articles about a $10 billion program for this and an $8 billion program for that, capped by a report this week that the health-care plan might cost $100 to $150 billion, at a time when deficit cuts remains a leading national preoccupation.
As a result of such reports, and the relentless efforts of Ross Perot to picture Mr. Clinton as a man who places a low priority on cutting the deficit, the President is in danger of seeming to be not what he said he was in last year's campaign -- a new kind of Democrat -- but an unreconstructed high-tax liberal.
 
Unfavorable Numbers
 Recent polls show that more voters now see Mr. Clinton as an apostle of government spending than as a foe of big government, and some show a plurality arguing that the nation is on the wrong track. Three months ago the numbers were much more favorable to the President, and the turnaround worries his advisors.
So does the seeming ability of Mr. Perot to hold on indefinitely to most of the support he attracted last year -- almost one voter in five, a group that Mr. Clinton badly needs if he is to assure his re-election in 1996.
Some of this was no doubt inevitable, and there are signs that hard lessons are being well learned.
Never again, senior officials say, will they make the mistake of describing the Republicans as "irrelevant," as some of them did when the Senate was debating the President's economic stimulus package. The slur, like the careless remark of rival players stirring up a football team, played a significant role in promoting enough Republican unity to enable them to sustain a filibuster and hand Mr. Clinton a major defeat.

HEADLINE: NORTH KOREA STIRS NEW A-ARMS FEARS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 5

 BODY:
Experts monitoring North Korea say they are increasingly concerned that the country may be preparing to use 50 tons of uranium now fueling a large reactor as raw material for nuclear weapons.
The diversion, under the guise of a long-planned change of fuel in the reactor, seems likely to come within weeks or months of June 12, when North Korea officially withdraws from the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons. If efforts to persuade North Korea to respect the treaty fail, the country's hard-line Communist leadership would be free on June 12 to convert the spent fuel into plutonium, the element at the core of nuclear bombs. 
 The 50 tons would be enough to produce two or three nuclear bombs. But the elaborate process could take several months or a year, depending on the size and sophistication of North Korea's sites. United States intelligence officials say Pyongyang has kept at least some reprocessing ability hidden from international inspectors.
 
Showdown Over Inspections
 The inspections, which started only last year, ceased about three months ago, just before North Korea announced that it would pull out of the treaty. After fencing with the International Atomic Energy Agency for months, Pyongyang said it would leave the treaty when the agency insisted on visiting two sites that United States intelligence identified as being at the center of the weapons project.
Ordinarily the removal of reactor fuel is closely monitored to assure that none is diverted to weapons. But North Korea has kept the agency guessing about whether it will be allowed to oversee the process, or precisely when it will occur.
Indeed, there is a growing suspicion that the Government is using the chance to monitor the removal -- and to take samples showing whether some fuel may have already been diverted to weapons -- as a bargaining chip in its tense negotiations with the West.
"They are dangling this in front of us, perhaps as a negotiating ploy," said one official involved. "They know that we know that once this spent fuel disappears, we suddenly will have a big problem."
 
Waltzing With Washington
 The Clinton Administration is pressing China, North Korea's closest ally, to persuade the Government to permit a "special inspection" of two buildings in Yongbyon, a heavily guarded research station 60 miles north of Pyongyang.
In recent weeks United States officials have said that if North Korea rejoins the treaty's members and allows full inspections, Washington may be prepared to open direct talks with North Korea. Indeed, United States and North Korean officials met today in Washington to lay the groundwork for high-level talks to defuse the tension over the nuclear program, Reuters reported.
Several American and Japanese officials say they doubt that diplomacy will lead the North to back down. Their view is that President Kim Il Sung and his son, Kim Jong Il, have determined that international inspections would eventually bring North Korea's multi-billion-dollar nuclear program to a standstill.
"North Korea's regime sees its nuclear program as vital to its survival, and there is every reason to believe it will go to the mat to protect it," Gen. Robert W. RisCassi, the commander of United States forces in South Korea, told the Senate Armed Services Committee last month in one of the most pessimistic assessments yet of the chances of keeping North Korea from becoming a nuclear power.
 
A Debate About Diplomacy
 General RisCassi, who appears to view developments in North Korea with even more alarm than do many in the intelligence community, said he was "increasingly concerned that North Korea could slide in an attack as an uncontrollable consequence of total desperation or internal instability."
"We must disabuse ourselves of the confidence we gained during the cold war that North Korea was manageable," he warned.
Indeed there is growing disagreement on the question of how to negotiate with North Korea, and in recent weeks officials in Washington, Tokyo and Seoul have frequently found themselves at odds. For weeks a debate has raged on whether actions by the Security Council to impose economic sanctions against Pyongyang would help to halt the nuclear project, or whether, as South Korea fears, it may provoke the North to lash out. Nor is it clear that China, which holds a veto in the council, would approve sanctions.
"The fact is that all the options are bad," a senior Japanese official said last week. "Military solutions to the nuclear problem are too dangerous. And even if we can get them passed, economic sanctions probably won't do much good."
No inspections have been made in North Korea since the country announced on March 12 that it would withdraw from the treaty to "protect our supreme national interest." The International Atomic Energy Agency says three inspectors were to enter North Korea last Sunday to change films in monitoring cameras, but they never received visas. The inspectors hope now to go to North Korea over the weekend.

HEADLINE: INFECTION LINKED TO TAINTED CIDER

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 5

 BODY:
A study published today has documented an outbreak of bacterial infection in southeastern Massachusetts caused by fresh-pressed apple cider.
The study by researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta showed that the bacteria, Escherichia coli 0157:H7, had been found in the cider and that it had caused severe diarrhea, abdominal cramps and other ailments in 1991. 
 The same strain of bacteria in undercooked hamburger caused three deaths and 500 illnesses in the Pacific Northwest earlier this year.
The study, published in The Journal of the American Medical Association, was conducted by Dr. Richard Besser, a medical epidemiologist at the disease control centers.
 
Four Had Kidney Failure
 He said it was unusual to find the E coli bacteria strain in apple cider, and added, "This raises our awareness that this pathogen can survive in many different types of food."
The study was based on an isolated outbreak of diarrhea and hemolytic uremic syndrome, a severe form of the infection characterized by kidney failure and anemia. Four young children in the Fall River area developed kidney failure, and local hospital officials called in investigators from the disease control centers, a Federal agency.
Twenty-three people, ranging in age from 2 to 70, were infected by the E coli bacteria strain, apparently from drinking fresh-pressed cider made from unwashed apples and sold by the Old Swanzey Orchard, a small cider mill in Swansea, Mass. They suffered from diarrhea, vomiting and abdominal pain. Six people, including five children, were hospitalized, but none died.
Anthony Andrade, owner of the Old Swanzy Orchard, said he had cooperated fully with the investigation. Although the evidence pointed to his cider as the culprit, he said, it was never definitively proven. He settled several lawsuits and has since got out of the cider business.
 
Long-Lasting Bacteria
 Dr. Besser noted that Swanzey had pressed its cider in a manner similar to that of other small cider producers. He said that apples already on the ground, called "drops," had been pressed without being washed and scrubbed, that the cider had not been pasteurized and that no preservatives had been added.
The apples may have been contaminated on the ground by deer feces or during the cider production. Dr. Besser found that the E coli bacteria survived for 20 days in the unpreserved refrigerated apple cider.
"We don't want to overreact from one outbreak," he said in an interview. "But we have no idea how big a problem this could be."
Dr. Besser said there were two previous outbreaks of diarrhea associated with apple cider. In 1980 an outbreak of severe infection in Canada was linked to an E coli infection of fresh-pressed apple juice. Apple cider was also believed to be the cause of a Salmonella outbreak in New Jersey in 1974.
The study is a cause for concern for apple growers throughout New England; each year they produce millions of gallons of fresh-pressed cider for sale at supermarkets and farmers' produce stands. Massachusetts has about 50 large cider mills registered with the state, but many small mills are not registered.
Frank Carlson, chairman of the Massachusetts Cider Guild and owner of Carlson Orchards in Harvard, Mass., said most cider pressed and sold in Massachusetts was of high quality and made properly. "As a large producer, I can't imagine not washing and brushing my apples," he said.
Apple growers say pasteurizing is not feasible; pasteurized cider creates apple juice, a different product, and alters the taste. Mr. Carlson also said the cost of pasteurization equipment is high and "would put hundreds of mills out of business."
Dr. Besser said a survey taken at a New England trade show last year showed that 36 cider producers of 45 at the show produced nine million gallons of cider in 1991 using "drops," and that only 12 reported routinely washing and brushing the apples before pressing.
 
State Regulations Cited
 Nancy Ridley, director of the Division of Food and Drug Administration in the Massachusetts Department of Public Health, said she had begun a statewide effort at educating all cider producers about state regulations that require washing and brushing of fruit before processing.
She also said she was concerned about the practice of using apples already on the ground. "With drops, if you've got breaks in the surface of the apple, washing and brushing may not be enough to get inside," she said. "Somebody needs to give serious consideration to the use of drops."
Apple growers say it would not be economical to make cider out of picked apples. Some growers use culls, or slightly marred apples, in cider production, but there are not enough culls to produce the volume needed.
Large producers of apple products pasteurize all of their apple juice products, even those called cider in some parts of the country. Larry Davenport, executive director of the Processed Apples Institute in Atlanta, which represents large apple-product manufacturers, said major corporations harvest their apples from the tree and drops are not used.
Dr. Besser said: "I don't say people shouldn't drink apple cider. But for someone at risk for more severe disease, like very young children or the elderly, I'd think twice about giving them apple cider."

HEADLINE: Irving Howe, 72, Critic, Editor and Socialist, Dies

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
Irving Howe, the literary critic and founding editor of Dissent magazine, who spent a lifetime advancing the cause of humane, democratic socialism, died early yesterday morning at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 72.
The cause was cardiovascular disease, the hospital said. Mr. Howe had collapsed at his home in Manhattan. 
 He was an emblematic New York Jewish intellectual, a man of modest origins who rose to pre-eminence in the serious study of ideas, literature and politics. He was known for many things, including a large, steady output of essays on culture and literature, the advocacy of democratic socialism and chronicling the Jewish experience in America.
 
National Book Award Winner
 Perhaps his most famous and widely read book was "World of Our Fathers," a history of Eastern European immigration to the United States that won the National Book Award in 1976.
Dissent, the magazine he founded and edited for nearly four decades, was for most of that time a leading journal of a certain kind of American politics. It was deeply critical of the abuses of capitalism and what its writers sometimes saw as the paranoia of this country, but it was even more repelled by leftist totalitarianism, in the Soviet Union, Cuba or elsewhere.
"Howe was always a counterpuncher who tended to dissent from the prevailing orthodoxy of the moment, whether left or right, though he himself was certainly a man of the left," said Morris Dickstein, professor of English at Queens College and the CUNY Graduate Center. "Whatever way the herd was going, he went in the opposite direction."
 
A Target of Conservatives
 Mr. Howe was persistently attacked for his lifelong commitment to socialism by conservatives, including many Jewish neo-conservatives grouped around Dissent's rival magazine, Commentary. He also quarreled famously with the leading figures of the New Left in the early 1960's and was reviled by many of the student radicals of that era.
"He lived in three worlds, literary, political and Jewish, and he watched all of them change almost beyond recognition," said Leon Wieseltier, the literary editor of The New Republic and a friend of Mr. Howe for 20 years.
"He saw the end of socialism. He saw literature be mauled by second-rate deconstructionists and third-rate sociologists of race, class and gender. And he saw the world of Yiddish disappear."
"But he never surrendered to nostalgia," Mr. Wieseltier said. "He remained almost diabolically engaged with the politics and the culture of his time."
 
Wrote Critical Studies
 Among Mr. Howe's influential books are "'Decline of the New," "Politics and the Novel" and an autobiography, "A Margin of Hope," published in 1982. He wrote critical studies of William Faulkner and Sherwood Anderson and a biography of Leon Trotsky, the Russian revolutionary who was one of his childhood heroes.
Mr. Howe, a tall man with wispy white hair who loved vigorous conversation above all things, had many highly developed interests.
For many years he was a Distinguished Professor of English at the City University of New York, where he was famous for passionate lectures on literature. He could be abrupt and flinty when confronted with what he regarded as stupidity or sanctimoniousness. The story is told, for example, of his response when a woman, attending a lecture he gave on "The World of Our Fathers," criticized him for not titling the book "World of Our Fathers and Our Mothers."
" 'World of Our Fathers' is a title," Mr. Howe responded testily. " 'World of Our Fathers and Our Mothers' is a speech."
 
The Fate of a Radical
 Or the time in the 1960's at Stanford University when he was harassed by a student radical, among the many who felt that Mr. Howe, lacking in his commitment to "the revolution," had become a lackey of the status quo. Mr. Howe turned to the student and said: "You know what you're going to be? You're going to be a dentist."
"There is utopia and utopia," Mr. Howe once wrote. "The kind imposed by an elite in the name of a historical imperative -- that utopia is hell. It must lead to terror and then, terror exhausted, to cynicism and torpor."
"But surely there is another utopia," he continued. "It cannot be willed either into existence or out of sight, it speaks for our sense of what may yet be."
He was a bon vivant. He married three times. He loved the ballet and classical music and going to parties.
 
Last of a Breed
 Above all perhaps, Mr. Howe was among the last of a breed of public intellectuals. Like his socialist colleague, Michael Harrington, or his intellectual and political rivals Norman Podhoretz and Irving Kristol, Mr. Howe could express learned, rigorous opinions on many subjects.
He honed his skills and his ideas in the lunchroom alcoves of City College in the late 1930's, debating socialism and Stalinism, fascism, Tolstoy and the meaning of Judaism.
"Part of what he embodied is the notion of being a serious intellectual who was both political and literary," said Paul Berman, a writer and contributor to Dissent. "It's not that he had two careers, but that he lived a life informed by the ideal of being as serious as you could be, both about culture and about politics, and his idea of socialism was rooted in the old idea that socialism was itself an expression of high culture."
 
A Bronxian Tangle of Poverty
 Irving Howe was born on June 11, 1920, in the East Bronx, a community, he said in his autobiography, that "formed a thick tangle of streets crammed with Jewish immigrants from Eastern Europe, almost all of them poor." His father ran a grocery store that failed, then worked as a peddler and finally a presser in a dress factory. His mother also worked in the dress trade as an operator.
It was a world of close families and of Depression-era economic insecurity, but also of occasional trips to Yankee Stadium to see Babe Ruth ("the greatest man in the Bronx") play.
And it was a world of radical politics. The young Irving Howe became, he said, a socialist at the age of 14, socialism for the Jews of the Bronx being "an encompassing culture, a style of perceiving and judging."
Except for a few years as an ardent follower of Trotskyism, Mr. Howe remained attached to socialism for the rest of his life. Like many upwardly mobile children of immigrants, he went to City College, where, he wrote in his autobiography, he spent more time talking with fellow students in the cafeteria than he did in class.
 
The Army, Then Book Reviews
 He graduated in 1940, just in time to spend four years in the Army, two of those years at a remote camp in Alaska where he was able to do a lot of reading. When he returned to the Bronx, he began writing book reviews and essays in the small intellectual magazines of the time, including Commentary, The Nation and Partisan Review. For four years, he earned a living writing book reviews for Time magazine.
In 1953, he was invited to teach English at Brandeis University outside Boston, thus beginning a career that would take him to Stanford and Hunter College before he settled down for a quarter of a century at City University. In 1954, he and a group of close friends founded Dissent, which became a leading journal of what Mr. Howe called "the moderate left." He published Andrei Sinyavsky's famous essay "On Socialist Realism," one of the opening salvos of the Soviet dissident movement. He published the black writer Richard Wright, and Norman Mailer's famous essay "The White Negro."
 
A Discovery: I. B. Singer
 Also in the 1950's Mr. Howe met a Yiddish poet named Eliezer Greenberg and the two began a long project to translate Yiddish prose and poetry into English, eventually publishing six collections of stories, essays and poems. His greatest discovery came when Mr. Greenberg started reading "Gimpel the Fool," a story by Isaac Bashevis Singer, at that time almost entirely unknown to all but the readers of the Yiddish language newspaper The Forward.
"It was a transforming moment," Mr. Howe recalled later. "How often does a critic encounter a major new writer?"
Mr. Howe persuaded Saul Bellow, who had not yet achieved fame himself, to translate the story, which was published in Partisan Review, thereby beginning Singer's climb to literary celebrity among nonreaders of Yiddish.
 
Encountering the New Left
 In 1962, as Mr. Howe recalled in his autobiography, several leading members of the newly formed Students for a Democratic Society, seeing in Mr. Howe a potential elder statesman of their movement, visited the offices of Dissent. It was an ill-fated encounter.
Mr. Howe and others of his generation saw in the New Left tendencies toward violence, irrationalism, petulance and intolerance, impulses that they associated with earlier utopias of the sorts that had come to no good in the Soviet Union. Mr. Howe became a leading critic of the student radicals, even predicting in a much-noted article in the New York Times Magazine in 1970 that "the first and mildest consequence" of leftist terrorism in America would be the election of Ronald Reagan to the Presidency.
Mr. Howe retired from City University in 1986, but continued to give speeches and to write essays for Dissent. His health had been deteriorating in recent years.
He is survived by his wife, Ilana, his children, Nicholas and Nina, and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: PORT REPUBLIC JOURNAL;
Where the Biggest News Is Something From 1778

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

DATELINE: PORT REPUBLIC, N.J.

 BODY:
THE monument to the battle of Chestnut Neck is hard to find, despite its 50-foot height that pushes a resolute figure of a granite Continental Army soldier above the tops of surrounding pin oaks and scrub pines.
Most travelers come upon it by chance, just as they might stumble across Port Republic, a town walled off along with its 350 years of history because of an unintentional partnership between conservationists and traffic engineers. 
 Salt marshes protected by the Federal and state governments form a wide green- and dun-colored band around the northern end of the Atlantic County coastline. And from the Garden State Parkway, the unbroken mantle of the Pine Barrens rolls westward to the horizon.
And that suits the 992 residents of Port Republic (1990 Census) and lovers of its 19th century clapboard ambiance just fine.
The opening of the parkway in the mid-1950's parallel to Route 9 was first seen as a local boon. Until then Route 9 was the major north-south roadway, and the summer traffic crawled bumper to bumper along it on the weekends.
But the new toll road did more than ease traffic on Route 9. It captured most of it.
Tourist cabins and roadside eateries on the old highway fell into disuse and closed. No new pizza joints or gas stations, the lifeblood of the Jersey Shore, opened. No shopping malls with cineplexes and concrete garages invaded the open spaces above the marshes and the sandy woodlands. No condos rose on the muddy banks of creeks and kettle ponds.
Then casino gambling in Atlantic City, 10 miles to the southeast, was approved in the late 1970's, and real-estate values in the vicinity shot up. Developers outbid each other for land along Route 9 in anticipation of an economic boom.
It reached Smithville, a neighboring town on Route 9, but traveled no farther.
"People were stacked up and sleeping in tents to buy new houses in Smithville," said Joan Hanselman, a Port Republic resident. "We thought it was just a matter of time till it reached us."
But concern over the threat to protected marshes halted development, she said, and the housing bust of recent years finished it off.
It was a close call, said Claire Gerber, who with her husband, Ned, a utility company executive, moved into the solitude of the Port Republic woods 23 years ago.
"At night we can see the lights of Smithville through the trees," Mrs. Gerber said, noting that the offending subdivision was a mile or two away.
Worse, she added, the sunset serenity at the sea's edge is broken by the sight of brightly lighted Atlantic City casino towers stabbing into the darkening sky.
There is also the steady rumble and whoosh of cars and trucks, mostly out of sight, on the Garden State Parkway.
"The parkway does benefit us in a way," said Gary Giberson, the Mayor of Port Republic, a city incorporated in 1905.
"We collect about $15,000 a year in fines and court costs from speeding tickets the state police write on the parkway along the six miles it runs through our city," he said.
Mr. Giberson said his forebears were among the first settlers on the New Jersey coast, Dutch shipbuilders and sawyers who settled along the Mullica River in 1643.
Port Republic, between the Mullica and a branch waterway, Nacote Creek, became one of the earliest ports in the region, and it was from here that musket and cannonballs for George Washington's army were shipped.
The British sent 400 troops and nine ships in 1778 to rout the defenders of Port Republic in the fort at Chestnut Neck and burned the village, destroying all the colonial homes.
The battle monument was erected in 1911 by the Daughters of the American Revolution. The highway was rerouted in the 1920's, however, so the soldier under the tricornered hat at the top has his back to Route 9.
Mr. Giberson said his family, which held a land grant from the king, was Loyalist, which was not unusual along the New Jersey coast, a hideout for Tories and marginal types who resisted any government, including the newly independent one, that threatened to intrude on their lives.
That outlook prevails today among local fishermen who resent restrictions placed on them by refuge managers.
When people in these parts look toward the rest of the Jersey Shore and south to Atlantic City, they see little to their liking.
"Change is a four-letter word in Port Republic," said Mr. Giberson.
"When I grew up here bald eagles nested on our property, and a young man could make a good living trapping muskrats. Most of that is gone now, of course, but it's still a wonderful place to live if you like small towns and don't mind the words quaint and wholesome."
Outside, a quarter-mile away, the parkway traffic whooshed on in a steady stream, rarely stopping.

(Sal DiMarco Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Fund Yields Change Slightly in Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered on tax-exempt and taxable money market funds were mixed in the latest week, with little movement in either direction.
IBC's Money Fund Report said yesterday that its survey showed tax-exempt money fund yields were down slightly in the seven-day period ended Tuesday after a sharp rise the previous week. 
 Tax-exempt yields were off an average 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Meanwhile, investors withdrew $743 million from tax-free funds, leaving them with $98.7 billion in assets. Analysts at the Money Fund Report noted that withdrawals were considerably less than in the previous period, when the outflow was $2.7 billion.
In the latest period, money managers increased the average days left to maturity of securities held in portfolios to 49, from the year's low of 48 days.
IBC/Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a tax-exempt money market fund slipped 3 basis points, to 2.01 percent, with the average seven-day simple yield off 2 basis points, to 1.99 percent. Analysts said that in the last 30 days, the compounded yield averaged 1.97 percent and the simple yield about 1.96 percent.
Besides reflecting interest rate activity in the market, the slip in yields may also be the result of a slight tightening in the amount of new issues available for pricing, which raises the price and lowers the yields.
Without state and local taxes, the taxable equivalent for the seven-day compounded yield is about 2.79 percent for investors in a 28 percent tax bracket and about 2.91 percent for those in a 31 percent bracket.
Among the tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, the Dreyfus Basic Municipal Money Market fund continued to be the best performer with a yield of 2.64 percent, about 9 basis points off the previous week's level, the Money Fund Report said.
 
Taxable Funds
 For the week ended yesterday, the assets of taxable money market funds declined $187 million, to $487.6 billion. Statisticians at the Money Market Report said the addition of several new funds distorted some of the figures.
Institutional fund assets, for example, showed a flow of $2.8 billion coming in. But excluding the new funds, the gain would have been about $1 billion less.
Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in taxable money market portfolios was unchanged at 63 for the second consecutive week.
"Given the weakness of the economy and recent signs underscoring that weakness," said Walter S. Frank, chief economist for the Money Fund Report, "this week's employment numbers could spark another round of expectations about a Fed move to lower short-term rates."
IBC/Donoghue's average seven-day compounded yield on a taxable fund was unchanged at 2.65 percent, with the seven-day simple yield at 2.62 percent. The compounded average yield over 30 days is 2.67 percent, while the simple yield is averaging 2.63 percent.
For the third straight week, the Dreyfus Basic Money Market fund turned in the highest yield among general-purpose taxable money funds, with a return of 3.45 percent, down a basis point from the previous week.
Banks, which compete directly with money market funds for investor cash, are offering a yield of 2.56 percent to depositors, about 2 basis points lower than in the previous week.

HEADLINE: Fed Cites Improvement In Economy for April

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve said today that there was "generally modest improvement" in the economy in April after the storm-related slowdown in much of the country in March.
In its survey of economic conditions, known as the beige book, the central bank said "shopper traffic and retail sales were reported to have rebounded modestly" last month. 
 The report was more upbeat than some of the Government's recent statistics. But many economists consider the beige book to be less reliable than the Government's statistical reports because it is based on informal surveys and impressions.
 
 
Short-Term Interest Rates
 The beige book was prepared for use at a meeting on May 18 of the Federal Open Market Committee, the central bank's main policy-making committee. The group will determine short-term interest rates over the next six weeks, and most economists expect it to leave rates unchanged. The group meets every six weeks.
The report said that in most of the country, manufacturers reported increased shipments and orders, with production in some automotive and steel plants near capacity.
According to the survey of the nation's 12 Federal Reserve districts, residential real estate activity is strong or on the rise in most regions around the nation, although the Southern California market remains in a slump.
The Federal Reserve said there was a "general increase" in bank lending, noting that it was concentrated in consumer loans and home mortgage refinancings, rather than in business loans. In several areas of the Midwest, however, there was a noticeable pickup in lending to small business.
 
 
Problems in California
 In the West, the survey said, the greatest economic problems were in California, where aerospace and military cutbacks have hurt consumer confidence and economic activity, and western Washington, with the strongest growth in Utah, Idaho and eastern Washington.
Job conditions were mixed in most regions, the report said. It noted that some companies are hiring modestly, particularly in auto parts and capital equipment. But none of the 12 Federal Reserve districts anticipated a flurry of new hiring, and several districts said employers were avoiding new hiring by extending hours, using temporary workers and increasing productivity.
The report saw little in the way of inflationary pressures, a result of stiff competition, slower sales growth and consumer resistance to price increases.
The Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco said lumber companies reported a 20 percent drop in lumber and plywood prices from their peak in March.
According to the report, many retailers said consumer confidence was lower than at the beginning of the year. A large Midwest retailer surveyed said sales growth was held back by bad weather, concerns about tax increases and uncertainty about the impact of changes in income tax withholding.
Steel production is doing especially well, the report said, because of increased sales of motor vehicles and consumer appliances.
 
 
New York Area Is Mixed
 In the New York area, economic developments "were mixed in recent weeks, but on balance tended toward improvement," the survey said. Many retailers said their sales were below projections during February and March, partly because of severe snowstorms, although some were able to make up the shortfall in late March.
Home builders in the region reported some recent improvement and predicted that home sales would surpass last year's level. The report noted that declining vacancy rates and other factors were prompting some prominent developers to plan new rental apartment buildings for the first time in years.
The report said that no one was anticipating a building boom, however, because of worries about job security and changes in Federal taxes.
According to the report, leasing activity was brisk in midtown Manhattan, with the vacancy rate edging downward.

HEADLINE: Texas Airport Refunding Priced

 BODY:
A $205.5 million tax-exempt bond refunding by the Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport was initially priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 5.10 percent for an issue due in 2002 through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.
All the bonds are insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation, giving the financing a triple-A rating from Moody's and Standard & Poor's. 
 Yields on the remaining serial bonds range from 2.30 percent for 1994 to 4.50 percent for 1998 and 5 percent for 2001. For investors in a 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable bond equivalent yields would be about 3.19 percent for the 1994 maturity, 6.25 percent for 1998 and 7.08 percent for 2002.

HEADLINE: Home Prices: Some Drops

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
Home values fell in one-third of the nation's housing markets in the first quarter from their levels a year earlier, and increases slowed in many others, a real estate trade group said today.
Homeowners in the West, particularly in California, were hit the hardest, according to the National Association of Realtors. The survey covered previously owned single-family homes in 129 metropolitan areas. 
 Prices nationwide increased 5.1 percent, to $104,200, compared with a 4.3 percent advance in the fourth quarter. But 46 of the 129 areas surveyed posted declines.
Until the economy began to weaken in the late 1980's, declines in home prices were rare during a 20-year inflation-paced boom.
The realtors said home values fell five-tenths of 1 percent in the West in the first quarter from a year earlier, to a median price of $142,200. The median price was unchanged in the Northeast at $137,400, after a drop of eight-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter. The median means half the homes cost more, and half cost less.

HEADLINE: Essay;
What About Weld?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Republican William F. Weld, successor to Michael Dukakis as Governor of Massachusetts, is building a record in office that should be a conservative's dream:
"Balanced three budgets without raising taxes or borrowing," goes his resume. "Held spending under inflation . . . received unprecedented triple upgrade in state bond rating . . . reduced Medicaid 'budget buster' rate of growth by 64 percent over a three-year period . . . cut taxes five times . . . proposed elimination of state capital gains tax for investments held for six years. . . ." 
 He's a hawk on stopping the Serbs and an ardent free-trader on Nafta. All music to Republican ears.
Why, then, is this robust, 6-foot-4, 47-year-old former chief of the Criminal Division of the Reagan Department of Justice not being thought of as a hot prospect for the 1996 Republican Presidential nomination?
One reason is that we're not supposed to think about '96 yet. The immediate Republican goal is to take control of the Senate in '94, which would make Bill Clinton the first half-term President and open the way to the Restoration.
More to the point about Weld, he's outspokenly pro-choice, which is universally assumed by the punditocracy to sink a right-wing candidacy before it is launched.
Let's examine that. Assume that Clinton appoints two, perhaps even three, pro-Roe justices to the Supreme Court; that Congress passes an abortion-rights law; that the French abortion pill hits the market; and that public opinion continues in the direction of compromise -- frowning on but not forbidding abortion.
In that case, the abortion issue will not be a lukewarm button in the campaign of 1996. We will see demonstrations for the new Lost Cause, but each party must, if electability is the criterion, choose a candidate in the widening center -- or one with a running mate who is clearly pro-choice.
But Weld will be charged with being soft on gays. Although he opposes homosexual marriage or insurance coverage for partners of gay employees, he issued an executive order giving the same bereavement leave to state workers to mourn homosexual partners as straights who lose spouses. "The vote was 17 to 1 in my staff meeting," Weld recalled over breakfast the other day, "and I was the one. Homosexual rights does not poll well. Unless opinion shifts, gay rights could make it hard for a person with my views."
Maybe so, maybe not; most Republicans, like most other voters, adopt an attitude of toleration toward homosexuals, withholding the sought-after moral approval but rejecting the gay-bashing that so demeaned the Republican Convention last year. The religious right is vocal, as it has every right to be, but has no veto power over the tolerant conservatives who will be the final contenders.
"My long suit is the economic stuff," says Weld, whose hero is Friedrich Hayek. Clinton's economic plan? "I can't believe he's acting so stupidly, because he's not stupid. Maybe he's trying to be all things to all people because he wants to be liked by everybody. But he was never part of the lunchpail coalition when he was Governor -- his new tax-and-spend policy is nowhere near the view of the majority of the electorate."
Here's my morning line on the Republican race: Jack Kemp was propelled out of the gate to take an early lead, wisely fell back to conserve strength before the first turn; Bob Dole has accepted front-runnership, but the last "Mr. Republican" was Robert Taft; Phil Gramm has fallen off the pace as a dove on Bosnia; Lamar Alexander, Dick Cheney, Pat Robertson, Pat Buchanan, Bill Bennett are bunched in back; Ross Perot could enter and scratch himself; Pete Wilson, if he can make it to the starting gate by getting re-elected California's Governor in '94, is the dark horse to watch in the stretch.
Weld, the fiscal conservative and social libertarian, is a long shot to win, a good bet to place. If Clinton fails to lay on the whip in the White House and continues into deficit mud, he could be overtaken by a ticket with a Governor who rejuvenated the Massachusetts economy after Democrat Dukakis nearly bankrupted it.
The Republican Weld knows how to bail out a Democratic state after a liberal activist overloaded its economy with "miracle" cures. The experience could come in handy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Third World Population Explosion Demands Western Response

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The juxtaposition of two articles on the front page April 25 reveals, as in a lightning flash, the fundamental problem confronting humankind at this juncture: the ongoing population explosion. I refer to the report on the Chinese effort to control it, and the article on our immigration service's being swamped by a seemingly uncontrollable influx of asylum seekers. 
 In either case we risk drawing wrong conclusions. It would be a tragedy if the excesses connected with the Chinese effort jeopardized President Clinton's intended reversal of American policy that denied funds for family planning abroad; this reversal can only be the beginning of a more ambitious effort, together with other industrial countries and possibly through a United Nations setup, to set third world countries on the path of radical population stabilization.
As far as the asylum problem is concerned, it would be a mistake to believe that revamping immigration services would suffice to deal with it. European countries have learned what we still have to learn: that behind the genuinely political persecutees there looms an infinitely larger number of what the Germans call "economic refugees," that is, tens of millions of third world people who, facing misery if not starvation, will press against the borders of the still affluent. But unless something radical is done, no exclusion laws will help, nor will barbed wire or guns.
Humankind confronts the novel condition -- unique in its entire history -- of its global numbers outgrowing the carrying capacity of the planet (these numbers now devouring and destroying what remains of the basic resources of the world: arable land, fresh water, forests, and so on). While in former eras "surplus" populations would find "empty" regions to which to migrate, the frontier is now closed.
Even countries like the United States, Canada, Australia or even European ones that still can (and should) absorb millions, with a world population increasing by about 100 million each year and doubling exponentially within ever shorter periods, migration alone cannot solve the problem. This can only be done by developed countries jointly assisting the overpopulated countries in family planning and education, combined with aid for basic need fulfillment and old-age security systems; and, if need be, denying aid to governments unwilling to engage in such policies.
Unless we act rapidly, it may be too late to approach the problem decently. Countries might be driven toward dealing with it through authoritarian coercion.
 
JOHN H. HERZ
Scarsdale, N.Y., April 28, 1993
The writer is emeritus professor of political science, City College, CUNY.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: Europe;
Europe's Call: Lead On, U.S.

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, May 6

 BODY:
Despite all their reluctance to agree with the United States about military steps to stop the killing in the Balkans, what the European allies have really wanted from President Clinton is firm leadership now that he has consulted with them.
More than one European diplomat has said in recent conversations that Mr. Clinton should stop asking them their opinion on what he plans to do and start telling them instead what he plans to go ahead with, preferably with their support. 
 After the Bosnian Serbs unexpectedly rejected the peace plan that their leader, Radovan Karadzic, had endorsed last Sunday, Mr. Clinton seemed galvanized, and he said today that the United States and its allies had to "act quickly and decisively" against the Bosnian Serbs.
But there is no European consensus on what to do to stop the killing in Bosnia and Herzegovina, or on how to prevent Croats and Serbs from carving up the country at the expense of its Muslims, and Secretary of State Warren Christopher will return home from Europe on Friday without an endorsement of military action. [Page A12.]
The degree to which the Europeans will now rally to the American banner remains to be seen. All that the European allies could tell Mr. Christopher was that whatever the next step was, it must be weighed cautiously.
But he and Mr. Clinton already know that.
During this week's consultations, the Europeans raised strong objections to Mr. Clinton's plan to lift the United Nations arms embargo enough to improve the Muslims' ability to defend themselves. Their objections to limited air strikes against Serbian supply lines and artillery positions if the Bosnian Serbs persist in rejecting the peace plan were less vehement.
The Europeans' concern about lifting the arms embargo on the Muslims was primarily that this would lead to a flood of new weapons into the region, and that if the Muslims were supplied from outside, the Russians would be under pressure to do the same for the Bosnian Serbs, with whom they share traditional cultural links.
Only the Germans, privately, supported easing the embargo, but British officials have indicated that if the United States decided to go ahead with air strikes, they would back the decision despite their reservations.
European reactions to the Bosnian Serbs' rejection of the peace plan again this morning were unanimous. The Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, spoke for the Europeans in saying rejection could lead to "monstrous bloodshed."
But the consensus on what to do to get the Serbs to change their minds was more of the same: Pressure should be increased on Serbia and Montenegro, which have been under economic blockade since last month, the Europeans said; the blockade should be tightened until the Serbs finally force their proteges in Bosnia to lay down their arms.
 
'Nothing Is Ruled Out'
 Mr. Christopher summed up his talks with NATO and European officials in Brussels before flying here this afternoon by saying: "We did not reach any decisions. Nothing is ruled out; nothing is ruled in."
A British official in London told the Reuters news agency today, "We keep open the option of air strikes." And Lord Owen, the co-author of the peace plan, said that in view of the "dangerous folly" of the Bosnian Serbs' rejection, "it may be that military action now has to be contemplated."
But advocates of military intervention say that as long as Western indecision reigns, nothing will persuade the Serbian forces in Bosnia to stop grabbing territory and forcing the Muslims who lived on it to flee.
The mere threat of air strikes, American officials believe, led the Bosnian Serbs' leader, Dr. Karadzic, to change his mind and sign the United Nations-backed plan after initially rejecting it. The assembly of Bosnian Serbs may have turned it down because they were still not convinced the threat of bombing was real.
 
Reasons for Not Acting
 European outrage is real, and growing, but each of the allies has a reason for not intervening militarily.
"We are constantly being led around by the nose and should not let this constant delaying and back-and-forth prevent us from doing what the Americans, the Europeans and the others concerned think necessary," the German Foreign Minister, Klaus Kinkel, said today.
"But on the other hand, military intervention would be a decisive, probably irreversible escalation."
So the buck went back to Mr. Clinton's desk, amid signs that Washington was preparing to act.
His predecessor, George Bush, led most of the European allies into the Persian Gulf war, but he also had the strong support of the British Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher.
 
Fears for British Troops
 But officials in London say that in Bosnia in 1993, Britain is concerned that military action could bring the wrath of the Serbs down on the heads of its lightly armed 2,000-member force working with the United Nations to deliver food and medicine to civilians.
The French are similarly concerned about their forces in the Balkans, and have been sniping at the United States this week for thinking of air strikes as the easy way out, with no need to expose American soldiers on the ground to similar dangers.
Germany, Mr. Kinkel said, would be unable to take part in any military action on constitutional grounds, and there would be, he said, "no intervention by German soldiers in the former Yugoslavia because of what happened in the Second World War." Because of continuing resentment there, the Germans believe, their soldiers could not take part in a peacekeeping force in Bosnia.
So far, the Turks, gravely worried about their fellow Muslims in Bosnia, have been NATO's leading supporters of limited air strikes. The alliance's representatives will meet in Brussels next week to consider the next steps, but it will take strong leadership from Washington, not just consensus-building, to get them there.

The Economy
The productivity of American factories soared in the first quarter, helped by production of computers and cars, but productivity in the entire private economy fell at an annual rate of 0.1 percent. [Page D1.] Shoppers cut back on visits to stores in April, depressing sales growth for most retailers. [D3.]
The Labor Department says that it overstated by 540,000 the number of jobs created in the late 1980's and how many jobs disappeared in the recession. [D1.] 
 Administration officials are considering alternatives to the investment tax credit to spur the economy, including small-business tax breaks and a smaller corporate income tax increase. [D1.]
How one young lobbyist preserved the tax-deductibility of airline and hotel club dues offers insight into Washington. [A1.]
The Senate voted to make lobbyists report on who hires them to sway public policy and what they spend doing it. [A18.]
Legislation to revamp the nation's health-care system will be delayed further before going to Congress. [A18.]
 
Companies
Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield was told by the U.S. that its handling of $1.7 billion in Medicare claims was so poor that its contract with the Government might be canceled. [A1.]
Some of the nation's biggest newspapers are forming a research consortium to explore new ways to use computers and telecommunications to deliver news. [D1.]
Carl Icahn offered to buy out holders of E-II Holdings' senior notes and take control of the company in a deal worth about $820 million. [D1.]

Computer makers and phone companies questioned the new U.S. plan to encode advanced electronic communications. [D3.]

OSHA wants to fine Con Edison $247,000 for a power plant explosion last November that killed one man and burned two. [B3.]
Grumman will close a major electronics plant on Long Island, along with others in Texas and Maryland. [B4.]
The firms built by Gov. Jim Florio's chief aide and another ally have become the biggest and most influential advisory concerns in New Jersey's municipal bond business. [B4.]
The largest law firms grew hardly at all last year, continuing layoffs and hiring freezes because there is not enough work. [B16.]
 
International
China has been on an American shopping spree in recent months, ordering more than $1 billion of goods. Driving the deals is the June deadline by which President Clinton must decide whether to extend China's most-favored-nation trade status. [A1.]
The French economy is in far worse straits than the previous Socialist Cabinet suggested, according to a report cited as a factor in the suicide of former Prime Minister Pierre Beregovoy. [A9.]
 
Markets
Stocks traded in a narrow range for much of the day, then turned down in the last hour. The Dow slipped 7.20. [D4.]
The Treasury's shift in its borrowing mix away from long-term debt is a bet that inflation will remain at low levels. [D12.]

HEADLINE: Job Loss in Recession: Scratch Those Figures

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Having declared last June that the recent recession had eliminated many more jobs than anyone realized, the Labor Department is now canceling that view.
The department says it overstated by 540,000 the number of jobs that were created in the late 1980's. And then it overstated, by the same amount, how many jobs disappeared in the recession. 
 Not until early this year did the Labor Department realize that any of these figures were incorrect, and that data processing companies that deliver payroll information to the Government had miscounted.
Among other things, they were counting paychecks rather than the people getting the checks -- so that a person getting a paycheck and then an overtime check came out in the data as two workers. The Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics will formally correct the job numbers in June, the month it sets aside for correcting mistakes.
 
 
'It Just Dawned on Us'
 "We blamed the recession for eliminating jobs that had never existed in the first place," said Thomas Plewes, an associate commissioner of the bureau. "It just dawned on us recently, after we had gone through millions of records, what really happened."
Beyond jobs -- and fresh doubts about the reliability of Government economic data -- the corrections appear to shed little new light on the economy. The unemployment rate, 7 percent through March, is derived from a different source: a survey of 65,000 households. Economic growth, or gross domestic product, is calculated from revenue and income data, not job holders. Only productivity, which measures worker output, may be revised in June.
"We now find that productivity fell trivially during the recession," said Edwin Dean, the bureau's productivity expert. "We might change this to a slight drop."
But the error might have given Bill Clinton some help in the election. The "accounting mistake," as the bureau now labels it, came at a bad moment for President George Bush. Until June, the bureau had calculated the job loss during the 1990-91 recession at 1.2 million people.
When June rolled around -- the annual moment for officially correcting mistakes -- the bureau ruled that the recession had cost more jobs than earlier data suggested, and that the real job loss during the recession, which officially lasted nine months (from June 1990 to April 1991), had been 1.7 million, not 1.2 million. The bureau issued what it now says was an incorrect correction.
Seizing the new 1.7 million figure, Mr. Clinton charged that Mr. Bush had callously minimized the recession's impact -- a charge that no longer stands up so well.
"Numerous claims made about the economy during the campaign by candidate Clinton were highly exaggerated, this being one of them," said Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers for Mr. Bush. "But the long period of recession and sluggish recovery, irrespective of any measurement error, was what the voters responded to."
But Mr. Bush will not emerge exonerated when the bureau issues its new corrections next month. He had been credited with some of the 540,000 extra jobs counted earlier in his term. Now his record for job creation will go from a meager 1.33 million new jobs during his four-year term, down to one million or so. The bureau is still working out the exact number.
 
 
Data for I.R.S. Are Used
 Counting American jobs took on a new complexity in the 1980's. Six million American companies, almost every employer, are required to deliver payroll and tax data to the Internal Revenue Service and state tax agencies, and some of this information is also used by the Bureau of Labor Statistics to count job holders.
Until the 1980's, the companies handled most of this work. Then the data processing companies got into the business, signing contracts with roughly a million companies employing 30 million people, Mr. Plewes said. Most were smaller operations with fewer than 250 workers. In an era of cost-cutting, they found it less expensive to subcontract this work. Somehow, a number of the data processors made similar mistakes: their software counted payrolls instead of people, or counted data for an entire month rather than the single week in mid-month that the bureau specifies.
This meant that a regular paycheck, for example, counted as one job holder, Mr. Plewes said. An overtime check to the same person came out in the data as a second job holder. And a bonus check, to the same employee, became a third job holder. In addition, counting paychecks for an entire month, rather than a single week, meant that people who received two or more paychecks were counted as two or more job holders.
 
 
Some Answers Emerging
 Just why these mistakes were made is not clear, but some answers are beginning to emerge. Steve Saxton, who manages the California government's program for current employment statistics, suggests that some of the companies may have shared common software. Then, too, the priority was to send pay data to the I.R.S. and to the state agencies. "Job information became secondary in this operation," Mr. Saxton said.
Fred Anderson, chief financial officer at Automatic Data Processing Inc. of Roseland, N.J., one of the companies doing the counting, takes that explanation a step further. "We do not furnish any information directly to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, and we are not required to do so," he said. The obligation was only to the I.R.S. and the state agencies. And the wage and tax information that went to them was correct, Mr. Anderson said, adding, "We are now part of a general industry group that is working with the Bureau of Labor Statistics to try to improve information."
Whatever the obligation, the computerized forms included a section for listing job holders, deriving the number from wage information. And the miscount in these figures was inadvertently fixed in late 1990.
The bureau asked employers for new information, including data like the number of offices and factories in a particular county, rather than counting them as a single entity. "That drew attention to the job-counting item," Mr. Plewes said. And it apparently led to software changes that corrected much of the job overcounting, Mr. Plewes said, without anyone realizing it.
 
 
Overcounting Accumulated
 So suddenly, in the first quarter of 1991, accumulated overcounting that had taken place for five or more years, showed up as a sharp drop in the total number of jobs. Also, for the first time, the national job count covering the six million companies veered away from the bureau's own monthly survey of 350,000 companies.
In effect, the new software had corrected, in one swoop, most of the 540,000 overcount. With more than 100 million Americans holding jobs, the 540,000 represented a divergence of half a percent -- enough to notice when corrected all at once, but hard to spot over the years with only a few thousand mistakes made each month. The bureau typically uses the more comprehensive job count, published quarterly, as the benchmark to adjust the monthly figures -- although in hindsight, the monthly survey turned out to be more accurate.
"Next month, our benchmark revision will be less than 100,000," Mr. Plewes said, insisting that since early 1991, the monthly survey and the larger count have been pretty much in sync. "We are almost right on."
He is not totally sanguine, however. "I am not satisfied that this won't happen again," Mr. Plewes said. "But we are establishing pretty strong contacts with these companies. I don't think there is anyone out there in the data industry any longer missing the concept of what we need."


GRAPHIC: Some payroll companies that supply job data to the Government were unknowingly counting some jobs twice until a change in computer software, made for other reasons, also eliminated the double counting. Economists mistook the statistical plunge for a genuinely huge job loss until its true cause came to light recently.
