HEADLINE: U.S. Muslims, Despite World Spotlight, Focus on the Personal

SERIES: Muslims in America -- Last of four articles.

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich.

 BODY:
There is an almost startling contrast between a resurgent Islam's tumultuous role on the world scene and the expectations of how a growing Islamic presence will change America.
The most likely effect, most experts believe, will be to bolster the forces of social conservatism on issues like sexual permissiveness, support for parochial schools and gay rights. 
 But American Muslims, a steadily growing group who already number perhaps three million to four million, are unlikely to become a major political force anytime soon that can, for example, transform American policy on abortion or toward the Middle East. One reason is their diversity of ethnic and nation origins. Arab Americans, and African-Americans and immigrants from Pakistan and other parts of Asia often differ widely in their outlooks and agendas.
Another reason is the power of the United States to absorb and assimilate religious groups. Yvonne Haddad, a University of Massachusetts professor who has studied Islamic life in the United States for more than 15 years, doubted that even a Muslim population of 10 million would overcome that power: "I'm afraid the American machine will chew them up like it chews up everybody else."
 
How They Will Compare
 Within a decade or so, there will probably be more Muslims in the United States than Presbyterians, and sometime after that more than the estimated six million Jews. At that point, although still equaling only a small fraction of the Christian population of more than 200 million, Muslims will be comparable to some of the bigger Christian groups, like the Methodists or Lutherans.
And Muslim leaders do have definite political and social goals, some more attainable than others. These begin with changes that would make it easier to practice their faith: things like school textbooks free of anti-Islamic stereotypes, permission at school and work to observe Islamic holidays, Muslim chaplains in the armed forces, the availability of food that meets Islam's dietary code, a drug-free, less sexually permissive environment for their children.
Many of these things have been achieved in communities with established Muslim populations like Dearborn, a city of 87,000, more than 20 percent of them believed to be Muslim, abutting Detroit. The student body at some of the public schools is overwhelmingly Muslim -- citywide, it is 36 percent -- and the lunchrooms serve no pork. City Councilwoman Suzanne Sareini, a Muslim of Lebanese descent, says that she has not encountered animosity because of her ethnicity or religion.
But beyond simply protecting the Muslim way of life, some Muslims have strong hopes of exercising real influence on American policies toward Islamic movements and populations overseas, and on shaping the social environment at home.
"Muslims' primary concerns are the personal things," said Linda Wolbridge, assistant director of the Middle East Institute at Columbia University. "Can my daughter be safe on the streets, are my children going to be entrapped by drugs, alcohol or promiscuity?"
The potential of Muslim political power as well as its limits were illustrated when Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, accepted an invitation a few years ago to what he thought would be a small Pakistani street fair. "I show up Sunday at 3, and there are 10,000 people in the street," he recalled. "There were many more Pakistanis in Brooklyn than I'd thought."
But he added: "They do not really have political clout yet. Many of the people are not registered to vote, and they are not that well organized."
 
Mosaic
Islam in America Has Many Faces
Islam in America is divided between African-American Muslims, who may account for one-third of the total, and immigrants. Many of the recent Muslim immigrants from Pakistan, India and Egypt are physicians, engineers and businessmen who locate in suburbia and look forward to assimilating quickly into American society. African-American Muslims, while they include professionals, tend to be concentrated in or around inner cities.
Immigrant Muslims themselves are divided by nationality and ethnicity, by different forms of Islam and by the generation gap between more assimilated immigrants and recent arrivals. In addition, the energy and resources of Muslims in America are currently being absorbed by efforts to organize their own religious community, and to finance new mosques and schools.
And while American Muslims are struggling with these problems, they confront the same forces of assimilation and intermarriage that have pared away the ranks of other religious groups. No intermarriage statistics exist for the United States, but Professor Haddad doubted that the rate here was lower than in Canada, where, she said, two out of three Muslim women are marrying men who were not previously Muslim.
Half of those husbands convert, but many of the conversions, she said, are pro forma: "Even the Muslims call them Cupid's Muslims." Islamic law forbids Muslim women to marry outside their religion.
If there is anything that appears to unite the vast majority of Muslims, it is the conviction that the United States unduly favors Israel in its dealings with Palestinians. Muslims are also deeply dismayed at what they see as European and American inaction in the face of atrocities in Bosnia.
But Muslim leaders doubt that this feeling will extend to other international conflicts involving Muslims, like the fighting between Christian Armenia and Muslim Ajerbaijan or the clash between India and a Muslim separatist movement in Kashmir.
Nahid Khan, a London-born Muslim of Pakistani background who is a reporter at The Moscow-Pullman Daily News in Pullman, Wash., said, "All these foreign issues are taken up by the leaders of groups, but it is hard to tell whether the rank-and-file take them to heart." Usually, she added, the fervor is limited to "the ethnic groups closest to a regional crisis."
"Politics begins at home," said Abdurahman Alamoudi, executive director of the American Muslim Council in Washington. "Unless we are involved with the issues facing people here, we won't get them to appreciate our concerns abroad." He is highly critical of Muslim reluctance to get involved in local politics.
His organization, which has enlisted support from both immigrant and black American Muslim leaders, was founded three years ago to mobilize Muslims politically. It has joined with the Roman Catholic bishops' conference and Jewish and Protestant leaders in demanding international protection for Bosnian civilians. A budget of $250,000 a year, raised from 2,500 dues-paying members plus contributors, supports seven full-time workers along with many volunteers.
That is still a small presence compared with the Washington offices of many other religious groups, and it does not promise in the foreseeable future to compare with groups lobbying on behalf of Israel. The task of urging greater American consideration for Palestinians will continue to fall to Arab-American groups that are not specifically Islamic.
 
Politics
Gazing Nervously Across an Ocean
While domestic concerns may dominate among most Muslims, the international issues are the ones that make Americans worry that this country could become the spawning ground for more political violence -- or the site of it. Muslim leaders do not deny the existence of terrorists in the population here but insist that they are a tiny minority.
In Dearborn, the home to many refugees from the civil war in Lebanon and Israel's 1982 invasion, there are least a few organizers for militant groups overseas. "These people came from a war ground, a killing field, and they brought everything with them," said Charles K. Alawan, chairman of the board of trustees at the Islamic Center of America, a mosque and community center mainly serving Lebanese Muslims who settled in Dearborn and belong to the Shi'ite branch of Islam.
Hezbollah, or the Party of God, the Shi'ite Muslim group supported by Iran that has held hostages and clashed with the Israelis, "is still part of their social discussions about the homeland," he said. So is Amal, a rival Lebanese militia.
Dr. Wolbridge agreed with the view of Mr. Alawan and several other Dearborn Lebanese that the attraction of Hezbollah and Amal had shrunk as immigrants established themselves in the United States and as Lebanon became more stable.
 
A Blend of Loyalties
 Mr. Alawan himself represents a combination of loyalties that may seem inexplicable to many Americans. He described himself as a Goldwater Republican. He also sat beneath a picture of the Ayatollah Khomeini, defending Iran's as the only truly Muslim government. Of Southern Lebanese descent, he did not disguise his opposition to Israeli power over Southern Lebanon.
But Mr. Alawan's real preoccupations appeared to be his mosque's efforts to attract younger members. Like other Muslims across the country, Mr. Alawan listed abortion, public acceptance of homosexuality and premarital sex as major concerns.
Mr. Alawan supported nondenominational prayers in public schools: "In this mad rush not to infringe on anyone's beliefs, we have forgotten we are a nation that recognizes the existence of the deity," he said.
 
Priorities
Focus on Schools, Role of Women
Schooling is a major issue among American Muslims. "Muslims are moving toward a system like the Catholic system," said Amina McCloud, who teaches Islamic studies at De Paul University. "They are being forced by the increasing violence in the schools and the lack of academic focus, with people trying just to stay alive and avoid drugs."
Fareed Nu-Man, director of research at the American Muslim Council, said there are 165 Muslim full-time Muslim schools across the country, although more than 90 percent of Muslim children remain in the public schools.
Ghulam Aasi, a professor at the American Islamic College in Chicago, said that some Muslims in the Chicago area supported President George Bush because of his proposal for government vouchers to pay for private school tuition.
 
Equality for Women?
 The role of women is changing among American Muslims. Many Muslims assert that Islam and its sacred text, the Koran, affirm the equality of women, and that many restrictions on women in Islamic lands arise from local culture rather than Islam itself. But there is no consensus on where to draw the line between cultural custom and religious obligation.
Councilwoman Sareini looked forward to changes in Islamic practice as more women are educated "to read the Koran and know their rights." Meanwhile, she said that Americans had no reason to fear Muslim legislators.
The Councilwoman, a conservative whose office is decorated with photographs of Presidents Ronald Reagan and Bush as well as a picture of her father outside the family's Uncle Sam's Shish Kebab Restaurant in South Dearborn, said, "Muslims will be good for the Republican party" because of their attitudes on the "family-values issues."
Deputy Mayor Adam Shakoor of Detroit disagrees. An African-American Muslim who was chief judge of one of Detroit's largest courts before Mayor Coleman A. Young appointed him to be the equivalent of a chief of staff, Mr. Shakoor said that Islam taught "compassion in terms of working-class people and have-nots that would lead a lot of Muslims to be Democrats."
Still, some Muslim leaders foresee a loose alliance with conservative Protestants, Catholics and Orthodox Jews in seeking government aid to religious schools as well as opposing abortion, pornography and the acceptance of gay relationships or other sexual behavior outside marriage.
 
Impact
How One City Has Been Changed
In Dearborn, it is easy to see the impact of the Arab Muslim immigrants, but harder to tell how much of that impact is Arab, how much is Muslim and how much immigrant.
In a city where the massive River Rouge auto works that once employed 90,000 people now employs 8,000, Muslim Arab-Americans have provided a new economic base of bakeries, restaurants and other small businesses along eastern Dearborn's Warren Avenue.
At the Arab Community Center for Economic and Social Services, which provides language, job training, counseling, health care, child care and other programs in English and Arabic for more than 25,000 people, there is no prevention or prenatal program for out-of-wedlock adolescent pregnancies. "I can't document the teen-age pregnancies that would justify applying for funds," said May M. Berry, who directs the center's Teen Health Clinic.
In the wider Detroit area, the Council of Islamic Organizations of Michigan, headed by Imam Abdullah El-Amin, remains a fledgling group. It brings together immigrants and black Americans, helped achieve passage of a city emergency ordinance banning the sale of drug paraphernalia in convenience stores and has supported laws requiring parental notification of minors seeking abortions.
Prospective candidates for city offices are said to have started meeting with Muslim leaders much as they have always done with Detroit's Council of Baptist Pastors.
In her office at Dearborn's City Hall, Ms. Sareini said "I don't see a big wave of Islam that would change politics as we know it." But asked what America would be like with a population of 10 million Muslims, she said, "We'd be a better place."
 
The Series
 The series on Muslims in America: An article on May 2 described the diversity and concerns of the growing population of Muslims in the United States. A second on May 3 described the turn to mainstream Islam among black Americans, and a third on May 4 described how a maturing Islamic community in New England has built friendly ties with other groups.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: U.N.;
Resolution Establishes Safe Areas But Lacks Enforcement Provision

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 6

 BODY:
The Security Council voted today to declare six war-torn Bosnian cities as "safe areas" in a resolution that demanded an end to taking territory by force and called on the Secretary General to deploy 50 more military observers to protect civilians in the towns.
How the zones would be protected was not addressed in the resolution, which was adopted unanimously. Although the resolution demanded total compliance from all parties, diplomats here say the possibility of cooperation is remote, even with 50 additional soldiers to carry out the plan. 
 There are some 9,000 United Nations troops in Bosnia now, but their only mandate is to protect aid shipments. About 220 Canadian peacekeepers have been attempting to maintain a safe area in Srebrenica, which is without water or power. Srebrenica, the first safe zone, was created by a resolution passed on April 11.
 
A Third Rejection
 Earlier today, the assembly of Bosnian Serbs rejected a peace plan for the third time. Since the safe areas were intended to guarantee the safety of civilians in Serbian-held areas until the arrival of the 60,000-member United Nations force stipulated in the peace plan, the rejection vastly reduced the possibility that the Bosnian Serbs would abide by the resolution.
Speaking after the resolution was adopted, the United States representative, Madeleine K. Albright, termed the action a "palliative" and warned the leaders of the Bosnian Serbs that Washington is "consulting with our allies about new, stronger and tougher measures." She did not spell them out.
The cities cited by the council were the capital, Sarajevo, Tuzla, Zepa, Gorazde and Bihac, as well as Srebrenica. The resolution said they should be "treated as safe areas by all the parties concerned and should be free from armed attacks and from any other hostile act."
 
Whose Referendum?
 Ms. Albright criticized the Bosnian Serbs for rejecting the peace plan that their leader, Radovan Karadzic, signed last Sunday. Calling them an "unelected group of dubious characters," she said the parliament had "made a mockery of the signatures in Athens."
Noting that the parliament had called for a referendum on the peace plan that had been put forward by United Nations and European Community mediators, she raised the question of who would be eligible to vote.
"Those responsible for war crimes will be allowed to participate in the referendum, if it ever occurs," she said, but "we doubt that those forced from their homes at gunpoint will be. We know that those who now enjoy the peace of the grave will not participate."
Today's resolution came after the Security Council sent a six-member fact-finding mission to Bosnia last week. The delegation, led by the Venezuelan representative to the United Nations, Diego Arria, recommended that the idea of safe areas, which had partial success in Srebrenica, be extended to other regions.
Mr. Arria, who last week called Srebrenica "an open prison," charged today that the world "had, in a way, encouraged the Serbs" in their defiant behavior. He said threats had failed and that it was time for "concrete action" such as air strikes.
Ms. Albright said that whether or not the Bosnian Serbs agree to comply with "this and other relevant Council resolutions in the next days will determine whether we and the rest of the international community decide that the use of force is inevitable."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mario Nobilos, left, representative from Croatia, Mohammed Sacirbey, center, representative from Bosnia, and Alexandros P. Mallias, a counselor at the Greek Mission, conferring yesterday at the United Nations. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Choking Yugoslavia"
 
MOST TRADE with Yugoslavia is banned. Medicine, food and relief supplies and services are exempt. As a result, inflation is running at 250 percent a month and there are shortages of basic goods, especially gasoline.
 
AIR LINKS are cut, and ships are barred from loading or unloading at Yugoslav ports. United Nations member countries are asked to impound Yugoslav ships, trains and aircraft in their territory if they violate sanctions.
 
SHIPPING through Yugoslavia by land or on the Danube River, an international waterway, is blocked. This sanction was imposed April 26, and it is too early to determine the impact.
 
ASSETS ABROAD, both private and belonging to the Yugoslav Government, were frozen on April 26.
 
DIPLOMATIC MISSIONS have been required to reduce staff levels.
 
PARTICIPATION in sports events and scientific, technical and cultural exchanges is suspended.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: Clinton's Plight;
For Bosnia's Serbs, the War Is Total, But the U.S. and Its Allies See Limits

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
The refusal of Bosnian Serbs to accept the peace settlement in Bosnia has put President Clinton in an exquisite diplomatic bind: his threat of military action has failed to produce a political solution, and the allies and Congress are still expressing reservations about carrying out the military threats.
The reason is simple. While many allies mourn for the Bosnian Muslims, others do not see a direct threat to their own national interests that would justify their deep involvement in a rescue mission. 
 The allies are ready to make sacrifices for Bosnia -- up to a point. The NATO powers feel threatened by the war -- up to a point. Mr. Clinton is wrestling with how to handle the Serbian nationalists, who seem ready to go all the way for their goals, while Washington and its allies are ready to go only part way to stop them.
Washington and its allies seem to be tailoring their strategy to what will sell at home, not what is needed to bring a decisive halt to the fighting.
 
Behind the Reluctance
 Mr. Clinton is ready to use air power and arm the Bosnian Muslims, but he says he will not commit American ground forces because he is not going to risk his domestic agenda trying to settle a European civil war.
The British and the French have sent a few thousand troops to aid in relief efforts, but they are reluctant to go further because that might imperil their troops.
Clinton aides are growing increasingly exasperated with Europe, which they liken to a family living in an upstairs apartment while the ground floor is on fire. The people upstairs refuse to call for help because they do not want their carpet to get wet as the fire is extinguished.
Mr. Clinton is unwilling to tell the United States that he is committing American troops to quell a European conflict that Europe itself is not ready to quell; for his own domestic political cover, Mr. Clinton needs to jump into Bosnia hand in hand with the Europeans.
"America has made its position clear," Mr. Clinton said in a speech to a trade group today. "It is ready to do its part, but Europe must be willing to act with us. We must go forward together."
 
The View From Europe
 The Europeans say they see things quite differently. After 40 years of American leadership, they are not used to being asked to move in tandem with Washington. They are used to being dragged. For their own domestic politics, they need to be dragged. In their view, Mr. Clinton has been acting like a general who wants his troops' permission before leading them into battle.
Now that the Bosnian Serbs have rebuffed the peace plan, the Europeans say they want Mr. Clinton to commit himself unequivocally to a military course of action, and then count on the Europeans to fall into line behind him.
But if all they want is for Washington to take the lead, why will they not even agree to lift the arms embargo on the Muslims? Maybe they fear a wider war in the Balkans more than a Serbian victory, and they just do not want to say that out loud to the Americans?
In any event, there are many reasons America cannot lead in Bosnia as it did in the Persian Gulf. At several White House strategy sessions last week, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin L. Powell, exclaimed, "Boy, was the gulf war easy compared to this!"
 
Differences Are Many
 And no wonder, a Clinton aide said.
"There what you had was one country, Iraq, invading another, Kuwait; here you have a civil war," he said. "There what you had was sand and desert; here you have trees and mountains. There what you had were neighbors who felt directly threatened by Iraq and were ready to do whatever was necessary; here the neighbors feel only a little threatened. There you were sitting on oil and there were clear-cut economic interests that the American people could understand; here the consequences are more indirect, and while they are just as important, they are less easy to describe."
And there is one more important difference. In the gulf, the allies had clearly defined, if somewhat cynical, political objectives: restore the Emir of Kuwait and push Saddam Hussein back across the border. In Bosnia the allies have a map, drawn up by mediators, but they do not really have a clearly defined, workable political structure to put in place.
What sort of Bosnia do they want? No doubt the allies all have views on this, but they are complicated to explain, and when it comes to taking a nation to war, if a President has to explain it, it is already too complicated.
None of this is news to Clinton aides. They do not present their policy options as a silver bullet; everything is described as the least bad choice in a bad situation that they inherited.
 
Implications for Clinton
 But this moment of choice has real implications for the Clinton Presidency. The Bush Administration approached Bosnia as a European problem on which Europe should take the lead.
Mr. Clinton has exposed himself -- some will say courageously, others will say imprudently -- by insisting that the United States has moral, humanitarian and strategic interests in Bosnia.
But as former Bush Administration officials now ruefully note, the minute Mr. Clinton crossed that line -- from turning his back on Bosnia to saying "we must do something" -- he made his own reputation vulnerable.
"Once you announce that you're going to war, you have to win it," a senior Administration official said.
Now, if Mr. Clinton does nothing, he will look weak and indecisive, and if he does something and it fails, he will weaken himself. Only if his military strategy works and leads to a settlement might he get credit. Even then, as Mr. Bush learned in the Persian Gulf, such credit is a rapidly diminishing resource.

HEADLINE: Factory Output Up In Quarter

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The productivity of American factories soared in the first quarter, an upbeat sign for profits and another indication that the drive to make American manufacturing leaner and more competitive has continued into the 1990's.
Spurts in the production of computers and cars helped push up output per hour in the manufacturing sector, which makes up about a fifth of the economy, at an annual rate of 4.8 percent in the quarter, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. 
 But productivity in the entire private economy -- which consists mainly of services like banking, health, education and retailing -- did not rise in the first quarter, the first no-growth quarter since the recession officially ended two years ago. The bureau said yesterday that productivity edged down at an annual rate of one-tenth of 1 percent, after having surged at an annual rate of 4.1 percent in the fourth quarter of 1992.
 
A Sluggish Expansion
 Meanwhile, retailers provided further evidence that the economic expansion remained sluggish in April. Several big department store chains reported yesterday that April sales were unimpressive. [Page D3.]
The leveling of productivity ended a string of solid gains that had raised hopes that long-term productivity growth, which had been less than 1 percent during the 1980's, had rebounded to its historical average of about 2 percent a year.
"It raises a question about whether we are on a new, higher productivity trajectory, especially in services," said Lawrence Mishel, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute in Washington.
Economists at the labor statistics bureau, who had maintained that speculation about a revival in productivity was premature, cautioned analysts not to make too much of the data from one quarter.
 
Improvement in Employment
 The lull in productivity growth did not surprise analysts. Productivity measures output per hour of work. The Government had previously reported that in the first quarter, the gross domestic product -- the economy's total output -- had grown at only half the fourth-quarter rate while jobs had sprouted at their strongest rate in several years.
"We had a definite improvement in the employment situation in the first quarter," said Edwin R. Dean, the associate commissioner of the bureau.
Part of the lagging overall productivity in the first quarter may have been the unusually severe winter weather. "Retailers and builders were hiring because the economy was improving," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch. "When the weather really knocked down consumer spending and construction, there were people on payrolls who weren't producing that much. That's obviously not going to continue."
Mr. Steinberg said he expected productivity would improve this year. "We think the stall was only a temporary setback."
Still, the report was a reminder that the slow-growth economy had either generated good productivity gains or a crop of new jobs, but not both in the same quarter. Over a period of years, productivity gains have largely determined whether real pay and living standards would rise.
The bureau also reported that hourly compensation grew at an anemic annual rate of 3.3 percent in the quarter, a bit more slowly than inflation. Meanwhile, the lack of an increase in productivity meant that unit labor costs jumped in the first quarter, a hint that profit margins outside manufacturing had probably weakened.
In contrast to the economy as a whole, manufacturing turned in a bright performance, with work hours and productivity rising in tandem. The total hours worked rose at a solid annual rate of 2.2 percent, while production increased at a healthy 7 percent annual rate. A lot of that production came from factories that churned out more computers to keep up with strong business spending on new high-tech gear and more cars and vans to satisfy the increased demand for vehicles.
The gains in factory efficiency in the last year had been the biggest in any year since 1977, and have helped drive unit labor costs down by 1.4 percent from a year ago.

HEADLINE: Investment Credit in Trouble, Clinton Seeks Alternatives

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
With the proposed investment tax credit in deep trouble in Congress, Administration officials said today that they were considering several other options to spur the economy, including new tax breaks for small business and a smaller increase in the corporate income tax.
Another option under consideration, officials said, would be to delay the proposed increases in personal and corporate income tax rates so that they take effect on Jan. 1, 1994, instead of being retroactive to this past Jan. 1. 
 Robert E. Rubin, assistant to President Clinton for economic policy, said today that in place of the investment tax credit, the White House was considering a proposal allowing companies to write off more of their investments in the year they make them.
Administration officials and Congressional aides said one possibility would be to increase the maximum investment that small businesses could write off in the first year to $20,000 or more, from the current $10,000. One legislative aide said some members of Congress were thinking of trying to raise the ceiling to $25,000.
A senior official said the Administration was also considering whether to recommend increasing the 34 percent corporate income tax by one percentage point, rather than the two percentage point increase it previously proposed.
Business executives have complained that raising the corporate income tax to 36 percent would hurt investment, and say that the smaller increase would tend to harm the economy less.
Many economists and corporate executives say the Administration's proposal to make the income tax increases effective this year has hurt consumer confidence and slowed spending.
But Clinton officials insist that over all, their deficit-reduction plan, including the proposed tax increases, has increased confidence. They acknowledge that Americans might feel freer to spend if the tax increases were delayed.
At a lunch with journalists today, Mr. Rubin said that if the investment tax credit were to die in Congress, the Administration still wanted to use the money that would have financed it to spur businesses and economic growth. The Administration estimates that the credit would cost a total of $21 billion from 1994 to 1997.
Mr. Rubin, though, denied that the measure was indeed dead and argued that it is needed to give the economy a boost when the President's deficit-reduction plan kicks in and limits economic growth.
"We think there are very good productive uses for this money if the decision is made not to go with the investment tax credit," he said, adding that he did not think that the money for it should be used for deficit reduction.
 
Incentive or Windfall?
 Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois and chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, as well as other prominent members of Congress, have criticized the investment tax credit on the ground that it favored certain industries and that companies would start making business decisions simply to take advantage of it.
They also questioned the wisdom of raising $30 billion through increased corporate income taxes and then giving $21 billion of it back to companies in the form of an investment tax credit.
The push to increase the amount of investment that small businesses could write off in the first year has come from the Ways and Means Committee, and the Administration is considering whether to support that proposal, Congressional aides said.
Thus, a company that invested $15,000 in equipment could write off $10,000 of that in the first year and depreciate the remaining $5,000 in subsequent years.
 
See Better Way to Fine-Tune
 Some Administration officials are unenthusiastic about increasing the ceiling, saying it rewards the first dollar of investment, when the more powerful way to spur the economy would be to reward the last dollar.
Gene Sperling, deputy assistant to the President for economic policy, said the Administration was willing to work with Congress to search for additional spending cuts, but he said the Administration did not want the lawmakers to scale back plans to spend $100 billion or more to increase investment in training and in public installations and services.

HEADLINE: Health-Care Plan to Be Delayed Further

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
Bowing to political reality and Congressional concerns, the White House said today that there would be a further delay in sending Congress legislation to revamp the nation's health-care system.
It now appears that the legislation, being developed by Hillary Rodham Clinton and her Task Force on National Health Care Reform, will not be sent to Congress before mid-June at the earliest, Administration officials said. 
 Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, said: "The task force is still on track to complete its work at the end of May. But exactly how we unveil that and when we take it up to the Hill is something that we're consulting with Congress about."
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said, "We expect that the task force will hand over its recommendations to the President, on schedule, at the end of May, and then the President will consult with members of Congress for the best time to announce it."
 
100-Day Deadline
 When he created the task force on Jan. 25, Mr. Clinton said its mission was to prepare "legislation to be submitted to Congress within 100 days of our taking office" -- in other words, by the end of April.
Mrs. Clinton was out of town tending her father for two weeks before he died on April 7. And Administration officials said the latest delay showed the President's political acumen.
On Capitol Hill, Democratic leaders welcomed the delay. They had warned Mr. Clinton that he could suffer political embarrassment if he sent up an ambitious health-care bill while lawmakers were still debating a comprehensive bill to raise taxes, reduce the Federal budget deficit and stimulate the economy.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said the most important political question was not when the President unveiled his plan, but whether the Administration would have a strategy to "explain it to the American people."
"If you don't figure out how to articulate it, we could be here for six years," he added.
People working for the task force say there are other reasons for delaying a detailed legislative proposal. For example, they say, the President and his advisers are still mulling over fundamental questions about the design and financing of the health-care system they want to create.
Moreover, Mrs. Clinton and Ira C. Magaziner, the day-to-day manager of her task force, have been moving steadily toward bolder, more complex and more sweeping proposals to remake the nation's health-care system, even as some members of Congress urge them to simplify and scale down their plan.
Members of the task-force staff say that Mr. Magaziner has shown an insatiable appetite for technical information and has concluded that huge sums of money could be saved by radically reorganizing the nation's health-care system.
 
Zeal to Help Uninsured
 Aides to Mr. Magaziner, who is the senior adviser for policy development, say his impulses reinforce Mrs. Clinton's zeal to help millions of people who lack health insurance.
Under the Clinton plan, sometimes known as managed competition, large groups of consumers and businesses would buy care from organized networks of doctors, hospitals and insurance companies.
At the White House, the Clintons had lunch today with Republican members of Congress, who generally oppose his recommendation for a Federal law requiring employers to provide health insurance coverage to their workers. Administration officials are seriously considering asking employers to pay a percentage of their payrolls in premiums to help finance health care.
Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, the leader of a Republican senators' study group on health care, said the idea of a payroll tax or premium "gives me a lot of problems," and added: "Republican senators are not in favor of that. We have deep concerns whether small business could handle it."
Senator Chafee and other Republican lawmakers said they had assured the President that they would not criticize him for delays in sending health legislation to Congress. It is more important to "do it right" than to meet an artificial deadline, the Senator said.
At a picture-taking session in the Oval Office today, the President said he did not know when he would announce the details of his health plan.
"The most important thing," he said, "is that we're going to finish the outline of the details on time, and then we're going to enter one more round of extensive consultations before we come forward with it." The timetable for sending legislation to Congress "depends in part on how we're doing in the consultations," he added.
Mrs. Clinton told members of Congress that the President's plan would help pay for long-term care, including medical and social services for elderly and disabled people living in their own homes. But she said the new coverage would be introduced gradually.

HEADLINE: 17 Companies in Electronic News Venture

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 6

 BODY:
Some of the nation's biggest newspapers are taking another look at the electronic paperboy.
A group of 17 companies, including the newspaper publishers Gannett, Knight-Ridder and Times Mirror, plan to announce Friday that they are forming a research consortium to explore new ways to use computers and telecommunications to deliver news. The possibilities might include electronic newspapers transmitted to pocket-sized wireless computers or personalized papers printed at home. 
 The project will be carried out at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Laboratory. Other participants will include the Tribune Company, Hearst, I.B.M., Capital Cities/ABC and BellSouth.
The five-year "News in the Future" program will cost from $1.5 million to $2 million annually. It is the latest in a series of developments indicating that newspaper publishers, after past disappointments in technologies like videotex and other forms of electronic news services, have a renewed interest in converging computer and communications technologies.
"There is a big scramble to deliver bits electronically to everyone's home," said Walter Bender, a scientist at the M.I.T. Media Laboratory and a principal researcher for the project.
"The cost factor has changed dramatically," he said. "It will cost the newspaper very little to get an electronic version to the home."
Electronic distribution, in fact, is already happening. Since last year, articles from The Chicago Tribune have been available via personal computer modem from America On-Line, an electronic information service based in Vienna, Va. And on Monday, The San Jose Mercury News will begin using America On-Line to offer virtually the complete text of each day's issue.
Initially, the Mercury News system will be a text-based version of the newspaper without pictures. But as higher-speed computer networks and data-compression technologies become available in the next few years, the paper is planning to add pictures.
"We're in a continuum of long, slow change and innovation," said Robert Ingle, the executive editor of The Mercury News. "People aren't going to flock to the electronic newspaper instantly. We need to use the printed newspaper to lead people into the new form, and this is Step 1."
There is no extra fee for the Mercury News service to customers of America On-Line, which charges $9.95 a month, plus $3.50 an hour after the first five hours of use each month.
 
 
Disastrous Early Venture
 The Mercury News, which is part of the Knight-Ridder chain of newspapers, is a good example of the willingness of the nation's newspapers to reconsider electronic alternatives. It was Knight-Ridder that in 1978 embarked on a disastrous foray into electronic publishing, known as Viewtron. The system was widely criticized as too costly and too slow, and it folded in 1986 after attracting only 20,000 subscribers.
"In 1978 we were inventing content and technology, and the market wasn't there," Mr. Ingle said. "The scars from Viewtron are still very vivid. It took a while to get it into people's minds that we should get back into electronic distribution."
The Mercury News's prime market is Silicon Valley, which has the nation's highest concentration of high-tech workers but a surprisingly low number of modems -- devices that enable personal computers to send and receive data over phone lines -- in homes. Only 17 percent of Silicon Valley homes have modems now.
The Mercury News project, which involves a revenue-sharing agreement with America On-Line, is not expected to be profitable soon.
"We don't know what the economics are, but we created a low-enough cost structure that it won't take very much to break even," Mr. Ingle said.
The chairman of the News in the Future project at M.I.T. will be Jerome B. Rubin, formerly a senior vice president of the Times Mirror Company, whose biggest papers include The Los Angeles Times and Newsday on Long Island. The project is intended to investigate ways to personalize electronic newspapers based on both wired and wireless technologies.
 M.I.T. researchers have already designed experimental personal electronic newspapers, which are tailored to an individual reader's interests. In such systems headlines and news articles could be selected for the reader on the basis of a profile each customer would program into the system. Some newspaper executives have criticized the concept of personalized news, saying that readers' eyes are often drawn to a headline or picture that pulls them into a story about which they may have had no prior interest. But Nicholas Negroponte, director of the M.I.T. laboratory, says there is no reason future systems cannot let readers customize the service or simply to browse, depending on their preference.
Other companies that have announced their sponsorship of the program include Advance Publications, Grupo Consolido, McCann-Erickson and Televisa.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Gamble That Inflation Stays Low

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Clinton Treasury is betting that the Clinton Presidency will succeed in creating a low-inflation environment over the next several years and that the President's successor will follow suit.
That is the gamble that the Treasury took this week when it announced that it would shift 45 percent of its longer-term borrowing to shorter- term maturities of from three years to three months. If the bet proves wrong and inflation does not stay low, taxpayers will be paying higher interest costs. 
 "Whether this turns out to be a good thing or a bad thing is whether they follow good economic policy or bad economic policy for the next several years," William Dudley, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said yesterday. "That is another way of saying that inflation stays low."
 
Debt Mix Shift Applauded
 The economist Henry Kaufman, who applauded the Treasury debt mix shift, added, "It is betting on your own economic policy."
But Mr. Kaufman also said that the shift, by helping to lower intermediate and long-term interest rates slightly, would assist the private sector, which he said should be a more important goal of the policy change.
"The Treasury should follow a policy that will be supportive of the economic recovery even if it is only in a marginal sense," Mr. Kaufman said. And, he said, borrowing more with short-term securities is a positive incentive for the Treasury.
"As the Treasury finances short term, its financing costs are more variable," he said. "As inflation goes up, interest costs will go up, so Treasury has an additional incentive in the fight against inflation."
Bringing the deficit under control, which has looked less likely in recent weeks because of the problems of President Clinton in getting his programs through Congress, is the kind of long-term repair the economy needs, analysts say. That would help foster confidence and help keep long-term interest rates coming down, making more investors believe that inflation will remain low.
Such a trend could lead to lower long-term interest rates and, at the same time, only small increases in short-term interest rates as the economy begins to pick up pace. In that case, it would be advisable to cut some long-term borrowing because long rates would be falling. And it would not be so risky to add to short-term borrowing because short-term interest rates would not likely rise enough to erase the savings gained by shifting from higher-interest-rate long-term borrowing to lower-interest-rate shorter-term borrowing.
But this blend of economic policies may also require that the economy grow at just a moderate pace, which would mean that the President's goal of creating millions of new jobs would be harder to attain.
There is another way to make the debt shift work, but that would be an even less desired condition for the Administration: a new recession that would bring both short- and long-term rates and inflation lower.
 
Move Seen Well Considered
 Analysts who do not support what the Treasury did on Wednesday -- which included a 40 percent reduction in the annual issuance of 30-year bonds; a shift to two, instead of four, 30-year auctions a year, and the elimination of the seven-year note -- do agree that the move was well considered. They say it was not just an all-out effort to cut borrowing costs and push interest rates lower by eliminating long-term borrowing. If this were the case, the Treasury could have eliminated the 30-year bond auction scheduled for next week and reduced the level of 10-year note borrowing.
"Given that they had made the bad decision to shorten the maturity of the debt, they went about it in a quite reasonable way." said Louis Crandall, the chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates.
 
Treasury Market
 Treasury prices were mixed yesterday as traders and investors awaited the Labor Department report on April employment, which is to be released this morning.
In the last 16 months, the price of the 30-year bond has rallied and the yield has fallen eight times in the week ahead of the employment report. This week became the ninth time as the yield on the long bond fell to 6.80 percent, from 6.92 percent last Friday.
Forecasters are expecting a moderate increase in nonfarm payroll jobs in the range of 157,000, according to Bloomberg Business News. But what is more important is the impression about the strength of the economy that the report leaves with traders and investors. A feeling that the economy has bounced back from the weather-related slowdown in March would make it harder for yields to break out of their current trading range and move to new lows.
In secondary trading, the price of the 30-year bond was down 6/32 as the yield rose to 6.80 percent, from 6.78 percent Wednesday, which leaves the bond little changed since the debt announcement. The price of the seven- year note fell 5/32 , to yield 5.51 percent. But despite the shift to shorter-term borrowing, prices of two-and three-year notes were up marginally and the discount rates on Treasury bills fell.

HEADLINE: At the Bar;
A Democratic firm merely flirts with Dan Quayle, and suddenly they're an item.

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
A historically Democratic law firm in Washington courts former Vice President Dan Quayle, perhaps the nation's most famous unemployed lawyer and previously its most famed bar basher. What is wrong with this picture?
That is what many people have asked since Legal Times, a weekly publication covering law and lobbying in Washington, recently reported that Mr. Quayle had held talks with Arent, Fox, Kintner, Plotkin & Kahn, another pea in the pod of major law firms in the capital. 
 The talks apparently came to naught, but not before surprising, intriguing, amusing, disgusting, or discomfiting plenty of people, including the firm's brass. Indeed, the firm's experience shows the perils of even flirting with former politicians who have aroused as much debate as Mr. Quayle.
Since being voted out of office, he has been pursuing the next phase of his life. He signed a $1 million contract to write his memoirs, he's giving speeches, and he may soon write a column for The Indianapolis Star, his family's newspaper. And continuing the work that first brought him to blows with lawyers, most famously in a speech to the American Bar Association, he will head a new "competitive center" at the Hudson Institute, a conservative study group in Indianapolis.
But apparently encouraged by former President Richard M. Nixon, who started his own return from political exile from a law firm, Mr. Quayle is at least considering private practice. It would clearly not be full time, nor presumably the conventional lawyerly lot of negotiating new deals and litigating busted ones; Mr. Quayle, after all, has never actually done either. Instead, his work would lie in what power lawyers call "rainmaking," i.e., bringing in business.
Enter Arent Fox. Its political tincture is Democratic, with one former Democratic Senator (John Culver of Iowa) and one former Democratic Congressman (Michael Barnes of Maryland) in its ranks. But when partisanship clashes with profit, or ideology with income, the latter invariably wins. The firm has always had its house Republicans, and since the most prominent of them -- J. Marshall Coleman, the former Virginia Attorney General -- left last August, it has sought a replacement.
So four Arent Fox partners, including Mr. Barnes and Mr. Culver, met with Mr. Quayle last month in the firm's downtown offices. The discussions were preliminary and exploratory -- "a question of 'what are you going to be doing in the future?' " as one partner described them -- and nothing much came of them. But law firms produce gossip in the same profusion as paper. When word of the talks leaked, the discomfort began.
Arent Fox is a firm under some economic stress, as evidenced by the fact that it promoted only 2 of 19 candidates eligible for partnership last year. Even so, the prospect of practicing law with Dan Quayle raised concerns, for reasons of temperament as well as politics. Arent Fox lawyers pride themselves on their industry; one senior partner, David Osnos, is forever invoking the adage most recently immortalized by John Houseman, about making money by earning it. How, many lawyers at the firm wondered, would Mr. Quayle fit into such an ethic?
Most lawyers in the firm learned of the dalliance when the head of the firm's general business group, Bill Charyk, met with 40 associates a few days after Mr. Quayle's visit. "I certainly hope they put a spell-check on his computer," one associate said on hearing the news. "Arent Fox Opens the Quayle-Hunting Season," Legal Times proclaimed a few days later, in an article filled with comments about the firm's shaky finances and complaints from anonymous associates.
Mr. Quayle has given no interviews since leaving office. His spokesman, Craig Whitney, would say only that the former Vice President "has had many discussions with many different people about things he may or may not do." But Mr. Quayle's former spokesman, David Beckwith, said he was "dumbfounded" to learn of the discussions.
"Practicing law, particularly making rain for a big-time Washington law firm, was never on his list of dream jobs," Mr. Beckwith said. "I think he would be far less bored working on something having to do with public policy." Around Arent Fox, however, on-the-record comments are much harder to come by. Mr. Culver did not return a telephone call. Mr. Barnes did, but was tight-lipped. "Our managing partner speaks for the firm on this sort of thing, not me," he said. And that managing partner, Rodney Page, reacted with audible annoyance when the subject was broached.
"I really can't comment on it at all," he said. "I don't think there's a story there. This was way overblown."
But will Mr. Quayle be joining Arent Fox? "Don't look for an announcement," Mr. Page said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Ties Deficit Cut to Talks Negotiations

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
President Clinton used a speech on international trade today to lobby for the passage of his deficit-reduction plan, saying that the United States will be in no position to press for open markets abroad if it does not address its own domestic problems first.
Mr. Clinton, who lost an important Congressional battle last month over a $19.5 billion package that he said would stimulate the economy and create jobs, pointed to a reduction in long-term mortgage interest rates as proof that his overall budget plan had been well received in the financial markets. As proposed, the deficit-reduction plan would cut the yearly deficit in half in four years through spending cuts and tax increases. 
 The President said reducing the deficit was the key to domestic economic revival. "This is the ultimate stimulus for the American economy if we can pass the budget that reduces the deficit and keep these rates down," he said in an address to the Export-Import Bank.

HEADLINE: Job Outlook Bleak at Big Law Firms

 BODY:
For the first time in decades, the nation's largest law firms grew hardly at all last year, according to a survey to be published this month.
The annual survey, by the legal magazine Of Counsel, found that growth at the nation's 500 largest firms was flatter than it had been since the 1950's and early 1960's. 
 Although the recession is over and legal business appears to be recovering from its effects, the firms are continuing to lay off lawyers and freeze hiring because there is no longer enough work to support the number of lawyers they employed in the booming 1980's.
"Corporations are more cost-conscious than ever," said Michael J. Crames, managing partner of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, a New York firm that the survey listed as one of the 10 large firms that lost the most lawyers. "They're trying more and more to undertake to work in-house to save money."
Last year the firm lost 50 lawyers, from 380 to 330.
 
Downward Trend Continues
 According to the survey, the firms collectively employed about 90,000 lawyers last year, roughly the same as the previous year, continuing a trend that many business experts thought had hit bottom in 1991, when the number of lawyers at the firms grew by less than 1 percent from the year before.
"This year it was such a minuscule increase that we didn't even bother coming up with a percentage for it," said Larry Smith, managing editor of the magazine, which has conducted the study for the last six years.
He said the survey suggested that no more than a dozen lawyers had been added to the pool of those working for the largest firms.
"We were stunned after we did the math," Mr. Smith said. "For the modern era of law firms, this kind of flat growth is unprecedented."
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
 To gather data for the survey, the magazine sent questionnaires to about 800 law firms. More than 500 firms participated, and 461 of those were large enough to be included. For the firms that declined to respond, the magazine used other published information, such as the Martindale-Hubbell Law Directory, to tally the number of lawyers employed.
The American Bar Association estimates that there are 800,000 lawyers working in the United States now. There are more than 42,000 law firms in the United States with more than one lawyer.
The study found that the nation's 67 largest firms, those that employ more than 300 lawyers, decreased by three-tenths of 1 percent, dropping from 31,132 to 31,048 lawyers in 1992. Eight of the 10 largest firms in the United States decreased, compared with six in 1991 and none in 1990.
Employing fewer lawyers does not necessarily mean that business is down. Bogle & Gates of Seattle, which dropped from 246 lawyers in 1991 to 214 last year, reported that 1992 was its best year in both revenue and profits.
"It actually proved to be the best adjustment we could have made," said Howard Booth, the firm's executive director. "Morale goes up when everybody's busy."

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 7.20 as Investors Await Jobs Data

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
In what has become a familiar story this week, the stock market was stuck in a narrow trading range for much of the session yesterday, before turning downward in the last hour of trading.
Once again, many investors remained on the sidelines waiting for another economic portent; this time, it was today's Government report on unemployment. 
 Meanwhile, the stock market showed little reaction yesterday to the Treasury Department's plan, released on Wednesday afternoon, to shift much of the Government's borrowing away from longer-term notes and bonds. There were no sharp moves in either the Dow Jones industrial average or the broader-based Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to indicate a large-scale shifting of money between stocks and bonds.
Most major stock indexes were down yesterday in moderate trading. A notable exception was the American Stock Exchange market value index, made up mainly of the stocks of midsize companies, which set a record high for the third consecutive day. The index closed up 1.06 point, to 426.95.
 
 
Even Nasdaq Was Sluggish
 Even the usually vigorous Nasdaq composite index, made up mainly of smaller-capitalization and high-technology stocks, showed the degree of investors' caution. It closed down 3.22 points, to 680.04, compared with Wednesday's rise of 5.10 points. In recent sessions, the Nasdaq has tended to outperform the Dow and the S.& P. 500.
The Dow industrials slipped 7.20 points, to close at 3,441.90, after trading most of the day around 3,450. The New York Stock Exchange composite index was down a half point, to 245.22. And the S.& P. 500 closed down 1.26 point, to 443.26. Volume on the Big Board totaled 255.5 million shares, compared with Wednesday's 274.2 million shares.
The Dow Jones transportation average, meanwhile, gained 4.64 points, to 1,580.35. The index was lifted mainly by UAL, parent of United Airlines, which closed up 2 1/2 points, to 136, on no discernible news.
The Dow industrials were dragged down by Woolworth, which was down 2 points, to 29 3/8, , on disappointing April retail sales; and Procter & Gamble, which was down 1 1/8, to 48, on no discernible news
 
 
RJR Roiled on Price War
 The most active stock on the Big Board was RJR Nabisco, up 1/8, to 5 5/8, on unusually heavy volume of 7.2 million shares. Competitor B.A.T. Industries announced it would respond to price cuts from Philip Morris's Marlboro and RJR Nabisco's Winston cigarette brands with discounts on its Viceroy brand.
Humana, the second-most active stock on the Big Board, saw its shares rise 7/8, to 10, on heavy volume of six million shares. The rise might have been partly prompted by the remarks of a Salomon Brothers analyst, who called Humana her No. 1 pick in the health-care industry.

HEADLINE: China Steps Up Spending To Keep U.S. Trade Status

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
China has been on an American shopping spree in recent months, ordering more than $1 billion of airplanes, cars, telecommunications and oil equipment, fertilizer and more.
Driving the deals has been a June 4 deadline by which President Clinton must decide whether to extend China's most-favored-nation status, which offers low tariffs and other trade privileges comparable to those of other United States trading partners. If China is denied the low tariffs it now enjoys, those deals would collapse, and the Chinese are determined to show the value of their market to the United States. 
 During his election campaign, President Clinton said he would not approve the extension without receiving Chinese assurances on human rights policies and arms sales. And in Washington in recent days the debate has focused on these issues.
But many American companies are vigorously lobbying the White House and Congress for an extension of China's trading privileges, pointing out that that billions of dollars in exports are at stake, as well as thousands of jobs.
Many business leaders say that using trade privileges to address human rights and arms proliferation will do little to persuade the Chinese to make changes. And some executives argue that selling to China can help the United States realize its policy goals.
"It has long been recognized that the pen is mightier than the sword," said Randall L. Tobias, vice chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. "The modern version of that is: the fax machine is mightier than the rifle. It is impossible for a society that has more open telecommunications to continue to be repressive."
 
 
Estimate of 150,000 Jobs
 Trade experts estimated that exports to China created about 150,000 jobs in the United States last year.
These are among the most recent negotiations between China and America:
*An $800 million agreement to buy 21 jetliners from Boeing, the largest foreign airplane order this year. China has agreed to buy or lease 215 airplanes worth a total of $9 billion in the next several years. Aerospace goods are the largest American export to China, accounting for $2.1 billion in sales last year.
*Orders for 4,600 vehicles each from General Motors, Ford Motor and Chrysler, worth a total of $160 million.
*The China National Petroleum Corporation ordered $200 million of oil drilling and exploration equipment from companies in Louisiana, Texas and Washington, and hired the Halliburton Company of Dallas to help with exploration and production.
*The Chinese Space and Aeronautics Administration is negotiating with Hughes Aerospace, a division of General Motors, for satellites that could cost up to $800 million.
*China's vice minister of trade is currently in the United States, shopping for wheat and phosphate fertilizers, while the president of China's National Cereals Corporation is on a buying mission, discussing grain deals with American companies and the Agriculture Department.
Clinton Administration trade officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, say they expect Mr. Clinton to set some conditions on renewal, which they hope the Chinese will accept. Congress would then have three months to override Mr. Clinton's decision.
But many American executives are nervous.
 
 
'People Will Lose Jobs'
 "President Clinton visited Seattle and promised that he was going to work hard to help keep aerospace jobs in America," said Lawrence W. Clarkson, vice president for planning and international development at Boeing. "Well, if he does not renew China's status or places unacceptable conditions on it, he will be doing the exact opposite of what he promised. We will lose orders and people will lose jobs."
A.T.& T. says it hopes to make billions of dollars through a joint agreement with the Chinese Government to provide the country with modern telecommunications. Company executives estimate that they can supply about half the 15 million telephone lines that China plans to install each year for the next several years. "We are talking about a business in China that is as big if not bigger than that in the United States," Mr. Tobias said.
"American companies are working the China trade issue more aggressively than ever before because the commercial stakes are so much higher this year," said Richard A. Brecher, director of business advisory services for the United States-China Business Council, a private association representing about 200 American businesses in China. "The pressure from the Chinese is not overt, but it's generally understood that all these big business deals will die overnight if their favorable status is revoked. Everything that we are selling, they can buy from someone else."
Also lobbying on behalf of China is Christopher Patten, Britain's Governor of Hong Kong, who met on Monday with President Clinton and other officials in Washington to press the case for continuing China's trade privileges.
 
Fastest-Growing Economy
 China has the world's fastest-growing economy, at 12 percent a year. While spending $7.47 billion in the United States last year, China exported more than three times as much -- $25.68 billion -- to the United States, mainly in consumer items like toys, clothing and footwear.
Orders from China last year, which were up 19 percent from 1991, were mainly for wheat, aircraft, fertilizer, cotton, wood, electric machinery, telephone and scientific equipment and chemicals.
Not every American company with Chinese connections takes issue with Mr. Clinton's views. Indeed, Levi Strauss & Company, the San Francisco-based apparel maker, announced Monday that it was ending most of its business in China, citing "the pervasive violation of human rights."
 
 
'I Have No Choice'
 But Levi Strauss is not a major player in China, buying less than 2 percent of its goods there. And whether other companies will follow Levi Strauss's lead is far from certain. Indeed, many other apparel companies, particularly those whose garments are made of silk or cashmere, simply cannot move their production out of China.
"I have no choice," said Gene Kuhl, president of Silk Club Inc., a New York company that contracts with Chinese factories for about 80 percent of the washable silk garments it makes. "At least 99 percent of the world's silk comes out of China. I'd have to become the Cotton Club to do what Levi's has done."
Another opponent of China is is the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which says that the Chinese export goods made with forced labor in its prisons. It also contends that the China imprisons union organizers and protest movement leaders.
"The factories and prisons are located right next to each other in many cases," said Burni Bond, director of research for the labor organization's international affairs division. "It's a philosophy of re-education through work, and it's simply not right." The Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 forbids the importation of goods made with prison labor.
But William B. Turner, chairman of IMC Fertilizer Group of Northbrook, Ill., said that ending China's favorable trade status might force his company to cut its staff by 20 percent, or 600 to 700 workers.
"With its concentration on agriculture, China is an essential market for us, and we can't afford to lose it," Mr. Turner said. "Having traveled there for many years, I have come to realize that it's better to work within their system rather than applying pressure from the outside."

HEADLINE: Grumman Says It Will Close Electronics Plant in Suffolk

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 6

 BODY:
In another sign of hard times for the military industry on Long Island, the Grumman Corporation announced today that it was closing a major electronics plant in Suffolk County. The company also said it was shutting plants in Texas and Maryland as part of a long-term plan to cut costs and consolidate operations.
Grumman officials said most of the 839 employees of the Long Island plant, in the hamlet of Great River on the South Shore, would be transferred to factories at the company's headquarters in Bethpage, L.I., by the time the shutdown is completed in mid-1995. The jobs of 424 workers in Webster, Tex., and Salisbury, Md., however, will be phased out when those factories close in 1994, Grumman officials said. 
 Susan Vassallo, a spokeswoman for Grumman, said that as the workers from Great River are moved to Bethpage, the company will determine how many will keep their jobs. "As the work is phased into the Bethpage facility, the company will identify duplication of function," she said. "At that time, there will be some layoffs."
The announcement of the closings comes at a time of retrenchment for much of the military industry, which has been forced to scale back as the Federal Government reduces arms spending, closes bases and cancels projects. On Long Island, the cuts have affected small military contractors as well as aircraft manufacturing giants like Grumman, whose work force on the Island is now 10,500, down from 33,700 in 1987.
Ms. Vassallo said the closing of the 96-acre Great River factory, which produces radar, intercom and weapon-testing systems for the Army, was part of the company's effort to consolidate operations and remain competitive. Grumman plans to sell the plants in Great River and Maryland, she said, adding that the plant in Texas is leased.
"This consolidation really is part of our ongoing efforts to cut costs," Ms. Vassallo said.
James L. Larocca, executive director of the Long Island Association, the Island's leading business organization, said he thought that the plant closing was necessary for Grumman's survival.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Hurt by Concerns Over Jobs Report for April

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended lower against other leading currencies yesterday, hurt by growing pessimism that today's employment report for April would reveal more unsettling weakness in the American economy.
Money brokers said there was some dollar buying early in the day. But later on, many traders reduced their dollar holdings as they became concerned that the Labor Department's employment report would show anemic job creation. Such weakness would put more pressure on the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates low, thereby making dollar-dominated investments less attractive. 
 "The dollar gave up some of the ghost at the end of the day," said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at the New York branch of the Bank Leumi Trust Company. "It was really a day when everybody sat back and said, 'Let's see what happens with unemployment.' "
 
 
A Sensitive Barometer
 The Labor Department's report is among the most sensitive barometers of the economy's stamina. The April numbers come against a background of new weakness that has emerged in American industrial output, productivity, retail sales and overall growth following a strong showing late last year.
The dollar even fell against the German mark, which had also been weakening because of growing economic problems in Germany.
Yesterday, for example, the German Government reported a rise in its April unemployment rate and a large drop in March industrial orders; the mark fell against European currencies as a result.
Many traders said that if the American unemployment number was particularly weak they expected to see the dollar fall sharply against the Japanese yen, which has become one of the strongest currencies in recent months.
After a five-day holiday in Japan, the dollar closed in Tokyo at 110.19 yen, down 0.91 yen from last Friday. In New York, the dollar fetched 110.025 yen late yesterday afternoon, down from 110.55 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5699, from $1.5665 late Wednesday. In New York, the pound bought $1.5805, up from $1.5650 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper Hits 5 1/2-Year Lows As Supplies Depress Market

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Copper prices fell to five-and-a-half-year lows yesterday, with the market depressed by increasing supplies of raw and scrap copper and weak demand from struggling economies around the world.
"It looks like copper is going to collapse," said Jim Steel, an analyst at Refco, a commodities brokerage firm. 
 On the Commodity Exchange in New York, copper for delivery in July dropped 3.4 cents, to 78.15 cents a pound, the lowest price since October 1987. Since January, the nearby contract in copper has shed 30 cents, or nearly a third of its value.
"A lot of traders are standing on the sidelines because they are afraid to buy and sell at these levels," said Andre DiMino, an analyst at R. F. Lafferty. "This is a very treacherous market."
 
China a Big Seller
China has become a big seller of copper, particularly on the dominant London Metal Exchange. Chinese stocks of copper are thought to be adequate for the next three to six months.
The demand for copper, a metal used heavily by industry, has dried up because of weakness in many nations' economies.
World output of copper continues to increase as mines step up productivity, and nowhere does demand appear to be growing, analysts said.
"U.S. demand, which accounts for 25 percent of world consumption, after appearing positive earlier in 1993, is now less than vigorous," Mr. Steel of Refco said.
In contrast, precious metals advanced, led by the resurgent gold market. Prices were lifted by the weak dollar, which has encouraged some investors to move to hard assets like gold. In addition, some investors reacted to the tensions in Bosnia by buying gold.
On the Comex, gold for June delivery rose $2.80, to $358.30 an ounce, and July silver gained 6 cents, to $4.375 an ounce. At the New York Mercantile Exchange, July platinum jumped $7.50, to $387.60 an ounce, while June palladium rose $4.05, to $120.75 an ounce.
Also on the New York Merc, energy futures prices ended mixed. June crude oil rose 1 cent, to $20.47 a barrel, after climbing earlier to $20.63. June heating oil firmed 0.18 cent at 55.91 cents a gallon and June unleaded gained 0.09 cent at 61.80 cents a gallon. June natural gas declined 5 cents, to $2.174 for a million British thermal units.

HEADLINE: No Change in Jobless Claims

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing first-time claims for jobless benefits was unchanged last week, the Government reported today.
The Labor Department said new applications for unemployment insurance held steady at 346,000. They had fallen by 10,000, from 356,000, during the week ended April 24. 
 Many economists had predicted that claims would change little last week. But the less volatile, four-week moving average of jobless claims fell. Analysts prefer the moving average because it more accurately reflects the labor situation.
The average dropped to 345,000 during the latest reporting period, down from 351,750 during the period ended April 24, and the lowest since the period ended Feb. 27, when it was 343,250.
The claims report was issued a day before the department was scheduled to release data on April employment. A consensus of economists called for the unemployment rate to remain at 7 percent for the third straight month, though nonfarm payrolls were expected to grow by 150,000.
Still, that pace of payroll growth would be less than half the monthly increases during previous recoveries. Payrolls had fallen by 22,000 in March.
The report also said 28,260 applications were filed under a Federal emergency unemployment program during the week ended April 24, down from 28,762 during the previous week.
Thirty-four states and territories reported decreases in regular claims during the week ended April 24, and 18 recorded increases. One reported no change.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Herbalife Cleanses Its Balance Sheet and Attracts New Interest

BYLINE: By Calvin Sims

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
HERBALIFE INTERNATIONAL INC., which nearly went bankrupt in the late 1980's after building a fervent following for its diet products and nutritional supplements, appears to have put the worst behind it.
The company has installed a new management team that has cleaned up its balance sheet, resolved its problems with regulators and charted a course for future growth that focuses mainly on international expansion. 
 As a result, Herbalife's sales are booming again, especially overseas, and earnings almost tripled last year. The company's stock closed yesterday at $11.875, up 12.5 cents, in Nasdaq trading. The 52-week low is $6.625 and the high for the year is $14.50. Herbalife has no debt and in January raised its dividend to 7 cents a share, from 4 cents.
"We are a much more mature company today than we were a few years ago," said Mallory Factor, a spokesman for Herbalife, which is based in Inglewood, Calif. "We now have to be cleaner than Caesar's wife on every aspect of what we do. Consumer confidence is riding on that."
Herbalife's problems began in the mid-1980's when many customers complained of diarrhea, nausea, vomiting and dizziness after using the herbal products, which promise to reduce weight and cleanse the body.
Federal and state regulatory agencies started investigations into Herbalife's product claims and sales tactics, and the resulting negative publicity caused sales to dive.
In 1986, Herbalife agreed to pay $850,000 to settle a suit filed by the California Attorney General's office that charged the company with making false medical claims and running an illegal pyramid-style marketing scheme. The company agreed to change the way it represents its weight-loss products and to insure that its distributors do not depend on recruiting sales personnel, rather than selling products, to make money.
Herbalife has introduced several new products, which analysts say are crucial to gaining market share in an industry that thrives on newness. It has also expanded its distribution network, and currently has about 50,000 distributors worldwide. Foreign sales now account for 80 percent of its revenues, up from 68 percent in 1991.
"As long as regulators don't bear down on them for their product claims or selling techniques, they should do very well," said Aaron Lehmann, president of the Fulton Group, a securities research firm based in Greenwich, Conn. "Absent that, this company is a very cheap stock."
Mr. Lehmann, one of the few analysts who follow Herbalife, estimates that the company could generate revenue of $650 million and earn about $1.40 a share this year. In the first quarter of 1993, Herbalife reported net income of $8.7 million, or 32 cents a share, compared with $3.8 million, or 14 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.
While Herbalife appears to have made a comeback, some analysts and nutritionists remain skeptical of the company's pills, powders and solutions. A number of product-liability lawsuits are working their way through the courts. Herbalife maintains that the suits have no merit and will have no effect on its bottom line.
In the 1980's, Herbalife sponsored cable television programs that featured testimonials. "In hindsight, some statements made on those cable programs probably should not have been made," Mr. Factor said. "Our products are very effective in helping people lose weight, and if you knock off 40 or 50 pounds that will help back pain or high-blood pressure. But we are very careful now about those kind of claims."
