HEADLINE: U.S. at Odds With Asia Bank

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MANILA, May 6

 BODY:
The United States rejected Wednesday any immediate increase in the capital base of the Asian Development Bank, and the bank said poor nations could suffer.
The bank's chief economist, Satish Jha, said without a capital increase, future lending would be cut, affecting Asia's poorest countries. 
 But the chief United States delegate, Jeffrey Shafer, said at the bank's annual meeting that the United States believed the bank should concentrate on being thrifty and living within its existing resources.
"More consideration of the scale of lending and the adequacy of current resources is needed before a decision on a capital increase can be taken," he told delegates from the 53 member countries.
Mr. Shafer's rejection left the United States, the biggest shareholder, largely alone in resisting calls for more capital.
The bank's Japanese president, Kimimasa Tarumizu, asked for the bank's capital base to be at least doubled from the present $23 billion. He said on Tuesday at the opening session of the three-day annual meeting the capital increase was critical.
Washington, which has fallen behind in its payments to the bank, does not want to be bound by past lending growth and is reviewing its policy toward the World Bank and regional institutions like the Asian bank, a member of the United States delegation said.
Mr. Shafer said Washington wanted to see more emphasis on quality in bank lending, noting that more and more of the bank's projects were failing.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber

 BODY:

Case of the Vanished Audience
Amid the raft of recent closings, the one surprise is "The Song of Jacob Zulu," which shuts down Sunday on the eve of the Tony nominations (it seems certain to garner at least one, for best score) after a run of just over a month.
The show, an anti-apartheid drama by Tug Yourgrau and featuring the a cappella singing group Ladysmith Black Mambazo, received mixed reviews, but attendance figures were quite respectable, hovering around 75 percent throughout the run. In addition, the producers said this week, the show seemed to have found the core black audience that it had particularly sought. 
 "We advertised heavily in the black press, on black radio stations and we had a lot of contact with the black churches," said Albert Poland, the production's general manager. And as a result, he said, "the audience was 50 percent African-American, very unusual for a Broadway show."
The problem seems to have been twofold. First, the discount ticket program that initially drew people to the show never spawned enough word of mouth to spur full-price sales. That, Mr. Poland said, was a function of the economy, explaining that for the audience the show had created, an atypical audience with limited discretionary income, theater tickets just weren't a high priority. So while the seats were three-quarters filled, the weekly receipts never rose much above $170,000, less than half of the potential gross and just under the show's break-even point.
Second, just at the time when the producers were expecting advance sales to take off, they died. "It turned in a day," Mr. Poland said. The day was Tuesday, April 20.
"That morning I was sitting on top of the world," Mr. Poland said. "I thought we were going to have our first profitable week. We already had a $120,000 advance for the week, and if the daily wraps had just kept pace with the previous week, we would've been over our break-even, which was about $190,000. But we ended that day $17,000 down from the previous Tuesday." For the rest of the week, he said, the comparative declines continued.
By that time, the production's reserve fund, initially $250,000, had been nearly depleted by the need for supplemental advertising, and when Mr. Poland and the show's producing entity, Steppenwolf Theater Company of Chicago, looked ahead only a couple of weeks, they envisioned not being able to pay their bills.
"We could've hung on for a week, but it would've been irresponsible," said Stephen Eich, Steppenwolf's managing director. Asked why the audience suddenly vanished, Mr. Eich, obviously perplexed and disappointed, said everybody had a theory.
"People say the World Trade Center," he said, referring to the real-life terrorist scare that coincided with the opening of the show, which deals, in some ways sympathetically, with a young terrorist. "People say the red-hot headlines from South Africa that never seem to cease." And the fact that "Tommy," which opened the week their business went south, is blowing everyone away?
"I just don't know," Mr. Eich said.
 
A Role by Any Other Name
 The Tony Awards administration committee met yesterday afternoon to make the final clarifications on the eligibility of shows and performers, One bone of contention was whether "Tommy" deserves consideration for best score. Most of the show's music dates, of course, from 1969, when the Who recorded the famous album, and the argument put forth yesterday by Arthur Rubin, producer of "Ain't Broadway Grand," was that the music was not written to be show music.
However, the committee ruled the score eligible after Michael David, one of the producers, introduced a copy of a 1968 magazine interview in which Pete Townshend, the composer, said that "Tommy," which was called a rock opera at the time, was written with the theater in mind.
Deciding not to create a special category to accommodate non-traditional shows on Broadway, the committee agreed that "Fool Moon," the clown duet starring Bill Irwin and David Shiner, would remain exactly where it was put at the last meeting, in the best-play category, denying a request by the show's producers that "Fool Moon" be considered for a special Tony. It was also decided that Lynn Redgrave's one-woman show, "Shakespeare for My Father," would be eligible for best play and Ms. Redgrave for best actress and best playwright.
The committee acted on the requests of several individual producers who were jockeying for advantages. Among the changes: Ron Leibman, who plays Roy Cohn in "Angels in America," was moved from the category of featured actor in a play to leading actor, where his chief competition (Stephen Rea, Liam Neeson, Robert Klein) is likely to be stiffer, but where it won't include other actors in the same show. And Anthony Crivello, who plays Valentin in "Kiss of the Spider Woman," was moved from leading actor in a musical to featured actor.
Harvey Sabinson, president of the League of American Theaters and Producers, who presided over the meeting, said the producers of "Kiss" requested the change even though Mr. Crivello is billed above the title because the show revolves around two main characters, Molina, played by Brent Carver, and Aurora, played by Chita Rivera. It's also true, however, that conventional wisdom has Mr. Carver vying for the award in a dead heat with Martin Short from "The Goodbye Girl," and that, in such a visible role, Mr. Crivello stands a better chance in the lesser category.
 
Footlights
 *The Rasputin of contemporary musicals, "Annie Warbucks," rises again. Headed now, as previously rumored, for Off Broadway, the show is to open at the Variety Arts Theater on Aug. 9. Ben Sprecher, Bill Miller and Dennis J. Grimaldi, the producers, said yesterday that the show would cost $1 million to stage. That's the same amount the original "Annie" cost on Broadway in 1977.
*Debra Monk, who appeared most recentlyin the ill-fated "Redwood Curtain," is taking advantage of her unemployment to help out the Circle Repertory Company, which co-produced "Redwood" on Broadway. From Tuesday through Sunday she'll play opposite Ron Rifkin in Jon Robin Baitz's play "Three Hotels," now at Circle Rep downtown, filling a scheduling gap between Christine Lahti's departure and Mercedes Ruehl's arrival.
*Bigger than Madonna! For the five-day period ending Tuesday, the original-cast album of "The Goodbye Girl" was the largest-selling recording at the Tower Records store near Lincoln Center in Manhattan; more than 300 copies were sold, pushing the new Sting album out of the top slot. "I was amazed by it myself," said Roger Ringheiser, the store employee who keeps track of such things. However, to cite the show's opening song (which is not on the album), "This Is as Good as It Gets": at Tower in Greenwich Village, over the same period, "The Goodbye Girl" finished 23d.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Theater Role for Parsons" -- Estelle Parsons, best known of late for her television role as Roseanne's mother, is to appear at La Mama E.T.C., beginning May 28, in "Extended Forecast," by the German playwright Franz Xaver Kroetz. Ms. Parsons, 65, who on May 18 is to be honored by the Retirement Research Foundation for her work on "Roseanne," plays a woman about to move to an old-age home.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;
Just Say Nah to Today's Mix of Parimutuel Taxes

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
One of the horse-racing advisers to the Governor said yesterday that the state should lower its taxes on bets as part of an overhaul of the parimutuel system "to revive the state's racing, wagering and breeding indutries."
The proposal was made in a report by Steven Crist, the racing writer, who was one of nine people named last year to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's Advisory Commission on Racing in the 21st Century. The commission is expected to send its recommendations to Cuomo early in June. It has already indicated that it favors some sort of merger of the New York Racing Association and the Off-Track Betting Corporation. 
 In a briefing at Belmont Park yesterday on the economics of betting in the state, Crist said that he was proposing reforms in four areas: a cut in the parimutuel tax, or takeout, on each bet; a new allocation of the money taken out of bets, both on and off the track, returning more to the bettor; a change in the formula for "breakage," or rounding off the money paid out in bets, and eliminating or refining the state's withholding of income taxes from high, winning bets.
"The only way to bring in more revenue to both government and racing," Crist said, "is to increase the parimutuel handle wagered by the public, whose bets provide every last nickel of funding for these industries."
His key proposal would lower the tax on bets in order to return more to the bettor, who would presumably promptly put it back into the system in new bets. When the parimutuel system began in New York in 1940, the takeout was 10 percent, with 90 percent returned to the bettor. The tax today ranges from 17 percent for straight bets to 25 percent for more exotic bets, and the state's six regional OTB corporations impose an additional surcharge of up to 6 percent on winning bets.
The money subtracted from each winning bet at the track is now split this way: 8.5 percent to the racing association, 4.5 percent to the state, 3.5 percent to purses.
"If you bet $100 on racing," Crist said, "you pay $18 as the cost. On a football game, you pay $4.50. I am suggesting a cut of 15 to 20 percent in the takeout on racing bets. If the state has to take a hit to save the industry, it will have to take it. But the state shouldn't take all the burden. In the long run, everybody should gain. Every time the takeout goes down, attendance and handle go up. It's that simple."
Gerard J. McKeon, president of the N.Y.R.A., who attended the briefing, said he agreed in principle, and added: "I don't see many alternatives."
 
Fly So Free Wins
 Tommy Valando's Fly So Free gave a stirring performance when he rocketed seven furlongs in 1:21 flat and won the feature race at Belmont yesterday by three and a quarter lengths over Magesterian.
The 1990 juvenile champion, now 5 years old, took charge at the head of the stretch, powered into the clear under a precise ride by Julie Krone and came within three-fifths of a second of the track record.
Scotty Schulhofer, who trains the chestnut son of Time for a Change, said later that the Metropolitan Mile on May 31 was next, and added: "He ran a powerful race. I'm not concerned about Alydeed or anybody else. This was meant to get him ready, and he's ready."
 
Rockamundo in the Preakness
 Rockamundo will try to beat the odds by running in the Preakness a week from tomorrow, less than two weeks after corrective surgery to repair a breathing problem. The colt, who won the Arkansas Derby at 108-1, ran 17th in the Kentucky Derby and then underwent minor surgery at Churchill Downs this week to correct a displaced soft palate.
"A horse can be back in training in three days," his trainer, Ben Glass Jr., said. "If everything looks good, he'll run in the Preakness."
 
Acorn at Belmont
 Next marquee event at Belmont: the Acorn, first race in the Triple Tiara series for fillies. It'll be run tomorrow, with Georgia Hoffman's Sky Beauty and Ogden Mills Phipps's Educated Risk heading a tight field of six. The distance is one mile, and the purse $150,000.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Messy Presidency

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
For weeks, some of President Clinton's closest advisers have been telling him that he has taken on too many problems. They warn him that he has to cut back, simplify.
If a handful of hard-line rogues among the Bosnian Serbs insist on suicide and bring on U.S. military action, the warnings obviously will take on urgency. Save your mind, energies and political capital for just a couple of the big ones, he will be told -- the budget and the intervention. 
 That is important, practical and plain-spoken advice. What should worry the country is that Mr. Clinton might take it.
The President's effort to streamline his staff and make it more efficient is no big thing. Every important executive should routinely do that.
But the advice to streamline and limit Mr. Clinton's own job -- there we cut to the meaning and role of the Presidency itself.
Some Clinton people have a distinct weakness for what psychologists call "Magic Think" -- I want it to be, so it is. They wanted the President to be able to concentrate only on economics. They wanted the rest of the world to fade into the background until summoned for photo ops. Therefore, they assumed the world and nation would so arrange their affairs.
The Presidency just does not work that way. No President can remove himself from what is important to the world or his countrymen -- and their continuing consequences.
In Bosnia, bombings would be the beginning for Mr. Clinton, not the end. Though the Bosnian Serbs may have brought it on their own heads, it will be Mr. Clinton's responsibility to prevent the war from spreading through the Balkans. No, that's not fair.
Bombing or peace, Mr. Clinton should be appointing people he trusts to figure out how Bosnia happened.
The West quickly backed Croatian and Slovenian declarations of independence. That made the Muslims' decision for an independent Bosnia inevitable. But neither Europe nor the U.S. figured out that Serbs, fearing they would be isolated in parts of their own country, might slaughter and rape their enemies to prevent it -- or what Western Europe would do about it other than wait for America.
In the next few years a dozen other secessionist movements may demand independence in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. What will we do? The President has to figure that one out now, not when the bombing decisions come around.
The U.N. -- will it forever be drumming up armies to protect shaky new countries? Or would it make more sense to insist that before membership is granted the U.N. should set conditions for stability and exercise trusteeship until they are met?
And while he is thinking about such things -- not after, while -- he should tell us what he intends to do about the really big one: the spread of nuclear and missile technology.
Right there on the front page with Bosnia is a story about China, the world's weapon supermarket, breaking its promise not to sell missile technologies to Pakistan. Here comes North Korea, moving into nuclear weaponry. Is there anybody in the White House who thinks Iran is not moving to the same goal? And how can any President clean such things off his plate?
Meanwhile another people cannot be wiped from the agenda even temporarily -- Americans. What makes the Presidential job worth the upkeep is that it is he who often should be telling Americans what ought to be on their minds, even if it is not.
For instance: Racially we are on the march backward. Should he go even another 100 days without saying, watch out America, black segregation is back, and back where it can hurt most -- the campus?
The fact that it is by African-American decision does not make it less dangerous for them and other Americans. For just one example of a country dividing itself by religion, color or clan, kindly see above under Bosnia.
Can the President keep virtually ignoring the one problem that runs up the highest costs for health care and crime and so deeply damages our own self-respect -- addiction to narcotics, tobacco and liquor? Are we going to do anything about it if the President acts barely interested?
Americans need a President precisely because the job is not simple and limited. It is big, adventuresome and wide-ranging but sometimes downright messy, just like his country. No marks for neatness.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Street-Vendor Vets Are Being Neglected

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There is no question that the streets of New York City must be rid of the illegal vendors and their merchandise. I, too, commend the Mayor for his initiatives ("Smart Steps on Peddling," editorial, April 20). However, at the time the New York State Legislature struck down the longstanding Chapter 687, displacing approximately 176 vendors who are veterans, it was with the understanding that the Fifth Avenue Association and the City of New York would live up to their promises to provide assistance and economic opportunities to them. 
 It has been nearly two years, and the streets are still cluttered with illegal vendors and merchandise. Unfortunately, while the Fifth Avenue Association lived up to its promise to raise $400,000 and has fully supported a number of initiatives, most have yet to be implemented.
I stand by my decision to support the repeal of this law and will continue to do so until all promises made are met.
 
ELIZABETH A. CONNELLY
Member of Assembly, 59th Dist., S.I.
Albany, April 27, 1993

HEADLINE: New York's Transit Fare Collection Lags

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your April 26 report ("A Fare Card for Transit Is Lagging") that all automated fare collection equipment for New York City buses will be delayed due to "the need to redesign, retest and retool a new fare box" is shocking. Such a system already operates in Washington, D.C. Moreover, I have recently spent two weeks in Copenhagen, where one can buy various types of transit tickets usable on buses and trains. These tickets are electronically programmed. The machines into which they are inserted automatically deduct the applicable fare. Why must the New York commuting public wait for such innovations when they already exist? 
 In a city so dependent on tourism and the revenue derived therefrom, it is surprising that New York City's bus system is not more "tourist friendly." Fare boxes now in use do not accept dollar bills as do those in other cities. Day after day, I see tourists frustrated because they must scrounge around for tokens or proper change.
Almost every recent article of yours concerning the transit system discusses the preservation of the present fare and the possibility of future increases. The M.T.A. ought to study the work and ideas of the late Nobel award-winning economist George Stigler about "elasticity of pricing" with respect to rapid transit fares. If the M.T.A. would provide civilized transit service to increase patronage, it would reduce the spiral of declining ridership and increasing fares.
 
E. MAGNUS OPPENHEIM
New York, April 27, 1993

HEADLINE: Clinton Unveils Financing Plan For Campaigns

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
Vowing to "change the way Washington works," President Clinton today proposed a bill that offers public subsidies for television commercials for Congressional candidates who limit their spending and seeks to reduce the influence of lobbyists and political action committees.
Under pressure from Congressional Democrats, who feared a campaign reform bill that would endanger their prospects for re-election, Mr. Clinton abandoned the pledge made in his Presidential campaign: to reduce to $1,000 from $5,000 the amount a political action committee can give to a candidate. 
 The bill proposed today keeps the $5,000 limit for House candidates and lowers the limit for Senate candidates to $2,500.
 
Sewing Up Loopholes
 But the bill calls for many new rules to tighten the campaign finance system, including eliminating the loopholes wealthy givers have used to evade contribution limits to Presidential candidates, funneling their money instead through political parties.
The bill would provide federally financed vouchers for television commercials and postage and printing for candidates who adhere to voluntary spending limits. White House officials estimated that candidates, receiving vouchers that match small donations they collect, would draw $75 million each year in public money.
The proposal would also forbid lobbyists from contributing to or raising money for anyone they have lobbied in the previous 12 months, a provision that some experts said raises Constitutional questions involving free speech.
 
No Change Until 1996
 The proposed legislation would not take effect until 1996, allowing all incumbent House members and one-third of the incumbent Senators to campaign in 1994 under the existing rules.
Today's announcement came after two months of haggling between the White House and other Democrats, particularly in the House, where members seek re-election every two years and do not want to make it too easy for challengers to knock them out of office.
Flanked by House and Senate Democratic leaders at the South Lawn of the White House, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that campaign finance was "a tough issue" and that "I favor a smaller PAC limit." But he said he believed the compromise represented "the most comprehensive reform of the political system in the history of this country."
Sounding less like the insider he has become and more like Ross Perot, who has made campaign reform a theme, Mr. Clinton declared, "This plan will change the way Washington works, the way campaigns are financed, the way that politics is played."
Indeed, the announcement brought a cascade of reaction from people who are immersed in the Washington political culture. Some lobbyists said the bill was too harsh; many Washington critics said it did not go far enough.
Sentiments on Capitol Hill will be best gauged next week, when the Senate is expected to take up the proposal. The House, whose leaders are more nervous about campaign finance legislation, is waiting for reaction from the Senate before it acts. Despite Republican opposition, prospects appear far brighter than last year, when President George Bush vetoed a campaign finance bill drafted by the Democrats that in some areas was weaker than the one proposed today.
 
Republicans Pounce
 There were no Republicans at today's announcement, and Republican leaders wasted no time in attacking the plan for not curbing political action committees more and for using public money.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader who had vowed to stage a filibuster against the bill even before it was introduced, said today: "Despite the friendly 'reform' label, it's nothing new or bold. It's a partisan package designed to protect the Democrat Congressional majority forever."
But Democrats who favor the proposal said they hoped the opponents would succumb to a public groundswell for improving the political system.
"There are cynics who will oppose it, who question our motivation," said Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, as Mr. Clinton stood nearby. "They cannot believe that incumbents would propose legislation to make election contests more fair. What the cynics ignore is the effect the current campaign finance system has on our system of Government. The American people no longer have confidence in the political process."
 
Anticipating Likely Objections
 Proponents said the biggest fight would be over the public financing. Anticipating the likely Republican objections, the President and Democratic leaders emphasized that the vouchers for broadcasting would not come from the general Treasury but would be financed by repealing the tax deductibility of lobbying expenses. Michael Waldman, the White House special assistant who headed the Administration team that worked on the proposal, said that provision would raise about $170 million a year.
To insure that the costs are covered, Mr. Waldman said, the bill also calls for raising the voluntary checkoff on tax returns for political campaigns to $5 from $1.
Fred Wertheimer, the president of Common Cause, a group that has lobbied for years to change the system, expressed concern that many specifics must still be worked out. Yet he praised Mr. Clinton, saying that he had "opened the door to fundamental change in the way our campaigns are financed."
Others who have pressed for changing the political system contended that the proposal's limits on spending and political action committees were not strict enough. They also said they were worried that big givers would pour even larger sums into the political parties' funds for building expenses, which are exempted from the proposal.
"In the 1992 election, the American public made a bold statement about gridlock and change in Washington," said Representative Mike Synar, an Oklahoma Democrat. "What the public got with this package does not meet their true test of reform."
Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who seized on campaign finance reform by refusing to accept donations of more than $100 when he ran for the Democratic Presidential nomination last year, said: "It's just another Washington hustle. It's not going to change the corrupting influence of money on national politics."
Reaction was just as intense from business leaders who argue that restricting political action committees will not solve the problem. Steven F. Stockmeyer, executive vice president of the National Association of Business Political Action Committees, said the bill would only help incumbents who "refuse to solicit PAC's but vigorously seek less accountable gifts from wealthy interested individuals."
David Wilhelm, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, who helped draft the provision that would limit the "soft money" big donors funnel to candidates through political parties, disputed the contention that donors would find a way to skirt those restrictions. The plan, he said, "ends the dependency on big money and special interests," adding that the Democratic Party "will suffer financial losses of more than 40 percent of our budget under the reforms proposed by the President."
White House officials were still drafting elements of the package on the eve of Mr. Clinton's announcement, and much is still unresolved.
For example, Mr. Clinton had pledged to prohibit bundling, the process by which one entity groups together contributions and gives them to a candidate in one bunch to demonstrate its clout. That provision came under heavy attack from Emily's List, a political action committee for female candidates, which argued that it should be exempted because it was not tied to a specific interest group.
The proposal today does not address the bundling issue because while the White House and Senate Democrats contended that groups like Emily's List should not get an exemption, House Democrats argued the other way.
"That's a hot issue up here," Mr. Clinton said, adding that "my own personal view is that the law should be the same for everyone." He said a compromise might be achieved in which Emily's List could have its contributors send identical envelopes to candidates.
The bill would also give the Federal Election Commission more authority to fine candidates who do not comply with election law. And it would require that broadcasters make commercial time available to candidates at the lowest rate available. The White House did not spell out how these provisions would work.
Another area where uncertainties remain is on restricting lobbyists. Initially, the White House intended to ban all political donations by lobbyists, but it diluted the proposal after warnings from lawyers that such a provision could be unconstitutional.
Daniel J. Swillinger, a lawyer here for Republican candidates, said he still believed the provision would violate the First Amendment rights to free speech and to petition the Government. "In reality," he said, "it would simply mean that a lobbyist would ask another corporate or association executive to make the contribution."
 
 
 
CAMPAIGN FINANCE: CLINTON'S PROPOSALS

 
Spending Limits
 
Proposed:
Voluntary spending limits on Congressional campaigns.
Senate limits would vary, from $1.2 million to $5.5 million for general elections, depending on the state's population. In the primaries, the limits would be 67 percent of the general election limit, up to $2.7 million.
House spending limits would be $600,000 in the two-year election period, but candidates could spend another 10 percent for fund-raising costs. In addition, the limits would be indexed for inflation from 1992. And candidates who have won a contested primary (margin of victory less than 20 percent) could spend another $150,000.
 
Current: There are no spending limits in Congressional campaigns.
 
Public financing
 
Proposed: House candidates who adhered to the spending limits would get vouchers to pay for television air time, postage and printing. In the House, candidates could get vouchers amounting to up to one-third of their spending limit, on a dollar-for-dollar matching basis against donations they receive of $200 or less. In the Senate, candidates could receive vouchers worth up to one-quarter of their spending limit.
 
Current: Congressional candidates get no public funds in any form.
 
Soft money
 
Proposed: Elimination of, the big, unrestricted contributions that wealthy donors, corporations and unions funnel through the political parties to help Presidential campaigns. The parties would still be able to accept large donations for funds that pay for their building or non-administrative office costs.
 
Current: Wealthy donors can know back candidates indirectly with large donations to parties whose is largely unrestricted.
 
Individual donations:
 
Proposed: Individuals would be allowed to give Federal candidates $60,000 per two-year election period. Within that limit, individuals each year can donate up to $25,000 to candidates, $20,000 to the national party committees and another $20,000 for grass roots political activities in the states.
 
Current: Individuals can give $30,000 each year to Federal candidates.
 
Political Action Committees
 
Proposed: House candidates could receive no more than one-third of their donations from political action committees. Senate candidates would collect up to 2O percent of their money from PAC's.
 The limit on how much a PAC can donate to a Presidential candidate would be lowered to $1,000 from $5,000.

Current: No caps on the amount candidates can receive from PAC's.
 
Lobbyists
 
Proposed: Registered lobbyists, or those whose activities must be reported under the the lobbying bill that passed the Senate Thursday, may not contribute or solicit money for any member of Congress or the President or Vice President if they have lobbied the lawmaker or, in cases involving the President and Vice President, the Executive Branch, in the previous 12 months.
 
Current: no special restrictions on lobbyists giving money.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Unemployment Surges To Worst Among Industrial States

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Dimming hopes for a brighter, more prosperous economy in the New York region, unemployment jumped sharply in New Jersey and rose in New York City last month, according to the Federal Government.
Joblessness in New Jersey rose to the worst among the nation's largest industrial states, according to the report, which was released yesterday. The state's unemployment rate climbed to 9.1 percent in April from 8.3 percent in March. That deterioration followed two months of mounting unemployment since January, when 7.4 percent of the state's job seekers were out of work, the Government said. 
 According to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, unemployment in April rose to 9.8 percent in New York City from 9.6 percent in March. It had dropped notably during the first three months of the year, inspiring some hopes for a steady recovery.
 
From Robust to Ravaged
 Nationwide, the unemployment rate was 7 percent for the third straight month. [Page 37.] That was also the rate for New York State and the March rate for Connecticut, whose April figures have not been released.
But experts said the worst news for the region was in New Jersey, a state that had been one of the most robust during the 1980's. It is now being buffeted by deep and stubborn economic troubles that show few signs of abating.
"The recession is not over for New Jersey," said Joseph J. Seneca, a professor of economics at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. In his view, the state's severe and continuing unemployment is undermining consumer spending, home sales and other sources of economic revival.
Other economic analysts say New Jersey is being hurt by an array of problems equalled in few other states. It is amply endowed with banks, insurance companies and other financial service concerns that expanded rapidly in the 1980's, but have retrenched even faster over the last four years, shedding thousands of workers.
More than most other Northeast states, New Jersey also retains a huge base of manufacturers, including chemical and pharmaceutical companies, auto plants and hundreds of metal bending factories, most of which are being badly hurt by the recession.
According to yesterday's report, New Jersey manufacturers have cut 200,000 jobs since 1989, a worse cut than in any other part of the state's economy and two-thirds of the total job loss since 1989.
Yet another drag on the state, the experts said, is its close proximity and economic lifeline to New York City, where more than 250,000 New Jersey residents commute to work.
"We are seeing a serious spillover of New York City's problems into New Jersey," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the New York regional commissioner of the statistics bureau.
Because of the surge in unemployment in New Jersey, and the slight increase in New York City, he said: "the recovery, at least in jobs, is not in sight."
"We are having great difficulty pulling ourselves out of a quagmire," he added.
In New York State, unemployment dropped in April, to 7 percent from 7.3 percent in March. The improvement reflected scattered areas of economic vigor largely confined to the cities and counties outside New York City.
 
Worst for Big States
 As is routine, the data released yesterday gave separate figures for only 11 of the largest industrialized states, with the release of unemployment rates for the other states to lag by two weeks. Connecticut, not included in the report yesterday, has sustained rates of unemployment roughly the same as the nation, despite deep cuts by the state's defense contractors and other severe problems.
Eclipsing California, New Jersey now has the worst unemployment rate among the largest and most populous states.
"There is just no engine to drive us out of this," said Mr. Seneca. Unlike many other states, which expect construction, home sales, manufacturing and other pockets of economic strength to pull them out of recession, "we have no players," he said.
With its slight increase in April to an unemployment rate of 9.8 percent, New York City and its workers may take some solace in the fact that the rate had exceeded 13 percent in January and was over 11 percent during most of the prior six months.
 
Rate Can Be Misleading
 Experts say the unemployment rate, although the most widely used gauge of employment, is sometimes misleading because it does not fully account for people who have stopped looking for jobs. Nor does it account for the degree to which the economy is creating more jobs but at a rate too slow for a growing work force.
But by all measures, the data released yesterday were a grim portrait of employment in New Jersey.
It said the number of people employed in the state had dropped steadily each month since January, with a decline of 64,000, to 3.6 million in April. During the same four months, the number of unemployed workers rose by 68,000, to 358,000 in April.
In contrast, the number of employed people in New York City has increased slightly since January, with a gain of 37,000, to 2.9 million in April. The number of unemployed workers in the city fell sharply since January to 317,000 in April, a drop of 30,000, the report said.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
UNITY WITH EUROPE IS SEEN BY CLINTON ON PLAN FOR BOSNIA

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
Despite the apparent lack of progress in a week of diplomatic consultations, President Clinton said today that he expected to produce "a common approach" with Europe soon on a strategy to bring the Bosnian Serbs to the peace table.
"There's still some disagreement around the edges about what the overall specific tactical steps should be," Mr. Clinton told reporters after a meeting at the White House with representatives of the European Community. "But I think there's a lot more agreement than you think, and I think in the next few days we'll see a common approach emerging." 
 The President declined to detail the emerging consensus between Washington and its allies. Administration officials said Mr. Clinton might have been a bit more optimistic than was justified by the results of Secretary of State Warren Christopher's consultations with the Western European allies and the Russians during the last week.
 
Persuading Moscow and London
 Nevertheless, one senior official said, while "not everybody is with us yet, there is at least a sense of movement, especially by the British and the Russians, toward where we want to go" -- which is a lifting of the international arms embargo on the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government, perhaps combined with air strikes against the Bosnian Serbs.
Douglas Hogg, the Deputy Foreign Minister of Britain, said in an interview with the BBC on Thursday that while Britain's objections to lifting the arms embargo "have not been diminished," London is nevertheless anxious to maintain a "united front" with the allies. He also said Britain could see "more merits" in air strikes, without lifting the arms embargo.
The Administration is discussing this as a compromise option -- bombing the Serbs for several days to see if that alone is enough to get them to endorse the so-called Vance-Owen peace plan, without taking the potentially escalatory step of lifting the embargo.
 
Christopher to Brief Clinton
 Mr. Clinton has scheduled a meeting at the White House on Saturday with Mr. Christopher and his top national security aides, to hear from Mr. Christopher about exactly where the allies stand, what type of military strategy might be forged from their disparate positions and how then to go about selling it at home and abroad.
"We are the only ones with a strategy, and everyone is looking to us to lead in a policy sense," a senior Administration official said. "That doesn't mean they will follow everything we suggest, but no one else is doing it and there is a strong desire out there for us to put something together."
Mr. Clinton's struggle to come up with an effective policy on Bosnia comes at a time when public opinion polls indicate that Americans' approval of the way he is handling economic and foreign policy issues has dropped. Ross Perot harshly criticized President Clinton in an interview to be published on Sunday in U.S. News & World Report, suggesting that the President might "get a little war going" in Bosnia to divert attention from broken promises at home. White House officials dismissed such a suggestion as nonsense.
But for the first time, the President began to make the public case for lifting the arms embargo on the Muslims, something Mr. Christopher has been trying to sell to the European allies for the past week.
Mr. Clinton said the imposition of the arms embargo on Bosnia "by the United Nations before actually this country was even created and recognized had the unintended consequence of giving the Serbs an insurmountable military advantage, which they have pressed with ruthless efficiency."
Lifting the embargo now, he said, is "certainly one of the options that we have urged that be considered, and I think it's certainly one of the options that's still on the table. I think we've got to keep the heat on."
 
Belgrade's Embargo
 Another option under discussion, first proposed by the Russians, is to try to build on the announcement by the Presidents of Serbia and the Yugoslav federation of an embargo on all trade with the Bosnian Serbs, except for food and medicine. The announcement came after the self-styled Bosnian Serb parliament defied their warnings and rejected the Vance-Owen plan.
If carried out, a cutoff of shipments of oil and weapons from Serbia to Bosnia would inevitably deplete the Bosnian Serbs' reserves. One idea now being floated inside the Administration is to have the United Nations endorse that cutoff and to put observers on the Serbia-Bosnia border. But this option is not likely to be pursued, American officials say, because United Nations observers on the Bosnian border would be exposed to great danger.
American officials said there would have to be a five-step process before any military action can be taken: first the Administration decides what it wants to do, then it consults Congress, then another attempt is made to sell it to the allies, then approval is sought from the United Nations, while Mr. Clinton would make the case to the American people.
 
10-14 Days for Military Action
 The general sense among American officials is that it would probably take 10 days to two weeks before any military action could be organized, and there is no indication of recent deployments of American planes, troops or ships. The top item on Mr. Clinton's agenda today was the announcement of his campaign-finance reform program.
American officials said they hoped that "some action" could be taken before the May 15-16 referendum that was called by the Bosnian Serb parliament on whether to accept the peace plan.
As he left Rome today, Mr. Christopher said "some military action" could be taken immediately and justified under existing United Nations resolutions on Bosnia, like Security Council Resolution 770, which authorizes all necessary means to provide relief aid. However, for "greater military action we would much more likely require the explicit authorization of the United Nations," Mr. Christopher said.
Should air strikes be mounted against Bosnian Serb targets, Mr. Clinton said he "would have a very specific, clearly defined strategy to pursue and very clear tactical objectives."
 
Falling Grade on Foreign Policy
 How the American public would receive all this is unclear. In the latest CBS News Poll, less than half the public approved of the way Mr. Clinton was handling foreign policy.
In the nationwide telephone poll of 1,233 adults, which was conducted May 4-6 and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points, 45 percent of respondents said they approved of Mr. Clinton's foreign policy record, and 35 percent disapproved. In a New York Times/CBS News poll taken in late March, 53 percent approved and 24 percent disapproved.
Public opinion of Mr. Clinton's economic policies has also declined. In the latest CBS News Poll, 38 percent of respondents said they approved and 50 percent disapproved of the way Mr. Clinton was handling the economy. In the March poll, 47 percent approved of his handling of the economy and 37 percent disapproved.
His overall job approval rating declined to 49 percent in the latest poll, down from 55 percent in March.
Asked for his reaction, Mr. Clinton said, "The only thing that matters is the polls that come around on election day."
 
 
 
THE ADMINISTRATION ON BOSNIA
 "If the Serbs persist in violating the terms of the current cease-fire agreement, the United States should take the lead in seeking U.N. Security Council authorization for air strikes against those who are attacking the relief effort. Air and naval forces adequate to carry out these operations should be visibly in position."
 Gov. Clinton - July 26, 1992
 
"I think we should stiffen the embargo on the Belgrade government, and I think we have to consider whether or nor we should lift the arms embargo now on the Bosnians, since they are in no way in a fair fight with a heavily armed opponent bent on 'ethnic cleansing.' We can't get involved in the quagmire, but we must do what we can."
 Gov. Clinton - Oct. 11, 1992
 
"We found, when we consulted with our allies, that if we would try to lift the arms embargo, they would probably abandon their humanitarian efforts. And we have to make a calculus there as to what is most helpful in that situation."
 Secretary Christopher - Feb. 28, 1993
 
""The hatred between all three groups -- the Bosnians and the Serbs and the Croatians -- is almost unbelievable. It's almost terrifying, and it's centuries old. That really is a problem from hell. And I think that the United States is doing all we can to try to deal with that problem."
 Secretary Christopher - March 28, 1993
 
"If you take action, if the united States takes action, we must have a clearly-defined objective that can be met. We must be able to understand it and its limitations must be clear. The United States is not, should not, become involved as a partisan in a war."
 President Clinton - April 23, 1993 News Conference:
 
"The time has come for the international community to unite and to act quickly and decisively. America has made its position clear and is ready to do its part, but Europe must be willing to act with us."
 President Clinton, on Thursday

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
President Clinton's health-care plan will cover the cost of treating people injured on the job or in automobile accidents, merging workers' compensation and the medical portion of auto insurance with standard health insurance in one big system, Hillary Rodham Clinton said. [Page 1.]
The unemployment rate remained stuck at 7 percent in April for the third consecutive month. Businesses added 119,000 jobs to their payrolls, but the total number of jobs remained a million shy of the pre-recession peak. [37.] New Jersey's unemployment jumped to 9.1 percent, the highest among industrial states. The rate also rose in New York City, but fell in New York State. [1.] 
 Companies have stopped giving job references because of legal threats from disgruntled employees. [37.]
 
 Companies
Five of the largest military and aerospace contractors are competing to build rail cars for Los Angeles's new mass transit system. Public officials say it is the first serious effort by the declining weapons industry to steer toward commercial work. [37.]
Most major airlines matched Northwest's summer fare cuts. But American refused to give details until it advertises. [37.]
Corning's chairman was in stable condition after surgery for leg injuries suffered when he was struck by a car. [39.]
Chevron agreed to operate an idle petroleum refinery in El Paso recently bought by the lenders to its bankrupt owner. [39.]
Nutri-System agreed to be managed by Heico Acquisitions while the two negotiate a purchase of assets. [39.]
Carolco Pictures reported a smaller annual loss but said it might have to close if its reorganization plan is rejected. [48.]
Fleet Securities was removed as a New York City bond underwriter because it was recommended by City Comptroller Holtzman, whose campaign owed Fleet Bank $255,000. [23.]
 
International
Canadian softwood lumber exports to the U.S. should not be subjected to countervailing duties, a five-member binational panel of the Free Trade Agreement ruled. [37.]
The Irish financial market was stunned by a scandal involving the country's largest brokerage firm, which admitted to buying a larger stake in a Government food company than allowed. [39.]
Polly Peck's chairman, who fled Britain to avoid prosecution on charges of stealing millions from the company, asserted that he went to northern Cyprus because he could not get a fair trial. [39.]
China's privatization of real estate on a huge scale has become one of county's hottest and craziest new businesses. [3.]
 
Markets
Stocks briefly broke out of the narrow trading range of recent sessions. The Dow average lost 4.71 points. [38.]
Treasury bonds declined, failing to find direction from the April employment report. Short-term securities were mixed. [46.]
The dollar ended higher and gold slipped in New York after rising overseas. [45.] Soybeans jumped to a 10-month high. [45.]
 
Your Money
Depositors who buy stock in savings institutions that convert from mutual ownership usually earn big profits. [34.]
Even those in charge of whipping up excitement for gold are telling investors to calm down over the metal's potential. [34.]
The Government's shift to borrowing for shorter periods is likely to make safe investments more appealing. [34.]
People contemplating personal bankruptcy are advised to have lawyers because the proceedings are not easy to navigate. [35.]

HEADLINE: Dow Ends 4.71 Lower But Is Higher for Week

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The stock market, still stymied by a torpid economy, yesterday briefly broke out of the narrow trading range it has hugged for the previous four sessions.
The market fell in the early afternoon before recovering somewhat to close with modest losses. 
 Most major indexes were down slightly, with the exception of the Nasdaq composite index, which was up moderately.
Investors seemed hesitant to trade, reacting mainly to short-term news, like the latest economic figures or movements in bond prices.
 
Jobs Data Have Little Impact
 Early yesterday, the Labor Department reported that the nation's unemployment rate remained at 7 percent in April, a figure most analysts had expected.
Stock prices showed little reaction to the employment report. But stocks followed bond prices down in the early afternoon, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling as much as 19 points. The Dow closed down 4.71 points, to 3,437.19. For the week, the Dow gained 9.64 points.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 0.95 point, to 442.31, while the New York Stock Exchange's composite index lost 0.54 point, to 244.68. Big Board volume totaled 223.6 million shares, compared with Thursday's volume of 255.5 million shares. Losing stocks outnumbered winners, 981 to 858.
Among other indicators, the Nasdaq composite index closed up 1.40, to 681.44. But the American Stock Exchange market value index closed down for the first time in four sessions with a decline of 0.89, to 426.06.
The three most active stocks had almost identical trading volumes but differing degrees of price movement. Royal Dutch Petroleum, the multinational oil company, was the most active stock. It was down 3/8, to 89 7/8, on news that it planned to advance development of some North Sea oil projects.
Philip Morris, the tobacco company and the second-most-active stock, was up 1 7/8, to 51, on reports that its chief rival, RJR Nabisco, was retreating from a cigarette price war. But RJR, up 1/8, to 5 3/4, denied that it was retreating.
Cisco Systems, a maker of computer networking equipment and the third-most-active stock, was up 3 1/2, to 48 3/4, on higher first-quarter earnings. All three stocks had volume of around 6.3 million shares.
 
Gold Prices Fall
 Gold, considered a haven in times of international crisis, continued to drop, even though President Clinton sought to convince European allies yesterday of the need for more insistent intervention in Bosnia. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery declined 70 cents, to $356.70 an ounce.
Most gold stocks also declined modestly. Newmont Mining, which sold a large stake in itself to the financier George Soros, lost 7/8, to 49.
The Dow was dragged down by Allied Signal, Exxon and J. P. Morgan. Allied was down 1 3/8, to 62 7/8,; Exxon 1/2, to 64 1/8, and Morgan 1, to 66 5/8 -- all on no discernible news. The Dow was lifted somewhat by Philip Morris.
Stocks rose in Tokyo yesterday. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 189.33 points at 20,811.36.

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Flat For April

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The nation's unemployment rate remained stuck at 7 percent in April for the third consecutive month, the Government said yesterday. The report provided new evidence that the economic expansion is still sluggish and that the job market is recovering at a painfully slow pace.
Indeed, the job market deteriorated in some states. In New Jersey, the jobless rate jumped from 8.3 percent in March to 9.1 percent -- higher than that of California or any other large state. 
 Unemployment edged up in two other large states, Michigan and Massachusetts, as well. In New York, however, unemployment slipped to 7 percent, the lowest level in two years, from 7.3 percent.
 
 
119,000 New Jobs
 Across the nation, businesses added a modest 119,000 jobs to their payrolls last month -- about the same pace, on average, as during the last seven months -- after shedding 9,000 in March. Employees worked more hours as well, a sign of gradual improvement in the job market.
Still, the total number of jobs in the economy remains more than a million shy of the pre-recession peak of 110 million. The recent job gains have merely kept up with population growth, too anemic to pull discouraged workers back into the work force or reduce the number of part-time workers who want full-time jobs. Last month, 8.9 million Americans were out of work, the same as in the previous two months.
"Businesses are hesitating to make commitments to permanent employees because of all the uncertainties in the economic and political outlook," said Mitchell S. Fromstein, chief executive of Manpower Inc., the nation's largest temporary help concern. "From what we see, this situation isn't likely to change substantially in the next several months."
 
'Bad News' for Clinton
 While the Labor Department report eased fears that the economy was slipping back into recession, the absence of signs of more robust job growth keeps pressure on the Clinton Administration to make good on its campaign promise to create jobs.
 "It's bad news for the White House," said Ted Van Dyck, a longtime adviser to the Democrats. "President Clinton is exactly in the same position that George Bush was a year ago: that is, with a flat current economy, for which he's blamed, but pointing to improvement in months ahead, for which he can't yet take credit."
The Administration's top economist, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, who heads the President's Council of Economic Advisers, called the unemployment report "neutral to positive."
"We've created more jobs between the end of December and the end of April -- 561,000 -- than was created in the previous 20 months," she said, adding that she did not expect job growth to pick up enough to bring the jobless rate down in the next quarter.
The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, blamed the President's budget proposals for "chilling effects" on job creation.
"If President Clinton wants to do something dramatic about unemployment," Mr. Dole said in a statement, "he should make a major policy speech announcing that he's junking his massive tax-and-spend agenda."
The sprawling service sector, which employs four out of five workers, created 198,000 jobs last month. Expansion came in business services (about a third of business service employment consists of temporary workers), health care, entertainment and financial services.
 
 
Fewer Government Jobs
 But Civil Service jobs shrank, bringing the decline in Federal Government jobs to 60,000 for the year. And construction jobs -- which were hit hard by blizzards and floods in March -- dropped another 10,000 as April rains delayed many projects.
Worse, factories shed 65,000 workers in April after a loss of 24,000 in March. The widespread decline more or less wiped out gains last fall and winter. The transportation equipment, processed food, lumber and clothing sectors were hit hardest.
"The 65,000 jobs lost in manufacturing reflects further downsizing due to weak first-quarter profits, sluggish exports, and fear of higher taxes and health-care costs," said Jerry Jasinowksi, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. With uncertainty about how the Clinton economic program will affect business costs, he said, a common refrain among manufacturers has become, "I'm not cutting back on capital spending, but I'm sure as heck not going to hire anyone."
There were a couple of bright spots that hinted that the job losses will not be repeated next month. The number of factory hours worked rebounded from a sharp drop in March that was probably a result of bad weather, and overtime reached a new high. Indeed, despite the drop in the number of jobs, factory employees worked more total hours in April than in March.
 
 
Effect of Automation
 But the reluctance to add new hands in manufacturing likely runs deeper than caution over the foot-dragging expansion and fears about the Clinton Administration's economic program.
Take the case of the Western lumber business, which accounted for some of April's job losses.
"We've bought tens of millions of dollars of automated state-of-the-art sawmill technology in the last 18 months," said John Purcell, a vice president of the Weyerhaeuser Company who is in charge of its Western lumber business, explaining how the industry was responding to a shrinking supply of logs from Federal lands. "The equipment gets more lumber out of each log, but the byproduct is that automating the process requires fewer workers."
Two years ago, he said, Weyerhaeuser had nine Western mills, with 200 or 250 workers each, that turned out 1.1 billion feet of lumber. The company can now produce 1.1 billion feet with seven mills.

HEADLINE: Long-Term Treasury Issues Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Treasury market got little help yesterday in its search for direction from the April employment report.
The monthly figures, which showed the jobless rate at 7 percent for a third consecutive month, failed to change the market's perception of a sluggish but growing economy. Instead, prices of long-term securities declined modestly on worries that the Treasury's refunding auction next week might saturate the market for bonds and notes. 
 The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond fell 18/32 of a point, or $5.63 for each $1,000 in face amount. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.84 percent, from 6.80 on Thursday.
 
 
Short-Term Prices Mixed
 Prices of short-term securities were mixed, which analysts said was because of traders who sold longer-term bonds to buy shorter maturities before the Treasury auction.
The Treasury plans to sell $16 billion of 3-year notes on Tuesday, $10.75 billion of 10-year notes on Wednesday and $8.25 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday.
In addition, traders were buying 10-year notes and selling 7-year notes yesterday in response to the Treasury's announcement on Wednesday that it would overhaul its debt management, in part by shifting some longer-term borrowing to shorter terms and by eliminating seven-year notes. Traders dumped the notes yesterday.
At first glance, the unemployment news seemed positive for the bond market, which tends to rise as the economy slows down because of the increased likelihood that the Federal Reserve will ease interest rates. Lower rates tend to raise the value of existing securities.
 But other figures in the report seemed positive for the economy. For example, factory overtime hours rose, pushing weekly overtime to a 25-year high. This is often viewed as a prelude to more hiring.
None of the trends in the latest employment survey would compel the Fed to change its wait-and-see policy on interest rates, said Daniel Seto, an economist for Nikko Securities Company International.
Dana Johnson, head of market analysis for First Chicago Capital Markets in Chicago, said: "I would say there was almost no reaction. It was a really bland report, very mixed."
The 30-year bond fell more sharply than other bonds amid political and economic uncertainties, including the prospects for the President's economic stimulus package and the possibility of United States involvement in Bosnia.
In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities rose 1/32 point, while intermediate maturities were unchanged to 6/32 point lower, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a face value of $1,000.
 
 
Bond Index Falls
 The Lehman Brothers' daily Treasury bond index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 1.60, to 1,300.71.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 2.92 percent as the discount rose 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 2.87 percent. Yields on six-month bills remained at 3.04 percent as the discount held at 2.96 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 3.21 percent; the discount rate edged up a basis point to 3.10 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 101 1/2, down 1/8 from late Thursday. The average yield to maturity rose to 5.85 percent from 5.84 percent.
